column2: Arthur B. Bisguier, former United States chess champion who recently returned from Bogota, where he was a prizewinner in the international tournament, made a good start last night in defense of the Manhattan Chess Club title.
A man held up a West Side tavern with an unloaded revolver early yesterday morning and was shot and killed by a policeman who was in the place.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -Three Eisenhower generations attended church services together this morning. President Eisenhower, his son, Maj. John S. Eisenhower, and two grandchildren, David, 9 years old, and Barbara Anne, 8, walked up the steps of the National Presbyterian Church about 9 o'clock.

The film version of the Rodgers - Hammerstein musical, "South Pacific," will be the first attraction at the United States National Theatre at the Brussels World's Fair, Howard S. Cullman, United States Commissioner General to the Fair, announced yesterday.

"I used to be a social butterfly" says Adelaide Milton de Groot, who is 82 years old, "but then I inherited money and went to work." A famous art collector, she was once an established painter in her own right on Paris' Left Bank.
ALBANY, March 9 -- A revised version of the Tweed court reform program is to be submitted to the Legislature tomorrow or Tuesday.

Prices of cotton futures moved irregularly last week, finishing at slightly higher levels. At the close of trading on Friday, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 2 to 18 points (10 cents to 90 cents a bale) higher than a week earlier.
A driverless car rolled down 174th Street, plunged through a five-foot-high picket fence and landed on the New York Central - Park Avenue tracks yesterday.

LAHTI, FINLAND, March 9 (AP)- Finland's Johani Kaerkinen and Ensio Hyytiae took the first two places in the special jump in the world Nordic ski competition today and gave Finland the unofficial team championship

TWO composers who profess the twelve-tone faith provided the music for a concert at the New School yesterday afternoon. Ben Weber an American, and Ernst Krenek, who now lives in this country, was born in Vienna, and though both employ serial technique, they inhabit instinctively different worlds.
North Korea still has not solved the problem of feeding, clothing and housing its people, but it will give priority to developing heavy industry, the Pyongyang radio has announced.
Broadway's National Theatre, which has been dark since the closing of "Winesburg, Ohio," on Feb. 15, is now available for bookings of new productions.
PARIS, March 9 -- Government experts are noting that measures taken to bring a measure of austerity to France have not entirely succeeded.

LIMA, Peru, March 9 (UP) -- In a duel with cavalry sabers Interior Minister Jorge Fernandez Stoll slashed and seriously wounded today a firebrand Senator who accused him of cowardice. Both spurned the traditional handshake and they left the field enemies.

Twelve performers collaborated late yesterday afternoon in a program of contemporary music at Carnegie Recital Hall. The program, which was poorly arranged, consisted for the most part of feebly eclectic pieces for one or two instruments.

Negroes and other minority groups in this state are confronted by sixteen major obstacles in their climb toward economic equality, the chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination reported to Governor Harriman yesterday.
A sunny, blue sky greeted the International Flower Show here yesterday. All afternoon a solid line of visitors moved inside the Coliseum to view the colorful gardens and exhibits.
Harvard University won the invitation intercollegiate court tennis tournament for the James H. Van Alen Bowl for the fourth successive year yesterday.

How far ahead will the next upturn in general business activity be known to economists employing advanced statistical techniques, a large array of information and the latest electronic computing machines?
WASHINGTON, March 9 -The Defense Department reorganization plan is in the final stage of preparation and may go to the White House in a week or ten days.

ALBANY, March 9 -- Republican leaders of the Legislature have flagged down temporarily e bill that would raise the salary of the Superintendent of Schools in New York City by 5,000 a year. The position now ays $32,500.
THE late Georges Rouault is represented at Galerie Herve, 611 Madison Avenue, with paintings in his familiar Luminous style.
BONN, Germany, March 9 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer is confident the Soviet Government has not spoken its last word in refusing to discuss German reunification at the next summit conference.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, March 10 (AP) -- Communist North Korea agreed today to return a United States Air Force pilot whose Sabrejet was shot down over the demilitarized truce zone last Thursday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -- If a budding trend in television film production continues, some programs next season may be out of this world.
A Grand Canyon of the Antarctic has been explored in the hinterlands west of McMurdo Sound.

"MRS. McTHING," Mary Chase's comic fastasy on life among the very rich, the underworld, sprites and witches, enjoyed both critical acclaim and sturdy boxoffice patronage upon its Broadway presentation in 1952.

Since we are at it again -- namely, at hiking prices, in this case postal rates -- may I draw attention to a strange inconsistency of attitudes? At least since sputnik we seemed to have adopted a more favorable attitude toward those whose business -or devotion -- it is to search for truth; we even realize that promoting such hitherto suspect activity might be in the interest of national security.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, March 9 (AP) -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic charged today that "imperialist" powers and Israel "want to take Jordan, Lebanon and parts of Syria and Iraq."
The future of Antarctica lies in the spirit of cooperation engendered by the International Geophysical Year, high school panelists on the New York Times Youth Forum said yesterday.
A Roman Catholic editor said yesterday that he hoped the unity movement among Protestant churches would be "so successful" that it would bring them into the Vatican fold.

Detroit's Red Wings maintained a pace that was just too fast for the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The visitors scored first, permitted themselves to be tied in the final period, but then struck back strong enough to win by 4 to 2.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has arranged a transAtlantic radio round-table discussion that will offer an exchange of views among Adlai E. Stevenson, Pierre MendesFrance and Hugh Gaitskell. It will be broadcast Wednesday from 10:05 to 11 P. M.
DURING the recent debates on the importance of science in school curriculums, home economics courses were called a "frill" that might be dispensed with.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 9 -- The United States is preparing to revive before the Commission on Human Rights, which convenes here tomorrow, discussion of the 1956 Hungarian revolt.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -The first New World landfall of Columbus' 1492 voyage may not have been the historically accepted Watling Island, generally called San Salvador, according to a report just published by the Smithsonian Institution.

MONTREAL, March 9 -- The Canadian rights for Eugene O'Neill's "Long Day's Journey Into Night" have been granted to Rupert Caplan, theatrical figure and a producer of many years' standing for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 9 -- The Vanguard satellite team, thwarted again yesterday in its effort on Cape Canaveral to fly a three-stage test vehicle, is expected to make another effort Tuesday or Wednesday.
The New York State Bankers Association announced over the week-end the establishment of a "University of Banking" on a 2,500-acre estate called Sedgewood at Carmel, N. Y.
BOSTON, March 9 (UP) -- The third-place Boston Bruins beat Toronto for the first time this season on home ice tonight, routing the Maple Leafs, 7 -- 0, to extend their unbeaten streak to six games.
ROME, March 9 -- Thousands of persons gave a rousing tribute to Pope Pius XII today at a mass audience in St. Peter's Basilica. Their thunderous cheers and "evvivas" visibly moved the Pontiff.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) -- Oren Harris, chairman of a House investigating subcommittee, proposed today that President Eisenhower be stripped of authority to name the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.
The congregation of Judson Memorial Church in Greenwich Village unanimously ratified yesterday a statement citing "acceptance and love" as the need of the students of Public School 701.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -James C. Hagerty inadvertently tipped reporters last week to one of his secrets for assuring that good news is associated with the White House and the not-so-good with other agencies.
MOSCOW, March 9 -- Everyone thought it was a lovely wedding.

President Eisenhower has indicated his deepening concern over the current recession. His letter to the Senate and House Republican leaders lists seven steps the Administration has been taking this past month to try to provide new stimuli to the economy and also to prevent human suffering.

MADRID, March 9 -- Spain, whose current tension with the North African Arab bloc is second only to that of France, apparently has seized upon a French proposal for a western Mediterranean pact with keen interest.
CHICAGO, March 9 (UP) -Dick Moore and Jean Beliveau scored two goals apiece tonight to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

Prof. Robert V. Daniels, in his letter published Feb. 24, raises a timely question, it seems to me, of the first magnitude. It involves the necessity for improved agencies or organized means of checking or preventing serious and widespread public abuses that flourish for long -much too long -- periods of time.

NEW ORLEANS, March 9 (AP) -- Ken Venturi, Billy Maxwell and Gene Littler conquered the soggy City Park golf course today with four-under-par 68's to share the first-round lead in the Greater New Orleans open tournament.

Colombians have now completed registration for their Congressional elections of March 16. These will be exceptionally important because they are the first popular elections since the overthrow last May of the military dictator, Lieutenant General Rojas Pinilla, and they will put the political agreement between the Liberals and Conservatives to a crucial test.

The Chrysler Corporation's backlog of defense orders for missile systems, tanks, trucks and other military equipment was $300,000,000 at the beginning of this year. That was $200,000,000 above the level at the start of 1957.

Nothing seems to annoy the Russian potentates more than even a feeble gesture of defense from nonCommunist nations. The Russians detest NATO. They abhor the Baghdad Pact. On Saturday they announced, and not for the first time, that they didn't approve of SEATO -- the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization -- which tomorrow will open one of its regular sessions at Manila.
One of the most remarkable feats recorded on a racquets court was seen at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday as a British team carried off the amateur doubles championship of the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -The Administration has developed a new weapon in the battle over foreign trade. It is a series of reports on how exports and imports effect the average citizen of Bristol, Conn., Flint, Mich., and Bessemer, Ala., among other places.
The state accused a New York stock broker yesterday of employing fraudulent methods in promoting the sale of stock in one of the city's first pay television ventures.
Prices of cotton futures closed 17 to 31 points higher yesterday. The contracts were led by strength in new-crop months, all of which established new life-of-contract highs.
ALBANY, March10 -- The Temporary Rent Commission agreed today to recommend a one-year extension of commercial and business rent controls for New York City.

The American Bankers Association has "complicated" the House Ways and Means Committee's consideration of a bill to increase taxes on mutual thrift institutions, the president of the association's savings and mortgage division said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Senate approved tentatively today a total of $14,300,000 for United States participation in the Brussels International Trade Fair.

BOSTON, March 10 -- The Committee on Campaign Contributions and Expenditures announced today the appointment of an executive committee. William H. Vanderbilt of Brookline, former Governor of Rhode Island, is chairman of the national bipartisan group formed last month to work for the revision and improvement of Federal election laws.
The Shell Transport and Trading Company, Ltd., announced yesterday acceptances of 7,940,000 ordinary shares in its recent offer of new stock to holders of the equivalent $15.40 a share.
ROME, March 10 -- The excommunication of three Hungarian ecclesiastics was announced today by the Sacred Congregation of the Council.

Arthur Godfrey announced yesterday that his "Talent Scouts" television program would move on Sept. 24 to Wednesdays from 8:30 to 9 P. M. It is currently presented at the same time on Mondays by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

A banking syndicate is being formed to negotiate the financing of an additional water source for southeastern Michigan at a cost ranging from $93,000,000 to $200,000,000 depending on the size of the service area.

The evening performance of "The Ten Commandments" tomorrow at the Criterion will mark the end of a seventy-week run, described as the longest in the theatre's history. The Cecil B. Demille production opened on a two-a-day reserved-seat basis on Nov. 8, 1956.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 10 (Reuters) -- Premier Abdullah Khalil's pro-Western Umma party maintained its lead tonight in the Sudanese general elections.
The Times Square Information Center, a building of plate glass, stainless steel and glazed brick, was officially inaugurated yesterday morning. It has been in operation since Nov. 25.

WHETHER you like it or not, the chemise is selling. Ever since last fall, a cyclone of controversy has whirled around the word "chemise." It represents the most revolu tionary shape to come along in a decade. It is the opposite of Dior's old, tiny-waisted "New Look." It has been praised as the "easy silhouette'' and the "relaxed line" and damned as a "sad sack," a "monster" and a "freak."
CHICAGO, March 10 -- The net income of the Commonwealth Edison Company in 1957 advanced, but failed to rise above an inadequate level of return on investment, Willis Gale, chairman, said today.
These last years I have followed with concern the situation in Cyprus, and I was greatly interested in the exchange of letters on the subject between Nuri Eren and Eugene Rossides.

A 4-year-old boy, carried under a subway train on a Brooklyn elevated platform by his mother as she jumped to her death yesterday, survived when he slipped between the ties. He hung suspended by his wedged foot sixty feet above the roadway until rescued.

The weather was brisk but sunny for yesterday's opening of the Jamaica and Belmont Park Race Tracks for the purpose of training thoroughbreds. About fifty horses, most of whom had spent the winter here, galloped over each course. Only the training track was used at Belmont Park.

The number of people who can speak with authority about the great Blizzard of 1888 grows smaller each year. This week marks the passage of seventy years since those four fateful days when this city was buried in what turned out to be, for various reasons, the classic snowstorm.
IT never rains, but it pours. This spring, there is a flood of flower-printed rainwear, all of it designed to perk up the spirits on the drabbest day.
A 51-year-old vice president of the First Boston Corporation plunged to the roadbed of the Broadway-Seventh Avenue subway line yesterday and was killed.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Organized labor's legislative spokesman told Congress today that the time had come for the Government to start building schools as an urgent program that would also lessen unemployment.

With the proper degree of historical perspective one could find a great deal of amusement in the present public criticism of the United States Supreme Court, as reflected in your editorial printed Feb. 26. A few years back most of the criticism was directed at President Roosevelt for his attempt to weaken the power of the court.

Two new issues of debentures of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., totaling $40,000,000, are being offered for public subscription today by a syndicate of seventy-one investment houses headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee was unable to vote today on Senator William E. Jenner's bill to restrict the power of the Supreme Court.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 10 -- "Hi ya, captain," called out the touring journalist from New York. On the other side of the Detroit dressing room, Billy Martin's ears vibrated at the once familiar salutation. He ran over.
The Coast Guard, in its efforts to determine the cause of the sinking of the tugboat Jim Steers, has asked for scientific assistance from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

In January and February there was a 21 per cent increase in traffic deaths in this city over the same two months of 1957. In these months, also, a 13 per cent rise in injuries and accidents was noted.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Army's two top spokesmen said today Congress must provide greater pay incentives if the Army "is to remain an effective instrument of our national defense" in the nuclear age.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Governor Harriman sought today to draw United States Senators Irving M. Ives and Jacob K. Javits, both Republicans, into the Albany battle over unemployment insurance.

BEDFORD, England, March 10 -- Methodists from all over Britain met at the Anglican Church of St. Paul's here tonight for a special anniversary service commemorating John Wesley's "Grand Assize" sermon.
LOS ANGELES, March 10 -- An extraordinarily vehement attack on the legal profession punctuated the opening today of the biennial congress of the International College of Surgeons.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10 -- A programing innovation of potential importance to many television stations throughout the country will be announced soon by National Television Associates.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- At the age of 25 John Storrs Cross made up his mind to make a million dollars and retire at 30.

PETER John Stephens' new play, "A Power of Dreams." which was given a theatre-in-the-round presentation at the Sullivan Street Playhouse last night, is a partly whimsical and partly capricious mood piece that never quite comes off.

LONDON, March 10 -- United States missiles scheduled for Britain were described today as "a lot of junk" and "a great waste of money" in a Parliamentary attack on the Government's air defense and foreign policies.

BUENOS AIRES, March 10 -- The provisional Government's threat to conscript male bank employes apparently has broken the strike that virtually had paralyzed Argentina's banking services for seven weeks.

ROME, March 10 -- The Vatican expressed disapproval of coeducational schools today when the Sacred Congregation of the Religious decreed that no member of a religious order might become the head of a secondary-grade coeducational school "except in case of dire necessity."

TORONTO, March 10 (Canadian Press) -- Alarm over actions of Provincial Governments and the United States in "creating barriers that have a direct affect on our operations," was expressed today by Mrs. Viola MacMillan, president of the Prospectors and Developers Association.

The House subcommittee now investigating the independent Federal agencies will be missing a bet if it confines its activities merely to the sins of omission or commission of prominent personalities in Washington and elsewhere. In fact, it will be missing the main purpose of the whole inquiry.
The election of Simon B. Siegal and James G. Riddell as directors of American Broadcasting-Paramount The atres, Inc., was announced yesterday by Leonard H. Goldenson, president.
Ninety boys have now been enrolled in the city's two special schools for suspended pupils, the Board of Education reported yesterday.

PEIPING, March 10 (Reuters) -- Chinese Communist "volunteers" who fought against United Nations troops in Korea are about to volunteer again -- this time for work on state farms in the wastelands of Manchuria.
LONDON, March 10 -- A strong appeal for nuclear disarmament appeared as a play on the Independent Television Authority network tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -The State Department said today that "arrangements" had been made to evacuate about 450 Americans in parts of Sumatra threatened by civil war.
The nation's largest copper producer announced yesterday that it would curtail mining sharply again "to more nearly keep demand and supply in balance."
Al Inniss of St. Francis College of Brooklyn won the basketball scoring championship of the Middle Eastern Conference, gaining a slim margin over John Lynch of Lemoyne of Syracuse.
Steel production dipped again last week after a brief rally in the preceding week. It was expected to rise slightly in the present week.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The National Football League Players Association today advised Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, it favored his bill to regulate professional sports.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Treasury bill rate rose sharply this week, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average annual rate on $1,700,000,000 of the 91-day discount bills was 1.532 per cent, compared, to 1.351 per cent last week.

Reflecting the sale of four subsidiaries during 1956, gross revenues and pre-tax earnings of the Merritt-Chapman and Scott Corporation dipped last year, but net income exclusive of non-recurring credits reached a record $13,170,332.
ALBANY, March 10 -- Republican leaders cleared the way tonight for exempting $500,000,000 from New York City's debt limit for school construction after 1960.
A 21-year-old man was arraigned yesterday on a charge of beating his 102-year-old grandmother with the buckle end of a belt.

Dick Elliffe remembers the day he played against an outfielder named Dwight David Eisenhower; the afternoon he taught Waite Hoyt to throw a curve ball, and the high school football games that drew 30,000 persons to Ebbets Field.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, March 8 -- There are reports here that Gen. Marcos Perez Jimenez and Juan Peron are preparing to go their different ways.

The Government presented its appeal yesterday from a tax case decision that would enable R. H. Macy Co., Inc., to collect at least $1,008,750 in refunds and possibly open the door for $8,000,000 more.

Spokesmen for a dress industry association not involved in the present strike negotiations yesterday accused local garment makers of submitting feebly to dictation by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.
SANTA ANITA, March 10 (AP) -- Terrang won the $28,100 San Bernardino Handicap today in a photo finish with Porterhouse and Seaneen before a crowd of 26,500 at Santa Anita.
An effort to resolve an impasse in the five-week-old strike of 1,200 excavation truck drivers may be made through a citizens' committee.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation, the nation's largest hotel chain, is planning to build 300-unit inns adjacent to the airports of leading cities across the country, Conrad N. Hilton, president, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- A dozen Puerto Ricans picketed the White House today to protest United States "imperialism.

A 16-year-old boy was charged yesterday with breaking the wrist of a 15-year-old girl classmate in a fight that reportedly took place Friday at Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn. The teacher was said to have been out of the room at the time.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- John S. Cross, a State Department expert on international communications, was nominated today to be a member of the Federal Communications Commission to succeed Richard A. Mack.

A Senate hearing in Washington about two months ago was told that the financial condition of the railroads was "precarious," with bankruptcy around the corner. A few days later the railroads doing business in New York State carried a similar message to Albany, with an appeal for help to survive against increased costs, high taxation, duplicated governmental regulation and subsidized competition of trucking and airlines.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Nothing could be more futile than having a "gumshoe" follow a newspaper man to learn his news sources, James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary, said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 10 -- The Soviet Union has informed the United States that it will not attend a proposed meeting of the Security Council on disarmament if anything besides procedural matters is to be discussed.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10 -- Paramount Pictures is going to do business behind the Iron Curtain, at least in a limited way.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 10 -- A suburban rapid-transit system to be financed and owned by a newly created state agency was recommended here today by the Nassau County Democratic committee.
LAHTI, Finland, March 10 (AP) -- The Russians have agreed to house their 1960 Olympic team with the other competing athletes at Squaw Valley, Calif.

Refrigerators and other fruits of the assembly line are not the only kinds of American products prized overseas. European dealers, collectors, museums and gallery-goers have shown increasing interest in abstract paintings by American artists.

American television viewers have at least one thing in common with set owners in twentyfour foreign countries -- commercials. However, there are twenty-two nations whose stations do not beam advertising messages.

CURTSIES for Hattie Carnegie. A bow-sprinkled collection, shown yesterday, should tie up traffic in this designer's custom salon for the entire spring. It is also a tribute to the late Miss Carnegie herself that her contribution to fashion is so durable.

The West Virginia Mountaineers yesterday were named the national major college basketball champion for the 1957-58 season by the United Press board of coaches in the closest final vote in the history of the ratings.

A delectable variation on creamed spinach, one of the vegetables in excellent supply now, is the French epinards au jus. To prepare it, thoroughly clean three pounds of fresh spinach and cook it six to eight minutes over high heat in a small amount of salted water. Drain spinach and chop fine.

Last year the New York State Legislature passed an amendment to the General Education Law mandating school boards to establish sufficient and proper educational facilities and classes for all mentally retarded school children between the ages of 5 and 21.
A policeman who thought he was rescuing a would-be suicide in Brooklyn yesterday was as surprised as anyone when the case took a different turn. A knowledge of Spanish would have helped.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The National Institutes of Health today announced a discovery that "sheds new light on hemophilia and other puzzling blood disorders."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Marilynn Smith chipped into the eighteenth hole from thirty-four yards away and defeated Fay Crocker by a stroke for the $875 top prize in the Jacksonville women's open golf tournament today.

Commission house selling, liquidation, stop-loss ordering and profit-taking tumbled cocoa futures almost the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Scale-down short covering, buying for price fixing and trade hedge lifting absorbed the offerings.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Republican politicians are more depressed these days than the economy. It is not only that they feel that their luck has run out but that both the Russians and the Democrats seem to have them over a barrel.

Formation of a new trade association of drug manufacturers, to be known as the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, was announced yesterday by the two groups it will replace. These are the American Drug Manufacturers Association of Washington and the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Supreme Court held today that the Northern Pacific Railway violated the antitrust laws when it sold land with the proviso that the buyers ship via the railroad. The vote was 5 to 3.
Hearings on homicide charges against two men accused of distributing wood alcohol that caused some of the recent twenty-seven deaths here were adjourned yesterday until tomorrow.
PHILADELPHIA, March 10 (AP) -- Russell Bufalino today refused to identify positively two of three men he drove to a crime convention at Apalachin, N. Y., last Nov. 14.

Commercial and finance paper outstanding in the United States increased $679,000,000, or 25 per cent in January to $3,345,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has reported. The increase was the largest since the survey started in 1953.
CHICAGO, March 10(AP) -Grain futures prices shifted fairly broadly on the Board of Trade today but finished mostly within minor fractions of Friday's close.
ALBANY, March 10 -- The Assembly took final action tonight on a proposed charter for Suffolk County. The bill now goes to Governor Harriman, who twice vetoed similar bills.
ALMOST twelve years after starting his "Talent Scouts" television show, Arthur Godfrey changed its format last night over Channel 2.

MANILA, Tuesday, March 11 -- Secretary of State Dulles warned this morning that communism might have aggressive new plans for Southeast Asia. Speaking at the opening session of the Council of Ministers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization, Mr. Dulles noted the "unusual attention" Communist quarters had given the meeting.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told Congress today that collections and credits totaling about $36,000,000 were received by the United States on World War II lend-lease accounts during 1956.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 10 (AP) -- The budget director, Percival F. Brundage, said today he thought there was a good chance of a tax cut this year.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., March 10 -- Building contractors and construction workers joined today in an attack upon "snob zoning" in this almost exclusively residential Westchester village. They included six other Westchester "country club" communities in their indictment.
If the idea is feasible, theatre-goers will be able to call the telephone company to ascertain what tickets can be purchased to Broadway shows and in what price range.

Back in 1924 New York City had the highest drowning loss in the nation, more than 500 a year. That year marked the beginning here of free Red Cross water safety in struction. Since that time nearly 1,000,000 men, women and children have received this training.
Alumnae, parents and friends of St. Mary's-in-the-Mountains School will attend a reception and dinner tomorrow evening at the St. Anthony Club, 16 East Sixty-fourth Street.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 10 (Reuters) -- Foreign Minister Aligholi Ardalan said today Iran "repudiated" the recent oil agreement between Saudi Arabia and the British-protected independent Sheikhdom of Bahrein on the Persian Gulf.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. had record sales of $1,965,000,000 in 1957. The $220,000,000 spent for construction and expansion of plants, laboratories and service units was also a new high. The figures were disclosed in the annual report now being mailed to more than 200,000 stockholders.
Cautious buying marked the opening of the ten-day American Toy Fair yesterday at the New Yorker and Sheraton-McAlpin hotels.

A little over three years ago the Manufacturers Trust Company startled New Yorkers by opening, at Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street, its "glass bank" -- walled entirely in aluminum and plate glass. Continuing its tradition-breaking bent, the bank will move its headquarters Monday from 55 Broad Street to 44 Wall Street, the first banking office of its kind in the downtown financial section in contemporary decor.

Stockholders at yesterday's regional meeting of Textron, Inc., were quietly insistent on the question of when the dividend would be raised. Addressing some 1,000 holders of securities at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Royal Little, chairman of the board, declared that the status of the dividend depended on earnings.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Representative George of Meader, Republican of Michigan, urged Congressional committees today to disregard what he called the Administration's doctrine of "Executive privilege to withhold information from Congress."
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The chairman of the Senate rackets committee accused an official of the United Auto Workers today of "rewarding" violence in the Kohler Company strike.
MIAMI, March 10 -- Fred Haney, the manager of the world champion Milwaukee Braves, brought a few of his champions and a lot of his tryout youngsters here from Bradenton, Fla., today.

THE skillet, whether electric or the kind that must be set on top of the range, is one of the home cook's handiest allies. It cooks the main dish in the following menu, which is planned with an eye to keeping the budget within reasonable limits.
"Die Walkuere" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera last night, with Jean Madeira making her first appearance there as Fricka.
KIEV, U. S. S. R., March 10 -- The vodka and cognac were set out in generous portions and good fellowship had reached the point of one chorus of "I've been working on the railroad."
NEW ORLEANS, March 10 (UP) -- Ken Venturi of San Francisco fell off his pace today but managed to fire his way into a three-way tie at the end of thirty-six holes in the $20,000 New Orleans Open.
City funds totaling about $49,000 are missing from a special bank account of the Bureau of Real Estate, Mayor Wagner made known yesterday.
BRANDENBURG, Germany, March 10 -- Farewell ceremonies for a unit of Soviet troops today were the occasion for Communist propaganda aimed at a withdrawal of United States troops from West Germany.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 10 -- (Reuters) -- Jan Masaryk, one of the leading statesmen in pre-Communist Czechoslovakia, was described in friendly tones today on the tenth anniversary of his death.
The world's newest weapons system, a nuclear-powered submarine armed with 1,500-mile rockets with atomic warheads, will be cruising the high seas in about two to three years.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Fred Hooper's Greek Game gave the favorite players something to cheer about as he came from fifth place to triumph by a length in the featured Iron Mask Purse today at Gulfstream Park.
The city's campaign to eliminate jaywalking is progressing "very, very slowly," Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday.

REGINA, Sask., March 10 -- One of the big issues that may be settled in the March 31 general election is the fate of the minority parties that have governed Canada's three western provinces for years.
CHICAGO, March 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markels here by t6e Department ot Agriculture follows;
HAVANA, March 10 -- President Fulgencio Batista today defended the six years of his regime and declared his Government would hold fair elections June 1.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 10 -- Parliamentary procedure and diplomatic dignity were strained this morning in the election of a new chairman of the Commission on Human Rights.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 10 -- About 1,500 Turkish school children and youths demonstrated today in Nicosia. They marched through the Turkish quarter chanting "Taksim (partition)!" and carried slogans denouncing "Foot the warmonger." Sir Hugh Foot is Governor of Cyprus.
Edward R. Murrow, the radio and television commentator, was projected yesterday into the race for the Democratic and Liberal party nomination for United States Senator.
WARSAW, March 10 -- Poland's ruling Communists have begun a vast propaganda campaign to explain the need for the harsh economic measures adopted by the party's Central Committee earlier this month.
WHITE PLAINS, March 10 -- Any expectation of tax savings from a one-year residence requirement for public relief was called a delusion today by Westchester officials.
TUNIS, March 10 -- M. Gaillard's proposal of a Mediterranean defense community has been greeted in North Africa with profound reserve.

Indonesia plunged deeper into a spreading civil war yesterday when the Communist-backed Government of President Sukarno began to land troops on Sumatra in an effort to crush the anti-Communist rebel regime established there last month. The landings, which follow a blockade and sporadic bombing of rebel strongholds, indicate that the Indonesian genius for compromise has failed to resolve the issues involved and that both sides, as they announce, are now determined to fight it out.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Eisenhower was host tonight at a White House dinner for sixteen business and civic leaders who are supporting his plea for continuation of the reciprocal trade program.
Fluorescent lamps two-and-a-half to three times as powerful as former units featured exhibits yesterday at the first National Lighting Exposition in the Coliseum.
The civil war that has erupted in Indonesia has been simmering under the furface for the eight years since the republic won independence from the Dutch.
The crash of a Northeast Airlines plans on Rikers Island on Feb. 1, 1957, with the loss of twenty lives, has been attributed by the Civil Aeronautics Board to pilot failure.
TRENTON, March 10 -- A state-wide investigation of garbage collection and disposal contracts was voted today by the Republican-controlled State Senate.
The stock market edged timidly ahead yesterday for its seventh consecutive day of gains.
Many game birds, like many people, found this a pretty rugged winter in the South as well as the North.
Three architecturally symbolic buildings will house a report at the Brussels world's fair on three of this nation's big problems -- segregation, the city and nature.
GENEVA, March 10 (Reuters) -- Prof. Grigori I. Tunkin, the chief Soviet delegate, called for an immediate ban on nuclear test explosions over the high seas.
What a supple composer Poulenc can be, and what sinewy strength shows in his songs, when they are sung with the fire and tenderness that Patricia Neway brought to them in her recital last night!

PARIS, March 10 -- United States and British diplomats seeking to mend strained French-Tunisian relations will carry to Tunis tomorrow outlines of a settlement. They also will take with them an idea of French long-range plans in the western Mediterranean area.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 10 -- The Corner Law School announced today that it had received $1,000,000 as a gift from Myron C. Taylor, a member of the class of '94. The money will help pay for a new residence hall for students.
HOUSTON, Tex., March 10 -- Since dramatic scripts are in short supply, Nina Vance's Alley Theatre has put together an interesting bill of one-act plays.
What's it like on Mars? Some answers can be found at the New York International Flower Show at the Coliseum.
ALBANY, March 10 -- The Tweed Commission's latest plan for court reorganization was endorsed today by present and former state officials.
Norman Thomas predicted yesterday that "one of the worst explosions in history" would erupt if the South African Government maintained its policy of apartheid, or racial segregation.

The discount rate, the charge by Federal Reserve Banks for loans to commercial banks, is still too high, in the opinion of Aubrey G. Lanston of Aubrey G. Lanston Co:, Inc., dealer in. Government bonds.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- United States officials scanned dispatches on France's plan for a Mediterranean defense pact today for hints that it was meant as a setting for a new French approach to the Algerian problem.

THE eighteenth century European world is an interesting place to visit in books, although one doubts that all its admirers would be content to live there. It was a time of swords and poses. The amenities of civilization were brought to a high polish; the cruelties of despotism tarnished it everywhere.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 10 (UP) -- Milton C. Lightner, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, criticized today the President's plan to increase unemployment benefits.
A spring tour of New York homes will benefit the New York League for the Hard of Hearing. The tour will be made on April 23.

WASHINGTON, Mar. 10 -- At least two members of the House Banking and Currency Committee were ready tonight to demand tomorrow an investigation into a possible advance leak of notice that the Federal Reserve Board was going to reduce the discount rate last week.
Basketball and politics are somewhat similar in that you win a few, you lose a few. In the former it's games. In the latter it's votes.
"BUILT-in self-controls for their children may be one reason the British have less of a juvenile delinquency problem than we do in America."

A major maritime legal bout appears to be in the making. It will be the Federal Maritime Administration and the American President Lines versus the Puget Sound Bridge and Dredging Company and the General Insurance Company of America.
GENEVA, March 10 -- Two weeks of debate at an international conference on the law of the sea have produced agreement on a single subject: that the high seas be kept free.
A 30-year-old Brooklyn man was sentenced yesterday to ten and a half to twenty-one years in prison for the theft of $174,000 from his employer, the American Express Company of 65 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- A Senate committee was told today that unless Congress acted, the nation's new Interstate Highway System would become "a billboard alley."

Ten years ago next December the United Nations General Assembly unanimously adopted a Universal Declaration of Human Rights. To implement this document the U. N. set up a Commission on Human Rights, which this week is beginning its fourteenth session at U. N. headquarters.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 10 -- Performing before large crowds these days to the thunderous applause of virtually no one are thirty-two baseball umpires, a thick-skinned group of citizens who, contrary to public opinion, are neither far-sighted, near-sighted, nor blind.
The existence of a $250,000-a-year bookmaking syndicate involving members of the New York Police Department was disclosed late yesterday.

Two new Junior Leagues have been admitted to the Association of the Junior Leagues of America. The new organizations, in Kingsport, Tenn., and New Britain, Conn., bring the total association membership to 190 Junior Leagues in the United States, Canada, Mexico and Hawaii.
A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday for a hold-up man and for being the occupant of a stolen car that injured five women in a hit-and-run accident Feb. 28 at a Utica Avenue, Brooklyn, bus stop.

A settlement of the six-day-old dress strike was reached early today. The parade of 105,000 members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union back to their shops in New York and six near-by states is expected to begin this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that fourteen states would contribute more money than they would receive under the Administration's proposed school aid program.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today he favored a tax cut over a massive spending program if further Governmental anti-recession action proved necessary.

A GROUP of draftsmen, sixty strong, from Italy and America, representing the figurative tradition, are brought together in an exhibition at Gallery "G," 200 East Fifty-ninth Street. National lines are crossed often in this exhibition in which some Americans display their virtuoso techniques in the Renaissance Italian mode and some Italians show the influence of applied design as practiced chiefly in the United States.
A former patrolman who has charged that he was tricked into pleading guilty to second-degree murder will have a hearing today before Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld.

The Iron Curtain separating the West from Soviet bloc nations can best be melted by the airplane. This is the view of Lord Douglas of Kirtleside, chairman of British European Airways, who was in New York yesterday for a brief visit following a trip to Moscow.

Alitalia, the Italian airline, has taken a lease on the major part of the thirty-second floor and on a large street floor area in the Tishman Building at 666 Fifth Avenue. The lease was negotiated by George L. Studley of Julien Studley, Inc., broker.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Robert W. Sarnoff, president of the National Broadcasting Company, said today proposed new regulations for television network operations might destroy television service as the public now knows it.

We have long known who discovered America -- omitting, to be sure, the Norsemen and Basque fishermen who may have been here but kept quiet about it. What has never been quite certain is exactly where Columbus made his first landfall. Tradition makes it Watling Island in the Bahamas, which the great Admiral called by the lovelier name of San Salvador.
DANNY KAYE bestrode the podium at Carnegie Hall last night, and conducting will never be the same again. Neither, for that matter, will the New York Philharmonic.

PARIS, March 10 (AP) -- Charles Humez of France, European middleweight champion, tonight twice floored Germany's Gustav (Bubi) Scholz in winning a decision in a ten-round non-title bout at the Sports Palace.

The management of Lord Taylor announced yesterday that in deference to Japanese religious feeling it had removed the arrows surrounding a statue of Kwannon, the Buddhist Goddess of Mercy, in one of the department store's windows.

Tony DiBiase of Astoria, Queens, defeated Peter Schmidt, a Yorkville welterweight, in the star bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The contest, an exciting one, drew repeated cheers from the crowd of 1,622 fans.

BUKITTINGGI, Indonesia, March 10 (AP) -- Indonesian warships and planes lightly shelled and bombed Padang today after a troop landing on the east coast of Sumatra. A showdown with the rebel regime based in this mountain capital appeared imminent.

JAMESBURG, N. J., March 10 -- Hunting pheasants on a preserve is not the same as hunting grouse or even pheasants on wild land, but at this time of year it is about the only thing available around here and it can be pleasant if it is not taken too seriously.
LONDON, March 10 -- The recent rise in the stock market was checked today. However, losses were small.

VIENNA, March 10 -- Rude Pravo, newspaper of the Czechoslovak Communist party, apologized yesterday for its mistranslation recently of an article by Marshal Ivan S. Konev of the Soviet Union in such a way as to offend Yugoslav national pride.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, March 11 -- The Government announced today the capture of three rebel-held towns in its drive against the revolutionaries in Central Sumatra.

GREAT NECK, L. I., March 10 -- The idea of creating special classes for gifted children instead of catering only to the needs of the average child appeared to be gaining wide support hero today at a teacher's conference on how to improve science teaching.
Detroit is pinching pennies to keep the overhead from getting out of control and to meet relief needs, Mayor Louis C. Miriani said here yestreday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 -- All the joy or living is beginning to desert Casey Stengel. His Yankees blew another ball game today, third in a row, and this one wasn't to be laughed off.
ALBANY, March 10 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the New York State Department of Commerce:

The foreign policy of the United States in China, the Near East, Central Europe, etc., has been under close scrutiny and subject to constructive criticism during the last few years. Not so the hesitations, meanderings and cross purposes of United States activities in broad and tremendously important lands of our own hemisphere south of the Rio Grande.
United States Attorney Paul W. Williams offered proposals last night for legislation to combat organized crime. They were:

" Jane Eyre," due March 31 at the Belasco, has been canceled. The play, which was adapted by Huntington Hartford from the Charlotte Bronte novel, will be withdrawn at the end of the week in Philadelphia, where it opened on Monday night.
Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday promised the full cooperation of the Police Department to District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Brooklyn in the police-bookmaking inquiry.

JERSEY CITY, March 11 -- A helicopter carrying ten passengers and two crew members from Newark Airport to La Guardia Airport made a forced landing today in the Jersey meadowlands near the Hackensack River.

ROME, March 11 -- Some Algerian nationalists offered today to open talks with France for a cease-fire and for arranging free elections, under European supervision, for a "sovereign" Algerian constituent assembly.
ALBANY, March 11 -- State legislation to stamp out corruption within labor unions has been recommended to Governor Harriman by a special committee he appointed to study the subject.
TOYS are not merely child's play. They also help youngsters understand their world, express their inner lives and reach emotional maturity.
The Columbia Broadcasting System yesterday split its television operations into two divisions.

DUCKS and other waterfowl are returning North and many a wildfowler and bird-watcher will be distressed by the sight of some of them committing slow, sure, painful suicide by swimming into oil slicks.

An investment banking group headed jointly by Halsey Stuart Co. and J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., bid successfully yesterday for an advertised issue of $15,000,000 of Newark, N. J., school, water and other general obligation bonds due from 1959 to 1978.
An automatic factory with what was described as "the nation's first all-electronically controlled line of machine tools" was put on display yesterday by the Hughes Aircraft Company.
The dress industry's first strike in a quarter century ended yesterday with wage increases that seemed likely to result in higher price tags on most spring and summer dresses.

IN a Phoenix-like transformation, Joseph Glasco comes forward in his new paintings at the Catherine Viviano Gallery, 42 East Fifty-seventh Street, with a different point of view. He has cleared away the crusty ridges, the tapestried detail, the strange porcelain-doll symbolic figures that used to inhabit his paintings.

To eat or not to eat in class is the question at Columbia College these days. Some students, most of them commuters, have acquired the habit of eating lunch during noon classes while their professors lecture.
Sales of the Grand Union Company rose in the fiscal year ended March 1 of this year to a record total of $427,876,672.
The fight for control of S. H. Kress Co., big variety store chain, ended in a compromise yesterday that was actually a victory for the Samuel H. Kress Foundation.
MIDLAND, Mich., March 11 (AP) -- The Dow Chemical Company is building a marine terminal at Bay City to ke advantage of the St. Lawrence Seaway.
ALBANY, March 11 -- An amended version of the Republican bill reorganizing the New York City Housing Authority was reported out of committee in the Senate today.

Today's new film is "Desire Under the Elms," Don Hartman's movie version of the Eugene O'Neill drama, starring Sophia Loren, Anthony Perkins and Burl Ives, at both the Sutton and Odeon Theatres. Proceeds from the evening premieres will go to the Yale Drama School's Eugene O'Neill Scholarship Fund.
ALBANY, March 11 -- Republican legislative leaders agreed today to pass their own version of the bill to authorize a charter revision commission for New York City.
WHAT is reported to be the most modern and most complete Japanese food store in the country opened recently at Amsterdam Avenue and 124th Street in the new Morningside Gardens Shopping Center.

An attempt to place the faculty and administrative staff of the United States Merchant Marine Academy under Civil Service regulations has aroused vigorous opposition among the alumni and faculty of the fifteen-year-old institution.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Navy said today that several hundreds of three types of front-line jet aircraft had been temporarily grounded because of a fuel control problem. The order is fleet-wide.

We commemorate today the hundredth birthday of Adolph S. Ochs, Publisher of The Times between 1896 and 1935. But in a sense every issue of this newspaper is a memorial to Mr. Ochs. Had it not been for him The Times would either not exist or it would not be the kind of paper it is today.
ALBANY, March 11 -- A Brooklyn woman who could not recall which legislative committee employed her was dismissed today.
CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -Grain futures prices moved narrowly on the Board of Trade today.

It is good news indeed that the walkout of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union has been settled -- and in such an extraordinarily short time, considering the size and complexity of both the industry itself and the issues involved. On strike only since last Wednesday, garment workers in New York and six neighboring states are now starting to return to work and the employers can still meet the rising demands of the Easter season.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Arthur Schwartz, composer for Broadway shows and motion pictures, charged today that the broadcasting industry had "deprived" the American people of "a free choice of music."
The city is raising family income limits for eligibility in some of its public housing.
The annual Mayor's Trophy baseball game, played most recently between the Yankees and Dodgers, yesterday was declared a casualty of the moves to California of the Dodgers and Giants.

The New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America, facing a schedule of rallying and racing covering more than thirty week-ends from April to November, has completed a thorough reorganization plan under the direction of Henry Szamota, the regional executive.

FLORENCE, S. C., March 11 -- A B-47 jet bomber accidentally dropped an unarmed atomic bomb near a farm home today. The TNT in the bomb's trigger device exploded, injuring six persons. However there was no atomic explosion.

I am writing to support, as strongly as I know how, the fight you are waging to save the present East Front of the Capitol from the threatened reconstruction. I am delighted that your excellent editorial of March 7 on the subject was given the lead position on your editorial page.
Following is the list of yesterday's awards in the New York International Flower Show at the Coliseum:
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Unemployment rose in February to 5,173,000, a post-war record and the largest total since mid-1941, the Labor and Commerce Departments reported today.

Three 15-year-old Queens girls were charged by the police last night with carving the initial "S" -- the symbol of an all-girl gang known as the Strikers -- into the right arms of four initiates with a kitchen knife.

Samuel Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., international grandmaster in chess, stopped off on his exhibition tour at Yeshiva University, Amsterdam Avenue and 184th Street last night. Against thirty members of the varsity chess club, he made a clean sweep on all boards within two hours and a half after he had adopted a variety of openings.
" Neighborhood laundry" service for ship cargo tanks was established in the Port of New York yesterday.
PARIS, March 11 -- The National Assembly began today another attempt to agree on a reform of the French Constitution to increase executive authority and governmental stability.
The Treasury must not compete "unnecessarily" with corporate, municipal and mortgage borrowers in its efforts to lengthen the maturity of the public debt, a high department official said yesterday.

CAIRO, March 11 (AP) -- Egyptian authorities are to announce Saturday a new organic law for the Gaza Strip giving Palestinians greater participation in the government. But the Egyptian Military Government will retain supreme powers.

A subcommittee has been formed by the Officers Wives Club at the Floyd Bennett Naval Air Station in Brooklyn for the benefit showing of the motion picture "South Pacific" on March 20 at the Criterion Theatre.

Directors of the Federation Bank and Trust Company yesterday increased the quarterly dtvtdend on the c0mmon stock with a declaration of 35 cents a share, payable on April 1. Shareholders had receivecl 30 cents a share previously.
Eighty-two farm animals -- the gift of religious groups here to the people of Nepal -- left New York by plane yesterday.
" WHAT is the most inexpensive type of installed lighting for the home today?" a designer asked a lighting expert yesterday. "Today's installation costs prohibit anything cheap," he answered.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 11 (AP) -- Federal Judge William E. Steckler ruled yesterday that the American Legion could not be sued in Federal court because the Legion is neither a citizen of Indiana nor of any other state.
GENEVA, March 4 -- A United Nations force of timber experts from East and West has penetrated forests near here to watch a demonstration of tractors churning up the neutral ground of Switzerland.

PARIS, March 11 -- With some gentle prodding by her American and British allies, France at last appears to be edging toward what is called "a NATO solution" of her grievous Algerian problem. This would seem to be the ultimate implication of Premier Gaillard's still vague proposal for a west Mediterranean pact.
LONDON, March 11 -- John Hay Whitney, the United States Ambassador, attempted tonight to reassure the British about the course of the United States recession.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- The Warner Stable's Levelation, a $2.80 favorite, scored a nose victory in the $4,000 Teen-Agers Purse at Gulfstream Park Today.

TUNIS, March 11 -- President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia showed stiff resistance tonight to proposals by British and United States conciliators in the dispute between his country and France. The proposals were brought from Paris.

TAMPA, Fla., March 11 -- Babe Herman was in the kitchen, preparing a feast of Lucullian sumptuousness. The one-time Dodger slugger fancies himself an expert in the culinary league and this was to be a gastronomic treat of such irresistible appeal that it would induce John Callison to sign with the Phillies, the team the Babe was scouting for.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Senator Edward J. Thye, Republican of Minnesota, lost a fight in the Senate today to block plans to lower dairy price supports on April 1.

Subway passengers yesterday were promised a smoother ride by the Transit Authority. The agency approved the expenditure of $557,862.50 for the purchase of a rail-grind ing train and two Diesel locomotives to pull it. If the Board of Estimate follows suit, the units will be delivered in ten months.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Internal Revenue Service announced today that most persons who had expense accounts would not be required to keep detailed records on them for tax returns covering their income for 1958.

ALBANY, March 11 (AP) -- The sponsor of a bill designed to forgive and forget criminal records of first offenders abandoned it in the Senate today under heavy fire from both Republicans and Democrats.

Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, sugar, wool and lead declined; copper, zinc and rubber rose; and price movements for cocoa, potatoes, cottonseed oil and hides were mixed.

The nation's production of raw steel dropped last month to 5,788,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings. This was the lowest monthly level, except for nationwide steel strike periods, since July, 1949, when output was 5,784,831 net tons.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Demands for an investigation into possible leaks of advance information on a discount rate reduction were rebuffed today at a closed session of the House Banking and Currency Committee.
Cotton futures closed 15 points up to three points down on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

The Navy's new missile-firing submarines now under development will represent a new order of magnitude in seagoing weapon systems. The United States today has three missile-firing submarines in commission. But they are conventionally powered slow-speed types that use Diesel engines on the surface and electric batteries submerged, and they must surface frequently.

Mounting pressure to step up Federal road-building expenditures in the next fiscal year makes all the more imperative the need for enacting billboard-control legislation now, at this session of Congress.

Bronx County Judge Samuel Joseph declared yesterday that the major manufacturers of radio and television tubes knew of an illegal rebranding operation that cost the industry and the public about $5,000,000 from 1953 to 1957.

Becker Becker Associates, industrial designers, leased offices in the Seagram Building, rising at 375 Park Avenue, at Fifty-second Street, through Cushman Wakefield, Inc., agent for the building. The lessees are designing all United States technological exhibits for the World's Fair at Brussels.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 11 -- Princeton University and the New Jersey Department of Education will sponsor a six-week program for high school chemistry teachers this summer, it was announced today.

MIAMI, March 11 -- "Where will I play and how will I handle the job?" Such worries are not limited to rookies in spring training camps, but are questions asked in some cases by players who have reached the pinnacle.
Investors added one Washington indication to another yesterday, decided that inflation was just around the corner and reached for the stocks best calculated to serve as hedges.
LOS ANGELES, March 11 -For once, a sword-swallower slipped -- and punctured his own esophagus, with near-fatal consequences.
One of seven teen-age gang members on trial for killing Michael Farmer testified in his own defense yesterday that the Farmer boy had grabbed him by the lapels before the fatal fight started.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 11 (UP) -- Willie Shoemaker, one of America's leading riders, was thrown from his mount and apparently suffered minor injuries today during the running of the fourth race at Santa Anita.

The clearance given by Republican leaders in the Legislature for a $500,000,000 exemption from New York City's debt limit of borrowing to be used for school construction is a beneficial insurance policy. These exempt funds, a grant of bon-issUing power beyond constitutional restrictions, will not be available before 1960, since passage by two Legislatures and approval by statewide referendum must intervene.
CINCINNATI, March 11 -American Opera Auditions announced tonight the eight winners out of 1,000 original entrants in its competition for young singers.

A charity ball to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Junior Women's Club of Leonia, N. J., and to help provide funds for its civic and welfare projects will be held at the clubhouse of the Women's Club of Teaneck, N. J., on March 29.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 11 -- The setting up of an Egyptian-sponsored Palestine Arab government in the Gaza Strip, under the leadership of the former Mufti of Jerusalem, Haj Amain el-Husseini, is thought likely by the Israeli Government.
THESE are Paris' last words on spring fashions: To each his own.

BOSTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics ended New York's last hopes for a National Basketball Association play-off berth tonight by defeating the Knicks, 126 -- 119. It marked the third straight season the Knicks had finished at the bottom of the Eastern Division and failed to make the play-offs.

WHEN Eugene O'Neill created a slattern, he didn't mince words. In his one-character, one-acter, "Before Breakfast," put on by ANTA yesterday as a special matinee at the Theatre de Lys, Eileen Heckart has gone him one better.
MADRID, March 11 -- High Spanish military circles are weighing the possibility of a defense arrangement with Britain for command of the Strait of Gibraltar on behalf of the Western world.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has cleared for offering more than $25,000,000 of new preferred and common stock of the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company.
All officers were re-elected at the annual meeting of the American Kennel Club at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.
The National Book Awards for 1958 went yesterday to John Cheever for fiction, Catherine Drinker Bowen for non-fiction and Robert Penn Warren for poetry.

NEW ORLEANS, March 11 (UP) -- Two Californians, Ken Venturi of San Francisco and Bill Casper of Apple Valley, shot spectacular final rounds today in the $20,000 New Orleans open to finish in a dead heat with 278 each for seventy-two holes.
NEWARK, March 11 -- The Central Railroad of New Jersey "is heading for bankruptcy" under its present operations, the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners was advised today.

In his letter published March 5 captioned "Investigating Scientists," Herbert Pell draws an interesting parallel between the absence of freedom of inquiry in Nazi Germany and the situation existing in our own country during and immediately following the McCarthy probes.
GREAT NECK, L. I., March 11 -- Science teachers from eight states completed a two-day conference here today with a statement that "the time is now" to revise and improve science teaching.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, said tonight that soft living was starting to produce young Americans who were reluctant either to work hard or to make real sacrifices for their country.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Administration's $625,000,000 request for the new Development Loan Fund was described today as "the barest minimum" for carrying the program forward in the new fiscal year.

Two years ago today a distinguished Spanish-Basque professor at Columbia University named Jesus de Galindez entered the subway to go home. He has never been heard from since. The story is so astonishing and so spectacular and is lit up by such a mass of lurid details, most true and some speculative, that it has already formed the subject for a half-dozen "whodunits."
WASHINGTON, March 11 -A Kohler Company employe told the Senate rackets committee today that a beating by strike sympathizers had contributed to his father's death.
A hearing on a stockholders' petition to inspect records of the Republic Pictures Corporation was postponed to next Tuesday in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday by Justice Joseph A. Gavagan.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 11 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has encountered its first serious problem, and the studio hopes it will be the only one, in making "Ben Hur." The Government of Libya has canceled a permit granted the company to film background scenes for the drama about early Christianity on locations already chosen in the North African desert country.

UNITED NATIONS, March 11 -- United States sources said today that a projected request for a meeting of the United Nations Disarmament Commission had not been filed. The request is being held up pending a Soviet reply to a United States suggestion for a companion meeting of the Security Council.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York voted yesterday against proposed Federal legislation to reverse the United States Supreme Court's decision in the case of Steve Nelson, a Pittsburgh Communist party leader.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 11 -- Brazil, beset by a grave financial crisis, was reported tonight to be seeking substantial emergency assistance abroad. She needs the aid to meet her international obligations this year and go on importing vitally needed goods.
A survey by the National Industrial Conference Board for Newsweek Magazine indicates that business spending will slide through 1958 and possibly into 1959.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -The deepening economic recession produced a flurry of taxcutting talk today without visibly improving prospects for early Congressional action.
MOSCOW, March 11 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev declined tonight to discuss with Western newsmen any serious problems, including a summit meeting of Communist and non-Communist heads of government.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- The House Armed Services Committee, by unanimous vote, called on the defense department today to abandon plans for a 10 per cent cut in the Army National Guard and Army Reserve.
A new program of incentives for industrial investment in Ireland and expansion of free-trade zone operations at Shannon Airport were announced by Irish officials yesterday.

Manhattan College's basketball team, which had been wondering not so much "Is this trip necessary?" as "Is it possible?" will be flying to Charlotte, N. C., tomorrow. The local Jaspers earned this junket to the site of the Eastern regionals of the National Collegiate court championship by engineering the sport's biggest upset of the year last night at Madison Square Garden.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., March 11 -- After six months of being shunted about, Commander of 'Gansett has finally found a home.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 11 (Reuters) -- The Sudan's pro-Western Umma (People's) party chalked up impressive gains in the nation's first general election.
BONN, Germany, March 11 -- A national campaign against atomic armament and the stationing of United States missile bases in West Germany was announced today on front pages of many leading newspapers.
PETROS, Tenn., March 11 (AP) -- Guards fired at 300 convicts in the state prison tonight to put down a renewed outburst of violence. A prisoner was shot in the cheek and taken to a hospital.

The Rev. Dr. J. Percival Huget, pastor of the Classon Avenue Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn, died yesterday at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Franklin E. Reed of Cheshire, Conn., after an illness of three weeks.

Ten pints of rare B-RH Negative blood left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday by plane for Norfolk, Va. They were the gift of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program to an ailing Greek seaman in a hospital in Norfolk.
ATA_NY, March 11 (UP)Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
ATLANTIC CITY, March 11 -- Marked differences of opinion on traffic safety were expressed today by various experts.
Walter D. Hoag of the Yale Club won the only match played yesterday as the National Squash Tennis Association championship tournament opened on the Harvard Club's courts.

March is the month in which Hungarians celebrate the anniversary of the revolution led by their great patriot Kossuth in 1848. To commemorate the event this year, John Day will publish on March 27 Emil Lengyel's history entitled "1,000 Years on Hungary."
As official inquiries into the city's Bureau of Real Estate widened yesterday, Mayor Wagner's office conceded that eighteen months ago he was warned to revise many of the bureau's procedures.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Atomic Energy Commission conceded today that a small underground atomic explosion in Nevada last summer had been detected in Alaska, more than 2,000 miles away.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- President Eisenhower welcomed his wife back from a two-week Arizona vacation today with a kiss.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 11 -- A new Federal Parliament of 301 Deputies is to be elected in Yugoslavia March 23.

BAYONNE, N. J., March 11 -- Five Navy prisoners disarmed their guards this morning on the decommissioned battleship Wisconsin. They escaped from the Bayonne Naval Supply Depot, but were recaptured within a half-hour.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 11 -- The Government has begun an operation of the combined services for a knock-out punch against the Central Sumatran rebels.
TIFLIS, U. S. S. R., March 11 -- Prematurely sunny weather has blessed Soviet Georgia, and a thousand unexpected vacationers poured in last week.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Ignoring Republican warnings of a Presidential veto, the House passed a bill today to authorize future construction of $1,500,000,000 worth of water projects.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A proposal to revise the Supreme Court's decision last June in the Mallory case, involving confessions of Federal prisoners, was reported to the House Judiciary Committee today. Meanwhile, Senate hearings on the issue resumed.

Enkells-Rakoff Co., realty operators, who recently bought the six-story apartment building at 4528-36 Broadway, opposite Fort Tryon Park on Washington Heights, have resold the property to an investing client of Benjamin Housman, attorney.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- United States officials see short-term gains and long-term dangers in President Gamal Abdel Nasser's new eminence as chief of the United Arab Republic of Egypt and Syria.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 11 (AP) -- The American movie "Paths of Glory," withdrawn here last week after several demonstrations, will resume Friday with a foreword to smooth French pride.
LONDON, March 11 -- Price movements on the stock exchange showed no firm trend here today. The end of the bookkeeping account tended to depress prices but toward the close they tended to harden.
ALBANY, March 11 -- A 128-year-old restriction on the right of property owners to set up trusts effective after they die will be eliminated this year.
A 17-year-old student was indicted yesterday for carrying a dangerous weapon. He had shot a boy in the Manual Training High School March 4.

Buying at the six-day International Toy Fair at the Statler Hilton Hotel has been spotty. Exhibitors at the show, which opened Sunday, said bookings were better than expected despite the recession. A good deal of the ordering was for Christmas selling.
The New York State Board of Regents and WOR-TV have reached tentative agreement on a plan to use Channel 9 for educational television.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -The Senate rejected today proposals to delay indefinitely an extension of the east front of the Capitol Building by thirty-two feet and six inches.

HAVANA, Wednesday, March 12 -- Constitutional guarantees were automatically restored in Oriente Province today when a forty-five-day suspension period expired. Oriente is a center of revolutionary activity against the Government of President Fulgencio Batista.
One of the biggest men on Penn State's campus these days is a crew-cut 130-pounder named Johnny Johnston.
Women will be paying more for their dresses as a result of yesterday's strike settlement, industry spokesmen said here yesterday.

IT'S nearly nine years now since John Brooks' "The Big Wheel" was published. That incisive, engrossing and penetrating study of moral dilemmas inside the editorial staff of an important news magazine was an exceptionally impressive first novel. Five years later came Mr. Brooks' second novel, "A Pride of Lions."
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- The House Judiciary Committee rejected today a Republican-sponsored constitutional amendment to settle the 179-year-old problem of Presidential disability.

OTTAWA, March 11 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's deficit in international payments rose to a record $1,383,000,000 in 1957 from the previous peak of $1,372,000,000 in 1956, the Bureau of Statistics said today.

WARSAW, March 11 -- Two journalists were acquitted today of charges that they had disclosed state secrets. Their trial generally is regarded by Western observers as a test case for Polish newspaper men.

Mayors from near-by towns and villages were guests of the New York International Flower Show yesterday. Mayor Wagner opened the Mayor's Day activities at the Coliseum.
As befits a man who has spent more than twenty years patching up quarrels between angry labor and angry management, Harry Uviller believes deeply in peace.

Two polo matches to be played at the 101st Cavalry Armory at Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street on March 27 will aid the Judson Health Center. The players will represent Squadron A, Westchester County, Long Island and sub-urban New Jersey.
Greatly improved products would serve as the best spur to lagging sales, according to a survey among 1,100 marketing and business executives.
The New York Infirmary will benefit from a gala premiere dinner when Maurice Chevalier opens in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria on April 7.
The American Women's Voluntary Services, Inc., yesterday, elected Mrs. Walter S. Mack national president at the first meeting of the organization's new board of directors.

The nation's known reserves of crude oil declined last year for the first time since 1943, but proved reserves of natural gas reached a new peak, according to a report of the American Petroleum Institute and the American Gas Association.

FRITZ REINER is a masterful conductor, and the Philadelphia Orchestra is a masterly ensemble. Thus many lovers of orchestral music assembled at Carnegie Hall last night with high expectations, for the concert gave New Yorkers their first chance to hear Mr. Reiner lead the orchestra in this city.

The six-story apartment building for 130 families at 789 St. Marks Avenue in Brooklyn has been acquired by Klausner Associates, real estate operators and investors. The Project Realty Corporation was the seller. Pearce, Mayer Greer were the brokers in the deal.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 11 -- Negotiations between the Screen Actors Guild and TV film commercial-makers are now expected to result in agreement on a new collective bargaining contract in the near future, according to reliable reports. The talks are being held in New York between guild officials and TV film commercial producers and the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

MANILA, Wednesday, March 12 -- Secretary of State Dulles told the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization this morning that its military forces were now ready to "respond immediately" to Communist aggression against any nation of the alliance.

MESA, Ariz., March 11 -- Although the Chicago Cubs have spent the past decade in the second division, the organization has the romantic notion that it is headed for a rich bundle of goodies in the 1958 National League race.

MICHAEL TATE is 14 years old, of the generation that may inherit outer space. In his bedroom at 37-32 Seventy-seventh Street in Jackson Heights out in Queens he has finished a nine-foot, three-finned rocket that should streak upward a full five miles or more.

DETROIT, March 11 (UP) -- Camille Henry scored his thirty-second goal of the season midway in the final period tonight to pull the New York Rangers into a 2-2 tie with the Detroit Red Wings that clinched a Stanley Cup play-off berth for the Rangers.
