A new line of tractors for farm and industrial use comprises the first American-made diesel products of the Ford Motor Company, it was announced yesterday. The tractors will go on display in dealer showrooms on Friday.

IT is good to hear Arthur Miller speaking in the theatre again. It is especially good to hear him speaking again through "The Crucible," which was given a superb revival last night in the new theatre in the round that has been fashioned in the Martinique Hotel.
WARSAW, Wednesday, March 12 -- Mr. Khrushchev said in an interview published here today that a foreign ministers' meeting to prepare a conference of heads of government was "probably inevitable."
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Senate approved tonight an appropriation bill carrying $14,399,000 for United States participation in the Brussels world's fair opening next month.

BOWIE, Md., March 11 (UP) -- A pair of long shots scored victories in the first two races at Bowie today for a $1,155,80 daily double and Pancho Villa posted an upset in the feature sprint for 3-year-olds.

The Esso Standard Oil Company, domestic affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), announced yesterday a reduction in the prices of home heating oil, kerosene and diesel fuel by 0.2 cent to 0.5 cent a gallon in its eighteen-state marketing area from Maine to Louisiana.
The American Committee for the Protection of the Foreign Born was ordered yesterday to stop soliciting funds unless the committee is registered as a charitable organization.

The outbreak of violence among teen-agers in our schools and the steady increase of juvenile delinquency reveal our tragic failure to cope with this human cancer. As a student of human behavior I believe that it is necessary for us to start to re-evaluate our basic method of raising our children.
LONDON, March 11 -- Considerable progress has been made toward a summit conference, Prime Minister Harold Macmillan told the House fo Commons today.

Vassily Smyslov, back at the board after three days of illness, played forty-one moves to adjournment last night in the third game of his world chess title match with Mikhail Botvinnik at the Tchaikovsky Concert Hall in Moscow.
The Hospital Council of Greater New York announced its endorsement yesterday of plans for a 350-bed teaching and research hospital at the State University's Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.
THE custom collection shown at Stein Blaine yesterday offered sixteen ways in which round women can escape the square sack this spring.
NEW CITY, N. Y., March 12 -- Building trades students in seven Rockland County high schools are constructing a school for handicapped children as part of their training.

BOWIE, Md., March 12 (UP) -Corso, a lightly-campaigned bay colt, moved past tiring horses in the stretch at Bowie today to gain a half-length victory in the $3,500 Glenwood Purse for 3year-olds. The winner is owned by Mrs. Milton Erlanger.

Fulfilling expectations, Mikhail Botvinnik, the challenger for the world chess championship, yesterday gained his third consecutive victory in his return match with Vassily Smyslov in Moscow after sixty-six moves, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.
LONDON, March 12 -- Britain's trading deficit last month was the smallest of any month since World War II with two exceptions.

June Summers, a pianist and composer from Michigan, was heard last night in a Carnegie Hall concert with members of the Symphony of the Air. She played Mozart's Concerto No. 15 (K. 450), Beethoven's "Emperor" Concerto and her own Piano Concerto No. 2 subtitled "The Age of Love."

Guideposts for Children, Inc., of Lenox Hill Hospital will benefit from the first annual Jewel Ball, sponsored by Cartier, Inc. The event will take place March 22 in the Carnaval and Crystal Pavilion of the Sherry-Netherland.
ALBANY, March 12 -- The Bronx and Queens lost again today their fight to get representation on the New York City Board of Elections.

A dance and fashion show for the support of the Community Homemaker Service of Bergen County will be held at the Community Center in Englewood on March 22. The sponsor of the event is the Northern Valley Section, National Council of Jewish Women.
The dress industry followed the union yesterday in giving formal approval to the settlement of the week-long strike of 105,000 dressmakers.

Cotton futures lost 5 to 26 points (25 cents to $1.30 a bale) yesterday and closed at the lows of the day as weakness developed late in the session. Persistent late selling by New Orleans interests touched off general selling and prices reacted 17 to 34 points from the highs of the day.

The dream of getting educational television off the ground in New York State may at last be capable of realization. M. and on Saturday until noon.

The nation's production of crude oil and natural gas liquids in the week ended last Friday declined 513,550 barrels a day to 6,327,735, according to the weekly figures of the American Petroleum Institute. The reduction reflected the reduction in March in the allowable production in many states.

Cocoa futures tumbled in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Only the distant positions did not decline the daily limit of 1 cent a pound. The spot March position, which has no limit, dropped 140 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).

Electric power production in the week ended last Saturday dropped to 11,793,000,000 kilowatthours from 11,803,000,000 kilowatt-hours the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended March 9, 1957, was 11,867,000,000 kilowatthours.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 12 -- An arrival at Dodgertown today was a young man who is either the most bashful or the most polite player in the major leagues.

DAYTON, March 12 (AP) -- Five Air Force officers began a simulated flight today to determine what effect long confinement in close quarters had on morale and efficiency.

The Liberty Mutual Insurance Company reported 1957 premiums of $304,837,208, highest in the company's history, according to the annual report released yesterday. This was a gain of 12.7 per cent, or $34,357,861, over 1956.

The United States Rubber Company plans to close its footwear manufacturing plant at Milan, Tenn., in July. The 275 employes will be laid off by groups, beginning early in April, the company announced yesterday.

In the wake of steady and almost universally gloomy news from other sectors of the economy, the Flintkote Company announced yesterday that its Meridian, Miss., insulation board plant, which has been operating on a five-day week for the past year, would go on a seven-day, three-shift schedule immediately.

The Council for Financial Aid to Education chose Dr. Frank Hugh Sparks as its new president yesterday. He formerly was president and board chairman of Wabash College. Dr. Sparks replaces Dr. Norman P. Auburn, who will return to his post as president of the University of Akron.

Judged by its timing, the statement issued by Vice President Nixon concerning the Administration's future plans for dealing with the economic recession, now eight months old, was defensive in nature. Its immediate purpose appeared to be to take the sting out of the latest figures of the Department of Commerce on consumer buying.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12 (AP) -- Nominations for the Emmy awards of the Academy of Television Arts and Science were announced today. Winners from among the list of 125 nominees will be disclosed April 15 after voting by Academy members.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 12 -On the outer rim of each of the three tracks at Ben White Raceway and close to the lanes that run to the barns are long rows of benches. In the beginning, the rows weren't so long. The original benches were placed so that trainers and their assistants could sit while awaiting turns to exercise the harness horses under their command.

To gain thirty-two and a half feet of space at a cost of more than ten million dollars the Commission for Extension of the United States Capitol under whiplash of Speaker Sam Rayburn is going doggedly ahead with its plan to vandalize the oldest part of this beautiful and historic building.
YONKERS, March 12 -- At least 102 automobile owners found flat tires today on their cars parked in a half-mile section of Bronx River Road in southeast Yonkers, adjacent to the Bronx River Parkway.
THE stores that made fashion names for themselves on Fifty-seventh Street must now remove them -- at least from their canopies.
ALBANY, March 12 -- Legislation to make annulments based on fraud more difficult to obtain narrowly passed the Assembly today. It now goes to Governor Harriman
TRENTON, March 12 -- Johnson Johnson has made known a decision to cease expansion in New Jersey because of a proposed net-income tax on business.

David S. Meister, realty investor, has purchased a row of four five-story apartment houses at 420-26 East Eightieth Street, between First and York Avenues. The buildings occupy a plot 103 by 100 feet and contain two stores and thirty-eight four-room apartments.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 12 (AP) -- Maryland, Manhattan and Dartmouth, winners of the opening National Collegiate basketball tournament play in New York last night, move into Eastern regional competition at the Charlotte Coliseum Friday night, along with Temple.
Wilt Chamberlain of Kansas yesterday was named to the United Press all-America basketball team for the second straight year and received the highest total of votes in the history of the poll.
Thomas J. Lipton, Inc., food producer, achieved record sales and earnings last year, Robert Smallwood, chairman, reported yesterday in the annual statement.

BOSTON, March 12 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers defeated the Boston Celtics, 127125, in the wind-up of regular season play tonight. The Celtics' Bob Cousy captured his sixth straight National Basketball Association playmaking title.

One of the factors that has made America great is its concern for every individual citizen and his right to a fair share of life's opportunities. Much of America's concern for every man is demonstrated through its governmental programs of assistance.
AHMADI, Kuwait, March 12 -- A gala ceremony marked a milestone today in Kuwait's development in the inauguration of two refining units to handle 160,000 barrels of crude oil a day.

TRENTON, March 12 -- A legislative hearing on four bills to tighten and clarify New Jersey's Sunday observance law drew a larger crowd to the State Assembly chamber today than any other event since 1948.
PASCAGOULA, Miss., March 12 -- A second new American luxury liner to travel between New York and the east coast of South America was launched today.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- A split among baseball player representatives developed today over a bill in Congress to establish the business status of professional sports.

WASHINGTON, March 12--Dr. Willard F. Libby, acting chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, assured Senator Hubert H. Humphrey today that the commission's error on the detection of the underground nuclear test last September was inadvertent and nonpolitical.

Three leaders of political opposition groups in the United States, Britain and France agreed in a symposium last night that an international summit conference should be held in an attempt to steer the world toward real peace.

IF Mark Twain had set Tom Sawyer to tell the story of the California gold rush, the result might have been a novel rather like "The Travels of Jaimie McPheeters."* Or so one may imagine. At any rate, this is the most entertaining narrative about the Argonauts of 1849 I have read in years of wandering through the adventurous realms of gold.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- Christopher T. Chenery's Yemen closed strongly in the middle of the track to gain a half-length victory in the $10,000 Hutcheson Stakes before 17,925 spectators today at Gulfstream Park.

Insurgent members of strifetorn Local 88 of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots moved yesterday to take control of the local. Officers of two factions took possession of the union's office at 105-7 Washington Street and announced their intention of remaining all night.

In your March 4 editorial entitled "The Benson Issue" you say, "It is doubtful that, even among those critics who profess to regard his policies as unsound, one could be found who would be prepared to meet the Secretary of Agriculture in open debate in public, which proves this much at least -- that though they may not know much about agricultural economics they at least have a highly developed instinct for survival."
A great deal of thought and planning goes into creating the floral arrangements that are a top attraction at the International Flower Show at the Coliseum.
A seminar on safety completed the undergraduate training of seventy-five drivers who received New York State operator's licenses yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12 -- The screen writers branch of the Writers Guild of America, West, tonight staged its annual frolic and awards presentation ceremony. The only serious note in the proceedings was the announcement of the prize-winners.

WITH a group of artists, most of whom are well known to visitors at New York exhibitions, the new Nordness Gallery has opened at 700 Madison Avenue. Many of the examples in the first "family" show are on loan from museums and private collections.
The National Invitation Tournament, the nation's oldest post-season basketball competition, will start in Madison Square Garden tonight for the twenty-first time.

Ivan C. McLeod, regional director here of the National Labor Relations Board, has recommended the nullification of a representation election held among the operating employes of the Sixty-ninth Street Brooklyn Ferry Corporation.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -The Senate passed tonight the session's first major anti-recession measure -- a $1,850,000,000 emergency housing bill. The vote was 86 to 0.

Your competent correspondent Elie Abel's dispatch in The New York Times of March 4 gave some inkling of the coercion under which religious leaders function in present-day Rumania. It was evident from the dispatch that Chief Rabbi Jacob Rosen, for example, suffers from severe limitations on his conduct and utterances.
A Swiss stamp worth 10 cents was the guest of honor at a luncheon here yesterday.
A leading economist took issue yesterday with proposals for widespread Federal tax cuts and sharply increased Government spending.

FLORENCE, S. C., March 12 (UP) -- Air Force decontamination and nuclear accident teams and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation rushed here today and closed the area in which an unarmed atomic bomb fell yesterday.

Constitutional guarantees have been suspended in Cuba, including automatic imposition of censorship on press and radio, on numerous occasions since March 10, 1952, when General Batista seized power in a military coup.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -The Supreme Court heard argument today on the validity of so-called "hot cargo" clauses in labor contracts.
PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (AP) -- Billie Holiday, night-club singer, was placed on probation for a year today after pleading guilty to possession of narcotics charges.

Floyd Patterson, the world heavyweight champion, will sail for England today aboard the Cunard liner Saxonia. Constantine (Cus) D'Amato, Patterson's manager, will accompany the fighter. Dan Florio, the champion's trainer, and two sparring partners, Obidiah Rhodes and Aaron Watson, also will make the trip.
District Attorney Edward S. Silver said yesterday that his Staff had requested the photographs of 153 policemen for use in a grand jury investigation of a bookmaking syndicate.
DENVER, March 12 (AP) -- An upturn in copper production and prices as soon as general business conditions improve was predicted today by Roy H. Glover, chairman of the Anaconda Company.
Reports reaching here last night said Brig. Gen. Antonio Kebreau, Haiti's strongman, has resigned as Chief of Staff of the armed forces and will leave Port-au-Prince shortly for Paris.
NO parent should try to be both a mother and father to a child. This can confuse the child about the roles of the sexes at a time when lasting impressions are formed.

TAMPA, Fla., March 12 -- "The most exciting player I've seen all spring," said Birdie Tebbetts, "is Vada Pinson. He's a 20-year-old outfielder with only a Class C background but he hit .367 and stole fiftythree bases. Common sense tells me he can't make my Cincinnati varsity and yet the feeling persists that he's another Frank Robinson, the kid who came from nowhere to stardorm"

FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 12 (AP) -- Holly Mims floored Spider Webb for a nine count in the sixth round tonight and punched his way to a unanimous ten-round upset decision. Webb, a Chicagoan, weighed 157 1/2 pounds and Mims 154 1/4 for the Fort Wayne Coliseum fight.
ALBANY, March 12 -- An advisory council of three Democrats and two Republicans to help with the investigation of the legislative payroll was named today by the legislative leaders of both parties.
ALBERTSON, L. I., March 12 -- Abilities, Inc., announced today that the general decline in the nation's economy had forced a temporary lay-off of sixty-five of the company's 309 disabled employes.

A plot of land zoned for industry along the Bronx River, between Westchester and Watson Avenues, the Bronx, has been sold by the Rosedale Engineering Corporation. The site, 200 by 110 feet, was bought by Harvey D. Krautman for improvement with a one-story factory building.
A move to forestall extensive road changes in the Washington Square redevelopment was made yesterday by the Washington Square Association.

By the style standards that prevail in collective bargaining generally, labor-management relations in the garment industry always have been as unorthodox as the chemise look. The settlement in the dress industry strike opens what may prove the most distinctive chapter in this unusual record of union -employer cooperation.

CHICAGO, March 12 (AP) -Some scarce high choice and prime offerings were among the slaughter steers today and buyers here paid $34.50 to $37.50 for them, the highest price since Jan. 21, 1953 when the grade brought $38.10.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Tax cut or public works -which is the better way of halting the recession?

MANILA, March 12 -- The foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France decided here today on the next step to be taken in dealing with Soviet proposals for a heads - of - government conference.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Representatives of two aluminum fabricating industries accused the larger aluminum producers today of choking competition by pricecutting tactics. David Laine, secretary of the American Die Casting Institute, told a House small business subcommittee that the Reynolds Metals Company "hot metal" contracts with General Motors and Ford were "no more and no less than out and out price cutting on a discriminatory basis."
Judith Anderson, absent from the Broadway stage since 1953, has signed contracts with Cheryl Crawford and Alan Pakula to star in a new play, "Comes a Day," by Speed Lamkin.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -President Eisenhower was confronted today with what is becoming an increasingly troublesome and critical problem in policy-making. This is how the Executive Branch of the Government is to reach immensely serious decisions involving the security of the nation when faced with conflicting testimony by the nation's scientists.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -A devotee of sailing on Chesapeake Bay has taken over the ticklish job of steering the House Legislative Oversight Subcommittee's course through the troubled waters of the Federal regulatory agencies.
PARIS, March 12 (AP) -- The Press Committee of the French National Assembly adopted a resolution of protest today against the police seizures of newspapers in Algeria and France.

A grocer who was held up last night on the upper East Side grabbed his rifle from a shelf, chased the two thugs in cabs and shot and captured one of them. A passer-by was also shot during the chase, but was not seriously wounded, the police said.

LIKE a fast-stepping bantamweight who isn't going to stand for any of that sparring stuff but is going right in there and punch it out for the grand prize, a 5 foot 2 inch tall chanteuse from Paris named Patachou came out on the stage of the Bijou last night, took a deep breath, and sailed right into her first song.
MOSCOW, March 12 (AP) -Sol Hurok signed an agreement today to bring the famous Bolshoi Theatre Ballet to the United States for a tour. A number of details remain to be worked out.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 12 -- New Jersey's urban and industrial growth has increased the need for effective mosquito control, Dr. William H. Martin declared here today. Dr. Martin is director of the state Agricultural Experiment Station.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon is the subject of a biography being written by Earl Mazo of The New York Herald Tribune's Washington staff. Mr. Mazo has traveled with the Vice President on many trips in this country and abroad.

IRELAND is more richly endowed with fine food than any spot on earth. Nowhere is the soil more fertile, the grass greener or the beef more tender. The prawns of Dublin Bay are the sweetest, the salmon from Eire's lakes and rivers are the most delicate and the oysters from Galway Bay are the essence of succulence.

City franchise tax relief totaling $1,244,850 a year for nine privately owned bus lines was recommended yesterday to the Board of Estimate. The relief was proposed largely to help the companies meet rising labor costs.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 13 (AP) -- Denver defeated Clarkson, 6 -- 2, tonight and gained the final of the National Collegiate hockey tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 13 -- The United States pressed the Hungarian Government today to reveal the fate of twenty-four prominent Hungarian citizens who disappeared or were jailed after the antiSoviet revolt of 1956.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Senator Barry Goldwater accused the United Auto Workers today of waging the Kohler Company strike on a rule of violence.

News from Cape Canaveral about the latest efforts to fire a Vanguard rocket has been unhappy. Time and again the scheduled firing has had to be postponed, sometimes because of weather conditions, sometimes because of mechanical malfunction detected in the countdown process.

MADRID, March 13 -- Senora de Franco, wife of the Spanish chief of state, and Fernando Maria Castiella, the Spanish Foreign Minister, will call tomorrow on Don Juan, Count of Barcelona and leading claimant of the vacant Spanish throne.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point off to 7 points (5 to 35 cents a bale) up yesterday. The only significant price fluctuations were in the near-by March, which expired at 12:30 P. M., closing at 35.26 cents, or 34 points, below the previous close.

The tenth annual April Ball, a subscription dance for postdebutantes, bachelors and young married couples, will take place on April 18 in the Sheraton-East (formerly the Ambassador). The event is under the direction of Mrs. Audrey M. Winston.

ALBANY, March 13 -- A bill resolving the conflict over taxes between the State Power Authority and Niagara County was introduced in the Legislature today. Governor Harriman announced that he would sign the bill when it reaches his desk.
THE "country look," the latest rage in urban decor, is a mid-Twentieth Century style that may, in time to come, claim the attention of sociologists.

WESTPORT, Conn., March 13 -- For fifty years, since he was a boy, Oscar W. Peterson has been tapping the five maples in front of his old farmhouse on the Boston Post Road here for sap. It is flowing now at the rate of twelve gallons a day from each tree.

Yvon Durelle and Tony Anthony will meet tonight in the most important light-heavyweight bout of the indoor boxing season. They are scheduled to go ten rounds at Madison Square Garden, and the winner will generally be regarded as the foremost challenger for the 175-pound class championship, now held by Archie Moore.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -The Eisenhower Administration and Democratic leaders of Congress have reached an understanding that may produce a bipartisan tax-relief bill to help stem the economic recession.

In a deal in the Crown Heights area of Brooklyn, the four-story apartment building at 1453 Prospect Place, corner of Rochester Avenue, has been sold by the Nagil Realty Corporation. The property is 127 by 100 feet and contains fifty-two apartments and three stores.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A big-game hunter will soon be in charge of the Federal budget.

ALBANY, March 13 -- Most of the state's Supreme Court justice's were placed on record today in opposition to the Tweed court reform program. Their stand may prove a fatal obstacle to the program in this session of the Legislature.
Snow, mixed with rain in many places, fell in New York New Jersey and Connecticut last night. New Jersey was the hardest hit.
CAIRO, Egypt, March 13 (AP) -- Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, and Orlando Garrido of Cuba gained the men's doubles final today in Cairo's tennis tournament.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 13 -- Georgi Konstantinovich Skriabin, a Russian microbiologist, has taken up a program of research at Rutgers University under the new cultural and technical exchange agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union.
GLASGOW, Scotand, March 13 -- The by-election tide continued to run strongly against the Government today as the Labor party won the traditionally Conservative Kelvingrove constituency here.

It was "business as usual" yesterday for Local 88, of the Masters, Mates and Pilots, although the two factions struggling for control maintained around-the-clock occupancy of the local's headquarters at 107 Washington Street.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -Following are excerpts from the discussion in the Disarmament subcommitte of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on the "lost atomic bomb" and the possibility of detecting underground atomic explosions.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 13 -- The nation might as well be alerted. It is almost certain there will be a terrific explosion soon and it won't be a satellite flattening itself against the moon. It will be Casey Stengel hitting a ceiling.

The Motormen's Benevolent Association yesterday demanded damages of $8,575,000 from the Transit Authority because the authority had "bugged" union headquarters.
"WHY is it that a nation whose scientists can smash an atom cannot teach its people to break a prejudice?"

LOS ANGELES, March 13 -Atomic explosions up to ten times the power of the World War II Hiroshima bomb may be within a couple years an every-day occurrence almost anywhere in the country under a program being pressed by scientists of the Atomic Energy Commission.
Sixty-second "singing editorials" in favor of fluoridation will make their debut on radio station WMCA next week.

CAIRO, March 13 -- The Communist-sponsored Afro-Asian People's Solidarity Council launched a campaign today in support of the Algerian rebels. It offered the use of its headquarters and propaganda machinery to the Algerian National Liberation Front, political arm of the rebellion against France.
The State of Massachusetts announced yesterday plans to borrow $96,877,000 in the bond market on April 16.

Details of the new joint organizing campaign of the teamsters and longshore unions were disclosed yesterday by Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, independent.
DALLAS, Tex., March 13 -- Although Margo Jones died three years ago, she is still a potent force in the theatre of the Southwest.

TORONTO, March 13 (AP) -- A wealthy Toronto hotel and mining executive, three New York investors and a North Bay prospector have been charged with theft, fraud and conspiracy involving $960,000, the Ontario Securities Commission said today.

MANILA, March 13 -- Secretary of State Dulles at a news conference today termed "ridiculous" the unwillingness of the Russians to have any agreements now with the West unless there was a summit conference.
Stocks went through an inconclusive but active session yesterday, starting lower, rising steadily until about 3 P. M. and then selling off.

The fourth annual meeting of the Southeast Asia Treaty Council held in Manila and attended by the foreign ministers of eight Western and Asian nations has ended on a note of determination to intensify the common effort to safeguard the area against Communist military aggression and subversion.
ST. LOUIS, March 13 -- Three thousand delegates were present tonight at the opening of the twenty-first triennial convention of the Young Women's Christian Association.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -Government reports projected today further downward pressure on the economy in two key sectors of demand.

An officer of the National Association of Claimants' Compensation Attorneys replied yesterday to an attack by Dr. Emil Seletz, neurosurgeon, on the legal profession and the tactics of lawyers. Dr. Seletz spoke Monday before the International College of Surgeons in Los Angeles.

A plan for a thirty-six-foot-wide roadway through Washington Square Park was submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack. The board referred the proposal to the City Planning Commission for a public hearing and report.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 13 (AP) -- The Government announced today the capture of the oil fields near Pakanbaru, in rebellious Central Sumatra, and said the Caltex Pacific Oil Company was now free to resume operations.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -The White House announced today the retirement of Lieut. Gen. Donald L. Putt, chief of Air Force development. The announcement prompted immediate comparison with the Gavin case.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 13 -- Four policemen were arraigned here today in the burglaries of a shoe store and a lumber company. They were accused of carting their loot away in squad cars.

Ticket sellers for the New York Central Railroad reported that sales yesterday morning and at noon were "like in a subway rush." The reason was a 7.5 per cent increase in some fares that went into effect last midnight.
HOUSTON, March 13 -- A leader of the American Council for Judaism urged American Jews tonight to dissociate themselves from those American Jewish organizations that are "Zionist-dominated."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 13 -- "Playhouse 90" has a World War II comedy and a drama about Hollywood scheduled for production on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
TEHERAN, Iran, Friday, March 14 (AP) -- The Royal Court announced today that the Shah of Iran has divorced 25-year-old Queen Soraya because she has not given him a child.

This is the time of year, above all others, when we pay tribute to the world of books, to the thousands of authors, agents, publishers, editors, artists, designers, lithographers, printers, binders and booksellers whose joint efforts bring us more than 10,000 spanking new titles each year in this country alone.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- American exports in January totaled $1,510,900,000, a drop of 8 per cent from December and about 10 per cent below January, 1957. The Department of Commerce, in reporting this today, said the total included about $108,000,000 of military shipments.
The Radio Corporation of America outlined yesterday a program that it hopes will eliminate illegal rebranding of its radio and television tubes.
Few except careful readers of The Times know that the budget which the Legislature has adopted cut in half the appropriation for state reimbursement to local Boards of Education for adult education.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 -- Stan Musial is the most unpretentious of baseball's super-stars. Fame has brushed so gently against him that it hasn't left a mark. Except for some twenty pounds in weight and a few hundred thousand dollars in bank balance, the Cardinal slugger hasn't changed from the friendly, gracious, obliging and eternally smiling youngster who reported to St. Louis in September of 1941.

ELBERT SEVERANCE was a farm boy around Hutchinson and Beloit in Kansas, long years ago. He got to know a lot then about broody hens and their chicks. One of his uncles pioneered with learned husbandmen at Cornell University in the air shipment of new-born chicks between New York and Egypt.

LONDON, March 13 -- Stock market trading was subdued today. This was ascribed to the shortage of money following heavy new capital calls, further doubts about the American business outlook, rising unemployment in this country and the possible effects of the pay increase awarded to London's busmen by an arbitration court.

The difficulty of agreeing on any constructive agenda for a summit conference demonstrates again that the fundamental contradiction between the ideological concepts of the super-powers is the basic problem of the United Nations, left unsolved by the U. N. Charter.

Seymour M. Wilson, former chief accountant of the city's Bureau of Real Estate, was arrested yesterday on a charge of grand larceny. He was accused of stealing $10,000 to $20,000 of the bureau's funds by manipulating bank accounts that he controlled.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Speaker Sam Rayburn's proposal for a simple statute to deal with the problem of Presidential disability came to an apparent dead end today in the House Judiciary Committee.
Leaders of the textile industry assailed sharply yesterday the Administration's reciprocal trade program and one of its leading advocates.
New York City is in real estate in a big way. As a property owner it is worth more than $4,000,000,000, and as a tenant it pays out nearly $4,000,000 a year in rent.

The six municipal colleges must have state aid to meet operating costs, Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, said yesterday. Otherwise, he said, they may have to reduce the number of admissions next fall.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 544,173 cars, the Association of American Railroads reported today.
Ontario is planning to borrow $75,000,000 in the United States market, according to a registration statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A. R. Fisher, chairman and president of the Johns-Manville Corporation, told the annual stockholders meeting yesterday in Manville, N. J., it was too early to "predict realistically" what the company's sales and profits would be this year.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 13 -- With dormitory accommodations for 250 in its resplendent new field house, the Naval Academy is more popular than ever as a site for such largescale athletic events as the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League championships now in progress here.
New York, the "Queen" among the world's ports, will receive the city's annual homage on Tuesday, in exercises marking the twenty-fifth annual Port of New York Day.

The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it would resume "warehousing" F.H.A. insured and Veterans' Administration guaranteed mortgages, if Congress completed passage of bills eliminating restrictions on discounts and free trading.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 13 -- Grim news for the people of Princeton came out here today. After an absence of four summers, "Mansonia perturbans" is returning.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A Senate Public Works subcommittee approved tonight a bill to speed Federal spending for highways and to regulate the erection of billboards along the interstate highway system.
TRENTON, March 13 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, a Democrat, appointed a Republican as his personal counsel today and created dismay in his own party.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -The Federal Communications Commission acted today to reopen the disputed case of Miami's television Channel 10.

Superintendent of Schools William Jansen asserted yesterday that the recent flare-up of juvenile delinquency did not have a racial basis. He said there was "a close relationship between the amount of delinquency and the economic level of the people."
Excavation work for construction jobs running into hundreds of millions of dollars was resumed here yesterday as most of the 1,100 unionized excavation truck drivers returned to work.
OSLO, Norway, March 13 (AP) -- Austria's Karl Schranz and Putzi Frandl swept to downhill victories today in the famed Holmenkollen Alpine skiing competition.
MANILA, March 13 (AP) -- Following is the text of the final communique issued by the foreign ministers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization countries today:
Police Commisioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday that more police and guidance workers were needed to cope with juvenile delinquency in New York.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 12 -- A growing number of Brazilians are blaming Finance Minister Jose Maria Alkmin for their country's deepening financial crisis.

These are critical days for the cause of court reorganization -- and a test of the legislators at Albany in whose hands its fate now rests. They have a heavy obligation to pass the concurrent resolution now before them which embodies the Tweed commission plan.
TUNIS, March 13 -- President Habib Bourguiba called on the United States and Britain today to choose between Tunisia's position and that of the French Government in their current crisis.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A public welfare expert said today the United States "must spend from $5,000,000,000 to $10,000,000,000 more each year to take care of its senior citizens."
ALBANY, March 13 -- Republican leaders agreed today on a new school-aid program. It calls for a $52,000,000 increase in state aid in the next school year.
PARIS, March 13 -- The Fire Department set fire to twentythree buildings in the heart of the city today -- on purpose.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 13 (UP) -- St. Michael's of Vermont eliminated Evansville, 78 -- 70, and South Dakota tripped Wheaton, 64 -- 60, tonight to move into the final of the National Collegiate smallcollege basketball tournament.
TASHKENT, U. S. S. R., March 13 -- In Central Asia, three days before election day, people are talking about the weather and about a chess match 1,800 miles away.
LUMBERTON, N. C., March 13 (AP) -- James W. Cole, grand wizard of North Carolina's Ku Klux Klan, was convicted here today of inciting a riot among Lumbee Indians last Jan. 18.
TRENTON, March 13 -- A spokesman for the New Jersey Catholic Conference urged today that religion be removed from the issue of restricting Sunday sales.
Robert M. Gray, advertising manager of the Esso Standard Oil Company, has been named manager of a combined advertising - sales promotion department.
It begins to be a question whether the lawmakers in Washington, Albany, Trenton and other capitals can reach the deathbed of the railroads in time to save the patient.
Net earnings of the Pittsburgh Consolidation Coal Company last year rose to a record total of $26,672,722, from $21,972,169 earned in 1956, the annual report disclosed yesterday.
NEWARK, March 13 -- A father and son were indicted here today by a Federal grand jury on charges of evading more than $1,000,000 in personal and corporate income taxes in 1951.
The Brooklyn Bridge will wear pink towers and gray steelwork this spring.
MANILA, March 13 -- John Foster Dulles implied approval here today of the general principle of a Western Mediterranean pact.

HAVANA, March 13 -- Tension mounted in Cuba today. President Fulgencio Batista, backed by the armed forces, and his youthful enemies prepared for what many believe will be the final struggle for power.

BONN, Germany, March 13 -An army fighting on an atomic battlefield will require as much manpower as one in the preatomic era -- and perhaps more, Western military authorities believe. They concluded this from a mid-winter field-training exercise conducted by the United States Seventh Army in southern Germany.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 13 -- President Francois Duvalier has dismissed Haiti's Army boss, Brig. Gen. Antonio Kebreau, because of the general's disregard of civil authority in running the country, a well-informed source said today.
SINGAPORE, March 13 -Three United States warships here have extended their stay for possible evacuation of Americans from Sumatra.
JERSEY CITY, March 13 -- New bids will be sought by the Hudson County Board of Free-holders for the furnishing of the $6,500,000 Administration Building.

Prices of futures closed irregular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, cottonseed oil and lead declined. The world sugar months, copper, rubber and wool rose. Price movements for coffee, the domestic sugar contract, potatoes, zinc and hides were mixed.
By stretching out the boom, Federal Reserve policy cushioned the impact of the present downturn, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said in its annual report, published today.
"THE MALE ANIMAL," the James Thurber-Elliott Nugent comedy, received a distressingly awkward production last night on "Playhouse 90" over Channel 2.
PARIS, March 13 -- French President Rene Coty intervened today to save from the guillotine a young Algerian woman whose fate has aroused world-wide compassionate interest.

Charles (Big Man) Horton, one of seven teen-age gang members accused of killing Michael Farmer, testified yesterday that he had never struck young Farmer with a machete. Moreover, he said, he was sitting on the grass in High Bridge Park when the boy was killed last July 30.
