It would seem that $158,859,804 represents a sizable sum. That was the amount of back dividends owed on cumulative preferred shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange on Jan. 1. However. it was 82 per cent below the $717,074,169 of arrears ten years earlier. At the start of 1957 the figure was $195,612,560.
WITH all the martial music in the air, it is no wonder that Michel of Helena Rubinstein is planning many of his spring hairdos around a band.
Non-agricultural employment in the New York-New Jersey-Pennsylvania region declined to 11,504,000 jobs in mid-January, a Labor Department survey showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -A Senate subcommittee heard additional views today on country or hillbilly music -- this time from a distinguished composer, conductor and educator in the field of serious music.

The National Defense Transportation Association was asked last night to throw its influence behind a proposal for all Hudson River ferry service to the city to be operated by the Port of New York Authority.
The Chelsea Community Council has urged the City Planning Commission to reconsider and approve a low-rent state-aided housing project to accommodate 775 families.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) -- The Federal Housing Administration reported today that February applications for F. H. A. mortgage insurance on new homes were 70 per cent higher than in the same month last year.
SAVANNAH, Ga., March 13 -- The Air Force altered today its original version of why an unarmed atomic bomb fell from a B-47 Tuesday in a rural area near Florence, S.C.

IT is easy to write a historical novel about Napoleon. Letters, memoirs and official documents abound. It is considerably harder to write convincing fiction about Julius Caesar. Although Seutonius and Plutarch have left us interesting short biographies, the established facts are few. And Caesar's own narratives of his military cam paigns, which were written at least in part for their propaganda effect, are dry fare singularly lacking in juicy details and intimate revelations.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) -- The chairman of the board of the Benrus Watch Company urged Congress today to approve a five-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Act, with new tariff-cutting authority.
Events today: Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde," Metropolitan Opera House, 7:45 P. M.; New York Philharmonic, Glenn Gould, pianist, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- An Air Force official told industry representatives today that high-volume production of military aircraft was a thing of the past.
Ninety-one present and former staff members at the Merchant Marine Academy will seek a trial for the return of about $200,000 in lost pay.

PARIS, March 13 (Reuters) -- Francoise Sagan, 22-year-old author of best - selling novels, was married here today to Guy Schoeller, 42, her publisher. A throng of 300 was present as Mile. Sagan, wearing a sack-line suit, arrived forty minutes late at the Town Hall of a Paris residential district near her parents' home.

William Lombardy of New York was among the winners in the second round of the annual international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata in Argentina, according to a report received through South Ameriican news sources yesterday.
A triple job confronts Reginald Denham. Having bought "Cielo Dentro de Casa" ("Heaven Is Home"), Mr. Denham says he will shoulder the adaptation-direction-presentation responsibilities.

"The Enemy Camp," Jerome Weidman's new novel, which Random House will publish, has been chosen as the July selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club. The story, which ranges in scene from the squalor of Manhattan's lower East Side to the quiet elegance of suburban Connecticut, is described as "a study of man's bondage to passion and prejudice."

ATHENS, March 13 -- The caretaker Government of Premier Constantine Georgakopoulos received a 265-to-60 vote of confidence tonight in Parliament. Mr. Georgakopoulos was recently appointed by King Paul to arrange for general elections soon.

An original parchment commission authorizing an Englishman to collect what taxes he could in the Dublin of 1809 was presented yesterday to the American Irish Historical Society by the National Democratic Club here.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 13 (Reuters) -- Yugoslavia's Communist leaders today underscored their faith in "different roads" to the ideal Marxist state in the first authoritative party program published here in ten years.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation stopped selling domestically mined copper to Europe when prices there fell below 25 cents a pound, "in the belief that the copper was worth more in the ground."
FOR food consumers with an eye on their budgets, the choice at meat counters this week would appear to be either turkey or corned beef.
The International Flower Show became in fact an international affair yesterday. Twenty-nine exhibits flown in from nineteen countries made their debut at the Coliseum.
PARIS, March 13 -- Thousands of policemen demonstrated in Paris today. The resulting anarchy shook the Government's authority.

Although one could not expect your March 5 editorial on Presidential disability to deal with all ramifications of this important and complex subject, there are two facets of the problem to which I should like to call attention.

NAHA, Okinawa, Friday, March 14 -- An American father pleaded for the return of his kidnapped six-week-old son last night over the Air Force television station as the police pressed an island-wide search for the infant.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -Dr. Willard F. Libby, acting chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, told Congress in testimony released today about "the little, tiny atom bomb" that crushed 400,000 tons of rock, made a mountain jump six inches, and then "disappeared" for four months.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- Lew Burdette signed his 1958 contract with the world champion Milwaukee Braves today, ending a twelve-day holdout, and then took batting practice.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 13 -- Fabio Arbelaez Cifuentes was shot dead by thugs in a Medellin coffee shop last night.

When Saint-Saens' "Samson et Dalila" was ready for production in 1877, the Paris Opera turned it down as being "too serious." The great merit of the revival of the opera last night at the Metropolitan was that it respected the work's seriousness.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 (UP) -- The annual St. Petersburg - to - Havana yacht race was canceled today because of the political strife in Cuba. Instead the fleet will sail from here to Miami on Saturday.

Dictators are like men who ride tigers. They cannot dismount. Last June President Batista of Cuba conceded to a correspondent of this newspaper that it is relatively easy to seize power but very hard to give it up.
Sweeping changes in the structure of the National Industrial Advertisers Association were recommended yesterday at a meeting of its board in Philadelphia.

Safety of navigation at sea, perennially a subject for study, has been improved in recent years with the installation of radio beacons on nearly all the lighthouses and light vessels in the United States, Europe and other parts of the world.
CHICAGO, March 13 -- Nathan Leopold walked out of Illinois State Penitentiary at Joliet today, pleading for "the gift of privacy."

THE biggest leg show in thirty years is due in town shortly. This may console American men, who even now are waving good-by to vanishing waists and bosoms. The cause of it all is the chemise, churlishly known as "the sack," but it may bring back more leg than anybody has seen since 1929.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon told the Alaska "Congressional delegation" today that he "strongly favors" separate consideration of the Alaska and Hawaii statehood bills."

William Souhrada divides his time between elephants and college. Visitors to the Bronx Zoo can see him in the elephant house, caring for his Indian and African charges, Dolly, Cutie and Sudana. At night, "Elephant Bill," as his friends call him, moves to Brooklyn and classes at Long Island University.

BOSTON, March 13 (UP) -- A Montreal goalie, Jacques Plante, suffered a brain concussion and a possible spine injury, and a Boston wing, Jerry Toppazzini, was lost for the rest of the season with a severe eye injury tonight as the Bruins whipped the Canadiens, 7 -- 3, in a National Hockey League game before a sell-out crowd of 13,909.
Operations of the Babcock Wilcox Company last year resulted in a net income of $16,456,000, compared with $14,081,000 earned in 1956, the ninetieth annual report disclosed to stockholders.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 13 --Drury Gallagher, a Belle Harbor (Queens) boy who took his first strokes in the salty surf of the Rockaways, bagged Fordham University's first major swimming title tonight.
Pyroceram, the new tough, heat-resistant Corning Glass Works ceramic, now is available in more than 1,000 different forms and in commercial quantities.

Two frontiers of our world -- Antarctica and outer space -- are being subjected to the control of man. Sentiment is being expressed that both should be placed under international control. The obvious imperative for this is to avoid violence in the national competition of exploration and exploitation of these realms.

LAGOS, Nigeria, March 5 -An advanced Negro civilization that existed centuries before the first white man set foot in Africa is slowly coming to light here as a result of archaeological discoveries in this area.
Harry Gross almost got his freedom yesterday after nearly seven years' imprisonment since his arrest in 1950 as head of a $20,090,000-a-year bookmaking empire.

The downtrend in the general economy was reflected in a 10 per cent reduction in 1957 earnings of the International Paper Company and its subsidiaries. The company is said to be the world's largest papermaking organization.

MANILA, March 13 -- Foreign ministers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization countries reaffirmed today their determination to maintain national and collective defense against the possibility of Communist and Communist-inspired armed aggression.

The present business slump has been caused by a sharp rise over the past few years in profits and production, while wages and consumption have risen more slowly. The result is that business has been pricing itself out of the market.
ALBANY, March 13 -- The Assembly approved today three bills on eavesdropping designed to overcome objections raised by Governor Harriman in vetoing bills approved earlier by the Legislature.
LONDON, March 13 -- Queen Mother Elizabeth became today the first member of Britain's royal family to have flown around the world.
ALBANY, March 13 -- An urgent appeal for emergency assistance to enable New York City to balance its next expense budget was delivered to legislative leaders today.

WHITE PLAINS, March 13 -- Fourteen owners of costly homes near Central Park Avenue in northeast Yonkers filed suit in the State Supreme Court here today to block another commercial encroachment on the avenue.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Percival F. Brundage resigned today as director of the Bureau of the Budget. President Eisenhower named Maurice H. Stans, at present the deputy director, to succeed him.
"We'd all gone up to our attic when the flood hit our house," said Mrs. Rena Roy of Cameron Parish, La. "Then the house lurched and we poked a hole in the the roof and climbed up."
The following reports, provided by the operators of the ski areas, were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses:
Dress manufacturers got a green light yesterday to keep their shops open on Saturday this week and next to rush out dresses for pre-Easter delivery.
ALBANY, March 13 -- Driver-education facilities in public schools would be made available to parochial and private schools under a bill approved unanimously by the Senate today.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, said today his bill to curb the Supreme Court was designed to check what he called its "grab for power."
GENEVA, March 13 (AP) -Saudi Arabia announced to the Geneva Maritime Conference today that it had extended its territorial sea boarder to twelve miles beyond its coast.
ALBANY, March 13 -- A revised Republican unemployment insurance bill received the unanimous approval of the Senate and Assembly today after three Democratic amendments had been rejected.

Two floors in the office building rising at 200 East Forty-second Street have been leased by the Standard Packaging Corporation, manufacturer of packaging materials. The lessee now is at 551 Fifth Avenue. Collins, Tuttle Co. is the agent for the

WASHINGTON, March 13 -The Senate passed today by a vote of 50 to 43 a resolution to freeze farm price supports and acreage allotments at not less than 1957 levels, pending further Congressional action.
A nation-wide gathering of young journalists heard yesterday that the world was becoming more complicated and so were the problems of gathering and interpreting its news.
Following are the awards given at the International Flower Show in the Coliseum yesterday:

CHICAGO, March 13 (AP) -- Nearly all grain futures came under moderate selling pressure on the Board of Trade here today and ended unchanged or lower. Old-crop wheat, however, again resisted the trend and advanced.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 13 -- Movie circles still were pondering today the question: where does Universal-International go from here?
The owners of six downtown loft buildings have been ordered to remove fire hazards within ten days or face closing, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. announced yesterday.
Development of a new type of synthetic rubber to help meet the jet-age need for heat-resistant materials was announced yesterday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co.
LONDON, March 13 -- The Soviet Union has agreed to discuss with the West the control of outer space and the question of intercontinental ballistic missiles as part of a general disarmament problem.
LONDON, March 13 -- The Board of Trade is investigating allegations of Soviet dumping of aluminum on the British market.

In commemoration of Henrik Ibsen's birth in 1828, the Scandinavian Society of Columbia University and the Norsemen's Federation will present a program honoring the Norwegian dramatist next Thursday at 8:15 P. M. in Columbia's Casa Italiana, Amsterdam Avenue and 117th Street.
TRIVANDRUM, India, March 7 -- In this city near the Arabian Sea, there are two buildings from which India's Communists have been ruling the state of Kerala for almost a year.
COLUMBIA, Mo., March 13 (AP) -- Participants in a freedom of information seminar suggested today that a central office be set up to integrate efforts at protecting the public's rights.
St. John's University of Brooklyn and St. Joseph's of Philadelphia posted victories as the twenty-first annual National Invitation Tournament began last night at Madison Square Garden.
Trans-Atlantic passenger ship fares will go up during the 1959 summer season. Cabin and tourist class berths will cost $10 more and first-class accommodations will go up by $17.
ALBANY, March 13 -- The Senate approved unanimously today a bill continuing the bank holding company "freeze" for one year.

The increase in borrowing by business at New York City banks in anticipation of March 15 tax payments is running about one-third last year's, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Mounting complaints against aggressive automobile salesmen, called "bird dogs" by their G. I. victims, have prompted the Pentagon to crack down at Army bases in Germany.
In cooperation with the .National Society of Interior De.: signers, the fifth annual tour of houses tO benefit the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation will be held on April 8 and 15.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -Prime Minister Harold Macmillan of Britain will visit President Eisenhower here June 9 and 10.

NEW DELHI, India, March 13 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today appointed Morarji Desai as Minister of Finance. He replaces T. T. Krishnamachari, who resigned last month as a result of controversy about the misuse of funds of the nationalized Life Insurance Corporation.
PHILADELPHIA, March 13 --Alastair Bradley Martin began his quest today for the title he lost a year ago.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 13 -On rainy days when exhibition games are postponed and when the weather is inappropriate for the race track, dog track or an outdoor poker game, many gentleman sportswriters turn clairvoyant and predict which ball players will be traded, which won't and which will soon return to the sticks.

New York and its municipal colleges are fortunate indeed in the appointment of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, Under Secretary of the United Nations, to the Board of Higher Education. Mayor Wagner has strengthened a board that has always within our memory needed strengthening with the choice of this distinguished educator, diplomat and Nobel Peace Prize winner.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad is negotiating with a group of banks and the Treasury for deferment of repayments on its $16,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent flood loans for an unspecified period "not later than the maturity" of the loans in 1965.

David W. Frankel, realty investor, has leased the six-story building at 605 Fifth Avenue, near Forty-eighth Street, from the Henry Phipps estate at a rental exceeding $1,000,000 for the term. He plans to alter the building into small offices. Tankoos Co. negotiated the lease.

Despite cutbacks in copper mining to help correct an oversupply of the metal, stocks of refined copper in producers' hands rose 24,936 tons last month to the highest level since August, 1949. The metals industry was in a slump at that time, too.
The latest box office success is the Design in the Home, '58, show at the Brooklyn Museum.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 14 -- Fifty-three cars from eleven states and the Territory of Hawaii lined up tonight for the first 1958 national rally of the Sports Car Club of America.
New York University and Cornell shared honors in the Intercollegiate Fencing Association championship yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today "a boiling storm is rising" over the bill to limit the review powers of the Supreme Court.
THIS week's art events would furnish a Variety Fair, with the artists occupying both ends of the seesaw of abstraction and realism.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 14 -- Maj. Gen. John B. Medaris, the Army's missile chief, said here today that only the military was equipped to explore outer space.
Tony Anthony, a Harlem light-heavyweight, registered a technical knockout over Yvon Durelle, strong man from Moncton, N. B., in the feature bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
BONN, Germany, March 14 -- Former Queen Soraya accepted today an unwanted divorce from the Shah of Iran at "the sacrifice of my own happiness."

NOTHING sabotages a woman's appearance as much as smeared or carelessly applied make-up. Fashion models, whose fortunes depend on impeccable make-up, are wise in the ways of powder and paint. Here are some of the techniques they use to keep make-up looking fresh and effective:

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 14 -- With each contributing a record performance, Yale's Tim Jecko and Roger Anderson advanced half way tonight to their combined goal of six titles in the eighteenth annual Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League championships.

PARIS, March 14 -- Paris' Prefect of Police, Andre Lahillonne, was dismissed today as a result of yesterday's demonstrations by thousands of off-duty policemen. Maurice Bourges-Maunoury, Minister of the Interior, offered his resignation, but Premier Felix Gaillard asked him to stay. M. Lahillonne had been appointed last December on M. Bourges-Maunoury's recommendation.

"Circus Festival," a Russian-made documentary feature, in color, showing highlights of the World Youth Festival held in Moscow last year, is today's new film at the Cameo Theatre. The Artkino release is a sequel to "Festival in Moscow," which opened here recently and is being re-shown as the second half of the program.
A 1955 injunction prohibiting the Alleghany Corporation from completing an exchange of preferred stock was debated again in court yesterday.

Frank Merlin's new one-character and one-set play, "I Got Shoes," has been acquired by Joe O'Brien and Rhett Cone for off-Broadway production next fall. It will be presented at the Cricket Theatre, Second Avenue and Tenth Street, owned by the producers.
PHILADELPHIA, March 14 -- Northrup Knox of Buffalo and Alastair Martin of Glen Head, L. I., will meet tomorrow morning at 11:30 for the amateur court tennis championship of the United States.
BONN, Germany, March 14 -- The Government beat a major tactical retreat today on the question of German reunification.

"The Republican Era: 1869-1901," a new book by Leonard D. White in his series tracing the evolution of the Government from 1789, will be published March 25 by Macmillan. The study begins with Grant's Presidency and continues through the Administrations of Hayes, Garfield, Arthur, Cleveland, Harrison and McKinley.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 14 (UP) -- Premier Sami es-Solh formed a new and expanded pro-Western Cabinet today.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- William A. McDonnell, a St. Louis banker, was elected today as president of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

Money market circles in Wall Street are pretty sure that there will be another reduction in bank reserve requirements soon -- unless the economy takes a decisive turn toward recovery. The immediate occasion for a cut would be the Treasury's coming to the market to borrow cash.
The New York Telephone Company filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission an application for authority to sell two bond issues totaling $130,000,000 and $120,000,000 of common stock.
ALBANY, March 14 (UP) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
HOUSTON, March 14 -- The need for a "new order of humanist Jewish scholarship and philosophy" on the American scene was stressed here today by a Jewish scholar and educator.
The State Housing Commission heard arguments yesterday on a proposed 10 per cent rent increase by Knickerbocker Village, Inc., a limited-dividend housing development on the lower East Side.

ALBANY, March 14 -- The Public Service Commission reported today that plans on the drawing boards of electric utilities would infuse more than $2,000,000,000 into the state's economy in the next five years.
ALBANY, March 14 -- A report filed with Governor Harriman today declared that the former immigration installation on Ellis Island was unfit for use as a narcotics hospital.

For the second successive week the investment banking community faces a period of only moderate marketing activity, compared with the hectic pace of most of the winter. Major bond issues coming up for sale total about $120,000,000, with local government borrowings accounting for more than half of the total.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 14 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen made his formal entry today into Pennsylvania's Republican race for Governor.
BONN, West Germany, March 14 -- The headquarters of the United States Air Force in Europe announced today that no atomic weapons were carried in planes flying over territory of the Federal Republic.
NORFOLK, Va., March 14 (AP) -- Nicky, the Barbary ape, surrendered to the United States Navy today.
The outlook seems poor for establishment of a New YorkNew Jersey Metropolitan Transit District this year.
The annual Three Choir Festival of Congregation Emanu-El opened yesterday afternoon in the assembly hall of Temple Emanu-El under the direction of Lazare Saminsky.

The way of the peacemaker is hard. That is certainly so in the case of Messrs. Murphy and Beeley, the American and British "good offices" envoys seeking to restore amicable relations between France and Tunisia.
PARIS, March 14 -- Gen. Paul Bailly has resigned as Chief of Staff of the French Air Force amid signs of discontent in aviation circles over cuts in the Air Force budget.
Protestants and Roman Catholics over the country will be asked tomorrow to open their hearts and their pocketbooks to aid the destitute and the hungry in other lands.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 14 -- Dartmouth's Big Green quintet performed up to its capabilities tonight. Manhattan's Jaspers did not.
SAMSUN, Turkey, March 13 -- Americans with hard currency to spend have been outbid in the local tobacco market by Turkish dealers, most of whom represent Iron Curtain countries on barter deals.

A one-story taxpayer containing eight stores on plot 140 by 195 feet at the northeast corner of Great Neck Road and East Gate Road, Copiague, L. L., has been sold by the I. Russo Corporation of Merrick, L. I., the builder.
The Coliseum doors will close at 10 o'clock tonight on the Forty-first International Flower Show.

Events today: Three Choir Festival. Temple Emanu-El. 10:15 A. M.; Young People's Concert, Little Orchestra Society. Hunter College, 11; "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Concert Artists Guild. Steinway Concert Hall, 3; Donald Betts, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; New York Philharmonic, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Shoshana Damari, folk singer, Town Hall, 8:30.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- Travis M. Kerr's Round Table became the solid favorite for the $100,000 adore Gulfstream Park Handicap when he smashed the track record for a mile and a sixteenth today while easily winning the $10,000 Challenge Purse at Gulfstream Park.

Tickets are still available to the March 27 benefit performance of "The Entertainer" at the Royale Theatre. They may be obtained from Miss Jessie Fanshawe at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street. Proceeds will aid the Hospital for Special Surgery.
The American Jewish League for Israel announced yesterday its affiliation with the World Confederation of General Zionist.
ALBANY, March 14 -- Legal action was threatened today by the Civil Service Reform Association to recover state funds paid out for "no-show" jobs on the legislative payroll.
A group of chemists heard yesterday that serious concentrations of carbon monoxide build up twice daily in the city as traffic reaches its morning and afternoon peaks.

David Bean, who had a very successful debut about a year ago, was heard in a piano recital last night in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He offered a solid program of Bach, Beethoven, Schoenberg, Ginastera and Chopin.

UNLESS a miracle occurs in Albany the Conservation Department will have to muddle along for at least another year without enough game protectors, without enough equipment for its game protectors and without enough money to do what it knows it ought to do.
A Puerto Rican leader suggested yesterday that church and labor groups cooperate to draw migrants to New York "out of their shells" and guide them away from "paper unions."

Cocoa prices advanced the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The spot March position, which has no limit, rose to 177 points (hundredths of a cent a pound.)
Gerard Russak, baritone, who has sung with the New York Civic Opera Company and took part in a joint recital here last spring, made his first solo appearance last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 (UP) -- Loretta Young faced charges today of "dishonesty, mismanagement and unfairness" in a suit filed by her husband, Tom Lewis, for dissolution of the Lewislor Production Company.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday asked the United States District Court here for an injunction against certain officers of the Jefferson Custodian Fund, Inc., an open-end investment company.
Once more we are being asked to contribute $4 billion for that gigantic fraud on the American people officially called "foreign aid," better known as "the give-away."

There was a note of warning in Randall Jarrell's speech this week on the occasion of the presentation of the annual National Book Awards. Mr. Jarrell, poet, critic and consultant in poetry for the Library of Congress, decried the effects of popular culture on our society, saying: "The impact of the stream of the mass media offerings is cumulative and strong."
Bitterness broke out again yesterday among lawyers in the General Sessions murder trial of the seven teen-agers accused of killing Michael Farmer.

Rent decontrol of 600 luxury apartments in the city becomes effective today. The apartments, all of which are believed to be in Manhattan, come under a decontrol order issued last fall by Robert C. Weaver, State Rent Administrator.
The Ford Motor Company's sales of defense products rose sharply last year. Such sales were $525,000,000 last year, compared with $273,000,000 in 1956, the pamphlet report disclosed.
Wet snow, alternating with rain, caused a variety of delays and inconveniences in the metropolitan area yesterday.
We read the article titled "Asmara Relaxes to Musical Fare" by Osgood Caruthers in your March 2 issue with interest and great surprise.

PARIS, March 14 -- Yesterday an enthralling drama opened in Paris. While Right-Wing and Left-Wing Deputies were snarling at each other and thumping National Assembly desks, thousands of policemen marched upon Parliament in a "demonstration," not a strike. Policemen are prohibited by law from striking.
Spring was officially welcomed yesterday when at least 3,000 members of The Fashion Group sloshed into the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to view a summing up of the Paris showings.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, March 14 -- Princess Grace gave birth today to a healthy, blue-eyed male heir for Monaco's 990-year-old throne, and this sun-splashed Riviera playground went wild. Champagne flowed church bells pealed and yachts in the harbor blew sirens. and without anesthetics. Both the baby and his mother were reported "doing well."
Forty business leaders and city officials braved snow and slush yesterday to plan New York's Salute to Spring.
There was real peace last night for the first time in three days at 107 Washington Street, headquarters of Local 88 of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots.

The centenary of the birth of Liberty Hyde Bailey, world-honored American botanist and humanist, is being celebrated in a special program today at the New York State College of Agriculture, Cornell University. Countless thousands of amateur and professional gardeners consider Dr. Bailey's name synonymous with horticulture; all gardeners, knowingly or not, are in his debt.

THE most authoritative book ever written on communism in America is J. Edgar Hoover's "Masters of Deceit."* Under directives from President Franklin D. Roosevelt and later men in the White House he has studied the thing more intensively and with ampler research facilities at his disposal than anyone else in this country.
Percy Gale Jr., $17,500-a-year director of the city's scandal-torn Bureau of Real Estate, resigned yesterday.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 14 -- It was confirmed here tonight that Brig. Gen. Antonio Kebreau, ousted boss of Haiti's Army, had taken shelter in the Embassy of the Dominican Republic.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 -- The long-projected filming by Columbia of "Joseph and His Brethren" apparently is not going to materialize, for the present at least.
CHICAGO. March 14 (AP) -The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The number of skilled immigrants must be increased, a State Department official yesterday told the annual conference of the National Council on Naturalization and Citizenship.

HAVANA, March 14 -- The Cuban Congress went into joint session this afternoon to approve the suspension of constitutional guarantees for forty-five days. The renewed suppression of basic individual rights was decreed last Wednesday by President Fulgencio Batista.

This is the day the Post Office Department is issuing another new three-cent stamp. It is green, a color deemed especially agreeable to gardeners, in whose honor it is being issued. (Coincidentally, being green it will make a fine St. Patrick's Day stamp, too.) Without in the least intending to bruise anybody's feelings, one may suggest that this is not the most attractive stamp the United States ever has issued.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- The National Science Foundation announced today that it would build the first national United States observatory on an Arizona mountain peak.

CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- The small majority by which the Senate passed the bill to retain 1957 farm price supports on 1958 crops is an indication that the measure is dead, traders said today as they applied selling pressure to nearly all grain futures.

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Marlene Hagge of Delray Beach, Fla., sank an eighteen-foot putt on the eighteenth hole today to gain a one-stroke lead at the halfway mark in the seventy-two-hole women's titleholders golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee approved today a bill authorizing the Maritime Administration to burial two big passenger ships for private operation in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans.
Several hundred youngsters who think they would like to be professional journalists were told yesterday of some of the difficulties of gathering news and meeting deadlines.

The difference between a political approach and a factual approach to the problem of unemployment is well illustrated by the differing statements of President Eisenhower and the economists of the First National City Bank.
Democratic leaders still held hope yesterday that opposition in the party to state court-reform proposals could be overcome.

Mikhail Botvinnik, the challenger in the world chess title tournament at Moscow, staved off imminent defeat last night in the fourth game of his twenty-four-game return match with Vassily Smyslov. The match was drawn after eighty-two moves, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.
NEW HAVEN, March 14 (AP) -- The American Cancer Society said today a pioneer study would be made to find out whether cancer occurred more frequently in some families than in others.

TASHKENT, U. S. S. R., March 14 -- Along the muddy trails of the Star of the Orient collective farm deep in Central Asia, three Americans studying Soviet politics got a glimpse today at one of the sources of Soviet power.

Abraham Leibman, president of the Deauville Construction Corporation, has purchased the old apartment houses on plot 100 by 170 feet on the west side of Briggs Avenue, 100 feet south of Bedford Park Boulevard, in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx.
Twenty-two members of the Brooklyn morals squad testified briefly yesterday before the special Kings County grand jury investigating an asserted police tie-up with a bookmaking syndicate.

The IRT and BMT subway lines were plagued yesterday by a series of power failures and electrical fires that delayed hundreds of thousands of riders. The trouble started in the morning rush hour and lasted into mid-afternoon.
Stocks went through a dull session yesterday and lost a little ground. Meat packers showed strength. Other groups were mixed or lower.
I have read with interest the arguments for partition of Cyprus as set forth by Ernest Jackh in his letter in your March 11 issue.

ALBUQUERQUE,N.M., March 14 (AP) -- Sterling Black of Los Alamos, son of Supreme Court Justice Hugo Black, said today that he would file a protest against Federal award of a permit for a national bank at the booming uranium center of Grants.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 -- As Casey Stengel trudged off Al Lang Field today he seemed to have only one regret. His Yankees will not see Birdie Tebbetts' Redlegs again this year they meet in next October's world series. And that's a long way off.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -A Canadian surgeon was granted a patent this week for a device to restore the action of the human heart by direct mechanical massage.
Nathan Leopold, freed on parole Thursday after thirty-three years in prison, stopped in New York early today on the way from Chicago to Puerto Rico and a $10-a-month exile as a hospital technician.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Leaders of two long-feuding textile workers' unions have signed an agreement that merger of their organizations is "necessary and fundamental to the best interests of the membership of both organizations."
ROME, March 14 (AP) -- Newsprint production in Europe and North America rose by more than 50 per cent in the decade after World War II.
NO matter what her age, activities or acreage might be, the suburbanite prefers to wear sweaters and skirts. Nothing else is as easy or suitable for the life she leads.

The Kings County District Attorney's office declared yesterday that it had broken up a television repair racket that had cost set owners thousands of dollars. Assistant District Attorney Robert Lazarus ordered the arrest of a repair shop owner and an employe on charges of mulcting scores of television set owners through fraudulent repairs and padded bills.
BERLIN, March 14 -- Soviet troop withdrawals from East Germany impress United States military opinion as related to modernization rather than to a reduction of striking power.
Private pharmaceutical manufacturers will participate in the nation's $25,000,000 search for drugs to treat cancer. Many of the details of the arrangement have been worked out.

CAPE COMORIN, India, March 7 -- In the bleak travelers' rest house near land's end, a pleasant-mannered Brahman explained gently how communism would come to power in India; how inevitably and quite respectably it would be done.

WHITE PLAINS, March 14 -Westchester County will seek a re-hearing on the Public Service Commission's dual order for higher commutation fares on the New York Central Railroad and discontinuance of all passenger service on the line's Putnam Division.
PENSACOLA, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- Doug Ford of Mahopac, N. Y., took the lead in the Pensacola open golf tournament today with a seven-under-par 65.
SAN JOSE, Calif., March 14 -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight out-distanced Mayor George Christopher of San Francisco today in a trial heat in California's senatorial sweepstakes.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 14 (AP) -- Secretary of State Dulles conferred today with President Chiang Kai-shek after opening a meeting of eleven United States Ambassadors to Far Eastern nations.

An official tabulation of the Board of Elections yesterday showed a 40 per cent decline in Republican voter registration between the 1956 Presidential and the 1957 mayoralty elections. It compared with a 20 per cent drop in Democratic enrollment and about 16 per cent for the Liberal party.

Two "hidden bank accounts" that contained $216,000, which may have been kept secretly for "certain officials" of the Department of Buildings, have been uncovered by accountants in the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 14 (AP) -- Nancy O'Connell, believed to be the youngest singles champion in the fifty-one-year history of the competition, defeated Bonnie Mencher today for the national women's indoor tennis title.

Thirty members of the 26th of July Movement last night picketed in front of Pier 16, John Street and the East River, to protest arms shipments to Cuba. The movement is headed by Fidel Castro, Cuban revolutionary leader.
CARACAS, March 14 -- A high-level United States Government mission has come to Venezuela to work out a solution for the problem of the world oil surplus as it affects this country.

Recent maneuvers of the United States Seventh Army in Germany have emphasized publicly weaknesses and problems that have been stressed repeatedly in Army circles. The maneuvers have called attention to the continuing reductions in the strength of the Seventh Army, the principal ground combat force on the vital central German front.

ROME, March 14 -- Neo-Fascist and Communist Deputies fought on the floor of the Chamber today. Four Deputies and three attendants of the sergeant-at-arms were treated for injuries at an infirmary following the clash.

Bruce Catton, editor of The American Heritage, and Paul Mellon of Washington, were honored yesterday by the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society at a luncheon in the Federal Hall Memorial.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., March 14 -- The College Women's Club of Montclair today began cashing in again on the concept, proved by time, that "old books never die." An eightinch snow cut the size of the opening-day crowd at the club's twenty-first annual book sale.
The Port of New York Authority yesterday rejected a proposal that it take over operation of a unified Hudson River ferry system.

TOKYO, March 14 -- The Tokyo police are reported to be searching for an unidentified Chinese and a Caucasian foreigner in connection with the suspected murder of a United States Army sergeant assigned to intelligence work.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Deaths from influenza and pneumonia, which have been running unusually high, declined in the week ended March 8. The Public Health Service reported today a drop of 3.9 per cent under the preceding week -- the first weekly decrease since January.

LAWRENCE, Kan., March 14 (AP) -- Kansas State saw a 1-point lead disappear in the final seconds of regulation time on a free throw by Cincinnati's Oscar Robertson, but bounced back for an 83-80 overtime victory tonight in the first round of the National Collegiate Midwest regional basketball tournament.
MIAMI, Fla., March 14 (UP) -- The wife and four small daughters of the deposed Venezuelan President. Gen. Marcos Perez Jiminez, arrived in Miami tonight.
City franchise tax relief estimated at $1,244,850 for 1958 was granted by the Board of Estimate yesterday to eight of the city's nine privately owned land operated bus lines.

TORONTO, March 14 (Canadian Press) -- The Mogul Mining Corporation, a holding company with major interests in eighteen mining concerns, proposed today a one-for-five stock consolidation and a $20,000,000 debenture issue.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 14 -- The use of radioactive chemicals in tracing the breeding grounds of mosquitos was outlined here today.

A curve in the design of a complicated piece of machinery can make all the difference in the world. If the curve is complex, expensive machine tools, often imported, are essential to build the machine part.

ST. LOUIS, March 14 -- Kings are said to be born to the purple. It might be said of William Archie McDonnell, the new president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, that he seems to have been born to the bankers' gray.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 14 (AP) -- Twelve men received prison sentences ranging from minimums of one month to a maximum of two years today for conspiring to defraud the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission of $500,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- The Hungarian delegation here rebuked the United States today for having inquired about the fate of twenty-four Hungarians who were jailed or who disappeared after the anti- Soviet revolt in Budapest in 1956.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 14 -- The month-old revolutionary government of Indonesia, now fighting a battle of survival against the armed strength of the Central Government, disavowed President Sukarno tonight as Chief of State, according to a rebel broadcast monitored here.
Three cops-and-robbers film series will be retired by the American Broadcasting Company this month.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Federal Communications Commission said today that its original decision in awarding a Miami television channel to a subsidiary of National Airlines had been based on "substantial" evidence.

TELEVISION, which has revolutionized the interior planning of the American home, is now going into doll houses. A miniature TV set with a three-and-one-half-inch screen is on view at Durant Sound, 80 West Fifty-fifth Street.
AMES, Iowa, March 13 -- The production revolution in farming has wrought a dramatic change in the cloistered halls of American agriculture.
A panel of medical specialists in chest diseases urged yesterday that persons afflicted with emphysema quit smoking.
S. Arnold Zimmerman has been elected secretary of Avon Products, Inc., here. He had been head of the legal department of Wallace Tierman, Inc., a New Jersey processing and manufacturing concern.
LUMBERTON, N. C., March 14 (AP) -- Two Ku Klux Klansmen were sentenced to prison today for inciting an Indian riot.
LEXINGTON, Ky., March 14 (AP) -- The bronze statue marking the grave of Man o' War, one of the great American race horses, was offered today for a public shrine.

LONDON, March 14 -- Virtually all principal share groups drifted lower in extremely quiet trading on the stock exchange today. Although partly inspired by the Government's defeat in the Kelvingrove by-election, the main reasons for the hesitancy remained the scarcity of money following some large capital calls and the disappointing business news from America.

A Curtiss-Wright Corporation stockholder has filed suit in Federal Court here against seven officers of the company. The complaint asks that alleged profits made by the officers, who were said to have bought and sold the company's common stock, be returned to Curtiss-Wright.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 14 (AP) -- North Dakota, Western champion, crushed Harvard, 9 -- 1, tonight and gained the National Collegiate hockey tournament final.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- The Government gave Pan American and Trans World Airlines tentative permission today to fly special "thrift" flights to Europe starting April 1.
ALBANY, March 14 -- Under the sponsorship of State Controller Arthur Levitt and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, legislation has been prepared to tighten state controls over pawnbrokers.

CHICAGO, March 14 (AP) -- A united fellowship of Christian laymen from all Protestant denominations was proposed today by Dr. Henry Pitney Van Dusen, president of the Union Theological Seminary in New York.

Aluminum production at two plants of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation in Washington will be further curtailed at the end of this month, the company announced yesterday. It cited "general economic conditions and a continuing oversuppy of aluminum."
SINGAPORE, March 14 -- Indonesian rebels declared tonight they had resumed the battle for the oil center of Pakanbaru and had gained support from another province of Sumatra.

EL CENTRO, Calif., March 14 -- To the fans dwelling here close to the Mexican border, it did not seem to matter that the tall outfielder hit only .240 last season, or that his career has been relatively unspectacular ever since Oct. 3, 1951.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- The Soviet Union conducted two more atomic tests today, the Atomic Energy Commission announced tonight. The twin explosions brought to five the number of known Soviet tests since Feb. 22.
Cotton futures declined 6 to 13 points yesterday in a dull session.

Central to the formulation of correct economic policy is the ability to diagnose correctly the current health of the economy and its prospective future change. To do this we have the help of a vast body of statistical materials far exceeding in richness the data available in the past, even in the Nineteen Thirties.
KANSAS CITY, March 14 (AP) -- Three suits for damages were filed against The Kansas City Star yesterday in United States District Court under the antitrust laws.
Lord Taylor has formally apologized to Japanese officials here for the way it recently displayed a Japanese statue of the Buddhist Goddess of Mercy.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., March 14 -- The Ridgewood Symphony Orchestra gave its second concert of the season tonight at Benjamin Franklin Junior High School here. An audience of 600 persons attended the performance, the orchestra's thirty-fourth since its founding in 1939.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The police chief of Sheboygan, Wis., Steen W. Heimke, indicated today that union political influence might have deterred police action on one occasion in the Kohler Company strike.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 14 (Reuters) -- The pro-Western Umma party, that won the largest number of seats in recent elections here for the House of Representatives, has gained a sweeping victory in elections for the Senate.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Official feelings on prospects of conciliation in the French- Tunisian dispute progressed today from despondency to uncertainty to guarded hope.

With regard to the controversy about nuclear weapons testing, I feel that the most important reason for suspending tests has not been clearly stated in your columns. It is this -- that such a ban is very much easier to police than any other first-step disarmament agreement that has been proposed.
MOSCOW, March 14 -- The Soviet Union disclosed today that active negotiations were under way among the major powers concerning the preparation of a summit conference.

ST. LOUIS, March ,14 -- The fact that the United States is a land of opportunity puts increased responsibilities on such organizations as the Young Women's Christian Association, Dr. Hadley Cantrill, chairman of the board of the Institute for International Social Research, said here tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The first indication of the March trend in unemployment reveals no improvement.
PITTSBURGH, March 14 (AP) -- Cornell took a one-point lead over Syracuse at the end of the quarter-finals of the fifty-fourth annual Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association tournament tonight.
MIAMI, March 14 (AP) -- A ninth-inning Dodger rally died with men on second and third and the Chicago White Sox defeated Los Angeles tonight, 3 -- 1.

TORONTO, March 14 -- Canada's election on March 31 probably will be determined in this big, prosperous and populous Province of Ontario and in French-speaking Quebec. They offer the richest prizes in votes to the Conservatives and the Liberals.

The United Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday the election of Wright A. Parkins and Leonard C. Mallet as vice presidents. The company is a leading manufacturer of aircraft engines, propellers and helicopters.

DETROIT, March 14 (AP) -- Passenger car production this week will move up slightly to 87,892 units, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. Last week 83,892 cars were built and in the like week of 1957 the total was 141,038.
LONDON, March 14 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan foresaw today the possibility of agreement with the Soviet Union on some aspects of disarmament before the next general election.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 14 -- Two 20-year-old co-eds at Hofstra College were killed tonight when their car was struck by a Long Island Rail Road train. A third girl, 19, was critically injured.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -The American Farm Bureau Federation endorsed an extension of the foreign aid program today but said it felt President Eisenhower's request could be trimmed substantially.

AMONG the misconceptions regarding chili peppers and, consequently, chili powders is the belief that bright red color indicates good chili flavor. If this were true, according to Joseph Farrell of the Consolidated Foods Corporation of Los Angeles, paprika should have the finest chili flavor in the world.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- The Reserve Officers Association expressed "vehement opposition" today to provisions that would exclude reserve officers from the Administration's pay rise bill.
GENEVA, March 14 (Reuters) -- Indonesia today insisted, despite United States objections, on ringing her entire archipelago with a twelve mile belt of territorial waters.
KANSAS CITY, March 14 -- Former President Harry S. Truman strongly defended today his order to drop atomic bombs on Japan because, he said, it saved thousands of Japanese and American lives.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Oscar Hammerstein 2d stoutly defended today before a House Small Business subcommittee the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers as being fair in its operations.

The payment of $4,500,000 to ease local opposition to the development of a hydroelectric plant on the Niagara River will require a larger bond issue to finance the project, it was announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 -- A drama built around activities at the Air Force Survival School in Nevada will be presented by "Studio One in Hollywood" on April 7 on the Columbia Broadcasting System network. It will be called "The Enemy Within."
TRENTON, March 14 -- The American importer and distributors of the Volkswagen, a beetle-shaped German automobile, today denied charges of illegal price-fixing and restraint of trade.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets advanced 0.2 per cent to 119.6 per cent of their 1947-49 levels during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

MANZANILLO, Mexico, March 12 -- Adolfo Lopez Mateos, whose election as President of Mexico in July is regarded as certain today passed the halfway mark of his campaign full of determination and anxieties. He was taking a one-day breather in this little Pacific port.

CONAKRY, French West Africa, March 15 -- This is intermission time in French Guinea.

MOSCOW, March 15 -- Loudspeakers blared gay music in Moscow's streets tonight and the last bits of red bunting were going into place as the Soviet Union prepared for tomorrow's national "celebration" of Election Day.
TEHERAN, Iran, March 15 (Reuters) -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi will not marry again immediately after the formalities of his divorce from Queen Soraya, a court spokesman said today.

SINGAPORE, March 15 -- The Indonesian Government sent reinforcements to Pakanbaru today to help its forces hold the big oil center in Central Sumatra, a rebel communique said.

Experts with Victor, Columbia, Capitol and Decca seem agreed, for once, that the pallid recordings of pop "standards" that blended into the living room like crumbs into the rug, are on the way out.
HAVANA, March 15 -- The police killed four young men in Lawton, a suburb of Havana last night.

BOSTON, March 15 (AP) -- A roaring northeast storm whipped by wind gusts up to 70 miles an hour battered New England yesterday and early today. It dumped up to 17 1/2 inches of snow, toppling power lines and clogging highway traffic.

ALTHOUGH Ernst Schnabel has won a certain amount of critical recognition in his native Germany -- this novel, originally entitled "Der Sechste Gesang," was awarded the Fontane Prize last year -- he seems to be practically unknown in this country.

In his discussion of the art of letter writing ("The Art of Letter Writing, By an Expert," March 2) Robert Moses might have mentioned another famous example of condensation, which his "Off agin, on agin, gone agin. -- Finnigin" recalled to my mind.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 15 -- It took ten minutes before Walter H. Reeves, the judge, for a Skye terrier, Ch. Evening Star de Luchar, to become best in show at the twenty-third Harrisburg Kennel Club event tonight.

THE Civil Aeronautics Board last week handed in its verdict of who was to blame for the Rikers Island crash of Feb. 1, 1957, that took twenty lives. The verdict: "The board determines that the probable cause of the accident was the failure of the captain to (1) properly observe and interpret his flight instruments and (2) maintain control of his aircraft."

" YOUR comments on 'The Magic World of Words'," a reader has written, referring to the Parent and Child column of March 2, "suggest that poetry reading may be beyond the scope of parents and teachers nowadays, that resorting to recordings is the 'modern' way to get the beauty of spoken music across to children.

IT'S a poor trend that doesn't work both ways. Statisticians have noted a rush from the city to the country. There is also, as a survey may some day show, a sort of drift from the country back to the city.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- John Walker, director of the National Gallery of Art, announced today that an exhibition of photographs by Alfred Stieglitz, to be opened to the public here tomorrow, would continue until April 27.

PARIS, March 15 -- New attempts to find a common ground between continental countries seeking tight, supranational economic integration and the looser British-Scandinavian proposals for a free-trade zone are under way here.

The ion microscope, mentioned in this departi'aent last week, which made it possible for the first time to make pictures of atoms in a metal crystal, was developed after nineteen years of effort by Dr. Erwin B{. Mueller, research Professor of Physics at Pennsylvania State University, University Park, Pa.

THE "electric eye" device that has brought automation to the amateur movie camera field was offered in an 8mm camera at the new low price of $149.50 at a press preview here last week. The camera is the Keystone Model KA-3, which Keystone Camera Company of Boston will display this week at the annual photographic trade show in Chicago.

THE three months, beginning early last December when the new foreign arrivals building at New York International Airport opened, have been a period of trial and testing. The novel devices and techniques so recently installed there for filtering incoming passengers through United States quarantine, immigration and customs have come under serious scrutiny.

In cities, towns and hamlets in nearly every state of the union committees are ready to spend this week in an intensified promotion of reading in homes. They will also focus attention on the country's library resources.

WHITE PLAINS, March 15 -- Efforts of Republican and Democratic leaders in Westchester prepare for big November battles by whetting grass-roots political interest in March village contests have jarred the county from its local-election lethargy.

THERE, is, alas, no relation between the monuments of a monarch and his virtue and success. The Baths of Caracalla are a more impressive reminder of "the grandeur that was Rome" than anything left by Marcus Aurelius, and London owes more, in the way of elegance at any rate, to the Prince Regent than to the Good Queen.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 15 -- No self-respecting Yugoslav newspaper goes to press these days without at least one article about a high-and-mighty bureaucrat who tramples on the rights of honest workers.
RHODES, Dodecanese Islands, Greece, March 11 -- Wild rejoicing marked the tenth anniversary this month of the Dodecanese Islands' incorporation into the Kingdom of Greece.
SHORT HILLS, N. J., March 15 -- The Junior League of the Oranges and the Junior Service League of Short Hills will be merged effective April 1.
Robert Moses' article brought to mind some communications I have received.
MIAMI, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- One of the most embarrassing experiences of World War II was recalled here today at a reunion of survivors of the destroyer, William D. Porter.
Among the transportation executives appearing at the Senate hearings into the "precarious" condition of the nation's railroads, George Chadbourne Taylor can testify from a relatively secure perch.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -Political attacks on the Supreme Court are a recurring phenomenon in American history. They go back at least to the time of Jefferson, who at one point called Federal judges a "subtle corp of sappers and miners constantly working underground to undermine the foundations of our confederated society."

MOST people are not aware of the extent of illiteracy in the world today. In an age that has produced the artificial satellite and the atomic submarine, it comes as a shock to many people to find that at least 44 per cent of the world's adult population, or about 700,000,000 human beings, cannot read and write.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- On the initiative of President Eisenhower, the office of Vice President has been established at the highest political and official level it has occupied in our history. And the incumbent, Richard M. Nixon, is increasingly active in this new role with the President's undoubted approval. Hence, unlike any predecessor, Nikon is publicly performing the duty of the President's constitutional deputy and the No. 2 political leader of the Administration.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 15 (AP) -- Denver scored three goals within four minutes tonight to rout North Dakota, 6 -- 2, in the final of the national collegiate hockey tournament. The Pioneers won their first college hockey title.
THE advent of the micro-groove ten years ago slowed the speed of turntables throughout the nation, but nimbly accelerated the tempo of sales of records and phonograph equipment.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Federal Communications Commission's move to pull a Miami television case back from the courts this week called attention to the fact that decisions by administrative agencies were subject to judicial review.

TWO major operatic releases are scheduled by London -- Strauss' "Arabella," with Lisa Della Casa, Hilde Gueden and George London, among others; and Giordano's "Andrea Chenier," with leading roles sung by Renata Tebaldi, Mario Del Monaco and Ettore Bastianini.

BENNETTSVILLE, S. C., March 15 (AP) -- More than 300 persons were routed from their homes in the chilly pre-dawn hours here today after a portion of an earthern dam crumbled, flooding a quarter - mile area.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 5 -- Between 3,000,000 and 4,000,000 Colombians are to choose a Congress tomorrow in a highly complicated election that will at the same time be a Presidential primary race.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -President Eisenhower will address some 3,000 delegates at his annual conference on occupational safety here on March 25. The conference lasts for three days.

THE idea of recording complete musical performances is far from new. Edison's phonograph had hardly been invented before he and others began to sense its possibilities for bringing music into the home.
Customs collections in the Port of New York area aggregated $32,874,288 last month, a gain of about $3,500,000 over February of last year, Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs, said yesterday.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, March 15 (Reuters) -- The annual session of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East, which ended here today, has approved the admission of Iran into the commission.

SEVERAL operatic sets will be offered by Angel, among them Puccini's "Manon Lescaut" with Maria Callas; the Glyndbourne performance of Mozart's "Idoneneo;" a "Meistersinger" with Ferdinand Frantz, Elisabeth Grummer and Rudolph Schock, and a "Gypsy Baron" with Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, Nicolai Gedda and others.

THE latest book by Sir Julian Huxley is a collection of essays and addresses. Its title promises more, perhaps, than the book actually delivers, for the wine, though excellent vintage Huxley, has been drawn from the same casks to which the author has returned for the past thirty years.
An effort to revive proportional representation in electing City Councilmen has been proposed as part of the current campaign to revitalize the Republican party here.
TOKYO, March 15 -- Japanese diplomats gathered here this week from all non-Communist corners of Asia to plan a massive friendship drive.

ROQUEBRUNE, France, March 15 -- Sir Winston Churchill ventured outside his Riviera villa again today and left the grounds for the first time since he suffered an attack of pneumonia and pleurisy Feb. 17. Accompanied by Lady Churchill and Mrs. Emory Reves, wife of his host, he lunched at a Cote d'Azur restaurant.
WITH the advent of high fidelity, the term hi-fi has grown in popularity to the point where it is a household word. Hi-fi has been used to describe everything from lipstick to soft drinks.

Experience. Experiments. Those two words, the nation's private electric utilities say, describe the basic needs for this country's nuclear power program.

No man inside or outside the United States Senate is more actively in favor of solvency than Harry Flood Byrd of Virginia. Since Senator Byrd first came to Washington in 1933 he has been conspicuous for his opposition to any plan for spending more dollars than could be extracted from the taxpayer.

The first indications, from laboratory test tube experiments, that the growth of fats in human arteries may be stopped or even reversed was reported yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., by Harvard University researchers.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Soviet Union in its overseas broadcasts is sedulously trying to sow suspicion of the United States good offices role in the French-Tunisian dispute.

NEW DELHI, India, March 15 -- Indian scientists are warming that great stretches of farmland in this country are being sown with a food crop that brings a crippling disease to millions who live on it.

THE success-story formula that the movies have mined so profitably over the years, the one about the office boy who rises to become head of a big corporation, now has come true in the real history of Hollywood.

EUGENE, Ore., March 15 (AP) -- A Southern Pacific passenger train jumped the tracks at 60 miles an hour near the summit of the snowbound Cascade Range early today, but none of the 197 persons aboard was killed.
The following, by the author of "Garden District," is a preface to the text of William Inge's "The Dark at the Top of the Stairs," to be published by Random House next month.
Donald Betts, pianist who made his debut here in 1951, played at Carnegie Recital Hall in yesterday's Twilight Concert.

TASHKENT, U. S. S. R., March 15 -- Oh, for the life of a pollster in the Soviet Union! A "candidate" for that matter. No troublesome issues, no baby kissing, no sectional differences, no last minute trends. No opponents.

THE lengthening days and the arrival of spring on Thursday are enough to spur the gardener into thinking practically about the planting season ahead. A sunny south or southeast window offers a chance to take the edge off his impatience, as well as to provide some vegetables and annuals for setting out later.

EUROPEAN curiosity, already aroused about the tactics of American advance guard painters, should be satisfied by the large exhibition being shipped abroad this week by the International Council at the Museum of Modern Art. Abstract Expressionists (in so far as that loose label means anything) to a man, and to a single woman, Grace Hartigan, these artists make "American type" painting embodying the new energy and ideas of the past decade.
Women's wear retailers got through the eight-day garment workers' strike on inventory, as warmer weather and Easter demand kept apparel sales at a high level.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The United Textile Workers Union adopted a nine-point financial clean-up plan today in a move to end its probationary status within the labor Federation.

THE trawler out of Gloucester was hauling her nets when it happened. A few yards off her bow, a shining cylinder of steel broke the surface of the sea in a swash of white water, erupted into flame, leaped with fantastic speed high into the air and was gone, with only a roiled spot on the sea's surface and a wisp of smoke to mark its passage.

Twenty-five Jewish organizations yesterday called on the State Legislature to enact the Asch-Rosenblatt Bill, the so-called fair Sabbath law.
The state of the nation's economic health continued to dominate both domestic and foreign news last week. That state was definitely queasy, though nothing like a crisis had set in.

State governments, state legislatures and state bodies concerned with pleasure boating are showing enlightenment as the sport mounts in popularity. New Jersey has been in the forefront for a number of years. New York has been ambitious in its forward thinking as have New Hampshire and others.

ATLANTIC CITY -- An outward air of urgency marked the sessions here last week of the Eastern regional conference of the President's Committee for Traffic Safety. But although the conference called for citizen support to spur reforms, it appeared to some observers to be groping in the dark.
BONN, Germany, March 15 -- The German question is a prime example of what happens when governments start jobs they cannot finish.
UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., March 15 -- In St. James Protestant Episcopal Church this afternoon, Miss Nancy Elliot Iayes was married to Willin S'ohn Hinmam The ceremony by the Rev. Orrin F. Judch
Assistant Secretary of the Army Hugh M. Milton 2d warned last night "against placing all our defense eggs in the nuclear basket."

HOUSTON, March 15 -- Clarence L. Coleman Jr., president of the American Council for Judaism, criticized the Zionist movement here tonight for what he termed was its "effort to include the Jews the world over in one nationalism -- the nationalism of Israel."

Mr. Clurman condemns the commercialism that exists in the theatre today. Commercialism is not only a problem in the theatre but also in other areas of American life today. Ground is expected to be broken late this spring for a $750,000 merchant marine memorial chapel. It will be built on the campus of the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L. I.
BOWIE, Md., March 15 -- A $1,500 investment made by Trainer Hirsch Jacobs fifteen years ago rang up $18,242 more on the cash register today as Paper Tiger won the Bowie Handicap.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The question whether there will be a summit conference gradually being supplanted in Washington by the questions, "When?" "Where ?" "Who?" and "What about?" The time mentioned most when is late summer or early fall.
HARBOR SPRINGS, Mich., March 15 (AP) -- It's time for the girls in the senior class of Harbor Springs High School to start dying their hair orange or black.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- The American Library Association, sponsor of National Library Week, called attention today to the need for more and better libraries.
NEW PRAGUE, Minn., March 12 -- One of the greatest scientific developments in agriculture is changing the face of a whole sector of American farming.

During the three-year period from 1954 through 1956 Soviet planes landed exploration parties on Arctic ice floes at more than two dozen points within 200 miles of North America and its off-lying islands.

The overblouse is top fashion this spring. It follows the season's favorite lanky lines, cuts loose in everything from pique to crepe, from delicate stripes to brash checks. Teamed with a straight or pleated skirt, it adds up to the latest version of the American woman's beloved uniform, the ubiquitous, long-lived costume known the world over as "separates."

AMMAN, Jordan, March 14 -- Most of Jordan has had little rain for several weeks. If substantial amounts do not fall soon, there will be a poor harvest of wheat and barley. In the Karak area of southern Jordan and around the Dead Sea there may be no harvest at all. Fields there are burned brown.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- United States officials said today that the Soviet Union had attached "wholly unacceptable conditions" to a new proposal for international control of outer space through a United Nations agency.

HIGH-FIDELITY recording techniques have brought, among other things, a revival of interest in organ literature. Carl Weinrich is deep in a project of recording for Westminster Bach's complete organ works. E. Power Biggs has recorded for Columbia an organist's tour of Europe, including performances of the Bach D Minor Toccata and Fugue on a number of famous European instruments.

MADRID, March 15 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco suspended in parts of Spain today constitutional provisions that protect Spaniards from arbitrary arrest and unlawful entry into their homes and that allow them to live where they choose. The action hits at strikers.

BIOGRAPHIES of the great written by their grandsons are apt to be partisan and overly reverent. "Louis Pasteur" by the great man's grandson, Pasteur Vallery-Radot, is not free of these faults. But Pasteur was really great, and his grandson, who is a noted physician and medical researcher in his own right, and the author of several previous books on Pasteur, makes him so appealing that the book's lack of critical shading does not matter much.
Recurring appeals for a broadening of the market for state and local government securities received timely support last week from the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

TEN years ago the Alley Theatre in Houston consisted of an energetic, good - humored lady with an idea and the enthusiasm of many other local amateurs. The word "Alley" in the title referred to the brick corridor that led from the street to the studio where the first production, "A Sound of Hunting," was performed.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The politics of fighting the recession -- much like the politics of reacting to the Soviet missile-satellite threat -- appears to have produced an extraordinary result: more agreement than disagreement about what to do.

In Washington last week the fact of the recession struck home with new impact. Day after day the signs that the recession was deepening multiplied, and the conviction grew that action to check it must soon be taken.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -- Northrup Knox of Buffalo and Aiken, S. C., retained the amateur court tennis championship of the United States today. The 29-year-old Yale graduate defeated Alastair B. Martin of Glen Head, L. I., at the Racquet Club, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3.

Blends of man-made fibers in students' and boys' suits have been losing ground and will account for only 11 per cent of the boys' volume and 4 per cent of the students' sales next fall, according to a survey by the Boys Apparel Buyers Association and the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.

And since, to judge by the contents of her book, Ann Bullingham is a woman of sense and honesty, this reader will take her word for it that the inhabitants of her particular village say things like, "He idn't there," "It be over now," and "maid," when they refer to a little girl.

Aside from being impeached, Johnson was accused of being illegitimate and a drunkard, of being a traitor to his party and his country, and of conspiring to assassinate Lincoln.

THIS is a dispiriting age for anyone whose mechanical aptitude reached its limit when he had to put a needle into a phonograph tone arm. SILVER SPRINGS, Fla., March 15 -- John Hoffman and Crawford Greene of Tampa, in a Renault Dauphine, led the Great Florida National Rally at the end of the first phase today. They completed the 476-mile, thirteen-hour sports car drive from Vero Beach to this resort town with 245 penalty points.

WITH the publication of the letters of Emily Dickinson, Thomas H. Johnson (assisted by Theodora Ward as associate editor) has completed the monumental task he set himself when he edited the three volumes of Dickinson poems, published in 1955.

BOSTON, March 15 -- An off-the-ice brawl marked the New York Rangers' 4-0 National Hockey League victory over the Boston Bruins today. The incident occurred when Lou Fontinato, a defenseman for the visitors, attacked a fan who heckled him.

Nikita S. Khrushchev is being hailed in the Soviet press as a great theoretician introducing fruitful advances into Marxist-Leninist theory. This is the highest acolade that can be given a Communist leader.

TRIVANDRUM, India, March 7 -- Communism's ballot-box victory in Kerala may turn out to be the political salvation of the democratic parties of this South Indian state.

MIAMI, March 15 -- A winter trade in baseball, a big item of interest in the off-season, can be a confusing operation. In some cases it can turn out to be a front-office error more disastrous to a club than a player's error on the field, or it can be a bonanza for one team.

The main question about the atom is simple indeed: does it stand for twilight or for dawn? Dr. Willard F. Libby of the Atomic Energy Commission gave cautious support in his testimony before a Senate committee, made public last Thursday, to the theory that the sun may be coming up instead of going down.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 15 -- Contract bridge experts from all parts of the nation arrived here today as the 1958 Spring Championship Contest of the American Contract Bridge League opened at the Traymore Hotel.

THE music division of the Library of Congress is resting a little easier these days because of the start it has made in solving the basic problem of all record collectors.

The $80,000, one-room, brick-and-glass building was officially dedicated last week, but its doors have been open since Thanksgiving.

Dr. Henry K. Wachtel has raised certain questions regarding the type of cancer research supported by public and quasi-public agencies. In response, Harry Grundfest has replied that the significance of research can only be evaluated in retrospect.

The Hebrew University of Jerusalem will benefit from the annual art sale and collectors' exhibition to be held by the Women's Division of the American Friends of the Hebrew University. The event will take place from May 4 through May 8 at University House, 9 East Eighty-ninth Street.

WHEN I was an undergraduate at Dartmouth, we sang a song that began: "'Don't send my son to Princeton,' the dying mother said." If this volume of essays, in which eleven Princeton seniors, class of '57, comment on their lives, their education and their hopes for the future, is widely read, the song may land in the No. 1 spot on the Hit Parade.

THE Alamo Chapel in the heart of San Antonio is a shrine visited by every Texan and thousands from over the world. Once inside they uncover in silence and reverence. Though the Alamo was once a mission, its meaning is not religious.

Plans for Soviet-American competition in sports in both countries this spring and summer are virtually complete, the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States announced yesterday.
Thousands eager for the sweet scent of spring thronged the Coliseum yesterday for the final day of the Forty-first International Flower Show.
WESTPORT, Conn., March 16 -- Memories of days when this was a sleepy village with a trolley car clanking along Main Street were revived today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- The Yankees defeated the world champion Braves today and thereby eased condsiderably the suffering of a painful winter of discontent. But the 4-1 victory, achieved before a gathering of 7,872, does not bear too close an inspection.
A panel of high school students on The New York Times Youth Forum could give no definitive answer yesterday to the question: "Are today's teenagers non-readers?"

A Queens man forced his way into the Brooklyn home of a woman acquaintance last night, shot the woman, her sister and her mother and then killed himself.

Increasing numbers of New York City patrolmen were said yesterday to be transferring to the Fire Department because the "discipline is much greater" in the Police Department.

PITTSBURGH, March 16 -Steel ordering was unchanged last week. There was no evidence of a decline, but neither was there any sign that an upturn was in prospect.
PARIS, March 16 -- The Independent party warned the Government today that concessions to Tunisia might lead to withdrawal of the party's ministers.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- A new Explorer satellite will be launched within about week, the Army Secretary, Wiber M. Brucker, said today.
