THE National Broadcasting Company presented yesterday afternoon two successive programs dealing with the state of contemporary entertainment media. On "Wide Wide World" there was a fascinating study of the theatre; on "Look Here," an interview with a leading television writer who scored the home screen's creative limitations.

NAHA, Okinawa, Monday, March 17 (AP) -- The first unofficial election returns gave proAmerican candidates a slim lead today over Leftists in a battle for seats in the Ryukyu Islands Legislative Assembly.

Governor Harriman, with a little help, turned librarian yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -Grain futures prices were hit last week by a mixture of influences, mostly bearish, and nearly all wheat, corn and oats contracts on the Board of Trade finished well below the preceding week's closing levels.

PARIS, March 16 -- A Rightist war veterans' leader who favors continuation of the military-political "pacification" program in Algeria won the most votes today in an important legislative by-election in Paris.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -The Government has taken the position for the first time that Americans have a constitutional right to travel abroad.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 -- Everybody in Hollywood is in show business, including taxi drivers.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 16 (AP) -- A dynamite blast ripped the front of the Jewish Community Center building tonight. A telephone call later linked the explosion to school integration.

SIR WINSTON CHURCHILL is 83 years old, a tired old man convalescing from still another illness. The brilliant mind, the indomitable will and the kinetic energy that enabled him to reach peaks of greatness unmatched by any of his contemporaries are no longer devoted to the welfare of his country and of the world.
Marcella Pobbe, who made her debut recently, will sing her first Marguerite at the Metropolitan Opera in Gounod's "Faust" on March 29.

COVINGTON, Ky., March 16 (AP) -- A Cincinnati physician said tonight that Maurice Stokes, professional basketball star of the Cincinnati Royals, might be suffering from encephalitis or a "brain fever."
OF the fifteen or sixteen pipe bands that will pace the St. Patrick's Day marchers this day the oldest is the Tyrone Band. The most anomalous in lots of ways is the Donegal Pipe Band.

A total of 1,045 dictating and transcribing machines has been delivered to 525 offices of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company by the SoundScriber Corporation. Henry J. Servais, SoundScriber executive vice president, said it probably was the largest single order of its kind.

Marco Sorisio, tenor, assisted by his brother Roberto, bassbaritone, appeared in recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Marco Sorisio offered a group of arias from operas of Domenico Freschi, a Schumann group, "Ah, la paterna mano," from "Macbeth," and works of Mayboroda, Fomenko, Menino, Barthelmy and Velasquez.

CHICAGO, March 16 (UP) -- Ed Litzenberger scored a third-period goal tonight to lead Chicago to a 3-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs that pulled the Black Hawks within 2 points of escape from the National Hockey League cellar.
LONDON, March 16 -- A survey by the Federation of British Industries has shown a decline in the profit margins of many British companies and in the rate at which new orders are being received.

PROVIDENCE, March 16 -Maxwell Riddle of Ravenna, Ohio, lost little time in judging best of show tonight. He selected the imported Airedale terrier, Ch. Westhay Fiona of Harham, owned by Harold M. Florsheim of Chicago and handled by Tom Gately of Wilton, Conn.

An agreement has been reached whereby Phil Silvers will star in a special one-hour revue May 13 over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network. It will be presented from 10 to 11 P. M., according to tentative plans, under the sponsorship of Pontiac.

ST. JOHN'S, Antigua, March 16 -- This island, which with its two dependencies has a population of 54,000 in an area of about 170 square miles, faces fewer problems than most of the units in the newly formed West Indies Federation.
Restraint of religious freedom was declared yesterday to exist not only in Communist-dominated countries but also in virtually every part of the world.

LIKE the bubbles in an uncorked bottle, the cost of champagne imported from France is likely to rise before the end of the year. According to Jacques Mercier, director general of a company in Epernay that bears his name, the last two years have produced harvests of grapes that were disappointingly, if not to say devastatingly, small.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- There is "no possibility" that the Soviet Union can realize Nikita S. Khrushchev's boast of catching up with the United States in meat and milk production by 1960, a farm study group said today.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -Henry Stoecker, who judged best in show at the National Capital Kennel Club dog show tonight, had exactly the same opinion of Ch. Evening Star de Luchar, a Skye terrier, as Walter Reeves had at Harrisburg last night.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 16 -- President Tito charged the West today with attempted "sabotage" of the proposed summit conference.

The Long Island Lighting Company estimated yesterday that the population of Nassau County had increased by 112,817 in the two years ended Jan. 1, 1958. It figured Suffolk County had grown by 106,293 in the same period.
A fashion show of dogwear will be one of the highlights of the tenth annual Spring Frolic benefit of the Humane Society of New York. The tea dance will be held in the Plaza on April 18.

Dr. Frederick Burkhardt, president of the American Council of Learned Societies, has made a stimulating report, to a Senate committee, on the lack of adequate facilities in this country for the study of Asian languages. He was able to point out the precise spots at which teaching materials, such as textbooks and dictionaries, were woefully inadequate.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- Fred Haney brought his Braves to this home base of the Yankees today for what might have been the eighth game of the world series. The only trouble was that Milwaukee wrapped up that business last October. But it still was uppermost in everyone's mind.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The Pentagon announced tonight a consolidation of the Various United States military groups in Taiwan advising and assisting the Chinese Nationalist forces commanded by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, March 14 -- The New Zealand meat trade is startled and bewildered at reports of a large-scale venture in the shipment of live beef cattle to the United States. American reports refer to four trial shipments each of 1,500 head of prime cattle valued at $750,000, to be followed by shipments of 1,500 every fifty days.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 16 (Reuters) -Pilots of KLM Royal Dutch Airlines in th eNetherlands went on strike tonight to support demands that the company take back two fliers it dismissed yesterday.

Neither conformity nor social planning can solve the "riddle of inequality," the Rev. Dr. Paul Tillich told an audience f teachers, college students and seminarians at Union Theological Seminary yesterday.

The net worth of ninety-eight investment banking houses having headquarters in New York City rose 5.2 per cent in the last year, according to a survey published by Finance Magazine in its March issue, out today.

PARIS, March 16 -- France's economic productivity increased 29 per cent between 1949 and 1956. The average increase for the seven-year period was 3.7 per cent a year.

The property at 134 Lister Avenue, Newark, consisting of an industrial building and two and three-fourths acres of land, has been purchased by Benjamin Moore Co., paint manufacturer. The buyer occupies the adjoining site and will use the newly acquired parcel for expansion.

Eighty nominees in seventeen categories were announced yesterday as candidates for the 1958 Tony Awards. "The Music Man" received the most nominations -- nine -- in the musical play list.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The convention of the United Textile Workers elected a new slate of officers today.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 16 -- The Swiss National Bank last week abolished, as from March 10, the last remaining obligations of banks to keep minimum cash reserves on deposit. The amount originally fixed had already been cut by stages in the last few months to a residual 25 per cent.
FLORENCE, Italy, March 16 -- The rebuilt Ponte Santa Trinita, one of the bridges over the River Arno that were destroyed by the Germans in World War II, was solemnly reopened today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 -- The Western-town set at Paramount studio is getting a $100,000 face-lifting in preparation for the start of filming on the Hal Wallis production, "The Last Train From Laredo." Part of the extensive remodeling job includes the laying of a stretch of railroad track, for this apparently is to be one movie where there will be an obvious connection between the title and the plot.

WHITE PLAINS, March 17 -- Allegations that the $11,000,000 Westchester County airport in Purchase is needless and a "fraud on the taxpayers" were denied today.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The House Agriculture Committee approved today a one-year farm price support freeze. It would prohibit Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, from reducing supports on this year's crop below 1957 levels.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. denied yesterday that discipline in the Fire Department was any easier than that in the Police Department.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 17 (AP) -- Five young Air Force officers who stepped out of a "space ship" today after five days of a simulated orbit of the earth submitted to tests to determine their efficiency on the flight.

The American Broadcasting Company plans a major shake-up in its radio division in order to make operations "compatible with present-day radio network economies."
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 17 --Years of research and preparation for launching the United States' first earth satellite funneled down today into the steady hand of a cool New Yorker.

Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., has declared a year-end dividend of 50 cents a share. It is payable March 31 to holders of record on March 26. The company paid a similar year-end dividend in March, 1957.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17 -- Agreement on a new collective bargaining contract covering actors in TV film commercials has been reached, according to John L. Dales, national executive secretary of the Screen Actors Guild.
The International Paper Company announced yesterday it had acquired the Lord Baltimore Press, Inc., of Baltimore, Md., through an exchange of stock. Details of the transaction were not disclosed.

The Vanguard rocket that put a small Navy satellite into orbit from Cape Canaveral, Fla., yesterday was known technically as TV-4. It was actually the sixth in a series of test vehicles going back to Dec. 8, 1956.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The White House announced today the appointment of John A. Stephens as a consultant to President Eisenhower's Special Assistant on Foreign Economic Policy.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Supreme Court held today that truckers who paid fines to states for overloading could not deduct them from Federal tax returns as "ordinary and necessary" business expenses.
CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -Demand for wheat broadened shortly before the close on the Board of Trade today. Prices at the finish were higher all along the line.
The country's chief mediator of labor-management disputes reported yesterday that the recession was cutting the strike total.

A $2,693,249 damage suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court against Madison Square Garden Corporation and five individuals. The action was brought by Leonard A. Peto, a former director of the Montreal Canadiens' professional hockey team, who charged he was prevented from establishing a major hockey team in Philadelphia.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 17 (UP) -- City and state officials acted today to avert further threatened violence after the bombing last night of a Jewish community center here. The blast followed by eighteen hours the dynamiting of another Jewish building in Miami, Fla.

Each day since New Year's we have driven by Thomas Edison's winter home here in Fort Myers. His biographies narrate his voracious reading and study from childhood to old age. During National Library Week it is salutary to recall his hundreds of attempts to find a usable filament, and the 40,000 words he copied into 200 of his notebooks from his own study and research for just one invention, the electric lamp.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 17 -- The Indonesian Army claimed victory tonight in a one-day struggle with the rebels for Medan, biggest city on Sumatra.

Since 1898 the Red Cross has served as an auxiliary to our armed forces. During the SpanishAmerican War the Red Cross in New York chartered the schooners Mary E. and B. W. Morse and sent them from Maine to Cuba with 1,643 tons of ice for the military hospitals.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Although the White House door is always open to George Gordon Moore, he has eluded the publicity spotlight so successfully that few of the capital's best-informed men would recognize him on sight.

ONCE in a while an item of food that is abundant, inexpensive and potentially delicious arrives at local markets, only to be ignored by the menu-planning public. Such an edible is mussels, a highly succulent and nourishing shellfish.
TOKYO, March 12 -- Japan's peacetime "kamikaze corps," the city taxi drivers, are under pressure to moderate their daredevil antics.

There was good cause for rejoicing yesterday when the news came that the Vanguard rocket had successfully put its first miniature earth satellite into orbit. The congratulations which were deservedly showered upon the scientists and engineers who had made this feat possible were all the warmer because this accomplishment had come after the earlier disappointments and failures.
In respect to your editorial of March 11 entitled "Can the Railroads Wait?" I feel that the following observations should be of interest.

Hofmann Industries, Inc., of Sinking Springs, Pa., manufacturer of metal castings, is soliciting proxies with a view to winning control of the directorate of the Van Dorn Iron Works Company of Cleveland at the latter's annual meeting on April 2.
Leaders of Government, business and advertising turned out yesterday to pay tribute to Bernard C. (Ben) Duffy, vice chairman of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborne, Inc.

How a theatrical feud mushroomed into class war is told in a new book titled "The Astor Place Riot" by Richard Moody. On the night of May 10, 1849, Edwin Forrest, the American actor, and his British rival of twenty-three years, William Macready, were both appearing in plays, the latter in "Macbeth" at the Astor Place Opera House.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 17 -- Colombia found herself today without a promising candidate for the May 4 Presidential election.
DENVER, March 17 (AP) -- The wreckage of a private plane was found today on a rolling, snow-covered prairie of eastern Colorado. All three occupants were dead.

The Federal Government filed yesterday an antitrust suit against the Hoover Company, manufacturer of electric vacuum cleaners, charging conspiracy in restraint of trade in the New York metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to consider an additional facet of the problem of military trials of civilians.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The State Department has given two Soviet diplomats permission to visit the University of North Carolina. It has restricted any side trips they might want to make beyond Chapel Hill to a distance of twenty-five miles.
ROME, March 17 -- The second legislature of the Italian Republic came to an end today when President Giovanni Gronchi dissolved both the Senate and the Chamber.
The atomic age in shipping will begin this summer for an advance guard of American seamen who will man the world's first nuclear-powered merchant ship.
PARIS, March 17 -- Mr. Murphy and Mr. Beeley arrived here by air late tonight from Tunis.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17 -- Dore Schary made it official today. His first motion picture as an independent producer will be a new version of "Miss Lonelyhearts," based on the play and novel written by Howard Teichmann and Nathanael West, respectively.
MADRID, March 17 -- The celebrated Spanish pride is emerging with a slightly novel twist these days.

Handling 5,209 fewer freight cars and 170,524 fewer passengers, the New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad Company in 1957 operated at a deficit of $388,489, compared with a deficit of $194,339 in 1956.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Some of the nation's top scientists came out today against a proposal in Congress to establish a Federal Department of Science with Cabinet status.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Industrial production dropped 3 points in February, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This matched the 3-point decline in January.

The scholarship and opportunity fund of Brookwood Child Care (Orphan Asylum Society of the City of Brooklyn) will be augmented as a result of a bridge party on Monday. The event will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre at 2 P. M.
One of the finest achievements of a distinguished career is Zinka Milanov's impersonation of Desdemona in Verdi's "Otello," which she sang for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera last night.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will be guest of honor at Hunter College's birthday assembly celebrating the fifteenth anniversary. of the Sara Delano Roosevelt Memorial House, which was donated to the college in 1943.
LONDON, March 17 -- A statement by the Federation of British Industries that profit margins were shrinking, and continuing uncertainty over United States trade, depressed the stock market here today.
Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld upheld yesterday the sanctity of information given to the Department of Commerce's Census Bureau by private concerns.
One of seven teen-age gang members on trial for the killing of Michael Farmer last July 30 was described yesterday in General Sessions Court as a "chronic epileptic."
TUNIS, March 17 -- A compromise settlement of the French-Tunisian crisis was predicted in well-informed quarters here today.

Richards W. Hannah, the newly appointed chairman of the State Lottery Control Commission, promised "fair and square" enforcement of the Bingo Law as he was sworn in yesterday by Carmine G. De Sapio, New York's Secretary of State.
The Metropolitan Opera and R. C. A. Victor have signed a three-year contract for a series of complete opera recordings.
The Intergovernmental Maritime Consultative Organization came into being yesterday. It is designed to set up a new United Nations agency in the field of shipping.

NAHA, March 17 (Reuters) -- All the parties except the Minren are pledged to cooperate with the American military government administering the Ryukyu's eighty-nine islands and islets stretching from the southern tip of Japan to Formosa.

"STUDIO ONE IN HOLLYWOOD" made an impressive return to professionalism last night over Channel 2. After a series of excursions into mediocrity, the program offered an absorbing and unusual drama by John Vlahos. It was produced and directed with rare artistry and acted with distinction.

A few days ago the head of the house was driving along the Merritt Parkway, headed west to New York from Boston, which is Down East. He was going at his usual rate of speed, which is the statutory number of miles per hour, plus five for the pot.
CINCINNATI, March 17 (AP) -- Barring complications, it now look's as if Maurice Stokes, Cincinnati Royals' basketball player, will recover from his sudden critical illness, a specialist said tonight.
TRENTON, March 17 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner named Raymond F. Male, his administrative assistant, as a member of the New Jersey Civil Service Commission today.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP) -- The State Department reminded twenty-six news organizations today that their correspondents should have theirs renewed before they expire Saturday.

PLANNING a home for retirement is a problem facing an increasing number of Americans every year. Of the millions who are retired from business today, many choose to revamp their present quarters while others exchange them for new ones.

We begin to wonder, with considerable concern, when New York City's Board of Education is going to recall from the streets the several hundred children still under suspension for bad behavior or delinquency. It is impossible to get up-to-date figures on how many students remain suspended; one would think that this problem is so serious and its solution of such urgency that a daily check would be made.

Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, accused Borough President John Cashmore yesterday of attempting "to obstruct" the $85,000,000 Brooklyn waterfront development program.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The revelations before the Harris subcommittee of the House, of political, personal and other pressures to influence the decisions of members of Federal commissions, point to a remedy which has been urged on Congress for at least four years.

TOKYO, March 17 -- The New York City Ballet received a rare tribute from an enthusiastic audience in the opening performance tonight of a tour of Japan. At the conclusion of the four - part performance, cheering Japanese dance lovers in the front rows showered the stage with bouquets, an unusual gesture in Tokyo, though it is an ancient custom in rural Japan.
CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, March 17 -If you're not confused about the current economic situation, it's a cinch you're not reading the Congressional Record.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a lower court decision sharply restricting the Government's power to prohibit the coloring of oranges with allegedly poisonous dyes.
The playing of the National Anthem helped to calm an excited gathering of 15,140 wrestling fans at Madison Square Garden last night.
Dr. John J. Theobald, who has three important city jobs, will be nominated this week for a fourth.
NOW here is a letter that presents an almost insoluble problem, though somebody skilled in juju may have the answer. It comes from Dr. Charles Sandler of 1749 Grand Concourse, a man under a curse.

The apartment house for seventy-two families at 2385-87 Creston Avenue, south of Fordham Road, in the Bronx has been sold by Morris Goodman after an ownership of thirty years. The five-and-one-half-story structure was purchased by a syndicate formed by the Irving Byron Company, realty operator and investor.

Sales of the Corning Glass Works last year were the second highest in its history of 106 years. The total of $159,069,721 was 2.4 per cent under the record of $163,053,554 established in 1956, the annual report yesterday said.
DALAS, March 17 (AP) -- Space must not become an uncoordinated "flying junkyard," Gen. Thomas D. White, Air Force Chief of Staff, warned today.
MADRID, March 17 -- The Spanish Government is preparing to help 30,000 Spanish colonists emigrate to the Spanish Sahara.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Navy's tiny test satellite -- a humming symbol of success after months of frustration -- seemed destined today for a life of up to ten years in space.

The recession has caught up with nickel, one of the metals in shortest supply during the Korean War and the years following. The largest producer, the International Nickel Company of Canada, announced yesterday that it was curtailing production because free world output "is substantially in excess of total market demand."

In February bankruptcies reported by Dun Bradstreet totaled 1,238, slightly fewer than in the longer month of January but 8 per cent more than in February last year. It was the highest level for any February in twenty-five years. However, the liabilities of the bankrupts totaled only $65,295,000 this February, compared with $65,406,000 a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Most Rev. Amleto Cicognani, Pope Pius personal representative in the United States, marked a double anniversary today.
BOCA RATON, Fla., March 17 -- Many problems in home building were attributed today to government planners' insistence on using the industry as an economic buffer.
ALBANY, March 17 -- Governor Harriman vetoed tonight a Republican bill to broaden the power of Attorney General Louis Lefkowitz to investigate crime.

Your columns, as well as those of all other papers, are amply supplied with news and opinions about two topics -- the needs of American education and inflation. There is one topic, closely related to both of these themes, which I feel merits immediate attention. It is the matter of the validity of retirement pensions.

There's a fourth brand of discrimination abroad today as unfair, amoral and economically wasteful as those based on race, color and creed. This is universal corporate employment discrimination against the middle-aged. It is now the unabashed practice of all corporations -- industrial, commercial and financial -- to seal their personnel offices against the job seeker over 40, and in many instances over 35, regardless of ability, experience or skill.
A couple of slugging Irishmen gave a St. Patrick's night crowd of 1,306 more than a wee bit to cheer about at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
The High School Teachers Association called upon Superintendent of Schools William Jansen yesterday to reconsider decision to return to old policies for suspending pupils.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to examine an antitrust judgment against the International Boxing Club of New York and other individual and corporate fight promoters.

Extensive footage that was not included in the released version of the feature-length documentary, "On the Bowery," has been given to the Museum of the City of New York. The unshown footage constitutes a film record of contemporary American life that no longer can be duplicated.
CHICAGO, March 17 -- Ritual plays an important part in the life of every exchange.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Two of three spokesmen for the nation's common carrier barge operators warned Congress today that their industry might well disappear if it were forced to pay tolls for maintenance and improvement of the inland waterways.

LONDON, March 17 -- Dr. Paul A. Siple, United States polar scientist, has been awarded the Royal Geographical Society's Patron's Medal. The society announced today Queen Elizabeth II had approved the award.

Someone, somewhere, seems to have slipped. This ought to have been designated as "Winston Churchill Week" here in New York. He pervades the news, just as he has always pervaded our interest, attention and affection.
The Navy's Vanguard rocket bore more than a globular satellite aloft yesterday.

First-quarter sales by Robert Reis Co., underwear manufacturers, will be below the $1,067,131 for the similar period last year, Arthur Reis Jr., president, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday. However, he said, a pickup in the soft goods field was anticipated by summer.

DENVER, March 17 (AP) -- Leaders of the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter workers called on Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, today to take immediate emergency measures to save the non-ferrous metals industry.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 17 -- Scientists of Project Vanguard fired a 6.4-inch satellite sphere into orbit around the earth today.
Mayor Wagner expressed concern yesterday over the "sharp repercussions" of the deepening economic recession on the city's budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

RABAT, Morocco, March 17 -- Morocco indirectly has brought up the question of its unsettled Saharan boundaries before the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Her economic attache in Washington formally expressed today his Government's "strict reservations" about a French request for a loan from the bank for exploitation of iron mines in Mauritania.
OVIEDO, Spain, March 17 (AP) -- A twelve-day strike of miners in the Asturian coal basin ended today under Government threats of drastic action.
Fordham will play top-seeded Dayton and Bradley, last year's winner, will engage Xavier of Cincinnati in National Invitation Tournament quarter-final contests at Madison Square Garden tonight.
The Pennsylvania State Public School Authority announced yesterday that it would offer at public bidding on April 8 an issue of $18,000,000 of refunding bonds of series B and series C.

Under the present law barring a third term for the President, Mr. Eisenhower is ineligible for re-election in 1960. There has been much debate as to how much, if any, this fact has weakened his authority and influence in the shaping of legislation in his second term.
A TIMID soul might be frightened off by a special department store sale called a "Door Buster." Not so an astute shopper. A sale by this or any other such name constitutes a challenge to her.
James R. Hoffa has personally intervened to permit the leader of his rank-and-file critics to run for office in a New York local of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
LONDON, March 17 (Reuters) -- High fashions decreed by Rome, Florence, Paris and London are the rage in Leningrad, according to Soviet Radio.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP) -- The National Institute of Municipal Law officers warned today that the nation was "fast dissipating" one of its major natural resources -- fresh air.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- An equally divided Supreme Court affirmed today a lower court ruling that Jack Benny violated the copyright laws when he parodied the movie "Gaslight" on television.
It is now Max Liebman's turn to envision a Broadway musical conception of "The Shop Around the Corner," the Miklos Laszlo comedy first labeled "Perfumerie."

MIAMI, Tuesday, March 18 (AP) -- Mogu, a forty-three-foot yawl sailed by F. S. Guggenheimer of St. Petersburg, Fla., took the lead on corrected time early today in the St. Petersburg-Miami yacht race.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Beverly Baker Fleitz of La Jolla, Calif., easily won her first-round match from Ingeborg Bogler of Germany today in the sixth annual Puerto Rican internation tennis tournament. The scores were 6-0, 6-0.

FREEPORT, L. I., March 17 -- There are some healthy looking boatmen in the South Shore Yacht Club in this Long Island town but about this time every year they develop an itch. It starts when they install their officers and rapidly turns into an epidemic of discussions about spring fitting-out and summer cruises.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The "wearin' o' the green" was almost as general at the White House today as the wearing of "I Like Ike" campaign-buttons used to be. From President Eisenhower down to the newest Secret Service agent, just about every other person sported a bit of green, whether a necktie or scarf, a flower or a store-bought silken shamrock and clay pipe for the lapel.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 17 -- The Aluminum 6.4-inch satellite that was launched here today is only a test sphere containing a minimum of instrumentation.

ALBANY, March 17 -- Governor Harriman urged the Legislature tonight to adopt a Republican bill that would give statutory recognition to the contract between the Transport Workers Union and the New York City Transit Authority.

CROTON - ON - HUDSON, March 17 -- Water in the New York City reservoirs is so plentiful that it is again going to waste here. Watershed engineers said 500,000,000 gallons went over the spillway of Cornell Dam today to flow down the Croton River and into the Hudson.

A syndicate managed by Stone and Webster Securities Corporation and White, Weld Co. is offering for public subscription 200,000 shares of $100 par value 5.16 per cent dividend convertible second preferred stock of the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company.

NEW DELHI, India, March 17 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Socialist-minded Congress party published today an analysis of the advantages of foreign investment to an underdeveloped country. It was the sort of article that could have been at home in the pages of The Wall Street Journal.
A Columbia University project holds that nuclear weapons tests can be detected "unless they are within an order of magnitude of conventional weapons."
TRENTON, March 17 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner and the Legislature were informed today that about $12,000,000 annually was diverted from charity in New Jersey by unscrupulous fund-raisers.
ALBANY, March 17 -- A bill to end competitive rates in casualty insurance was strongly condemned tonight in a memorandum released by the State Insurance Department.

A recommendation that the 1960 Winter Olympic Games start a week later than the original Feb. 12 date at Squaw Valley, Calif., will be made by Prentis C. Hale of San Francisco, the president of the Organizing Committee.

Commodity futures moved generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was active in several markets. Cottonseed oil, cocoa, coffee, copper and rubber rose; wool and hides declined, and price movements for sugar, potatoes and lead were mixed.
The Board of Higher Education's five-year investigation of subversive influences in the municipal college system will be formally finished at the end of this month.

THE plan to offer educational television over Channel 9, which now has won the support of Republican legislative leaders and seems assured of Governor Harriman's approval, could prove to be the year's most important television development.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17 -- The United States is standing firm on its plan to have United Nations organs endorse proposed disarmament negotiations outside the United Nations.

Last week-end Generalissimo Franco "suspended in parts of Spain constitutional guarantees that protect Spaniards from arbitrary arrest and unlawful entry into their homes and that allow them to live where they choose. The action hits at strikers."
GENEVA, March 17 -- Canadian demands for wider fishing rights in the high seas gained support today at the United Nations conference on the law of the sea.
NEW LONDON, Conn., March 17 (UP) -- The Navy announced today that the first atomic submarine division in naval history would be formed here on March 31.

DO it now. That is the message of today's Shop Talk. The morning's program includes notes on where to buy spring slip covers to fold over your books and bouquets of fake flowers to arrange as pinch-hitters for the garden variety. To wit:

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court, by 5 -- 4, refused today to interfere with the distribution of asserted excess commuter fares paid by riders in the Chicago area to the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad.

After first ridiculing President Eisenhower's plan for control of outer space missiles, Moscow has now seized upon a distorted version of it to make a typical Soviet proposal. The Soviets declare themselves willing to ban the use of outer space for military purposes in return for the elimination of foreign military bases on territories of other states, primarily in Europe, the Middle East and North Africa.

ATLANTIC CITY, Tuesday, March 18 -- Mrs. Sally Young and Robert Jordan early this morning took the first-session lead in the three-session mixed pair championship of the 1958 Contract Bridge Spring National Championships. The Philadelphia pair had 224 match points at the Traymore Hotel here.

There will be a preview of a J. Arthur Rank film at 8:30 tonight at the Beekman Theatre for the benefit of Neighbors United, a unit of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association. The title of the film will not be announced until the showing.
Stocks reacted to a week-end diet of tasteless business and industrial news by giving ground yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, March 17 -- Sweden's Royal Ballet will tour the United States next year. A preliminary decision on this was made when Sol Hurok, impresario, made a week-end visit to Stockholm.
At least twenty long-distance passenger trains of the New York Central Railroad arrived late in Grand Central Terminal yesterday as the result of a freight derailment upstate Sunday morning.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 17 -- This being spring training the Yankees today decided to practice something new. They concentrated on picking themselves off the mat after an early knockdown and then rallying to gain a smashing victory.
The new Vanguard satellite was apparently heard but not seen yesterday.
Prices of cotton futures moved 3 points up to 8 points off on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. A point is equal to 5 cents a bale.
Sales and operating revenues of the Aluminum Company of America reached a record $869,378,093 last year, compared with $864,416,165 in 1956.
ALBANY, March 17 -- A bill to permit harness racing to start in New York on March 25 instead of April 1 was submitted to the Legislature tonight.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 17 -- The most delightful rookie along the Grapefruit Circuit undoubtedly is Albie Pearson of the Washington Senators. He isn't fresh. He's just refreshing. He's bright of face, bright of mind and bright in his conversation.

The American Gas and Electric Company reported yesterday that its earnings set a record in February. Net for the month was $4,218,642, for a gain of 2 per cent over the $4,137,096 reported a year earlier.

The bloodmobiles of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will visit The New York Daily News today at 220 East Forty-second Street and the American Bosch Arma Corporation, New South Road, Hicksville, L. I. Blood will also be donated at the New York Telephone Company, 199 Fulton Street, Hempstead, L. I.
JACKSON, Miss., March 17 -- A bill of complaint charging that Negroes were being kept from voting in Jefferson Davis County was filed today in Federal District Court.
THE giggles have died down. The chemise is no longer the maverick of the fashion world. The "Trapeze Line" means a definite shape, not circus equipment.

Net savings in New York State's 235 savings and loan associations rose $19,572,945 in February to $3,125,402,756, according to the Savings Association League of New York State. This was $2,800,594, or 16.7 per cent, higher than the gain in February, 1957.
ALBANY, March 17 (UP) -- The following skiing conditions were reported to the State Commerce Department today:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 17 (AP) -- The Arkansas Supreme Court declined today to pass on whether President Eisenhower had acted within proper authority in stationing troops here last September to enforce court-ordered integration of Central High School.
Increased competition from Soviet aluminum exports appears to be at least the near-term prospect for Western aluminum producers.

The ex-President and ousted dictator of Venezuela, Gen. Marcos Perez Jimenez, is reportedly planning to move from his present roosting-place in the congenial climate of Ciudad Trujillo to the neighborhood of Washington, D. C., where his former chief of police already boasts a home.

WHITE PLAINS, March 17 -- After thirty years of vainly fighting railroad fare increases and service reductions, Westchester County decided today on a new course. It plans to deal with the railroads as sick industries in need of help.
A little man named Tubby stopped Willie Hall on a Harlem street corner about four and a half years ago.

The top four in the annual international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata retained their positions in the standing after yesterday's play in the fifth round, according to a report received through Argentine news sources.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- A majority report of the Senate Anti-Trust subcommittee said today that electric utility companies had received large benefits from the Government's tax write-off policy.

Your March 14 editorial "Court Reform Crisis" confronts the Legislature, and particularly its Democratic members, with the challenge to adopt the concurrent resolution approving the reform, or to be chargeable with a serious failure in social responsibility.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 17 -- Law enforcement is as much a calling as any dedicated profession, according to Guy W. Calissi, Prosecutor of Bergen County. Therefore he believes that all counties in New Jersey should have academies to train police candidates under state supervision.
NAHA, Okinawa, March 17 -- Unofficial returns today in the elections for the legislature of the Ryukyu Islands showed that the non-Communists widely outnumbered the Communists.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 17 -- Israel expects Dr. Francisco Urrutia, personal representative of the United Nations Secretary General, to return to this area soon for further talks on the status of Mount Scopus.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -Republican women were told today that the recession would fade as a big issue by next fall's Congressional elections.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 17 (UP) -- King Faisal of Iraq announced today the completion of a Constitution for the new Iraqi-Jordanian Federation. He expressed the hope that the union would gain victory "against all our enemies."

BASSETERRE, St. Kitts, West Indies, March 13 -- The relationship of organized labor to government on this small island is a good example of what may be expected throughout the newly formed West Indies Federation in the near future.

Bankers' acceptances outstanding in the United States increased $100,640,000 in February, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The increase compared with a rise of $114,748,000 in January and a decrease of $19,328,000 in Feruary, 1957.

Most dealers in nonferrous scrap metals have been operating at a loss because of a price drop on most commodities and a steady decline in the flow of supplies, Max Bluestone of the Bluestone Metal Company, Pittsburgh, said yesterday.

WESTPORT, Conn., March 17 -- Ten "desirable" municipal projects were announced here today by the Board of Selectmen for the consideration of the Board of Finance. The total cost is $4,492,000. The projects could be completed by 1964, according to First Selectman Herbert E. Baldwin.

MOSCOW, March 17 (AP) -- The United States amateur ice hockey team suffered its second defeat inside Russia tonight. The Americans lost, 5 -- 3, to the Soviet A team, runner-up in the recent world championship.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Treasury bill rate fell off again this week after a temporary rise last week.

J. Lennox Porter of the Yale Club, the defending champion, and Rodney G. Fiske of the Harvard Club were among those advancing to the quarterfinals in the National Squash Tennis Association championship tournament yesterday at the Harvard Club.
LONDON, March 17 -- The Soviet Union maintained diplomatic pressure for summit talks by delivering yet another letter to Prime Minister Harold Macmillan today.
URBANA, Ill., March 17 -- A specialist in family life education said last week that knowledge -- or ignorance -- of the facts of life had but small influence on adolescent behavior.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney proposed today a bill that would label the price of an automobile. He said it was designed to "do away with the advantage now held by a few unscrupulous dealers."

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Col. George Gordon Moore talked today of sugar, ships and factor fees. Colonel Moore, the brother-in-law of Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, swore that none of these had anything to do with the Federal Communications Commission's award of a Miami television channel to a National Airlines subsidiary.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 17 -- A pilots' strike is expected to ground within the next day or two most of the eighty aircraft operated by the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines.

"THE GUIDE," by R. K. Narayan, is a novel about a man who loved a dancer. He thought he loved her, anyway, in his fashion. What he really loved, though, was himself -- and what he suffered for the girl implemented this primary devotion. Unexpectedly, the affluence and the trouble brought about by his double ordeal made him first a celebrity and then, to his consternation, a public martyr.

Governor Harriman yesterday signed a certificate incorporating the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, L. I. The diocese, which embraces almost 500,000 communicants in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, was created by the New York Archdiocese last April.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers were outhit, nine to four, by Spokane today, but managed to gain a 3-2, ten-inning victory over their Pacific Coast League farmhands.
MOSCOW, March 17 -- A three-man United States delegation that observed the Soviet election visited Nikita S. Khrushchev for an hour and a half today.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 17 -- Most of the players drive new cars and never talk about money, but the rookie pitcher is almost broke and he's pressing, hoping to make the majors before his wife has their third child in August.

Isaac Logart and Virgil Akins, who are to meet in a twelve-round bout at Madison Square Garden Friday night, agreed on one point yesterday, when they met at a luncheon at Leone's Restaurant. The boxers voiced the same opinion that the fight should be billed as being for the welterweight championship of the world, rather than as the semi-final in the elimination series to determine the division ruler.
PARIS, March 17 -- The domestic and international outlook for France today is complicated, paradox-filled equation with one dominant unknown: x equals Gen. Charles de Gaulle.
James Felt took over the city's scandal-ridden Bureau of Real Estate yesterday, fortified by Mayor Wagner's promise of a free hand "to clean up the situation."
LONDON, March 17 (AP) -- A few wives of United States servicemen living in Britain are drawing British Government family allowances, Parliament heard today.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Probable United States and Soviet bargaining positions for a summit conference are beginning to take shape, according to diplomatic officials.
Unification in action describes the Armed Forces Staff College at Norfolk, Va.
Two new films open at first-run theatres today.

Gilbert M. Haas who described himself as an investment counselor and an independent shareholder in the Mesabi Iron Company, announced yesterday that he was soliciting proxies for the company's annual meeting on April 18 at Wilmington, Del.

SALVADOR DALI, the surrealist with the aerodynamically intriguing mustache, was the guest last night on a bizarre quiz program entitled "Put It in Writing," which ran for thirty minutes over Channel 5. The show was something of a cathode abstraction.
TUNIS, March 18 -- The mood of this capital today, after two months of tension and expectation, is one of disappointment and discouragement.
The Vanguard satellite's final rocket stage remains unseen, the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory reported yesterday.
The promotions of two high-ranking officials was announced here yesterday by the United States Lines.
Cotton futures advanced 13 to 15 points yesterday. The close was not far from the best levels of the day on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Striking pilots of the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines continued yesterday their virtual paralysis of the company's operations and forced the cancellation of three of its four scheduled trans-Atlantic flights.
Four men were indicted yesterday in the recent wave of wood alcohol poisonings that resulted in the deaths of twenty-seven persons.

On the best-seller list of books is one called "Where Did You Go? Out. What Did You Do? Nothing." If you asked these questions of any Junior Red Cross volunteer you would get very dif ferent answers because many of them spent their vacations and after-school hours going places and doing many things.
DENVER, March 18 -- Former President Harry S. Truman accused the Administration tonight of leading the United States into great international peril and an unjustifiable recession.
The Queens District Attorney began investigation yesterday of vandalism directed at a Queens bakery having labor trouble.
One of the teen-age members of the Egyptian Dragons gang on trial for the killing of Michael Farmer, a 15-year-old polio victim, repudiated his confession yesterday.

Boys High, the defending titleholder, and Clinton moved into the final of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship play-off yesterday. The defenders scored by 55 to 49 over Tilden at Madison Square Garden after Clinton had gained a 59-57 decision in overtime against Morris.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- "It's like I say, banks today are too cold, stiff and formal. Walk in one, walk in another, they all look alike. Now our bank makes you feel right at home. Everything * * *."
SEOUL, Korea, March 18 (AP) -- A United States pilot shot down by North Korean gunfire said today that the Communists had questioned him for seven days but had not treated him roughly.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today crop plantings for harvest this year seemed likely to drop slightly below last year's low level.

An offering of $25,000,000 of Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation first mortgage pipeline 4 7/8 per cent bonds is being made today by an investment banking group headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc. The bonds come due in 1978 and are priced at 99.50 to yield about 4.915 per cent to maturity.

WHEN Art Students League revelers get into high gear at their annual frolic in the Roosevelt Hotel's grand ballroom sometime between 10 o'clock next Friday night and 4 o'clock Saturday morning, chances are the calmest figure in the hubbub will be Susie Leonard.

LONDON, March 18 -- An agreed Western position on disarmament, military disengagement and other issues for a heads-of-government conference cannot be formulated until May, qualified sources said today.
Stocks went through an uneasy session yesterday but climbed near the close and ended with only a modest decline.
Mayor Wagner forsook the rough and tumble of his City Hall office for several hours yesterday to enter his annual budget retreat in the Municipal Building office of Budget Director Abraham D. Beame.

LONDON, March 18 (AP) -- Pro-American newspapers in Europe today labeled the orbiting Vanguard I superior to other satellites because it goes higher and faster. Some newspapers, however, stressed its small size.

SYRACUSE, March 18 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Warriors scored their first play-off victory on a Syracuse floor tonight, beating the Nationals, 101 -- 88, to capture the third and decisive game in the opening round of the Eastern Division play-offs in the National Basketball Association.
One of the two voices of Vanguard I, the test satellite launched from Florida Monday, may still be singing in the sky ten years from now.

The Douglas Aircraft Company is planning to borrow up to $60,000,000 on an issue of sinking fund debentures, Donald W. Douglas, Sr., chairman, said yesterday. The bonds will not be convertible into common stock, he said.

ALBANY, March 18 -- A bill passed by the Assembly today would let employers discharge summarily any employe who refused to answer questions in a loyalty hearing on the ground of possible self-incrimination.
LONDON, March 18 -- Eamon de Valera, Prime Minister of the Republic of Ireland, said today that he would like to see the United States use its good office to bring an end to the partition of Ireland.
Bent Larsen of Denmark continued his winning streak to hold the lead with a score of 6 -- 0 in the annual international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata yesterday.
For the eleventh straight month sales of major chain store and mail order companies were Higher in February than a year earlier, but the rate of increase was down sharply.

ARCHITECTS and decorators have been engaged for years in a "to be or not to be" war over door, window and wall moldings. Today, without an armistice in sight, the decorators have the highly ornamental edge.
George F. Trommer, former president and director of John F. Tromm, Inc., left $929,004 to 215 individuals, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed here yesterday with the state.
CHICAGO, March 18 -- Robert McKinney, United States representative to the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna, called today for more atom-powered electrical plants.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The new director and depant director for Legislative Bureau took their oaths of office in unison today.

The Great Western Financial Corporation, the nation's only savings and loan holding company, reported yesterday 1957 net earnings of $6,019,938, or $9.47 each, on the 635,000 shares outstanding Dec. 31. This compared with $4,436,565, or $7.39 each, on the 600,000 shares outstanding Dec. 31, 1956.
WASHINGTON, March, 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eizenhower's address today to a luncheon meeting of the Republican Women's National Conference:
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 18 -- Playing "chicken" with his big ten-wheel dump truck cost a Kingston driver the loss of his license for five years last night in near-by Franklin Township.
CHICAGO, March 18 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Are subway riders' eyes closed to the appalling filth to which they are exposed every day?
Columbia College announced yesterday that it had begun a five-year expansion of its Oriental Studies Program that will also increase oriental studies in other schools.
Voters went to the polls yesterday in the annual spring elections of eighty-one villages in the four metropolitan counties of New York State.

"Grant equity to New York City's municipal colleges," The New York Times editorially urges on the Legislature. And on March 14 The Times reported Dr. Harry Gideonse as telling the Women's City Club that our municipal colleges must have state aid to meet operating costs.

WHAT time has wrought in old master paintings -- the golden illumination of dust and varnish -- is intentionally reproduced by a 22-year-old painter, Frank Roth, having his first one-man show at the Artists' Gallery, 851 Lexington Avenue.

James Rossetti, former president of the Greater New York Cartmen's Association, has voluntarily surrendered his license to operate a private cartmen's business, License Commissioner Bernard J. O'Connell disclosed yesterday.

NEWARK, March 18 -- Newark's long-awaited middle-income housing project in the North Ward moved ahead today. The sponsor, the Metropolitan Corporation of America, filed plans with the Federal Housing Administration.

OTTAWA, March 18 -- Lester B. Pearson, recent Nobel Peace Prize winner and leader of the Liberal party in the Federal election campaign, said tonight that Canada should support an immediate ending of nuclear weapons tests.

The National Dairy Products Corporation last year achieved the highest sales and earnings in its history and expects to exceed these results in 1958, according to E. E. Stewart, president and board chairman.
HAVANA, March 18 -- Cuba looked with anxiety today for signs of an outbreak of the "total war" that Fidel Castro, rebel leader, has declared on the Government.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Eisenhower pledged his Administration today to take any action, including tax reductions, that would lead to a healthy economic recovery in the nation.

There is a strong possibility that "Studio One in Hollywood" will be terminated at the end of the summer. The "Studio One" television drama series has been sponsored by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for nearly nine years.
FORT MYERS, Fla., March 18 -- When Ted Kluszewski stepped into the batting cage a fortnight ago for his first swing as a member of the Pittsburgh Pirates all other activity ceased.

PARIS, March 18 -- Western preparations for a summit conference may at the moment be considered a grim joke. This week NATO's Council meets to hear reports from the Big Three ambassadors on their ideas for a possible meeting with Khrushchev. The Council is likely to be less enlightened than cynically entertained.
CHICAGO, March 18 (AP) -- Soybeans came under fairly solid selling pressure shortly before the close of the Board of Trade today. Prices were clipped more than a cent a bushel in all contracts.

In its annual report, issued for publication today, the United States Steel Corporation said that personal and corporate income taxes had reached levels at which individual incentive and job-producing industrial growth were being seriously endangered.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Two Democratic Senators today questioned the usefulness of the Senate rackets committee as now constituted and operating.
A FRENCH designer who set out to achieve success by running like a tortoise finds himself getting ahead with the speed of a hare.

THE great epic poems born of the heroic ages of Western peoples never die. We cannot read them today with anything like the simple wonder and unquestioning belief of the men and women who first heard them recited or chanted in a king's palace in ancient Greece or in the great, smoky hall of a Viking chief.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 18 -- So drastic have been the changes in baseball's rules of etiquette that it is no longer considered chic for the gladiators to flail, insult, or spike one another -- not even when the umpire's back is turned.
The Department of Christian Social Relations of the Protestant Council of New York City last night reaffirmed its endorsement of Sabbath legislation.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 18 (UP) -- Gil Hodges singled home the winning run in the tenth inning as the Los Angeles Dodgers gained a 5-4 victory over the Kansas City Athletics in a 3-hour 13-minute exhibition baseball game today.

TAMPA, Fla., March 18 -- Cookie Lavagetto, holding down or stuck with the managing job for the Washington Senators, is having a tough time keeping his chin from dragging on the ground. After speaking to him today, one got the impression that the team's lowly stand in the American League would continue this season unless Lady Luck offered a hand.
The Hew York State Society of Real Estate Appraisers will hold its eighteenth annual appraisal conference for the metropolitan area on Friday at the Astor Hotel.
MANILA, March 18 -- President Carlos P. Garcia said tonight that he would ask the United States Government to lend the Philippines $300,000,000 to $350,000,000.
CHICAGO, March 18 -- Theodore V. Houser, chairman of Sears, Roebuck Co., said today the company was engaged in a program to cut prices on many items and to increase installment sales.

ESTABLISHMENT of four new national wildlife refuges, approved by the Migratory Bird Conservation Commission last Tuesday, drew attention again to the debate in Washington over what is to be done with the hunter's duck-stamp money.

The Naval Ordnance Laboratory has awarded a contract for field-test quantities of new weight-saving, cost-reducing plastic shell case for artillery ammunition to Tube Turns Plastics, Inc., Louisville, Ky.

Judge Harold R. Medina of the United States Court of Appeals was named yesterday to receive the 1958 Public Affairs Award of the New York Newspaper Guild. A special award in public affairs went to Marian Anderson, the contralto.

The Texas Company reported yesterday a record consolidated net income for 1957 of $332,303,644, or $5.94 each on the 56,355,506 shares outstanding, according to the company's pamphlet report. Gross revenues from operations were $2,344,176,856.

Woo the consumer and offer him really new products. These were the main ingredients of a prescription for dispelling the recession, presented yesterday by Dr. Ernest Dichter, president of the Institute for Motivational Research.

The first national rally under the new rules of the Sports Car Club of America was an unqualified success. The instructions prepared by the rally committee of the Florida Region for the Great Florida event were concise and exact, without tricks.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18 -- The Yankees today engaged in one of their favorite diversions, that of slapping an American League rival around to forestall any wrong ideas of how things are going to be later.

Two major upsets not only were possible in last night's quarter-finals of the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden but also appeared probable. For after Xavier of Cincinnati had surprised 12,160 court fans by eliminating last year's winner, Bradley of Peoria, 72 -- 62, in the opener, Fordham's Rams sped to an early 9-point lead over top-seeded Dayton in the second game.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., March 18 -- Processing of customer orders, which formerly took a week to ten days, now is on a twenty-four-hour basis at the headquarters of the Carborundum Company here.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- Within twenty years the health of three-fourths of the American people will depend upon how well the country deals with "urban sprawl," the undisciplined growth of cities, a Federal health official said here today.

The April 8 performance of "Look Homeward, Angel" at the Barrymore Theatre will benefit the Bryn Mawr College Alumnae Regional Scholarship Fund. Proceeds will aid the committee in maintaining sixteen students from New York State and southern Connecticut, who could not otherwise attend the school.

DETROIT, March 18 (UP) -- Gordie Howe and Norm Ullman each had a goal and two assists tonight as the Detroit Red Wings moved within 4 points of the second-place New York Rangers with a 4-2 National Hockey League victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.
Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn sent another missive yesterday in his battle with the Port of New York Authority over the $85,000,000 waterfront development program in the borough.
A novel way of giving all candidates in union elections full access to the rank and file will be tested this month in a New York local of the scandal-scarred International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
Gross mismanagement and "unjustified extravagance" of corporate funds wiped out $250,000 invested by 1,400 persons in the Seaboard Drug Company, Inc., a court-appointed trustee charged yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, March 18 -- Mexico celebrated today the twentieth anniversary of her expropriation of foreign petroleum interests.

Cocoa futures fell the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The near-by March position dropped 99 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) and all the other months tumbled the limit. The volume was 433 lots. There were eight unsatisfied offerings at the close at the permissible decline for a day.

ALTHOUGH Shakespeare lovers know that their viol wrote "Two Gentlemen of Verona," it may be observed without too much argument that comparatively few of them have ever seen it performed on the stage professionally.
London, March 18 -- The United States Air Force and the Royal Air Force will continue to use hydrogen bombs in operational and training exercises based on Britain, the Prime Minister said today.
BONN, Germany, Wednesday, March 19 (Reuters) -- Public service and transport workers in most of West Germany started a twenty-four-hour warning strike today to protest delays in wage negotiations.
Vassily Smyslov, the world chess champion, yesterday won for the first time in his title series with Mikhail Botvinnik in Moscow. In forty-one moves, he defeated the man he had dethroned last year.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Republican leaders proposed today the replacement of the present state Division of Investigation with a temporary bipartisan crime commission of four members.

A man described by Judge Samuel Joseph as the master-mind behind an illegal rebranding operation on raido and television tubes was sentenced in Bronx County Court yesterday to a two-and-one-half-year prison term.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Representative Brent Spence introduced a bill today for a $2,000,000,000 program of loans to state and local governments for public works.

SINGAPORE, March 18 -- Indonesian rebels announced tonight that they had retaken the oil center of Pakanbaru and that an advance guard of Achinese Moslem warriors had reopened the fight for Medan, in Northern Sumatra.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 18 -- Guerrilla warfare along the frontier between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland is well into the second year of its latest phase. But it appears to have little effect on the campaigns for election of a new House of Commons in Ulster.
The Atomic Energy Commission was accused yesterday of not following scientific standards of objectivity and candor in its statements on radio active fall-out from nuclear tests.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The House of Representatives refused today to agree with the Senate's decision to charge 5 cents postage for out-of-town letters. The House voted last August to raise the general rate on first-class mail from 3 to 4 cents an ounce.

ATLANTIC CITY, Wednesday, March 19 -- Top-ranking contract bridge players led a field of 214 pairs in the mixed-pairs championship of the 1958 spring national championships. The second qualifying session ended early this morning at the Traymore Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Administration showed coolness today toward the "Monroney Plan" for creating a second World Bank to make long-term, low-interest loans to under-developed nations.
CHICAGO, March 18 -- The dissident family groups in the Pabst Brewing Company proxy fight nominated their candidate for president today.

Back in 1895, a smug Uncle Sam in sailor suit -- chair tilted back, thumbs in galluses, pipe in mouth -- said to stout John Bull, peering through a monocle at the America's Cup, "Wa-al, old feller, you've got another chance to look at it, anyhow, even if you can't win it."

MIAMI, March 18 (AP) -- Jake Hershey's Ca Va, a newcomer to Southern Ocean Racing Conference circles, won the St. Petersburg-to-Miami yacht race today after a stirring duel with Jack Price's Comanche.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The almost immediate call by Soviet Ambassador Mikhail Menshikov on John Foster Dulles as the Secretary of State returned to the Capitol today caused considerable speculation.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Legislation to give New York City $375,000 for a special disciplinary school program was approved unanimously in the Assembly today without debate. It now goes to the Senate.

Zaven Khatchadourian, an Armenian pianist born in Turkey, made his American debut last night in Town Hall. His difficult program consisted of Franck's Prelude, Chorale and Fugue, Schumann's Sonata in F sharp minor, three selections by Aram Khatchaturian and three pieces from Albeniz' "Iberia."
COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 18 -- A Bull Goose, a little-known intercontinental missile bent on deception rather than destruction, was fired today from the Cape Canaveral launch site.

RICHARD STRAUSS began studying the violin at the age of 7, and when he was 18 he wrote a violin concerto that he dedicated to his teacher, Benno Walter. That concerto was played last night at Carnegie Hall by Carroll Glenn at the third concert of the season of the National Orchestral Association.

A package of old or new items to be sold at the Corner Shop and a $2 ticket will qualify patronesses and their friends as "tourists," and will entitle them to join a benefit tour of the Decorative Arts Center at 305 East Sixty-third Street tomorrow.
Cutler-Hammer, Inc., Milwaukee, plans to acquire the assets and business of Airborne Instruments Laboratory, Inc., of Mineola, L. I.
ST. LOUIS, March 18 -- Miss Lilace Reid Barnes of Lake Forest, Ill., was re-elected president of the Young Women's Christian Association of the United States today. She has held the post since 1955.

Cornelius Shields Sr. of Larchmont, the chairman since the class began in 1937, was reelected at the spring meeting of the International One-Design Class at the New York Yacht Club last night. William Edgar John Jr. of Mamaroneck remained secretary.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 18 -- The Nashville Community Relations Conference today urged law enforcement agencies to make every effort to arrest the dynamiters of the Jewish Community Center.
ALBANY, March 18 -- The Senate gave unanimous approval today to an Administration proposal to permit the sale or lease of public housing to limited-profit corporations.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 -- Take it from Mrs. Herbert Frank York, there is nobody else of her acquaintance who gets so much zest from daily living as her husband, the new chief scientist of the nation's new space agency.
New York City's $200,000,000 port redevelopment program is well under way, with appropriations already covering one-fourth of the total outlay envisioned.

JERSEY CITY, March 18 -- A suit charging fraud and diversion of a $100,000 campaign fund in the 1956 Presidential election race was filed today in Superior Court. The action was taken by the City Hall Victory Democrats against the regular county Democratic Organization.

Your memorial editorial of March 8 on Walter W. Stewart, in referring to his having resigned from the Amherst faculty in protest against the removal of Dr. Alexander Meiklejohn as president, states that this removal was due to the latter's liberal views on teaching.
Net income of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., and subsidiaries, declined about 10 per cent last year to $86,141,000, the metals concern reported yesterday.

Although Yale captured eight of the sixteen titles in last week-end's Eastern Intercollegiate League swimming championships, Coach Bob Kiphuth left Annapolis feeling none too sanguine about his Bulldogs' chances in the National Collegiates at Ann Arbor on the week-end after next.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 18 -- Five prominent Venezuelans accused of plotting to overthrow the Government were expelled from the country today.
PARIS, March 18 -- Important elements of a compromise formula for settling the French-Tunisian dispute were under attack today by the French Right Wing.
The British will try to put jets in service across the Atlantic this year before the Americans do, it was reliably reported here yesterday.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Enough Senate votes to pass the revised Tweed court reform plan appeared in sight tonight. But there remained grave doubt of Assembly passage.
Against a background of widening investigations into the city's Bureau of Real Estate, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that he would not tolerate official wrongdoing.

The effects of the recession to date have skipped the Mississippi-Arkansas-Louisiana region, at least as far as utilities are concerned, according to Edgar H. Dixon, president of Middle South Utilities, Inc., which serves that area.

"HOW to Gain a Chemise and Keep a Husband" was the text of yesterday's fashion "symposium" at Bergdorf Goodman. To make sure the message was understood, it was delivered in two languages by as many designers.
Opening dates and theatres already have been thought of for a couple of Robert Whitehead's future entries.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 18 -- Three prisoners escaped here from the Fairfield County Jail shortly after 9:30 A. M. today after attacking a guard, taking his keys and locking him in an icebox. They were still at large tonight.

Eighty-two housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration borrowed $136,262,000 yesterday to finance low-rent housing on short-term notes due from June 13, 1958, to April 10, 1959.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Otto Harbach, song writer, today defended the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers as a group that helps young composers.
Three villages on Long Island -- Mineola, Manorhaven and Northport -- and fifty-eight upstate voted yesterday to permit the playing of bingo within village limits.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A Johns Hopkins University physicist urges air zoning to combat air pollution.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 18 (UP) -- Oscar (Ossie) Solem of Springfield College, whose coaching career is one of the longest in American football, today said he was quitting the game.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 -- The Federal Government once more is on the trail of Harry Bridges.
BOCA RATON, Fla., March 18 -- Government officials were warned today that any hopes that the home building would lead the country out of the recession might be overly optimistic.

A painting valued at more than $1,000,000 arrived here from the Art Institute of Chicago last night, amid elaborate precautions against theft and damage, for a six-week exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that some private real estate concerns had made "excessive" charges and possibly had "illegally converted" city funds in managing property for the city.
JERSEY CITY, March 18 -- A $60,500,950 municipal budget, $1,000,000 below last year's record appropriation, was passed today by the Jersey City Commission.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A House investigator charged today that perjury "may have been committed" in testimony about pressures on the Federal Communications Commission.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 18 -- The Zionist movement has failed to establish an effective relationship between Israel and the world's Jews, Dr. Nahum Goldmann declared tonight.

TETERBORO, N. J., March 18 -- Details of a control system that aids man to fly the 1,200-mile-an-hour B-58 bomber were disclosed today by the Eclipse-Pioneer division of the Bendix Aviation Corporation.

Refusal by the Atlantic pact nations to accept United States missile installations would mean the end of Europe's influence on world affairs, Dr. Henry A. Kissinger contends in an article appearing today in Foreign Affairs.

"The Big Change in Europe," a new book by Blair Bolles, will be published Monday by Norton. Mr. Bolles looks at the way people live in western Europe and in the Soviet satellite countries, presenting the individual countries and their notables.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -Secretary of State Dulles said today that Soviet proposals for control of outer space were "not in a very-acceptable form."
NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 18 -- The Cypriote terrorist organization's truce this week entered its second year, but a solution of the Cyprus problem appeared no nearer today than it did a year ago.
New York Catholic Charities will seek to raise $3,000,000 in 1958. Msgr. George H. Guilfoyle, executive director of the organization, said yesterday that this was the highest goal it had ever set.

After a trip to the Antarctic, Sitka, one of five part-wolf huskies that participated in Operation Deepfreeze, may come home to his former owner in Manhattan -- unless his Navy training has made him too expensive.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Navy's next step into space will be a scientific satellite to measure the bombardment of earth by X-rays from the sun.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that there was growing concern in grain markets over a possible shortage of "free" wheat before the 1958 harvest.
A 15-year-old boy in one of the city's two special schools for delinquent pupils was arrested yesterday after "pushing" or "punching" a teacher.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Two new omnibus banking bills were submitted to the legislature today in the hope of favorable consideration in the closing days of the present session. But there was no assurance from legislative leaders that this would happen.
ALBANY, March 18 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:
The French Army, until World War II often called "the best in the world," has become a key factor in the continuing internal crisis of the Fourth Republic.

LONDON, March 18 -- The decline in industrial shares became more widespread on the Stock Exchange here today. Prices were sensitive to a small increase in selling and once again there was little buying to offset it.
Twelve members of the Police Department were directed yesterday to appear before the special Kings County Grand Jury investigating an alleged police hook-up with a borough bookmaking syndicate.

PARIS, March 18 -- Premier Felix Gaillard received another suspended sentence today from the National Assembly. By a vote of 282 to 196, the Assembly accorded him its confidence on the immediate issue of constitutional reform.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today another reduction of one-half percentage point in the required reserves of its member banks. The reduction was the same for all sizes of banks.
Oscar Robertson, Cincinnati's outstanding 19-year-old basketball forward, today was named player of the year in the annual United Press poll.
IF everything goes according to present plans, tourists of the world soon will he nourished, and perhaps amused, by what might appear as the less formal aspects of American cuisine.
A minor hoodlum sought by the Brooklyn police in connection with a gangland shooting was found dead yesterday. He had been shot three times in the head and once in the chest.

As I listen to and in a minor way participate in the controversy over the present or future danger to mankind from the radioactive fall-out associated with bomb testing, I am becoming more and more sympathetic with the nonscientists in our society who must be getting more and more confused by the day. I am therefore encouraged to try to clarify the situation.

Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack declared yesterday that the "mistakes of some earlier projects" would be avoided in relocating tenants from the site of the $205,000,000 Lincoln Square redevelopment.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 18 (UP) -- Johnny Ruane gained his third victory of the day when he booted Sir Putnam to an impressive one and one-half length victory today in the $4,000 Brown Wisdom Purse for older horses at Gulfstream Park.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a bill that would restrict the power of Federal courts to issue writs of habeas corpus for prisoners in state custody.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev and other Soviet officials have conceded to three American election observers that Sunday's national vote and the single-slate nominations that preceded it were controlled at all times by the Communist party.

Another milestone on the road toward a United States of Europe will be set today when a new European Parliament assembles in Strasbourg to preside over the economic integration of six European nations as a step toward their political integration. This Parliament is the common Assembly of the European Economic, Atomic and Coal and Steel Communities, called by the French the "Assemblee Unique."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 18 -- The United Artists Corporation today announced an out-of-court settlement with James Nasser, independent producer and northern California theatre owner. The matter involved the latter's "unauthorized" television exhibition of four moves originally distributed to theatres by U. A.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Sometimes a small incident tells more about the problems of United States foreign policy than a month's debate in the Senate. President Eisenhower's luncheon yesterday with the Advisory Committee of the Foreign Service Institute is a case in point.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Governor Harriman suggested informally today that the state freeze temporarily the amount of local taxes paid by all the railroads in the state. Their current local tax bill is about $45,000,000.
