The Pennsylvania Railroad experienced a loss of more than $8,000,000 last month, James M. Symes, president, announced in the company's 1957 annual report. In January the road had a $2,527,000 net loss. In February of last year it reported earnings of $853,956.
Twenty-four persons died amid chaos and panic yesterday in a five-alarm fire in a loft building at 623 Broadway, just north of Houston Street. Fifteen other persons were injured.

Harry Canelstein, New York and Florida realty investor and builder, has sold the two-acre shopping center at Newbridge Road and Bellmore Avenue in North Bellmore, L. I. The buyer was a syndicate of New York investors represented by Louis Rogin, attorney.

GENEVA, March 19 (AP) -The new United Arab Republic declared today its opposition to the traditional three-mile territorial sea limit and to the right of innocent passage for foreign warships in coastal waters.

Marshall Field Co., which conducts the largest retail department store business in the Chicago area, increased its net sales to $219,011,532 in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 from the $211,004,140 in the previous fiscal year.

The Transport Workers Union started injunctive proceedings yesterday in Federal Court, Washington, to halt alleged "raiding" tactics of Local 333, United Marine Division of the National Maritime Union, which represents most of the harbor craft workers in the Port of New York.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 19 -- Dr. Guillermo Leon Valencia, who a year ago was the symbol of Colombia's fight for freedom, awaited today an unavoidable sentence to the political sidelines.
ALBANY, March 19 -- The Legislature approved today a Republican bill setting the primary election for Aug. 12 and the state political conventions Aug. 25 and 26.

SEBRING, Fla., March 19 (UP) -- Stirling Moss of England, driving an Aston-Martin, set a course record today as he warmed up for Saturday's eighth annual Florida international Grand Prix of Endurance.

On March 4 the distinguished dean of The New York Times Washington correspondents, Arthur Krock, returned to the question of the relationship between labor unions and antitrust laws. The object of his attack was a spokesman for Secretary of Labor Mitchell who said that he had been unable to find a lawyer who could explain exactly how the antitrust laws could be made to apply to labor unions.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, is circulating to the railroad industry for comment a proposed bill that would set up a multimillion-dollar Federal agency to guarantee loans for the purchase of railroad equipment.

Consideration by the State Legislature of the McGahan bill raises a basic question of increasing urgency: shall discrimination in employment based solely on age be prohibited by law? The McGahan measure makes this practice illegal as to those from 45 to 65 -- in help wanted advertising, hiring, pay, working conditions, promotion and discharge.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 19 (AP) -- Charles Horace (Pete) Stoneham, 30 years old, son of the president of the San Francisco Giants' baseball club, was sued for $250,000 today in the death of a Canadian woman and injury of her husband in an automobile accident.

LISBON, Portugal, March 19 -- The Portuguese Opposition announced today that it had chosen Admiral Manuel Carlos de Quintao Meireles, retired, as its candidate for president in the forthcoming elections.

BALTIMORE, March 19 (AP) -- Dr. Winston Price, who isolated one of the common cold viruses last fall and developed a vaccine to combat it, may have discovered a way to diagnose chronic diseases by analyzing particles in the blood stream.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -The House Merchant Marine Committee recommended today the construction and sale of two new superliners.

Directors of American Export Lines, Inc., yesterday elected Paul C. Smith, vice presidenttreasurer and Joseph T. Graziano, vice president-controller. C. Michael Paul was elected a director, filling a vacancy on the board.

The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company, manufacturers of paper, paperboard and paper products, is absorbing the Fulton Bag and Products Company of New Orleans, La., through a cash transaction. While the amount was not disclosed, trade sources estimated the net worth of Fulton at $4,500,000.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad went "into the red" last month for the first time in seven years.
Current events in Indonesia illustrate how a people can become the prey of communism in the guise of nationalism or anticolonialism, Governor Robert B. Meyner said last night.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The scientific leaders of the United States satellite program have recommended to the Administration a long-range programof space research looking toward exploration of the moon and planets and manned space flight.
PARIS, March 19 -- Eighteen prominent French university professors have expressed their conviction that independence for Algeria is the only way to end the forty-one-month-old armed rebellion there.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $718,313,000 convertible debentures issue -- the largest single new financing effort in business history -- drew a record 99.7 per cent of subscriptions by stockholders. The company said yesterday that this was the highest percentage ever recorded in its stockholder offerings.

HAVANA, March 19 -- President Fulgencio Batista of Cuba replaced the national police chief today as the Government tightened military control in preparation for the "total war" declared by Fidel Castro, rebel leader.
Murky skies and a slight drizzle failed to dampen the official Harbor welcome yesterday afternoon to the Israeli passenger liner Theodor Herzl.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, British West Indies, March 19 -- The Prime Minister of Barbados expressed regret today that members of the West Indies Federation were not sending their "best men" to the new Federation's first House of Representatives.
William J. McCurdy, acting executive officer of the Bureau of Real Estate, was dismissed yesterday as the city continued to investigate the bureau's handling of city-owned properties.

ALBANY, March 19 -- The first major step toward solving the transit crisis that has plagued the metropolitan New York area was taken today when the Assembly unanimously voted to create a New YorkNew Jersey Transit District.
Mayor Wagner renewed his offer yesterday to meet with a committee from the special Kings County grand jury investigating lawlessness in Brooklyn public schools.
MOSCOW, March 19 (UP) -Bob Hope kept an Englishspeaking audience here in an uproar of laughter tonight with his running comments on things Russian, including sputniks, vodka, cigarettes and fur caps.
LONDON, March 19 -- Sir David Eccles, President of the Board of Trade, cautioned tonight that capitalism was being challenged economically by "the controlled and regimented system of the Communists."
America had better stop neglecting its intellectuals and start cherishing them if it wants to survive, a group of business and financial leaders were warned yesterday.

In your issue of March 2 Benjamin Fine reported on recent proposals favoring a change in the graduate program of our universities. As far as I can see, these proposals essentially amount to a renaming of the master's degree to Ph.D. and to abolishing the Ph.D. degree as it is now.
Four low-rent housing projects were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission. They will provide 2,000 apartments at a cost of $33, 221,000.
For some time before yesterday's Broadway blaze, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. had been waging an intense fire-prevention campaign.

THE group of downtown galleries continues to offer a fair sampling of work by younger painters and sculptors. In general, what these cooperative galleries lack in consistent quality they make up for in variety and happy unpredictability.

BOSTON, March 19 (UP) -The final round of the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division play-offs opened tonight with the Boston Celtics scoring a 107-98 triumph over the Philadelphia Warriors.

Presidents of the twenty-three member colleges of the Empire State Foundation of Independent Liberal Arts Colleges, Inc., 11 West Forty-second Street, New York 36, are engaged in a spring campaign to raise funds for the foundation. Teams of the college presidents are calling upon business executives in New York City, in Westchester, on Long Island and in other parts of the state.
WARSAW, March 19 -- Poland accused the United States and West Germany tonight of attempting to face the world with the "fait accompli" of equipping West German military forces with nuclear weapons.

The Export-Import Bank of Washington, overseas lending arm of the Treasury, announced yesterday a $10,000,000 credit to Marcona Mining Company, Peruvian iron ore subsidiary of the Utah Construction Corporation of San Francisco.

NEWARK, N. J., March 19 (AP) -- The state Public Utility Commission today granted the Erie Railroad and the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad permission to raise their restricted intrastate commutation rates by $2.70 a month, and their unrestricted rates by $3.
LONDON, March 19 -- The Soviet Government has accused Britain and the United States of delaying heads-of-government talks while making "war preparations."
West Virginia borrowed $8,740,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the payment of money bonuses to veterans of the Korean War.

The Federal Reserve Board has just released the credit brakes by another notch in its efforts to assure business that it need not be deterred in expanding its activities for fear of a lack of funds at reasonable rates of interest. For the second time within a month the system has supplemented its credit easing open market operations by reducing the proportion of reserves its member banks must hold in terms of their demand deposits.

New York University researchers announced here yesterday that guinea pigs had been altered so that they developed a heart condition similar to congestive heart failure -- the most common cause of human death.
An observant taxicab passenger has lighted the way for the Traffic Department to put its signal system in sequence.

An accountant in the District Attorney's office testified yesterday that he knew last summer of the existence of two "hidden bank accounts" reportedly kept for officials of the Department of Buildings.
A public offering of 200,000 shares of common stock of Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., priced at $25.50 a share, will be made today by an investment banking group headed by Blyth Co., Inc.

TRENTON, March 19 -Charles R. Howell, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, approved today an over-all increase of 18.5 per cent in Blue Cross hospitalization insurance rates. The new premiums become effective July 1.
TOKYO, March 19 -- Japanese Governmental and financial circles were badly shaken by reports from Taipei that Nationalist China had decided to break all trade relations with Japan.

Mrs. Leonard B. Smith, honorary chairman of the committee of French-American Wives, sponsors of the thirteenth annual Bal des Berceaux to be held on the night of March 28 at the Sheraton-East (formerly the Ambassador) has announced the patroness committee, of which she is chairman.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- Detailed plans for Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's trip to Moscow were announced here today.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee was told today that continued military assistance to the allies was "absolutely vital" to the security of the United States.

The giant of the Sports pages, baseball, garnering several columns even in the off season, and swallowing great portions of space until it consumes all room available given it by a newspaper, is with us again.

LONDON, March 19 -- The stock market staged a modest recovery today under the lead of the oil section and British Government securities. However, the improvement was net accompanied by any increase in turnover.
An insurgent group that now controls the affairs of the deck officers' union here met yesterday with none of the fireworks it threatened a week ago.
DR. RICHARD WILLIAM PORTER, key man in the United States earth satellite project, is a guided missiles authority who moves easily into more terrestrial pursuits.
The question of whether atomic tests constitute a major threat to civilization because of radiation and fall-out will be examined by Edward R. Murrow's "See It Now" on March 30.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -The Administration will ask Congress soon to authorize the use of Treasury general funds to finance state-operated unemployment compensation plans during an extended period of jobless relief.
Directors of the Corn Products Refining Company increased the quarterly dividend yesterday for the second successive quarter with the declaration of 45 cents a share. It is payable April 25.

TAMPA, Fla., March 19 -There was no major league exhibition baseball game here today because of rain and the way the Florida weather has been acting up this season there is no guarantee of a game tomorrow.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Tim Tam rallied from next to last to win easily in the $16,850 Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park today. The victory established Tim Tam as a prohibitive favorite in the forthcoming Florida Derby.
JERICHO, Jordan, March 10 -- On the last stretch of the road from Jerusalem to Jericho a large settlement comes into view. Above it looms the green headland named Mount Temptation.
A former dive bomber pilot told yesterday how he now uses his flying skill as an evangelist who has to cover seven western states.

ALBANY, Calif., March 19 (AP) -- The Board of Stewards of Golden Gate Fields today suspended three trainers and two grooms in the reported doping of two horses a week ago. The cases were referred to the California Horse Racing Board.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 19 (AP) -- The Ministers of Interior, Finance and Economic Affairs were replaced today in the first major shuffle of Premier O. K. Yui's Cabinet since it was formed in 1954.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Merry Andrew," a MetroGoldwyn-Mayer comedy in CinemaScope and color, co-starring Danny Kaye and Pier Angeli, is at the Radio City Music Hall. Sol C. Siegel produced and Michael Kidd directed from a scenario by I. A. L. Diamond and Isobel Lennart.

SOAP opera almost took on the aspect of an art form last night when Douglas Moore's new one-act "Gallantry" received its world premiere at Brander Matthews Theatre. Mr. Moore, who set his opera to a libretto by Arnold Sundgaard, has composed a paean to Lochinvar Soap and Billy Boy Wax, and has nearly brought it off.
A tea will be given by the Human Relations Workshops of the New School for Social Research at 3 P. M. on March 31 at the school, 66 West Twelfth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins is offering a prize to anyone who can figure out the meaning of a 212-word sentence in the Government's latest income-tax instructions. He said a puzzled constituent had written him, asking what the sentence meant.

CRESSKILL, N. J., March 19 -- The Teachers Association here issued a statement today chiding voters who twice last month rejected the 1958-1959 school budget. The association said the voters had been "either uniformed, misinformed, and/ or people who simply do not believe in the principles of public-school education."
Tuesday's reduction in Federal Reserve Board reserve requirements for member banks and anticipation of the release after the close of short interest statistics dominated the stock market yesterday.
The new city-owned Cadillac assigned to the exclusive use of Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa was delivered to him yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported officially today what many men have long suspected: The fellow with the higher income is more likely to get the girl.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- Several hundred billion dollars will probably be spent in the next forty to fifty years to develop the world's water resources, a panel of seven experts declared today.
Spectacular--and tragic--fires abound in New York history. The famous Triangle factory fire took 145 lives forty-seven years ago this month.

WARSAW, March 18 -- The Prosecutor's office was reported today to be preparing an appeal in the acquittal of two Polish newspaper men on charges that they had disclosed state secrets.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Eisenhower issued orders today aimed at speeding work on about $2,250,000,000 worth of private, cooperative and local government projects aided by the Federal Government.

What are believed to be the first photographs of Vanguard I or its last rocket stage and the first visual observation of the rocket were announced yesterday by the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory in Cambridge, Mass.

CHICAGO, March 19 (AP) -Slaughter steer prices hit a new high for almost six years here today when a top of $39 was paid for a load of scarce prime egrade steers scaling 1,250 pounds. It was only 25 cents under the previous high paid on April 16, 1952.
PHILADELPHIA, March 19 -- The great need of American cities is not more schools or housing, but brains, character, organization and leadership, Dr. Luther Gulick declared here today.

DENVER, March 19 (AP) -- A platform urging that all agricultural commodities produced in the United States be placed under marketing quotas was laid before the convention of the National Farmers Union today.

The nation's production of crude oil and condensate again declined in the week ended last Friday, falling 70,750 barrels to 6,256,985 a day, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This is the lowest level since the week ended on Nov. 12, 1954, when production averaged 6,220,150 barrels a day.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 19 (AP) -- Government troops were still in control of Pakanbaru and Medan today. Military spokesmen said that land, sea and air forces were preparing to strike at the main rebel positions in Central Sumatra.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -The House of Representatives, without debate, passed a $1,850,000,000 emergency housing bill today and sent it to the White House.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 -- Reports that the "N. B. C. Matinee Theatre" may be nearing the end of its network run are continuing to grow. Albert McCleery, producer of the Monday through Friday hour-long dramatic series, is now in New York.

MANAMA, Bahrein, March 19 -- A new activity by rebel sheikhs in the Sultanate of Muscat and Oman indicates they are getting fresh help from abroad, a reliable source said today.

The quarters will be used by Brooks Brothers of 375 Madison Avenue, Manhattan, clothiers, a subsidiary of Garfinkel Co., to consolidate all its manufacturing operations in the metropolitan area.
A moonwatch team in New Mexico reported yesterday that it had sighted, in less than an hour, all three artificial earth satellites now in orbit.
The price of refined copper was advanced 1/2 cent a pound yesterday, to 23 1/2 cents, by leading custom smelters. It was their first change since Feb. 26, when they trimmed the quotation 1/8 cent.
Having lived abroad for several years I had not really faced what it would mean to have the Metropolitan Opera House torn down until I attended a recent performance.

Your editorial of March 14 entitled "Let Them Eat Pork" is a fine example of a curious type of provincialism which seems to dominate the thinking of metropolitan newspapers when they consider waterdevelopment programs.
CHICAGO, March 20 (AP) -The longs and shorts in the market had a frantic few minutes in evening up operations shortly before the close of the Board of Trade today.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 20 -- More than 150,000 Long Island homes were without light, heat and power today as heavy snow and high winds raised havoc with power lines. In midafternoon, at the height of the storm, more than 2,000 telephone lines also were affected.

NEW DELHI, India, March 20 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and his daughter are giving warm support to a nationwide campaign to honor Paul Robeson, American singer to whom a passport has been denied by the State Department.
Forty families were evacuated last night from a five-story Bronx apartment building declared unsafe, possibly as a result of a three-alarm fire Wednesday night.

ZAKOPANE, Poland, March 20 (AP) -- Arlette Grosso of France led a European comeback against the three-girl American entry by winning the special slalom today in the Zakopane international Alpine skiing competition.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 -- Major league baseball, which has undergone some startling territorial changes in recent years, soon may witness another, possibly by 1959. And this one could be even more revolutionary, since it would involve a switching of interleague franchises.
LONDON, Friday, March 21 -- The prolonged absence of Selwyn Lloyd from the House of Commons revived speculation in the press today about the future of the Foreign Secretary.

Franklin Fireproof Warehouses, Inc., has purchased the ten-story building at 88-90 Gold Street for the storage of records. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured the title. The property was sold by the Nikler Investors Corporation. Walter B. Morgan and Ben Keiser were the brokers.
The Rev. Daniel Linehan, the scientist-priest who proved that there was land above sea level at the South Pole, received Fordham University's Insignis Medal yesterday.

Proceeds from the third annual May Fair of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church will help to equip a new three-floor addition to Grace Church School. The fair will be held on May 2 and 3 on the school grounds, part of the 110-year-old church property at Broadway and Tenth Street.

Two airliners skidded on the slushy runways of the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, last night and their nose wheels collapsed. However, none of the sixty-two persons aboard the planes was injured.
Winter, which came in gently last Dec. 21 with bright sunshine and 50-degree temperatures, roared out yesterday with heavy snow, sleet and rain, high winds and even thunder cracks.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Senate rackets committee announced today five new series of hearings. Its chairman, Senator John L. McClellan, also said he hoped to wind up the committee's work this year.
The city terminated the services of another private management agent for city properties yesterday in reorganizing its Bureau of Real Estate.

What happened on Broadway Wednesday afternoon is tragically clear. An explosion in a gas oven on the third floor of an ancient five-story loft building spread fire, in a matter of seconds, over a wide area of wooden benches and flimsy textiles in a room that extended clear back to Mercer Street.
MAGWA, Kuwait, March 15 -- One thing more noteworthy than the Arab liking for powerful cars is the speed with which an illiterate Bedouin can progress from goatherd to skilled machinist.

In an amazingly short space of time, reminiscent of the early days of the New Deal, both houses of Congress have now passed their first important measure to combat the recession. This is a housingfinance bill, designed to stimulate construction of 200,000 new units and thereby furnish employment to some 500,000 persons this year.
Two of the women who survived Wednesday's fire on lower Broadway yesterday praised the calm of a man who brought some order to the general hysteria before he died in the blaze.
A "bill of rights" to protect the civil liberties of union members was proposed yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union.

Cocoa futures continued to fluctuate sharply yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Most positions opened strong, then tumbled but recovered toward the close. The swing during the day was as much as 1 1/4 cents a pound.

FLAMINGO, Fla., March 20 -- It is not hard for an angler here to choose in the morning where he is to go; there are hundreds of good water pockets for all kinds of fish. His difficulty comes in the evening in figuring out where he has been.
Net income of the Anaconda Company plummeted 60.5 per cent last year as prices of copper, zinc and other metals declined, according to the annual report released yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 539,057 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The German and Japanese submarine warfare against American merchant shipping is the subject of a new book by Theodore Taylor entitled "Fire on the Beaches." Mr. Taylor concentrates on 1942 when the German wolf-packs and the fewer Japanese submarines "roamed the seas almost at will" until convoy escorts, American submarines and the Air Force put an end to the menace.
The Corn Products Refining Company achieved record worldwide sales and earnings last year, William T. Brady, president, informed stockholders in the fifty-first annual report.

The forty-seven-foot yacht that churned up a flood of Senate criticism against lush practices of the high command of the International Union of Operating Engineers is about to float out of the union's possession.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Congressmen hunting for multi-million-dollar abuses in the Federal regulatory agencies closed in today on a $2.40 telephone call.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- A group of scientists charged today that the Atomic Energy Commission could not be trusted to report accurately the facts needed to formulate a disarmament policy.
ELIZABETH, N. J., March 20 -- One thousand eight hundred houses in Union County were without electricity today as the snowstorm felled utility wires.

WITH hems on the rise, a woman should be well-heeled for spring. These are the sentiments of Arnold Constable, whose press showing of spring shoes yesterday proved that nothing compliments legs as much as heels.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Republican and Democratic legislative leaders were reported today to have agreed on the selection of Stanley Kreutzer of Great Neck, L. I., as special counsel to the joint legislative committee that will investigate payroll practices in the Legislature. The formal announcement is expected tomorrow.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Judges could sentence narcotics addicts to treatment facilities instead of jail under a bill approved unanimously by the Assembly today. It now goes to the Senate for concurrence.

Legal documents were signed in the Richmond County Surrogate's office yesterday for the first adoption to be arranged by the City Department of Welfare. A 3-year-old girl was the first to be placed permanently with a family since the department opened its adoption service in January, 1957.
A "virtual blacklist as mean and cruel as any inquisition" exists in American universities, Dr. Louis M. Hacker, dean of Columbia University's School of General Studies, charged last night.
PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- Social planners were asked today to look not at the well advertised cracks in the picture windows in the suburbs, but through some of their vistas.
LONDON, March 20 -- The cut in the bank rate had a tonic effect on industrial stocks on the stock exchange today.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -A State Department official approved "in principle" today a second world bank to make easy-term loans to underdeveloped nations.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan March 20 -- Abdullah Khalil, hard-fisted former Army officer with pro-Western leanings, was chosen today to continue as Premier of this young African republic.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday a record consolidated net income for last year of $354,284,000, or $11.38 each on the 31,130,789 shares outstanding at the year-end. Sales and operating revenues were $2,730,085,000.

LONDON, March 20 (AP) -Twelve American girls were presented to Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace today -and saw the end of a chapter of British history. The Queen has decreed that this will be the last of the debutante parties at the Palace.

LONDON, March 20 -- The Western powers' hopes for a summit meeting go no higher than a comparatively modest success that would lead to further progress, Prime Minister Harold Macmillan declared today.

NEW DELHI, India, March 14 -- A screen actress in Bombay, a free-lance photographer in Calcutta and a housewife in New Delhi all have discovered recently that a 600-page book they never have seen is having an effect on their lives.
Coppers and pharmaceuticals were strong in the stock market yesterday and rails were weaker. Judged by the averages, the result was virtually a stand-off, with a tiny advantage on the plus side.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan, disclosed today a Defense Department contract to buy $21,000,000 worth, of Japanese - manufactured military trucks this year. He called it a "shocking" agreement.

The Better Business Bureau of New York City cautioned the public yesterday against putting funds in out-of-state savings and loan associations that advertise higher-than-usual dividend rates and represent their accounts as "commercially insured to $10,000."

A RICH - HUED contralto voice of unusual beauty was the foremost asset of Dorothy Parker in the program of Italian arias, German lieder and Sibelius songs she sang last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.
Sixteen employes of the Civil Aeronautics Administration will be honored today for "courageous action involving jeopardy of life."

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 20 -- The four-day-old strike of pilots against KLM, the Royal Dutch Airline, was brought to an end late today by the nation's voluntary labor-management mediation board.

The outcome of the marketing of Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company bonds at a 3.77 per cent yield will show whether a limitation of the borrower's right to pay off the debt early is still as much of a market force today as it was in the period of rising interest rates of last year.

WHITE PLAINS, March 20 --Westchester County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian suggested today the elimination of "uneconomical" government regulations and the granting of tax abatements as possible solutions to railroad problems.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Governor Harriman vetoed today a Republican program bill to liberalize the mortgage lending powers of savings banks.

THE cost of beef and pork cuts is high again this week-end. For example, ready-to-eat smoked ham is up 4 cents a pound to 73 cents; porter-house steak, at $1.29 a pound, is 31 cents more a pound than it was last year, and both sirlion and round steak are $1.10 a pound.
LONDON, March 20 -- The bank rate, which was raised six months ago to the unusually high level of 7 per cent, was cut today to 6 per cent.
CINCINNATI, March 20 -- The Bishops of the six Ohio Roman Catholic dioceses issued a statement tonight in opposition to the proposed "right-to-work" Ohio Constitutional amendment.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz yesterday told the special grand jury investigating school lawlessness to exercise its own judgment on whether to direct Mayor Wagner to appear before the panel.

TRENTON, March 20 -- A state of emergency was declared throughout Mercer County tonight as this city and surrounding communities were buffeted by the most crippling snowstorm in a quarter of a century.

Outstanding loans to business by the seventeen larger New York City banks rose $354,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with an increase of $376,000,000 in the like week a year ago.

From campus to campus, Dayton and Xavier are fifty miles apart in the Buckeye State of Ohio, but the Flyers and the Musketeers will meet in the final of the twenty-first annual National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden tomorrow.
PARIS, March 20 -- Premier Felix Gaillard successfully defended today his right to conduct delicate negotiations for healing France's breach with Tunisia without harassment from Parliament.
BERLIN, March 18 -- The East German regime started a new campaign today to convince farmers of the Communist-ruled state that individual ownership of tractors was uneconomic.
Following are the dead and injured in the fire Wednesday at 623 Broadway, as issued by officials:
BOSTON, March 20 (UP) -- A 45-year-old housewife who had joined the Communist party as a counter-spy told Congressional investigators today that the Red menace to America was growing.
PARIS, March 20 -- "C'est Pratique."

CHICAGO, March 20 (UP) -- Glen Skov scored twice and Ed Litzenberger collected his thirtieth goal of the season for a $500 bonus tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 5-4 triumph over the Detroit Red Wings.

ATLANTIC CITY, Friday, March 21 -- The Vanderbilt Cup Team-of-Four Championship, most important event of the 1958 Contract Bridge Spring National Championships, started belatedly last night at the Traymore Hotel.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 20 -- Although the Indians once traded Manhattan to the Dutch for $24 worth of geegaws and no outfielders, most bargain-hunters nowadays prefer to deal in cash or horseflesh. The single exception perhaps is found in the game of baseball where they like to trade flesh for flesh, prefering only that the flesh run quickly and hit the curve.

TAMPA, Fla., March 20 -- Eleven of the major leagues' player representatives meeting here today unanimously reversed their action of a month ago concerning a sports bill under consideration by a House subcommittee by withdrawing their support of the measure.
BONN, Germany, March 20 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today his Government would not oppose nuclear arming for West Germany's Army should the Atlantic alliance require it.

AUSTIN, Tex., March 20 (AP) -- The Texas Railroad Commission bowed to demands of independent oil producers today and slashed the state's April allowable production by 120,203 barrels a day, fixing the flow at 2,444,571 barrels a day.
Oscar Hammerstein 2d has accused Actors Equity of "pinpricking" George M. Cohan's ghost. Mr. Cohan, who died in 1942, was one of Broadway's most memorable, versatile and dynamic showmen.

Oklahoma points with pride to a new football winning streak. The current Sooner freshman players rolled it up, with an unbroken record of first semester success against a pair of formidable opponents, chemistry and mathematics.
The Advertising Council is contemplating a national campaign in all media aimed at restoring faith in the economy.
DENVER, March 20 -- The National Farmers Union stressed today that vast changes were taking place in agriculture.

It is hard to believe that some of the least familiar territory on earth lies within a short distance of the site of some of the oldest civilizations. Yet this is true of the northeastern bulge of the Arabian Peninsula, not far inland from the Persian Gulf route, followed from time immemorial by trading ships and today about as well known to tanker captains as the Suez Canal or the Caribbean.

MONTREAL, March 20 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens set a National Hockey League record for most goals scored in a season when they whipped the Toronto Maple Leafs, 7 -- 4, tonight with a four-goal barrage in the final period.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 (AP) -- George Bayer whipped the wind and mud today and took the lead after the first round of the St. Petersburg Open.

A 28-year-old Army veteran was declared legally sane yesterday. The man had previously been diagnosed by a psychiatrist assigned to the Bellevue Hospital prison ward as suffering from a mental disorder.

The Georgi Power Company raised $20,000,000 in the bond market yesterday by the sale of thirty-year first mortgage securities to a syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., Kidder, Peabody Co. and Shields Co.
City College announced yesterday that its 1957 Robert J. Flaherty Award in the documentary film had been given to "The Hunters," an American entry.

Your letters column of March 11 contains Harry Kamish's very valid, overmodest plea on behalf of the mentally retarded among our children. This brings to mind the general tendency of our educational system to reward the already fortunate while punishing the underprivileged.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Mansfield D. Sprague, Assistant Secretary of Defense, said today that 85 per cent of the funds voted for foreign military aid this year would be spent in the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold expressed today a firm belief that both sides in the "cold war" harbored a "sincere wish to get results in the field of disarmament."

It has been announced that Philippine President Garcia will visit the United States in June. One purpose of his trip, it has been stated in Manila, will be to seek United States loan assistance for his country in the amount of $300,000,000.
ALBANY, March 20 -- A bill to abolish junior high schools in New York City passed the Assembly today 117 to 29. It now goes to the Senate.
HAVANA, March 20 -- The Superior Electoral Tribunal tonight postponed Cuba's general elections, scheduled for June 1, until Nov. 3.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farmers in ten Midwestern corn belt states apparently are keeping hog production for the spring season in line with a 6 per cent increase forecast last December.
Differences between Judaism and Christianity should not obscure the underlying unity of the human race or the common needs of life, Rabbi Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland said here last night.

CAIRO, March 20 -- Gamal Abdel Nasser attacked the Arab Federation of Iraq and Jordan today in a speech to hundreds of thousands of persons gathered from all over Egypt. He declared the Federation was "London-inspired" and had been conceived as an opposition grouping to the United Arab Republic of Egypt-Syria.
Judging by the reports in The Times, the "Harvard view" is that public works spending is the superior policy for ending the current economic recession.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The United States shifted today toward a tougher policy on a summit meeting.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Army gave Maj. Gen. John B. Medaris today the prestige and authority he had sought to expedite its missile, anti-missile and space weapons programs.

IT is almost impossible to believe. At the age of 74 Ernest Ansermet, one of the distinguished conductors of our time, made his first appearance with the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall last night.
BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, British West Indies, March 20 -- Barbados probably is in the least envied position of all the islands in the new West Indies Federation.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The Senate quietly and without opposition approved today a Republican resolution designed to keep Nelson A. Rockefeller, a potential candidate for governor, in the political limelight.

LONDON, March 20 -- British challengers for the America's Cup are preparing for the nineteenth holding of the 107-yearold yachting event in September with a cold, scientific determination to recover the trophy at any cost. The race was last held in 1937.

Plans have been completed for a benefit concert, art exhibition, and tea, which will take place tomorrow afternoon at 128 East Fifty-eighth Street, headquarters of the Alumni Association of the Fontainebleau (France) School of Music and Fine Arts.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A broadcaster testified at a Senate hearing today that a radio station manager who tried to escape the current flood of rock 'n' roll was hampered by the "shortage of good music."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20 -- An appeal to abolish racial "membership restrictions" within the American Federation of Musicians has been sent to George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organization, by a group of Los Angeles Negro musicians.

The Soviets have again resorted to a maneuver which is justifiably interpreted as an attempt to raise their price for a summit meeting and to put all blame on the West if it refuses to pay this price and the meeting does not take place.
PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., March 20 -- Neither rain nor sleet nor snow prevented the Pleasantville station of the New York Central Railroad's Harlem Division from beginning its travels today.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 20 (UP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, proposed tonight that the United States set up schools in Moscow in an "education-for-peace" program.
"Beetles" with arms and hands may be common sights at air bases of the future, according to the General Electric Company's aircraft nuclear propulsion department at Cincinnati.

The United Aircraft Corporation, a major producer of aircraft engines, propellers and aircraft equipment and helicopters, has offered to purchase the assets and business of the Norden-Ketay Corporation.
Governor Harriman said last night that a "primary purpose of American statesmanship" in the Middle East was to convince, Arab rulers' that any destructive nationalist movement would fails.
While the State Assembly was voting to abolish junior high schools in this city, the Board of Education approved final plans yesterday for the construction of a new one.

ONE of the more awesome groupings in town is the New York Stratoliners, the only local chapter of the American Affiliation of Tall Clubs. It's sixty members, almost evenly divided between men and women over six feet in height, assemble every other Saturday in a chamber above the Terminal Restaurant at 47 Vesey Street, downtown.

GOULIMINE, Morocco, March 19 -- The Moroccan administrator of Goulimine said today that old men, women and children had been arriving in the Goulimine area in large numbers in the last month from Rio de Oro and Mauritania.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The House of Representatives approved today a one-year freeze on farm price supports and planting allotments. The action came in the face of an almost certain Presidential veto.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Herman Stichman, trustee of the bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad, appealed today to legislative leaders for tax relief to keep the line in operation.

John Derr and Jim McKay will be commentators of the Master's Golf Tournament in Augusta, Ga., which will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on April 5 (5 to 6 P. M.) and April 6 (4:30 to 6 P. M.).
A teen-age gang member accused of taking part in the killing of Michael Farmer changed some of his testimony yesterday under cross-examination.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Public Health Service warned today that children protected against poliomyelitis might still pass on the disease to their parents.

NAPLES, Italy, March 20 -Charles (Lucky) Luciano, former New York racketeer, was pronounced "a free citizen" today by a special commission of the penal ,tribunal here. The commission rejected a police recommendation to have Luciano formally reprimanded and admonished to mend his ways.
SINGAPORE, March 20 (UP) -- The Dutch liner Oranje removed to safety about 500 American, British and Dutch nationals today from Sumatra.
American industry's part in the launching of this country's first earth satellite was praised yesterday by Lieut. Gen. B. M. Bryan, commanding general of the First Army.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Legislation that would have permitted New York City storekeepers who observe another holy day to open on Sundays was killed today in the Assembly.
A palace that Jason of Golden Fleece fame might have lived in was recently found in an excavation in Volos, port and main urban center of Thessaly, Greece.

LONDON, March 20 (AP) -- Judy Devlin of Baltimore and Margaret Varner of El Paso, Tex., gained the semi-finals today in the all-England badminton tournament, regarded as the unofficial world championship.
Peter F. Long, who is head of the second largest motion-picture studio in Taiwan (Formosa, has arrived in New York to investigate the latest in film-processing techniques.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that all issues in an appeal from a deportation order, including a claim of citizenship, must be decided in a single court proceeding.

Three members of the New York Police Department including a lieutenant appeared yesterday before the Kings County grand jury investigating a reported police tie-up with a Flat-bush bookmaking syndicate.

The election of Boone Gross as president of the Gillette Company was announced by the directors yesterday in Boston. Mr. Gross, who has been president of the Gillette Safety Razor Company, a division of Gillette, since 1952, succeeds Carl J. Gilbert, who becomes chairman, filling the vacancy caused by the retirement of Joseph P. Spang Jr.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 20 (AP) -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus said today that a plan to "restore harmony" to integration-troubled Arkansas was in the making. But he disclaimed knowledge of the plan's details.

NAHA, Okinawa, March 20 -Japan's Socialists have sent congratulations to Okinawa's Socialist party on its showing in Sunday's elections. Japan's big labor union council, Zenro, also congratulated the party here.
The short interest position on the American Stock Exchange reached a record high in the month ended March 14.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 (AP) -- A soggy, wet snow that brought down thousands of power and telephone lines buried the eastern half of Pennsylvania today. The remainder of the state was gripped by sub-freezing temperatures.
The city's Chief Medical Examiner has dismissed Dr. Alfred L. Shapiro, assistant medical examiner in Brooklyn, on charges of neglect of duty.

Vassily Smyslov, defending his world chess championship, resorted to aggressive tactics in the sixth game of the series with Mikhail Botvinnik, yesterday, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.

BALTIMORE, March 20 -Details of a method that may diagnose diseases through blood serum patterns were given today by Dr. Winston H. Price of Johns Hopkins University School of Hygiene and Public Health.
The State of Ohio borrowed $32,000,000 yesterday to finance the construction of major highways.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 20 (AP) -- Three members of the Ku Klux Klan were sentenced to prison today for plotting to bomb a Negro school near here last Feb. 15.
A SELF-RELIANT, hard-driving executive who has shown a touch of genius in straightening out the Army's production problems is taking over-all command of its missile and rocket - propulsion program.
A rapidly expanding civilian economy would be the best tonic for the national defense, Dr. Arthur S. Flemming told an audience in the financial district yesterday.
"The World of Suzie Wong" is being eyed by Richard Burton. It is "almost certain," he said, that he will accept the starring assignment in the Paul Osborn dramatization of Richard Mason's novel.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Federally enforced safety laws for longshoremen are needed to help the nation's "most hazardous occupation," a Senate Labor subcommittee was told today.

NEW CITY, N. Y., March 20 -- The owner of the largest tract of land in Rockland County asked the State Supreme Court today to name a referee or commission to help the Town of Clarkstown out of a serious tax tangle.

THE Metropolitan Opera last night presented Wagner's "Parsifal," the twenty-fifth and last of the operas that it is giving this season. And though this presentation was two weeks in advance of the traditional one on Good Friday, it brought the spell of Holy Week into the opera house.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 -- The Phillies tangled with the Yankees today for the first time this spring and met disaster on two counts.
Top-level changes at the Sinclair Oil Corporation were announced yesterday, following a meeting of the directors.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- The House Armed Services Committee voted unanimously today to grant a $669,379,000 pay rise to members of the armed forces. It rejected the pleas of some members for a delay.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20 -- Two Hollywood stars, John Wayne and William Holden, have a competitive interest in filming the story tentatively titled "Stein Dodge," about the exploits of an adventurer in ancient Japan before the country established relations with the Western world.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The political truce on tax-cutting that Secretary of the Treasury Anderson arranged with Speaker Rayburn and Senate Majority Leader Johnson permits the economic factor for the present to dominate the political in the ultimate official decision on what many regard as the key anti-recession measure.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy has ordered all 660 rookie policemen attending the Police Academy to go on night patrol starting today.

This is the tag end of the winter, and everything that lies in the future is bound to be better. Well, one can hope that it is the tag end of the winter, just as one can hope that everything will be better.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 20 -- Brazil's Communists were given an assist today in their plans to organize an anti-United States front for the October election campaign. A court revoked an eight-year-old order for tse arrest of party leader Luis Carlos Prestes.
The Texas Company, oil producer, announced yesterday plans for borrowing $150,000,000 in the public market.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Members of Congress are put "behind the eight ball" when the dictator of a country receiving United States aid reportedly spends a million dollars to send his son to school in the United States for a year.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Governors of two oil-producing states appeared before the House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee today in support of a further limitation of oil imports.

TEHERAN, Iran, Friday, March 21 (UP) -- The Shah of Iran told his people in a dramatic nation-wide broadcast today that he had sacrificed love in favor of his country's future when he divorced Queen Soraya.
MINDEN, La., March 20 (AP) -- A grand jury today accused W. Wilson White, United States Assistant Attorney General in charge of civil rights, of interfering with its work.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20 -- George Bayer, an automobile salesman, listened to the two fellows arguing about their golf scores. Since they were friends rather than customers, there was no need for Bayer to be discreet.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Friday, March 21 -- The Unionist party retained control of the Government in the general election yesterday but lost four seats in the House of Commons to the Northern Ireland Labor party.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- International Geophysical Year scientists are proposing that a satellite be used to settle the controversy over whether time runs faster or slower in space.
SEBRING, Fla., March 20 -All of the more than sixty cars entered for Saturday's twelvehour endurance race for world championship points were ordered out for practice this afternoon and tonight.

SOMETIME in the year 1742 the pampered son of a wealthy Chinese family that had fallen on evil days began to write a novel in the language of everyday speech, not in the traditional "literary" language of the ancient classics. Tsao Hsueh-chin completed eighty chapters before his death. One of his editors, Kao Ou, finished his book with forty more chapters.
Mayor Wagner called yesterday for legislation to prevent loft fires like the one at 623 Broadway on Wednesday that took the lives of twenty-four textile workers.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 20 -- Electric power service in southern New Jersey was crippled yesterday when ice knocked out a trunk transmission line feeding seven counties.
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 20 -- A twenty-day strike against the Waterman Steamship Lines was nearer a solution today after Gov. Luis Munoz Marin had held a second conference with both sides.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A Southern Democratic Senator raised the traditional states' rights objection today to Federal unemployment compensation payments.

Torakichi (Pete) Nakamura, the Japanese golf professional who won the International Golf Association championship last October in Japan, and his partner, Koichi Ono, arrived yesterday and did not utter a word of complaint about the snow and non-golfing weather.
MADRID, March 20 -- Spain has offered to return to Moroccan sovereignty the southern zone of the former Spanish protectorate in Morocco, diplomatic circles reported today.

MIAMI, March 20 (UP) -- Don Drysdale pitched four innings of perfect ball tonight but the Los Angeles Dodgers had to rally to down the Detroit Tigers, 6 -- 4, before a Miami Stadium crowd held to 2,281 by cold, windy weather.

Isn't this a nation of plan-ityourself folks, do-it-yourself and build-it-yourself practical persons? Doesn't nearly everybody feel he could make a newspaper better than the editor or design a house better than the architect?
Member bank reserve positions were virtually unchanged in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

The New York State government must bear its share of the blame for the fact that New York City, its Board of Education, its courts, its policemen cannot deal properly with its juvenile-delinquency problem. The state's failure to provide adequate capacity in its training schools, its failure to expand such capacity rapidly enough have a warping effect on the city's disposition of problem boys and girls.
NEWLYWEDS seem to have two reactions when shopping for furniture for their first home: fright at the thought of making a decision and terror at the thought of the bill.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Governor Harriman announced today an additional program of highway construction for Long Island to stimulate employment and relieve the effects of the economic slump.

LONDON, March 20 -- A project for the integration of Malta into Britain appeared to be in abeyance tonight at the end of talks between the Maltese Prime Minister, Don Mintoff, and Colonial Secretary Alan Lennox-Boyd.

Lincoln Square business men complained yesterday that a realty management concern had sent them allegedly intimidating letters in an effort to get them to vacate prematurely the site of the proposed $205,000,000 redevelopment.

Events today: New York Philharmonic, Myra Hess, pianist, Ernest Ansermet conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Bizet's "Carmen," special student performance, Metropolitan Opera House, 1; Saint-Saens' "Samson et Dalila," Metropolitan Opera House, 8.
The following reports, provided by operators of the ski areas, were filed at telegraph offices yesterday at the times indicated in parentheses:
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- President Bourguiba's declaration of solidarity with the West today was warmly welcomed at the State Department.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Senator Edward J. Thye, Republican of Minnesota, moved today to help a Navy lieutenant keep Bravo, a sled dog. The officer trained Bravo while in the Antarctic but the Navy says he cannot even buy the animal.
TUNIS, March 20 -- President Habib Bourguiba extended an olive branch today to the Western world and even to France.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Republican leaders abandoned today their plan to bring the present legislative session to an end on Saturday. They are now hoping, instead, for a final adjournment on Tuesday or Wednesday of next week.
An oval-shaped, unstable and sluggish low-pressure center sulking over the Atlantic just east of the city was the chief cause of the cold mixture of rain and snow delivered here yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 3 to 6 points (15 to 30 cents a bale) yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 21 -- Congress has declined to approve funds for the construction of a new building for the United States delegation to the United Nations.
TORONTO, March 21 (Canadian Press) -- Frobisher, Ltd. has sold its block of shares in the British Newfoundland Corporation to the Suez Canal Company.

WHEN Albert Einstein urged President Roosevelt to further the making of atomic bombs in defense of democracy he started a chain reaction that still shakes Creation. The debate over the uses and misuses of atomic energy has split more groups and spread over a greater area than just about any other topic of our time.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 21 -- In baseball, as in most anything else, even the best and most promising will have a bad day. Today Tony Kubek had his.

MOSCOW, March 21 -- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko indicated informally tonight that the Soviet Union would be willing to accept a delay of three or four months in its proposed schedule for high level East-West meetings.

LONDON, March 21 -- The advance in the stock market following yesterday's cut in the bank rate lost some of its impetus today. While British Government securities continued to rise, the improvement among industries slowed up considerably and most groups had a sprinkling of falls.

RABAT, Morocco, March 21 -- The Moroccan Government has almost reached the "end of its patience" with Spain, a foreign affairs official said today in commenting on Spain's refusal to restore her Southern Protectorate to Moroccan control.
Sales and earnings of the Ingersoll-Rand Company last year were the highest in its history. While sales were 8.6 per cent above those of 1956, earnings were little improved.

LOUISVILLE, March 21 (AP) -- Kentucky's three - time champions snapped Temple's twenty-five-game winning streak tonight, 61 -- 60, and Seattle crushed the tournament favorite, Kansas Sate, 73 -- 51, to reach the final of the National Collegiate championship.
A substantial proportion of 45,000 Long Island homes that had been without electric light, heat or power since Thursday had service restored by last night.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) -- Officials of the Agriculture Department urged Congress today to pass legislation that would permit almost half of next year's expected Rural Electrification Administration loans to come from private funds.
Manufacturers of folding cartons were urged yesterday to increase development of new products as a spur to faltering profits.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices rose 0.2 per cent to 119.7 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -United States officials are working on a plan to dispose of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of obsolete military aid equipment piling up in European depots.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The bill to preserve the Old Patent Office Building as a national gallery of portraiture and contemporary art was sent to President Eisenhower today.

TUNIS, March 21 -- The dominant political parties of Tunisia and Morocco have scheduled a pan-North African conference in which the insurgent Algerian National Liberation Front will participate. It is planned for early next month in Tangier.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Harold T. Murray Jr., a 16-year-old Boy Scout from Charleston, S. C., has been selected to receive a Young American Medal for bravery.
BOWIE, Md., March 21 (AP) -Eligibles for the Kentucky Derby make up half the field of ten for tomorrow's $30,000 added Governor's Gold Cup race at seven-eighths of a mile.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) -- Admiral Felix B. Stump, Supreme United States Commander in the Pacific, said today that he did not believe the United States "eventually can resist communism" if all Asia slipped into the Soviet orbit.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 21 (AP) -- A three-run blast by Henry Aaron in the seventh inning powered the Milwaukee Braves to a 6-4 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.

MESA, Ariz., March 21 -- Even though baseball has been around since 1839, no statistician ever has taken the time to reveal such pertinent facts as to which player holds the record for foul balls, broken bats, missed train or, for that matter, which player on the diamond does the least amount of work.
GUATEMALA, March 21 -- A storm of protest has been raised here in intellectual and educational circles over an affront to a law school dean ascribed to a United States consular official.
LONDON, March 21 (AP) -- The world heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson, jolted British boxing pride tonight when he admitted he did not know the name of the British heavyweight champion.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Gov. Raymond Gary of Oklahoma told Congress today that excessive imports of foreign oil have plunged his state into "a crisis against which we are helpless to defend ourselves."
PARIS, Saturday, March 22 (Reuters) -- The French National Assembly approved early today a constitutional reform bill aimed at strengthening the Executive and making Cabinet crises less frequent.
Noting the futility of trying to forecast snow depths, the weather man yesterday marked this as the snowiest season in eight years.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Eisenhower took a look at weather reports this afternoon and decided to fly to Augusta, Ga., early tomorrow for a week-end of golf and bridge.

WASHINGTON,March 21 -- The Public Health Service said today that a new and virulent strain of staphylococcus, which resists antibiotics, had become a national problem.

Plans have been completed by members of the Finch Drama Club for six consecutive performances starting Monday, March 24, of "Extra-Curricular," a musical revue, which will be presented at the Finch Theatre, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson today set the national wheat allotment for 1959 at 55,000,000 acres, the minimum permitted by law. He set June 20 for a referendum in which farmers will vote on quotas for the 1959 crop.
STRASBOURG, France, March 21 (AP) -- The new European Parliamentary Assembly ended its initial session today with a new step toward formation of Europe-wide political parties.

WARSAW, March 20 -- Beneath the heavy blanket of snow still covering the entire country lies what may be Poland's best winter grain crop since the end of World War II.

The City Council adopted yesterday a home rule message asking the Legislature to pass a bill to increase the voting powers of six of the eight members of the Board of Estimate.
ALBANY, March 21 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt disclosed today that the state intended to take a hand in New York City's investigation of its Real Estate Bureau.

One scheduled and two unscheduled changes took place in last night's performance of "Samson et Dalila" at the Metropolitan Opera.

BONN, Germany, March 21 -- Franz Josef Strauss, Minister of Defense, recouped for the Adenauer Government today some of the propaganda losses it suffered in a debate in the Bundestag on foreign policy and armaments.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (U-P) -- The Senate rackets committee sought today to find out whether some Chicago lawyers had used hoodlums to settle labor disputes.

Insurance for art's sake could well be the motto of Howard Sloan, a partner in the Harris Sloan Brokerage Company, Inc. He has become in recent years a specialist in the insuring of art of all types.
DETROIT, March 21 (AP) -- United States auto factories, operating on restricted schedules, were expected to build 84,622 cars and 16,604 trucks this week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

Late last month President Eisenhower expressed the hope that this month would "mark the beginning of the end of this recession." Krebiozen, as a "natural immunity" agent against cancer, has been the subject of disagreement in the medical profession since its discovery in 1949. CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- Carrol M. Shanks, president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said today that a quick increase in the pace of Government defense spending and a substantial tax cut "right away" were needed to give a lift to the nation's economy.
FORT HUNTER, N. Y., March 21 (AP) -- The Mohawk Indians were gone today from the land along the Thruway that they occupied last spring on the ground it was theirs under an ancient treaty.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- A House member who has been critical of pressures on Federal agencies was disclosed today to have once asked the Federal Communications Commission for special action.

MONTREAL, March 22 -- The techniques of prospecting aren't what they used to be, but the effects of a "strike" on the one who makes it haven't changed since man began probing for the earth's wealth.

ALBANY, March 21 -- By an overwhelming show of hands -- but without any record vote -- the Assembly killed today for this year a bill that would have permitted the use of radar to obtain convictions for speeding on state highways.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), March 11 -- When the wind is from the south, planes landing at Kalandia Airport, near Jerusalem, circle eastward on their approach. WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee stirred up a controversy today by moving to scrap the lease-purchase program and substituting hard cash to pay for new Government buildings.

MANILA, March 20 -- Philippine economic difficulties are less pressing now than they were three months ago, when President Carlos Garcia proclaimed a program of austerity.

Plans currently before the City Planning Commission, if approved by the city government, would give New York its first modern industrial park, a $30,000,000 development in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn. CHOCOLATE cakes made from commercial mixes rank high when compared with cakes made from standard recipes, according to a recent study conducted by the State College of Home Economics at Cornell University.

The fourth annual conference of the Central Opera Service opened yesterday morning at the Biltmore Hotel under the auspices of the National Council of the Metropolitan Opera. The conference, which continues through this afternoon, is centered on problems of community opera production.

Three four-story loft buildings at 227-29-31 Water Street, corner of Beekman Street, have been purchased by the Bee Water Corporation. They were sold by Charles H. Demarest, Inc., in a deal arranged by W. E. Dean Co., broker.

The Eastman Kodak Company has budgeted its capital expenditures this year at a record $62,000,000. In 1957 the big photography manufacturer invested $56,000,000 in additions, improvements and replacements for plants, processes and equipment.

A Supreme Court jury awarded $30,000 to a Boston lawyer last night in his suit against Winthrop Rockefeller and the defendant's former wife, Barbara Sears Rockefeller. However, the judge immediately set aside the verdict and criticized the jury.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -Consumer prices edged upward again in February to still another high, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

THE Juilliard Opera Theatre is ambitious. It undertook a production of Strauss' "Ariadne on Naxos" at the Juilliard School last night. CLEVELAND, March 21 (AP) -- Ron Delany of Villanova wound up his indoor track campaign tonight by winning his twenty-fourth consecutive mile race. His time of 4:12.7 was far off the 4:03.4 world indoor record he set at Chicago a week ago.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Officials here are wondering whether the Soviet Union is preparing to announce its intention to suspend nuclear arms production as soon as its current series of tests is completed.
ALBANY, March 21 -- The Assembly defeated today a bill that would have required one year's residence within the state to qualify for public assistance. The vote was 69 in favor and 72 against.

MORGANTOWN, Pa., March 21 -- More than 800 men, women and children trapped up to thirty-six hours in a snowbound Pennsylvania Turnpike restaurant were rescued this morning by bulldozers and helicopters.

BEERSHEBA, Israel, March 21 -- Units of the Israeli and Jordanian Armies were confronting each other this week along the old border areas northeast of here. But for a change they were not pitted against each other.

One of the world's most beautiful bridges, which had been one of the world's great architectural monuments, has now been restored in its original form. WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) -- The General Services Administration had asked for $3,975,000 to construct the United States mission building at First Avenue and Forty-fifth Street. It said $1,035,000 already had been provided for site and planning work, for a total contemplated outlay of $5,010,000.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -- An examiner for the National Labor Relations Board ruled today that it could be an unfair labor practice for an employer to make workers wear buttons saying "We Are Happy."

The Academy of Religion and Mental Health has announced a grant of $10,000 from the Smith, Kline French Foundation to provide fellowships for psychiatric training for theological students and clergymen of all faiths who want to become chaplains in mental hospitals. Trading volume in copper futures yesterday on the Commodity Exchange reached 312 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot). This was the highest total for a single session since the exchange reopened on July 27, 1951, after a suspension of trading during World War II.

Lowell Thomas' "Search for Paradise" will complete its engagement at the Warner Theatre on May 3, according to an announcement yesterday by the Stanley Warner Corporation. The fourth feature in the Cinerama process will have lasted thirty-one weeks.

Subway service was disrupted yesterday morning by storm-related electrical fires and power failures. Bus operations through snow and slush-covered streets were described as "fairly normal'' by the Transit Authority.

WINTER PARK, Colo., March 21 (AP) -- John Bower of the Eastern Ski Association raced over the four and a quarter mile course in 34 minutes 9.5 seconds to win the cross-country title today in the national junior ski championships.
CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- Corn, rye and soybeans moved well ahead on the Board of Trade today but wheat lost ground and oats held about steady.
NEW DELHI, India, March 21 -- Henry Cabot Lodge, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, has been denounced by one of India's leading anti-Communist organizations.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 -- Senator William F. Knowland flew home today to file his candidacy for Governor, aim a volley at "labor bosses" and picture his Democratic rival as an addict of generalities.

Mikhail Botvinnik, with a two-pawn advantage when the sixth game of his match with Vassily Smyslov for the world chess championship was adjourned Thursday, went on to triumph yesterday in Moscow. The game lasted 49 moves, according to reports from Soviet news sources.
In an East Side living room adorned with sculptures and pictures of Hindu deities, the vice president of India yesterday prophesied a universal religion.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 21 -- The Indonesian Army said tonight that rebel forces had been isolated southwest of Medan, in Sumatra, and that 300 others had been captured.

IT is already clear that the Soviet rockets that sent Sputniks I and II into space orbits accomplished far more than merely scientific feats. In this country they set into motion a process of re-examination of old beliefs and old values for which there is no recent precedent.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Committee for Economic Development recommended today a temporary 20 per cent across-the-board reduction in personal income taxes if the recession deepens in March and April.

Henry Barraud, French composer in the United States as a guest of a State Department program, was present in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon to hear the first New York performance of his Symphony No. 3. It was played by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Charles Munch.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 22 (UP) -- Marlene Mathews, a 23-year-old Australian sprinter, smashed a women's world record for the second time in less than three days by winning today's 220-yard dash in 23.4 seconds at the national track championships.

HAVE twelve-tone music and its blood relation, serial technique, a future? The answer depends primarily on the caliber of the composers who profess the faith and on the quality of the music they produce.

DENVER, March 22 -- A Colorado Supreme Court ruling on Municipal Court trials may open the doors for 600 prisoners in Denver County Jail. It may also force refund of millions of dollars in fines and make every city ordinance unenforceable.

Three thousand person, mostly American high school pupils, attended the twelfth annual New York Herald Tribune Forum for High Schools in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday afternoon. They heard thirty-four teen-agers from abroad criticize the United States for segregation, "supernationalism" and a somewhat faulty educational system.

DETROIT, March 22 -- This city is suffering from the highest sustained unemployment of the post-war period. Moreover, at this time there appear to be no reliable indications that an early upturn in business is in prospect.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Responsible figures in the Eisenhower Administration now concede that the Soviet Union is ahead in the propaganda battle over the summit conference. Although the Soviet campaign has overreached itself at times, the net result has been to keep the United States on the defensive.

FOR THIS WEEK: Last call to start petunia, snapdragon and verbena seed indoors. . . . Feed trees as ground thaws. . . . Rabbit repellent will stop the long-eared visitors from nibbling bulb foliage. . . Feed lightly rhubarb and asparagus. . . . Cut a few crabapple branches and force them indoors. . . . Start a garden diary for reference.

DETROIT, March 22 (AP) -- Two driving lay-ups by Slater Martin in the closing ninety seconds lifted the St. Louis Hawks to a 99-96 victory over the Detroit Pistons today. The triumph put the Hawks ahead by 2 -0 in the four-out-of-seven series for the Western title in the National Basketball Association.
Control of the turbulent affairs of Local 88 of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots will be taken over tomorrow by the international president, it was reported yesterday.
Claire McCardell, designer of clothes to give women a look of casual comfort, died of cancer yesterday in New York Hospital. Her age was 52.

WASHINGTON, March 22--Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the Eisenhower Administration had not yet made a choice between tax relief and major public works as a possible anti-recession weapon.

IN the serene detachment of his years, Learned Hand here surveys government by the many and judicial restraint of its aberrations. His essays, delivered as lectures at Harvard, are liberal in the proper sense; they disclose no constraint to maintain conventional attitudes -- even those of conventional liberalism.

MIAMI, Sunday, March 23 -- The Dodgers of Los Angeles and the Yankees, who still live in the Bronx, met last night for the first time this spring and apparently liked each other's company so much they carried their encounter right into the early hours of this morning.
A large committee has been announced to work for the success of the gala concert to be held in Town Hall on April 15 to aid the victims of last October's flood in Valencia, Spain.

STEPHEN LONGSTREET has almost prestigious facility as a writer, and a gift of turning practically everything he writes -- including his musical, "High Button Shoes" which ran 727 performances in New York -- into cinema or TV or radio.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 22 -- The Bergen County Board of Freeholders gave a preview this week of its 1958 movie, "County on the Move." The film depicts the impact on county and municipal government of the surge in population since the end of World War II.

TOKYO, March 22 -- The Japanese police seized today a small but powerful fishing vessel that they believed to be the "flagship" of a Communist fleet engaged in clandestine operations between Japan and Communist China.
Graduate schools of social work are reporting a steady increase in student enrollment. Current registration has climbed to within 4 per cent of the total nation-wide enrollment of the peak year 1950.
BOSTON, March 22 -- Maine Democrats trumpeted the opening of the 1958 political campaign in New England this week with their biennial state convention, held at Lewiston.
CAMBRIDGE, March 22 -- A hitherto unexhibited portrait of the late Prof. Charles Townsend Copeland, Harvard University's beloved "Copey," was presented tonight to the Signet Society.

AFTER getting off to a faltering start, this English novel about a straggler in a World War II Atlantic convoy speeds up and ends with the reader firmly in its grip. The writing is singularly flat, the dialogue banal.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, March 22 (UP) -- The Communist North Koreans charged today that United Nations Command jet planes had violated the frontier.
A man who represents the oldest unbroken family line on Manhattan Island will forsake the familiar ground of his ancestors this month.

TOKYO, March 15 -- American consumers who buy "cheap" Japanese products are not getting any bargain by Tokyo standards, according to a survey of the United States market made public this week by a leading Japanese export promotion organization.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, characterized the four-year-old Kohler Company strike today as a struggle between "two stubborn men."

A B-17 navigator caught in the Japanese conquest of the Philippines during the opening days of World War II and taken prisoner on Corregidor, Edgar D. Whitcomb refused to give up. Together with a marine companion, he eluded his captors and swam the dangerous eight-mile stretch of water from Corregidor back to the mainland under cover of darkness.

DISSENSION has invaded the inner councils of the scheduled trans-Atlantic airlines. Through the din of debate can be discerned the clinking of tableware and savory odors of meats, cheese, garnishes and things.

ST. THOMAS, V. I. -- One of the good-natured boasts of the natives here is that whereas the United States paid a mere 2 cents per acre for Alaska, these exotic islands cost them $25,000,000 -- about $300 per acre -- when they were purchased from Denmark in 1917.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 22 -- Arthur Knapp Jr., heading for a repeat winter sailing championship at Larchmont Yacht Club, captured his eighth regatta of the frost bite season with Agony today. Winning two of the seven contests, Knapp finished with 190 points of a possible 210 to lead Glen Foster, skipper of Ordeal, by 1 point. The last race decided.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., March 22 -- The Village Players, an organization of North Shore amateur theatrical enthusiasts, will present "The Tender Trap," a comedy by Max Shulman and Robert Paul Smith, in the school auditorium on April 25 and 26.
Fishing goes with pleasure boating almost like ham with eggs, or lox with bagels.

THE isle of Bali, separated from Moslem Java by two miles of shark-infested ocean and by six centuries of magically preserved pre-Moslem Hindu art and culture, is a microcosm of the grace and beauty of Indonesia's medieval past. It is also a microcosm of Indonesia's troubled present.

ST. PETERSBURGH, Fla., March 22 -- Casey Stengel was relaxing in the dugout at Miller Huggins Field the other day, just before his departure for Miami and the weekend series with the Dodgers. He was rambling along in one of his typical disjointed conversational excursions when he suddenly settled on one topic and surprisingly stuck to it.

DETROIT, March 22 -- Walter P. Reuther and his United Automobile Workers will begin a major bargaining drive Tuesday in an effort to win higher wages and a share of the auto manufacturers' profits.
