The first debutante ball for American and French debutantes will be held in the Orangerie of the Palace of Versailles on the evening of July 12. Planned to promote goodwill between the United States and France, the event will be a benefit to aid in the restoration of Versailles.

WHITE PLAINS, March 22 -- Democratic and Republican leaders in Westchester both found encouragement this week in the county's changing political picture. Interpretations of the picture depended largely on which part of it was examined.

The latest attempt to revive Mount Washington's American Inferno downhill ski race, last officially held in 1939, came to an end yesterday when this year's version was canceled because of lack of entries. It was scheduled for next Saturday or Sunday, depending on conditions.

Last week's big snowstorm astonished most of us. It need not have done so. Big snowfalls, as the weather specialists often remind us, are as likely as not to come at the edge of the seasons. As Dr. George H. T. Kimball says in his entrancing book on "Our American Weather," "the heaviest falls have a habit of occurring when the temperature is between 24 and 30 degrees Fahrenheit."
Two great singers were guests of the Metropolitan Opera at yesterday's matinee of "Der Rosenkavalier." Rudolf Bing was so pleased about it that he took the audience into his confidence.

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 18 -- Economic shadows are lengthening over South America.

LUBBOCK, Tex., March 22 -- Illinois racked up 47 points to take the fourteenth annual National Collegiate fencing championship today. Columbia was second with 43. The 1957 champion, New York University, finished fifth in the two-day tournament with 36 points. It was Columbia's third straight year as a second-place finisher.

Robert R. Bowie's "Analysis of Our Policy Machine" (March 9) discourses on the "complexity" of "ways," "devices," "procedures," etc., of the foreign policy "machine." But it does not reach the heart of the matter: the quality of the men who run it and the spirit which animates it.

How It Was Then When the competitive civil service was organized seventy-five years ago, the chief problems facing the nation were taxes, tariffs and the distribution of postmasterships. WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Plans to acquire 414 acres of land for 1,150 family housing units at McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey, were approved yesterday by a House Armed Services subcommittee.
LOUISVILLE, March 22 -- Kentucky battled to its fourth National collegiate basketball championship tonight, rallying to whip Seattle, 84 -- 72.

NOW in her tenth-anniversary year, tiny Israel, cradled in the oriental Middle East, continues to surprise and inspire observers. Her heroic struggle against hostile nature and neighbors, on a patch of earth held sacred in East and West, is one of the great stories of the century.

Investments in industrial facilities in February in the Chicago area climbed to $20,136,000 from $6,479,000 in January, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry has reported. Just as he has been sending up satellites, man has also been making some small additions to this "celestial gravel pit." Recently, the Air Force fired into space two artificial meteors, about the size of marbles, from an Aerobee rocket.

TRIPOLI, Lebanon, March 22 -- An occasional fierce squall swept in from the whitecapped Mediterranean today to pelt Lebanon's second city and its citizens. But only the weather was gusty.

A tour of homes in Somerset County, N. J., will be held on May 10 for the benefit of the Somerset Hospital in Somerville. The event is being sponsored by the Somerset Hospital Auxiliary. Tickets may be obtained from the auxiliary.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 22 (UP) -- Budge Patty, the 34-year-old tennis globetrotter from Los Angeles and Paris, gained the men's singles final today in an international tennis tournament with a 6-4, 6-3, 6-0 victory over Earl Buchholz of St. Louis.

THE self-styled "fat, balding, middle-aged" author of this book was only 19 when he and 18-year-old Richard Loeb -- precocious, pampered kids -- murdered Bobby Franks, another Chicago youth. Nathan Leopold, recently paroled from his sentence of "life plus 99 years," recounts here what has happened to him in the subsequent thirty-four years; he does not tell us why he joined Loeb in the murder.
OTTAWA, March 22 -- It looks increasingly as if Canada is moving back to a two-party system, in the federal political field at least.
Associate Justice Tom Clark of the United States Supreme Court was guest of honor last night at a dinner of the Phi Alpha Delta Law Fraternity in the Statler Hotel.

An award of $105,000 with interest was announced yesterday in a suit against the state for structural damage to a five-story apartment house in the Bronx. The damage to the building, at 1890 Crotona Parkway, was caused by excavation work for the Cross Bronx Expressway.
BOSTON, March 22 -- The attic of a farmhouse in central Maine has yielded three rare postage stamps that are believed to be worth about $20,000.

GEORGES SEURAT, one of the greatest and most influential painters of modern times, died on March 29, 1891, less than five months after his thirty-first birthday. He was active as a mature painter for little more than ten years.
THE design of the promised stamp commemorating the bicentennial of the birth of James Monroe, the nation's fifth President, was given out yesterday by Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield.

Over this week-end Pakistanis are celebrating "Republic Day," since today is the second anniversary of the proclamation of the republic. It could also be called "Constitution Day" because the republic was set up through the adoption and promulgation of Pakistan's democratic Constitution on March 23, two years ago.

ALBANY, March 22 -- A bill authorizing Mayor Wagner to borrow $17,000,000 on three-year bonds to pay New York City's share of Social Security benefits for its employes was approved today by Governor Harriman.

ZAKOPANE, Poland, March 22 (AP) -- Four American ski stars, barred from competing in Communist Czechoslovakia, said today they would seek International Ski Federation sanctions against the Czech sports authorities.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 23 -- The newspaper of the influential Nationalist party reported today that the United States, prior to the capture of the Pakanbaru area by government troops March 12, had "requested" Indonesia's permission to land American paratroopers there.

Construction of a National Opera and Ballet Theatre in Washington was urged here yesterday by Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, so that "we will not hang our heads in shame whenever people tell us about the Bolshoi Theatre" in Moscow.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, March 22 (Reuters)-- The Hiroshima City Council called on former President Harry S. Truman today to "reflect on his opinionated remarks that he felt no compunction" after ordering the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

The deep underground detonation of that "little, tiny atom bomb" under the top of a mesa in Nevada last Sept. 19 has opened up the possibility that, in addition to its many potential peacetime applications in industry, biology, medicine and agriculture, it may yield, as a by-product, artificial diamonds and a host of other precious gems.
NAPLES, Italy, March 22 (UP) -- Foreign Minister Giuseppe Pella tonight gave the United States sweeping credit for Europe's post-war recovery and for spurring European integration.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- As if the military did not have enough problems getting missiles to fly, there is now a problem of just getting a rocket to stand on its tail.

ANOTHER literary ballistic missile has been launched by Paul Blanshard at the Roman Catholic hierarchy in the United States. It is an updated and somewhat longer version of "American Freedom and Catholic Power," which has sold more than 200,000 copies in this country since publication nine years ago.

The scientific leaders of the United States earth satellite program have performed a major public service in presenting to the Administration a comprehensive series of proposals for the investigation of space well beyond the International Geophysical Year which ends Dec. 31.

The scholarship fund for Boys at the Bonnie Brae Farm in Millington, N. J., will be aided by the proceeds of the annual benefit bridge and charity bazaar to be held at the farm on May 19 and 20. The auxiliary of the farm is the sponsor.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., March 22 -- Indian Harbor Yacht Club; frostbite helmsnen defeated the Riverside Yacht Club, 235--222, today in their annual teami series.

Variety characterizes the auction sales this week. Antiques, finely worked embroidery pictures, Renaissance silver, unredeemed pledges in jewelry, Old Master drawings, nineteenth-century paintings and Chinese art all are on hand.

Snow, slush and rain combined late last week to dash hopes for a plus sign in store sales compared with 1957 volume in the metropolitan area Sales had been going well until Wednesday. After that, bad weather kept the customers away. Department store officials estimated that sales for the week had been 5 to 10 per cent below the 1957 level. Branch stores especially were hard hit.

THIS is as fine a literary biography as has appeared in a long time. Joyce Hemlow's scholarship is deep and broad, her style a delight; and her sympathy for Fanny Burney (1752-1840) is perceptively warm yet objective.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 22 -- The ranks of Czechoslovak Communists have been remolded into a monolithic Stalinist order in preparation for the eleventh party congress to be held in Prague in May.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 22 -- Former President Harry S. Truman wielded a silver baton and Jack Benny played first violin tonight to lead the Kansas City Philharmonic Orchestra out of debt. The former President conducted a rousing, foot-stomping performance of Sousa's "Stars and Stripes Forever."

ORLANDO, Fla. -- Central Florida, with its thousands of lakes, many picturesque rivers, rolling hills and outstanding private attractions, offers a different type of spring or summer vacation to those who prefer sight-seeing, boating and fishing to lolling on a beach.

THIRTY youngsters, most of them 9 and 10 years old, took part in a mid-year "graduation" at Public School 132, Manhattan, last month. No college ceremony could have represented a more genuine "commencement."

THREE famous Charleston, S. C., gardens -- Magnolia, Middleton Place and Cypress -- are synonymous with azaleas in March and April. Even though bloom is somewhat late this year, it is expected to be better than usual.

PITTSBURGH, March 22 -- The economic picture in this heavy industrial area is still bleak on the morn of spring. Between January and February 14,000 person were put out of work. The Pittsburgh labor market had 90,700 jobless workers in January and had 104,000 as of this date.

IN spirit with the season, metropolitan art galleries this week are for the most part offering lean Lenten fare. One exception to this is the show of still-life paintings at Knoedler's which includes, along with some unremarkable pictures, several of high interest and beauty.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 -- In the nation's third-ranking industrial area, the recession, while it has affected thousands of individuals, from a community standpoint is still predominantly a statistical matter. Complaints about conditions still are confined largely to specific groups affected, such as unions in certain trades.

FOR many years Father Harold C. Gardiner has given Jesuit weekly America the character of a reputable literary review. This experience has admirably prepared him for the writing of his new book, a book that, in the nature of things, will be wholly acceptable to hardly anyone.

IT'S tomato starting time for Northeastern gardeners. Seed should be on hand or in the mails. Indoor sowing begins at the end of this month so that sturdy seedlings will be ready for planting by mid-May.

BEETHOVEN: Piano Sonata in D minor; CHOPIN: Etudes Nos. 1, 8 and 5 (Op. 25); Mazurka in A minor (Op. 14, No. 4); Scherzo in C sharp minor; Dorothy Eustis, pianist (Alta). Thoroughly competent playing of popular concert hall pieces. Clear recorded sound.

JUST how wrong can certain people be? On Sunday, March 16, Peter Goldmark, in discussing the tenth anniversary of long-playing records, completely ignored the fact that the American Foundation for the Blind, the Library of Congress and the American Printing House for the Blind, in Louisville, had been making long-playing records available to blind people since 1934.
Two developments -- the long-range missile and the nuclear-powered submarine -- have emphasized more dramatically than ever the strategic importance of the Arctic.
LONDON, March 22 (UP) -- Judy Devlin of Baltimore retained the women's singles title today in the all-England badminton tournament, She defeated Margaret Varner of Boston, 11 -- 7, 12 -- 10.
In the "Letters" column of March 2 John Sampson asks "Can we absolve Churchill from responsibility" for the decline of the British Empire?
TORONTO, March 22 -- The New York Rangers routed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 7 -- 0, in a National Hockey League game tonight before 12,692 at the Gardens.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Some officials here are deeply disturbed over the Administration's apparent willingness to negotiate a summit agreement in principle on nuclear test suspension.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Senator Styles Bridges has joined Senator Mike Mansfield in mapping defense-reorganization legislation in advance of President Eisenhower's recommendations on the subject.

RATHER an anomaly among contemporary sculptors, Gerhard Marcks in his long career has taken part in the principal phases of the modern movement, encountered disaster and, after being associated with abstract and expressionist movements, has returned to his first love -- human and animal figures, which have, however, profited by much that he has learned on his journey and applied.
ALBANY, March 22 -- Governor Harriman today approved a bill clearing the way for modernizing the Suffolk County government.

NEW ORLEANS, March 22 -- A Federal Court jury here will begin hearing a case Monday in which a widow is seeking damages of $779,500 from two tobacco companies. She alleges that the lung cancer from which her husband died in 1955 was caused by his smoking.
The Financial Institutions Act, a 252-page omnibus bill that attempts to sweep the cobwebs out of the nation's banking laws, is arousing increasing controversy as it nears the House floor for debate.

NEW HAVEN, March 22 -- Ralph H. Gabriel, historian who developed one of the first courses in American thought and civilization, will retire as Sterling Professor of History at Yale on June 30. He will reach the mandatory retirement age of 68 on April 29.
LONDON, March 22 -- Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Labor party, again urged a series of summit talks today as a means of bringing the East and West closer together.

The unmistakable notes of the red-winged blackbirds are heard in the boglands again, undeniable proof that the season approaches April. The red-wings are a more reliable index than the robins, for they only occasionally winter this far north. When we hear that lilting challenge, "O-kar-eeee!" we know that the peepers will be calling before very long.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., March 22 -- The world's most glamorous missile center is a desolate 15,000 acres of scrub, sand and swamps.
ATHENS, March 22 -- Greece's complicated electoral system, known as "reinforced proportional," is expected to be further discussed, contested and amended in the Chamber of Deputies next week.

ESSEN, Germany, March 22 -- Workers and their Ruhr bosses, an anxious eye cocked toward the United States, are wondering whether hard times are on the way for the industrial heartland of West Germany.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 22 -- The motion picture colony was shocked this morning by the death of Mr. Todd, who in less than three years had become recognized as one of Hollywood's most colorful and resourceful personalities.

SEBRING, Fla., March 22 -- Peter Collins of England and Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif., drove a new 2,953-cubic-centimeter Ferrari to victory tonight in the Sebring Twelve-Hour Grand Prix of Endurance for sports cars. They won easily, finishing more than a lap ahead of another Ferrari team car driven by Luigi Musso of Italy and Oliver Gendebein of Belgium.
A New York County grand jury will check next month into the reported domination of professional boxing in this area by underworld figures.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- If you asked your favorite "typical American" to cite a statistic on the recession, chances are that he or she would cite unemployment and might know that it's at a post-war record of more than 5,000,0000.
RHODODENDRONS and azaleas generally are among the costliest specimens in the garden. Growers watch over them with careful eyes. When the least abnormality appears, they often are concerned.
THE first "wax museum" in America -- patterned after the famed establishment of Mme. Tussaud in London -- opened last week in a former stable not far from the Lincoln Memorial in Washington.
ALBANY, March 22--A bill to grant state aid to towns for applying binder material to town highways was vetoed today by Governor Harriman.
ATLANTA, March 22 -- The number of unemployment compensation claimants in Georgia declined from a peak of 50,300 in the first week of March to 49,200 March 15.

Mrs. John S. Burke, president of the Carroll Club, and head of the benefit committee for the theatre party to be held at the May 7 performance of Christopher Fry's play, "The First-born," has completed plans for the event.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Senator Robert S. Kerr accused the Administration tonight of trying to cover up policy mistakes that he said had brought on an "Eisenhower brand" of recession.

A men's committee has been announced for Gotham in the Spring, a gala twilight dinner dance being arranged for Easter Sunday, April 6, in the Ballroom of the Plaza. Proceeds will aid the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club.
ATLANTA, March 22 -- The South's voting practices came in for new attention this week.

THE latest of R. K. Narayan's pensive comedies is a brilliant accomplishment in his special kind of literature, the novel of the dreaming scamp. Like all his books. "The Guide" is part of the life of Mr. Narayan's imaginary city of Malgudi.

Vassily Smyslov, in defense of the world chess championship in Moscow, yesterday drew the seventh game of the series with Mikhail Botvinnik, according to a report from Soviet news sources. The game lasted only sixteen moves.

Morris High School's foilsmen of the Bronx moved into a first-place tie with Lincoln as the penultimate bracket in the city Public Schools Athletic League's title fencing round robin tournament was completed yesterday.

Even though spring is here officially, color is still faint on the landscape in the Northeast. The crocus, witch hazels and snowdrops lead the floral list. In the South shrubs and spring bulbs -- brilliant azaleas, tulips and daffodils -- already proclaim the season.

BELFAST -- Since 1951 Northern Ireland tourism has been able to register an appreciable gain each season in its total of visitors. Its share of holiday traffic, not only from the United Kingdom, but from the Commonwealth, America and Europe, is forecast as a record this year.
Prof. Edward Corwin's letter published on March 16 on the "aggressive tendency" of the Supreme Court strides to its conclusions on the matched stilts of bare assertion and strong language.

THREE boys share the spotlight in this episodic novel set in Ironwood, a coed prep school. Colton Muir -- introduced in the author's previous novel, "The MacQuarrie Boys" -- Savey Miller and Vance Draper illuminate a teen-age problem that's worse than a squeaky voice: growing up.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 22 -- The launching of the Vanguard I test satellite has come as a tonic to the American public.
Puerto Rico is attempting what may seem like a minor miracle these days -- a reduction in food prices.

The Fire Department continued its efforts yesterday to obtain clear-cut details of the loft-building blaze last Wednesday at 623 Broadway in which twenty-four persons were killed and fifteen were injured.
The sound of falling tenpins rates as heavenly music these nights to the visually handicapped keglers who mow 'em down in The Lighthouse alleys.

It's spring, and the days are getting longer. There have been a lot of dark spots in the economic picture and the added daylight, figuratively and literally, will be welcomed.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- There has been speculation in Washington for some time that if Premier Bulganin were to be removed from his post, the logical time would be at the first Supreme Soviet meeting after the elections.

THE more one considers the before and after of the Misses, Queens and Princesses (Princess Peanut Butter, Queen Processed Cheese, Miss America) the more interesting the situation becomes. These are not just pretty, costumed girls beaming out of the newspaper -- the Miss or Princess career has a beginning and an end. In "Princess in Denim" Zoa Sherburne presents such a career in interesting detail.

In the capitals of the West last week, it was a time for assessment of the chances of getting to the summit. Thousands of words have been written and spoken on East-West issues and proposed summit procedures. Last week the exchange continued unabated.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Democrats and Republicans in Congress are now fully engaged in inter-party warfare on the broad front of anti-recession legislation. In the sector of tax-cutting alone there is a truce between the Democratic leadership and the Administration, but even this truce is an armed one. And when it ends about mid-April the fighting will be harder than on any other part of the political battlefield.

RYE, N. Y., March 22 -- Mrs. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, was a guest of honor today at a luncheon celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Barnard College Club of Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- In the coming month the ominous mushroom cloud of the atomic age will start rising once again over the crescent-shaped Eniwetok atoll in the Pacific. Over Soviet Central Asia and the Barents Sea north of Murmansk similar clouds can be expected to unfold from Soviet atomic test explosions.

THE "wizard" of Eugene Block's title is Edward Oscar Heinrich (1881-1953), who lived in Berkeley, Calif., and plied his scientific detection throughout the nation and the world. Heinrich was one of this country's greatest forensic criminologist -- and possibly the most versatile criminal expert outside of fiction.

A 10,000-ton tanker crashed into a cluster of tugboats and tow vessels tied up at a Staten Island dock last night. Two seagoing tugboats were sunk and a third tugboat, a dredge scow, two steel car floats and two barges were set adrift, the harbor police said.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 19 -- "You're hoeing a tough row these days if you're looking for a Modern Republican in Indiana," a veteran party stalwart said today.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that the Soviet Union had tested another nuclear weapon "in the medium range."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 22 -- Mason Sears' Yankee forebears, not given to flowery speech, might have squirmed to hear him talk this week about "African flowers that will have to grow in their own soil and blossom into their own colors."
BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, British West Indies, March 22 -- Because of its population squeeze and labor problems, Barbados is potentially one of the Western Hemisphere's greatest trouble spots.
TUNIS, March 23 -- Tunisian political quarters and the press have indicated that there will be no further concession to French demands in the current crisis.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer went winging home with a six-under-par 65 today and won the $15,000 St. Petersburg open golf tournament with a birdie on the final hole. His 72-hole total was 276.

PITTSBURGH, March 23 -The consensus here last week was that March steel order volume would do well if it matched the daily average in February. But there were still those who, taking a look at weekly production totals, felt that April business might be a trifle better.

Seventy-three University of Minnesota students enjoyed a roast chicken lunch yesterday in two buses in a muddy West Side lot. The buses were parked in the Greyhound bus "garage" on West Forty-fifth Street, between Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues.
The New York Philharmonic during its 1958-59 season Will have thirty instrumental soloists, eighteen of whom are United States-born or have received their major musical training in the United States.
Although snow lingers over much of the North, swimsuit manufacturers have their 1958 marketing plans and advertisements set.

HAVANA, March 23 -- President Fulgencio Batista tonight termed the recent declaration of "total war" against his Government by Fidel Castro, rebel leader, a demonstration of "arrogance." General Batista said he would take the necessary measures "to maintain order."

CAIRO, March 23 -- Although negotiations for an eventual Summit conference remain confused and inextricably mixed with propaganda, encouragement may be derived from one recent development. This is the indication that Moscow at last seems to take seriously President Eisenhower's effort to isolate outer space from military exploitation.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Just sit and talk with Carmen Basilio for any length of time and you'll understand why everybody likes him. He's forthright and direct, that's why. He speaks just about the same way that he fights, steady and rugged, with no frills, and he pulls no punches.
RIDGE, L. I., March 23 -- Three of six small mid-island school districts whose consolidation has been ordered by a District School Superintendent have retained counsel to fight the move.

The Citizens Committee for Children of New York City, Inc., presented to Mayor Wagner yesterday a list of "serious deficiencies" and instances of "waste" in the city's welfare program. It asked for a meeting with him.

Jose Quintero, who staged "Long Day's Journey Into Night" for Broadway, has changed his mind about presenting Eugene O'Neill's long one - act play, "Hughie," at the summer festival in Spoleto, Italy. He will do it here instead, late next winter.
PARIS, March 23 -- A Socialist candidate today edged out a Communist in a by-election in Nord Department.

The traditional Good Friday performance of "Parsifal" and the return of "Don Giovanni" to the repertory will be features of the Metropolitan Opera's twenty-third week, beginning next Monday.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., March 23 -- Building lots here were given away in New York for cigar coupons and soap wrappers sixty years ago. The lots might as well have been on the moon, for most of the owners never tried to find the properties or were thwarted by thickets and swamps.
A bipartisan measure calling for a step-up in Federal aid to airports was introduced in the Senate last week.

CAIRO, March 23 -- The abrupt dismissal today of Lieut. Gen. Afif Bizri, former Chief of Staff of the Syrian Army, was regarded here as proof that President Gamal Abdel Nasser had taken complete control of the Syrian forces.
ALBANY, March 23 -- New York State may be on its way to ditching of De Witt Clinton's big ditch.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's proposal that rural electric cooperatives obtain needed funds from private sources rather than the Government was criticized by two sources today.
Normal power and telephone service were restored throughout the New York metropolitan area yesterday for the first time since last week's snowstorm.

The Chamber Music Circle, a cooperative of skillful young instrumentalists, presented its third concert of the season late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. As usual, the performances were good and the selections unhackneyed; though in this instance the program had nothing very substantial on it.

One of the nation's leading dairy experts said yesterday that the city's insistence upon dating milk containers had been made unnecessary by modern preservation techniques.

BOSTON, March 23 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics overpowered the Philadelphia Warriors, 106 -- 92, today with a second-half display of versatility that all but clinched their National Basketball Association semi-final playoff series. The Celtics lead the best-of-seven competition, 3 -- 0.
FRANKFURT, Germany, March 23--Erich Ollenhauer, Social Democratic leader, called today for a general strike to upset the Government's decision to accept nuclear arms.
PARIS, March 23 -- The powerful Federation of Mechanical Industries is strongly opposed to a zone of free exchange now being proposed by Britain in connection with the new common market area.
THE seventh annual Artur Schnabel Memorial Concert last night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art presented Alexander Schneider, violinist Leonard Rose, 'cellist, and Beveridge Webster, pianist.

AROSA, Switzerland, March 23 (UP) -- Sally Deaver of Philadelphia won the final event of the Three Summits ski meet today by covering a 1.5-mile slalom run with forty-five gates in 2 minutes 57.7 seconds.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 -- The increasing tendency of the State Department to place restrictions on overseas travel by newsmen and other Americans was criticized today by the American Friends Service Committee.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Democratic leaders of Congress have been quietly exerting their influence, with apparent successes, against rank-and-file agitation for tax reduction.

The relaxation of the Federal Reserve's policy of credit restraint (in force since early 1955) began in the second half of October last year. Open market and discount policies were both changed. The availability of reserves to member banks was increased and the cost of member bank borrowing from the Reserve Banks was reduced.

Puerto Rico is planning to borrow $18,300,000 in the public market by the sale of public improvement bonds on April 1. Bids on the issue will be taken by the Government Development Bank for Puerto Rico at 37 Wall Street.

A pink-coated top-hatted Bank of England messenger walked into the courtyard of that venerable institution last week and held up for all to see a board carrying a cryptic announcement. Reading the statement, the waiting crowd burst into a cheer; for they were watching the weekly ceremony of the posting of the bank rate, and what elicited the cheer was a big figure "6" on the messenger's board.
Laszlo Varga was the soloist with the New York Philharmonic in the Hindemith 'Cello Concerto Saturday night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Varga is the first 'cellist of the Philharmonic.

A panel of college students on the New York Times Youth Forum agreed yesterday that the United States rightly attached great importance to its program of foreign economic aid.

Elmo Roper, a pioneer in public opinion research, has written an account of the American people's shifting attitudes toward persons and issues in "You and Your Leaders: Their Actions and Reactions, 1936-56." He focuses on nine men who have been dominant in political life and offers his "insights" into their actions and personalities.
The port's municipal piers could be operated at a profit if they were run as a separate entity, Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, said yesterday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, March 23 -- The Czechoslovak Government announced today that the Ministry of Local Economy, whose decisions have helped determine the living conditions of Czechoslovak citizens, has been abolished. Its power was given to municipal committees.

ATLANTIC CITY, Monday, March 24 --The contract bridge pair of Ivar Stakgold of Washington and Leonard B. Harmon of New York early this morning won the Spring National Open Pairs Championship at the Traymore Hotel here.
The Columbia Broadcasting System marked its thirtieth year in 1957 with record sales and earnings.

If boos, audible giggles and shouted remarks during the performance of Morton Feldman's piano pieces yesterday discouraged the composer momentarily, he must have been heartened by the cheers that mingled with the applause at the end.

SEBRING, Fla., March 23 (UP) -- Peter Collins and Phil Hill picked up checks and trophies today for winning the Florida Grand Prix of Endurance sports cars race, then set out for New York hoping to make arrangements to enter a race next week-end.
The business recession "can be made into a time of spiritual revival," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday.

AUGUSTA, Ga. March 23 -- President Eisenhower played another full round of golf at the Augusta National Club today and, late this afternoon, flew back to Washington aboard his plane, the Columbine III.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23 -- John Sutherland Productions, Inc., is expanding its operations to include the production of teaching films on science subjects for college and high-school students. The company specializes in making information - entertainment pictures for theatrical exhibition and movies used by industry for worker-training purposes.
The appointment of City Magistrate Paul Balsam as a Justice of the Court of Domestic Relations was announced by Mayor Wagner yesterday.

If anyone at yesterday afternoon's Town Hall concert wondered who was the gentleman with silver hair, mustache and an unmistakable Boston aura who conducted the ensembles so efficiently, he was Arthur Fiedler, longtime conductor of the Boston "Pops" Concerts. Mr. Fiedler's name was inadvertently left off the program.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., March 23 (AP) -- Johnny Kelley, tuning up for defense of his Boston Athletic Association marathon championship, easily won the third annual National Amateur Athletic Union junior thirty-kilometer race today in record time.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 23 (UP) -- Don Taussig's three-run double in the eighth inning enabled the San Francisco Giants to post an 8-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles today in an exhibition baseball game.

The Jewish Braille Institute of America has purchased the five-story limestone and brick dwelling at 48 East Seventy-fourth Street for its headquarters. The property, which is 20 by 102 feet, will be used as a cultural and religious center for the Jewish blind.

WILLIAM ESENWEIN has come to town with three rattlesnakes from Arizona -- a Mojave, a red rattler and a sidewinder. He keeps them in a double-padlock box with proper air vents. He feeds them hamburgers, meat strips and cod liver oil.

Leonard L. Farber, president of the International Council of Shopping Centers, will address a dinner meeting of the Savings Bank Mortgage and Real Estate Forum tomorrow at 6:15 P. M. at the Yale Club, Forty-fourth Street and Vanderbilt Avenue.
MIAMI, March 23 -- It took the Yankees some time today before they were able to put the Dodgers in their proper place. When they finally got around to it, they did a thorough job of it.

TEANECK, N. J., March 23 -- Harold M. Florsheim's 3-year-old Airdale, Ch. Westhay Fiona of Harham from Chicago, added another best-in-show triumph to her list at the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey event today.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 -- Having produced a long list of familiar dramas, the Actor's Workshop is enjoying the luxury of mounting a new play, "A Gift of Fury." It has been written and staged by Herbert Blau, one of the two directors of this six-year old institution.

ST. LOUIS, March 23 (AP) -- The Detroit Pistons walloped the St. Louis Hawks, 109 -- 89, today for their first victory in the National Basketball Association's Western Division semi-final play-off series. The Hawks lead in games, 2 -- 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23 -- The television pilot-film virus is again running through the body of Hollywood production. The fever annually rises at this time, fed by spring and summer program cancellations.

Stockholders of the Glen Alden Corporation will be asked to approve the acquisition of the List Industries Corporation at a meeting April 11. Proxy statements also have been sent to List Industries shareholders for a vote on the proposal at their meeting on the same date.
Broken wall surfaces caused by such awkward architectural faults as protruding bookshelves and badly situated hallway openings can be dramatically treated to give a look of continuity.

The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, administered confirmation to forty-two men, women and children yesterday in St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

BUKITTINGGI, Indonesia, March 23 -- Continued reports of rebel setbacks have had no visible effect on the morale of the revolutionary leaders here. As of last night, according to announcements at Jakarta, Indonesian Government forces had control of nearly half of Sumatra.

Two five-story apartment houses at 111-15 West 190th Street, two blocks north of Fordham Road, the Bronx, have been sold by Rubin Birnbach. They occupy a plot 80 by 100 feet and contain forty-two apartments. Maxwell Fox was the broker in the sale to a client of Maurice Heller, attorney. The assessed valuation is $128,000.
Coach Phil Watson's New York Rangers finished their National Hockey League campaign on a successful note last night as they whipped the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 2, at Madison Square Garden.
A second wave of influenza hit New York City in January and February and a marked increase in the number of deaths coincided with it, according to the City Department of Health.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved moderately but steadily upward last week. At the close of trading on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 26 to 47 points from the close of the previous week.

OCRACOKE, N. C., March 24 (UP) -- Medical supplies dwindled today in the face of an influenza epidemic sweeping this isolated island. More than half of its population of 500 is sick.

A Moscow correspondent of this newspaper reports that there is an unusual atmosphere of expectation in that city about this week's session of the Supreme Soviet, the first since that body was "elected" last week. WASHINGTON, March 24 (UP) A Government effort to crack down on dividends paid by pipeline companies to parent oil-producing companies was thrown out of court today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Treasury bill rate reached a three-year low this week, the Treasury reported tonight. The average interest rate on $1,700,000,000 of the ninety-one day discount bills fell to 1.189 per cent, compared with 1.343 per cent last week.

A PLAY of stirring poignancy and beauty, superbly acted by Julie Harris and Christopher Plummer, was presented last night on "Hallmark Hall of Fame" over Channel 4.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -Sir Harold Caccia, the British Ambassador, announced today that twelve American college and university graduate students had won British Marshall Scholarships.

Lou Rossini of Columbia will replace Howard Cann as head basketball coach at New York University. This was learned authoritatively yesterday, although the official announcement of Rossini's selection is not expected to be made until tomorrow.

The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company has shelved its plan to refund at lower interest cost $30,000,000 of 4 7/8 per cent debentures that it put out last September. WASHINGTON, March 24 -The Public Health Service said today it had obtained samples of a new and more virulent Asian influenza virus reported yesterday by the New York City Health Department. Tests on the virus will be conducted by the service.

WARSAW, March 23 -- A number of Polish Communists who have been enthusiastically encouraging Poland's increasing contact with the United States are furious with Senator John F. Kennedy.

GENEVA, March 24 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia submitted a proposal today in the eighty-seven-nation conference codifying the law of the sea that would bind states "to refrain from testing nuclear weapons on the high seas."

FOR the last twenty years -and, in avant-garde circles, even longer -- the answer to every problem that parents have raised about child behavior has boiled down to: Love your child. Accept your child. Respect him for what he is, not what he does.

A Federal Reserve Board examiner erred in opposing its application to form a new holding company, the First National City Bank of New York said yesterday in a brief filed with the board in Washington.
HAVANA, March 24 -- The Cuban Government lifted censorship today on English-language newspapers and magazines from the United States.
ALBANY, March 24 -- The Legislature's two fiscal committees proposed tonight to cut the amount available for legislative spending by $633,258 below last year's total.
Montgomery Ward Co., Inc., in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, increased sales for the third successive year.

TAMPA, Fla., March 24 (AP) -Bunching four of their nine hits in the sixth inning today, the Cincinnati Redlegs tallied three times to edge a makeshift collection of Phillies, 4 -- 3. The victory snapped a two-game losing streak for the Cincinnatians.
New low prices and a mass production start on a silicon power rectifier by the General Instrument Corporation will open a $100,000,000 annual market in two years, the company said yesterday.
ALBANY, March 24 (AP) -Governor Harriman today urged President Eisenhower to approve legislation that would freeze farm support prices at present levels for the year beginning April 1.
Many patronesses have been announced for the eleventh annual Salute to Summer cocktail party and tea dance, which will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on May 19.

Copper futures dipped yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in the heaviest trading since the market reopened on July 27, 1951, after suspension of activity during World War II. The close was off 11 to 19 points (hundredth of a cent a pound) on 333 lots (50,000 pounds to a lot).
Despite the recession, delinquencies in home mortgage payments have remained near a record low of less than three-tenths of 1 per cent, according to the records of a leading lending institution.
The lowest weekly steel production in nearly six years -- not counting those weeks when output was reduced by major strikes or holidays -- has been scheduled by the industry for this week.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 24 -- This is the time of the season when uneasy lies the head that wears a rookie's cap. Most clubs already have engaged in preliminary pruning.

CITY dwellers might appreciate a bit of spring bloom in their apartments. Two plants, neither of which needs much care to survive, are available at the Goldfarb Flower Shop, 160 East Fifty-seventh Street.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 24 (AP) -- Whitey Lockman, who broke in with the Giants in 1945 at the age of 19, provides the insurance of experience so necessary to a San Francisco club counting heavily on rookies.

Two Swiss trusts were permanently barred yesterday from doing business in securities in New York State. They had been accused last fall of participating in an international stock fraud that cost investors in Canadian and American oil and mining shares about $8,000,000.

In a first move to avert the constant Cabinet crises that plague France, the National Assembly has at last passed a constitutional reform bill to assure more stable government. The bill is still limited in scope and must still surmount many parliamentary hurdles, perhaps even a national referendum, before it can become effective, if it ever does. It may even represent an attempt to sidestep reform rather than achieve it.
ALBANY, March 24 -- A bill increasing state aid to local school districts by $53,535,000 a year was given final approval in the Assembly tonight and sent to Governor Harriman.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 24 (Reuters) -- Yugoslav citizens gave President Tito's Communist regime more vigorous approval in one-party elections on Sunday than they did five years ago, early returns indicated today.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 24 -- The World Jewish Congress is "deeply worried" over the disappearance of Jewish spiritual and cultural life in the Soviet Union, a spokesman for the organization said today.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Carmen Basilio enjoyed a complete day of rest today in anticipation of his fifteen-round fight with Ray Robinson tomorrow night. Basilio, from Chittenango, N. Y., will risk his world middleweight championship against the famed Sugar Ray of Harlem.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UP) -- Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, Army research chief, will retire next Monday after reviewing a parade of the Eightysecond Airborne Division, which he commanded in Europe in World War II.
CAIRO, March 24 -- King Saud of Saudi Arabia handed over some of his absolute powers today to his brother Crown Prince Faisal.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- A Senate Commerce subcommittee today heard further opposition to a railroad proposal that truck haulers of fresh fruits and vegetables be regulated by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The New York Rangers, competing in the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs for the third straight season, meet their arch-rivals, the Boston Bruins, in a best-of-seven semi-final series beginning tonight at Madison Square Garden.

Most senior class high school athletes these days are thinking about regents, sports scholarships and prom partners. But Alvin Reid, a serious, 18-yearold student-athlete at DeWitt Clinton High, is thinking about baby bottles and breadwinning as well as books and his basketball future.
The United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, has been forced to schedule three extra weeks for arguments this term because the case load has increased 25 per cent over last year.
The driver lost control of a Fifth Avenue bus yesterday and it mounted the sidewalk between Forty-eight and Forty-ninth Streets. Scores of persons were on the walk, but only two were hit.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., March 24 -- George E. J. Pistor, a construction engineer, died here yesterday at a nursing home after an illness of several months. He was 78 years old and lived at 55 Elston Road, Upper Montclair.
A confidence man, termed "the meanest sort of swindler," was sentenced yesterday to serve up to three years in jail by Special Sessions Justice Benjamin Gassman.
MONTREAL, March 24 (UP) -- The annual race to open Montreal harbor and win the traditional gold cane was under way, port officials reported today.

WESTBURY, L. I., March 24 -- A presentation without the guest of honor but with food served Cantonese style and harness horses working out on a track surrounded by snow marked Roosevelt Raceway's pre-opening luncheon today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Supreme Court has now imposed financial liabilities on those hacks -already burdened with the guilt of producing shoddy imitations -- who parody famous works of literature. But a chance rereading of "Lochinvar" created an irresistible urge which materialized in the following (and anyhow the statute of limitations has run out for Sir Walter Scott):
Seatrain Lines, Inc., pioneer in transporting of loaded railroad cars by sea, will soon branch out to include loaded trucks.
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 24 (AP) -- A proposal to end the twenty-four-day strike against the Waterman Steamship Corporation here was submitted to both sides today by Gov. Luis Munoz Marin.
WASHINGTON, March 24--An immediate tax cut of $6,000,000,000 to $8,000,000,000 was urged today by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.
The appointment of the Rev. Dr. Gardner C. Taylor of Brooklyn as a member of the Board of Education was announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
Orange concentrate will continue to be scarce for the rest of 1958. This means higher prices for a product that probably will not be as sweet as that available in previous years.
ROME, March 24 -- Eighty-six parties officially started campaigning today for the general elections.
Two rounds, the ninth and tenth, in the international chess masters tournament at Mar del Plata, were played over the week-end, according to reports received yesterday through Argentine news sources.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -Wheat, corn and rye were under increasing pressure near the close on the Board of Trade here today and all finished with losses of about a cent or more a bushel.
Nine persons were injured yesterday when a fuel pump exploded in an oil distribution depot in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. The blast ignited a three-alarm fire.
The Citizens Union came out in opposition yesterday to 1958 recommendations of the Tweed Commission on the ground that they give only the "illusion" of court reform.

MONTREAL, March 24 (AP) -Dickie Moore of the Montreal Canadiens has won the National Hockey League scoring crown for the first time, even though he played the last five weeks of the season with a cast on his left wrist.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 24 -- The United States has given up an attempt to have United Nations organs meet on the disarmament question before late April.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -The nearness of Passover will bar graveside eulogies tomorrow for Mike Todd.

Total assets of Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association topped the half-billion-dollar mark last year, according to the 1957 annual report. Total assets of $535,452,013 compared with $493,986,334 in 1956. Insurance premiums of $3,755,292 compared with $3,193,135 a year earlier, while premiums for annuities totaled $35,635,471, against $32,170,673 in 1956. Total income of $63,761,864 compared with $56,814,083 a year earlier.
ALBANY, March 24 -- Senate Republicans forced through tonight their version of a state crime commission. The vote was 37 to 21. They rejected an offer from Governor Harriman to consider a compromise.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- The Navy announced formation of a new-type of anti-submarine task force today and named one of its most famous aviators, Rear Admiral John S. Thach, to command it.
Broadway's version of the Robinson-Basilio fight as telecast last night in Loew's State was no pictorial masterpiece, but seemed to satisfy the sellout-and-standee audience.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Senate rackets committee labeled James R. Hoffa today the boss of a "hoodlum empire" surrounded by men who used union funds for the care and feeding of idle thugs.
New York State borrowed $49,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of highways and mental health institutions and the elimination of railroad grade crossings.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Representative Charles O. Porter, Democrat of Oregon, said today he had suggested to Senator Styles Bridges that he apologize to the Army and personally compensate members of the Army band for their services at a gathering last week.
A Brooklyn judge acquitted yesterday five construction company officials of second-degree manslaughter charges growing out of the death of six children in a Williamsburg cave-in.

American Airlines yesterday became the second major air carrier to sign a contract with the flight engineer union insuring the use of flight engineers on future jet airliners even though they do not have pilot training.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Senators John F. Kennedy and John Sherman Cooper urged Congress today to underwrite the success of India's imperiled Five-Year Plan.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 25 -- President-elect Mario Echandi and several members of his future Cabinet left by air today on an official visit to the United States.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 25 -- The Vanderbilt Cup Championship reached the semi-final round here tonight at the Traymore Hotel. Only three contract-bridge teams remained in contention for the team-of-four national championship.

Three private lenders and the International Finance Corporation agreed yesterday to lend $6,400,000 to help finance the development of a copper mine and smelter in northern Chile. The corporation is the private lending affiliate of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank).
ALBANY, March 25 (UP) -- Skiing conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 25 -- The Government declared today that it would not join either of the Arab unions or any other group that would limit its "independence, sovereignty and freedom."
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson tonight pulled another "first" in boxing annals after regaining the middleweight title when he barred the press from his dressing room.
Artists have plucked out the lighter moments of American history for the playful decorations for the annual masque ball of Artists Equity Association on Friday night.

Ten boys, ranging in age from 13 to 18 years, were ordered arrested last night in the beating of a parochial school teacher Monday in Crotona Park, the Bronx. The police said that the boys had admitted attacking the teacher while they were "pepped up" with wine.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points (15 cents a bale) up to 5 points (25 cents a bale) off yesterday.
ALBANY, March 25 -- A second attempt to pass a bill setting residency requirements for relief recipients was beaten in the Assembly today by an even larger margin than before.

Swiss officials in this city will be guests of honor at an "Evening in Switzerland," on Friday in the student lounge of the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn. The event will comprise a dance, entertainment and the showing of a color film, "Souvenir."

Free parking for Paramount Theatre patrons will be provided beginning on April 3 as part of the Paramount's "new look." Patrons will be invited to park their cars at the Loubell Parking Lot, 245 West Forty-first Street. Parking lot tickets will be validated by the theatre cashier at the time of the admission purchase.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The House Antitrust subcommittee began a long-planned investigation today of the 1956 consent decree settling a Government antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

The Southern Railway Company reported yesterday a net income of $4,552,341, or 62 cents a common share, for the first two months of this year. For the similar period of last year, net income was $5,307,676, or 74 cents a share.
SAN PEDRO, Calif., March 25 -- Four pacifists sailed today in a thirty-foot ketch for the South Pacific to stage a protest demonstration against the forth-coming atomic tests.

A five-story building containing ten apartments and two stores at 171 East Seventy-seventh Street has been purchased for investment by the East 77 Realty Corporation. Title was insured with the Guaranteed Title and Mortgage Company.
MONTREAL, March 20 -- Lester B. Pearson's Liberal party has much to lose and little to gain in Montreal.
Once upon a time, last March 3, to be exact, a young carrier pigeon named Snapper who lived in a coop over a garage in Linden, N. J., decided that the time had come to take a wife.
Nearly everyone knows about the American Red Cross and what it does for people in great disasters. Last year, for example, it helped thousands of refugees from Hungary.
RUMSON, N. J., March 25 -- The Rumson Country Club will be the setting for a dessert, card party and fashion show April 8 to aid Monmouth Memorial Hospital, Long Branch.
The Eastman Kodak Company has announced a "tremendously increased" spring-summer advertising program.

The maintenance of a high level of United States foreign trade in 1958 was forecast yesterday at opening sessions of the forty-first annual convention of the Export Managers Club of New York. The two-day meeting is being held at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

The Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation, maker of men's shirts, expects first six months' sales and earnings this year to equal or exceed those of 1957, Seymour J. Phillips, president, told a meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts here yesterday.
LONDON, March 25 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan offered today to share defense secrets with Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Labor Opposition, to give a bipartisan basis to Britain's defense policy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 25 -- The Russians charged today that the United States, not the Soviet Union, had distorted the facts regarding the discussions about a resumption of disarmament negotiations.

PARIS, March 25 -- United States and British diplomats probed cautiously today for a basis for settlement of France's dispute with Tunisia without unsettling the delicate political situations in both countries.

Most visitors to the Fort Greene Houses in Brooklyn prefer to walk up three or four flights instead of taking the elevator. They choose the steep, cold staircases rather than face the stench of stale urine that pervades the elevators. Nowhere this side of Moscow are you likely to find public housing so closely duplicating the squalor it was designed to supplant.
MIAMI, March 25 (AP) -- Braniff International Airways listed the persons aboard its airliner that crashed here early today as follows:
Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education, said yesterday that the city should have twenty or twenty-five special schools for children with behavior problems.
Electronics experts will have a lot of reading to do if they want to know everything that is going on at the Institute of Radio Engineers convention.
CHICAGO, March 25 -- The round-by-round description of tonight's middleweight championship bout between Ray Robsinson and Carmen Basilio (opinions as to round winner are those of Joseph C. Nichols) :
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Courageous Carmen Basilio sat on a dressing-room table tonight and spoke of a return bout against Sugar Ray Robinson.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Eisenhower Administration has agreed on a new "voluntary" program for the further restriction of oil imports.

MOSCOW, March 25 -- Deputy Premier Anastas I. Mikoyan expressed doubt tonight that Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, could convince the Soviet Union to rejoin the disarmament negotiations in the United Nations.
Johns Hopkins University, which went through its 1957 schedule without a defeat to capture the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association title, is a solid choice to retain its crown.

Raids on three Harlem apartments yesterday were believed by police to have broken up a policy ring with an average daily take of nearly $300,000. Thirteen men were arrested. Fifteen shopping bags holding thousands of policy slips were also seized.

The work of the junior committee of the Catholic Big Sisters will be furthered with the proceeds of their annual post-Easter subscription tea dance. The fete, known as the Afternoon Assembly, will take place in the Trianon Room of the Sheraton-East, formerly the Ambassador, on April 25.
LONDON, Mach 25 (AP) -- The space dog, Laika, panted furiously and her heart pounded as she rode a rocket out into space in the second Soviet satellite.
The National Maritime Union has announced that it will build a new national headquarters building on the west side of Seventh Avenue between Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Howard Stores Corporation of Brooklyn, a nation-wide clothing chain, was accused by the Federal Trade Commission of making deceptive pricing claims for garments sold at its retail outlets.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Food and Drug Administration issued standards for ice cream today. They require 10 per cent milk fat and limit the content of air and water. The standards also cover egg ice creams sold as frozen custard, French ice cream or French custard ice cream; ice milk, which has been sold as soft ice cream; fruit sherbets and water ices.

Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman challenged yesterday the Democratic party's wisdom in allowing Senator Lyndon B. Johnson and Representative Sam Rayburn to shape the party's issues for the 1960 Presidential campaign.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Students of railroad economics had their chance today to tell Senate investigators how the carriers' "precarious" condition could be eased.

TAMPA, Fla., March 25 -- Bilko of the Redlegs isn't even distantly related to the Bilko of television fame. In fact, Steve Bilko, the ballplayer, is as big as Sgt. Ernest Bilko and Phil Silvers combined. His size has been bedeviling him since he first shoehorned himself into a uniform and he's still somewhat sensitive on the subject.

Alexander Menditto, the 17-year-old Brooklyn youth who had been taken for a gang-style ride, died last night of his injuries. He had been beaten badly, shot and thrown out of a car early on the morning of March 16.

Carbon monoxide fumes seeping from a basement oven through a two-story bakery and residence caused the death of a Queens baker and his wife early yesterday. Five other persons, including three policemen, also were overcome.
An increase in the economic recession will undoubtedly bring about greater Federal intervention in local affairs, public administrators were told here today.
ALBANY, March 25 -- The Legislature voted today to make the finances of New York City subject to review by the State Controller.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- The commandant of the Marine Corps has told Congress that cuts in Marine strength have hurt the organization's fighting ability.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- A former Kohler employe swore today that two officials of the Wisconsin plumbing company shot him during a 1934 strike.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The House approved overwhelmingly today a bill designed to add $668,397,000 a year to the pay of military men. The vote was 366 to 22.
AS a novelist, Francois Mauriac feels that the theatre is an alien medium.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 25 -- Automation in the packaging industry has resulted in additional employment, rather than lay-offs, officials of the packaging Machinery Manufacturing Institute said today.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 25 -- The Rev. Oral Roberts, next to the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham the widest-known evangelist in the country, opened six-day crusade for souls here tonight.
ALBANY, March 25 -- The Splake became an officially recognized member of New York's game fish family today with Governor Hariman's approval of a bill sent him by the Legislature.

MIAMI, March 25 (UP) -- Survivors of today's crash of a Braniff Airways DC-7 said that all aboard might have been killed had not a flaming wing section ripped loose from the plane and had not Everglades marshes helped absorb the shock of the impact.
BARCELONA, Spain, March 25 (Reuters) -- The Governor of Barcelona took swift action today to block a general strike called by anti-Government agitators.

Earnings of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company in the four months ended Feb. 28 declined sharply below the levels of the corresponding period last year, David L. Luke, president, reported at the annual meeting here yesterday.

A Kings County grand jury investigating lawlessness in Brooklyn public schools has abandoned temporarily any plan to invite or subpoena Mayor Wagner, District Attorney Edward S. Silver said yesterday.
Louis Alvarez, 17-year-old former assistant president of the Egyptian Dragons gang, said yesterday he did not remember even seeing Michael Farmer the night young Farmer was slain.

CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- The market for butcher hogs was strong to 35 cents higher today with more No. 1 grade among the offerings and selling up to $23, the highest top since Aug. 2, when it was at the same figure.

The Home Office Employes Union, Local H-63 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes, announced yesterday that it had broken off contract negotiations with the major motion picture producers here.

Despite repeated warnings in the pre-sputnik era and despite the national focus in the post-sputnik era, the Defense Department, and particularly the Department of the Army, has failed miserably to take advantage of a "built-in" situation.
John Brady yesterday was elected captain of Fordham's basketball team for the 1958-59 season. The Rams also named Bill McCadney as the team's most valuable player.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Senate Republicans today voted, 17 -- 14, to urge President Eisenhower to sign the one-year farm price-support freeze now on his desk.
Mayor Wagner and the City Council declared themselves yesterday against a "mystery bill" to speed the eviction of commercial tenants from the controversial Lincoln Square redevelopment site.
PARIS, March 25 -- The Theatre National Populaire of Paris will make its first American visit in October.

CAIRO, March 25 -- In his only published book, a self-revealing brochure entitled "Egypt's Liberation,'' Gamal Abdel Nasser observes: "The pages of history are full of heroes who created for themselves roles of glorious valor which they played at decisive moments.
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Mike Todd, film producer, was buried here today.

IN the spring some men's fancies turn to frankfurter wagons -- to neo-classic hotdog carts of chrome and stainless steel that kick sun glare back into the sun's eyes. Itinerant peddlers start polishing their equipment when the robins coast the air slopes into Central Park.
PARIS, March 25 -- Christian Pineau was reported today to be in favor of the demilitarization and neutralization of part of Central Europe.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 25 -- Viewed from any angle the Philadelphia Phillies do not look too prepossessing this spring. Even their manager, Mayo Smith, will not dispute this too vigorously.

Twenty-one singers will make debuts with the New York City Opera Company during its spring season of American opera, it was announced yesterday by Julius Rudel, general director of the company. The season will open April 3 and continue through May 4.
ALBANY, March 25 -- The Assembly rejected two revised Senate-approved versions of the Tweed court reform plan today.
BONN, Germany, March 25 -- The Bundestag approved the Government's nuclear armament policy tonight after a four-day debate marred by violent scenes.
LATE one afternoon outside the Harlem Boys Club at Stephen Foster Houses a teenager climbed into the steel bars of a playground "jungle."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 -- The American Federation of Musicians has informed Hollywood Local 47 that it has won support from the International Federation of Musicians with a pledge not to assist movie companies in attempting to make music scores for films in Europe.

AS another erstwhile candidate for Mayor of our city, I want to join my friend Newbold Morris in urging the enactment of a new Proportional Representation voting law for the election of City Councilmen.

SAINT - QUENTIN, France, March 25 (AP) -- A 36-year-old soldier who fled the United States Army in 1944 to live with a French woman will be tried by United States military authorities on wartime desertion charges.
BONN, Germany, March 25 -- Britain is to be brought into the arms-development program of the Western Allied powers on the Continent.
HOLLYWOOD, March 25 (AP) -- To the traditional chant of a Jewish cantor and the organ strains of "Around the World in Eighty Days," the movie world today mourned the passing of Mr. Todd.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25 (UP) -- Don Drysdale and Clem Labine pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to an 8-0 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals in an exhibition baseball game today. It was the second straight shutout defeat for St. Louis.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi emeritus of Temple Emanu-El, is 80 years old today. He looks ten years younger, hustles around the country as if he were twenty years younger and is full of plans.

The Swedish Chamber of Commerce of the U. S. A. elected as its new president yesterday G. Hilmer Lundbeck, resident director of the Swedish American Line, New York. He succeeds Nils A. Sterner, who presided at the annual luncheon in the Biltmore Hotel.

Potato futures opened lower yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but the active near-by months recovered to close the 30-point limit above Monday's settlement price. One point equals one hundredth of a cent a pound.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 25 (AP) -- Brazil's policy of buying its surplus coffee in an effort to maintain world prices is under Congressional fire.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor says an indication of Soviet wealth in military equipment was to be found in the fact that Russia now is giving some of its best war goods to its European satellites.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Secretary of State Dulles cut through the maze of diplomatic ambiguities today and made the Russians a clear and simple offer.
LOS ANGELES, March 25 (UP) -- The City Council today voted to ask for a Congressional investigation into the Los Angeles Dodgers' contract with the city for a new baseball park.
CHICAGO, March 25 -- Sugar Ray Robinson beat Carmen Basilio in a fifteen-round bout at the Chicago Stadium tonight to become the middleweight champion of the world for the fifth time.

The Soviets have now spelled out their real conditions for a summit meeting. Secretary Dulles has promptly rejected these conditions as a Soviet attempt to dictate, among other things, the agenda of the meeting. Actually, the Soviets attempt to do much more than that.

The Rev. Dr. John T. Peters was elected board chairman yesterday for Religion in American Life, Inc. The nonsectarian movement has since 1949 been emphasizing the importance of religion in personal and community living.
