For the second time in a month a last-minute compromise has avoided a proxy fight for control of the Penn-Texas Corporation. The battle has been threatened off and on by a group of dissident directors since last August.
General but small gains for the oils ran against the major downward trend in yesterday's stock market.

Acrimony marked the opening of the Stanley Cup hockey semi-final play-offs at Madison Square Garden last night as the New York Rangers defeated the Boston Bruins, 5 -- 3. An overflow crowd of 15,925 saw the Broadway Blues take the first game in the four-of-seven series.

Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of the Economy of West Germany, who is paying a visit to this country, emerged from a White House conference this week to offer the comforting observation that the present United States recession would not be prolonged and that it would not have any serious repercussions on the national economies of Europe.
TUNIS, March 25 (AP) -- A quiet but persistent Communist campaign to infiltrate Tunisia is being gradually stepped up.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The American metals mining industry was described today as a victim of knockout blows delivered by the Federal Government and Congress.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 25 (UP) -- Brazil, which withdrew from the 1953 world sugar pact, has decided to send a delegation to the International Sugar Conference to be held at Geneva in September, it was announced today.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 25 (UP) Brooks Robinson drove in four runs with two homers for an 8-5 exhibition victory by the Baltimore Orioles over the Cleveland Indians today.
ALBANY, March 25 -- The Senate tonight unanimously approved a bill requiring the Long Island Rail Road to get Public Service Commission approval before raising rates in the future.

LONDON, March 25 (AP) -- Cleveland Williams, a heavyweight from Houston, tonight won by disqualification in the fourth round from Dick Richardson, a Welshman, at Empress Hall. Referee Frank Wilson stopped the fight after warning Richardson several times for "persistent butting."
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Following is the text of the State Department's transcript of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today:
Harve Hearl is a gourmet, an amateur chef and a cookbook author. These are good qualifications for his main job, which is selling frozen food packaging for the Continental Can Company.

CAMDEN, N. J., March 25 -- Preliminary plans for a proposed international jet aircraft terminal in Burlington County were made public here today. The $200,000,000 project would involve between 16,000 and 17,000 acres of the 22,216-acre Lebanon State Forest in Pemberton Township between Routes 70 and 72.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Commerce Department made public today an analysis indicating that the decline in plant and equipment spending this year could have an even more depressing effect on the economy than earlier figures had showed.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 25 (UP) -- The defending champion, Leon R. Sikes Sr. of West Palm Beach, Fla., scored a first-round 4-and-3 victory over P. C. Jarboe of Elizabethtown, N. J., in the American seniors golf tournament today.
UNDERCOVER agents at Gimbels report that no body but no body can wear the relaxed silhouette without a firm foundation.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Army, in a departure from one of its basic policies, assigned to a private contractor today the task of developing, testing and producing a new major weapon.

DETROIT, March 25 -- The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers gave assurances today that they would seek a contract settlement this year that would be good for the country, as well as their private interests.

LONDON, March 25 (UP) -- The Moscow radio omitted the name of Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin from a broadcast list of Soviet officials who entertained Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold at a Kremlin dinner this evening.

NORTH KEY LARGO, Fla., March 25 -- There still are fishing places in this part of the world, and some of them fairly accessible, that are relatively unknown to the forlorn Yankee. The forlorn Yankee is any out-of-stater, who must pay $3.50 for a nonresident fishing license good for only fourteen days.

HARTFORD, March 25 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff announced the appointment tonight of Dr. Wilfred Bloomberg of Atlanta as State Mental Health Commissioner, effective Sept. 1. He succeeds Dr. John J. Blasko, who resigned last August.

Despite the hesitancy in many areas, of the economy, the Jewel Tea Company, Inc., is going forward with its plans for a record growth program, Franklin J. Lunding, chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
Through an inadvertence, a section was left out of the text of a Soviet aide-memoire to the United States that was published in The New York Times yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 25 (AP) -- Government commandos pushed within eighty-seven miles of Padang, rebel nerve center, and tightened their economic noose on rebellious Central Sumatra, it was announced today.

Three machines that ordinarily form and wind nylon or rayon tire cord have been combined, in effect, into one machine invented by R. J. Clarkson, a textile development engineer of the United States Rubber Company.
Twice within a week The Times printed letters which plumped in favor of smaller cars. As a satisfied owner of a "larger" car I'd like to comment on the subject.

The South Shore Child Guidance Association, which functions under the direction of the Nassau County Mental Health Board, will begin its 1958 fundraising campaign with a dinner dance on Friday night at Guy Lombardo's Restaurant in Freeport, L. I.
MILFORD HAVEN, Wales, March 25 -- A dream that has lasted more than 150 years may yet become a reality for this quiet town of 12,000 inhabitants in southwest Wales.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 25 (AP) -- Dale Long blasted three of six Chicago home runs as the Cubs belted the San Francisco Giants, 15 -- 4, in an exhibition game today.
HAVANA, March 25 -- The police are seeking the forty-four members of the board of governors of the Cuban Bar Association.

There shouldn't be any doubt, after last Saturday's twelve-hour sports car championship race at Sebring, Fla., that the 5.2-mile airbase course provides one of the world's toughest tests of men and machines.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to approve Federal payments to jobless workers during an extended period of state-operated unemployment compensation.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The chief physician of a union welfare fund accused organized medicine today of failure to police its ranks while refusing to permit anybody else to judge it.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 25 -- With the departure of Maj. Gen. Mercer C. Walter from Belgrade this week, the United States program to equip and train Yugoslav armed forces has been liquidated.

MONTREAL, March 25 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, paced by Phil Goyette's three goals and Maurice (Rocket) Richard's two early goals, overwhelmed the Detroit Red Wings, 8 -- 1, to win the opener of their Stanley Cup semi-final play-off series tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the United States would lose its shirt if it accepted Soviet terms for a heads-of-government meeting.
"Agencies had a list of newspapers and the head man knew how much each publisher would let his space rates be cut. The better your bargaining ability, the more ad clients you had."
PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, B. W. I., March 25 -- The British West Indies federated islands went to the polls today to choose members for the new Federation House of Representatives.
The largest total realized in the liquidation of a single collection was reached yesterday at the sale of the Alfred H. Caspary stamp collection.

TOKYO, March 25 (Reuters) -- The Japanese Ministry of Trade announced today it would lift the ban on exports of Japanese woolen knitted gloves and sweaters to the United States and Canada, effective tomorrow.

LONDON, March 25 -- Prices declined on a wide front in the stock market today. The end of the fortnightly bookkeeping account and some fears of labor strife accounted for the contraction of trading volume and the light selling pressure.

Ellis H. Wilner, president of the Textile Fabrics Association, last night declared that production cut-backs made late last year by cotton textile manufacturers were not enough to keep prices from declining further. He spoke at the groups' annual meeting in the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 25 -- Queen Elizabeth II of Britain and her husband, Prince Philip, arrived this morning for the first official call paid on the Netherlands by a reigning British monarch.

CLOVELLY, England, March 25 -- Conservative party posters ornament the windows of cottages along the steep street that leads to the sea, but the by-election Thursday is a long way and a long time from Clovelly, in Devonshire.
Macy's, the world's largest department store is revising its revolving credit plan, called Cash-Time, making it more like the conventional charge account with a small service charge.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- West Germany recognizes its responsibility toward underdeveloped nations but does not plan to help them by direct Government loans, Dr. Ludwig Erhard, Minister of the Economy, said today.

The first of a two-volume definitive biography of Sir Winston Churchill by Lewis Broad is planned for fall publication by Hawthorn Books. Mr. Broad, author of "Winston Churchill" and "The Adventures of Sir Winston," has based his new work on the two earlier books and new material that has become available through the publication of the reminiscences of military and political leaders since 1956.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- All-American Elgin Baylor of Seattle said today he wanted to play professional basketball and it appeared that he would be drafted by the New York Knickerbockers.

THREE Old World classics -- chocolate souffle, Bishop's bread and Viennese sweet biscuits -- ordinarily demand much time, patience and skill in the making. But they can be concocted speedily and with a modicum of effort.
Seventeen men and a woman were convicted yesterday by a Federal Court jury of being members of a $20,000,000-a-year international narcotics ring. The trial began Feb. 3.
THE label of Claire McCardell will continue and so will the credo that governed her timeless, superbly functional clothes.

Lise Schneider, a 21-year-old pianist from Mount Kisco, N. Y., made her debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. She played a taxing program, which included the Bach Partita No. 4 in D, Schumann's "Kreisleriana," the Ravel Sonatine and the Fourth Prokofieff Sonata.

MEXICO CITY, March 25 (UP) -- Four of the seven leading Latin-American coffee-producing nations announced today the suspension of all coffee exports for an indefinite period in a move aimed at stabilizing prices.

If the legislators at Albany have more respect for the lobbyists of the billboard industry than they have for the beauty of the Empire State and the safety of its citizens they will adjourn without acting on the billboard-control bill now bottled up in committees of both houses.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- Congress approved today a $2,861,008,793 supplemental appropriations bill carrying $250,000,000 to handle an unexpected flood of applications to join the soil bank acreage reserve program.

THE comprehensive exhibition of paintings and drawings by Georges Seurat, which opens to the public today at the Museum of Modern Art, is one of the most interesting and best-installed shows devoted to the work of a single artist that the museum has ever put on.

Yet even the keenest advocate of talks with the Soviets cannot safely overlook certain basic aspects of the present international situation. The aims of Moscow are the withdrawal of American forces and liquidation of all foreign bases; the disruption of NATO; Communist domination of the entire world.

A good many people stayed home from work that day when spring came in like a roaring lion. For one thing, it was a Friday, an occasion which always encourages groping around for a reasonable excuse to stay home.

Blood will be given today at Manhattan College, Riverdale, the Bronx, to the Red Cross blood program. A bloodmobile also will visit the armory at 321 Manor Road, West Brighton, S. I., for a community donation.
Events tonight: "The Marriage of Figaro," Metropolitan Opera, and Verdi's "Macbeth" in concert form, Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman conducting, Carnegie Hall, both at 8 o'clock.

ALTHOUGH winter seems to be overstaying its welcome spring, according to the calendar, is here. And now is the time to refurbish the bedroom. To hasten spring, here are some ideas for transforming sleeping quarters into a light and airy garden.

CAIRO, March 25 -- Crown Prince Faisal of Saudi Arabia was reported today to have barred King Saud's five foreign advisers from all future Cabinet meetings. This was reported to be the first action taken by the Prince after his brother, the King, handed him sweeping administrative power yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The senior member of the Federal Communications Commission testified today that the broadcasting industry had paid some of his hotel bills and had put color television sets in his home.
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- In the absence of any strong influences either way, grain futures prices moved along within a steady to firm range on the Board of Trade here today.
MOSCOW, March 25 -- The leading Soviet cultural newspaper joined today in the Soviet press campaign warning Jews in the country against migration to Israel.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Some expensive details were added today to the inflationary story of the Legislature's cost of living. Today's chapter: legislative buying habits, or politicians don't get it for you wholesale.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A proxy contest for one seat on the Pennsylvania Railroad's nineteen-man board of directors took on a new aspect today.
The Wagner Administration moved yesterday to tighten the fire laws to prevent fires like that of March 19 at 623 Broadway in which twenty-four lives were lost.

DETROIT, March 25 (AP) -- The St. Louis Hawks turned in a blazing first half, coasted the rest of the way and gained a 145-101 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight. The triumph put the Hawks ahead, three games to one, in the Western Division finals of the National Basketball Association play-offs.
LOS ANGELES, March 25 (UP) -- The Australian All-Star rugby team opened its four-game California tour today with a 36-9 victory over the University of California at Los Angeles.

Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., is planning to finance the passenger ships Brasil and Argentina, now under construction, by a public issue of $24,000,000 of mortgage bonds secured by Federal mortgage insurance.
TRENTON, March 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner assailed vehemently today business and industrial executives who have criticized his tax program.

"Dialogues of the Carmelites" is in the process of being tied up by the successful producing team of Leigh Connell, Theodore Mann and Jose Quintero. Mr. Mann acknowledged that his firm was enthusiastic about the script, which is heir to quite a career. Terms, however, have not been agreed upon yet, according to Mr. Mann.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- President Eisenhower today urged "eternal vigilance" by industrial leaders and "each person working in national industry" to prevent accidental injuries.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress today on unemployment benefits:

RYE, N. Y., March 25 -- Committee chairmen of Family Service of Westchester, Inc., met recently at the home of the board president, Mrs. Richard W. Dammann, to discuss details of their forthcoming benefit. The organization has reserved 1,500 seats for the World Championship Tennis Matches, which will be played at the Westchester County Center in White Plains on the evening of April 8.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which already has five television program vice presidents, will add another on Monday. The new member of the expanding echelon is Michael H. Dann, who resigned from the National Broadcasting Company last October to become president of Henry Jaffe Enterprises.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- An atomic scientist today it was easier to get information on radioactive fall-out from Japan than from the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

In Canada, there is confidence that the decline in capital expenditures by business can be offset. The Bank of Montreal believes that the increasing number of housing starts, plus outlays for university facilities hospital and public works this year "should more than offset the adverse effect on construction * * * from the decline expected to occur in investment by industrial and other business firms."
TRENTON, March 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed today a bill that appropriates $10,000 to finance a legislative inquiry into the taxation of New Jersey residents by adjoining states.

A plot of land fronting on Bronx Park East and Waring and Barker Avenues, in the Bronx, has been purchased by a building company headed by Jack Goodstein for improvement with a six-story building containing apartments with two to six rooms.

WHITE PLAINS, March 25 -- Westchester park officials reported endorsements by conservationists today of the county's plan to develop a sportsmen's center on George's Island, a 137-acre peninsula projecting into the Hudson River at Crugers.

Combustion Engineering, Inc., maker of steam generating equipment, nuclear reactors and other products, last year attained the highest sales and the second largest earnings in its forty-seven-year history.

Vassily Smyslov, defending his world chess title in a return match with Mikhail Botvinnik in Moscow, overlooked an opportunity to win a pawn in their eighth game yesterday, according to a Soviet report. Play was adjourned after forty moves had been recorded, with the rivals on equal terms.
21 -- Despite reports of Government troop convoys off the west coast of Sumatra, civilians and military men have shown no evidence of panic. They seem resigned to the fall of Padang.
The State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday ordered the removal of an insurgent group that had held control of the deck officers' union local here for two weeks.
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), March 25 (AP) -- Premier David Ben-Gurion said today that there could be peace between Israel and the Arabs if foreign powers would guarantee Israel's borders.

A syndicate of savings banks here has made a first mortgage loan of $6,500,000 on the Astor Hotel in Times Square. The mortgage was the largest taken so far under a law passed in 1956 that permits savings banks to join together in financing operations too large to be undertaken by a single institution.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 25 (UP) -- The Kansas City Athletics jumped on Tom Morgan for four runs in the eighth inning today and defeated the Detroit Tigers, 8 to 6.
Mayor Wagner served notice on the City Council and his top aides yesterday that every instrument at his disposal would be used to frustrate unethical actions by city officials.

The dairy farmer's dream, green grass the year 'round, has become a reality. That's good news for farmers with herds of twenty to sixty head and able to purchase a new structure described here yesterday by the Buckeye Corporation of Springfield, Ohio.
ALBANY, March 26 -- The Republican State Chairman declared tonight that the 1958 legislative session had demonstrated the necessity of electing a Republican Governor next fall.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 26 -- About 6,000,000 Dutch voters went to the polls today and registered mild dissatisfaction with their Socialist-dominated coalition Government.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -Scientists said today that the Army's Explorer III satellite would be a scientific success, even if its lifetime in space was short.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 26 (AP) -- Rosewood passed Pink Velvet in the final stride for a nose victory in the $29,150 Suwannee River Handicap at Gulf-stream Park today.
NEWTON, Iowa, March 26 (AP) -- Sales and earnings of the Maytag Company have experienced no slump so far in the first quarter of 1958, stock-holders were told yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Following are texts of President Eisenhower's statement and of the report, Introduction to Outer Space, prepared by his Science Advisory Committee:
BONN, Germany, March 26 -Plans went ahead today to prevent the Government from equipping the West German forces with nuclear weapons if the Atlantic alliance requests the step.

The New York Teachers Guild has scheduled a demonstration today at 4 P. M. outside City Hall to protest "the failure of Mayor Wagner to discuss revision of the present New York City teacher salary schedule." The guild said that "several thousand teachers" were expected.
ONCE again the Delacorte Gallery, 822 Madison Avenue, offers New Yorkers an opportunity to see the strange and compelling creations of the ancient Copts.
THE combined efforts of thirty-five leading ladies could not stop fashion from walking off with the show last night during the telecast of the Academy Award presentations.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation had the highest sales in its history last year and its earnings rose 8 per cent above those for 1956.

The Fire Department ordered three connected loft buildings in downtown Manhattan closed yesterday for alleged violation of fire regulations. The buildings are three blocks north of the loft building at 623 Broadway where twenty-four persons lost their lives in a fire last week.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- A House committee disclosed testimony today indicating that an Indiana contractor building a highway with foreign aid funds sold equipment to himself for more than it cost him years earlier.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Herbert V. Kohler denied today improper or illegal activities by his company during the four-year strike against it. He claimed victory in the fight.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) -- The House on a party-line vote approved today an appropriation of $177,255,000 to pay outright for sixty-six new multiple-purpose buildings previously approved for construction under lease-purchase, a sort of installment plan.

HERE'S a paradox. If you want to test the dramatic power of an operatic score, put it on in concert form. Performed in this way at Carnegie Hall last night, Verdi's "Macbeth" generated an intensity and a compassion that were no disgrace to the Shakespearean original.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -House investigators heard today that former Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. first suggested to American Telephone and Telegraph Company officials that a Government antitrust suit might be settled by a consent decree.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- A new helmet for Little League baseball players will be recommended tomorrow to 300 delegates from all over the world at the third annual Little League Congress in the Morrison Hotel.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26 -- New independent production companies continue to sprout in Hollywood like field mushrooms after a rain.

BUKITTINGGI, Indonesia, March 26 (AP) -- Indonesian Army forces pushed closer to this rebel capital today. They captured a small town about sixty miles east of here on the other side of rugged mountains.
A new precious-metals plant to help supply increasing needs of electronics and guided missiles manufacturers on the West Coast was opened yesterday at El Monte, Calif., by Handy Harriman.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, March 26 (Reuters) -- Abdullah Khalil, recently re-elected Premier of the Sudan, retains the Defense Ministry in a new Sudanese coalition Government announced today.

A Brooklyn boy has built a 2,000,000-volt atom smasher in his mother's living room. He is Mel Steinberg, a tall, slender, quiet-spoken high-school senior. Just turned 16 years old, he is an amateur astronomer who wants to be a nuclear physicist. His other hobbies areice hockey, baseball and deep-sea fishing.
NEW DELHI, India, March 26 -- The Communist Government of the South Indian state of Kerala has begun to attract funds from major Indian industrialists.
THE profusion of different textiles now offered in clothing and home furnishings was said this week to dissuade consumers from purchasing them.

Lawyers for the executors of Serge Rubinstein's estate filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday an intermediate accounting of their administration of the affairs of the slain speculator. The report showed assets of $1,281,668.68.

May I commend to the attention of your readers the First Report of the British Council on Prices, Productivity and Incomes. The council was appointed in August, 1957, "to keep under review changes in prices, productivity and the level of incomes (including wages, salaries and profits) and to report thereon from time to time."

DULUTH, Minn., March 26 (AP) -- A conference is planned next month on the possibility of the United States Steel Corporation and its Oliver Iron Mining division to discuss constructing a new taconite plant in northern Minnesota.

TOKYO, March 26 -- Japanese scientists reported today that they had discovered uranium in the Antarctic near the Japanese base on the Prince Harald Coast. Samples of the ore are being brought to Tokyo on the expedition's ship, the icebreaker Soya, for analysis.

MOSCOW, March 26 -- After three days of discussions with Soviet leaders, Dag Hammarskjold reaffirmed today his belief that disamament talks by heads of government would be no substitute for negotiations in the United Nations.
The Greenwich Mews Theatre, community playhouse, has reached an agreement under which it will receive the financial support of a nontheatrical labor union.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- For the first time, a nominee for a Federal judgeship was asked today to swear that he would not participate in any decision designed to alter the meaning of the Constitution or of any law passed by Congress and adopted under the Constitution.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Gen. Lauris Norstad told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that Mutual Security aid has greatly strengthened the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and would bring it to full organizational strength in the next two to three years.

Revenues of the Hilton Hotels Corporation last year exceeded $200,000,000 for the first time, but net earnings declined from the record attained in 1956, Conrad N. Hilton, president, reported to stockholders.
Dorothy Kirsten of the Metropolitan Opera will star on four television programs to be presented this summer by the "Chevy Show" over the National Broadcasting Company network.

FORT SALONGA, L. I., March 26 -- A picturesque 179-acre estate of woodland, terminating in a high bluff towering above a half-mile of sandy beach, has been added to Sunken Meadow State Park on Long Island Sound.
Paul C. Harper Jr. has been appointed executive vice president of Needham, Louis Brophy, Inc., in one of a series of executive changes at the Chicago agency.
The thrift shop committee of the Children's Health Service will sponsor its annual bundle bridge and tea party on May 13 at the National Society of Colonial Dames.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Eisenhower intimated today that he might be willing to negotiate a "reliable" agreement for a ban on nuclear tests without insisting on a concurrent suspension of nuclear production for weapons.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 26 -- The Bergen County Board of Freeholders hired a New York engineering concern today to help organize a traffic engineering staff. The move was forced by the growth of the county since World War II and the consequent increase in automobile traffic.
LOS ANGELES, March 26 (UPI) -- The City Council today approved a resolution asking the State Legislature to investigate all aspects of negotiations between the city and the Los Angeles Dodgers.
BIDEFORD, England, March 26 -- The queerest aspect of the confused and, at times, hilarious by-election in the Torrington constituency in Devonshire is the continued obscurity of Leonard Lamb.

TORONTO, March 26 (AP) -- The Toronto Star, Canada's largest newspaper, was sold today for $25,555,021 to the Hawthorne Publishing Company of Toronto. The price was reported here to be the highest ever paid for a newspaper property.

Reorganization of the city's Bureau of Real Estate, now under investigation, will be completed in June, James Felt said yesterday. Mr. Felt was named March 14 as acting director and told by Mayor Wagner to make the bureau "absolutely foolproof."

RUMBAI, Indonesia, March 25 -- A group of American youngsters were playing tag here today in a paved street where there was only rough jungle a few years ago. Gross income of American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., increased last year to a record $215,877,026 from $206,915,705 gross in 1956, Leonard H. Goldenson, president, reported in the annual statement to stockholders.
LONDON, March 26 -- One of the most controversial works of sculpture by Sir Jacob Epstein was bought today for display at a waxworks in the west coast resort of Blackpool.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Paper work has caused further delay in the announcement of further restrictions on imports of crude oil, Administration officials said today.
FORT CHURCHILL, Man., March 26 (Canadian Press) -- A group of United States scientists completed a series of International Geophysical Year tests today.
the school board at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, and will draw its pupils from among girls suspended as troublemakers.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Senator Styles Bridges defended as "entirely proper" today the use of Army musicians at a reception last week for a group of women from his state of New Hampshire.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26 (UP) -- Garnet (Sugar) Hart closed Charlie (Tombstone) Smith's right eye tonight and cut his left eye to gain a technical knockout in the eighth round of a scheduled ten-round bout.
In his letter published March 21 Prof. N. Arnold Tolles puts forward the suspension of income tax withholding as an effective, speedy recession stopper.

A few months ago many people would have been skeptical if told that before the end of March, 1958, the United States would have put more satellites than the Soviet Union into orbit around the earth. Yet that is the situation, now that another Explorer satellite has joined Explorer I and Vanguard I in space.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -Angry words were touched off today at a House inquiry by a suggestion that some Federal Communications Commissioners might have committed a "penal" offense during official travel.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Several Senators asked the Pentagon today to answer two questions about a proposed $668,000,000 pay increase for career military personnel.

TAMPA, Fla., March 26 -- The impression keeps getting stronger that Sugar Ray Robinson is a figment of someone's imagination. He's too incredible, too colossal to be true. He even seems able to defy the laws of nature by making time stand still for him. Sugar Ray is as ageless as he's wonderful, the most remarkable fist-fighter of his generation.

The $3,000,000 advertising account of Max Factor Co. will leave Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., on July 1 because of a "mutual difference of opinion." The agency has handled Max Factor cosmetics for seven years. No successor haw been named.

Potato futures fluctuated over a wide range yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices opened almost the 30-point daily limit higher. Before the final bell, prices had fallen the daily limit. A point is a hundredth of a cent a pound.

A merger of the Puget Sound Pulp and Timber Company and the Pacific Paper Mills of Washington, Inc., has been approved by directors of both concerns. Stockholders of Puget Sound Pulp will vote on the proposition at a special meeting on April 15. Pacific Coast Paper stockholders will vote on April 10.
Joseph Edward Collins has retired from baseball and, no matter what reports may be heard to the contrary, he will stay retired.
The advance guard of 160 young men and women who will represent the United States at the Brussels World's Fair arrived in New York yesterday. There were eight girls and two boys in the group.

NEW ORLEANS, March 26 (AP) -- United States District Judge Herbert Christenberry today denied a motion seeking a speedy trial of a $779,500 damage suit against two tobacco companies. He placed the case at the bottom of the court docket.

William Lombardy of New York, representing the United States in the international chess masters tournament at Mar Del Plata, was one of five winners in the eleventh round, according to a report received yesterday through Argentine news sources.

PARENT educators who act as experts-with-all-the-answers, advice-givers and pattern-setters are a vanishing breed and, the more that research reveals about the realities of family life, the surer their eventual extinction seems.
Directors of Getty Oil Company approved yesterday a proposal to exchange one share of that company's common for each three shares of its preferred stock.
New York, the Army's largest port of-embarkation, presents specialized problems for the Red Cross. Not the least are those of helping hundreds of families on their way to join servicemen in Europe.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -Outmoded labor contracts were cited today in Congress as being largely to blame for the "precarious" financial condition of the nation's railroads.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West German Minister of the Economy, wound up today a three-day round of talks with Government officials.
The Roosevelt Hospital Progress Fund will be augmented by a gala preview dinner of Trader Vic's restaurant at the Savoy-Plaza on April 13.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 26 (UP) -- Willie Mays and Orlando Cepeda hit two home runs each and Daryl Spencer added a fifth as the San Francisco Giants defeated Baltimore, 7 -- 5, today.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The cost of man's first round trip to the moon will be roughly $2,000,000,000.

In urging full American support for India's economic development program Senator Kennedy observed that "no thoughtful citizen can fail to see our stake in the survival of free government in India." The point that he and the co-sponsor of his resolution, Senator Cooper, were making on the floor of the Senate is painfully obvious.

SHREVEPORT, La., March 26 (AP) -- Orvis Sigler, 36, the basketball coach at the United States Military Academy since 1954, today was named basketball coach and athletic director at Centenary College, He will assume his new duties next Tuesday.

The American News Company elected Malcolm Kingsberg, Dr. Charles P. McKhann and Donald J. Singer directors at its annual meeting here yesterday. Mr. Kingsberg, a management consultant, was formerly vice president and treasurer of the Magna Theatre Corporation and president of RKO Theatres, Inc. Dr. McKhann is chairman of the executive committee of the Chemway Corporation, drug manufacturer.
Ski Sketch: Although the colorful Ford (Tex) Thompson has been the chef at Mad River Glen's base restaurant in Waitsfield, Vt., for the past eight years, he has been on skis only twice.

Electric power production in the week ended last Saturday fell to 11,756,000,000 kilowatt hours, from 11,860,000,000 in the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended March 23, 1957, was 11,723,000,000 kilowatt hours. Comparative percentages with the like two weeks are:
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., March 26 -- The eleventh Wellesley-in-Nassau garden tour of four estates will take place the afternoon of May 8.

NORTH KEY LARGO, Fla., March 26 -- Professional fishing guides are men of strong convictions and they are great disciplinarians. They do not willingly tolerate nonsense from the client, who is at his best a dilettante and likely to have either murky or irrational ideas about fishing.
The First National City Bank of New York agreed yesterday to take over the Park Avenue block that was to have been the site of the Astor Plaza skyscraper.
VALD'ISERE, France, March 26 (AP) -- Sally Deaver of Whitemarsh, Pa., won the women's giant slalom race today in the Grand Prix of Savoy Skiing Carnival.
Residents of the Netherlands and France whose movable property was confiscated by the Nazis should register claims at once, the World Jewish Congress advised yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -President Eisenhower declined to say today whether he would veto a bill for a one-year ban on reduction of farm price supports below 1957 levels.
New York Hospital will start construction in July on a two-story building in honor of Dr. Connie Guion, Emeritus Professor of Clinical Medicine at the Cornell University Medical College.

Arrangements are being made under the chairmanship of George W. Merck for a theatre party on May 13 for the benefit of the Viewpoint School Scholarship Fund. The committee has chosen the evening performance on that date of "Say, Darling," starring David Wayne, Vivian Blaine and Johnny Desmond at the ANTA Theatre.

The New York Central Railroad had a net loss of $9,869,840, in February in contrast to a net income of $2,020,713 a year earlier, the road reported yesterday. Gross revenues for the month dropped to $46,189,416 from $61,603,954 a year before.
MADRID, March 26 (Reuter) -- New strikes broke out in Spain today following walkouts by nearly 3,000 workers in Barcelona.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The following are the members of the President's Science Advisory Committee:
Stockholders of the Monsanto Chemical Company were told at annual meeting yesterday in St. Louis that first-quarter sales were running 13 per cent below those of a year ago.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 26 (UP)-- Harvey Balch, the 1958 Pacific Coast junior men's figure skating champion, captured first place in the novice men's school-figures division in the national figure skating contest today.

"Baseball in Israel" was launched at a cocktail party at Al Schacht's restaurant yesterday afternoon. This movement will receive further impetus at a $50-a-plate dinner at the Roosevelt Hotel on June 4 in honor of August A. (Gussie) Busch, the owner of the St. Louis Cardinals.
LONDON, March 26 -- Stock market prices declined in a slow session today. Only South African gold mining shares and a few selected industrials advanced narrowly against the trend.

LAST night's telecast of the annual "Oscar" awards of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences was sponsored by the motion picture industry. It was a bewildering and saddening occasion. The best the world of films could do was put on a third-rate television program.
An all-day conference on transportation planning for the Borough of Richmond will be held Saturday at Wagner College on Grymes Hill.
Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson yesterday asked representatives for creditors of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company to advise him on the legality of abandoning the railroad.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Congress is planning a generous Easter holiday from April 4 to April 14. If the plan is executed, the seven days after April 14 will be a week to remember.
Almost two months after its launching, Explorer I, which was joined in space yesterday by its twin satellite, is still sending out scientific data.
EVER since he was 18 years old, James Alfred Van Allen has had his thoughts in the clouds -- or higher.
A mural in stained glass, depicting various aspects of Canadian wealth and activity, was installed yesterday in the lobby of Canada House.

The New York Legislature has completed a productive session and, except for the unforgivable and intolerable failure to advance court reform, could be congratulated wholeheartedly this morning for many sound accomplishments. This major defect in the record must be remedied.

New Jersey had a hot potato tossed in its lap yesterday. Perry Shoemaker, president of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, warned the state: "We see no present prospect of having $2,500,000 with which to pay those 1958 taxes due Dec. 1."
Prices and volume sagged in yesterday's stock market as investors failed to extract comfort from either business news or Washington reassurances.

LONDON, March 26 -- A new chapter in the story of the Princess and the fighter pilot opened today when Group Capt. Peter Townsend returned from a journey around the world and spent nearly three hours with Princess Margaret.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, March 26 (AP) -- A radio relay web, the United States' $140,000,000 answer to Alaska's vast distances, electronic barriers and defense needs, began operating over a 3,000-mile network today.
Magistrate Walter Gladwin praised the police yesterday for their swift arrest of twelve youths in the beating of a parochial school teacher on Monday in Crotona Park, the Bronx.

A 16-year-old truant contradicted yesterday the testimony of three of the seven teen-age gang members accused of killing young Michael Farmer in High Bridge Park. He also denied testimony by his mother.

New York State's total of workers drawing unemployment-insurance benefits declined 8,000 in the week ended March 21, the state Labor Department reported yesterday. For the state as a whole 432,000 received unemployment payments, compared with 440,000 in the week before.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -President Eisenhower focused world attention today on Eniwetok Atoll in the mid-Pacific and on the forthcoming series of nuclear tests to be held there.

A 16-year-old truant contradicted yesterday the testimony of three of the seven teen-age gang members accused of killing young Michael Farmer in High Bridge Park. He also denied testimony by his mother.

New York State's total of workers drawing unemployment-insurance benefits declined 8,000 in the week ended March 21, the state Labor Department reported yesterday. For the state as a whole 432,000 received unemployment payments, compared with 440,000 in the week before.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -President Eisenhower focused world attention today on Eniwetok Atoll in the mid-Pacific and on the forthcoming series of nuclear tests to be held there.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -The Air Force has ordered its bomber crews to "lock in" their nuclear bombs on practice missions.
WINCHESTER, Mass., March 26 -- Regional cooperation among the six state universities in New England will go into effect next fall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26 -- "San Francisco Crusade," a series of hour-long programs about the Rev. Dr. Billy Graham's coming evangelistic campaign in the Bay city, will begin on the American Broadcasting Company television network May 3.
PAKANBARU, Indonesia, March 26 -- Indonesian Government forces, now in control of most of Central Sumatra, have closed loopholes for rebel barter trade across the Strait of Malacca.

Arthur S. Lall, India's Permanent Representative to the United Nations, will have his second novel published April 28 by Harper. Called "The Seasons of Jupiter," the story takes place in India over the last half century.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) -- Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's new conference today:

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
MOSCOW, Thursday, March 27 -- The first minutes of the opening session of one of the two houses of the Supreme Soviet, the Council of Union, produced no indication of Government changes this morning.

EDNA FERBER, the John Gunther of our novelists, has advanced her campaigning field from Texas to Alaska. In her new book, "Ice Palace," she has a territory twice as big as Texas to guntherize. She makes the most of it with unflagging zeal among the mountains, the snows and the seals.
PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, B. W. I., March 26 -- Norman W. Manley's Labor party, which is Socialist in orientation, has returned a majority to the new West Indies Federation's House of Representatives

Robert Moses, chairman of the Slum Clearance Committee, denied yesterday that a controversial bill introduced in the Assembly last Friday was designed to raise the rents of commercial tenants in Title I redevelopments.
ALBANY, March 26 -- The reorganization of the New York City Housing Authority was assured today as the Legislature raced toward the close of the 1958 session.
MARACAIBO, Venezuela, March 21 -- United States oil companies in Venezuela are confident they can successfully pass the scrutiny of their activities by the country's labor movement.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 26 (AP) -- Pete Cooper of Lakeland Fla., played rebarkably steady golf today to win top money of $1,000 in the annual Seminole pro-amateur golf tournament at the Seminole Golf Club. His two-day score was 71, 68 -- 139.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) -- Scientists concerned with the medical aspects of space flight completed tonight an optimistic look at man's impending ventures beyond the earth.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26 -Twenty-nine nations have submitted scientific papers for consideration by the second international conference on the peaceful uses of atomic energy, it was announced today.

CHINA LAKE, Calif., March 26 (UP) -- Explorer III appears to be "going awfully fast and coming in very close" at the nearest point of its elliptical orbit, trackers at the China Lake Naval Ordnance test station reported today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 11 to 17 points in moderate trading yesterday.

A new issue of $20,000,000 of bonds of the General Telephone Company of California is being offered for public subscription today by a syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. and Kidder, Peabody Co. at a price to yield 4.1 per cent. The bonds were sold to the bankers at competitive bidding yesterday at a price of 99.599 for obligations bearing an interest rate of 4 1/8 per cent.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 26 (AP) -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation's net earnings in 1957 dropped to $1.62 a share from $2.21 in the previous year. In its annual report released yesterday, the company reported net earnings of $4,346,429 for 1957.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- Ray familiar but ever-pleasing role of the "new middleweight champion of the world." The amazing Sugar Ray of Harlem showed few signs of having been in a savage fight last night in which he lifted the 160-pound crown from the battered brow of Car-Robinson held court today in the men Basilio.
THE liaison of fruit with savory items, such as meats and cheese, occupies an important niche in the realm of cuisine.

MOSCOW, March 26 (AP) -Marshal Mikhail N. Tukhachevsky has been hailed as one of the Soviet Union's greatest military commanders, twenty-one years after his execution by a firing squad on treason charges in the great purges of the Stalin period.
ALBANY, March 25 -- Republicans in the Legislature unexpectedly gave final approval today to a measure to curb the Long Island Rail Road's freedom to raise its fares.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 26 -- The stand taken yesterday by the new Lebanese Cabinet against joining either of the rival Arab federations has emphasized the reluctance of small Arab states to be swallowed up in the name of unity.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, March 19:

SYRACUSE, March 26 (AP)--Dean Morris E. Hurley, of the Syracuse College of Business Administration, resigned today, effective June 10. He said he was going to Milan, Italy, where he will head a school of business and technical management to be formed by a United States company.
McCutcheon's, 102-year-old store specializing in linens and other fabrics, will move to 16 East Fifty-second Street this summer.
LONDON, March 26 -- Liberian Ambassador C. L. Simpson tonight defended the much-criticized shipping taxation systems of Liberia, Panama and Honduras.

The Investors Funding Corporation of New York, Jerome Dansker, president, has purchased the nine-story apartment house at 70 East Seventy-seventh Street. The building, which is on a plot 99 by 102 feet, contains twenty-eight apartments and two penthouses.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr, yesterday urged the city's labor leaders to meet with him to help clean up the "hazardous mess" in factories and buildings on the lower West Side.

PARIS, March 27 -- The French police seized today copies of a book in which a Communist editor in Algiers presented a circumstantial account of alleged torture at the hands of French paratroop officers.
Gil Turner, the Philadelphia welterweight who lost out in the title elimination series, will meet Mickey Crawford of Saginaw, Mich., in the ten-round feature bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The director of foreign aid said today that Congressional cuts in the aid program prompted by the recession would be "almost precisely what the Soviet has been hoping for."
Pleasure boating has here and there a paradox. Take the matter of steering a boat.
PLYMOUTH, England, March 27 (Reuters) -- A Naval Board of Inquiry continued today its investigations on board the 2,650-ton minelayer Apollo where forty-two seamen are under arrest.
After months of frustration, Harold Petrie, a taxi driver, yesterday won possession of $11,200 in water-soaked bills that he found in the rear of his cab last July 24.

BOSTON, March 27 -- Eleven persons were injured tonight when a four-car train composed of lightweight, low-slung Buddliners struck the rear of a standard twelve-car train in South Boston. None of the injured was in critical condition.

JAKARTA Indonesia, March 27 -- The Royal Dutch Shell group here announced today that a new company, to be incorporated in Indonesia, would take over its oil interests in the archipelago from its subsidiary incorporated in the Netherlands in 1907.

Directors of R. Hoe Co., Inc., yesterday deferred action on the quarterly dividend usually declared on the Class A stock at this time. The company has been paying 25 cents quarterly on the stock, the last of which was disbursed on Jan. 15.
Howard Pyle, deputy assistant to President Eisenhower for Federal-state relations, said yesterday it was "little short of incredible" that some persons had little faith in the nation's economy.

The F. Trowbridge vom Baur recommendations, quoted by Arthur Krock in his March 18 column, visit penalties solely on applicants or their representatives before Federal regulatory commissions -- not on the Commissioners or their staff. This would seem to be one defect.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan moved yesterday on two fronts in his investigation of illegal activities in professional boxing.
The major news in advertising yesterday was electrical, with these developments emanating from that industry:
Gainfully employed blind men and women descried their work and play at the fifty-second annual meeting yesterday of the Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind.

Business loans outstanding at the seventeen larger New York City banks dropped $98,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. In the corresponding week a year ago business loans were off $119,000,000.
Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., reported yesterday gross revenues of $65,637,080 and net income of $2,852,194 for 1957.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, March 27 -- Thirty-five Spanish-speaking New Yorkers bound for Cuba to join Fidel Castro, rebel leader, were arrested today by United States Coast Guardsmen who rammed and boarded their arms-laden trawler. arrests at sea were made before dawn aboard the seventyfoot trawler Orion. Two Coast Guard patrol boats from Port Isabel at the mouth of the Brazos River intercepted the trawler as she lay off Padre Island.
Jerry Toppazzini's "suddendeath" shot gave a 4-to-3 victory to the Boston Bruins over the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. His shot came at 4:46 of the first overtime period.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 -- Members of the National Association of Broadcasting Employes and Technicians have rejected the contract proposals offered them last month by the National and American Broadcasting Companies.

Although the most modern of rockets will launch the first trip to the moon -- manned or unmanned -- the aim and speed required will be computed according to formulas established in the seventeenth century.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -A State Department official conceded today that the Administration proposal to share atomic secrets with allies could result in bringing new nations into the atomic arms race.
Events today: Bizet's "Carmen," special student performance, Metropolitan Opera House, 1; Gounod's "Faust," Metropolitan Opera House, 8.
BALTIMORE, March 27 -- The City of Baltimore officially received plans today for the redevelopment of a twenty-two-acre tract in the downtown business district.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., March 27 (AP) -- A couple of college youths eliminated the defending champions of the Hollywood four-ball golf tournament in the opening round today over the Orange Brook Country Club course.
VALLAURIS, France, March 27 (AP) -- A forty-piece wall panel painted by Pablo Picasso for the United Nations was assembled today for the first time. The first art expert who saw it was ecstatic.

Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin was relatively unknown to the outside world in February, 1955, when Nikita S. Khrushchev had him elected Premier of the Soviet Union, the job Marshal Bulganin vacated yesterday.
ALBANY, March 27 -- Governor Harriman announced today that the Public Works Department would construct a three-mile spur this year to facilitate access to the Thruway from Schenectady.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 27 (AP) -- A group of eighty-two Lebanese leaders mostly pro-Nasser, warned Western-minded President Camillje N. Chamoun in a manifesto today against seeking re-election.

AN ambitious live dramatization of "A Tale of Two Cities" was undertaken last night on the "Du Pont Show of the Month" over Channel 2. The massive Charles Dickens classic proved rather too much for TV's limitations in space and time.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 27 -- Explorer III, the nation's newest satellite, evidently will survive a good deal longer than the two-week maximum estimated at first.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- The President's Conference on Occupational Safety recommended today a national program to encourage high school students to conduct rocket experiments under supervision.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- "Cash" savings rose by a near-record total of about $13,600,000,000 in 1957, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. The total on Dec. 31, 1957, stood at $262,109,000,000 compared with $248,492,000,000 a year earlier.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 27 -- Michigan State's William Steuart and Ohio States Don Harper were the title-winners tonight in the opening session of the thirty-fifth annual National Collegiate swimming championships.
Federal Judge Sidney Sugarman dismissed yesterday a complaint by the National Maritime Union against the regional office here of the National Labor Relations Board.
Congregation Emanu-El announced yesterday that its board of trustees had elected David Sarnoff a trustee and Frederick F. Greenman a vice president of the congregation.
A new Kinsey report says most abortions are performed on wives.

The election of General of the Army Omar N. Bradley as chairman of the Bulova Watch Company was announced yesterday by John H. Ballard, president and chairman of the executive committee. General Bradley has been chairman of the Bulova Research and Development Laboratories, Inc., a subsidiary, since 1953.
LONDON, March 27 -- Group Capt. Peter Townsend sought today to check a wave of speculation that he might marry Princess Margaret.

World-wide sales of Sterling Drug, Inc., exceeded $200,000,000 last year for the first time in the company's fifty-six-year history. The increased sales, reflecting the largest gain for any year since World War II, lifted earnings 11.2 per cent to a new high.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- The House voted $9,517,876,481 today to run twentyseven Government agencies.

Bela Bartok, the Hungarian composer, spent the last five years of his life, from 1940 to 1945, in self-imposed exile in the United States. A personal account of those years is given in "The Naked Face of Genius," by Agatha Fassett, a friend and companion of the composer and of his wife, Ditta.
More than a half-million dollars will be required by the Metropolitan Educational Television Association within the next two years, the organization's president declared yesterday.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 27 (AP) -- Tim Brown topped the defending champion, David Jenkins, in an opening duel of their national figure skating title struggle today. But he had only a shaky chance of ultimate victory over the champion.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -When the Secretary of Defense is looking for a man to rocket to the moon, a disgruntled oil man wants it to be Matthew Vaughan Carson Jr., the Navy captain who administers the Government's curb on oil imports.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) An article in The New York Times criticizing Representative John J. Rooney, Democrat of Brooklyn, was assailed today on the floor of the House by Representative Abraham J. Multer, Democrat of Brooklyn, as "irresponsible."

The New York Times of March 17 reports a suggestion of Dr. W. F. Libby, a member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, to restrict atomic bomb tests by means of an international pact. Such pact would bind the different nations not to exceed a certain preassigned quota of fall-out radiation.
PARIS, March 27 -- An avalanche of mail is pouring into the United States Embassy here asking clemency for an American deserter from World War II.

Today's new film is "A Love Story," a German-made romantic drama, based on a novel by Carl Zuckmayer, at the Seventy-second Street Playhouse. Hildegarde Neff, O. W. Fischer and Viktor De Kowa have the principal roles in the Topaz Films release, produced by Eric Pommer and directed by Rudolf Jugert.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 27 (AP) -- The President of the American Bar Association termed today as "false and misleading" a recent assertion of a California physician that lawyers subjected physicians to "brutal" treatment to undermine their expert testimony in court cases.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that world-wide observance of human rights would never be realized without "concerted citizen action to uphold them close to home."
OKEECHOBEE, Fla., March 27 (AP) -- Unusually heavy rains have cut the supply of palm leaves for the coming Palm Sunday.
BONN, Germany, March 27 The Government moved swiftly today to head off the Opposition's campaign against equipping the West German Army with nuclear weapons.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The "spectre" of a nationalized transportation system was raised today at a Senate subcommittee hearing on the "precarious" condition of the railroads.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today cigarette output in 1957 jumped to a record total of 442,000,000,000, a gain of about 18,000,000,000 above the 1956 total and nearly 7,000,000,000 above the previous record set in 1952.
ALBANY, March 27 -- Governor Harriman announced today the selection of Thomas K. Finletter, former Air Force Secretary, to head the State Civil Defense Commission until September.
In a radical departure from tradition, the American Merchant Marine Institute, Inc., will defend American-owned ships flying foreign "flags of convenience."
The city's program for the care of underprivileged children has become inefficient and wasteful because of official neglect, Mayor Wagner was told yesterday.
John E. Muhlfeld has been named vice president of sales for Air Express International Corporation, effective April 1. He is vice president of sales and traffic for Slick Airways, Inc.
A FINE new Brangene, a Cleveland-born mezzo-soprano, Grace Hoffman, made her debut at the Metropolitan Opera last night in Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde."
WASHINGTON, March 27 -A House subcommittee was told today that a letter urging the Attorney General to dispose of an antitrust suit against the Bell System had been based on a Bell official's draft.

No New Yorker needs to be told that it is in the city's schools the problem of "shook-up" adolescents reaches a stormy climax. Ever since the novel and film "Blackboard Jungle," New Yorkers have been increasingly aware of the impact of teen-age violence on the educational system. In recent weeks there has been a new series of tragic incidents.
CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MADRID, March 27 -- Industrial disturbances in the North of Spain continued to spread today, according to reliable reports here.
It is completely in character for Herbert H. Lehman at the age of 80 to be looking forward rather than backward.
MOSCOW, March 27 (AP) -Twelve talented young musicians, including an American girl, made the violin finals today of the Tchaikovsky international piano and violin competition.

The Louisville and Nashville Railroad raised $7,695,000 in the public market yesterday on equipment trust certificates to help finance the purchase of 1.100 steel gondola cars costing about $9,625,077.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 27 (UP) -- Home runs by Harry Anderson and Stan Lopata paced the Philadelphia Phillies to a 6-2 exhibition baseball victory over the Chicago White Sox today.
ALBANY, March 27 -- Lawyers won a new round against judges today over the power of courts to regulate legal fees.
A NEW kind of antiques outlet for Greenwich Village is taking shape at 89 University Place. It is fashioned, on a small scale, after the model of an antiques fair.
ALBANY, March 27 (AP) -- An appellate court today dismissed an $80,000 damage award made after the death of a boxer, George Flores.

EXCEPT for the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto the music on last night's New York Philharmonic program was low in vitality. It contained elements that were pleasing, elegant and imaginative, but it was not stuff that stirred the blood.
The New York City Federation of Women's Clubs presented an award to Spain at its annual spring festival luncheon yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- When Del Webb, a co-owner of the Yankees, recently made the suggestion that the Kansas City Athletics shift their franchise into the National League (thereby permitting the Philadelphia Phillies to enter the American), it is understood that the idea did not sit well at all with his general manager, George M. Weiss.
The Kings County grand jury investigating lawlessness in the schools called upon Governor Harriman yesterday to sign a measure permitting teachers to use reasonable force for class discipline.
HAVANA, March 27 -- Senor Castro has issued instructions to the people of Cuba for a general revolutionary strike to be called "at any moment" in an effort to overthrow the Government.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- President Eisenhower today lowered the ceiling on imports of crude oil and set up procedures to discourage importers who would not respect it.

A newly established Paul Krichell Memorial Award will be presented to a member of the Yankee organization "who has made outstanding contributions to baseball, the club and the community" on the night of April 18.
RALEIGH, N. C., March 27 -This was Carl Sandburg Day in North Carolina. From Gov. Luther H. Hodges down citizens paused to pay tribute to the 80year-old poet, Lincoln biographer and novelist.
ALBANY, March 27 -- Governor Harriman announced today that he would approve the Republican crime commission bill left with him by the Legislature when it adjourned last night.
Motorists' tolls accounted for a major share of the Port of New York Authority's record revenue of $84,753,000 last year. The income represented a rise of 10 per cent over 1956.
"The Girls in 509" belongs to Alfred de Liagre Jr., who is planning to bring it here Oct. 22.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 27 -- This was one morning after, when Hollywood, at least, was patting itself on the back about the handling of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences award show.

The article "Milk Dating Here Called Needless" which appeared in The Times of March 24 impelled me to consult my file on this matter which was a public issue just five years ago. The article states that Dr. A. C. Dahlberg was requested to make his study as a result of "a request by the city's Department of Health for additional information on the problem."

A professor of criminology proposed yesterday that homeless alcoholics arrested for drunkenness be given indeterminate two-year sentences, instead of the customary sentences of five, ten or thirty days.

Following are the text of President Eisenhowetr's address last night at the conference in Washington on international trade policy, as recorded by The New York Times, and the prepared text of the speech by Adlai E. Stevenson:

The State of Iowa received no bids yesterday for $24,700,000 of bonds to finance the payment of bonus compensation to veterans of the Korean War. The conditions of sale required that the interest cost should not exceed 2 1/2 per cent for bonds due serially from 1958 to 1976.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association asked Congress today to liberalize duties on imports of newsprint to take into account the trend toward narrower newspaper pages.

The heirs of the late Joseph Pulitzer, founder of The New York World, received $17,233,268 in income from the Newspaper Trust set up in his will between April 7, 1930, and Sept. 4, 1947." Trustees of the trust reported this to the Surrogate's Court yesterday.

Secretary of State Dulles has upheld the State Department's refusal to renew the passport of William Worthy Jr. Mr. Worthy, a foreign correspondent, has disregarded the State Department's restrictions on travel to Communist China and Hungary.
LONDON, March 27 -- British steel manufacturers announced today a cut in steel prices.
LONDON, March 27 -- The trustees of the National Gallery appealed to the public today for financial assistance in acquiring works of art.
The Rev. William Howard Melish must vacate the rectory of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn within thirty days or face eviction.
TOKYO, March 27 -- A strike of transport workers left an estimated total of 11,000,000 commuters stranded in their omes today.

The Penn-Texas Corporation reduced its outstanding short-term debt from more than $10,500,000 last November to some $9,900,000 at the end of February. The company reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that some of its loans had been liquidated, others renewed and a few new ones negotiated.

Record earnings and case sales last year have been reported by the Pepsi-Cola Company. It sold more of its product than ever before, both at home and abroad, Alfred N. Steele, board chairman, and Herbert L. Barnet, president, said in the annual statement to stockholders.
WALDWICK, N. J., March 27 -- Bergen County is in the forefront of an urban revolution, a leader in city planning told the Northwest Bergen Regional Planning Association here tonight.
Two young children died last night in a flash fire in a tenement at Lexington Avenue and 107th Street.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -The capital was even more confused than usual today as a result of President Eisenhower's press conference comments yesterday about atomic weapons testing and inspection.
Except for issues of a few machine tools manufacturers, rising because of a small upturn in new orders, stocks generally declined yesterday.

Never will a spring be so welcome as this one, never will a winter be plunged into retirement so completely unmourned. True, there are those who ski and those who skate, and for them a certain amount of winter gives a snow pudding dessert to the meal of life.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Senate passed today an anti-recession highway construction bill. The measure is designed to pour $5,500,000,000 into the economy over the next two years and create thousands of new jobs.

On June 15, 1954, Governor Dewey signed a bill passed by a special session of the Legislature that represented a beneficial bargain among the Long Island Rail Road, its parent, the Pennsylvania, and New York State to assure the rehabilitation of the Long Island.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- President Eisenhower and Adlai E. Stevenson appealed today for Congressional support of a liberal foreign trade policy as vital to domestic prosperity and world peace.

The five-day visit of Vietnamese President Ngo Dinh Diem with President Garcia of the Philippines was a good idea to begin with and it has obviously borne the fruit that was expected from it. There are good reasons why Saigon and Manila should embrace every opportunity to draw more closely together.

A special three-judge Federal court lifted a 1955 injunction yesterday and cleared the way for the Alleghany Corporation to issue 1,300,000 shares of 6 per cent convertible preferred stock in exchange for its series A 5 1/2 per cent preferred shares.
Photographs of policemen entering and leaving Harlem policy drops are expected to result in a police shake-up.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The United States, with three artificial satellites circling the earth, announced plans today to explore space in the vicinity of the moon.
Job experience is as difficult for the would-be top executive to get as it is for employes farther down the scale, and one company is doing something about it.

ROME, March 27 -- Unexpected advances by the Communist labor unions have assumed significance for the Italian general elections May 25 and 26. The victory of the Communist-controlled Italian Mechanical Workers' Federation in a shop steward election at the Lancia Automobile Company in Turin yesterday followed a series of similar Red successes scored recently at important plants.

LONDON, March 27 -- British Government securities showed gains of as much as 5 shillings (70 cents) here today. They were virtually the only share group to show a decided trend in the stock market. Elsewhere trading was hardly sufficient to test prices.

A new high in Senatorial fatuity and a new low in Senatorial efforts to demean the Federal judiciary was reached by the Mississippi statesman James O. Eastland this week when in the course of a subcommittee hearing he asked a nominee to the Federal bench to take an oath that amounted to swearing he would stand by his oath of office if he were confirmed.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 27 -Any good race horse, young or old, should see his dentist at least twice a year -- not for extractions or fillings but for filings and check-ups.
THE food shopper will find meat prices high again this week-end.
NORTH KEY LARGO, Fla., March 27 -- There can be no question that Florida fishing in general has been and is sensationally poor this year. There have been exceptions but the rule still holds.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 27 (UP) -- Dave Abeyta, Idaho State's powerful featherweight, hammered his way into the semi-finals of the National Collegiate boxing championships today by outpointing Danny Kosora of Hawaii.
Governor Harriman signed a bill yesterday putting Long Island Rail Road fares back under the jurisdiction of the State Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- In opposing today Senator Kennedy's proposal that labor union officials be required to report borrowings from business men with whom they have contractual relations, George Meany complained that this would put union labor "in a class apart."
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- Following are the texts of the statements by the White House and the Defense Department on the new moon-rocket program:

An electronic machine that can read ordinary typewritten addresses on envelopes and sort them by city and state was described here yesterday. The machine, still in the experimental stage but already tested in a post office, was developed by the Intelligent Machines Research Corporation, Alexandria, Va.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -Negro pastors of this city led a one-day boycott today on the "big five" downtown department stores to protest what they called a policy of not hiring Negroes as salespeople.
Social assistance to ease the hardships of families uprooted by slum clearance was recommended yesterday by the Community Service Society's committee on housing.

LONDON, March 27 -- A new civic theatre in Coventry was opened tonight by the Duchess of Kent. The modernistic 911seat house is the first theatre to be built by a municipal authority in Britain since before World War II.
UNFURLING the history of Japanese book illustration, the New York Public Library, at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, exhibits a group of singular examples from its renowned Spencer Collection.
Your lead editorial of March 25, "The Trade Program," is notable for its strident tone, highly emotional onslaught on the protectionists and remarkable errors of fact.
The Waterfront Commission yesterday swung the mace of its year-old extended powers for the first time in assessing the maximum penalty against a stevedoring concern.
MOSCOW, March 27 -- Nikita Sergeyevich Khrushchev became Premier of the Soviet Union today. Thus he has emerged as the undisputed leader and chief spokesman of this nation in name as well as fact.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- United States observers commenting on the appointment of Nikita S. Khrushchev as Soviet Premier today leaned heavily to the view that he felt a need to become leader in name as well as in fact.

A plot of land with a frontage of 200 feet on the east side of Manida Street, 100 feet south of Randall Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by the W. J. Fitzgerald Paving Company for improvement with buildings for its own occupancy. J. P. McCann and Henry Waltemade, Inc., were the brokers.
ABOUT 2 o'clock one recent morning a distinguished New York matron called J. Gardiner McAnerney at his country home.
PARIS, March 27 -- The promotion of Mr. Khrushchev to a front seat at an eventual summit conference was seen here as the principal purpose of his assumption of the Premiership.
Work will begin in about a week on the largest and costliest passenger and freight terminal in the Port of New York. It will be built for the HollandAmerica Line at a cost of $18,723,000.

A new riddle has appeared in the Middle East as a result of the shift of power from King Saud to Croxx-n Prince Faisal. The latter, hitherto titular Premier and Foreign Minister. has now been invested with "full power" over Saudi Arabia's internal, financial and foreign policies and has been charged with the specific task of reshaping the antiquated governmental structure that goes back to the Biblical Age.
MONTREAL, March 27 (AP) -The Foundation Company of Canada, Ltd., has been awarded the general building contract for construction of the Place Ville-Marie project in downtown Montreal.
PEIPING, March 27 (Reuters) -- All "Rightist" civil servants have been "disposed off," Hsi Chung-hsin said in a speech published today.

An eloquent call to national action has been made this week in the series of full-page advertisements inserted in this newspaper by the McCann-Erickson Company -- a leading advertising agency. Their message, which deserves wide reading, is in refreshing contrast to the neurosis of inferiority into which the sputnik launchings at first threw this country.
Nikita S. Khrushchev began this career as Soviet Premier yesterday by promising his people a higher standard of living than people in the United States enjoy.

The Belgian Congo is planning to borrow $15,000,000 in the United States market through a public offering of bonds. The transaction will mark the first time that the African colony has made a bid for development capital from the United States. The issue was registered yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Cotton futures advanced 14 to 26 points yesterday.

VAL D'ISERE, France, March 27 (AP) -- Sally Deaver and Betsy Snite of the United States finished 1-2 today in the second giant slalom of the Grand Prix of Savoy skiing carnival. Another American, Linda Meyer, finished fifth.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -A researcher advised physicians today to discuss disease and fees with patients.

LONDON, March 27 -- The delay in arranging summit talks with the Soviet Union has caused anger, anxiety and uncertainty in the Opposition, among independent M. P.'s and even in Government circles in the House of Commons.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 27 -- Political sentiment in the Netherlands has swung noticeably to the Right in the last two years.
