They may be only straws in the March wind, but the Chase Manhattan Bank thinks there are some signs that the business decline is moderating.

All wool positions fell to new lows for the life of the contract yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, Prices closed at, or near, the lows of the day in active trading. Tops declined 1.7 to 2.2 cents a pound and grease wool was off 1.4 to 2.2 cents.
The insurgent group that has been holding control of Local 88, International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, staved off a court ouster yesterday.
The law of a foreign country was applied in Federal Court here yesterday for the first time in a complicated admiralty negligence case.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -America's only active whaling fleet, consisting of three vessels, brought in 237 whales during the 1957 season, the Department of Interior reported today. This was ninety-two more whales than the previous year, when the West Coast whaling industry was reactivated after a five-year lapse.

In politics, as in other areas of life, it is always important to distinguish between the reality of power and the appearance of power. So far as anyone outside the Kremlin can tell, the change made in Moscow yesterday was one which affected appearance rather than reality.

Mrs. T. Edward Hambleton, chairman of the tenth annual theatre benefit of the New York Alumnae of Bennington College, has announced that plans are under way for this year's event, which will take place on April 15.
CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -The broadest rally of more than a week occurred on the Board of Trade today.

ST. LOUIS, March 27 (AP) -Cliff Hagen led the St. Louis Hawks to a 120 -- 96 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight in the decisive game of the National Basketball Association semi-final play-offs. St. Louis won the series, four games to one, and will meet the Boston Celtics in the championship play-offs for the second straight year.
WHITE PLAINS, March 27 -A 6-year-old girl was awarded $400,000 damages and three other members of her family received $79,000 for automobile accident injuries today.

NORWALK, Conn., March 27 -- Commuting may produce disruptive influences in the home, Dr. Fred Brown, chief psychologist at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, declared here last night. Tensions in the commuter's life, he said, may lead to instability in the family unit, marital stress and juvenile delinquency.

MONTREAL, March 27 (UP) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard broke up a tense hockey game with a pair of third-period goals to pace the Montreal Canadiens to a 5-1 victory over Detroit and a 2-0 lead in the four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup semi-final series tonight.
OTTAWA, March 27 -- Irritation over what is regarded in Canada as interference by Washington in Canadian affairs has swept across Canada in the last week of the general election campaign.
A 49-year-old man, described as "the largest operator in unemployment - insurance - fraud history," was back in Felony Court yesterday.
TAMPA, March 27 (UP) -- Led by Dee Fondy's home run and the pitching of Brooks Lawrence, the Cincinnati Redlegs routed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9 -- 1, in a Grapefruit League game today.

When a citizen is as valuable to the community as Herbert H. Lehman, former Governor, former Senator and constant servant of the public, it is an added piece of good fortune that he has also the quality of longevity. Mr. Lehman is, according to all the available records, 80 years old today.
Red Cross disaster workers in Brooklyn were roused before dawn reecntly when a factory fire threatened surrounding dwellings and residents had to be evacuated to icy streets.

FOR more than two weeks recently I tantalized myself. A copy of Peter De Vries' "The Mackerel Plaza"* rested on my desk and, with a fine sense of virtuous self-denial, I did not open it. I kept postponing reading a book that I anticipated with great pleasure in order to read others whose pleasures were problematical.

BOSTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics came to life in the final period after a lethargic start for a 93-88 victory over the Philadelphia Warriors tonight and clinched the semifinal National Basketball Association play-off series between the clubs.
FOR the owners and directors summer camps for children, February through April is the peak period of enrolling new campers.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 27 (AP) -- Andre Rodgers hit two home runs and Ramon Monzant, a right-hander, pitched the best ball of the spring for San Francisco today as the Giants blanked the Baltimore Orioles, 10 to 0, in an exhibition baseball game.

GROTON, Conn., March 27 -Another atomic-powered Navy submarine, the Skipjack, will be launched May 26 at General Dynamics Corporation's Electric Boat Division here, the corporation announced today. The Skipjack is described as the first craft of the Navy's new model for attack submarines.

Leonard W. Hall, former Republican national chairman, said last night that he could find no one who could "think of one bold and courageous thing" Governor Harriman had done in office. Mr. Hall told 120 persons at the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, that he had not made up his mind about being a candidate for Governor himself this fall.
The April 15 performance of "Who Was That Lady I Saw You With?" a comedy at the Martin Beck Theatre, will aid the scholarship fund of the Connecticut College Club of New York.

Another draw, the fourth in the series, was recorded in the ninth game of the world chess championship match between Vassily Smyslov and Mikhail Botvinnik, the challenger, in Moscow after 40 moves, according to a report received last night through Soviet news sources.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 27 (UP) -- Boston tallied twice in the first inning off Dan McDevitt today and the runs held up behind tight pitching as the Red Sox won their fifth straight Grapefruit League baseball game. They defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2 -- 1.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), March 27 -- The Government and other landowners were empowered today to evict peasants who seized land ten years ago when the nascent State of Israel had not yet established authority.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -Nearly half of the nation's 149 major employment areas in mid-March were in the "substantial labor surplus" category, the Labor Department reported today. This meant 6 per cent or more of the labor force was out of work.

Figures from the Old Testatament re-enact dramatic Biblical events in an exhibition of children's mosaics now being hung in the Jewish Museum at Fifth Avenue and Ninety-second Street. The fifty panels are the work of arts and crafts classes of Jewish schools in the metropolitan area.

IN ancient Britain the officer who went ahead of royalty to prepare lodging for the court was a harbinger. The term stems from the French words auberge and herbergier -- auberge, an inn; herbergier, to provide lodging. Wild birds have their own harbingers, flock scouts that fly north to look over nesting sites and to find out how close to the surface the flock can expect to find worms.
Biblical scholars engaged in deciphering ancient scrolls of the early Christian and preChristian eras have a new partner -- a twentieth-century electronic computer.
This is the day for fresh bankrolls at the Jamaica track. It's expected that about 25,000 winner-seekers will be present for the opening of New York's 210-day racing season.

The 17-year-old organizer of the Bronx Dragons, reputedly one of the city's more powerful gangs, testified yesterday that a defendant had called him for help on the night that young Michael Farmer was slain in High Bridge Park.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 27 -- The Waterman Steamship Corporation's lift-on, lift-off trailer ship Bienville steamed back to New Orleans today with its refrigerated cargo, consigned to San Juan merchants, still in its holds. The dock strike against the Waterman lines entered its twenty-seventh day while union and shippers were debating Gov. Luis Munoz Marin's proposal to end the tie-up.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 533,019 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -Congressional pressure on President Eisenhower to sign a oneyear freeze of farm price supports was stepped up sharply today. Senator Lyndon B. Johnson sent the President a petition signed by forty-two Democratic members of the Senate urging such action.
THE news in home furnishings this spring has been enlivened by a Cinderella story -the revival of Tiffany glass.
The 175th Anniversary Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will be the beneficiary of the annual spring festival of St. James Episcopal Church.

BRIDGEPORT, Tex., March 27 (AP) -- Two military planes collided in the air over this north Texas town today. Air Force reports showed that eighteen service men had died when the planes crashed. No one survived.

Arnold Hoffman, vice president of Mesabi Iron Company, announced yesterday that he was supporting the nomination of a slate of directors in opposition to the present management. In a letter to stockholders, Mr. Hoffman offered a slate of four directors, in addition to himself.
Aluminium, Ltd., jolted the aluminum market yesterday.

Changes in the location of starting lines, order of class starts and courses were approved by the delegates at the spring meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound yesterday. The meeting was at the New York Yacht Club following one by the organization's junior affiliate.
ALBANY, March 27 -- Governor Harriman brought two years of interparty warfare over unemployment insurance to a halt today by approving a compromise bill.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -Senator John F. Kennedy told George Meany today that if he did not like the Kennedy labor bill he ought to "suggest reasonable alternatives here that the friends of labor can support."

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Walter P. Reuther conceded today that his union had erred in the four-year strike against the Kohler company. He contended, however, that the mistakes had been made in a setting ignited by "modern industrial feudalism."
The Indonesian Government has reached an agreement with British underwriters for the release of approximately thirtynine Dutch ships valued at $33,720,000 that it seized last Dec. 5.

Along about this time of year when woodchucks come blinking out of hibernation, lilac buds swell and rabbits scamper in the moonlight, the voice of the spring peeper is usually heard over the boglands.
The Public Service Commission will begin an investigation soon into the financial condition of railroads operating in New York State.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 28 (AP) -- A hormone collected from the brains of dead persons is making dwarfed children grow, a physician reported today.

CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- Five precinct judges were sentenced and fined today for frauds in a special Congressional election Dec. 31. Roland Libonati, a Democrat, won the election to fill a vacancy caused by death.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UP) -- The State Department is prodding the Soviet Government to lift some of the restrictions on the activities of Ambassador Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr. in Moscow, it was reported today.
The headlines read: "400,000 in New Jersey Lose Electricity" -"74,000 in Long Island Without Power," this winter, as they have: almost every winter, with some variations.
AMESBURY, England, March 28 -- The complicated and controversial job of restoring Stonehenge, most famous of Britain's ancient monuments, began this week.
BUSHEY HEATH, England, March 28 (AP) -- A. E. Matthews lost the battle of the concrete lamp-post today, but from the battlefield he vowed that the war had only just begun.

PARIS, March 28 -- Pvt. Wayne Powers, wartime United States Army deserter, and Mlle. Yvette Beleuse appeared together in public today for the first time since the interruption of their fourteen-year secret love idyl in a village in northern France.
ALBANY, March 28 -- Following is a summary of the more important actions taken by the 1958 session of the Legislature:

TRENTON, March 28 -- A United States Senate investigation of the vending and jukebox machine business was urged today by a Mercer County grand jury. It requested that such an inquiry specifically include transactions in New Jersey.
The ancient and reverent traditions of Palm Sunday will be observed tomorrow by thousands of Christian churchgoers.

In his first speech as Premier of the Soviet Union Nikita S. Khrushchev made a statement which the Soviet people will note and of which we would be well advised to take cognizance. He declared, "We shall conquer capitalism with a high level of work and a higher standard of living."
Solar energy proved itself an effective force at Jamaica yesterday, when a sun-charged crowd of 34,460 turned out for the opening of the new 210-day horse racing season.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 28 (UP) -- Ted Kluszewski hit two home runs and a single today to pace the Pittsburgh Pirates to an 8-7 decision over the Philadelphia Phillies.
ROME, March 28 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev has made a determined effort to get Italy out of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and into a neutralist position.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The Administration recommended today a $100,000,000 appropriation to help pay off some owners of war-seized German assets and settle all American war claims against Germany and Japan.

The Citizens Housing and Planning Council, outraged by "unjust" evictions from city housing projects, called yesterday for a halt to all evictions until pending cases could be reviewed by social workers.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 28 (AP) -- Only ten owners elected today to send their horses against Calumet Farm's Tim Tam in tomorrow's $119,000 Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park.
CHICAGO, March 28 -- J. H. Kindelberger, chairman of North American Aviation, Inc., said today that man's space travel would be limited to orbital distances from the earth for the foreseeable future.

MANILA, March 24 -- When President Ngo Dinh Diem of Vietnam was being accompanied by Philippine officials on a motor tour last week, the well-matured sedan of Diosdado Macapagal broke down as the procession coursed through the very center of Manila. Mr. Macapagal had to desert his stalled vehicle and thumb a ride with a friend.

The annual benefit luncheon and fashion show of the St. Luke's Hospital Auxiliary will be held on April 8 in the ballroom of the Pierre. Reservations may be made with the benefit chairman, Mrs. Edmund C. Lynch of 720 Park Avenue.
The Penn-Texas Corporation last year had a net loss of $9,444,374 after all charges and special items, the report showed yesterday.

BONN, Germany, March 28 -- The executive committee of the German Trade Union Federation called on all sections of the populace today to demonstrate against the Government's decision to permit arming the West German Army with nuclear weapons.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 28 -- Marcel Marceau, French pantomimist, "conducted" the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra last night in a special concert for the benefit of the orchestra's Pension Fund.
CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Members of a Senate Interior subcommittee agreed today with witnesses that Uncle Sam should not permit trade with his allies to strangle the domestic mining industry.
MOSCOW, March 28 (AP) -- A Soviet scientist said today that the Soviet Union was close to sending a man in a rocket into space and back.
BAMAKO, French Sudan, March 19 -- An iron pot for cooking, a bicycle to ride -- these are the marks of relative prosperity here in the heart of French West Africa.
LONDON, March 28 -- The Liberal party revival became a boom today. Its candidate nosed out the Conservative nominee and won yesterday's critical Parliamentary by-election at Torrington in Devonshire.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 28 (UP) -- Joe Bliss of Nevada reached the final in the 139-pound class of the National Collegiate boxing tournament tonight by stopping William Hartz of Virginia in 1:22 of the first round.

PARIS, March 28 -- Defense Minister Jacques Chaban-Delmas said today that two French military planes and a parachute unit in Algeria had recently been fired on from Tunisian territory by Algerian rebels.

OWEN WISTER (1860-1938) was a Philadelphian who played his own piano compositions for Franz Liszt in Vienna, learned law at Harvard, knew Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes, Theodore Roosevelt and Ignace Jan Paderewski and, in his novel, "The Virginian," gave our language an immortal phrase: "When you call me that, smile!' "
An Artists and Models party to be held on the afternoon of April 19 at the Villa Victor Restaurant in Syosset, L. I., will benefit the Family Counseling Association of Nassau County.

MOSCOW, March 28 (AP) -- The members of the Supreme Soviet praised Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's plans to reorganize agriculture today and apparently will wait until next week to hear reports on nuclear tests and formation of a new Government.
AUSTIN, Tex., March 28 (AP) -- Eight Texas Relays records were set and another tied tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Administration was bracing itself today for Moscow's next big propaganda strike. It is expected to be a declaration that the Soviet Union would end nuclear testing or production or both.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A cheery note from the nation's farms burst upon the generally depressed economic scene today.

Charles V. Gris, a private detective, shot and killed himself yesterday in his apartment at the Parc Vendome, 350 West Fifty-seventh Street, the police said. He was under indictment charged with violating the state's new eavesdropping law.

Premier Kishi has made some dramatic reversals of previously held positions on the defense of Japan. To a turbulent session of the Diet he has announced that his Government would construe an attack upon any American defense positions in the archipelago as an attack upon Japan itself, and that Japan might be obliged, to meet an attack, to dispatch Japanese forces to foreign positions.

All three major aluminum producers in this country will trim the price of primary aluminum 2 cents a pound next Tuesday as a result of reductions of about the same amount by their principal Canadian competition.
Pat Suzuki, whose record albums have hit the best seller lists, may portray a featured role in the forthcoming Broadway musical, "The Flower Drum Song."

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 28 -- A "crash program" to prevent the Port of New York from losing business to the St. Lawrence Seaway was advocated here tonight before the Transit Committee of Bergen County.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas and chairman of the Senate Rackets Committee met today with a delegation from New York Local 88 of the Masters. Mates and Pilots who asked that the union be investigated by the committee.

THERE is nothing especially new or startling about "A Love Story," yesterday's new German film at the Seventy-second Street Playhouse. But in a quiet, careful way, this eighteenth-century romantic drama about a thwarted young officer and his beautiful mistress is consistently absorbing and moving.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation received a patent this week for a plastic plate that enables small newspapers to do their own engraving.

BEERSHEBA, Israel, March 23 -- Anyone wishing to witness an event that has been going on, with a few minor adjustments and interruptions, for several hundred years, can do so by coming here any Thursday morning.

In a laudable attempt to ease the city's traffic congestion Mayor Wagner has called upon the automobile manufacturers to build smaller cars -- tactfully suggesting that big, long cars complicate traffic life. But abridgment of private cars alone will not solve the problem.
ALBANY, March 28 -- As Governor Harriman vacationed in Florida, his legal staff plunged today into the stack of 853 bills left him by the Legislature to sign or veto.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (UP) -- The House Appropriation Committee voted $750,000 today o finance the Government's New civil rights commission, ending a month-long delay.

NEW ORLEANS, March 28 (AP) -- A Mississippi man today filed a $2,000,000 damage suit against three cigarette firms, contending he had contracted cancer of the vocal cord through heavy smoking over a twenty-three-year period.
James F. Oates Jr., president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, called on industry yesterday to take an enlightened attitude toward alcoholics.

The city was accused yesterday of having assigned more than $2,000,000 in tenant relocation work to the Nassau Management Company under a contract drafted by a Bureau of Real Estate employe who was not a lawyer.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- Stockholders of the Diamond T Motor Car Company, Chicago truck maker, voted today to accept an offer of about $10,100,000 from White Motor Company of Cleveland for the inventories, tools, fixtures, patents and the goodwill of Diamond T.
BOWIE, Md., March 28 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's famed devil red racing silks will appear for the first time tomorrow at 44-year-old Bowie, and they'll be in a familiar role of favorite aboard Iron Liege.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 28 -- Michigan's Tony Tashnick accounted for the most spectacular developments -- positive and negative -- in today's second session of the thirty-fifth annual National Collegiate swimming championships.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UP) -- The duPont Foundation awarded its sixteenth annual radio and television awards tonight to stations KRON-TV, San Francisco and KARD-TV of Wichita, Kan., and Clifton Utley of Chicago, a commentator.

Through 200 years and many editions the Encyclopaedia Britannica has been a treasure chest of answers to an amazing variety of questions. In "The Great E. B.: The Story of the Encyclopaedia Britannica," Herman Kogan tells how the enterprise began, who made it flourish and what have been its successes and failures.

There isn't a finer-looking, better-equipped school in New York than Macon Junior High School at 141 Macon Street, Brooklyn. The positive impression made by this three - year - old, three - story tannish brick building is enhanced by the extreme poverty of its setting.
ALBANY, March 28 -- An aggregate of $1,185,000 has been voted for thirty-seven special studies and inquiries to be made by joint legislative committees.
A member of the Board of Education disagreed with Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt yesterday on the value of the city's special schools for delinquent pupils.

MINNEAPOIS, March 28 -- A Federal District Court jury was dismissed late today when it failed to reach a verdict in a $550,000 civil suit in which four University of Minnesota hospital physicians were charged with negligence in a heart operation.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A major scientific breakthrough was reported today for making extremely precise instruments to study, through light, the structure of the universe.
Virginia Babikian, soprano, and Oscar Ravina, violinist, gave a joint debut recital late yesterday afternoon in Town Hall under the auspices of the New York Madrigal Society.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -Average wholesale prices at the primary market level rose 0.2 per cent to 119.8 per cent of the 1947-49 average during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

LONDON, March 28 -- Politics is the family business of Mark Bonham Carter, whose victory for the Liberals in the Torrington by-election yesterday catapulted him into the political spotlight in Britain.

Since Senator Jenner's extremist bill to limit jurisdiction of the Supreme Court has been running into trouble, His brother-in-arms Senator Butler has come up with a proposal to accomplish the same ends by different means.
TWO antique mahogany chairs inherited from great-great-grandfather and a side table from cousin Emily caused Mr. and Mrs. "B" to look -- in the beginning -- for other antique mahogany pieces.

HAVANA, March 28 -- President Fulgencio Batista and his Cabinet tonight resolved to ask Congress to declare a "state of national emergency" and to grant special powers to the President to deal with the present situation.
BARCELONA, Spain, March 28 -- The anti-Government strike movement was reliably reported today to have spread to many of Barcelona's major textile plants.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Greater power for the Secretary of Defense and for the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff will be urged in the Administration's proposals for changes in the Pentagon's organization.
DETROIT, March 28 -- The General Motors Corporation said today that two additional assembly plants and one body assembly plant would be shut down all of next week.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 28 (AP) -- A glittering show of free skating artistry brought Dave Jenkins from behind and enabled him to capture his second straight national figure skating championship tonight.

W. W. Estates, Inc., an investing corporation, has taken title to the apartment building at 90 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, from 90 Prospect Park West, Inc. The property is 52 by 97 feet and is assessed at $41,000.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., March 28 (UP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower motored to their farm here today for a weekend of relaxation and a quiet pre-birthday celebration for their grandson David.
The Bronx grand jury investigating the illegal rebranding of radio and television tubes said yesterday that human life had been endangered when reprocessed tubes were sold to the medical profession.

Two vacant five-story buildings at 235-37 East Eightieth Street have been sold by Fourems, Inc., to an investor who plans to modernize the houses for occupancy next September. The property is 50 by 100 feet.
Throughout Holy Week most New York churches will conduct special programs and services.

LONDON, March 28 -- Aneurin Bevan, the Labor party's spokesman on foreign affairs, said tonight Britain should seek a summit conference on her own if the United States delayed or prevented four-power summit talks.

The New York Central Railroad plans to give its Chicago train the Commodore Vanderbilt a vacation again this summer. Effective April 27, the Twentieth Century Limited, which leaves New York at 6 P. M. daily, will be "consolidated" with the Commodore Vanderbilt.
DENVER, March 28 -- Problems that science teachers face in their classrooms are problems that run deep in American society, an educator suggested here today.
BARCELONA, Spain, March 28 -- About twenty-five Puerto Ricans studying medicine at Barcelona University have become victims of the wave of political and industrial unrest here.

DENVER, March 28 (AP) -- Maurice Travis, 47 years old, of San Pablo, Calif., former Denver union official convicted of falsely denying Communist party membership, was sentenced today to eight years' imprisonment and fined $4,000 by United States District Judge Lee Knous.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 28 (UP) -- Dr. Edward U. Condon, atomic scientist, predicted today that many thousands of persons would die in agony because of poisons released by hydrogen bomb tests.
VAL D'ISERE, France, March 28 (AP) -- Sally Deaver of Whitemarsh, Pa., missed a gate in today's final race of the Grand Prix de Savoie ski meet and lost a chance for the women's combined title.

Hundreds of costumed revelers presented the Americana theme at the Artists Equity Association's annual masque ball last night.

NORTH KEY LARGO, Fla., March 28 -- Capt. Tommy Gifford is a man who knows his own mind, finds it sufficient and doesn't want to know any other. It tells him with clear authority that too many saltwater fishermen use heavy line that they are not men enough to handle.
Dr. Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, did the "commercials" last night on an hour-long radio broadcast to promote the $82,500,000 drive known as A Program for Harvard College.

"Le Rouge et Le Noir," a French-made adaptation of Stendhal's classic novel, co-starring Gerard Philipe and Danielle Darrieux, has been scheduled to open on April 8 at the Fifty-second Street Trans-Lux Theatre, it was an nounced yesterday by Distributors Corporation of America.

Mickey Crawford, a cool young man from Saginaw, Mich., sharp-punched his way to a unanimous decision over Gil Turner of Philadelphia in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
ALBANY, March 28 -- The 1958 session of the Legislature, which had been billed as an interparty Donnybrook, closed quietly this week on a note of compromise.
A Jewish scholar prophesied last night that American Judaism would be united within the next fifty years.

SOARING meat prices contribute significantly to the record high cost of living today. And meat takes the biggest bite out of the weekly food budget, as every penny-conscious shopper knows. What can be done to keep expenditures for that important food within reasonable limits ?

LONDON, March 28 -- A four-point plan for promoting the political advancement and social integration of all races in the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland was published today by the National Executive of the Labor party.
MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, B. W. I., March 28 -- The outstanding impression left after a two-week visit to Cuba is that Havana is ripe for rebellion.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 28 -- Dr. Bernard Schwartz asserted tonight that the "real work" of administrative agencies began after the hearings on cases. Then, the commissioners retired to country clubs to decide how to vote, he declared.
ALBANY, March 28 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- High military sources at the Pentagon today described the nation's moon exploration plans as limited in scope and imagination.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28 -- Columbia Pictures intends to produce only a limited number of productions" in the future, with new policy plans calling for "a majority of the product to be produced by independents financed by the company."

We have commented on the quality of the New York Legislature's product. We would now like to commend the Legislature and its leadership on the way it did its work. The statistics of the recently completed session tell part of the story.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 28 -- The pro-Jakarta Medan radio in North Sumatra said tonight 500 rebel soldiers in that region had surrendered so far to Indonesian Government troops.

My friend Lambert Fairchild in his letter to you published March 25 abandoned his usual accuracy, possibly as a result of his prejudice against the system of Proportional Representation. He stated that in the election of our first City Council in the Borough of Brooklyn a Communist was elected on the Communist party ticket, but that no Republican was elected.

Six one-year journalism scholarships valued at $2,500 each were announced yesterday by the Inter-American Press Association Scholarship Fund, Inc. The Latin-American winners will study in this country and the United States winners will study in Latin America.

CAIRO, March 28 -- Today's most influential Arab leader, Gamal Abdel Nasser, will soon make a state visit to the Soviet Union. The political consequences of this trip are both predictable and immense.
Many persons entertained last night in connection with the thirteenth Bal des Berceaux at the Sheraton-East, formerly the Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Secretary of Labor called on Congress today for quick approval of the Administration's "simple" plan for temporary Federal aid for the jobless whose unemployment insurance has expired.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 28 (AP) -- Cleveland's manager, Bobby Bragan, put on a pinch-hitters' parade in the eighth and ninth innings today and the Indians scored a 9-8 victory over the San Francisco Giants in a wild exhibition game.
ALL over the land plans are simmering for Easter Sunday. Easter bonnets are hatching, the eggs are boiling and children are being fitted for their new spring coats.
AFTER nine years of living abroad with other people's furniture Mr. and Mrs. "A" settled down with their own last April.

LONDON, March 28 -- Stock market prices improved moderately today. They were helped by favorable dividend statements from several leading industrial concerns, notably Imperial Chemical Industries, but volume remained small.
Herman (Hymie the Mink) Wollman started court action yesterday to force District Attorney Frank S. Hogan to return records that were seized in an investigation of illegal boxing activities.
Two Canadian issues -- debentures of Ontario and Edmonton, Alberta -- will share the spotlight in the public market for new capital here next week.

Discharges from state mental hospitals in New York have increased for the third consecutive year, Dr. Henry Brill said yesterday. Dr. Brill is assistant commissioner of the State Department of Mental Hygiene.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 26 -- Two months after her revolution, Venezuela is a land of hope and uncertainty.
Prices of cotton moved 3 points off to 6 points up yesterday in moderate trading on the New York Cotton Exchange. One point equals 5 cents a bale.
Ray H. Sullivan, a Ford Motor Company vice president, told science teachers yesterday that in their field it was "time for a model change."

THE slogan on the announcement read, "Let's Cheer This Rutgers Team to Victory." The "team" for which support was being requested was the Rutgers University Choir, and the "victory" was a performance of Bach's Passion According to St. Matthew.

KINGSTON, N. Y., March 28 -- Seventeen persons were injured today when a Greyhound bus struck the rear of an automobile and swerved off into a ditch on Route 9W about a mile north of here. Four persons were hospitalized. The others were treated for cuts and released.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Sale of The Army-Navy-Air Force Journal to leRoy Whitman, editor, and Mrs. Dorothy Cone Brown, general manager, was announced today by the John Callan O'Laughlin trust. The trust is administered by the executive committee of The Gridiron Club, an organization of Washington correspondents.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Navy scientists seeking ways to harness the hydrogen-bomb reaction for power production have been able to heat gases to indicated temperatures of more than a million degrees.
A West Side landlord yesterday lost his fight against a law room of dwellings converted into rooming houses.

DETROIT, March 28 (AP) -- Motor vehicle output this week is expected to consist of 93,167 cars and 17,701 trucks, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. Last week, 80,560 cars and 15,797 trucks were built. In the like 1957 week, 130,233 cars and 22,479 trucks were produced.
We're in a recession. I don't like it. Nobody likes it. Is there any way out except to backtrack on the road by which we came in?
A report that the Ghana Marketing Board sold large quantities of cocoa bolstered futures prices yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange.

On the theory that two-thirds of a possible loaf is better than the certainty of no loaf at all, we are encouraged by the Senate's approval of a mild bill to control billboards along part of the new Federal interstate highway system.

Of the many cases of exposed pipes in the home, those under the bathroom basin are probably the ugliest in appearance. Since this occurs in a vital storage space, why not use it as such? The extra toiletries and bathroom supplies would find a convenient home if this area were enclosed.

OTTAWA, March 28 -- Premier Leslie Frost of Ontario threw the support of his powerful Ontario Conservative organization behind Prime Minister John Diefenbaker today in the closing phase of the Federal election campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- A. L. Dougherty, contractor, said today that the United save $250,000 to States would $350,000 by his purchase of used equipment from himself for a big highway job in Cambodia.
RABAT, Morocco, March 28 -- Four important leaders of the province of Mauritania in French West Africa pledged fealty today to King Mohamed V of Morocco.

Superintendent of Schools William Jansen notified the city's school principals yesterday that they could retain their power to suspend troublesome pupils until the end of the current school term, June 27.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Two members of the Federal Communications Commission called today for Congressional action to speed its decisions.

CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- One moderate burst of selling clipped about a cent a bushel off new crop wheat futures in early dealings today on the Board of Trade. But the selling met stiff resistance at that point.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 28 (Reuters) -- A decision by the Australian Government to buy British rather than American and French-made airliners for two of Australia's major airlines came under fire today from top Australian air officials.

A recent study indicates that children of divorced parents suffer less from psychosomatic ailments, are less inclined toward delinquency and have a better relationship with their parents than children whose parents quarrel perpetually.

LARAMIE, Wyo., March 28 (AP) -- Iowa State held a 19-17 lead over Oklahoma State tonight at the end of the quarterfinal round in the National Collegiate wrestling championships.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that the city-owned workhouse at New Hampton Farms in Delaware County would be made available to the state for the care and rehabilitation of juvenile delinquents.
Nikita S. Khrushchev has publicly grasped all the power levers once held by Stalin, but the question remains whether he is actually another Stalin.
Deposits in the nation's 520 mutual savings banks increased $149,000,000 in February to a record total of $32,066,000,000, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

BYRON BROWNE, whose recent paintings are at Grand Central Moderns, 1018 Madison Avenue, is one of the contemporary artists for whom Picasso still remains a vital inspiration and not a monument to be venerated in museums.
A police official testified yesterday that in twenty-two years on the force he had "never witnessed an act of police brutality."
Annabelle Brack a 19-year-old freshman at Finch College, fell or jumped to her death yesterday from a ninth floor window at the college, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street, the police reported.
Harold Seletsky, assisted by a small group of musicians, gave a recital of clarinet music last night in Carnegie Recital Hall.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Administration's proposal to share secrets of atomic weapons with allies ran into an unexpected delay today in Congress.

Events today: "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 2; "Ariadne on Naxos," Juilliard Concert Hall, 3; Randolph Singers, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; "Faust," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "The Barber of Seville," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:15; "La Forza del Destino," Opera Workshop, Public School 75, West End Avenue at Ninety-fifth Street, 8; New York Philharmonic, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; American Mandolin Orchestra, Town Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- The Navy bestowed an official parting pat today on its only Very Important Dog. This is the young ,husky named Bravo who was born and raised in the Antarctic.
GOLDENS BRIDGE, N. Y., March 28 -- Ten miles more of high-speed road for New York motorists bound for the Berkshires and western New England are planned by the State Department of Public Works.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- After ten weeks of Senate hearings into the "precarious" financial condition of the nation's railroads, the Interstate Commerce Commission and railroad creditors took the stand today.
TAMPA, Fla., March 28 (UP) -- Bob Rush became the first Milwaukee Braves' pitcher to go the route this spring as he stopped the Chicago White Sox, 11 -- 2, today, on a five-hitter.

Most of the action in yesterday's session of the stock market was in a few specialties disturbed by rumors. The major groups moved little and most of them, with oils and pharmaceuticals the main exceptions, moved down. The close showed a small loss.

A bulldozer, cutting a ponderous swath in a road-building operation at Yazur, about five miles from Tel Aviv, Israel, sliced into a cemetery more than 5,000 years old. Its whereabouts had eluded an archaeologist for years.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28 -- This was Sunshine Festival Day in St. Petersburg, but it wasn't exactly a glittering success for the Yankees. In fact, Manager Cookie Lavagetto and his supposedly forlorn Senators did a most surprising job in taking a lot of sunshine out of the usually merry life of Casey Stengel.
A live two-hour telecast of Roman Catholic and Protestant Easter services will be presented by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Sunday morning, April 6.

ALBANY, March 28 -- The Board of Regents organized today two new groups to assist with the educational television program that will be initiated in New York City next fall.
A Presidential fact-finding board studying a three-way dispute between Eastern Air Lines and its pilots and flight engineers may turn to the pilots' side of the controversy next week.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Walter P. Reuther stormed today at his political foe, Senator Barry Goldwater. He cried "smear" when the Arizona Republican exhibited a picture of union violence in the 1941 Ford strike. The incident broke what had been a relatively calm, all-day question - and - answer period for the president of the United Automobile Workers at a hearing of the Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 28 -- President Tito of Yugoslavia spent the last two days in confidential discussions with Janos Kadar, chief of the Hungarian Communist party, in a hunting lodge near the Yugoslav town of Karageorgevo.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy shook up the tenth inspection division in Harlem yesterday in an investigation of alleged police protection for policy racketeers. He said he had found "great laxity in administration."
BONN, Germany, March 26 -- Work has begun at Wilhelmshaven on a 380-mile pipeline system designed to pump some forty million tons of oil a year to Rhineland refineries.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., March 28 -- A wave of vandalism, attributed by the police to youths from good families and expensive private schools, has aroused this community.
LONDON, March 28 -- The dollar price of gold tonight was at its highest level in London since the gold market here reopened four years ago.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., March 29 -- After a sixteen-year interruption, Mrs. Charles J. Cole is back carrying books, listening to lectures and doing homework.

PINK flamingo statuettes, a plaster elf painted in candy-store colors, the fountainful of configurations from Greek mythology -- these notorious sights have given garden statuary unsavory connotations in the minds of many gardeners. ABIDJAN, French West Africa, March 23 -- A trend toward socialism and one-party systems marks the political life of French West Africa.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 29 (AP) -- A tired but enthusiastic group of fifty persons completed the first eighteen miles tonight in a "walk for peace" to New York City.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 15 -- An account of what happened in hundreds of suburban towns in the population explosion following World War II is typified in a survey report of this community's experience.

The twelfth annual egg-rolling contest to be conducted by the Department of Parks will be held on the Great Lawn, Central Park, between Eightieth and Eighty-fourth Streets, at 2 P. M. next Saturday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 29 -- The voice of experience finally spoke and peremptorily ended a somewhat aimless dugout discussion the other day as to what qualities make for greatness in a catcher. The voice belonged to Joe Garagiola, a droll fellow who once talked for free while catching for the Cardinals, Cubs, Pirates and Giants.

THE UNITED STATES 3-cent stamp to be released at Chicago on May 31 in commemoration of the International Geophysical Year carries a design which is inspirational rather than scientific, according to the artist, Ervine Metzl of New York, a former president of the Society of Illustrators.

LARAMIE, Wyo., March 29 (UP)-- Oklahoma State University won its twentieth national collegiate wrestling championship tonight with 77 points, a record-breaking total, beating the mark of 73 set by Oklahoma in the 1955 championship.

Because of the hour at which brunch is served -- generally between 11 A. M. and 1 P. M. -- it can be the most unhurried of meals.

IT is a revealing symptom of our times that the problem of identity in recent years has claimed the attention of so many psychiatrists, social psychologists and social philosophers. For David Reisman the most representative man in our chaotic era is "the other directed person," the individual who develops sensitive antennae to perceive the heterogeneous opinions and rapidly changing values of his environment and who makes a major effort to adjust to them.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 29 -- With the help of a record-equaling performance by Tony Tashnick, Michigan retained the team title in the thirty-fifth annual National Collegiate swimming championships today.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- On the long, devious, treacherous road to the summit, the Soviet Union is scoring propaganda victory after victory. No matter how it turns its policies, Washington finds itself reeling and from reverse to reverse on the propaganda front.

The yearning for mild days and the look and feel of spring is as natural to man as March begins to merge with April as is the urge of a migrating bird to fly north. That is why we watch hopefully for the big signs and make so much of the little ones.

Drury Lane Theatre has, indeed, a colorful history and Richard Brinsley Sheridan, both as its manager and as the author of "The School for Scandal," contributed some of that history's most exciting pages.

SONGBERD'S GROVE, a dreary row of once-elegant old houses in London, became the scene of exciting events when Martin, the 12-year-old newcomer to No. 7, decided not to be bullied by Lennie in No. 1. Mudface and Rusty and others liked being members of Lennie's gang, but Martin thought they were "silly poops" and Geneva, who lived upstairs at No. 7, was a girl of spirit who shared his opinion.

Nikita S. Khrushchev gathered into his hands publicly last week all the reins of Soviet power. THE state's new point system to force habitual traffic violators off the road will go into effect Tuesday. It is an administrative change worked out by Joseph P. Kelly, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, at the suggestion of Governor Harriman, and it reshuffles the scoring method on traffic penalties so as to lay greater stress on violations by moving cars, such as speeding, passing red lights, and similar offenses.

But even $4,250,000 does not represent the true cost of repairing these buildings, which include some of the most famous architectural works in England.

OTTAWA, March 29 -- For the second time, nuclear scientists from across the world will meet in Canada Monday in the hope of charting a way to peace.

BOSTON, March 29 -- The state of American education is a scandal, a Cornell University professor said today. He spoke at a New England Regional Cornell Conference attended by 150 persons at the Somerset Hotel here.

ATHENS, March 29 -- An electoral law providing for "reinforced representation" was approved today by two-thirds of the Greek Deputies who were elected just over two years ago on a modified majority system.

JAZZ, a form often associated with gin and high living, is acquiring new respectability by means of television. BISMARCK, N. D., March 29 -- North Dakota Republicans rejected late last night the bid of William Langer for a fourth term in the United States Senate.

CONTRIBUTING to the new, weighty look of furniture today is the revival of interest in the Renaissance period. While decorators dust off ornate Renaissance antiques, furniture designers borrow the silhouettes and carved ornament of the period for simpler, scaled-down versions. The trend, which first appeared at last June's wholesale furniture show in Chicago, was established by additional collections shown at the recent January display.
