Oil rigs pierce the underwater soil to the petroleum far below. A geologist says one of the most difficult things is to drill a dry hole here.
The United States is "the hottest place in the world" in terms of radioactivity in the atmosphere, according to Dr. Willard F. Libby, scientist member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

A National Airlines plane, approaching New York International Airport with fifty-eight persons aboard, narrowly averted a head-on collision yesterday. Jack A. Guthrie, the pilot, said he put the four-engine DC-6 into a 100-foot dive when he saw a two-engine plane flying directly toward it, just ahead.

The State Department has lifted the passport of William Worthy Jr., a press and radio correspondent who, it says, visited Communist China and Hungary "in violation of the limiting and restricting endorsements contained in the passport and in willful disregard of declared United States foreign policy."

LARAMIE, Wyo., March 30 (UP) -- Oklahoma State University won its twentieth national collegiate wrestling championship last night with 77 points, a record-breaking total, beating the mark of 73 set by Oklahoma in the 1955 championship.

Down at Fort Bragg, N. C. today, the Eighty-second Airborne Division will pass in review before its war-time chief. This will be the last review that "Slim Jim" Gavin, Lieutenant General, United States Army, will take in uniform.

The Associated Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Associations of Greater New York announced yesterday that a community center would be constructed this summer on the grounds of Montefiore Hospital, Bainbridge Avenue and 210th Street in the Bronx.
Two executives of the Kudner Agency, Inc., have resigned and the executive staff has been realigned for the second time in recent months.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 30 (UP) -- Ken Lehman's bases-filled walk to Dale Long today enabled the Chicago Cubs to gain a 2-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles in a twelve-inning exhibition baseball game played before 3,067 fans.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. March 30 (AP) -- A concerted attempt to oust J. Norman Lewis the attorney for the major league baseball players the past five years, apparently failed today. Several clubs that had been expected to cast negative ballots voted to retain Lewis as counsel for another year.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 30 -- Glen Foster was victorious with his dinghy, Ordeal, today in the next-to-last regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club frostbite championship season.
Judy Garland was notified last night by a Brooklyn night club that she had voided her $25,000-a-week contract by failing to complete a scheduled appearance.

THE photograph printed at the right of these words conveys remarkably well the emotion felt by many persons when they are reminded of the glory that was Greece. It shows all that has survived of the temple of Poseidon at Sunium -- only a few ruins, but their beauty, grace and dignity suggest a perfect whole of which they were once a part.

Joseph Schuster, former first 'cellist of the New York Philharmonic, appeared as soloist with his old colleagues Saturday night in Carnegie Hall. The performance was under the baton of the Philharmonic's associate conductor, Franco Autori.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 30 -- Western governments and international agencies distributed $5,510,000,000 in economic aid to under-developed lands in the 1954-56 period, according to a United Nations report published today.

PEIPING, March 30 (Reuters) -- China's 2,000-strong Salvation Army still is spreading the Gospel, but in muted tones that contrast strikingly with its brass brands and street corner meetings in other lands.

A personal report on Communist Poland by Christine Hotchkiss, entitled "Home to Poland," will be published next Friday by Farrar, Strauss Cudahy. Mrs. Hotchkiss, a member of the Reader's Digest editorial staff, was born in Poland and lived there until World War II.
The Government's farm program was attacked sharply yesterday as favoring large corporate farms over small-farm owners.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Total assets of this country's national banks increased by $4 billion in the final quarter of 1957 and deposits climbed by $5 billion, Ray M. Gidney, controller of the currency, reported today.
A Brooklyn man with a police record for gambling was shot dead last night. The body was found in an automobile parked in front of a Sheepshead Bay lumber yard.

CLEVELAND, March 30 (AP) -- Current demands on education are too staggering to be taken care of through present state and local resources, Michigan's Gov. G. Mennen Williams told a convention of the American Association of School Administrators in a speech here tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- United States military officials are worried about the continuation of hostilities in Indonesia. They have been particularly disturbed by reports of serious fighting after the initial inactivity that followed the formation of the rebel government Feb. 15.

The Mamenic Line, a six-year-old Nicaraguan - flag venture, has set up a new company to serve as general agent in the operations of its fleet. The new company, the Mamenic International Corporation, will soon open headquarters at 26 Broadway.
A medical screening of 297 husbands and 290 wives, all apparently healthy, detected evidence of unsuspected cancer in eighteen, the New York City Cancer Committee said yesterday.
BOSTON, March 30 (UP) -- The Boston Celtics routed the St. Louis Hawks, 136 -- 112, today and tied the National Basketball Association best-of-seven championship series at one game apiece.

LONDON, March 30 -- The United States-British good-offices team attempting to settle the dispute between France and Tunisia is studying the possibility of having United Nations observers stationed on the Tunisian-Algerian border.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Monday, March 31 (Reuters) -- The United States will evacuate its Little America Antarctic base, Rear Admiral George Dufek, commander of Operation Deepfreeze, said here today.
HONG KONG, March 30 -- LaRance Sullivan, turncoat American soldier, who had lived for four years and two months in Communist China, was either unwilling or unable to tell much about it here today.

Two floors in the office building rising at 200 East Forty-second Street have been leased by Joseph Durst, the owner, to the National Council on Compensation Insurance, an organization of 317 insurance companies in thirty-eight states.

GRENOBLE, France, March 28 -- This university city and the Alpine region surrounding it have become an important showcase for the extraordinary revival of economic and intellectual vigor some parts of France have experienced in the last few years.

MOSCOW, March 30 -- A major foreign policy statement by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko will be one of the highlights of tomorrow's session of the Supreme Soviet. The theme of his address will be the question of halting nuclear weapons tests.
Alcoholism was singled out yesterday by a Jesuit priest as a major problem confronting the liquor industry.
LONDON, March 30 (AP) -- Princess Margaret flew back from West Germany today and rushed off to see Queen Elizabeth II at Windsor Castle.

The Marine Cooks and Stewards Union has offered the facilities of its recently established training school to the Office of Civil Defense for use in emergencies. The member union of the Pacific District of the Seafarers International Union owns a 380-acre tract in Santa Rosa, seventy miles north of San Francisco.
When disaster strikes furniture, the damage often can be repaired quickly and with a little skill.

OTTAWA, March 30 -- Canada's voters will decide tomorrow whether to retain Prime Minister John Diefenbaker and the Conservatives or give the Liberals under their new leader, Lester B. Pearson, another chance to rule.
The collective pocketbook of New York State's manufacturing workers was one-half billion dollars lighter in 1957 than in 1956.

PARIS, March 30 -- The sword duel between the Marquis de Cuevas, ballet company proprietor, and Serge Lifar, retired ballet dancer, ended today in tears and embraces. But not before the 72-year-old Marquis had lightly pinked his 52-year-old antagonist on the right forearm in the seventh minute of what may well have been the most delicate encounter in the history of French dueling.

WOODBURY, L. I., March 30 -- Full crews of tree surgeons are working daily to cut out or repair 100,000 trees destroyed or severely damaged on Long Island's North Shore estates in the last great snow and ice storm of the winter.
ZURICH, Switzerland, March 30 -- No positive market trend developed here last week.
A man on Twenty-first Street has to drive to the other side of the street every day so that the police won't put a parking ticket on his boat.
CHICAGO, March 30 -- A concerted campaign "against the forces of paganism, dictatorship and hate" was proposed tonight by more than 1,200 leaders of the Combined Campaign for American Reform Judaism.

The six-story building at 433 Fifth Avenue, near Thirty-ninth Street, has been purchased by Bill Meyer-Fifth Avenue, Inc., home furnishings, for occupancy with a retail store and wholesale showrooms. It is 25 by 125 feet and was bought from a partnership known as 431-33 Fifth Avenue.
The fortieth anniversary of the proclamation of the independence of the Byelorussian Democratic Republic was observed here yesterday.
Staff changes in two major shipping lines and in one of the area's maritime training institutions were announced over the week-end.
The International Terminal Operating Company, Inc., is "extremely surprised" at the severity of the Waterfront Commission in suspending its stevedoring license, a company official said yesterday.
The Ford Foundation announced the grant of $5,375,000 more yesterday to Resources for the Future, Inc., for expanded research and education in the proper use of natural resources.
Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday expressed his opposition to a tax cut to resolve the current recession. He spoke on "Between the Lines," televised over WABD.

THE walls of the American home are due for a shake-up. Just as professionals and amateurs are getting the hang of arranging a dozen or more paintings of different shapes, sizes and subject matter on a wall, a new dimension is being introduced into the picture.

PARIS, March 30 -- A French Foreign Ministry official indicated tonight that the stationing of United Nations observers along the Algerian-Tunisian frontier could not be excluded as a possibility in helping to settle the dispute between France and Tunisia.
The X-15 rocket plane -- scheduled to carry a man into the near reaches of space next year -- will turn a glowing red as it plunges back into the earth's atmosphere.
The General Dynamics Corporation and its subsidiaries had record sales and earnings last year, Frank Pace Jr., president, reported in the annual statement released for publication today.

CAIRO, March 30 -- By self-admission Nasser is a conspirator. He enjoys intrigue. He boasts he outsmarted King Saud and "nationalized" the latter's bribe money in a recent plot. Delightedly, he confesses that he runs clandestine radios and plants agents in the stations of his enemies.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., March 29 -- A packet of yeast for testing the reaction of living organisms to the absence of gravity was carried in the Vanguard satellite destroyed Feb. 5.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The United States has made no effort to decipher data from Soviet earth satellites because it expects the Russians to supply the information, an official said today.
Subliminal advertising -- the pitch to a set owner's subconcious -- was tested last night on Channel 9 during the debut of a trade program called "Ad World."

THE world's largest geo-physical relief globe, hand-painted so that its oceans, mountains, polar snow caps, deserts, canyons, rivers and valleys look pretty much as they would from a Terra ship in outer space, is almost finished in a ninth-floor loft at 48 West Twenty-fifth Street.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Link-Belt Company announced today that it would build one of the largest automatic coal preparation plants in the nation for the Clinchfield Coal Company which operates mines in Virginia.
A detective and a patrolman have received honorable-mention citations -- the highest city police awards -- for heroic service last year.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. yesterday threatened Governor Harriman with defeat this fall if he provides state funds for Alexander Hamilton Houses, projected for his Harlem Congressional district by the City Housing Authority.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., March 30 -- Mrs. Victor Hugo-Vidal Jr. of Bedford Village, Geoffrey Craig of Rye and Jill and John Klein of Bedford Hills were chief winners at the Sunnyfield Farm horse show today.
Four new films are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
A teacher tried to take her life yesterday in the apparent belief that she had done nothing about the emotional disturbance of an 11-year-old former pupil who has confessed drowning two playmates.

James J. Flynn challenges the accuracy of Mr. Truman's statement that President Roosevelt "intervened and brought about a peace settlement" of the Russo-Japanese War, and affirms, by quoting Dr. Thomas A. Bailey, that Japan "secretly asked Roosevelt to act as mediator."

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Congressional Democrats continued their drive for anti-recession legislation today as Congress approached a ten-day Easter recess that will give members a first-hand look at economic conditions across the country.
ROME, March 30 (UP) -- Pope Pius XII warned nations today that a new world war would be total, terrifying and "disastrous for all humanity."
Mayor Wagner declared last night that the United States would not achieve any success in the Middle East unless "we are clear in our own minds as to who our friends are, and who are our enemies."

DETROIT, March 30 (UP) -- Andre Pronovost's unassisted goal in the first overtime period lifted the National Hockey League champion Montreal Canadiens to a 2-1 "sudden-death" victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight. It was Montreal's third straight triumph in the Stanley Cup semi-finals.

Oliver La Farge, president of the Association of American Indian Affairs, charged yesterday that the Interior Department tolerated anti-Indian activities in the Bureau of Indian Affairs on both national and local levels.

PITTSBURGH, March 30 -- Steel order volume showed no improvement last week. With no backlog to help support it, steel production was receding to a point where it would meet the lower level of new business. As a result, the production rate has declined in recent weeks, despite some reports of stabilization.

Clyde Pangborn is dead. And he died not in the wreckage of a crashed plane but in a hospital from natural causes. His uncanny skill as an aviator had cheated death hundreds of times. In forty years of flying he never had a serious accident.

The steamship charter market continues in a state of depression. The last week was marked by an increase in activity but only at new lows in rates, forcing one of the sharpest index drops of this year.

Two conductors, three pianists and a small orchestra shared the stage of the Hunter College Auditorium on Saturday night. The sequence started when Boris Goldovsky led the orchestra through Weber's "Peter Schmoll" Overture.

When Frank Efinger, former middle distance star runner at DeWitt Clinton High, Andover and Yale, went to Avon Old Farms School at Avon, Conn., for the first time two years ago, he received two surprises.

Housing starts in New York State declined in February for the twenty-eighth consecutive month, State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray said yesterday. The figure, he added, is the lowest for the month in nine years.
DAME MYRA HESS played the solo parts in two Mozart piano concertos with a chamber orchestra under Alexander Schneider yesterday afternoon at the New School for Social Research.

William Lombardy of New York and Eric Eliskases of Argentina played to a thirty-one-move draw in their fourteenth-round game yesterday at the chess tournament in Mar del Plata, Argentina, according to a report received through South American news sources.

IN a department store sale of fashions, everyone gets the best of the bargain. The customer profits from the price cut, the store cleans out slow-moving merchandise and, if it is a "special purchase sale," the manufacturer unloads a surplus of fabric.
A Navy radio telescope in Washington has been equipped with an amplifying device to enable men to "see" Venus ten times closer.

The first performances of three American chamber works were presented at midnight Saturday in Carnegie Recital Hall. The performers were the Beaux-Arts String Quartet, Emery Davis, clarinetist, and Sterling Hunkins, 'cellist.

Phil Watson brooded and plotted all yesterday, deeply concerned with devising a plan to improve the chances of his New York Rangers in the current National Hockey League play-off series with the Boston Bruins. He claims he came up with a plan but wouldn't spring it.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 30 -- Like the host who is afraid dinner guests will arrive before he has put on his necktie, the Brussels World's Fair of 1958 is frantically dressing for an official opening only eighteen days away.

It seems odd to me that in all of the discussions pertaining to alleviating the present recession through various income adjustments little or nothing has been said concerning the reduction of the rates in the higher brackets.
MIRIAM BURTON, soprano, who was heard on Broadway in "The House of Flowers" and off Broadway in "Simply Heavenly," late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall gave her first New York recital.
ONE of the most unusual collections of recipes to cross this desk in several months is a many-faceted volume entitled "Look and Cook" (Brown Bigelow).

Lazard Freres Co. announced over the week-end that Richard H. Mansfield and Edward G. Miller would become partners in the investment banking concern on May 1, subject to approval of the New York Stock Exchange.

KOENIGSWINTER, Germany, March 30 -- The political profits in a pull-back of opposing military forces in Europe might justify the increased military risk for the West, Sir John Harding, former Chief of the Imperial General Staff, said today.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- For five days the question tormenting Washington has been: What sent John Foster Dulles in riotous anger to the Paris barricades in his student days?

The sacrifice of the twenty-four lives in the recent Broadway loft building fire will not have been utterly in vain if it stirs the government and people of New York to heroic action to prevent anything of the sort from ever happening again -- not to mention something even worse.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) -- The Government issued a set of instructions and safety measures today for young students experimenting with rockets and other missiles.

It is highly gratifying that the basic forces which make public opinion and law in New York State are all moving in the same direction. I refer to the editorial in The New York Times of March 13 and to the initial appropriation by the State Legislature of $369,000 for the Board of Regents to be used for educational television.

The establishment of an advisory review board to help in resolving disputes over procurements made by the Military Clothing and Textile Supply Agency, Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot, was announced yesterday by Maj. Gen. Webster Anderson, U. S. A., executive director.

Five high school students voiced agreement yesterday on the New York Times Youth Forum that educational opportunities must be increased for the African people to speed their integration into the free world.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -There is little chance that Congress will vote $100,000,000 for the Administration's plan to settle war damage claims against Germany and make partial repayment for German property seized here in World War II.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 30 (UP) -- More than 300 persons today attended the twenty-seventh annual Knute Rockne Memorial mass and breakfast on the Notre Dame campus.
ALBUQUERQUE, March 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Eunice Sally Brillhart, wife of a service man, who was freed last summer from a life sentence in the death of her three children, died here Friday.
The Eisenhower Administration may have lost the initiative in the disarmament deadlock to the Soviet Union, Adlai E. Stevenson said yesterday.

Gross operating income of the Sinclair Oil Corporation rose to a record $1,251,069,054 last year from $1,180,101,830 in 1956, P. C. Spencer, chairman and chief executive officer has reported to 115,500 stockholders.

If we could have assurance that never again would there be a test of a nuclear weapon in any country this would be spring indeed. We are sure that it is not with any gladness that our scientists and strategists get ready to do some more experimenting with H-bombs in the vicinity of the Eniwetok Atoll.

The New York Hakoahs defeated the Philadelphia Uhriks, 4 -- 1, at Zerega Oval, the Bronx, yesterday, to take the lead in the American Soccer League. At half-time the victors led, 2 -- 0. The visitors did not tally until five minutes from the end.

WILMINGTON, N. C., March 30 (UP) -- Howie Johnson, an insurance salesman who turned professional golfer, tied Arnold Palmer for first place today in the Azalea open golf tournament, setting up an 18-hole play-off tomorrow for the top prize of $2,000.
ROCKLAND LAKE, N. Y., March 30 -- The Palisades Interstate Park Commission will acquire Rockland Lake and most of the land at its edge to add to the park facilities at Hook Mountain.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) -- Two films dealing with the life of former President Hoover will be presented to the Library of Congress tomorrow by Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, acting as chairman of the Herbert Hoover Birthplace Foundation, Inc.

TAMPA, Fla., March 30 -- In the estimation of Birdie Tebbetts, a not very neutral observer, the most valuable pitcher in the National League for 1956 was Hershell (Buster) Freeman, a relief operative for the Cincinnati Redlegs.
The League of Off-Broadway Theatres, which claims to have a membership of fifty theatre owners, managers and producers, is getting ready to open war on Actors Equity.
A series of major air route awards, establishing four new turnkline services into Florida from Great Lakes cities and St. Louis, were voted last week by the Civil Aeronautics Board.
NEW ORLEANS, March 29 -- This city's $20,000,000 International Airport expansion program is now three-fourths complete.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 30 (AP) -- Queen Carol Heiss took an unroyal ribbing from her figure-skating friends today for a mid-ice fall, but it was in good fun and a tribute all its own.

Most people never know the feeling of community in the hugeness of New York City. This lack of community feeling is a basic cause of many New York City problems. Greenwich Village is a rare exception -- a community whose inhabitants have a feeling of belonging.

Some tickets still remain for the season's second theatre benefit of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House. The event is the April 10 performance of "Say, Darling" at the ANTA Theatre. The tickets may be obtained at the beneficiary, 331 East Seventieth Street.

BATAVIA, N. Y., March 30 (UP) -- A former state assemblyman from New York City announced the start of a new letter-writing campaign among Americans of Italian descent to defeat the Communists in Italy's Parliamentary elections in May.
SINGAPORE, March 30 (AP) -- Sixty-five Indonesians, including sixteen Government soldiers, arrived in Singapore today under the "protective custody" of twenty-eight Dutch marines.

TRENTON, March 30 -- Len Sutton, a 32-year-old automobile salesman from Portland, Ore., won his first 100-mile United States Auto Club National championship race today. Sutton got the checkered flag after 1 hour 2 minutes 48 seconds of thrilling action before a cheering crowd of 10,000 at the Trenton Speedway.
"SEE IT NOW" presented yesterday afternoon an eighty-five-minute program of compelling and frightening import -- the hazards of radioactive fall-out.

Lois Marshall, soprano, sang a recital at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night. The event was one of the Young Artists Series financed through a special grant from Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, March 30 -- Prime Minister Tengku Abdul Rahman said today that if the Communists succeeded in establishing supremacy in Malaya all Southeast Asia would be lost.
PARIS, March 30 -- A Rightwing leader of war veterans today easily won election to the National Assembly in the second and final round of a Paris by-election.
MOSCOW, March 30 -- Valery Klimov, 27-year-old Russian, was named winner today of the international Tchaikovsky violin competition. The final round of the two-week contest ended here last night.
Either cornstarch or flour may be used to thicken sauces and soups. Cornstarch gives a transparency such as that found in many Chinese dishes; flour gives an opaque look.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 30 -- The Netherlands Bank reduced the discount rate again last week from 4 1/2 to 4 per cent. This followed a similar reduction two months ago.
CHICAGO, March 30 (AP) -- Grain traders paraded in and out of the futures market last week, uncertain of their position as they gave various interpretations to developments from Washington.

Under the caption "Knife With Red Fluid" your issue of March 22 describes a patent that has been registered in Washington for a knife "that discharges a red liquid when the user squeezes a bulb in the handle. The object is to release the liquid when the point touches a playmate."
NEW DELHI, India, March 30 -- In the gritty and baking barrenness of the land of the warrior princes, India began today to build a canal that will turn a desert into a granary.
LONDON, March 30 -- Largely, because of some good company profits reports, the downward trend in the stock markets early last week was reversed toward the end.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 30 -- Tanks, heavy mortars and machine guns were used today in a new border flare-up between Israeli and Syrian forces over Israel's reclamation work at Lake Hula.

MADRID, March 30 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Fernando Maria de Castiella was reported to have left unexpectedly by plane tonight for the United States. Persons who saw the minister board a Spanish Iberia airliner a few minutes before 10 P. M. said he was accompanied by Eduardo Ibanez y Garcia de Velasco, Director General of African Affairs in the Foreign Ministry.
Cardinal Spellman presided yesterday at a solemn pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral that opened the observance of Holy Week.
CHICAGO, March 30 (AP) -- A group of white residents on the South Side held a street meeting today to protest the presence of Negro tenants in three buildings in the block.
MOSCOW, March 30 -- Georgians from the land of Stalin "took over" this capital last week.
HAVANA, March 30 -- In an atmosphere of fear and uncertainty, the Cuban people began the observance of Holy Week with Palm Sunday services in the churches of the island.
A Protestant clergyman urged Christians yesterday to "let Palm Sunday be a voice from Christ" protesting the nuclear arms race between the United States and the Soviet Union.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 30 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers today sent Pete Wojey, a pitcher, and a reported $20,000 to the Cleveland Indians for Milt Bolling, an infielder, and Vito Valentinetti, a pitcher.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., March 30 -- The gas equipment industry so far has weathered the recession with little, if any, change, Clifford V. Coons, president of the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association, said here today.
The old concept that the primary role of the New York metropolitan area is as expediter for goods made elsewhere has been deflated by a study just completed.
Passover Sunday was celebrated yesterday morning at the Community Church of New York, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street

Business is slow but the retailer's usual remedy, a spoonful of price-cutting, is not being used. The chief reason seems to be that the prices merchants pay are not only not coming down but are firm and showing signs of going higher.

Out on the West Coast there is a shy 18-year-old high school senior called The Hill, who looks a lot like Johnny Mathis, the popular singer; dresses in the tweediest tradition of the Ivy League, drives a souped-up 1950 Mercury and plays basketball.

Authorities identified yesterday the plane reported in a near-collision Sunday with a National Airlines DC-6. It was another National Airlines craft -- a twin-engined Convair with fifteen persons aboard.
Douglas Haskell, editor of Architectural Forum, last night criticized "the dirty little kind of life" that the city's "traffic hounds" were trying to offer the Washington Square area.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Army announced today a long-range program to reorganize and modernize National Guard and Army Reserve units.
Steel production this week is expected to fall to the lowest level in almost nine years, except for strikes and holiday periods.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, March 31 (UP) -- A Norwegian passenger ship carrying 1,300 persons caught fire and sank in the Indian Ocean tonight. A British freighter steamed to the scene and made a dramatic rescue of all those aboard but one.
Chesty little Ismael (Milo) Valenzuela rode his second daily double in three racing days at Jamaica yesterday.

Inflation of a sort has caught up with the New York Stock Exchange. Yesterday it announced several important Changes in listing requirements. A company that applies for listing must now have 400,000 Common shares in the hands of the public, instead of 300,000.

The nature of the proposals advanced by Senators Cooper and Kennedy in the Senate on March 25 with respect to India has not clearly emerged from press reports. Before accepting the view that their initiative is merely a wise and well-meant lost cause for this session of Congress it may be worth considering further exactly what is involved.
ALBANY, March 31 -- The state's point system for penalizing dangerous drivers becomes tougher tomorrow.

A Government anti-trust suit against the B. F. Goodrich Company and the Dayton Rubber Company, both of Ohio, was terminated yesterday in Federal Court here soon after it was filed. The action ended in a consent judgment signed by Judge Frederick vanPelt Bryan.

The Little Orchestra Society will have a single subscription series of eight concerts during its next season, it was announced yesterday by Thomas Scherman, conductor. This season the society had subscription series of four concerts each at Town Hall and Carnegie Hall.
In a fight marked by warnings from the referee and complaints from both corners about fouls, Rudy Sawyer scored a unanimous decision over Jimmy Peters at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 31 -- Israeli and Syrian forces resumed fighting today in the Hula valley.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 31 -- President Iskander Mirza dismissed tonight the 86-year-old Governor of East Pakistan on charges of having acted unconstitutionally.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 31 (UP) -- The Cleveland Indians tonight announced they had traded an outfielder, Gene Woodling; a utility man, Dick Williams, and a pitcher, Bud Daley, to the Baltimore Orioles for an outfielder, Larry Doby, and a hurler, Don Ferrarese.

Official records showed last night that March was as exceptionally wet as most persons in the metropolitan area thought it was. Light rain fell throughout most of the month's final day, but clearing weather was predicted for today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A Southern move to deprive the new Civil Rights Commission of operating funds was beaten tentatively in the House of Representatives today. A final vote will be taken tomorrow.
Today is April Fools Day. Accordingly, the New York Telephone Company will intercept calls to the Bronx Zoo for Messrs. Lion, Lyon, Bear, Baer, Baehr, Bayer, Fox, Wolf and Katz.
Freedom of the press is a prize that is never safely won or ever permanently lost. It is like a battle one must go on fighting, sometimes attacking, sometimes defending.
TRENTON, March 31 -- The Assembly adopted and sent to the Senate today a bill that would permit local housing authorities to build middle-income as well as low-income housing.
THERE will be some startling changes in men's hats this Easter. But look sharp, or you may miss being startled.

Contracts for future construction in the United States, usually considered a sensitive barometer of the economy, dipped 10 per cent in February below the corresponding month in 1957. It was the second consecutive month in which a 10 per cent decline was registered.

CHICAGO, March 31 (UP) -- George S. May said tonight a financial dispute with the Professional Golfers Association had forced him to cancel the All-American and the "world" tournaments, two of the richest events on the summer pro circuit.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits tonight urged the Government to provide an additional $500,000,000 of economic aid in the next five years for both Arab states and Israel to help hold the Middle East for democracy.
The promoters of chain letters and pyramid clubs are busy again, the Better Business Bureau warned yesterday. This time, the bureau said, they are using a new twist with United States savings bonds.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Eisenhower vetoed today legislation freezing for one year farm price supports and acreage allotments at 1957 levels.
The outbreak of Asian influenza last fall brought an estimated total of 850,000 cases to upstate New York, according to the State Health Department's annual report released yesterday.
TOKYO, March 31 -- Japan's anti-prostitution law goes into effect tomorrow. Brothel operators have closed their doors in Japan's red-light district, releasing 100,000 prostitutes.

Harold Roth, president of United States Hoffman Machinery Corporation, said yesterday that the long-discussed merger between his company and Continental Industries, Inc., of which Mr. Roth also is president, had been deferred. He said the merger at this time might become a burden to the managements of the two concerns.

The New York City Ballet has just scored an impressive triumph in Tokyo. An extra performance had to be scheduled. A class session for young Japanese ballet students was given. Critical acclaim was general.
OTTAWA, March 31 -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker led his Conservative party today to its greatest election victory in Canada's history.

FORT MYERS, Fla., March 31 -- It was more than just a no-hitter that Bob Friend of the Pirates was pitching against the Dodgers on one memorable occasion last year. Protecting a 1-0 lead, he came roaring into the eighth inning with a perfect game going for him, Tension was mounting everywhere except on the mound. Friend was calm and unperturbed.
A major primary battle is shaping up in the Bronx to wrest the Republican county leadership from Herman Winner. Mr. Winner took over the party reins last year after the death of John J. Knewitz.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Mobilization Officials said today that Government purchases of domestic lead for the long-term stockpile probably would end by mid-year.
Leo DeOrsey, a director of the Washington Senators, yesterday offered Congress a plan to save baseball from "being murdered by the big leagues."

A $1,250,000 admiralty action was filed yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court, against the owner of a 16,500-ton oil tanker that sank or damaged fourteen craft anchored in the Arthur Kill of Staten Island on March 22.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., March 31 (AP) -- The body of Dr. Lillian Starr, who taught archaeology at some of the foremost colleges in the East, remained unclaimed in a mortuary here today.

Plants, like the humans who grow and use them, don't like shock and stress. Heat spells, sudden cold snaps, prolonged rain, drought and a host of other vagaries of nature that affect humans also affect the plants.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Tuesday, April 1 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev is coming here tomorrow at the head of an impressive Soviet delegation, the Hungarian Government announced at midnight.

WILMINGTON, N. C., March 31 (AP) -- Howie Johnson, aided by a penalty stroke Arnold Palmer called against himself, gained the first major tournament victory of his professional golfing career today, winning the Azalea open play-off by one stroke.

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- Wheat futures slid off, but only moderately, on the Board of Trade today after President Eisenhower vetoed the measure which would have retained all 1957 farm price supports for 1958 crops.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- A sprightly New Jersey school teacher with a class of boisterous eighth-graders in tow was accorded special distinction here today.

Your columns are filled with the great debate on the shortcomings of American education. A recent poll of United States public opinion, cited by Elmo Roper, gives superior education as the outstanding reason for Russia's lead in satellites. Plans are advanced by faculty and laymen, including one by President Eisenhower, to produce more scientists and engineers lest the Russians continue to outflank us.
PARIS, March 31 -- The new note of the Western Big Three to the Soviet Union has the unreserved backing of the other members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
The Advertising Research Foundation has abandoned its proposed consumer magazine audience study. The program had raised considerable controversy in the magazine industry.
The Esso Research and Engineering Company has invented and developed a new polymer synthetic rubber it says can triple the life of key equipment used in manufacturing tires.
A "Little Wagner Act" granting city employes many of the same bargaining rights as workers in private industry was signed yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
Francis S. Baer, chairman of the executive committee of Bankers Trust Company, retired yesterday as an officer of the bank, having reached the mandatory retirement age of 65.
A highly important road in the time of the Judean kings was discovered in the last month by Dr. Nelson Glueck. It led from Beersheba to Sinai and from there to Egypt.

JEAN STEIN'S interview with William Faulkner in "Writers at Work"* is the central feature in Malcolm Cowley's habitat group, a pavilion of contemporary lit'ry celebrities. Here Mr. Faulkner is led to speak about nearly everything that interests an author in writing -- and that interests the public in how and why an author writes.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Administration has been following closely a Senate inquiry into the "precarious" condition of the railroads during the last ten weeks. It has told the investigators, however, that it is not yet prepared to present any remedies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- The Musicians Guild of America, formed as a rival union to the American Federation of Musicians, today made application to the National Labor Relations Board office in Los Angeles for certification to represent film studio musicians.
Herman Wallman, a prizefight manager, denied yesterday an assertion by the District Attorney's office that he was a front man for Frankie Carbo, underworld figure.
New securities offered publicly here in March showed a marked decline from the levels of the previous months and a year ago.
NEW HAVEN, March 31 -- A sea-going auxiliary yacht arrived here today with what Yale University experts hope may prove to be a record marine biological collection from the Indian Ocean.

Pleas for state aid for the city's public colleges were voiced yesterday at a ceremony marking the official opening of the Board of Higher Education's new headquarters building at 535 East Eightieth Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- Expressing confidence in the drawing power of top quality motion pictures, Paramount will undertake an "expanded production program," according to a joint announcement today by Barney Balaban, president, and Y. Frank Freeman, vice president in charge of studio operations.

WHITE PLAINS, March 31 -- Westchester labor leaders announced today that they had united all unionists in the county for "a big push" to help the International Typographical Union in its strike against the eight dailies and three weeklies of the Westchester County Publishers.
All merchandise, from stuffed giraffes to hooked rugs, in the special Easter sale at the Elder Craftsmen Shop this week will sport tiny Easter bonnets.
Nations of the European Economic Community (Common Market) have been urged by the International Chamber of Commerce to delay putting new anti-trust regulations into effect.

Eight adjourned games were played off yesterday to complete fourteen of the fifteefi rounds in the international chess masters tournament at NIar del Plata, according to a report received here through South American news sources.
GIVE the actors a few more performances of "Blood Wedding," which opened last evening at the Actors' Playhouse (down, down the stairs into the cellar at 100 Seventh Avenue South).
DEARBORN, Mich., March 31 -- The top negotiator for the Ford Motor Company said today that he was "very skeptical" about the profit sharing proposal of the United Automobile Workers.
BUFFALO, March 31 (AP) -- Dangerous blood clots are safely melted away by shots of a newly found chemical, scientists reported today.

WHITE PLAINS, March 31 -- Thirty-three men and seven women in the fields of education, journalism and broadcasting have been selected to receive fellowships totaling $205,000. The announcement was made by the Fund for Adult Education here today.
Five detectives denied yesterday in General Sessions Court that they had struck or threatened any of the seven defendants on trial for the murder of Michael Farmer.
PARIS, March 31 -- A wave of strikes is expected to tie up important sectors of France's economy tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Shubert theatre interests lost today an effort to recover $143,069.79 in claimed over-payments on Federal taxes. The Supreme Court refused to review a lower court decision rejecting the claim.

Inventories of Northeastern lumber mills are sharply higher than a year ago but the outlook for sales is generally stable, according to a survey of members of the Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association.
LONDON, March 31 -- Most industrials improved modestly in the stock market today under the lead of British Government securities.

It seems fashionable for champions of the "free enterprise" system to speak out against Government "subsidizing" of special-interest groups. Why, then, are there no champions of free enterprise to speak out against Government subsidizing of special-interest groups each time the postal rate structure, already discriminatory, is made even more so in favor of special groups?
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- Steve Brooks needs only one more winner to join racing's select 3,000 club.
THE long winter is over and spring is here, proof of which will be visible along the banks of Catherine Creek in the Finger Lakes region at 5 o'clock this morning.
The list of securities on the New York Stock Exchange closed trading in March with a small gain. Results for the first three months of the year also showed a modest gain.

LONDON, March 31 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of an address today by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to the Supreme Soviet, in which he announced the Soviet Union's decision to suspend nuclear tests.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- There are three ways to deal with the Communists: the best way is to play the diplomatic and propaganda game to the hilt; the next best way is to ignore them and concentrate on the unity of the West, and the worst way is to compromise between the two and lose the advantages of both. Unfortunately, the United States has chosen the third way.

LOS ANGELES, March 31 (AP) -- The world featherweight champion, Hogan (Kid) Bassey, risks his title tomorrow night against Ricardo (Pajarito) Moreno of Mexico City in a fight expected by few to last the scheduled fifteen rounds.

WHITE PLAINS, March 31 -- A former law associate and a former secretary to James M. Landis received suspended sentences today in the filing of a fraudulent petition for the reelection of Mr. Landis as Democratic Supervisor of the Town of Harrison last Nov. 5.
The United States Steel Corporation has evolved a program aimed at increasing the market for steel.

The gangland meeting last Nov. 14 in an isolated hilltop mansion at Apalachin, N. Y., revealed a serious defect in the state's law enforcement apparatus, the legislative watchdog committee said yesterday.
Jane Todd, Republican state vice chairman, said last night that "clean-up vs. cover-up" would be a principal issue of the 1958 campaign for Governor.
RABAT, Morocco, March 31 -- The pretender to the throne of France warned the King of Morocco today against the dangers of democracy.

A mid-century view of a number of leading American novelists is given by Maxwell Geismar in his newest book "American Moderns: From Rebellion to Conformity." The volume contains essays and criticisms, spanning the literary field from Dreiser and Hemingway to J. D. Salinger and William Styron.

CHARLOTESVILLE, Va., March 31 -- Robert Schuman said here today that the North Atlantic, Baghdad and Southeast Asia alliances should help in preventing the loss of French North African positions to "outsiders" hostile to European and Western interests.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Soviet Union, which announced today that it was suspending nuclear tests, has exploded at least thirty-nine devices in the last nine years.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- The winter season was "one of the most disastrous of this century" for Florida crops, the Federal-State Frost Warning Service said.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Supreme Court let stand today the convictions of Matthew J. Connelly and T. Lamar Caudle for conspiracy to defraud the Government.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 31 -- The creation of a new park district for the Town of Hempstead will be proposed here tomorrow at a meeting of the Town Board.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31 -- Under a cloudless sky and a glittering sun, the Yankees and Dodgers met today for probably the last time this year. Chance, of course, may throw them together again in next October's world series, but expert opinion seems to rule against this.
YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., March 31 (AP) -- An Army helicopter rescued four skiers from a windswept ledge high on the slopes of Mount Lytell today. One was critically ill.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- House investigators disclosed today that the National Broadcasting Company had provided favors ranging from entertainment in Havana to prizes for girls' bowling leagues for employes of the Federal Communications Commission.
Insurgents in control of Local 88 of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots took their fight to retain control into state Supreme Court yesterday.
MOSCOW, March 31 -- The Soviet Union declared today that it was halting tests of atomic and hydrogen bombs. It called on the other nuclear powers, the United States and Britain, to do the same.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 28 -- Venezuela is taking stock of the good and the bad that she inherited from almost a decade of military rule here under the dictatorship of Marcos Perez Jimenez.

Futures prices closed irregularly yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Cocoa, sugar, copper and zinc rose; wool, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and lead declined, and price movements for potatoes, coffee, hides and rubber were mixed.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 31 -- A state of emergency was declared today by the Board of Supervisors in Suffolk County for the storm-ravaged barrier beach along the South Shore of Long Island.

The Flintkote Company has a new president, George J. Pecaro. He has been active in Flintkote's operations as a producer of paperboard, cement, composition floor coverings, industrial lime, prefabricated chimneys, paving and automotive products and a wide line of building materials.
Almost every group on the New York Stock Exchange showed a loss yesterday and the gain in the averages for the month of March was all but eliminated.

The Federal Home Loan Banks are offering $290,000,000 of five-year bonds today.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Senator Pat McNamara, who has contended that recent hearings of the Senate rackets committee were "rigged against labor," quit that committee today.

A new issue of $30,000,000 of first mortgage bonds of the Wisconsin Electric Power Company is being offered for public subscription today by a syndicate headed by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith and the Equitable Securities Corporation.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 18 to 30 points yesterday.

The weather and the prevailing mood were rather thick with gloom yesterday, but we had one piece of news that should make New York feel good. The $10,000,000 pledge by the Ford Foundation, added to a previous commitment of $2,500,000, to help build the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts is generous, constructive, enlightened philanthropy.

Deposits of state-chartered banks increased 2.99 per cent in 1957 to $123,7442,555,000 on Dec. 31, the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks reported yesterday.
ALBANY, March 31 -- The Legislature's watchdog committee today accused the highway superintendent and a former assessor of the Town of Putnam Valley of violations of the law.

The Bankers Securities Corporation, a holding company, yesterday announced it would solicit proxies against a deferred compensation plan proposed by Best Co., New York women's and children's specialty store concern.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Administration's plan for Federal aid to the unemployed was described today as "one of the most fantastic proposals of all time."

Lincoln Kirstein, general director of the New York City Ballet, will receive the 1958 Award for Distinguished Service to the Arts of the National Institute of Arts and Letters, according to an announcement by Malcolm Cowley, president of the institute.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 31 -- A new scheme to help eighth-grade and ninth-grade pupils plan careers -- even in classes whose teachers lack previous training in guidance -- is about to be tried out nationally.

JACK PLATT'S new drama, "The Legitimate Steal," which had its premiere last night at the Fourth Street Theatre, is a dull chronicle of a family wrangle over a legacy of about $35,000 left by one of its members who mysteriously disappears at sea.

John B. Poor has been named general manager of R.K.O. Radio Pictures, according to Thomas F. O'Neil, president of R.K.O. Teleradio Pictures, the parent company. Mr. Poor, who is 42 years old, has been a vice president and director of the parent company since January, 1956.

Premier David Ben-Gurion of Israel said in an interview published in this week's issue of Look magazine that he would "definitely go to Cairo" to meet President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic "anytime he invites me."

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 31 (AP) -- The southpaw ace, Herb Score, and a right-hander, Ray Narleski limited the San Francisco Giants to four hits today as the Cleveland Indians triumphed, 8 -- 2, in an exhibition game.
MOSCOW, March 31 -- The pitfalls of international communication were demonstrated here today when diplomats went hunting for a little Russian vowel that wasn't there.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The Supreme Court voted today, 5 to 4, to extend to civil actions the criminal trial rule that a defendant who takes the witness stand voluntarily waives any right to plead the Fifth Amendment during cross-examination.

Mayor Wagner has made some fortunate choices in filling the important post of Deputy Mayor. Henry Epstein served him well before moving on to the judicial bench. Dr. John J. New York State's motorists would do well to acquaint themselves with the major provisions and underlying philosophy of the new, more stringent traffic-safety regulations that go into effect today.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A sharply divided Supreme Court upheld today the power of the Government to deprive native-born Americans of their citizenship.
CHICAGO, March 31 -- Montgomery Ward Co. announced l price cuts today on 20,000 items in its midsummer sales catalogue. The cuts were said to average 13 per cent and would be effective immediately.

LAKEHURST, N. J., March 31 -- The Navy retired a legend today.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The House Banking and Currency Committee voted today to cut reserve requirements for New York and Chicago banks.

American Metal Climax, Inc., reported yesterday for 1957 a consolidated net income of $27,895,000, or $1.95 each on the 14,153,448 common shares outstanding. This is the first annual report of the company, which is a merger of the Climax Molybdenum Company and the American Metal Company, Ltd.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -Senator James O. Eastland, Democrat of Mississippi, said today that while Congress sought "to repair ,the damage to antisubversive legislation caused by recent Supreme Court decisions, the Communuists are planning to take fall advantage of this respite."
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Supreme Court rejected today an assault on the long-established rule that Federal courts may punish for criminal contempt without a jury trial.
Two lieutenants and the entire plainclothes squad in the Tenth Inspection Division in Harlem were transferred yesterday as the investigation of alleged police protection of gamblers continued.
CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

NEW DELHI, India, March 31 -- India's ruling Congress party is suffering from a series of rebellions and defeats that is shaping up as an important crisis. The best description is one Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru sometimes uses -- a crisis of the spirit.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The United States warned the free world today not to be beguiled by the Soviet Union's proclaimed ending of nuclear arms tests. Free nations, the State Department said, should not relinquish their collective capacity to defend themselves and deter aggression "merely in reliance on a Soviet statement of intention for whichthere is no system of verification, which can be evaded in secrecy and altered at will."

BOGOTA, Colombia, March 31 -- Alberto Lleras Camargo, chief of the Liberal party and a former President of Colombia, emerged tonight as the joint Liberal-Conservative Presidential candidate for the four-year term beginning in August.

Increased passenger revenues were largely responsible for the 10 per cent gain last year in total operating revenues of Trans World Airlines, Inc., above those of 1956. In the first quarter this year, international bookings were 42 per cent abo]te those a year ago, while .domestic business was 9 per cent ahead, the company said.
LONDON, March 31 -- The Soviet Union's decision to halt nuclear tests has increased pressure on the Conservative Government to follow suit.

The Texas Gas Transmission Company, Owensboro, Ky., reported yesterday a new high in gross revenues for 1957. W. M. Elmer, president, placed 1957 gross revenues at $95,980,000, against $80,359,000 in 1956.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Soviet Union has given its word that, on some unspecified date and for an unspecified period, it will make no further tests of nuclear weapons. So prominent among the issues this pronouncement raises is, how good is the word of the Soviet Union?

The Commissioner of Hospitals accused a Brooklyn hospital yesterday of failure to comply with emergency ambulance regulations on March 1 when a seriously ill woman waited six hours to be picked up. The woman died of bleeding ulcers and other complications shortly after she was admitted to the hospital's emergency room.

Harold Keith, University of Oklahoma publicist, is the winner of the John Newbery Award for the most distinguished children's book published in 1957, it was announced yesterday. The title of his book is "Rifles for Watie."
BOCA RATON, Fla., March 31 -- Coal and steam turbines will be hero for a long time, 600 electric utility executives from the Southeast were told here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- The two major television talent unions -- the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists -- are reliably reported to be seeking a peaceful solution to television tape-recording jurisdictional questions.
THE home cook of today is fortunate in having at her disposal culinary equipment made of an infinite variety of materials.

ALBANY, March 31 -- Governor Harriman criticized the Republican - controlled Legislature today for not having extended the maximum period in which an unemployed worker could receive insurance benefits.

The American Bar Association has authorized its corporation, banking and business law section to support in Congress an amendment to the Securities Act of 1933 that would prohibit the Securities and Exchange Commission from refusing to accelerate the effective date of a securities offering upon the filing of a price amendment.
LONDON, March 31 -- The British Treasury attempted today to dispel "the strange view" that Britain "is living on its past, careless of its world responsibilities."
The Koppers Company, Inc. announced yesterday that Fred C. Foy, president since 1955, has been elected to the additional office of chairman.

NEWARK, March 31 (AP) -- The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad's control, Frank Masterson, testified at a Public Utilities Commission hearing today that the line operated at a $2,003,465 deficit in 1957.

NEW frozen foods -- some already in stores here and others to be available soon -- composed the bill of fare last week at a luncheon held in conjunction with the first Eastern Frozen Foods conference in Hartford.
ALBANY, March 31 (AP) -- The State Conservation Department has no intention of trying to shut off a stream of $1 contributions started by a Syracuse sportsmen's group.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The National Labor Relations Board explained today how a union may legally operate a hiring hall, or job referral agency, in agreement with an employer, or group of employers.

Percy Gale Jr., retired director of the Bureau of Real Estate, was responsible for the financial terms of the contract under which a private company received more than $2,000,000 for relocating tenants, it was contended yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Supreme Court refused today to re-examine its 1952 ruling that during an American military occupation of a foreign country American civilians may be tried by special military commissions.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Treasury reported tonight another decline in its short-term borrowing costs. It said that bids on this week's issue of ninety-one-day treasury bills averaged 1.148 per cent interest. The new bids replaced last week's as the lowest since mid-February, 1955.

The Federal Communications Commission announced in Washington yesterday its approval of the transfer of television station WATV (Channel 13) and its radio affiliates, WAAT and WAAT-FM, to National Tele-film Associates, Inc.

For some weeks now at Geneva more than eighty nations have had under consideration the report of the International Law Commission of the United Nations seeking a codification of the law of the sea. Numerous reports have been carried, giving the inconsistent positions that are being taken by various nations. These positions, in most instances, are dictated by self-interest.
WESTBURY, L. I., March 31 -- Harness racing, often referred to as the "trots," returns to the local area tomorrow night.

Many prominent persons in the metropolitan area are planning to entertain at Gotham in the Spring, the Easter Sunday twilight dinner dance. The fete will be held in the ballroom of the Plaza from 6 to 10:30 P. M. for the benefit of the Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club at 283 Lexington Avenue.

Choice box and orchestra seats for the second performance of the Moiseyev Dance Company on April 15 at the Metropolitan Opera House have been taken by the Greater New York chapter of the American National Theatre and Academy.

HAVANA, March 31 -- The Cuban Congress approved tonight a "state of national emergency" for a period of forty-five days and granted President Fulgencio Batista almost unlimited powers over the nation.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The United States, Britain and France asked the Soviet Union today to enter into talks in Moscow next month in preparation for a heads-of-government conference.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- It is an old Soviet adage that the surest path for personal advancement in the Soviet Union is through the Communist party apparatus. That adage would seem to have been confirmed once again yesterday when Frol Romanovich Kozlov was named a First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union.

Premier Khrushchev begins his rule as undisputed ruler of the Soviet empire with a spectacular but transparent maneuver. He announces through Foreign Minister Gromyko, to the cheering approval of the Supreme Soviet, that Soviet Russia is suspending unilaterally and of its own accord all further atomic and hydrogen weapons tests as a first step toward disarmament and asks the United States and Britain to follow suit.
MORRISTOWN N. J., March 31 -- Seven blind persons, students of Seeing Eye, Inc., of Whippany, were injured today when a bus in which they were riding crashed into a tree.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Tuesday, April 1 -- Union negotiators rejected early today a final offer made by the Republic Aviation Corporation in an effort to prevent a strike at the company's plant at Farmingdale, L. I.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- The Army conceded today the taxpayers should not have to pick up the bill for the Army band music at a party given by Senator Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire.
NEW DELHI, India, March 31 -- The Government announced today a slight liberalization in imports of raw materials to maintain production in some industries.
Federal Judge Archie O. Dawson decided yesterday to let a church lawsuit go to trial, but he chided the litigants for draging a religious matter through the civil courts.

There is a statistic floating around which is worth a moment's close attention. During last year, it says, some forty-five million pounds of aluminum found their way into the pleasure-boat industry. This poundage became cleats, runners, motors -- and also hulls.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Mervin J. Kelly, president of Bell Telephone Laboratories, told Congressional investigators today his service on a Defense Department civilian committee had nothing whatever to do with an antitrust settlement.

DETROIT, March 31 (AP) -- The auto makers are scheduling production at 1,130,000 passenger cars for the second quarter of 1958. They built about 1,244,000 in the January-March quarter. In the second quarter of 1957, assemblies numbered 1,580,835.
THE general uneasiness in the give-away show market was reflected last night on the Columbia Broadcasting System, which apparently has decided that the secret ingredient of ratings is money.
