A 17-year-old youth suspended from classes at Samuel Gompers Vocational High School, the Bronx, returned yesterday and attacked a teacher when ordered to leave the school.
The Girls Service League, Inc., will give a theatre party at next Tuesday's performance of "Oh Captain!" at the Alvin Theatre.
ALBANY, April 1 -- The New York City Board of Education renewed its fight today to force former Communist teachers to inform on their fellows.
WIESBADEN, Germany, April 1 -- The notice outside the courtroom door read: "Anna Anderson versus Duchess Christian Ludwig zu Mecklenburg."

Consolidated sales of the General Tire and Rubber Company for the three months ended Feb. 28 increased to $96,565,835 from $95,497,316 in the same period a year earlier, William O'Neil, president, told stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Akron, Ohio.
CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- Corn futures advanced sharply on the Board of Trade today. Prices moved well ahead despite some profit-taking along the way.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Administration is offering a "negotiated peace" to Congressional opponents of its plan for further centralization of authority at the Department of Defense, Senator Styles Bridges said today.

GENEVA, April 1 -- The United States and Britain have split on a crucial issue at the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea. Vital security and economic interests of the two traditional allies underlie the dispute.
PROSPECTIVE parents, worried about heredity defects or diseases in their offspring, can now consult a heredity clinic and learn what the risk will be and whether there is a cure.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 -- The passion fruit and pumpkins of the President of the United Nations General Assembly are causing a bit of a stir here.

CLINTON, N. J., April 1 -- Hot Toddy, a 2-year-old pointer owned by Joe Bales of Thomasvile, N. C., and Dirt Road Sport, a 16-month-old pointer owned by Ernest Allen of Hatchechubbee, Ala., were first-place winners today as the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club completed its annual four-day spring field trials at the pubic shooting grounds.

Twenty circus elephants marched rapidly and nonchalantly from the Sunnyside yards of the Pennsylvania Railroad in Queens, over the Queensboro Bridge and through midtown traffic to Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

HAVANA, April 1 -- Cuba is waiting anxiously for the "total war" that Fidel Castro, rebel leader, has threatened to start in Oriente Province today against the Government of President Fulgencio Batista.
BOSTON, April 1 -- The New York Rangers showed their smooth passing attack at its best tonight and registered a 5-to-2 victory over the Boston Bruins in their Stanley Cup play-off game.
The city's new anti-bias housing law went into effect yesterday, and an educational drive got under way to bring about compliance with the controversial law.
CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- Radioactive rivers are flowing into human bodies to fight cancers beyond the power of the surgeon's knife.
Haiti intends to seek a $12,000,000 additional loan from the Export-Import Bank for the long-pending Artibonite power and irrigation project.
Three hundred passengers were trapped in a derailed BMT subway train last night but were led to safety over an improvised bridge of seat cushions.
BOCA RATON, Fla., April 1 -- The nation's electric utilities were urged here today to intensify their research and development efforts in order to build "a solid atomic power industry."

On a day when President Eisenhower's signature of the $1,900,000,000 housing bill stood alone as a counterbalance for news of short work weeks, plant shutdowns and pay cuts the stock market behaved remarkably well. The loss in market value of New York Stock Exchange shares was a little more than $800,000,000.
LONDON, April 1 -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer said today there was a good opportunity this year for Britain to stop the rise in prices, "which has troubled this country for twenty years."
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Justice Department opened today a grand jury investigation intended to bring down the actual retail prices of automobiles.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 1 -- The United States declared today that human rights were being repressed by "the desire in many countries for security, for national stability or promotion of national interest."
In a series of simultaneous raids yesterday, squads of policemen and District Attorney's investigators smashed a multi-million-dollar policy ring in Brooklyn.

Periodic dizzy spells caused by a head injury in 1955 are hastening the retirement of Vincent Jacobi, 62-year-old president of Theatrical Protective Union (Local 1). His illness also is forcing him to resign as president of the Combined Theatrical and Amusement Crafts Council, representing twenty-seven local unions. He has held that post nineteen years.
TAMPA, Fla., April 1 -- Casey Stengel, after observing his Yankees tangle with the White Sox today for 3 hours 24 minutes, found himself more confused than ever.

The following table shows executive budget recommendations for the various city departments for 1958-59, as submitted by Mayor Wagner to the Board of Estimate and the City Council. It gives comparison between the budget for 1957-58, as modified to March 15, 1958, and the executive budget for 1958-59.
TRENTON, April 1 -- Deputy Attorney General Saul N. Schechter was assigned today to coordinate the twenty-one-county investigations now going on into garbage collection contract practices.
LONDON, April 1 (Reuters) -- The world heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson, lost on points and pounds today to Mrs. Bessie Braddock, a Labor member of Parliament.

PARIS, April 1 (UP) -- The United States Embassy assured the French people today that the case of an American soldier who deserted in wartime for the love of a French woman "would be judged "with all understanding compatible with the application of law."
PHILADELPHIA, April 1 -- The Pennsylvania Railroad cut salaries today of employes earning more than $10,000 a year by 10 per cent.

HAVANA, Wednesday, April 2 -- Nineteen rebels have been killed during the last twenty-four hours in encounters with Government troops in Oriente Province, the center of revolutionary activities against the Batista Government, according to a communique issued during the night by Camp Colombia Army headquarters here.

Efforts to locate the body of a barge captain missing since late Monday night off Ambrose Lightship were hampered by fifteen-foot waves yesterday. His craft sank after a collision with the freighter Albion Victory.

LOS ANGELES, April 1 (AP) -The world featherweight champion, Hogan (Kid) Bassey of Nigeria, unleashed a savage arrack to knock out Ricardo (Pajarito) Moreno of Mexico in the third round of their scheduled fifteen-round title fight tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Senate-House conferees agreed today on a bill to speed highway construction. It provides for Federal regulation of billboards along about 65 per cent of the projected 41,000-mile interstate system.
The Pennsylvania Railroad yesterday took official notice that proxies were being solicited by an independent shareholder.

The Film Producers Association of New York has scheduled a dinner for next Tuesday at Toots Shor's to begin its latest campaign to advance film production here. Mayor Wagner will be among those speaking on the status of the motion-picture industry in the city.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 -Managing officers of the White House, 104-year-old department store in this city, have agreed to its sale.

The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico borrowed $18,300,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of bonds maturing over fifteen years at an interest cost of 3.2266 per cent. The money raised by the sale will be used to finance public improvements.

THE oldest holiday in the world begins at sunset Friday, when families of the Jewish faith will gather to celebrate Passover, the feast of freedom. The name of the eight-day festival derives from the final miracle consummated in Egypt more than 3,000 years ago, when the Lord fulfilled His promise to Moses and passed over the homes of the Israelites while smiting the Egyptians.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The House Antitrust Subcommittee was told today that Wilber M. Brucker strongly urged the Justice Department not to bring to trial an antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telepraph Company.
Rear Admiral Robert H. Meade, who retired last December as the Navy's chief civil engineer and head of its bureau of yards and docks, got back in harness yesterday.

FLORENCE, Italy, April 1 (AP) -- A Florence court made up of three Roman Catholic judges said tonight the constitutional rights of Italian citizens must be protected against any infringement by the church.
RABAT, April 1 -- The Supreme Court declared a mistrial today in the case of two French Army officers condemned to death in absentia last week.

Mayor Wagner's new executive "budget of austerity" would increase the city's spending by $79,500,861 in the fiscal year 1958-59, but represents in general the first pause in expansion of program and services in recent years. The $1,996,952,986 budget misses the two-billion-dollar mark by a whisker, a political accomplishment achieved only by bond-issue borrowing, various bookkeeping devices and strenuous economy.

LONDON, April 1 -- Sir Hartley Shawcross, one of the most prominent figures in the post-war Labor Governments, resigned his seat in the House of Commons today. In the last few years his independent approach to politics has brought him into conflict with the Labor party.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Administration recently considered beating the Soviet Union to a suspension of nuclear tests and rejected the idea, Secretary of State Dulles said today.
DENVER, April 1 (UP) -- Vince Boryla, the coach of the New York Knickerbockers' professional basketball team, today said he would make an "announcement of newsworthy importance" on Saturday.
EVEN if snow should fly again and winds howl, it's really spring. Birds and bees, bushes and trees and crawling things opened the green season last Sunday. On Monday and yesterday signs multiplied.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 (AP) -- Jack Kramer, the professional tennis promoter, was named today to initiate an intensive training program to help the United States regain the Davis Cup from Australia.
OSWEGO, N. Y., April 1 (AP) -- Mayor Vincent A. Corsall lost part of his power in an election today, but won th eright to return to his job as a high school science teacher.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 -- Chevrolet will continue sponsoring the "Chevy Show" on the National Broadcasting Company for a fifteen-week summer period beginning June 22.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -The Veterans Administration said today it was being flooded with mail because of an incorrect report that it was holding $60,000,000 in unclaimed dividends on World War II G. I. life insurance policies.

With the unanimous approval of all fifteen member nations of the North Atlantic Council, Soviet Russia has been invited to participate during the second half of this month in diplomatic exchanges leading to a meeting between foreign ministers and looking forward to the holding of an early summit conference.
PASSAIC, N. J., April 1 -- The Passaic Section of the National Council of Jewish Women made recommendations today for improving mental health programs in the Passaic-Clifton area.
KIRKLAND LAKE, Ont., April 1 (Canadian Press) -- A television announcer's April Fool hoax panicked housewives here today and cost the announcer his job.
ALERT visitors to the exhibition of Seurat paintings and drawings at the Museum of Modern Art may come away with ideas on how to handle their own collections of wall decorations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 1 -- Kamil Abdul Rahim, representative of the Arab League, said today that the organization had taken no official stand on the question of stationing United Nations observers on the Tunisian-Algerian border.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1 -- Lebanon's Minister of Economy has threatened to resign in the aftermath of a riot caused by the sentencing of three pro-Egyptian youths.

Potato futures opened lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange following the issuance of 258 notices, the largest number for any one day. Yesterday was the first April delivery day. Prices recovered to close at, or near, the highs of the day.

The Indianapolis-type car race at Trenton (N. J.) Speedway last Sunday was the first event on the United States Auto Club's national championship calendar for the year. In addition to the more than 10,000 fans, the race attracted a host of officials, car owners and drivers from all branches of the sport.
LEVITTOWN, L. I., Wednesday, April 2 -- The possibility of an immediate strike at the Farmingdale (L. I.) plant of Republic Aviation Corporation faded early today.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 1 (AP) -- The Air Force tried to test the Atlas today but cut off the rocket engines a second or two before the intercontinental ballistic missile could get off the ground.
The economic impact of alcoholism was explained yesterday to a group of business men.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 1 -- External Affairs Minister Richard G. Casey said today that discontinuance of Soviet nuclear tests at this stage was no real concession to the democracies.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The subject of railroad "featherbedding" on the management as well as the employe level was raised in Congress today.
Spokesmen for the New York Central, the New Haven and the Baltimore and Ohio railroads said yesterday that the carriers had no plans to cut executive salaries.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 11,431 pints of blood in March. Included were eighty-eight pints given Monday.

DEARBORN, Mich., April 1 -- Ford engineers demonstrated today a three-foot model of a wheelless vehicle that speeds on a thin film of air only three-thousandths of an inch above its table top roadbed.

A pact, under which the merged labor federation and the American Social Hygiene Association will work jointly to "strengthen and foster the health and welfare of American families," was made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- The House of representatives passed a $15,558,870 money bill today for running the White House and related agencies. It rebuffed a last-ditch Southern effort to eliminate funds for the new Civil Rights Commission.
The Brookmeade Stable's The Runner, a beaten odds-on choice last Saturday, redeemed herself yesterday with a length and a half victory in the $6,000 Outline at Jamaica.
Two postal clerks were arraigned yesterday in Special Sessions Court for being loan sharks where they worked.
I was interested to see on March 29 your comment on taxicabs in New York City and an expressed hope for better accommodation than is now in effect.

HONG KONG, April 1 -- Communist China voiced prompt approval today of the Soviet Union's announcement of unilateral cessation of nuclear weapons testing. Simultaneously official spokesmen and newspapers echoed the Soviet proposal that the United States and Britain likewise stop nuclear trials.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Secretary of the Interior announced today the appointment of Navy Capt. Mathew V. Carson Jr. as director of the Office of Oil and Gas.

MARTHA GRAHAM last night opened her two-week season at the Adelphi Theatre with the premiere of her evening-long dance work called "Clytemnestra," with music by Halim El-Dabh, decor by Isamu Noguchi and costumes by Miss Graham herself.
The $11,200 in old, discolored bills that was awarded by a court to a Brooklyn cab driver, Harold Petrie, was collected for him yesterday by his attorney at Police Headquarters Annex.

DETROIT, April 1 (UP) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard, Montreal's great right winger, fired a three-goal "hat trick" -- as the Canadiens posted a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight for a 4-0 sweep in their Stanley Cup semi-final hockey series.
Two new films open at first-run theatres today.

New orders received by the machine tool industry in February showed an increase of 18 per cent over the January level and 23 per cent over that of December, 1957, which was the poorest month since October, 1949. A survey of leading machine tool companies indicates that the March figure will equal or exceed that of February.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Justice Department is giving consideration to dropping the treason charges against Ezra Pound, the poet, with a view to letting him return to Italy.
RABAT, Morocco, March 31 -- United States and Moroccan representatives are understood to have arrived at a "wide divergence of views" on the prospective status of United States military bases.

A FEW years ago, the forgotten child of fashion was the girl between 10 and 12 years old. According to one designer who remembers shopping for her twin daughters, the sub-teen was relegated to a limbo. Too old to wear little girls' dresses and still too adolescent for teen-age fashions, she had a limited choice of clothes. Generally, a sub-teen's wardrobe consisted of full skirts, sweaters and wide belts.
CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Discrimination against Jews in the state has decreased in recent years, according to a report made public yesterday. Complaints during a twelve-year period were reviewed in the paper, issued by Commissioner Charles Abrams of the State Commission Against Discrimination.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- Members of the Senate rackets committee put their partisan feuding behind them today and ended six weeks of stormy hearings on a note of good feeling.

PARIS, April 1 -- United States and British efforts to conciliate the French-Tunisian quarrel dragged on in a stalemate today. At the same time, signs multiplied that France was headed for new difficulties with Morocco.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 1 -- A station wagon southbound on the Hutchinson River Parkway hurdled the center island this afternoon and landed upside down on the front of a sedan in the outside northbound lane. The driver of the station wagon was killed and four other persons were seriously injured.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Harris Perlstein, president and chairman of the Pabst Brewing Company, said at the annual meeting today that a merger or consolidation or the acquisition of other companies were possibilities if he continued in office.

CLEARWATER, Fla., April 1 -- Mayo Smith nodded in the direction of Wally Post, a large and broad-shouldered citizen of formidable mien. "He should become," Smith said pointedly, "the big hitter the Phillies haven't had since we traded Del Ennis."
Fish trading is a far cry from dealings in stocks and bonds, but Boston has an Exchange that deals in seafood on an auction basis not unlike the business in securities.
Dinah Shore and Bob Hope have been named to receive George Foster Peabody awards for 1957.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of the message President Eisenhower sent to Congress today after signing the housing bill;
There were a record 364,876 fight fans in 174 theatres in 140 cities watching the Sugar Ray Robinson-Carmen Basilio middleweight championship fight, staged in Chicago on March 25.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 1 -- The Lake Hula situation was discussed at an extraordinary meeting of the Israeli cabinet today. Premier David Ben Gurion's government then ordered a suspension of the reclamation work.

GUNTHER JAECKEL harbors warm thoughts for the chemise. Sensitive to the elusive proportions of the chemise, this store's spring furs are designed to "cover everything up so they don't compete'' or they are short enough "so that the line shows beneath."

A contract to purchase the six-story building containing forty-four apartments and eight stores at 4396 Furman Avenue, the Bronx, has been resold by Enkells-Rakoff Co., realty operators. The buyer was an investing client of Arthur Berliner, attorney.
BOULDER, Colo., April 1 -- Last week-end may have been one of the greatest periods of sunspot activity observed since 1612, the year Galileo started man watching the surface of the sun.
ALBANY, April 1 (AP) -- Objections were voiced by county welfare agencies to a state order made public today directing them to consider alcoholics as "disabled" and to provire aid.
Social Security payments should be scaled to the cost-of-living index, a banker told a social welfare meeting here yesterday.

A young British couple who fled their homeland to escape the wrath of the girl's father were married for the second time yesterday in Manhattan Supreme Court. They were married in Havana in January but repeated the ceremony to make sure they were legally wed.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The American Medical Association charged today that medical care for coal miners was being subordinated to union financial interests.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 1 (AP) -There were red faces around the staid, strait-laced Augusta National golf course today.

Two floors have been leased in the six-story building at 7 East Forty-eighth Street, which is being renovated by Joseph B. Rosenblatt and Rennold Wacht, realty investors. They acquired the property last year on a long-term lease from the Henry Phipps Estate and are spending $100,000 on alterations.
NEW DELHI, India, April 1 -- Moscow's decision to suspend nuclear tests is likely to win the Soviet Union more political credit in India than almost any step since World War II.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- This was April Fool's Day to a lot of people but it was no joke to John Foster Dulles.
SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., April 1 (AP) -- San Francisco batters collected only three hits off Baltimore pitching today, but the Giants parlayed them into a 4-1 exhibition victory over the Orioles.

Vassily Smyslov, defending his world chess title, yesterday defeated Mikhail Botvinnik in the eleventh game of their return match in Moscow, according to a report received through Soviet news sources.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the Conservative landslide in the Canadian elections would not change "the good relations" between the United States and Canada.
LONDON, April 1 -- The Government's conduct of negotiations with Malta on that Crown Colony's political future was approved tonight in the House of Commons.
New issues of corporate debt securities totaling $40,000,000 will be offered for public subscription today by investment banking syndicates. They are:
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today that it was investigating the near-miss of two National Airlines planes over New Jersey Sunday.
BUFFALO, April 1 (AP) -- Economic indicators in Western New York moved unevenly this week, revealing both upturns and downturns.
New York University's baseball players were scrupulously avoided yesterday by their friends at Ohio Field, where Wagner College was defeated, thoroughly but silently, 5 -- 0.
Record sales of $153,503,048 were made by the H. K. Porter Company last year, but profits were lower than in 1956, the annual report of Thomas M. Evans, chairman, showed yesterday.
BERNARD MANNES BARUCH has crowded so much living into a long lifetime that it is hard to say where the man leaves off and the legend begins.

Senator McNamara's resignation from the McClellan committee is a signpost that points two ways: to the future of the committee and to the likelihood of Federal legislation, at least at this session of Congress, to curb labor and management abuses. In both directions the going looks rough.
A group of dissident dress contractors in northeastern Pennsylvania has rejected for the third time a strike settlement approved by their own leaders.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers threw his weight today against two pending Congressional proposals aimed at the Supreme Court.

PARIS, April 1 -- The French economy was nearly paralyzed today when 1,000,000 public workers struck for twenty-four hours. Hardest hit was transportation. Train, plane, bus and subway service throughout France was at a virtual standstill.
Four management awards for promoting art work were presented yesterday by the Art Directors Club of New York as Visual Communications Week began.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Following is the text of the State Department's transcript of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today:
Mayor Wagner sent to the Board of Estimate and the City Council yesterday an executive expense budget of $1,996,952,986 for the fiscal year starting July 1.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -The Federal Trade Commission today endorsed legislation requiring that the Government get advance notice of mergers planned by companies with combined assets in excess of $10,000,000.

NEW ORLEANS, April 1 (AP) -- The Orleans Parish grand jury today accused four men of buying control of a large industrial company with the concern's own money. It indicted them for theft of $1,900,000 in Government bonds.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York increased its net operating earnings after taxes $1,126,952, or 14.9 per cent, for the first three months of 1958, compared with the like 1957 period, the bank reported yesterday.

The special dispatch from Jerusalem (Israeli Sector), published on March 28, is misleading both in its caption and substance. The "law" just passed by the Israeli Parliament is neither intended to be against "squatters" on land nor designed to protect "the Government and other landowners" against peasants in Galilee "who seized land ten years ago."
OTTAWA, April 1 -- Aside from the magnitude of the Conservative party victory in yesterday's elections, the most significant result was Canada's return to the two-party system.

Consolidated net income of the General Telephone Corporation and consolidated subsidiaries for the two months ended Feb. 28 totaled $7,214,000 or 47 cents a share, Donald C. Power, president, reported yesterday. This compared with net income of $7,348,000, or 49 cents a share, for the same period of 1957.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Eisenhower signed the $1,850,000,000 emergency housing bill today. The new law is the first major anti-recession housing bill passed by Congress.
SINCE the Festival Company of Canada is a repertory troupe, it added to "Two Gentlemen of Verona" a production of "The Broken Jug," which opened last evening at the Phoenix.
The board of directors of the New York Central Railroad Company yesterday voted to abolish the office of chairman of the board and to omit payment of a second-quarter dividend.
The efforts of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., to win re-election to Congress won the backing yesterday of a Methodist church group.
Those old clothes providently donned by Gus Stager and Bruce Harlan for the final session of last week-end's National Collegiate swimming championships have been stowed away carefully for future use.

The price of pig lead has been reduced here by 1 cent a pound to 12 cents by two leading custom smelters. It is the first change since Dec. 2, when the price was cut to 13 cents a pound from 13.5 cents.
The rush of foreign-flag tramps to abandon the bleak rates of the open charter market for the haven of the Cargo Preference Act received a new impetus yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The director of the National Cancer Institute said today that scientists were on the verge of "major breakthroughs" to conquest of cancer.

The eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area did better in March than in the corresponding period of 1957. Their sales, on the average, were 12 per cent above the year before, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.
The first gold medal of the Lafayette Fellowship Foundation will be presented to Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther at a dinner on May 27 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 1 -- In a startling overnight reversal, the agreement between Colombia's Liberals and Conservatives on a Presidential candidate appeared today to be on the verge of collapse.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Representative Usher L. Burdick, Republican of North Dakota, said today he would withdraw from seeking-re-election if his son Quentin runs for the office.
A fight for proxies among the 1,500 members of the National Republican Club is in progress as a result of a challenge to the re-election of Daniel J. Riesner for a fifth term as president.
RIJEKA, Yugoslavia, April 1 (Reuters) -- Yugoslavia has opened a shipbuilding program under which seventy-five ships will be built for shipowners from fourteen countries at a cost of $140,000,000.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 1 -Once upon a time -- and not too long ago -- folks used to ridicule the sport of harness racing. In 1940, the year that old Roosevelt Raceway was introduced to the public, 4,584 persons showed up and wagered $40,741 the first night.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -Consumer installment credit declined in February, breaking an uptrend that had prevailed since late 1954, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
LONDON, April 1 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan stood firm today in the face of a volley of demands that the Government follow the Soviet Union's lead and abandon nuclear weapons tests.

MONTOUR FALLS, N. Y., April 1 (AP) -- The fish won the annual battle of Catherine Creek today as the trout season opened in the Finger Lakes and their tributaries. But it was a tainted victory, with the anglers out in only a third of their usual strength.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The merged labor federation argued today that its organizers were managerial employes and not eligible for union recognition. It found all five members of the National Labor Relations Board skeptical in some degree.
Three young rocket scientists will appear in court today to tell a judge about a successful raid on the Army's headquarters of air defense for the metropolitan area.
OTTAWA, April 1 -- A United States scientist said today he believed the United States should continue testing nuclear weapons on the interests of developing a "clean" bomb.
Manufacturers of products yielding industrial wastes were warned yesterday by the city to remove injurious chemicals from these wastes or face possible punitive action.
The annual spring house tour sponsored by the Smith College Club of Long Island will be held on May 6.
CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- A Roman Catholic Bishop and a Russian concert pianist were in a class of 150 persons granted United States citizenship today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 1 -- The meeting between Secretary General Hammarskjold and Foreign Minister Fawzi Thursday and Friday will be their first since Egypt and Syria merged to form the United Arab Republic. Mr. Hammarskjold, now in London, is scheduled to arrive in New York from Geneva on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization ended today the granting of Federal tax benefits to assist the construction of plants and laboratories for conventional defense programs.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 2 to 8 points yesterday.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 1 -- President Jose Figueres overruled his Foreign Ministry today and ordered that a group of touring Soviet newspaper men be given visas to Costa Rica.

ORLANDO, Fla., April 1 (UP) -- The Washington Senators scored two runs in the ninth inning to tie the score and then beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7 -- 6, in the tenth today. Charlie Neal bobbled Norm Zauchin's grounder, allowing Albie Pearson to score the winning run.

CAIRO, April 1 -- Foreign Minister Mahmoud Fawzi plans to go to Switzerland tomorrow to urge Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, to intercede personally in the latest flare-up of fighting along the frontier between Israel and the Syrian region of the United Arab Republic.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, April 1 -- The test of Nasser's empire-making talents will come in this dour, ancient city. Virtually all Levantine potentates since Syria's Empress Zenobia have had to unite the desert Arabs and Nile-bound Egyptians before achieving greatness. This was accomplished by Saladin, by the Mamelukes and later by'the Turks. It is the Lnitial goal of Hasser's Pan-Arabian movement.
Dr. Bela Fabian, a member of the Hungarian Government in exile, was acquitted yesterday in Special Sessions Court on a charge that he had interfered with policemen who were making an arrest.
FRIENDS of Dr. Charles Sandler will be happy to learn that he has cured himself of a loathsome fishing disease that he was never able to diagnose. But he doesn't knew how he did it.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Secretary of State Dulles affirmed today a United States position of strict neutrality in Indonesia's troubles with rebels in Sumatra.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 27 -- Venezuela plans to borrow up to $150,000,000 in the New York market to help pay off short-term debt incurred under the ousted regime of General Marcos Perez Jimenez. At present, Venezuela has no direct obligations of the Government outstanding in the form of external debt payable in foreign currencies. The proposed New York borrowing would be the first.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 -- Tennessee Williams' play, "Orpheus Descending," will be produced as a motion picture by Martin Jurow and Richard Shepherd for United Artists release. Anna Magnani, who the author originally had expected would perform in the play, will star in the film with Anthony Franciosa.

We read with interest your editorial on court reform which appeared on March 27. We were particularly pleased to note your renewed support of the unrevised Tweed commission plan of last year. We are disturbed, however, by your suggestion that the Governor call a special session to deal with this issue.

EUGENE ORMANDY was a bountiful provider of unfamiliar music at last night's Carnegie Hall concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra. He offered first New York performances of pieces by George Rochberg, a 39-year-old American; Miklos Rosza, who was born in Hungary almost 51 years ago and now resides in Hollywood, and Serge Prokofieff, who needs no introduction.
A clay tablet found by an American scholar in a Moscow museum has yielded the first known example of a lament for the dead from ancient Sumer in the Euphrates Valley.
The Transit Authority yielded yesterday to time.

Marchers in "Walk for Peace" delegations passed through New Jersey and Connecticut yesterday on their way to the United Nations headquarters to petition for an "immediate end to nuclear weapons tests."
MOSCOW, April 1 -- The Soviet Union charged tonight that the United States was using "artificial" reasons for not following the Soviet lead in halting nuclear weapon tests.
CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- Profit-taking and hedge selling clipped off more than half the early advances in corn futures on the Board of Trade today. However, all contracts closed higher.

MADRID, April 2 -- The Spanish-Moroccan agreement on the return of the former Southern Morocco protectorate to Moroccan jurisdiction is expected to prepare the way for a potential partnership in developing North African resources.

The person in New York with the greatest opportunity today to profit from advice unlimited must be Harold Petrie, the 65-year-old taxi driver who now, by court order, gets to keep the $11,200 which he found in his back seat last July.

Roy M. Callahan, former president of the Swan-Finch Oil Company, admitted yesterday in Federal Court that he had turned over stock of a subsidiary to Lowell M. Birrell, another former president of the company.
Protestant relief officials opened campaign yesterday to obtain 50,000,000 pounds of clothing for overseas relief in the next few years.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Eisenhower said today the Soviet nuclear test suspension was "a gimmick" that was "not to be taken seriously."

SAN FRANCISCO, April 2 -- A campaign aimed at placing the new baseball stadium for the San Francisco Giants on a downtown site instead of one being developed at the southern end of the city was promised today by a member of the Board of Supervisors.
DETROIT, April 2 (AP) -- Two students were stabbed and a male teacher was attacked with rocks today in the second day for reported violence in Detroit public schools.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2 -- The United Arab Republic announced today that it would not ask now for a meeting of the Security Council on the Lake Hula dispute with Israel
Troubled by the prospect of further government restriction, the fifty-three bank holding companies registered with the Federal Reserve Board have formed a national organization.

LONDON, April 2 -- British Government securities were again in strong demand on the stock market today following the announcement of last month's improved gold and dollar reserves. Industrial shares also improved on balance, although gains rarely topped 1 shilling (14 cents).
The textile industry should see a turn for the better before the middle of the year, Marvin R. Cross, president of Greenwood Mills, Inc., asserted yesterday.
HARTFORD, April 2 (AP) -- An official tabulation of Connecticut's mentally retarded population will be made, it was announced today.

BUENOS AIRES, April 2 (AP) -- Anti-Government demonstrations were reported today in Paraguay's capital, Asuncion. Rebels were said to be holding four towns in Southern Paraguay. The reports were brought to Argentina by persons from Paraguay.

As a Catholic priest stationed for eighteen years in the much-publicized Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn, I take strong exception to Harrison E. Salisbury's sweeping assertion in The Times of March 26. "Only the Pentecostal pastors seen interested in whether Bedford-Stuyvesant lives by the Gospel or not."

AS one of the sponsors of the Federal signboard-control proposal, along with Senators Gore and Kuchel, I believe I can truthfully stress that even the limited victory we have achieved would have been impossible without the enlightened and persistent support of such newspapers as The New York Times.

QUITE the liveliest and most diverse exhibition in the long list of annuals put on by the American Water-Color Society will open to the public today in the galleries of the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue.
PEIPING, April 2 (Reuters) -- Communist China's "rectification'' campaign has moved right into Chinese homes.
ALBANY, April 2 -- The state borrowed $100,000,000 from nineteen banks today so that it could pay its bills.

In the course of rejecting the court reform plan the Legislature also saw fit to terminate the intensive work which has been going on for the past two years upon proposed revision of the New York Civil Practice Act, by failing to provide for continuation of this work and failing to appropriate money for it.

BOSTON, April 2 -- Phil Watson is optimistic now, but not overconfident. The coach of the New York Rangers believes that his team will beat the Boston Bruins in the National Hockey League Stanley Cup semi-finals, but he expects the series to go the full seven games.

District Attorney Edward S. Silver said yesterday that he had uncovered no evidence of police protection in his raids forty-six policy racket drops Tuesday.

CONCORD, N. H., April 2 -- In the six weeks since he was nominated to be staff director of the new Federal Civil Rights Commission, Gordon McLean Tiffany has been commuting between here and Washington as a $50-a-day consultant to the commission.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2 -- Sol Lesser, independent producer and theatre owner, has sold his controlling stock in Sol Lesser Productions, Inc., to Sy Weintraub, New York television film distributor and president of radio station KWIT in Mineola, L. I.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Generalities founded on divisions in the Supreme Court are among the most hazardous ventures in this category, since they can be disproved by the divisions that appear a week later. But two can soundly be based on the events of last Monday.
MARSEILLES, France, March 31 -- This major seaport has traditionally turned its back on Paris and looked toward the Mediterranean Sea.

Financing for California's state and municipal governments had the center of interest in the market for local government capital yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- George C. McConnaughey testified today that he had lunch with interested parties in two controversial television-channel disputes at the time their cases were before him for settlement.

The Belmont Stakes Ball will be held June 6 in the ballroom of the Garden City Hotel. Mrs. Joseph Walker Jr., chairman of the event, has announced that the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association will be this year's beneficiary.

A report from the United Nations shows that the free world in the last two-year period has extended about five and a half billion dollars in aid to the less privileged countries. Radio and television engineers, technicians and camera men voted yesterday to strike against the Columbia Broadcasting System. However, union leaders have not called a walkout.

The Canadian elections on Monday provided such a stunning result that it will take days and weeks to figure out just what has happened and why. The chances of the Conservatives under Prime Minister Diefenbaker getting a clear majority in Parliament were recognized as good in advance.

A floor in the building at 260 Fourth Avenue, southwest corner of Twenty-first Street, has been leased by the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association. It will house the association's program services, Christmas seal sales activity and administrative offices.

The artist and craftsman, rather than the showman, came to the fore yesterday as Salvador Dali officiated at the presentation of his latest creation in gold and precious stones.

LOUISVILLE, April 2 (UP) -- Rory Calhoun posted a knockout tonight when Yolande Pompey failed to answer the bell for the sixth round of a scheduled ten-round fight. The ring physician halted the bout after the West Indian light heavyweight had complained of a neck injury.

The Bakelite Company, a division of the Union Carbide Corporation, announced yesterday that a new fully automated plant for making high-density, low-pressure polyethylene was in commercial production at Institute, W. Va.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. reported today record sales for the year ended Jan. 31, but a 2.28 per cent drop in net profits. The decline was attributed by officials to competition and rising costs.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 7 to 12 points (35 to 60 cents a bale) yesterday, in a moderate volume of business.

An appeal to Japan to reconsider the recent trade agreement between Japanese businessmen and Communist China was made public yesterday by the Committee of One Million (Against the Admission of Communist China to the United Nations).

A sharp rise in large-scale housing work helped to raise the total of engineering construction awards throughout the country for the wek that ended Monday to $598,500,000. This was the largest weekly volume recorded since August, 1956.

LONDON, April 3 -- British Government securities continued to advance on the stock market today. They were helped by a slightly lower Treasury bill rate, the interest rate that the money market charges the Government for short-term loans.

Loans to business by the seventeen larger New York City banks declined $123,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The decline compared with one of $65,000,000 in the like week a year ago.
Christ's Last Supper with His disciples was commemorated in Christian churches yesterday, Holy Thursday.
Is the consumer changing his spots? Is he renouncing his love for lower, longer, fleeter automobiles and super-automatic kitchens?
An implied threat to strike to enforce demands on the jet crews marked the opening testimony of the pilots union yesterday before a Presidential fact-finding board.

VERDUN, France, April 3 (UP) -- The United States Army has sent Pvt. Wayne Powers to an Air Force hospital in Landstuhl, Germany, to give psychiatrists a chance to try to find out why he put love before war, an Army spokesman said today.
Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" received its eighth performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera. There were numerous cast changes on this occasion.
Yesterday was a mournful day in the life of Harry B. Frank, justice of the State Supreme Court and a fan of the New York Giants.

ALBANY, April 3 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the Suffolk County Commissioner of Public Welfare, J. Milford Kirkup Jr., must stand trial on two criminal indictments. The indictments charge him with conspiracy to obtain property by false pretenses and wrongful disposition of property held by the county.
The Jewish people the world over will usher in Passover at sundown tonight. The festival commemorates the deliverance of the ancient Israelites, under the leadership of Moses, from Egyptian slavery.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 3 -- Tractors roared into action throughout eastern Suffolk County today as potato growers, held back by three weeks of bad weather, started planting.

The United States has at last moved openly to stop arms shipments to the Batista Government in Cuba. An announcement has now been made of an order to hold up 1,950 Garand rifles which President Batista had paid for.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) -- The Airline Pilots Association accused the Civil Aeronautics Board today of having issued an inaccurate, contradictory and false report that blamed the pilot for the crash of a Northeast Airlines DC-6 last year.
The "Malay barrier," an archipelago rich in oil and rubber that is one of the world's key strategic positions, is at stake in the nebulous war in Indonesia.
An American mission agency is preparing to distribute to its schools in Africa slides depicting Christ and those around Him as black-skinned men.
HAM and turkey are among the best meat buys for Easter Sunday dinner.

During the years following the French Revolution, Juliette Recamier, "chaste and married," was France's greatest beauty; and Germain de Stael, "notoriously amoral," was the intellectual queen of Europe. A dual biography of these two women, "The Passionate Exiles," by Maurice Levaillant, will be issued April 18 by Farrar, Straus Cudahy.

The W. T. Grant Company, which operates a chain of 691 variety stores, had record sales of $406,337,450 in the year ended Jan. 31, but earnings were little changed from those of 1956, the fifty-first annual report disclosed yesterday.

One hundred and fifteen persons hiked into the city yesterday on a "Walk for Peace" that started last week-end. Eighteen were reported to have walked the ninety miles from Philadelphia, eighteen the eighty miles from New Haven and two of them twenty miles from Westbury, L. I.
AMMAN, Jordan, April 3 (AP) -- Jordan's Government decided today to seize control of petroleum supplies in Jordan to keep them from being at the mercy of the hostile United Arab Republic.
Members of the New York Stock Exchange have approved a 13 per cent increase in brokers' commissions, effective May 1.
Six estates on the North Shore of Long Island have been chosen for the annual spring garden tour of the New York Botanical Garden, which is scheduled for May 8, rain or shine.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The United States will enjoy a flourishing foreign trade this year, but will not match the record export and import volume of 1957, the Department of Commerce reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 3 -- According to the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, the Soviet Union will soon be faced with a serious manpower shortage that can be met only by reducing its armed forces.

It was a relatively subdued Nikita S. Khrushchev who arrived in Budapest Wednesday. This newspaper's correspondent, Elie Abel, noted that some of the Soviet Premier's "old bounce was absent." Premier Khrushchev has shown little sign of lack of energy on the Moscow scene recently.
Massive base plates that will support the main columns of the new Time and Life Building were lowered into concrete beds yesterday.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 3 -The Ceylonese Government decided today to rush troops and police reinforcements to likely trouble spots in the flare-up of communal tension between the Sinhalese and the Tamils. In a broadcast to the nation, Prime Minister S. W. R. D. Bandaranaike said the Government was determined to maintain law and order.

MIAMI, April 3 -- Eleven pilots of two Cuban airlines asked political asylum in the United States here tonight. They said they had refused to obey orders to fly arms from the Dominican Republic to Cuba.
The Ford Foundation announced yesterday grants totaling $2,666,958 for educational and cultural projects, including an oral history of American jazz.

For the C-B-I, known irreverently to some disaffected military personnel stationed there as "Confusion Beyond Imagination," was the source of many madcap situations.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 3 (UP) -- Directors of the International League will meet in Miami Sunday to decide what to do about the Havana baseball franchise in view of the political situation in Cuba.

IF the City Center is crowding history, it does so with banners flying. It believes that American opera has substance now and is not merely a dream of the future. With a $105,000 blessing from the Ford Foundation, it set out last night to demonstrate its faith.

Cuts in suburban train service on April 27 were announced yesterday by the New York Central and the Pennsylvania Railroads.

Two five-story store and apartment buildings at 800-02 Lexington Avenue, southwest corner of Sixty-second Street, have been sold by Diogo Aguiar De Barros of Brazil to Milton C. Rose and Michael W Straight, trustees representing an estate.

MOSCOW, April 3 -- The Soviet press reported with great pleasure today the reaction in the rest of the world to Moscow's announcement that it was halting nuclear tests for the time being and urging the United States and Britain to follow suit.

Harold Alzana, who was injured in a fall at the openingnight performance of the circus at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, was reported in satisfactory condition last night at St. Clare's Hospital.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 3 -- Australia's Murray Rose made an impressive competitive debut in this country tonight as the amateur Athletic Union's national indoor swimming championships opened in Yale University's fifty meter practice pool.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 3 (UP) -- A Snark guided missile was fired from Cape Canaveral today, probably to a target 5,000 miles away.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 -- The Columbia Broadcasting System has acquired the deed, in the form of TV rights, to a much sought-after property known as "Wonderful Town."
A 5.9 per cent fare increase on the Long Island Rail Road was approved yesterday by the Public Service Commission. The increase will go into effect Tuesday.

GENEVA, April 3 -- An Indian move to outlaw the use of the continental shelf for military installations was defeated today, 31 votes to 18, with 6 abstentions, in the United Nations conference on the law of the sea.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -The worker is learning more about labor law rights and getting more assertive about them.
The case against fluoridation of the city's water supply lost ground among physicians yesterday but gained the support of an important official -- Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) -- The Government announced today that teachers and other employes may deduct from their income tax courses taken voluntarily to improve skill in their work.

Samuel C. Waugh, president of the Export-Import Bank, predicted yesterday that about $625,000,000 of contracts and orders would be placed with United States companies under loans from the bank, in the first half of this year.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 3 -- Since 1956 Ken Venturi has been planning to win the Masters golf tournament. In the first round of the 1958 tournament today, the 26-year-old Californian satisfactorily completed an opening bid with a score of 68.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended last Saturday totaled 532,172 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 3 -- India has rejected all the proposals made by Dr. Frank P. Graham, United Nations representative for India and Pakistan, for a settlement of the long-standing Kashmir problem.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 3 -- Lebanon appeared today to be finding a way out of the crisis between the Government and the Moslem population in southern Lebanon around Tyre.
Turning over the city's piers to the Port of New York Authority would be "a giveaway," Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa declared yesterday.
LONDON, April 3 (Reuters) -- Britain's Negro population now numbers more than 100,000 and is increasing at the rate of about 25,000 a year.
The twenty - fifth annual donor luncheon and fashion revue of the Sisterhood of Hartman-Homecrest for Children will be held in the grand ballroom of the Plaza on April 17.
Harrison Tweed blamed certain "judges and other politicians" yesterday for killing the court reorganization plan.

LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- The head of the world's biggest merchant shipping group today appealed to British shipbuilders to meet a growing challenge from Japanese yards. He estimated that the price of a tanker built in Japan ran about $1,000,000 less than one built here.
HAVANA, April 3 -- Cuba invoked drastic measures today to prevent a general revolutionary strike. Fidel Castro, the rebel leader, had announced he would call the strike at the "opportune" moment.
CROSS RIVER, N. Y., April 3 -- State highway officials were urged at a public hearing today to avoid creating another suburban bottleneck for Sunday traffic.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 3 -- Florida weather, apparently determined to remain perverse to the end, dealt a final blow to the Yankees today. It rained out the Bombers' game with the Boston Red Sox, which was to have concluded the exhibition season in the Sunshine City. Considering how little sunshine the baseball clubs actually have had this spring, it seemed a fitting close.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, April 3 -- The leader of underground rebels in Santiago de Cuba indicated today that a sudden dramatic uprising against the strong Government force occupying the city was not in the cards.
The Commission on Intergroup Relations has received the first complaint under the city's anti-bias housing law, which became effective last Tuesday.

BISMARCK, N. D., April 3 (AP) -- North Dakota's Supreme Court ruled today television station WDAY of Fargo was not liable for statements made over its facilities by a candidate in the 1956 general election campaign.

WESTBURY, L. I. April 3 -This was examination day at Roosevelt Raceway. Twentythree standardbreds, hoping to keep the barn space they occupy at the Nassau County plant, had to prove they had what it takes in terms of speed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 3 -- Seven Arts Productions, independent company headed by Eliot Hyman and Ray Stark, is negotiating a long-range exclusive financing and distribution agreement with United Artists.
ABIDJAN, French West Africa, March 24 -- A broadly Socialist front of political leaders is trying to strike a bargain with foreign capital in French West Africa.

MESA, Ariz., April 3 (UP) -- The San Francisco Giants traded Bobby Thomson, the slugging Scot from Glasgow, to the Chicago Cubs today for an outfielder-first baseman, Bob Speake. The move was described by both clubs as one "to strengthen" their hitting.
WHILE "Say, Darling" was crossing the stage of the ANTA Theatre last evening, your correspondent had an unworthy thought. How much more gusto it would have if it were a musical comedy!

PARIS, April 3 --France's balance of payments, critical index of this nation's efforts to solve its central financial problem, moved deeply into the red during March, it was announced today. The balance of payments is the measure of profit or loss in financial dealings with foreign countries.
Stocks fell to the lowest levels of the year yesterday. There was a semblance of a rally in the late afternoon, but it petered out and prices closed irregularly down.
Three men were hurt yesterday by a taxicab that went out of control at 9:30 A. M. in front of the French Line's Pier 88, Forty-eighth Street and the Hudson River.

A floor in the tower of the office building rising at 200 East Forty-second Street has been leased by the builder, Joseph Durst, to the Consulate of Finland. The lease was negotiated by Emil Schattner of Pease Elliman, Inc., broker.

BOSTON, April 3 -- No fooling around for the Boston Bruins tonight. The local skaters played a possession game all the way and sent the New York Rangers to a 6-to-1 defeat in their Stanley Cup semi-final round hockey contest.

THOSE who try to second-guess as to which decorating fad will survive more than one season will not go wrong if they choose oriental. The latest evidence to support the theory of oriental's longevity in the American home is the fact that Charles R. Gracie Sons has moved.
Benefit payments by insurance companies to New York State residents covered by health insurance policies reached a new high last year, the Health Insurance Institute reported yesterday.

The 150th anniversary of the establishment of the Roman Catholic Diocese of New York will be observed on Sunday at a 10 A. M. pontifical mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Cardinal Spellman will be the celebrant.

The agreement for cooperation between the A. F. L.-C. I. O. and the American Social Hygiene Association has focused public attention on one of the less known activities of the federation. BUFFALO, April 3 (AP) -- A team of neurosurgeons at Columbia University reported success today in growing new nerve fibers in the spines of cats across gaps of about an inch.
The legality of the Transit Authority's 1954 bargaining contracts with two unions was upheld yesterday by the state's highest court.
MIAMI BEACH, April 3 (UP) -- Top-seeded Mervyn Rose of Australia and the unseeded Mexican champion, Mario Llamas, fought their way today into the semi-finals of the Good Neighbor tennis tournament.

American Window Glass Company of Pittsburgh, Pa., yesterday announced to stockholders the terms of a proposed merger with Blue Ridge Glass Corporation of Kingsport, Tenn., and the American Saint-Gobain Corporation. holders will meet April 22 to vote on the terms.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 3 (UP) -- Two home runs by Charlie Neal and one by Dick Gray, a rookie, helped the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 5 -- 3 victory over the Milwaukee Braves today as the National League rivals opened their annual spring tour.

United Artists Associated, Inc., organized this year, plans to purchase the assets, properties and film television business of Associated Artists Production Corporation, subject to approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 3 -- President Sukarno strongly reaffirmed tonight his faith in "guided democracy," a major factor in the Jakarta Government's armed struggle with the anti-Communist rebels in Central Sumatra.

DENVER, April 3 (AP) -- Spectators jeered and the referee warned both fighters for inaction tonight as Nino Valdes of Cuba waltzed to a split and loudly-booed decision over Wayne Bethea in a ten-round heavyweight match.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Department store sales in March, allowing for such factors as the date of Easter, were better than in February but well below March a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

A filmed interview with Gamal Abdel Nasser, president of the United Arab Republic, will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Sunday from 3:30 to 4 P. M. The interview will be carried on radio from 12:05 to 12:30 P. M.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- For the first time since World War II trading stopped briefly today on the Chicago Board of Trade.

CHICAGO, April 3 (AP) -- Corn futures rallied shortly before the close of the Board of Trade today and all contracts finished with gains for the fourth consecutive day and at their high prices of the day.

PARIS, April 3 -- Jacques Heim, the couturier, believes that the greatest benefit to haute couture lies in closer ties between Paris and the other fashion centers of the world, particularly the United States.
OTTAWA, April 3 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's domestic exports declined 6 per cent in February to $319,600,000, from $340,100,000 a year earlier, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 3 -- Negotiations have broken down between Britain and the Maldives for establishment of a Royal Air Force base on Gan Island. Work on base construction has come to a standstill.

TRENTON, April 3 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared today that unemployment benefits should be extended only as a "last resort" in seeking to alleviate the recession.

Cotton futures prices moved 8 points (40 cents a bale) up to 1 point (5 cents a bale) off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Trading volume was moderate.
WIESBADEN, Germany, April 3 (Reuters) -- A West German court trying to determine whether Anna Anderson is Anastasia, youngest daughter of Czar Nicholas II, adjourned today until next month.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The United States, which has received six letters in four months from the Soviet Union on a summit meeting, prodded Moscow twice today for another.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- William C. Huebner of Mamaroneck, N. Y., who has spent half a century in the field of graphic arts, obtained a patent this week for "smoke printing." The apparatus deposits electrically charged particles on paper without the application of pressure.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 4 -- Two New Jersey youngsters were injured severely today in accidents involving home-made rockets. A third youth was recovering from a similar accident yesterday.
DETROIT, April 4 -- Additional plant shutdowns and temporary lay-offs are scheduled in the auto industry this month.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- (UP) The Commerce Department rejected today a Republican Congressman's protest against its decision to let American concerns bid for a contract to supply design data for a Russian tire plant.

The names of the women who will serve as hostesses on the fifth annual tour of houses for the benefit of the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation have been announced.

The greatest tool of science for studying the universe, from the constitution of the galaxies and clouds of cosmic dust in the far reaches of space to the infinitesimal spaces within the nuclei of atoms, is the spectroscope. It uses the characteristic spectrum of light emitted by each individual object, large or small, in the manner of "cosmic finger prints."
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- One of the most prolific sessions on Capitol Hill appears to be in the making as an aggressive and self-reliant Congress pauses for a ten-day Easter recess.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (UP) -- The American Veterans Committee attacked today the American Legion and what it described as other "veterans-firsters" for asking Congress to pass anti-recession measures that would benefit "veterans only."

BIG SPRING, Tex., April 5 -- Dave Sime of Duke led all the way today in beating Bobby Morrow, Abilene Christian College's Olympic sprint champion, in a wind-blown 100-yard dash that settled theirs three-year rivalry. Sime, timed in 9.6 seconds, won by a foot and a half.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 5 -- Spring in Suffolk County is not an unmixed blessing. It brings, among other and better things, the annual plague of the punkies.

BOSTON, April 5 (UP) -- Jim Poole of San Diego, defeated favored Finn Kobbero of Denmark, 15 -- 8, 6 -- 15, 15 -- 8, tonight to win the national badminton men's singles title.

FORT WORTH, April 5 (UP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers and the Milwaukee Braves fought gusts up to forty miles an hour today in an exhibition game, which the Braves won, 9 -- 5, before 7,859 fans.

THIS book is an amplification of one that Irving Kolodin edited in 1940. At that time it was named "The Critical Composer." Here it comes out considerably bigger, under a new title, with some extracts that were then curtailed (such as Berlioz on the Beethoven symphonies) now presented in full.

BOSTON, April 5 -- The names of four ministers have been placed in nomination for president of the American Unitarian Association. Their names are to appear on ballots prepared for the annual meeting here May 26-27.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 5 -- An Israeli delegation spokesman denied today that his Government had "bowed to urgent American demands" in halting work this week on its Lake Hula reclamation project on the Syrian border.

TOKYO, April 6 -- Tokyo Meteorological Agency has revealed that recent readings of radioactivity in the air over Japan registered a record. Radioactivity discovered in rain from March 18 to the end of the month varied from 3,000 micromicrocurie per liter to 200,000 micromicrocurie per liter.

The Getty Oil Company last year had a net income of $14,637,735, or 93 cents each, on the 15,155,968 common shares outstanding at the year-end, according to the 1957 report. This compares with $7,887,947, or 49 cents a share, in 1956.

Cautious captains bound along the Inside Passage between Seattle, Vancouver or Victoria and the Alaskan ports used to heave to outside the Seymour Narrows and wait for the tide. If the tide were right they usually stayed outside when the Narrows were wrapped, as they often were, in a blanket of Pacific fog.

THE war between husbands and wives was the subject of both operas presented at the City Center last night. It is a theme that has been done to death in other areas of American entertainment, and if the lyric theatre is looking for a field where the dividends are small, this is it.

Smith, president of Smith-Corona, and Walter Kassebohm, executive vice president and general manager of Marchant Calculators, said a formal merger agreement would be submitted to the boards and shareholders for their approval.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6 (AP) -- The Professional Golfers Association today added the $20,000 Eastern open at Baltimore to the summer tournament schedule as one of the replacements for the Canceled Tam o' Shanter All-American championship.

" THIS Prisoner Barabbas," an Easter dramatization over Channel 4 yesterday, was an inspiring hour of television. The script by Henry Denker was suggested by the story of the thief whose life was spared on the day of Christ's death.

Cotton futures weakened last week. At the close of trading on Thursday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 15 to 34 points from the previous week's close. The exchange was closed on Good Friday.

A supermarket building at 154-56 Henry Street in downtown Brooklyn has been sold and leased back by H. C. Bohack Co., the occupant. John J. Reynolds, Inc., broker, negotiated the deal, which involved $1,300,000.
WARSAW, April 6 -- A new dispute between Poland's ruling Communist party and the majority of the country's writers has erupted over Marek Hlasko, the most popular of Poland's new young writers.

In its original orchestral version, however, it is virtually unknown. Yet on Saturday night that version, even though the performance of it did not start until midnight, drew 1,850 persons to Carnegie Hall.

President Eisenhower's message to Congress last week on reorganization of the Pentagon is unlikely to satisfy the armed services, Congress or the section of the public that has studied defense organization.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, which purchased television rights last week to the musical "Wonderful Town," agreed to pay the authors $150,000. The sum is believed to be the highest ever paid by television to an author or group of authors for a single property.
MIAMI BEACH, April 6 (AP) -- Australia's Mervyn Rose and Brazil's Maria Bueno took the men's and women's singles titles in the tenth annual Good Neighbor tennis tournament today.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 6 -- There has been a payments balance on current account for some time past that shows a surplus of no less than 250,000,000 guilders a quarter. PARIS, April 6 -- A quarrel over the projected European free trade zone threatens to break up the European Payments Union. SAN ANTONIO, April 6 -- When a fellow stays overly long in the Arizona Desert he has a tendency to lose his grip on reality. Nor does it help him much to flee to Texas, where everything is on a grandiose scale and where perspectives can be just as warped.
ROME, April 6 -- Pope Pius XII urged the world today to dedicate all its resources to the "firm restoration of a just peace."

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 6 (AP) -- The McMillan Cup was awarded to Navy today after rain and poor visibility had forced cancellation of the third and final race in the thirty-first Atlantic Coast invitation regatta for big boats.

The Flying Tiger Line reported yesterday that it expected a substantial increase in group tourist travel this year.

H. R. TREVOR-ROPER, Regius Professor of Modern History at Oxford University, is a scholar who takes all history for his province -- or at least all European history. While other historians narrowly concentrate on Stuart statutes or Merovingian morals, Mr. Trevor-Roper confidently roams across the abysm of time, from the Age of Homer to the Age of Toynbee.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Congress's jealously guarded power of the purse appeared today to be a major stumbling block in the way of President Eisenhower's plan for reorganizing the Defense Department.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 6 -Recent heavy rains in northern California have increased significantly the levels of radioactivity in leafy vegetables. However, they are still safe to eat.
Marco Rizo, pianist-composer, offered a program of his own compositions at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon.

Potato futures soared in active trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The near-by April position rose the daily limit of 1/2 cent a pound and the May futures climbed the limit of 30 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) from Thursday's settlement price.
Kings County District Attorney Edward S. Silver promised yesterday to present to the grand jury all the facts in an alleged police brutality case.

Arthur Knapp Jr. of Larchmont will leave the canyons of commerce for the sea during those months. The Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland reports in its monthly review that food prices, which generally rise in the spring, rose higher and sooner this year than usual.

BENJAMIN OREN, a young pianist who was born in Argentina and raised in Israel, gave his first New York recital last night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The program was the first of three in which he will appear there, for on April 27 he will be the accompanist for Charles Treger, violinist, and on May 11 he will give a joint recital with Leslie Chabay, tenor.
Northwest Airlines, Inc., last year attained the highest revenues and net income in its thirty-one-year history.

Eighty-one housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration will take bids April 15 on issues of short-term notes totaling $77,340,000 to finance low-rent housing.
