TAILORED WOMAN is crystal gazing this spring. Its first floor is strung with all sorts of crystal necklaces -plain and fancy, clear and iridescent. The beads are made up into every sort of necklace, from a single rope to a twenty-one-strand bib.
The Consolidated Edison Company postponed yesterday the sale of $50,000,000 of thirty-year mortgage bonds from April 22 to June 3. No reason was given.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) has elected Leo D. Welch to the executive committee. This increases the membership of the committee from five to six. The board also designated Mr. Welch and three other members of the committee as executive vice presidents.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- President Eisenhower will throw out the traditional first ball at the major league baseball opener next Monday between the Washington Senators and the Boston Red Sox, the White House announced today.

Steel production was cut back a little more last week, partly because of the Good Friday observance. But it was scheduled to be reduced even further this week, to 1,306,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 7 -- The Admiral Corporation today filed a countersuit in Federal District Court here, charging the Zenith Radio Corporation with patent infringement and acts of unfair competition.

Chairmen of the tenth annual Spring Frolic tea dance and officers and directors of the Humane Society of New York, which will benefit from the event, will attend a cocktail party on Thursday at the home of Mrs. August M. Funke, a director of the society.

YOKOTA AIR FORCE BASE, Japan, Tuesday, April 8 (AP) -- A silver jet Stratotanker streaked off the United States Air Force runway at dawn today for Madrid, trying for a new world distance and speed record. The flight will be nonstop and without refueling.

A reappraisal of the causes of the Civil War is given by Otto Eisenschiml in his newest book, "Why the Civil War?" The author contends the conflict was "not inevitable" and that Lincoln had a plan that might have preserved the peace without appeasement.
A Penn-Texas Corporation "Clean House" stockholders committee has announced it will solicit proxies for a slate of eight candidates for the nineman board to be elected here on May 5.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 7 (UP) -- A Russian guard at the Soviet pavilion of the Brussels World's Fair has been shot and killed under mysterious circumstances, it was disclosed today.

KAMPALA, Uganda, April 7 -- During a short visit to Uganda, Eugene R. Black said that in the next ten to fifteen years the World Bank would be more active in Africa than in any other part of the world.
TOKYO, April 7 (Reuters) -The ten remaining Japanese war criminals convicted of major responsibility for leading their country into aggressive warfare were freed unconditionally today.

KNOW all men by these presents from John Brennan that New Hampshire's lust for battle has been aroused. It will defend, as Bowie defended the Alamo, its title as the greatest little fresh-water fishing state between Vermont and Maine.

LONDON, April 7 -- Lady Violet Bonham Carter compared her experiences in the recent by-election to those of a soldier in an "army of liberation entering an occupied country which for years has been ruled by quislings and collaborators."
CAIRO, April 7 -- Eugene R. Black said tonight the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development would help Egypt in drafting plans to increase the capacity of the Suez Canal.
The management of the Collins Aikman Corporation, a $33,000,000 textile concern, is waiting to see if it will have a fight for control on its hands.
DETROIT, April 7 (AP) -- The auto industry still is trying to pare dealer inventories.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Treasury bill rate dipped again this week to the lowest point since January, 1955.
Payrolls shrank by $1,500,000,000 in the first seven months of the present recession, the National Industrial Conference Board estimated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- The State Department announced today that Seattle had been selected as the site for the annual meeting of the eighteen Colombo Plan nations. The session will seek way's to develop South and Southeast Asia.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 7 -- Dr. Seth B. Nicholson, astronomer with the Mount Wilson and Mount Palomar Observatories in California, does not think it is worth the cost to land a human being on the moon, unless Siberia is overcrowded.

WARSAW, April 7 -- A two-page paper bearing the name of the liquidated Polish students weekly Po Prostu is circulating in Warsaw. The format and type of the paper are similar to those used by the weekly.
SZOLNOK, Hungary, April 7 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev said today that Americans were good people but destined for second place in the race for world economic leadership.

NEWARK, N. J., April 7--The Greater Newark Women's Division of the American Jewish Congress will benefit from the performances on April 9, 10, and 13 of "Peter and the Wolf," to be presented by the Holiday Theatre at the Clinton Place Junior High School here.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- A national wildlife group official today asked Congress for money to construct twenty-two wildlife refuges around the nation.

Two Hungarian-born musicians collaborated to give a distinguished recital last night in Town Hall. They were Ede Zathureczky, violinist, and Bela Boszormenyi - Nagy, pianist. Both currently teach at Indiana University.
An autopsy on the body of Andrew J. Kennedy, a real estate man, has disclosed a "substantial amount" of barbiturates.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 8 -- President Iskander Mirza, whose word less than a year ago had considerable to do with the making and breaking of Pakistani Governments, is facing a hard fight to save his own political life.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 8 -- National League managers who have been down-grading the Giants -- mostly from force of habit -- had better start revising their calculations. Not only has Bill Rigney popped up with three rookie prizes in Orlando Cepeda, Willie Kirkland and Jim Davenport, but some of the more established operatives have shown new life as well.
Martha Graham's revival of "Appalachian Spring," postponed from last week, took place last night in Miss Graham's repertory season at the Adelphi Theatre.
A Federal judge's musicians-union card has created no discord between the bench and opposing lawyers in the retrial of James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
BRIGHT color is the common denominator of this spring's unusually varied collections of decorator fabrics.
The Writers Guild of America feels that American troops in Saudi Arabia, Eritrea, Iceland and other far-flung areas should not be exposed to television commercials.
Judy Garland's debt to the State Tax Commission was settled yesterday in Queens Supreme Court with the payment of $8,936.08.

The Textured Yarn Company of Philadelphia, maker of yarns under the trade name Tycora, yesterday introduced yarns for woven fabrics for the fashion trade. They included lace, jersey, brocade and crepe yarns in various weights, made of synthetic fibers.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Eisenhower urged Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev today to make a start toward disarmament by agreeing to study methods of inspecting disarmament.

Stockholders in the Duquesne Light Company were told at the annual meeting yesterday in Pittsburgh that the company's atomic power plant at Shippingport, Pa., had proved itself to the point where it could substitute for conventional power plants when they were scheduled to be out of service.
A store will be opened early next month in Ridgewood, N. J., by W. J. Sloane. The announcement was made yesterday by Raymond S. Reed, president of the concern's Eastern division.

MILBURN, N. J., April 8 -- The Children's Theatre of the Junior League of the Oranges and Short Hills will present "Alice in Wonderland" at the Paper Mill Playhouse here on Saturday morning. The performance will be a benefit for the Children's Theatre.

PARIS, April 8 -- There are several explanations for Khrushchev's decision to forgo unilaterally the testing of nuclear weapons. There is, for example, the obvious propaganda advantage which Washington has rather lamely recognized.
Stockholders in the Blair Holdings Corporation voted yesterday at their annual meeting here to change the corporate name to Pepsi-Cola United Bottlers, Inc.

GENEVA, April 8 -- The United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea gave preliminary approval today to the principle that for purposes of international recognition there must be a "genuine link" between a nation and ships flying its flag.
WARSAW, April 9 (AP) -- Poznan's Cegielski railroad plant -- where the June, 1956, freedom riots started -- has discharged a group accused of trouble-making, the newspaper Party Life reported today.
As long as Americans want "an eyeful," small, economy cars have a limited future here, one of England's top automotive industrialists said yesterday.

An amendment to the state's security-risk law, rushed through the Legislature during its closing days, is now lying on Governor Harriman's desk awaiting -- we hope and expect -- his veto. This bill moves directly contrary to the common-sense philosophy expressed earlier this year by the Governor's special committee on public employe security procedures headed by Whitelaw Reid.

Dr. Arthur F. Burns, formerly Chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, is reported in The New York Times of March 23 as urging an official anti-inflation policy. That policy was declared as a governmental order in 1789 in the United States Constitution, Article 1, Section 8, Clause 5: "The Congress shall have * * * power to coin money, regulate the value thereof * * *."
RALEIGH, N. C., April 8 (AP) -- A $12,000,000 nuclear test reactor will be built in North Carolina, the first to be operated by a service organization rather than a manufacturing company.

Sales psychology at the International Automobile Show at the Coliseum: The blond spieler at the Chrysler exhibit wearing a gold-plated evening gown that cost as much as two Imperials or four British Triumph Tr3's or eight Swedish Saabs. Car sales, all over the two floors, have been brisk.

Earnings of the P. Lorillard Company for the first two months of this year rose more than 400 per cent and sales were up more than 120 per cent over the same period last year. Lewis Gruber, president, reported the results to some 700 stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A maze of Government figures on jobs and joblessness added up today to some further deterioration in March, after allowance for normal seasonal expectations. Although the total number of employed increased over February, mostly because of farming, and unemployment rose slightly, the key figure showed a sharp decline.
AS a housewife and an American I wish to vehemently protest the action of Mayor Wagner in proclaiming "Z. O. A. Enrollment Month" and in urging New Yorkers to join the Zionist organization.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The General Electric Company has appealed to the Government for stiffer barriers against imports of heavy equipment for producing electric power, such as generators and transformers.

ALGIERS, April 8 (AP) -- French troops and Algerian nationalists clashed in three areas of Eastern Algeria today and a French announcement said 243 rebels had been killed. The French losses were not given.

LA PLATA, Md., April 8 (AP) -- A California company today bought 7,775 acres in Charles County, Md. It is believed to be the largest single land transaction ever carried out in the Washington metropolitan area. Tax stamps issued indicated the price was $6,000,000.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 8 (UP) -- Phil Paine's squeeze bunt in the thirteenth inning today enabled the Milwaukee Braves to post a 5-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers and evened their spring exhibition series at four games each.
Two major bond issues, $80,000,000 of American Can Company debentures and $40,000,000 of Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., debentures, are being offered to investors today.

Three floors in the office building at 535 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Forty-fourth Street, have been leased by Ellington Co., advertising agency, through the Charles F. Noyes Company, broker. The deal involves 35,000 square feet and rentals of $1,500,000.
OTTAWA, April 8 -- The Royal Commission on Canada's Economic Prospects recommended today three steps to keep United States investment from threatening Canada's economic independence. They were:

Directors of the Western Electric Company yesterday elected J. Wilson Newman and Kurtz M. Hanson as members of the board. The company is the manufacturing subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

HISTORY repeats itself in a sequence of English chintzes and French toiles on exhibition at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 57 East Fifty-seventh Street. The exhibition will continue through June.
TUNIS, April 8 -- Leaders of the Algerian National Liberation Front are expected to arrive here tomorrow from Cairo.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed off 10 points (50 cents a bale) to 4 points (20 cents a bale) up yesterday, after fluctuating in a narrow range all day.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 8 -- Although the Yankees failed to win today, Manager Casey Stengel, who can be a magnanimous loser, didn't seem to mind it a bit. In fact, he was smiling as he headed for the train that was to take this baseball road show on to Winston-Salem, N. C.

FORMATION of the Long Island League of Salt Water Sportsmen, dedicated to fighting any efforts to license salt-water fishermen, was announced yesterday by Don Manns, its temporary executive secretary.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities said today that four persons employed by the Government in the Nineteen Thirties and Forties had refused to reply to questions about Communist affiliations.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter charged today that a lawsuit aimed at banning atomic weapon tests was a "propaganda hoax" engineered by Communist sympathizers.
ALBANY, April 8 -- Governor Harriman vetoed today without comment a bill that would have saved millions for utilities of the state.
An attempt to head off the possible appointment of Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the City Housing Authority that is to replace it came into the open yesterday.

COATESVILLE, Pa., April 7 (AP) -- The first glimpse at the profits picture in the ailing steel industry in the first quarter came today when the Lukens Steel Company, a specialty maker, reported that net income for the twelve weeks ended March 22 was not quite half what it was in the corresponding period a year ago.
BONN, Germany, April 8 -- A steel strike in the Ruhr was averted early today when union officials and mill owners reached a provisional agreement for a wage increase.
Ned Irish knew that Fuzzy Levane was coming so he baked a cake.

Three fires in Columbia University men's dormitories shortly after 3 A. M. yesterday sent more than 500 sleepy students from their rooms for half an hour while firemen put out the blazes. No one was injured.
The Erie Railroad has cut the salaries of all executives earning more than $12,000 a year by 10 per cent.

With a display of courage and common sense heretofore absent from official discussion of the subject a Mayor's committee headed by Charles F. Preusse, City Administrator, has advised sale of the cityowned subway power plants to Consolidated Edison.
A former Internal Revenue Service clerk was accused yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court of making ten false income tax refund claims on which she collected $2,394.

Directors of Daitch Crystal Dairies, Inc., yesterday declared an extra dividend of 2 per cent in stock. The company, operator of a chain of supermarkets in the New York area, reported sharp increases in sales and earnings.

Net income of the United Shoe Machinery Corporation and its associated domestic companies in the year ended Feb. 28, declined to $9,511,772, or $3.96 a common share, from $12,601,298, or $5.26 a share, in the preceding year.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Daughter of the American Revolution reported today there were eleven candidates for the seven vice-president general posts to be filled during the D. A. R.'s Sixty-seventh Congress here April 14-18.

John Hildring, president of the General Aniline and Film Corporation, told the annual meeting here yesterday that he had been informed that the Government hoped to be able to dispose of most of its stock in the company.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads said today that Class I railroads operated at an estimated over-all deficit of $9,000,000 in February. The loss reflected both severe winter weather, which hampered transportation, and the general decline in business.
HAVANA, April 8 -- Encounters in Oriente Province between Government troops and insurgents continued today, according to communiques from army headquarters.

College coaches who attended the Amateur Athletic Union's national indoor swimming championships last week-end came away strongly impressed by the brilliant young talent on display in Yale's Payne Whitney Gymnasium pool.

Please accept my congratulations for the series of excellent articles by Harrison Salisbury on juvenile delinquency. A more timely and significant topic does not exist. May I take the liberty to emphasize one or two most important points?

A two-day-old strike against the Columbia Broadcasting System by radio and television technicians won short-lived support here yesterday from teamsters. However, the backing lasted long enough to keep scenery and props from some of the shows.

TRENTON, April 8 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner and State Supreme Court Justice Joseph Weintraub today urged state magistrates to employ a rarely used power and jail motorists found driving while on the revoked list.
Union-management unemployment benefit funds have put more than $25,000,000 into the pockets of jobless automobile and steel workers, a survey disclosed yesterday.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, April 8 -- Israeli engineers began moving new machinery into the Lake Hula area today. They plan to resume work there tomorrow.
Dr. Ernst Weber, president of the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, yesterday assailed proposed national research institutes that use Federal funds.
LOS ANGELES, April 8 -- The chief factor in the increase in lung cancer is air pollution, not smoking, a pioneer in smog research said today.
A "SACK" that reverses, a child's chair that doubles as a play table, a rocker and a tunnel and a push-button-operated kitchen were among the products cited yesterday for their versatility of design.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 8 -- "Unofficial" candidates of the opposition United party were elected today to two seats in the South African Parliament to represent Cape Colored voters.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Southern railroads abandoned today their campaign to increase rates for export-import traffic.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield announced today that 918 new post office buildings had been started throughout the country or would be under construction by early fall. The cost was estimated at $49,245,000.

HONG KONG, April 8 -- The arrival today in Peiping of a Soviet trade delegation foreshadowed possible important new trade arrangements between Communist China and the Soviet Union. The mission's leader is Ivan G. Kabanov, Minister of Foreign Trade, a Peiping radio dispatch said.

The pressure for increased United States economic aid to India builds up apace. Such increased aid is strongly favored by Senators Cooper and Kennedy in Washington. In your March 27 editorial you gave sympathetic consideration to their views, and on April 1 you printed a letter from Prof. W. W. Rostow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, elaborating further on the Senators' proposal.

Accentuating the positive and eliminating the negative may be a good way to make friends and influence people, but a corporation should not try it within sight of the Securities and Exchange Commission. That is especially true if the company is about to undertake financing in the public market.
It was Cicero who in one of his most famous orations asked a question now echoed by many of us, "Where on earth are we?" -- in his own orotund and rhythmic Latin, Ubinam gentium sumus?
GENEVA, April 8 (Reuters) -- A United States Government grant of $450,000 will help resettle 950 White Russian refugees stranded in Hong Kong, it was announced today.

In a prompt and plainly worded reply to Premier Khrushchev's first message to him President Eisenhower questions the sincerity of the Soviet announcement of an uncontrolled nuclear test suspension and challenges Mr. Khrushchev, as the new head of the Soviet Government, to reconsider his Government's position and to demonstrate in action its peaceful professions.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8 -- Dag Hammarskjold said today that he welcomed the Soviet Union's unilateral decision to stop nuclear test explosions.

ONE hot June morning in 1880 Tommy Sullivan sat barefoot on the doorstep outside his father's humble cottage in Bedford Street in Fall River, Mass., when a clerical-looking gentleman, a stranger, came by.

OSSINING, N. Y., April 8 -- Forty Roman Catholic specialists in problems confronting the less-developed areas of the world opened a four-day conference here today at Maryknoll Seminary. They will seek ways to integrate religious and cultural efforts in those areas with action in the social and economic fields.
TORREJON AIR BASE, Spain, April 8 (UP) -- A four-jet United States Air Force tanker plane streaked 10,233 miles across two oceans and a continent today without stopping or refueling.

An elegant, distantly arrogant member of the first-night audience will no longer sit on the aisle at Broadway openings. George Jean Nathan, the grand panjandrum of drama criticism, died yesterday after two years of failing health, bringing to a close an active career that had lasted a half century.

For the last eleven years, at least, Alfonso Lopes has had a deep and abiding hatred for work, according to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan. And this was the underlying reason that Lopez was arraigned in Felony Court yesterday on a charge of grand larceny.

Philip Morris, Inc., showed first-quarter sales of approximately $99,472,000, a gain of 4.4 per cent over the $95,294,000 volume in the same period last year, Joseph F. Cullman 3d, president, reported yesterday.
Blood will be given today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, 31 Nassau Street,and at the City Penitentiary at Rikers Island.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 8 (AP) -- Chancery Court Judge Collins J. Seitz today handed down a restraining order forbidding election results of Williams-Mc-Williams, Inc., from going into effect.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Administration's plan for policing a suspension of atomic tests calls for stationing squads of international detectives on land, on the sea and in the air throughout the world.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Hog receipts today were far above expectations and prices of butcher grades declined 75 cents to $1 in the late trade. The offerings of 13,000 head were the heaviest since Jan. 7, and 5,000 head more than had been expected.
Harry Canelstein, realty investor and builder, has contracted to buy the one-story taxpayer at 1762-68 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx. The stores are on a plot 100 by 120 feet.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, April 9 (AP) -- Warren Wright, a political veteran who bucked the Republican organization, claimed victory early today over Louis E. Beckman in the feature race of the Illinois primary election.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Federal Office of Education sweepingly endorsed educational television today as a giant force waiting to be fully harnessed.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 8 -- Indonesia made a new request today to buy $120,000,000 worth of United States small arms, planes and warships.
The United States Government has closed the books on its first venture in 100 per cent ship mortgage insurance. It was an unhappy venture.

LONDON, April 8 (UP) -- The International Amateur Athletic Federation, revealing a bitter feud between the world's top sports organizations, today threatened to set up a rival "world championship" if the International Olympic Committee did not give it a share of the receipts from the games.

A corporation and three of its former officers were found guilty last night by a jury in Federal Court here of conspiring to defraud the Government. They were accused of selling to the Army brake parts described by a prosecutor as "nothing but junk." A fourth man was acquitted.
SANTIAGO DE CUBA, April 8 -- A loud explosion rocked Santiago de Cuba tonight causing a flurry of nervous firing by Government troops stationed on rooftops throughout the city.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, said tonight "it is obvious" the Soviet Union was "on a war footing despite their occasional wily protestations of peaceful intent."
A young pianist named Jane Stanton made an appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall last night.

The question of whether to wax or not to wax a vinyl floor perplexes many a homemaker. Vinyl manufacturers contend that buffing maintains the natural luster without waxing and that a mild detergent in water will clean the floor.
Maryland borrowed $24,582,000 in the public market yesterday to finance school and other construction projects.
LOWESTOFT, England, April 8 -- There are a good many inhabitants of this once prosperous fishing port who think expanded trade with the Iron Curtain countries would be a good thing for Britain.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A labor union argued today that it had the same right to withdraw from bargaining with a group of employers that one of the employers had.

WHITE PLAINS, April 8 -- The New York Central Railroad offered today to continue operating its Putnam Division passenger service experimentally for six months if Westchester County would meet one of two conditions.
The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts has revised its site plan in anticipation of city and Federal approval of the acquisition of half a block more.

News that the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is going to help Egypt draft plans to deepen and widen the Suez Canal makes good sense. Issues of this nature should be divorced from politics and from international rivalries or favoritisms.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 8 -- Billy Haughton, Stanley Dancer and other harness racing drivers may hog the headlines -- and the purses -- but Charles Wingate, a comparatively unknown sulky pilot created a stir in the first week of competition at Roosevelt Raceway.
PITTSBURGH, April 8 (AP) -- Allison R. Maxwell Jr., president of the Pittsburgh Steel Com-

United States Rubber Company has developed a process that is said to improve the quality of nylon passenger car tires. Nylon tires, made by the new process, called pressure tempering, will not stretch and are practically immune to tread-groove cracking, according to G. Raymond Cuthbertson, vice president and general manager of the company's rubber division.
HAVING abandoned all hope, Jean Anouilh can write the most devastating comedies of our time.

BUKITTINGGI, Indonesia, April 8 (AP) -- Assassins hurled hand grenades at the revolutionary government headquarters last night, apparently in an attempt to kill a top rebel leader. Three guards were wounded by the window-shattering blasts.

CHICAGO, April 8 (AP) -- Corn futures bumped into moderate resistance on the Board of Trade today after five consecutive days of advances but finished fractionally ahead in three of the five major contracts.

A contract for the purchase of the eleven-story apartment building at 60 West Sixty-eighth Street has been resold by David Hammerman, who contracted to buy the property a few days ago in a deal negotiated by James Pessel of the Kaye Realty Company.
A NEW device that should prove a boon to the homemaker is a portable washing machine that will launder four pounds of clothes at one time.

A pair of Chinese ferret-badgers, animals never before in captivity in the United States, have arrived at the Bronx Zoo in a cloud of oriental mystery. Apart from the fact that this mammal is to be found in southeastern China and Indochina, little is known about the ferret-badger.

THE voice of the old-fashioned carpet beater, once a harbinger of spring, has been replaced by the whirring vacuum cleaner. The impact of spring cleaning has been lightened by science, the ingenuity of mechanical engineers and improved procedures.
Kentucky, the National Collegiate basketball champion, had one of the best-balanced teams in the country, according to N C. A. A. figures reevaled yesterday.
"Look Homeward, Angel," Ketti Frings' adaptation of Thomas Wolfe's turbulent autobiographical novel, yesterday won the Drama Critics Circle award as the best American play of the season.
The insurgent group in the Mesabi Iron Company said yesterday that it had received proxies from more than 1,200 shareholders, or more than half of all the shareholders.

VIENNA, April 8 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union reversed himself today, assuring Hungarian Communists that they could count on armed support of the whole "Socialist camp" in the event of another revolt.
NEWARK, April 8 -- Harrison A. Williams Jr., candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, was far more confident than ever tonight of winning next Tuesday's primary election.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 8 -- Government forces in Central Sumatra are finding nature a tougher foe than the rebels. The insurgents have not been putting up a determined resistance.
Auto makers are cooperating in old-style meetings aimed at making their dealers get out and sell.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -Secretary of State Dulles said today that the United States would not supply arms "to either side" in the Indonesian civil war.
The fate of the sunken Italian liner Andrea Doria was debated yesterday in conflicting statements from both sides of the Atlantic.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 8 -- The Federal Small Business Administration invited Long Island business men today to partake of $500,000,000 worth of Government buying to ease the recession in this region.

NEW DELHI, India, April 8 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru made a careful attempt today to remove political implications from his support for celebrations tomorrow marking the sixtieth birthday of Paul Robeson.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- The Washington Pilgrimage of 1958 announced today the following awards for religious leadership:
The current campaign to encourage New Yorkers to "Cross at the Green, Not In Between" got statistical support yesterday from state and city accident reports.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 8 -- The undergraduate Interclub Committee, which coordinates elections to student eating clubs at Princeton University, stated today that it "disapproves on moral grounds of racial and religious discrimination."

The United Aircraft Corporation had sales in the first quarter this year exceeding $300,000,000, H. M. Horner, chairman, told shareholders at their annual meeting in East Hartford, Conn. In the same three months of last year the company's sales were $298,000,000.
Despite the decline in the fortunes of Hollywood, the business of making films -- including those for industry, education and television -- is bigger and better than ever.

Record gross revenues of $7,978,314,000 for last year were announced yesterday by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in its pamphlet report for 1957. This was about 10 per cent above the $7,281,883,000 reported for 1956.
Scattered price reductions in copper, aluminum products and zinc were announced yesterday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 8 -- Representatives of the Navy, the Army and the Coast Guard approved here today the proposed lowering of bridge clearances over the East Coast Intracoastal Waterway to fifty-five feet from eighty feet.
The Fire Department's intensive investigation of the city's loft and factory buildings spread into the garment district yesterday.

Henceforth, "Three Against Time" will identify Pearl Buck's new and original play, temporarily referred to in 1956 as "The White Bird." Since then the script has gone through two extensive reconstruction jobs in accordance with suggestions from "top theatrical figures," who remain anonymous.

The unwary commuter who steps aboard the train on Track 24 at Grand Central Terminal without first reading the signs is in for a surprise. Instead of heading for Suburbia, he will find himself transported back to the nineteenth century.

LOS ANGELES, April 8 (AP) -- A medical researcher asserts that a young man who became drunk on eighteen Martinis in five hours was sobered in thirty minutes with two large doses of a thyroid substance.

Following is the text of a summary of proposals -- the first on Jan. 21, 1957, and the second on March 25, 1958 -- by the Consolidated Edison Company for the purchase of the three rapid transit power plants owned by the city.
Detectives of the narcotics squad last night arrested a 38-year-old painter accused of hiding heroin valued at $305,000 in the apartment of an elderly woman who did not know she was being duped.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 8 (AP) -- Harry L. Freyn's Floridian led throughout in the $4,000 Sun Archer Purse today before 10,458 spectators at Gulfstream Park. The $6.30-for-$2 choice defeated Lady Elliott and My Preference, who raced coupled as the Ione Groves entry.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Robert Wilbur Burgess, top counter in the Census Bureau, established his talent with figures -- among other things -- a half-century ago, as high man in his class at Brown University.
LONDON, April 8 -- A Labor member of the House of Commons criticized today the reception given by the United States Embassy to a delegation representing demonstrators against nuclear armament.

Commodity futures closed irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Copper, potatoes and world sugar contracts were active. Sugar, potatoes, cottonseed oil, copper, zinc and wool declined; cocoa, coffee, hides and rubber rose, and price movements for lead were mixed.

BETHPAGE, L. I., April 8 -- The Japanese Defense Agency plans to purchase 300 Super Tiger jet aircraft, the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation announced today. The purchase for the Air Self-Defense Force must be confirmed by the Japanese National Defense Council.

MONTREAL, April 8 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens made their vaunted power play pay off twice tonight to beat the fierce-checking Boston Bruins, 2 -- 1, before a crowd of 14,316 in the first game of the Stanley Cup hockey finals.

How old is an antique? Connoisseurs agree that America has reached the age when its heritage warrants an encyclopedia of the country's early decorative and applied arts. Fifty authorities have combined to present a pictorial story in "The Concise Encyclopedia of American Antiques," which Hawthorn Books will publish April 18 in a two-volume boxed set.

John McCarthy, one of the teen-agers being tried for the murder of Michael Farmer, was described yesterday as "a kid who has a mind like a scrambled egg." His attorney said he should be acquitted so he could be sent to an institution where he could be helped.

The "firing" of an important missile soon will lift the spirits of many Americans. The missile will be a baseball, and the firing officially begins at the opening of the major league season next week.

NEW HAVEN, April 8 -- Harry S. Truman came to Yale today and offered a preview of political observations he is likely to make during three days of student seminars. The former President said of the recession: "It's a recession when your neighbor loses his job; it's a depression when you lose yours."

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 8 -- Francis J. McCaffrey, former newspaper man, was elected today to the Rhode Island House of Representatives in a special election in this city's Ninth Representative District.
The United States Supreme Court's dismissal of Frank Costello's denaturalization case has endangered similar cases against fifteen Communists and three racketeers here.
The sale of the city's three rapid transit power plants to the Consolidated Edison Company at a gross price of $123,000,000 was recommended to Mayor Wagner yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will translate into a movie next year the Broadway play, "Blue Denim."

MOSCOW, April 8 -- Observers here regarded President Eisenhower's first letter to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev as a thoughtful appeal for the beginnings of a disarmament agreement between the Soviet Union and the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A "research report" attacking the Supreme Court as "an instrument of Communist global conquest" was issued by the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee today.

The New York Central Railroad's fixed interest debt rose by $24,449,835 last year, the company disclosed yesterday in its 1957 annual report. On a consolidated company basis, debts totaled $1,079,867,178 on Dec. 31, 1957.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- When Senator Arthur V. Watkins offered a prize for the best translation of a 212-word sentence in a Government income-tax booklet, he did not realize how many Americans love a contest.
After nine sessions of decline, the stock market reversed itself yesterday with a modest rally. Every important group showed gains.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Following is the text of the State Department's transcript of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today:

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Supreme Court was asked today to invalidate a California law stripping churches of their tax exemption unless an official of each church swears it does not advocate violent overthrow of the Government.

ASIDE from its great popularity, the art of Renoir, which radiates such an air of life and sunshine and happiness, is an ideal subject for the loan exhibition, opening today at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street.
PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- A Roman Catholic educator urged today that parochial schools throughout the country share in whatever state and Federal aid the public schools receive.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 8 (AP) -- The Bethlehem Steel Company will not have its first-quarter Sales and earnings available until later this month, Robert E. McMath, vice president and chairman of the finance committee, told the annual meeting today.
LONDON, April 8 -- The demand for British Government securities was again the feature of stock market trading today after the four-day Easter holiday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The six members of the Federal Communications Commission have accepted invitations to the convention of the National Association of Broadcasters at Los Angeles starting April 27.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 8 (AP) -- A Federal grand Jury today indicted Landon V. Butler, former multimillionaire commodities speculator, on a mail fraud conspiracy charge.

The Air Force is considering the abandonment of Mitchel Air Force Base, according to Under Secretary Malcolm A. MacIntyre. Mr. MacIntyre told a news conference yesterday that the question had been raised anew by officials seeking to tighten the Air Force budget.
PARIS, April 8 -- French authorities at Nice were holding today a cargo of radio equipment found in a Tunisian diplomatic shipment. It was allegedly bound for Algerian nationalist rebels.
A service station operator won a $275,000 pre-trial settlement yesterday in a negligence action against Socony Mobil Oil, Inc.

FROZEN hors d'oeuvres of outstanding quality are among the new foods now at Fraser-Morris, 872 Madison Avenue. Well-seasoned fillings -- smoked turkey pate with almonds, chopped chicken liver with wine and cheese with brandy, to name a few -- are encased in a light, tender pastry.
The social service program of East Side House Settlement will be furthered with the proceeds of a luncheon and fashion show next Wednesday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., April 8 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon's first-inning home run with the bases loaded provided the difference today in Cleveland's 11-7 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
Though it received fourteen bases on balls, Brooklyn College bowed, 13 -- 5, to the New York University baseball team on the Kingsmen's Roosevelt Field yesterday.
Jamaica had its second disqualification in a feature race within two days yesterday, with Ogden Phipps' Bureaucracy losing the decision this time to Mrs. Julie Miron's The Great Man.

MOSCOW, April 8 -- The Soviet Union promised West Germany today that it would examine "in good faith" the applications of all German citizens who wished to leave Soviet territory and return to Germany.
The vanguard of the first Soviet artistic ensemble to visit America in twenty-three years I prepared yesterday for a debut next M(mday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

Forty per cent of a group of 332 "unemployable" arthritics have been rehabilitated in an experimental project conducted by the New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation in cooperation with the Institute for the Crippled and Disabled.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., April 9 (AP) -- The International Union of Electrical Workers posted pickets today at General Electric's strikebound turbine generator plant.
CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- Soybean futures rose sharply on the Board of Trade today on an unconfirmed report that Spain had started or soon would start to buy large amounts of soybean oil.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of parents, lists the following films as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old. The films will be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise noted.

New jobs for old ships are planned as part of the Navy's future ship construction and conversion program. The Navy of today and tomorrow, profoundly altered in character by the technological revolution in warfare, is experiencing more rapid change in the twentieth century than ever before in the history of warships.
PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, April 9 (UP) -- The beaning of Frank Robinson overshadowed the pitching of Harvey Haddix as the Cincinnati Redlegs posted a 2-0 victory over the Washington Senators today.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.

RABAT, Morocco, April 9 -Tunisian Embassy spokesmen charged today that French intelligence officials had "staged" the seizure in Nice Monday of radio equipment being transported under Tunisian diplomatic seal.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -President Eisenhower said today he would consider "very seriously" suspending nuclear weapons tests if the impending series produced satisfactory scientific information.
LONG BEACH, Calif., April 9 (AP) -- A giant red, white and blue airliner was rolled out today, bringing the jet age to a pioneer builder's long line of air transports.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 9 -- The American Federation of Musicians disclosed today that Samuel Goldwyn Productions, a major Hollywood independent film producer, has signed an interim agreement for the employment of union musicians here.
Reports of increased fighting in Cuba and rumors that the rebel strike was gaining momentum strengthened sugar prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

DALLAS, April 9 (UP) -- Hank Aaron slammed his eighth home run of the spring and his third in three games today as the Milwaukee Braves wound up their exhibition series with the Los Angeles Dodgers by gaining a 5-4 decision.
OSSINING, N. Y., April 9 -In spite of comprehensive social services the impact of change is weakening the family unit in Puerto Rico, the Rev. Ivan Illich reported here today.

The Indonesian Government's announcement that it had seeded a mine field in a sixty-mile stretch of coastal waters off Western Sumatra has alarmed marine underwriters as well as mariners sailing those waters.
Western Union Telegraph Company stockholders were told at yesterday's annual meeting that the company's future looked bright, despite a drop of more than 30 per cent in first-quarter earnings.

A year ago this month -- April 23 -- a pair of obscure jockeys rode the first victories of their careers at the Jamaica race track. Yesterday at the same place the same jockeys participated in separate divisions of the feature event, the Prioress for 3-year-old fillies, and each won.

Proponents of jet travel are fond of exciting prospective passengers with the thought of breakfast in New York and lunch in Los Angeles. Within a decade, if the design chief of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation is right, they are likely to be looking for ways to make the notion of two breakfasts attractive.
WHOLE boiled artichokes and boiled lobsters are occasionally referred to as the foods most likely to produce a feeling of panic when eaten in public.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 9 -- Though outhit by a considerable margin, Army took advantage of six St. John's errors to defeat the Redmen, 8 to 4, in an eight-inning baseball game at Doubleday Field today.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -Senator Thomas C. Hennings Jr. said today that the counsel for the Senate Internal Security subcommittee had specifically directed that an attack on the Supreme Court be published in a form suitable for reprinting and mailing.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 9 -- Indonesia has asked the United States for an "explanation and clarification" of Washington's comments on reports that Jakarta was ordering military equipment from Communist countries.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 9 -- The Screen Actors Guild has rejected a bid by the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists to form a joint authority covering actors in taped television commercials.
Shipments of zinc from United States smelters declined again last month as demand continued slow. Stocks of unsold metal in zinc smelters' hands rose to the highest level since the end of May, 1954.

GENEVA, April 9 -- A deadlock on the crucial issue of territorial waters loomed today at the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea after India rejected two Western attempts to achieve a compromise.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 9 (AP) -- The International Baseball League's president said that today's outburst of violence in Havana, had prompted reconsideration of opening the Havana Sugar Kings' season on home grounds.

A decline in the week ended last Friday of 1,893,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies totaled 214,754,000 barrels, compared with 216,647,000 a week earlier and 203,310,000 a year ago.
NEW HAVEN, April 9 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman said today he could not think of a single legislative mistake made under his leadership.
There can be no certainty that the bottom of the recession is at hand, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York warns.

DALLAS, April 9 -- The world champion Milwaukee Braves came wheeling into this rendezvous of millionaires for their final spring training joust today with the Dodgers, an organization of California gold-diggers.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 9 -The Ankara morning newspaper Ulus (The Nation) was ordered closed for one month today. Its cartoonist was sentenced to a year in prison and fined 10,000 liras ($3,571) on charges of insulting the Government.
A legacy of three knotty pier problems was bequeathed yesterday to his successor by Harold Kolovsky, retiring New Jersey member of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.

HARLIGEN, Tex., April 9 (UP) -- Mike McCormick, the San Francisco Giants' 20-year-old left-handed pitcher, posted a 6-3 victory over Cleveland's Herb Score today. He was helped by an error by the Indians' first baseman, Mickey Vernon, which led to three unearned runs.

CAIRO, April 9 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser was reported today to be hopeful of an early settlement of the question of compensation for nationalization of the Universal Suez Canal Company. The company was nationalized in July, 1956.

A ground-breaking ceremony was held yesterday for a fourteenstory cooperative apartment building at Fifth Avenue and 108th Street, the first middleincome project of its kind in Manhattan with private financing under the National Housing Act.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A new and as yet untitled play by N. Richard Nash has been bought by David Susskind and Roger L. Stevens for production next season.
Several leases of executive office space in buildings on Park Avenue were reported yesterday.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 9 -For more than three-quarters of the featured mile Class A pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, Caton Hanover "didn't get a call," as they say in the trade.

A merchant seaman fell into a ferry slip and disappeared in propeller-churned water last night while attempting to cross from one city ferryboat to another in the ferry terminal at St. George S. I. The police began a search for the man, whose identy was not learned immediately.

A letter from the Superintendent of Schools of Long Beach, Long Island, published on this page today suggests something of the problem created by Congressional delay in deciding whether the Federal Government is going to furnish financial aid for public school construction.
LONDON, April 9 -- Prices advanced in most sections of the stock market today, with British Government securities in the van.

The management of Best Co., New York specialty store company, won its week-long proxy fight with Bankers Securities Corporation of Philadelphia in a thirteen-and-a-half-hour annual meeting here on Tuesday.
SANTIAGO DE CUBA, April 9 -- In this hotbed of guerrilla operations, the general strike began fitfully at 11:30 this morning.
DARIEN, Conn., April 9 -Only registered voters will be permitted to take part in a referendum here Monday on a $3,000,000 bond issue for a new senior high school.
OLYMPIA, Greece, April 3 -Bulldozers and other mechanical monsters are disturbing the pastoral quiet, frightening the sheep and causing shepherds to gape like tourists.

The long-awaited report of the Royal Commission on Canada's Economic Prospects seems to have nothing in it to alarm American business men and investors. Since the report is 500 pages long, a judgment today has to be preliminary, but enough has come out to provide reassurance.
A Harlem "prophet" who rode in a pink Cadillac and reportedly sold "good-luck blessings" for $5 was arrested yesterday on mail fraud charges.
CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- The Air Pilots Association has ordered a strike against American Airlines on April 16 to support its demand for higher wages.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -The Army spelled out today the role it might have to play in civilian defense. The job could include taking over law and order and conscripting civilian manpower, if civilian authority was unable to handle the job.
NEWARK, April 9--The future of this country's economy rests "squarely and inevitably" upon private enterprise and not upon Government spending, Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell said here today.
New issues of corporate debt securities totaling $105,000,000 will be offered for public subscription today. They follow:
IT took time for the musical salute called "Swing Into Spring" on Channel 4 last night to burst into full bloom. When it did it was something to see and hear.
Dag Hammarskjold, a resident of New York by international fiat, will receive today the "freedom of the city" in which he has lived five years.
The Pennsylvania State School Building Authority sold yesterday two issues of bonds totaling $18,000,000 to a syndicate of banking houses headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.
ALBANY, April 9 -- Governor Harriman reluctantly approved a $9,500,000 supplemental budget bill today. He said that its legislative items could have been trimmed.

Difficult as it may be to believe, the New York State Legislature has passed a bill which would legalize the use of vacant cellar apartments declared unfit for human habitation twenty-eight years ago.
Because two boys from Connecticut ran away to New York to see the International Automobile Show, the Secret Service yesterday recovered a $10,000 gold certificate it had been hunting since 1937.

NEW DELHI, India, April 9 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru hailed today President Eisenhower's disarmament proposal to the Soviet Union yesterday as an important step toward easing world tension.

Columbia's baseball team scored its first triumph of the young season with an avalanche of thirteen hits yesterday. The blows fell on City College at Baker Field and resulted in a 16-3 triumph for the Lions, who had been beaten twice.

Ray Lev's recital at Carnegie Hall last night showed evidence of the pianist's growth and maturity.

Many American women believe that they are being shortchanged by the automotive industry, according to a survey by the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

WINSTON-SALEM, N. C., April 9 -- The Phillies, it develops, really are getting into Casey Stengel's hair. Cleanliness in hospitals often suffers from division of responsibility, a Harvard surgeon and specialist on hospital infection problems said yesterday.

SEVEN poised young women and eight trunks of clothes -- all insured for $l,000,000 -arrived here yesterday with the impact of a tornado. The women are models in the house of Christian Dior in Paris, and they will appear tonight in a pageant at the April in Paris Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Modern music predominated on last night's Musica Viva program at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. There were scores by the Frenchman Darius Milhaud, the German Hans Werner Henze and the Italian Luigi Nono.
WASHINGTON, April 9--Notice was served today by President Eisenhower that he would appeal directly to the people, if necessary, to win acceptance of his plan to reorganize the Defense Department.

BERLIN, April 9 -- Walter Ulbricht, Communist leader of East Germany, has set terms that the Evangelical Church must meet if it is to have "normal" relations with his regime. The Evangelical Church is Germany's largest Protestant body.

HAVANA, April 9 -- Violence flared in Havana and other sections of Cuba today as rebels called for a general strike against the Batista Government. At the end of the first day of clashes the insurgent forces apparently had achieved none of their major objectives in the city.

Today's new film is "Manhunt in the Jungle," a Warner Brothers drama in color, filmed in South America, at the Embassy Theatre. Robin Hughes, James Wilson and Luis Alvarez are among the principal players. Cedric Francis produced and Tom McGowan directed, from a screenplay by Sam Merwin Jr. and Owen Crump.

BOSTON, April 9 -- Roque Cordero, Panamanian composer, has received a travel grant from the American International Music Fund. Recent talk emanating from Washington concerning the possibility of Federal aid to local school systems for urgently needed classroom construction is aggravating the illness it is supposed to cure. Local initiative and effort are whittled away as the idea gains currency that a deepening of the depression is inevitable and that when it arrives the Federal Government will embark upon a school-aid program in order to help get the nation on its feet.

A virtually unlimited supply of compressed air is being made available to firefighters here for the first time. The Fire Department yesterday unveiled a mobile unit that will go to major fires and replenish the small tanks carried by firemen to supply their breathing masks.

Although a Federal prison might seem an improbable place to give a full symphony concert, Saul Caston did it with his Denver Orchestra last season with considerable success. The response was so favorable, he said yesterday, that the orchestra will give three more concerts in penal institutions next season.

Superb end - game play enabled Mikhail Botvinnik, the challenger, to win another point in the world chess championship match with Vassily Smyslov in Moscow yesterday, according to a report reecived through Soviet news sources.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP)--A Senate report warned today against trying to equal or surpass the soviet Union's satellites and other scientific advances by trying "to do it as the Russians do."

LISBON, Portugal, April 9 -Gen. Umberto Delgado, an outspoken friend of the United States, has decided to run as an Opposition candidate in the Portuguese Presidential election, according to reliable reports.

BUENOS AIRES, April 9 -Argentina broke off diplomatic relations with the Dominican Republic tonight. The Foreign Ministry said it had proof of "persistent activity by refugee" elements in Ciudad Trujillo linked to the ousted dictator Juan D. Peron and hostile to the government here.
Crime and racketeering were listed yesterday by Miss Jane Todd, Republican state vice chairman, as the two key issues in the fall political campaign in New York.

A new book has been written by Milovan Djilas. His previous writings caused his expulsion from the Communist party of Yugoslavia and his dismissal from high offices in the Yugoslavian Government, which he had served as vice president. His new work, called "Land Without Justice," will be published April 23 by Harcourt, Brace.

The crystalline structure of uranium is being determined by an instrument, said to be the only one of its kind, that will position samples with accuracies to a millionth of an inch. The device was developed by metallurgists of the General Electric Company at the Hanford, Wash., atomic plant.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 9 (AP) -- A Rhode Island group headed by the Salmanson family, owners of the Adams Drug Store Chain, today acquired the assets of Colt's Plastics Company, Inc., North Grosvenorsdale, Conn., from the PennTexas Corporation of New York, the parent company.

MOSCOW, April 9 (AP) -- Van Cliburn of Kilgore, Tex., and Daniel Pollack of Los Angeles advanced tonight to the final round of the piano competition in the Tchaikovsky International Piano-Violin Festival.
HALLANDALE, Fla., April 9 (AP) -- Star Ruler smashed the Gulfstream Park track record for five furlongs today while winning the $10,000 Juvenile Stakes by four and a half lengths.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Supreme Court heard oral argument today on the power of the Federal Trade Commission to stop false and misleading advertising of health, hospital and accident insurance.

Your correspondent Sami Hadawi, whose letter was published in your issue of April 2, is, I fear, guilty -- one would hope inadvertently -- of a serious error of fact. And it is on this error that his entire argument rests.
NEW DELHI, India, April 9 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that efforts in the United States to solve the problem of racial segregation were meeting with growing success.
PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -Roman Catholic schools should not be complacent about delinquency although they have few such problems, a Catholic edition said today.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Soviet and United States Army veterans of the 1945 Allied linkup on the Elbe have finally won the battle to meet again, this time on the Potomac.
The Ford Foundation yesterday announced its first grants to strengthen and expand the scope of education for leadership in business and industry.

HOBOKEN, N. J., April 9 -- A blue and white pennant with a green cross was hoisted today to the mast of the passenger cargo liner Excambion. The pennant and a certificate for safety achievement and life-saving at sea were awarded to the crew by the American Merchant Marine Institute and the marine section of the National Safety Council.

The Socony Mobil Oil Company plans capital and exploratory expenditures this year of $435,000,000, the company announced yesterday in connection with the issuance of its pamphlet report for 1957. This would be some $14,000,000 more than the record expenditures of $420,803,990 last year.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 14 to 20 points yesterday. The gain equaled 70 cents to $1 a bale.
The city school system is making progress in meeting the current shortage of teachers, but the problem is still serious, Superintendent of Schools William Jansen said yesterday.
The Samuel H. Kress Foundation here announced yesterday the opening this month of two regional galleries to house foundation works of art or long-term loan arrangements.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- Officials said today that the United States was not entirely satisfied with the way the tiny kingdom of Laos was using American aid. But they said the $40,000,000-a-year program would continue for the time being.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 9 (AP) -- Two New York aviation company officials were ordered today to stand trial April 26 on a charge of defrauding a Pakistani aviation concern of 51,000 rupees ($10,500).
LAUREL, Md., April 9 (AP) -Horses that didn't race caused the most interest at Laurel today.
LAKELAND, Ga., April 9 (AP) -- Mrs. A. B. Baskin, a Lanier County teacher who said she had been forced to resign because of a segregation incident, was reinstated yesterday.
AN extensive collection of nightgowns and pajamas for the spring bride was shown at Elizabeth Arden's yesterday, and there wasn't a yawn in the lot.
LAST night's "United States Steel Hour" play on Channel 2 was bound to appeal to any loyal New Yorker.

Atlas Corporation expects to receive about $25,000,000 from the recent sale of its oil and gas subsidiary, Petro-Atlas Corporation, to American Petrofina, Inc., according to the 1957 annual report released yesterday.

The Investors Funding Corporation of New York has purchased the fifteen-story and penhouse apartment building at 1215 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of 102d Street. The property is 100 by 100 feet and contains sixty-one apartments. It was sold by William M. Chadbourne, who acquired it in 1947.
PASSAIC, N. J., April 9 -The Board of Commissioners has received for study a nineteen -step traffic program that would redesign downtown Passaic at an estimated cost of $2,760,000.

LONDON, April 9 -- At the Foreign Office, Harold Beeley is known as "the Middle East expert," with emphasis on the "the." He is essentially a scholar, a tall, lean, donnish man who was drawn into diplomacy after World War II from a career as a historian. His academic province was the modern history of the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -British industry representatives said today "there is no basis" for the General Electric Company's contention that imports of heavy electrical equipment were threatening the security of United States.
A radio and television technicians' strike against the Columbia Broadcasting System passed the third day yesterday as the city sought to bring both sides together.

GENEVA, April 9 -- Philippe De Seynes, United Nations Under Secretary for Economic and Social Affairs, said today that the economic situation in the United States and Western Europe "represents a more serious challenge to national and international economic statesmanship than any other economic set-back since the second World War."

The United Nations has just published a report with the formidable title "Mass Communications in the Non-Self-Governing Territories" which will be discussed next Monday at a session to be held at the U. N. headquarters. The problem which this report actually attacks is of course an easily understandable one.
A diamond jubilee luncheon to commemorate the opening of the first Florence Crittenton Mission here is being arranged by the board of directors of Barrett House, the New York branch.

The Kroger Company, which operates a retail food chain, largely in the Midwest and South, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the first quarter this year. The company ranks third in its field in sales.
Stocks gave an uneven performance yesterday. More issues rose than fell but in the final hour enough of the leaders collected minus signs to send the market averages down for the day.
William M. Spire has formed his own agency in Miami with the $1,500,000 account of the General Development Corporation of that city.

One of the defense lawyers in the Michael Farmer murder case appealed to the jury yesterday to "divest yourself of the era of hysteria about juvenile delinquency" and be "judges of the facts who go right down the middle."
TEANECK, N. J., April 9 -Pancho Gonzales, seeking his fourth consecutive world professional tennis championship, continued his domination of Australia's Lew Hoad tonight.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 9 -- John Diefenbaker, Canadian Prime Minister, said here today that if the Soviet Union really wanted a world-wide halt in nuclear weapons tests there must be international inspection in all countries conducting such tests.
NORWALK, Conn., April 9 -- The Board of Education last night approved a record budget of $4,649,023 for 1958-59.

Not Dog Days A lady who usually is calm and agreeable was speaking the other day of spring. Since she is the mother of three, she was not speaking only good things of spring. In fact, she was blowing her top.
Milton C. Lightner, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, proposed last night a program to end the recession and spur economic growth.

WHITE PLAINS, April 9 -No "violence, hoodlumism or gangsterism" will be countenanced in the schools of Westchester County, Children's Court Judge George O. Becker told eight teen-age participants in a "knife duel" in a junior high school.

Earnings of Revlon, Inc., for the first three months this year totaled $2,235,000 on sales of $25,011,000, Charles Revson, the president, said yesterday. He spoke to 500 shareholders at the annual meeting in the Plaza Hotel.

KNOWN as "the saddest man in Europe" after the first World War, George Grosz was in fact considerably more than "sad." He was outraged. He viewed the post-war catastrophe of Germany with extravagant horror, which found its proper outlet in hundreds of drawings and prints characterizing his native country in its frenetic degradation.
A piece of music much discussed but never heard in America made its appearance at the New York Philharmonic concert last night.
A lower opening and a morning decline sent stocks to new 1958 lows yesterday, but an unassuming rally in the final hour or so brought a modest gain for the day.
