WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The American Security and Trust Company and the National Metropolitan Bank, third and fifth largest banks here, plan to merge into a $318,000,000 institution.
The cosmopolitan City of New York paid honor yesterday to the man who runs the cosmopolitan enclave on the East River, the United Nations.

The Presidential press conference on Wednesday resembled, as usual, the conversation contemplated by the Walrus in "Through the LookingGlass" -- that is to say, subjects as varied as shoes, ships and sealing wax, cabbages and kings. But the President touched on one human and personal phase of his office.

The Tri-Continental Corporation reported yesterday net assets of $320,108,568, equal to $38.38 a share, at the end of the first quarter. This compared with $316,670,247, or $43.17 each on fewer shares, a year earlier.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, dropped a broad hint today to military officers to resign if they were unalterably opposed to the President's defense reorganization plan.

City expenditures for youth were heavily attacked yesterday for being inadequate as the Wagner Administration began two programs to combat juvenile delinquency. The criticism of city outlays for the education, health and social needs of New York's youngsters was voiced at a meeting of the Citizens Committee for Children of New York.

At various times there has been some deploring of the failure on the part of President Eisenhower to assert his leadership. On occasion he has taken attitudes that were noncommittal when more positive positions would have been worth while.
ALBANY, April 10 (AP) -- The State Tax Department ordered its staff to overtime duty today to handle the annual last-minute rush of income-tax filing.

Two four-story walk-up apartment houses at 422 Saratoga Avenue and 1820 Park Place, Brooklyn, were sold by Barzel Associates. They are assessed at $96,000. The buyer was an investing client of Irving Bira, broker in the deal.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -President Eisenhower decided late today on a golfing weekend at the Augusta National Club.
CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -Corn futures resumed their upward trend on the Board of Trade today with advances of as much as 2 5/8 cents a bushel.
POPULAR beef cuts, as well as pork and poultry, are the leading buys this week-end.

The sixteen United Nations members who stemmed the Communist attack in Korea have asked the Red regimes in China and North Korea to clarify their offer of "free" elections to unify Korea. They want to know whether the Communists mean what they say and are willing to modify what they say to comply with United Nations decisions, or whether they are merely trying to maneuver the United Nations forces out of South Korea.
CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, April 10 -The head of the Justice Department's Criminal Division amiably confesses a fairly common fault: "I pace the floor," he says. This particular pacer, 41-year-old Malcolm Anderson, was named today as head of an organized Federal drive to clean up major crime across the country.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- A Soviet aviation expert listed as an embassy chauffeur the last time he was here has been denied permission to re-enter the United States.
BONN, Germany, April 10 -The campaign to prevent the Government from equipping the West German Army with nuclear weapons appears to be gaining ground.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 10 -- This is something that began in Texas, but the memory of it lingered all the way into Arizona. It started on the bus that whisked the Milwaukee Braves from the Dallas Airport into town. Two motorcycle policemen led the way. But there was no ostentation to this police escort, no screeching of sirens to herald the approach of the champions of the baseball world.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 10 -Next to the caliber of horseflesh, the most important factor in harness racing is the post position. Even more important than the skill of the driver is luck in the draw that decides which horses start close to the rail.
LONDON, April 10 (UP) -"World heavyweight champion wanted. Must be under 21. Must be 6 feet or over. Experience unnecessary."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10 -- Plans for a new agency to help under-developed countries use their economic resources have been drafted by a committee of the General Assembly.
GENEVA, April 10 -- The Soviet Union proposed today a meeting of trade ministers of all European countries and the United States in the fall.

A rent-gouging case that has come to be known in the Criminal Courts Building as "The Case of the Hot Epsom Salts" was causing chuckles all over the building yesterday. The case was heard before General Sessions Judge William E. Ringel.

The U. N. buildings on the East River have become an essential part of our skyline and would crumble with it if the skyline ever went down. What goes on in those buildings is primarily intended to save our own skyline and the skylines of all cities, big and little, everywhere. In this effort the figure of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold looms high among the world's diplomats.

Macy's, which says it attempts to save its customers 6 per cent for cash, reported yesterday that its sales volume went up by almost that much in the year ended Feb. 1. R. H. Macy Co., Inc., the parent concern that operates Macy's New York and its branches in this area as well as stores in other cities, reported to its stockholders that sales for the year were $454,166,000.
High misadventure ended for two 17-year-old boys yesterday when they returned to Connecticut in the custody of two detectives of that state.

SAIPAN, Marianas Islands, April 4 -- United States defenses in the western Pacific and the welfare of a Micronesian population are the dual responsibility of the United States Navy on the tiny tropical islands of the northern Marianas, once held by Japan.

The Raytheon Manufacturing Company, maker of electronic equipment for industry and the military, increased its firstquarter earnings to $1,734,000, or 58 cents a share, from $1,143,000, or 40 cents a share, on fewer shares outstanding last year.

MONTREAL, April 10 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins surprised the Montreal Canadiens with some of the home team's own brand of power hockey tonight to score a 5-2 victory and even the four-of-seven Stanley Cup finals at one victory apiece.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 10 -- One of the great human dramas of life in Hollywood neared a climax today in an office at the Samuel Goldwyn studio, but no cameras were on hand to record it. The story, as old as the history of drama itself, might well be titled "Auditioning for a Job."
MADISON, Wis., April 10 -Classification of human skin may become possible, Dr. Ray S. Owen said today.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 10 -- Mrs. Robert B. Meyner, wife of the Governor of New Jersey, is honorary chairman of the April 29 luncheon and fashion show that will benefit the New Jersey Neuro-Psychiatric Institute here.
The first Soviet chorus girls ever to invade Times Square stopped sidewalk traffic several times yesterday in a casual sight-seeing expedition.

United States-owned ships flying the flags of other nations are a vital part of the country's defense system, Carl F. Vander Clute, general manager of the marine department of Gulf Oil Corporation, declared yesterday.
QUANTICO, Va., April 10 -More attention was being paid to the barometer and the anemometer than to the stop-watch and the tape measure tonight on the eve of the Marine Corps School Relays.
Blossoming thirty-foot chestnut trees and hundreds of lanterns transformed the Grand Ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria into a large sidewalk cafe last night for the seventh annual April in Paris Ball.

PARIS, April 10 -- France was reported tonight to be seeking ways to keep alive United States-British good offices in the dispute with Tunisia in order to avert a new debate on the quarrel in the United Nations Security Council.

BOSTON, April 10 (AP) -- An oral surgeon demonstrated today that a patient's teeth can be transplanted from one part of his jaws to another. He added that a tooth bank to replace diseased or knockedout teeth was within the realm of possibility.

Formation of the Worth Fund, Inc., a closed-end investment company that will specialize in textile securities, was announced yesterday by Robert L. Huffines Jr., who will serve as president and chairman.
LIMA, Peru, April 5 -- The Government is being accused of spending too much on development plans and, at the same time, of not doing enough for the country.
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is "emphatically not the instrument" for economic assistance to underdeveloped countries, Dr. Roy Blough of Columbia University said yesterday.
Three new films will open at first-run theatres today.
LONDON, April 10 -- Britain faced the strong possibility of a nation-wide railroad strike as union leaders assailed today the rejection of their demands for more pay and a shorter work week.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Friday, April 11 (AP) -- A United States airman accused of pushing and injuring a Nationalist Chinese major was held under United States military arrest today.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Government forecast today a winter wheat crop of 963,636,000 bushels.
It's spring-fever time again, the season that finds many a middle-aged business man yearning to chuck it all and seek adventure and fortune in some misty, faraway land.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 10 -- A foreign ministers' meeting of East Germany, Poland and Czechoslovakia opened here today. It will devise the next step in their efforts to head off atomic rearmament of West Germany.

The editorial of April 9 on the subject of the security-risk law discloses, I respectfully submit, a misunderstanding of the purpose and effect of the amendment of the act adopted at the recent session of the Legislature and now awaiting action by His Excellency, the Governor.

The City Council now has before it, for possible action next Tuesday, an amendment to the administrative code that would authorize the Police Commissioner to allow the Loyalty Day parade to march on Fifth Avenue through the business district below Fifty-ninth Street to a reviewing stand at the Public Library at Forty-first Street.

A new issue of $125,000,000 of long-term sinking fund debentures of the Aluminum Company of America is on the market today on terms yielding 3.9 per cent to investors. The issue is not subject to refunding at an interest cost lower than 3.96 per cent until April 1, 1963.

Any definitive judgment on the flare-up in Cuba must be suspended until the situation becomes somewhat clearer. Americans, however, cannot be expected to ignore a drama so charged with tragedy occurring off our shores in a country so closely connected with our life and history.

James Couzens (1872-1936), the self-made Canadian who became Henry Ford's partner and later Republican Senator from Michigan (1922-1936), is the subject of a new biography by Harry Barnard. To be called "Independent Man," the book will be published May 15 by Scribners.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- On the same day this week (1) Attorney General Rogers politely declined to testify a second time before a Senate subcommittee on bills designed to release to Congress more information on internal Executive activities; and (2) Adlai E. Stevenson attacked the Administration for what he termed "the abuse of the people's right to know."
SANTIAGO DE CUBA, April 10 -- The outcome of the rebel general strike here remained in doubt tonight.

RENATO BIROLLI belongs to a generation of Italian painters who resisted Government-sponsored traditionalism during the Fascist epoch in Italy and, instead, found means to parallel fresh painting developments originating in France.

The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday profit of $23,396,118, equal to $1.98 a share for the first quarter, compared with $18,745,607, or $1.58 a share, in the like 1957 period.

Futures prices closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Domestic sugar contracts, hides, rubber, Burlap and lead rose; world sugar positions, potatoes, copper, zinc, soybean oil and coffee declined, and price movements for cocoa, cottonseed oil and wool were mixed.
HOBOKEN, N. J., April 10 -If the Democratic primary for the Senate nomination in New Jersey were a horse race, handicappers might describe John J. Grogan as: "Never beaten in cheaper company."

ATLANTIC CITY, April 10 -A leading educator said today that "a great challenge to public school educators is that of finding a way, within the framework of our democratic public educational system, to equate opportunity to capability."
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 10 -- A three-day visit to Brazil by Argentina's President-elect Dr. Arturo Frondizi raised hepesl here 'ef closer cooperation be- tween the two countries.
The Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish acted yesterday to prevent his eviction from the rectory of the Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights.

Manhattan CoUege'.s baseball team yesterday scored its fourth straight victory, trouncing Hunter, 17--4, in a seven-inning sme at Hunter's diamond in the Bronx. John Schoenberger and Mickey Burkoski of the Jaspers collected three hits each.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks dropped $111,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with no change in the like week a year ago.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 10 -- Lebanon's President and Premier held an emergency conference today with the nation's security chiefs on a gun fight last night in Southeast Lebanon.
LONDON, April 10 -- Big Ben, the great bell whose hourly bong has become world-famous, was cast here a hundred years ago today.
Signs are multiplying that the Soviet Union's economic challenge to the West is entering a phase radically different from anything yet encountered since World War II.
CLEVELAND, April 10 (AP) -The second general synod of the United Church of Christ will be held at Oberlin (Ohio) College July 5-8, 1959, it was decided today by the church's executive council.

TUNIS, April 10 -- A new emergency aid agreement between Tunisia and the United States, announced in Washington today, is viewed here as an indication of changing United States policy toward this former French protectorate.
Six large steel and automobile concerns have loaned the Freeport Sulphur Company a total of $25,250,000 to help finance Freeport's nickel and cobalt mining project at Moa Bay, Cuba.

They have arrived -the seeds ordered a few days ago. They could well have been left in the box in which they were so carefully packed. For the ground is still cold and very, very wet, and until the other day in some places where the sun never reaches small mounds of snow -- in unpretty gray -- hung on.
NEW DELHI, India, April 10 -- India's Communist party capturing the political attention of the nation with a new program designed to put the party in power by means of the parliamentary system.
Corporations gave $150,000,000 to education last year, a forum sponsored by the American Management Association was told yesterday.

AT stage right behind the curtains at the Royal Playhouse on East Fourth Street, where Deric Riegen's play "Bed Time" opened last night, a blow is regularly struck on the wooden stage floor by something blunt or heavy.
The Saturday radio matinees of the Metropolitan Opera will move from the American Broadcasting Company to the Columbia Broadcasting System next season.

Scientists at the University of California's radiation laboratory have photographed the annihilation of an antineutron. It is considered the newest evidence of the great efficiency with which matter and anti-matter destroy each other when they touch.
MOSCOW, April 10 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev declared today that the Soviet Union would surpass the United States in the production of consumer goods.
PARIS, April 10 -- The colonization of a region in Siberia by Soviet Jews failed because of the individualistic nature of the colonists, according to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union.
PARIS, April 10 -- France will propose a previously suggested establishment of an international control group for nuclear tests, Foreign Minister Christian Pineau said today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -The National Labor Relations Board overturned a ten-year precedent today. It ordered an election involving a union not in compliance with filing requirements of the Taft-Hartley Act.
" LOST IN THE STARS" means well. Like Alan Paton's novel "Cry the Beloved Country," on which it is based, it is on the side of the angels.

LYNCHBURG, Va., April 10 A baseball spring training campaign is supposed to serve many purposes. It aims to prepare and harden the athletes for the varying conditions they are apt to encounter in the course of a championship season.

RABAT, Morocco, Friday, April 11 -- New troubles early today between Morocco and Spain held up the transfer to Morocco of the Southern Protectorate that had been scheduled to take place later in the day.
OSAKA, Japan, April 10 (AP) -- The New York City Ballet raised the curtain today on Osaka's first International Festival of Music, Drama and Art.
Union leaders and representatives of the Columbia Broadcasting System will meet in Washington at 11 A. M. tomorrow in an effort to settle a strike by 1,300 radio and television technicians.
CAMDEN, N. J., April 10 -Another attack on Mayor George E. Brunner was made known today with an announcement that petitions seeking his recall were being circulated.
ALBANY, April 10 -- Governor Harriman approved today a new law designed to help schools curb juvenile delinquency.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 1 to 10 points (5 to 50 cents a bale) yesterday.

DETROIT, April 10 -- The automobile industry demonstrated some of its newest safety devices today to a group of doubting Governors. The objective was to refute the charge that the car makers sacrifice safety to style.
TRIPOLI, Libya, April 6 -Eleven foreign companies are conducting in Libya an intensive search for oil that, if successful, could change overnight the character of this sleepy Arab country.

The United States may lose the "cold war" at its cocktail parties, according to the findings of an American temperance official. He is William A. Scharffenberg, executive secretary of the International Commission for the Prevention of Alcoholism and the American Temperance Society.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Appointment of Kenneth M. Birkhead as finance director of the Democratic National Committee was announced today.

Every three months the Federal Reserve Bank of New York surveys trends in business loans by the large banks in this city. Yesterday it reported that 2,790 short-term loans totaling $925,000,000 and bearing a 4.2 per cent average interest were placed in the first fifteen days of March.
Man has learned more in the last ten years about his heart and circulation than ever before, the American Heart Association reported yesterday.
City Construction Coordinator Robert Moses called on the Board of Estimate yesterday to approve plans for the highly controversial second stage of the Brooklyn approach to the Narrows bridge.
An Erie County drive to win this year's Democratic nomination for the United States Senate for Peter J. Crotty, its chairman, is scheduled to start Thursday.
Society, not a gang of seven teen-agers, is responsible for !the killing of 15-year-old L1v[iehael larmer, two defense i lawyers sa[id yesterday.
The Borden Company has acquired Marcelle Cosmetics, Inc., maker of products designed to avoid allergic reactions. The transaction was made for stock, but details were not revealed.

Senate rackets investigators began an inquiry yesterday to determine whether underworld elements among Pennsylvania dress manufacturers were blocking settlement of the last vestiges of the seven-state garment strike.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, today named Lieut. Gen. Bruce C. Clarke as chief of the United States Continental Army, effective Aug. 1.

I note with interest the remarks of Jane Todd reported in your paper on April 1 and April 10. Miss Todd, Republican State Committee vice chairman, prophesies that "the clean-up of corruption versus the cover-up" will be "major issues of the coming gubernatorial campaign."

OSSINING, N. Y., April 10 -A Jesuit missionary became a legendary figure in the Fiji Islands by helping the primitive inhabitants to set up their own credit unions and thus escape from the toils of local loan sharks.
Mayor Wagner intervened yesterday in the latest round of the long fight between waterfront terminal operators and truckmen over the loading of trucks at piers.
The Erie County, N. Y., Water Authority borrowed $6,500,000 in the bond market yesterday on obligations secured by service revenues.
PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -The viewpoint of progressive education was defended today at the fifty-fifth annual conference of the National Catholic Educational Association.
NORTH COLLINS, N. Y., April 10 (AP) -- A B-47 stratojet bomber was ripped in two by an explosion high over western New York today and fell in flames. Its four crew members were killed.
The downturn in international trade was reflected here last month in a slight reduction of customs collections in the Port of New York.

For the first time in more than a century the Pennsylvania Railroad is mailing out proxies for the election of a nonmanagement director. This is required by the proxy rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Fifteen years ago Lloyd Peterson was running a trolley car in Brooklyn. Yesterday he was sworn in as the $10,000-a-year secretary of the Transit Authority -- the first Negro to get official rank in the agency.
FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., April 10 -- The Army is trying to end a baffling difference in British and American measurement standards -- a breech equal to one inch in 25,000 miles.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -- A coroner's jury ruled today that a woman died here last month from taking a "pep-up pill" in amounts recommended by the manufacturer.
A civil antitrust suit was filed here yesterday against Universal Pictures, Columbia Pictures and Screen Gems.

TRIPOLI, Libya, April 6 -The growth of the United States Air Force facility, Wheelus Air Base, and the invasion of American, British and French oil exploration teams have brought a housing boom to Tripoli.
A national campaign aimed at restoring faith in the economy was announced here yesterday by the Advertising Council.
MILAN, April 10 -- Italy is still a man's country, but the electronic kitchen may change all that.
Twenty-nine persons, including two women, were arrested yesterday in a police round-up on the Lower East Side.

AMONG the afflictions of modern life one of the most intellectually fashionable is to be lonely in a crowd. But long before heavy volumes were written about this commonplace result of modern urban life hordes of people were familiar with it. Some of them were young and newly arrived in the big city where they hoped to make their fortunes.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Friday, April 11 -- A teen-ager was stabbed to death here early this morning after a fight with other youths.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Air Force, working on plans to send man into space, gave a new indication of progress today in the preliminary task of launching animal-occupied satellites.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -The United States has agreed to make available 20,000 tons of surplus wheat for an emergency work relief program in Tunisia.
LONDON, April 10 -- Stock market prices continued to move strongly ahead today with British Government securities still in the lead.
Even the world's largest corporate entity felt the recession in the first quarter of this year.
ALBANY, April 10 (AP) -- Skiing conditions reported today to the State Commerce Department:

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday struck down a ruling by the State Rent Commission that limited to $2.75 a month the rent increase a landlord might charge each tenant after completely rewiring his house.
HOUSTON, April 10 (UP) -The Cleveland Indians rallied for three runs in the tenth inning to defeat the San Francisco Giants, 15 -- 14, today.

ALBANY, April 10 -- Robert Moses asked Governor Harriman today for $30,000 to start work on a new elevator on the United States side of Niagara Falls. Because of rockslides in the area the old elevator has been shut down.
BALTIMORE, April 10 (AP) -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad set April 26 today as a "tentative target date" for ending passenger service between Washington and New York.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A pamphlet based on a Government health survey says that Americans see physicians at the rate of 4.8 times a year.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board is studying the possibility of a repetition of a mishap in last Sunday's crash of a Capital Airlines Viscount at Midland, Mich.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said today that no evidence had been found to support a Japanese report that fish and marine life in the western Pacific had been contaminated by radioactive fall-out from atomic tests.

Officials of the new $5,000,000 Monticello Raceway in the Catskills disclosed yesterday that they would open their first season on schedule on Friday night, June 27. Fourteen stakes are carded for the seventy-fournight season.

His own sense of failure may well have been the irritant that prompted him to use his last day in Hungary to make public the fact that his long-cherished plans for economic integration of the Soviet bloc are meeting formidable re sistance.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A high official of the Organization of American States denounced United States policy toward Latin America today as "essentially negative."

Form made things warm for the favorite players at Jamaica yesterday. The atmosphere was raw and damp, and there must have been many in the crowd of 24,547 who wished that they had decided to spend the afternoon elsewhere.

There was a baseball game yesterday at Ebbets Field -- the scene of many a thrilling and dramatic contest.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -The question of the Government's power to keep Americans from traveling abroad was put to the Supreme Court today in one of the major oral arguments of the term.

Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse have accepted a top priority assignment. The longtime collaborators will dramatize Howard Nemerov's novel "The Homecoming Game," a job that had been turned over to Elihu Winer.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Bomber crews of the Strategic Air Command are on the alert in many lands to retaliate in the event of an enemy attack. One crew, however, was on its toes recently for a far different and more mysterious event -- eruptions on the sun.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee has asked the Justice Department to consider undertaking an antitrust inquiry into the operation of General Motors Corporation.

ROME, April 10 -- Modern psychology, regarded as a whole, is worthy of praise from a moral and religious standpoint, Pope Pius XII said today. But methods used by psychologists are not always blameless, he added.
SHADES of Marco Polo! The Venetian blinds that the explorer was said to have introduced to the Western World 663 years ago are now opening up new vistas in decorating.

FOR eight months or so a woman who lives in the Sixties has been bedbound with a virus infection, and mighty weary of it. She hit on the idea last mid-week of hiring a Scully-Walton private ambulance to take her, her miniature black poodle Mimi and a gentleman she knows into a Fifties sidestreet on Easter Sunday.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 10 -- The body of a Trenton food store manager, who disappeared late Friday night, was recovered today from Lake Carnegie in Princeton. He was an apparent kidnapping and murder victim.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 10 -- Directors of the Tennessee Valley Authority say the distributors of T. V. A. power appear "overwhelmingly" to want revenue bond financing for future T. V. A. power needs and do not favor any other plan.

FROM now until the end of the school year, teen-age social life can be expected to increase. The old line about a "young man's fancy" is as true in the space age as it was in the era of troubadors. But what about the youngster who is left out of things?
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 10 -- A court suit testing the principle of television-rerun payments to actors was won in Los Angeles Superior Court today by the Screen Actors Guild.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 10 (UP) -- The Tallahassee City Commission released from jail today two Negro youths serving sixty-day terms for violating a bus-seat assignment ordinance.
The city's audit of the accounts of a dozen real estate concerns doing business with its Bureau of Real Estate has been slowed because records are divided between two municipal agencies.
AS if things were not gloomy enough at the strike beset Columbia Broadcasting System, the network put on a sodden filmed melodrama called "The Dungeon" on "Playhouse 90" last night.
A man in town shoots his daughter every day. Shoots his niece, too. Out of a big cannon and into a net.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- One hundred public enemies were nominated, but not identified, today for the "highest priority" in the Federal Government's long-range campaign to combat crime throughout the United States.

Percival E. Jackson, a director of Philadelphia Reading Corporation who is soliciting proxies against the management, sent his first proxy letter to stockholders yesterday. He revealed that he had been joined by Theodore W. Stemmler, another director, in nominating Lincoln Stevenson, a New York attorney and business executive, as an opposition candidate for a board seat.
A New York publishing executive, accused of selling $250,000 worth of his concern's paper for $25,000, is being held by the police of Hot Springs, Ark.

The election of Elmer F. Franz and John A. Baldinger as vice presidents of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company was announced yesterday by Gilbert W. Chapman, president, following the annual meeting in Stamford, Conn.

The Temka Realty Corporation has purchased the fivestory apartment building at 400 East 180th Street, northeast corner of Webster Avenue, the Bronx, from a client of Irving Bira, broker in the deal. Assessed at $64,000, the property is 50 by 100 feet and contains twenty-two apartments and three stores.
Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, said yesterday he fully supported the President's plan for centralization of the three armed services.
LONDON, April 10 -- Britain's guided weapons chief told his countrymen tonight that, for ten years, offense by nuclear weapons would have an almost absolute superiority over defense.
HAVANA, April 10 -- This city was quieter today after yesterday's attempt by rebels to provoke a general strike throughout Cuba.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended April 5, 1958, totaled 516,225 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- Paraguay has lodged a formal protest against Argentina for allegedly supplying aid to antigovernment rebels in a recent clash with Paraguayan troops.

PITTSBURGH, April 10 (AP) -- A department store sale the proprietors had advertised as "End the Recession Sale" turned into a near riot today. Five women were hurt when a plate glass window was broken.

FEW warming words can be said now to the strong, hardy outdoorsmen who will stand in a disorderly rabble along the shores of New York's and New Jersey's streams when the trout season opens tomorrow morning. It will be about a normal opening day.
GROTON, Conn., April 10 -On the eve of its fifty-eighth anniversary, the Navy's submarine service paraded today one of its greatest assets, the nuclear -powered Seawolf.
DALLAS, April 10 (AP) -- Four American records were set and three defenders were upset tonight in the women's national Amateur Athletic Union indoor swimming meet.
WASHINGTON, April l0 -An Administration spokesman today called the foreign aid program "a very strong plank in the anti-recession drive."

At the session of the Legislature just concluded bills were introduced which would have established a length of residence requirement in New York State as a condition of obtaining public assistance and care. Since 1873 the sick and the needy have been provided for in New York State without residence requirements, and the proposed legislation would have been a serious step backward in our humane and enlightened social welfare program.
PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -Cynicism might be what the doctor orders for himself to keep his anxieties away, a psychologist said here today.

LONDON, April 11 -- The rate of rotation of the earth has been slowing more or less steadily since about September, 1955, to January this year, according to observations published jointly today by British and United States observatories.
A new plan for providing expense grants to universities where Rockefeller Foundation fellows are studying was announced last night by Dean Rusk, president of the foundation.
LONDON, April 11 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of today's Soviet memorandum to the Western powers on a heads-of-government conference as distributed in English by Tass, Soviet news agency:
A whole galaxy of stars will be coming to television Monday, April 21.

SEOUL, Korea, April 11 (AP) -- Capt. Marvin E. Kemp of Kilmichael, Miss., was convicted today of assaulting a 14-year-old Korean boy, who had been nailed in a packing crate and flown twenty-five miles.

A State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that Ethel Merman does not have to appear as a pre-trial witness in a $100,000 damage suit brought by Eugene Wesson, an actor, against the Actors Equity Association.
Rain in the city and snow mixed with rain in the suburbs, upstate New York and Connecticut produced annoyance but little serious damage yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -Life in a Soviet Antarctic camp was described today by an American who has lived there as a combination of hard work, caviar and friendly discourse.

The merger of the List Industries Corporation into Glen Alden Corporation was delayed for at least two weeks yesterday by stockholder objections and by court orders served at shareholder meetings of both companies.
FROM the Flea Market in Paris to Tokyo's department stores, travelers will find home furnishings fun for which to shop.

WHEREAS air travel is a relatively simple matter because of its brevity and no-tipping convention, an ocean voyage can be a strain on a woman, particularly if it is her first trip and she is traveling alone.
Stock market excitement ran through the rails, the aircrafts and a number of low-priced issues yesterday, but by the close price moves were irregular and small.

A radio-television performers' union yesterday warned producers of shows for the strike-bound Columbia Broadcasting System that the union's members were not obliged to work under "hazardous" conditions.

Gore Vidal, who brought hilarity to Broadway last season with his satiric comedy "Visit to a Small Planet," is at work on a new comedy with serious overtones. It is untitled, calls for a cast of about eight and its action takes place in a so-called guest-paying house in Switzerland.
Your editorial of April 1 is to be praised for its clear analysis of the gradual but steady ascendancy of Khrushchev as the undisputed leader of the Soviet Union.
PURDYS, N. Y., April 11 -A 28-year-old minister is working his way through college as a circuit-riding preached in this area.
Steel production in March was 141 per cent below that of the same month last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
A scientific project took Dr. Walsh McDermott of New York and his associates to the Navaho reservation in Arizona six years ago. The challenge of a neglected segment of America kept them there.

SYRACUSE, April 11 (AP) -The St. Louis Falstaffs today accumulated the highest team all-events total ever in an American Bowling Congress tournament and placed new leaders in the doubles and individual all-events divisions.
Motorists driving past Teterboro Airport are advised not to become alarmed if they see a conventional-looking airplane following some steep and thoroughly unconventional flight patterns.
A LITTLE research goes a long way in packing a wardrobe for any trip abroad.
LONDON, April 11 (UP) -- Europe's major airlines joined in battle against Pan American World Airways today over this issue: When does a sandwich become a meal?

LOS ANGELES, April 5 -For a man who has been a golf professional, movie publicist, aviation instructor, real estate broker and helicopter service operator, manufacturing spaghetti might seem a nonsequitur.

KLM Royal Dutch Airlines increased operating revenues last year 15 per cent to a record $130,587,000, from $114,248,000 in 1956; the annual report disclosed yesterday. Earnings, however, were almost unchanged.

Perhaps the time may come (soon, we hope) when there will be no occasion to remark on the appointment of a first Negro to this or that position. But since that time is unfortunately not yet here, we are happy to take note of the selection of Lloyd Peterson as secretary of the Transit Authority and to congratulate him and the authority.

It is agreed that the winter was the worst, the very worst. It now can be agreed today that the winter is not over. There are peepers, sure, to salute the spring, there are crocuses, pussywillows and buds on the maples.

TULSA, April 11 (UP) -- Don Taussig, a rookie outfielder, smashed a run-scoring single in the tenth inning for the San Francisco Giants today to beat Cleveland, 2 -- 1, and reward Ruben Gomez and Ramon Monzant for a three-hit pitching job.

Events today: "Samson et Dalila, "Metropolitan Opera, 2:15 o'clock; Ellie Mao, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 3; Morton Estrin, pianist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 5:30; "Lucia di Lammermoor," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "Tale for a Deaf Ear" and "Trouble in Tahiti," New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; "The Barber of Seville," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:15.

In the speediest response to a Soviet note on record the United States has turned down a Soviet proposal for a meeting of ambassadors in Moscow on April 17 to prepare for a summit meeting. The reason for this rejection is that the Soviet proposal is tied to conditions which purport to accept the Western position in form but categorically reject it in substance.
WARSAW, April 11 (Reuters) -- A 32-year-old Polish woman was jailed for six years here today for bribing customs officials on goods sent to her from the United States.

The report of the Mayor's committee that recommended sale of the city-owned subway power plants to Consolidated Edison was so conclusively convincing that it would seem impossible for the Board of Estimate to reject it. Nevertheless, we assume that before the board acts on a matter of such importance and of such long-standing controversy it will want to hear the views of chiefly interested parties.
BONE, Algeria, April 11 (Reuters) -- The British freighter Baltic Exporter sailed today for West Germany without the eighty-six cases of arms that French authorities ordered unloaded yesterday.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 11 -- A nonviolent civil-disobedience campaign was started today by the Tamil-speaking minority.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 11 (Reuters) -- Arson and murder flared in Cyprus tonight.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 11 -- Three trainers with one thought: "We want out."
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The United States Government indicated today that it would not agree to the latest Soviet conditions on preparatory talks for a heads - of - government meeting.

LONDON, April 11 -- A glut is giving British housewives the cheapest butter they have had in twenty years. Some butter is little dearer than margarine and can be bought this week-end for as little as 2s (28 cents) a pound.
GENEVA, April 11 -- The Soviet Union is turning to the United States and West Europe for help in producing more and better products for consumers.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 -- A seven-car motorcade rolled down the magnolia-lined drive of Augusta National Golf Club today and fifteen minutes later President Eisenhower was driving off the first tee.
Certain large-dosage packages of the drug iproniazid were put under embargo by the Department of Health last night. A city-wide search for stocks of the drug will begin today.
Eight young women of Polish-American families were presented last night at the Kosciuszko Foundation's Silver Jubilee Ball in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
DETROIT, April 11 (AP) -- The nation's auto plants will build 83,897 cars and 17,135 trucks this week compared with 64,318 cars and 16,888 last week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
Six large contemporary paintings went on display last night at New York University, the fruits of a new art project of the School of Education.
LONDON, April 11 -- Radioisotopes can vastly increase the world's food supply and preserve food in storage, a British atomic scientist said today.
Activity in the public market for long-term capital continues high despite the first major reduction in several weeks in the backlog of new issues of corporate securities slated for marketing.
RAHWAY, N. J., April 11 (AP) -- A management slate gained another member on the board of directors of the Metal and Thermit Corporation today.

HOMEMAKERS who consider menu planning for two as trial and tribulation should ponder the plight of the chef de cuisine of an ocean liner. Even in times of turbulent seas when, perhaps, a quarter of the passengers are down with bouts of mal-de-mer, the shopping list goes something like this for a round trip to Europe:

The 1520 Associates, Inc., purchased the six-story apartment building for seventy-two families at 1510-20 Sheridan Avenue, the Bronx, in a deal negotiated by Abbott Adams, Inc., broker. The property is 153 by 138 feet and was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $311,500.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -The Treasury Department proposed today that Congress strip the nation's life insurance companies of many of their special tax benefits.
ALBANY, April 11 (UP) -- Sking conditions reported to the New York State Commerce Department today:
GREENSBORO, N. C., April 11 (UP) -- Don Whitt of Alameda, Calif., shot a four-under-par 67 today to take a one-stroke lead in the first round of the Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.
GRAND FALLS, Nfld., April 11 (Canadian Press) -- The Anglo-Newfoundland Development Company, which operates one of Newfoundland's two paper mills, showed a 58 per cent drop in earnings in 1957.

TRIPOLI, Libya, April 7 -- Libya sometimes has two totally different climates within a period of hours. One is delightfully cool, when the wind is from the north, off the Mediterranean Sea. The other is oppressively hot, when the wind shifts to the south and blows in from the hot sands of the desert.

ELIZABETH, N. J., April 11 -- An employe who broke his collar bone while playing soft ball during his lunch hour is not entitled to workmen's compensation, Union County Judge Milton A. Feller ruled today.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The labor movement asked today for an investigation of the broadcast of recent Senate hearings without identification of the source.
MONTREAL, April 11 (AP) -- A St. Lawrence Seaway Authority spokesman brushed aside reports today that Canadian construction of a Cornwall Seaway bridge was both defective and behind schedule.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People opened its drive to raise funds and increase membership in the metropolitan area at a dinner held last night in the Belmont Plaza Hotel. Two hundred persons were present.
The new head of the International Union of Operating Engineers will recommend next week that the union's much-investigated Long Island local be placed in trusteeship.

New officers of the American Federation of Film Societies were elected yesterday during the organization's fourth annual convention. The voting took place at the Donnell Library Center, 20 West Fifty-third Street.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 11 -- Ronald J. Davenport, 17 years old, who admitted the penknife slaying of another youth in West Hempstead early today, was released after eight hours of questioning by Nassau County detectives.
Two firemen were rescued from the flame-swept roof of a five-story warehouse in East Harlem yesterday with the aid of a curtain of water. Moments later, three floors of the building collapsed.

PARIS, April 11 -- Premier Felix Gaillard received urgent appeals today from the United States and Britain to keep the Tunisian dispute out of the United Nations Security Council and continue to seek a compromise settlement.

" The insecure rate situation" and possible effects of the recession on natural gas consumption have prompted a 40 per cent cut this year in pipeline expansion plans by the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company.
PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- James P. Warburg, author and authority on international affairs, charged tonight that this country's foreign policy was bankrupt.
CHICAGO, April 11 -First Federal Savings and Loan Association, biggest in Illinois, plans to go into Federal District Court early next week to fight for its supermarket "shop-save service."

AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France, April 11 (AP) -- Nick Carter, a Californian living in Europe, today upset Denmark's Kurt Nielsen, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 9, 6 -- 4, in the quarter-finals of the Aix-En-Provence tennis tournament.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -The National Catholic Educational Association adopted resolutions today calling for greater participation by parents and lay teachers in the operation of Roman Catholic schools.

KANSAS CITY, April 11 (AP) -- This country would be in much better shape if the schools gave to their brightest students the same loving attention they give to their top athletes, an educator said here today.

CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- A renewal of export business sparked a rally in wheat futures on the Board of Trade today. All contracts closed substantially higher after working out of losses of as much as a cent a bushel.
The last of two New York Assemblies, a subscription dance series, was held last night in the ballroom of the Pierre. There were prefatory Dutch I Treat dinners in the Colony i Restaurant.
The city appealed yesterday to the Federal Maritime Board for an early decision on applications by waterfront terminal operators here for higher truck-loading rates at piers.
Federal investigators have found that the propeller blades of the Viscount airliner that crashed in Michigan Sunday were at a normal angle at the time of impact, it was reported yesterday.
Ruth Kobart made her debut with the New York City Opera Company last night at the City Center. She was heard as Augusta in "The Ballad of Baby Doe."

MADRID, April 11 -- Spanish forces in Africa barred a Moroccan Army detachment from passing through Spanish territory yesterday. The Moroccans were en route to planned Spanish-Moroccan ceremonies today at Villa Bens, in the Southern Protectorate of Morocco.

PALM BEACH, Fla., April 11 (AP) -- The president of the American Cotton Association said today the soil bank program "has been most unsatisfactory and prejudicial to the economic welfare of the Southeast and to some sections of the central belt."

CEDARHURST, L. I., April 11 -- The Five Towns Branch of the American Red Cross will benefit from a spring tour of six outstanding homes here and in the neighboring villages on May 6, from 1 to 5 P. M.
Proof that old age need not mean boring inactivity is being given by 2,000 men and women between 60 and 101 years old in the Twelfth Annual Hobby Show for Older Persons, which opened yesterday.

MESA, Ariz., April 11 (UP) -Duke Snider hit a home run in the eleventh inning today to break a tie, but Ernie Banks nullified it by belting one with two mates on base, enabling the Chicago Cubs to post a 5-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
ALBANY, April 11 -- Governor Harriman cleared the way today for a longer than usual election campaign this year.

DALLAS, April 11 (AP) -- Sylvia Ruuska of the Berkeley, Calif., Y. M. C. A. successfully defended her 500-yard freestyle championship in the Women's National Amateur Athletic Union indoor swimming meet tonight. She set a meet record of 5:44.9 and beat Chris yon Saltza, who had established a record in the preliminaries.
MEDAN, April 11 (AP) -- How long it will take for the rebel regime in Central Sumatra to collapse seems to depend upon the striking power, determination and economic health of the Jakarta Government.

Commissioner Cavanagh's order abolishing the Fire Department Band as of June 15 next may not be popular with the forty-six firemen who play in it and who will be returned to full fire-fighting duties. New Yorkers, especially the younger ones, will miss its brave appearances in parades and other functions.

ALBANY, Calif., April 11 (AP) -- Stretch-running Silky Sullivan failed to make up a twenty-nine-and-one-half-length deficit today and finished third behind Gone Fishin' and Furyvan in a Kentucky Derby tune-up at Golden Gate Fields.

Many reservations have been made for the annual benefit luncheon and fashion show of the New York Women's Bible Society. The event is scheduled to take place next Thursday in the ballroom of the Pierre.

The Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad plans to begin operating its own sleeping cars on July 1. The road eventually will discontinue Pullman Company operations entirely, in favor of its own equipment.

MOSCOW, April 11 -- The Soviet Union and Poland were reported today to have reached a preliminary agreement on future trade relations. The execnanges during the next seven years are to be facilitated by a closer integration of the two countries' national economic plans.

Wenzell Brown, author of several works of fiction and nonfiction about narcotics and juvenile delinquency, has three books for publication this season. Two of them are originals and all are paper-bound editions.

The Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago has published a comparative analysis of the three post-war recessions. It finds that industrial production moved downward slightly faster in the six months to Jan. 31 than in the other two recessions. The percentage decline in employment is about the same as in the 1948-49 recession and more than in the 1953-54 dip.

ROME, April 11 (AP) -- Italy's Left-Wing Socialist party rejected today a Communist bid for a Popular Front alliance in next month's elections. It was the campaign's biggest surprise so far, since the Socialists had shown signs of moving back into the Red camp.

Prime Minister Nehru's statements on racial segregation in the United States, made in his own Parliament, should be warmly welcomed here. His is a powerful voice in Asia and it has been raised on behalf of a better understanding of what is being attempted in this country.
For the second time in less than two weeks, a General Sessions Court judge and a defense lawyer were involved in a case in which Epsom salts played a part.
EAST LANSING, Mich., April 11 (UP) -- Abie Grossfeld of Illi-I nois won the all-around cham-I pionship tonight as the National] Collegiate championships began! at Michigan State. I

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -- An official of the Retail Clerks International Union said today it would seek a Congressional investigation of the National Labor Relations Board as the result of a precedent-breaking ruling in a Toledo, Ohio, labor dispute.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Federal housing authorities have decided not to pay New York City for interest costs that the city claims as part of its reimbursable slum clearance expenses.
DETROIT, April 11 -- A plan for changing highway designing was advocated today by the General Motors Corporation in a program aiming to reduce accidents.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 11 (AP) -- The Council of Bishops called on Methodists today to corect a theology that it said reflected a loss of political initiative in world affairs.
Potato volume reached 4,041 car lots yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. There are 45,000 pounds in a car.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations has called on its member unions to help unemployed members obtain benefits to which they are entitled.

PASCAGOULA, Miss., April 11 (AP) -- The launching of the world's fastest commercial tanker -- a vessel that later may be converted to nuclear propulsion -- was described today as foreshadowing the merchant fleet of the future.

BOSTON, April 11 (AP) -- Johnny Busso of New York floored Larry Boardman with a left hook at the end of the ninth round tonight to score a technical knockout in their scheduled ten-rounder at Mechanics Building.
BOSTON, April 11 -- Eight persons in the field of communications and public opinion were cited tonight by Boston University.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- ''An important breakthrough" in cancer research technology was reported at the opening of the forty-ninth annual meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research today.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 11 -- A top merchandising executive said today that American industry was guilty of a "horse and buggy" attitude on foreign trade in this modern space age.

THE storm signals have been out for Camille Chamoun, President of tiny Lebanon, since the merger that made Syria a part of the United Arab Republic last February under President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt.
A young man apparently on the prowl for refunds from the Internal Revenue Service was arrested yesterday in Queens on a charge of mail theft.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Kennecott Copper Corporation has enlisted microbes in its mining operations. The bacteria revive the spent liquid in which metal has been soaked out of low-grade ore so that it can be used again.

BEIRUT, April 11 -- The Lebanese Government moved reinforcements today into the high mountain passes along the road to Damascus. Gendarmes fought a running battle there yesterday with a band of armed gun smugglers. The smugglers allegedly were bringing in weapons from Syria to arm opponents of the pro-Western Government of Premier Sami es-Solh.

AGANA, Guam, April 6 -While the United States and Japan debate administrative rights on the tiny, strategic Bonin Islands, the 193 mixed-blood island settlers with names like Washington and Robinson and Furukata and Ikeda have made their controversial Pacific rocks a small-scale economic utopia, according to United States Naval fiscal reports on the islands.
The KC-135 that captured the record for long-distance jet flying last Tuesday by going from Tokyo to the Azores flew to McGuire Air Force Base, N. J., yesterday with a crew delighted by its aircraft.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 11 (UP) -- Maria Esther Bueno of Brazil and her Mexican partner, Marta Hernandez, won the final of the women's doubles of the Masters tennis tournament today.

The property measuring 95 by 98 feet at 148 to 154 East Twenty-Seventh Street, at Broadway Alley, a private street, has been sold by the estate of Fannie Levy. The buyers, Albert Harrison, builders, plan a seven-story apartment house on the site.

Arthur S. Bernard, who was an independent realty broker, has been appointed sales manager of the C. B. Snyder Realty Company of 41 East Forty-second Street. He was co-broker with James Pessel of the Kaye Realty Company in the purchase of 60 West Sixty-eighth Street by David Hammerman, who has since resold the property.

Two separate but similar delays disrupted service yesterday for thousands of riders on the West Side IRT subway. In both instances, short circuits in brake shoes stopped southbound East 180th Street express trains and caused rerouting of other expresses.
RICHMOND, Va., April 11 -The Yankees wound up their Southern spring exhibition tour today by thrashing their Richmond farm hands, 14 to 2.
NANTES, France, April 11 -- Here in lower Brittany, where maritime, industrial and agricultural activities converge, France's major political and economic divisions seem to be carried to extremes.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., April 11 (AP) -- Bernie Bukiet of Cleveland began the defense of his singles crown today as the twenty-eighth annual United States national open table tennis championships started.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 11 (AP) -- The management of Williams-McWilliams Industries was the apparent victor today in a proxy battle for control of the New Orleans dredging corporation.

BENNINGTON, Vt., April 11 -- The nor'easter Rally, a Sports Car Club of America national championship event, lived up to its name today. Its first phase, a run of slightly more than 300 miles through New York, Massachusetts and Vermont, was beset by snow, sleet, rain and consequent treacherous road conditions.

WILKESBARRE, Pa., April 11 -- Judge Thomas Lewis today signed an order requiring the Glen Alden Corporation and its officers to show cause why a temporary injunction should not be granted to bar confirmation of a reorganization agreement under which the Glen Alden and List industries would merge as List Alden Corporation. Hearing was set on April 17.

DETROIT, April 11 (AP) -- General Motors Corporation said today it would shut nine Chevrolet manufacturing plants next Monday for one week and close nine assembly plants for a similar period the following week.

WILLIAM FAULKNER won his Nobel Prize with a multivolume chronicle of Yothapatawpha County in the Mississippi highlands where his heart lies and also his treasure. Slightly younger than Mr. Faulkner, Evelyn Waugh has meantime been writing about his own county people, whose habitats are in London's Mayfair and its stately provinces.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 11 -- The South African Government forbade today any gathering of more than ten Africans in any major city.

A floor in the office building being erected by Joseph Durst at 200 East Forty-second Street has been leased by Finland's delegation to the United Nations. Last week, the consulate of Finland leased a tower floor in the same building.
A tour of six fashionable apartments on the East Side next Tuesday will benefit the Arthritis and, Rheumatism Foundation. It is the second part of the tour which began last Tuesday.
CHICAGO, April 11 -- Paul G. Hoffman suggested today that the universal hunger for something to read while traveling be exploited for propaganda purposes.
LONDON, April 11 -- A committee convened by the Church of England recommended today that religious opposition to birth control be dropped.
MOSCOW, April 11 -- The Soviet Union proposed today that diplomatic negotiations to prepare an East-West heads-of-government meeting should begin in Moscow next Thursday.
LONDON, April 11 (AP) -- Katsuo Okazaki, former Japanese Foreign Minister, said today Japan wanted no oil war with American or European companies in the Middle East.
Five million members of the Eastern Orthodox Churches in the United States will observe their Easter tomorrow -- one week later than the date commemorated by the churches of the West.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Three statistical reports showed today further declines in economic activity in March and early April.

UNLESS cloudbursts or blizzards forbid, the year's biggest concentration of trout fishermen is likely to be on the streams on this opening day and tomorrow, and it will leave its mark. Its mark will be beer cans, pop bottles, half-eaten sandwiches and other lunch trash, old tires, torn boots and other rubbish.
Vassily Smyslov, the chess champion of the world, yesterday won the fifteenth game of the return world title match with Mikhail Botvinnik in Moscow.
HAVANA, April 11 -- Nineteen Cuban rebels were killed in encounters with Government troops during the day, the Presidential Palace said tonight.

TOKYO, April 11 -- The Japanese police arrested today three Government officials suspected of having turned over to the Japanese Communist party secret Government information. Three other Government officials were called in for questioning.
HOLLYWOOD, April 11--Lana Turner's 14 - year - old daughter, Cheryl Crane, was found by an inquest today to have committed "justifiable homicide" in killing Johnny Stompanato, her mother's suitor.

NORMAN, Okla., April 11 (AP) -- A team of Russian wrestling champions made their United States debut an impressive one tonight by defeating an American all-star squad, 7 -- 1, at the University of Oklahoma field-house.

RABAT, Morocco, April 11 -- The evacuation of foreign troops is the principal problem in Morocco today, according to her Foreign Minister. Other immediate preoccupations of the Government are: the determination of frontiers, the Algerian war, reorganization of Morocco's colonial economy and the establishment of a united North Africa.
NEWARK, April 11 -- In the opinion of Robert Morris New Jersey needs "a strong new voice in Washington." He declares himself ready, able and willing to supply it.
Assistant District Attorney Robert R. Reynolds completed his summing up yesterday in General Sessions Court by asking the jury to convict seven teen-age boys of the murder of Michael Farmer.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 11 -- The Lebanese press has started a bitter attack on United States handling of economic aid. The attack is chiefly a tactical move in domestic politics, but the United States is the scapegoat.
BRISTOL, Pa., April 11 (AP) -- Local 130 of the United Auto Workers has voted to accept a tentative agreement that would keep open the commercial division of the Kaiser Metal Products Company, Inc.

PEARL RIVER, N. Y., April 11 -- As part of a special young people's program here, high school students have organized a Community Service Day April 19, on which the teen-agers will spruce up this village.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 11 -- The Antara News Agency reported today that two battalions had defected from the rebel Government in Central Sumatra.
Directors of the Grand Union Company yesterday raised the annual cash dividend rate on the common stock to 80 cents from 72 cents, with the declaration of a quarterly dividend of 20 cents a share.

GENEVA, April 11 (UP) -- The Fisheries Conservation Committee of the United Nations conference on the law of the sea adopted today an article giving coastal states the right to take unilateral conservation measures in near-by areas of the high seas.

Too many metropolitan areas that have accepted Federal funds for studying problems of urban growth have failed to follow up with remedial action, the National Housing Administrator complained yesterday.

PARIS, April 11 -- When Hitler committed suicide in a shabby Berlin anti-aircraft bunker that particular spirit of liberalism first cultivated in Western Europe and expressed by Montesquieu, Voltaire and Goethe drew a breath of deep relief. Among ugly stains it hoped and assumed had been removed from the currents of modern thought was that of anti-Semitism.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -- The American Legion's National Security Commission called on its parent organization today to support President Eisenhower's defense-reorganization plan.
LUXEMBOURG, April 11 (AP) -- England and Italy qualified for Sunday's final of a junior soccer tournament today. Eng-I land beat Rumania, 1--0, andI Italy defeated France, 3--Oj in the semi-finals.
Subway construction, disabled traffic lights and a fire caused heavy traffic tie-ups last night on the West Side.

BONN, Germany, April 11 -- Friedrich Flick, who was jailed by the Nuremberg war crimes tribunal, has merged two automobile concerns to make West Germany the seat of Europe's leading producer of motor vehicles.
An annual award for the best dramatic criticism written by an American is established in the will of George Jean Nathan, long-time dean of New York drama critics, wwho died last Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman arrived in Washington today and plunged into the controversy over plans to extend the Capitol's east front.

Sales and earnings of the St. Regis Paper Company in the first quarter of 1958 were sharply below the totals for the similar period last year, Roy K. Ferguson, chairman, reported at the annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.

An episode in the McClellan committee hearings on the affairs of the United Automobile Workers and its president, Waiter P. Reuther, has received less public attention than it deserves -- largely, no doubt, because it came at the end of the series late on a Saturday afternoon. In striking contrast to the constantly recurring exposures of union misdeeds the hearing on March 29 staged an impressive exposure of labor rectitude.
MOSCOW, April 11 -- A boyish-looking, curly-haired young man from Kilgore, Tex., took musical Moscow by storm tonight.

The three passport cases on which the Supreme Court began hearing oral argument this week may, when they are decided, go far to clarify the extent to which the State Department can restrict the constitutional right of every American citizen to travel.

A Federal judge said yesterday he could not conduct a fair retrial of James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, on wiretap conspiracy charges if a Senate committee held scheduled hearings on teamster activities at the same time.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., April 11 (AP) -- In a fresh protest against hasty tax reduction and massive spending proposals, Maurice H. Stans, Budget Director, said today that "we can wreck this country by financial irresponsibility just as much as by military carelessness."
ROME, April 11 -- The first copy of the new Roman Catholic Bible in English was presented today to Pope Pius XII by the international group responsible for its publication.
LONDON, April 11 -- The sustained advance of British Government securities was checked on the stock market today and prices moved sharply into reverse.
Sugar Ray Robinson and Rocky Graziano will be in opposite corners on Monday night in the St. Nicholas Arena. Yesterday the New York State Athletic Commission granted seconds' licenses to them.

OSSINING, N. Y., April 11 -Over the next ten years many underdeveloped countries with "sleepy" agricultural economies will awaken to the thorny problems of industrial labor, Roman Catholic missionaries were warned here today.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The level of average primary market prices remained unchanged at 119.6 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Average prices of processed foods did not change and an 0.7 per cent rise in average prices of farm products was offset by a decline in prices of commodities other than farm products and foods.
POUND RIDGE, N. Y., April 11 -- Residents in this northern Westchester town and in Ridgefield, Conn., were seeking today to enroll members in a commuters' bus-pool.

THE Juilliard Dance Theatre, with Doris Humphrey as director, last night gave the first of two performances at Juilliard Concert Hall. Besides the revival of an old work by Miss Humphrey herself, the program contained the premieres of three new compositions by as many guest choreographers.
AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France, April 9 -- Budge Patty is tall, handsome, articulate and 34 years old. He is also more at home on the French Riviera than at Forest Hills.
JERSEY CITY, April 11 -- A group of Newark municipal workers today won their fight to invalidate a 1932 city ordinance requiring them to live within city limits.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The Administration today recommended that Congress restore import taxes on copper. They have been suspended most of the time since 1947.
OFFENBURG, Germany, April 11 (UP) -- Ludwig Zind, a schoolteacher, was sentenced to one year in prison today for having advocated and approved Nazi extermination methods against the Jews.
The Metropolitan Opera will stage twenty-six operas during its 1958-59 season, it was announced yesterday by Rudolf Bing, general manager.

Ismael Valenzuela continues to make it easy for the horse players at Jamaica. The daring young jockey from McNary, down Texas way, was the star of the show yesterday as he brought home three winners in six attempts.

QUANTICO, Va., April 11 -- Ohio State's Glenn Davis was a double individual winner and Villanova picked off the chief team prize today as the Marine Corps schools relays opened in a chilly rain at Butler Stadium.

In a March 30 editorial you wrote on the common good that has and will be done by the eradication of malaria. The editorial concluded that while the solution of international crises and conflicts is distant, the battle against disease relentlessly forges ahead.

Mrs. Robert Flaherty will introduce and discuss her husband's documentary "Man of Aran" (1934) on Cinema 16's program tomorrow and next Sunday at the Beekman Theatre. The programs will take place also on Wednesday evening at the Fashion Industries Auditorium and Friday evening at the Museum of Modern Art.

HOLLYOOD, Calif., April 11 -- Columbia Pictures and Charles K. Feldman, agent and film producer, are discussing a prospective association to make the movie version of the Broadway hit, "Two for the Seesaw," William Holden reportedly would co-star in the two-character romantic drama written by William Gibson.

LONDON, April 11 -- Skepticism pervaded British reac tions to the latest Soviet note on preparations for a heads-of-government conference.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -- A proposed regulation under which placards could be used on retail displays of bulk citrus fruit to show that the fruit had been treated with a preservative was announced today by the Food and Drug Administration. It would not require identification of the chemical used.

Institutional Investors Mutual Fund, Inc., open-end investment fund through which New York State mutual savings banks invest in common stocks, reported total net assets of $34,808,137 on March 31. This was $7,600,000 higher than the year before and $4,800,000 higher than on Dec. 31.

KANSAS CITY, April 12 (AP) -Bill Tuttle singled with two out in the ninth inning and drove in Frank House with the winning run today as the Kansas City Athletics took the first contest of a three-game exhibition baseball series with their Missouri cousins, the St. Louis Cardinals. 4 -- 3.

WALLPAPER is taking on new functions in today's homes and apartments. A stock decorative furnishing of the traditional home, usually covering four walls of a room, it is used more sparingly in the modern interior. A roll or two, perhaps a mural, is used on one wall, much as paintings are, to add a dash of color and pattern to today's often blandly neutral background.

OTTAWA, April 12 -- Selection of his new Cabinet is the most urgent problem facing Prime Minister John Diefenbaker on his return from a week's holiday in Bermuda.

The President's news conference last Wednesday started in routine fashion. Mr. Eisenhower answered questions -- on tax cuts, anti-recession measures, nuclear tests -- in his characteristically conciliatory manner. WASHINGTON, April 12 -Representative Kenneth B. Keating said today that a survey of wiretapping laws in other countries supported his view that some taps should be authorized here.

A dog with a New York license, found astray in Buenos Aires, was reunited with its owner in Argentina -- thanks to the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals here.

An Albany - to - Manhattan marathon June 1, the first such race on the Hudson River since 1952, is one of the twenty-three stock outboard long-distance events listed for the coming months. QUANTICO, Va., April 12 -Ohio State's Glenn Davis closed the Marine Corps Schools Relays today on the same high note of triumph with which he opened them yesterday. In the mile relay finale of the twoday carnival, the indefatigable Olympic 400 - meter hurdles champion ripped off a blazing 147.3-second quarter-mile to give the Buckeyes a three-yard decision over Villanova.

Admiral Jerauld Wright is entering his fifth year in his dual command at Norfolk that links the striking forces of NATO in the Western Hemisphere with those under the Supreme Allied Command Europe. Admiral Wright is Supreme Allied Commander Atlantic and is also Commander in Chief of the Atlantic Fleet of the Navy.
PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -The deaf may one day "hear" through the skin, a Harvard University scientist suggested here today.
WILTON, Conn., April 12 -- A man and his wife were suffocated early today when fire swept their apartment on Farrier's Lane Here. Two volunteer firemen were injured battling the blaze.

MARTHA GRAHAM's season at the Adelphi Theatre, which closes tonight, has swept across the local scene like a blast across the desert, and if any of us still remains smug he must be either a titan or a nitwit. From coast to coast and from the Great Lakes to the Gulf, the pleasure-boating season of 1958 will see more predicted-log contests for pre-eminence in navigating power cruisers than ever before. This fast is becoming the family skipper's popular challenge.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., April 12 -- The task of building the $625,000,000 Niagara power project has begun with a rush in the suburban town of Lewiston.

Soviet advances in brain research and the possible advent of pharmacological warfare were cited last night by an eminent psychologist in a plea for a greater American effort to penetrate the secrets of the mind.

" THE game" that gives Michael Hastings' remarkable first novel its name is the game of growing up as it is played by a widely assorted group of boys and girls -- some of them still children, others fumbling their way into adulthood -- in a weedy vacant lot in one of London's drearier sections.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, April 12 -- Indian Kashmir is watching two strong men who once called each other brothers duel to political death.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 12 -- A controversy over the proper age to admit children to school has arisen in Bergen County. On one side are parents, led by the Bergen County Committee on School Age Requirements, and on the other is the County Department of Superintendents.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., April 12 (AP) -- Defending champion Bernard Bukiet of New York was upset in the fifth round of the United States open national table tennis championship tonight.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 11 -- The Brazilian Government is seeking to ease the country's worsening financial crisis.
American transport lines have asked the State Department to help safeguard their share in the movement of European emigrants to Canada.

Smartly gowned, slender Mrs. George Hamlin Shaw sat among fragile and priceless French antiques in the drawing room of her East River apartment and said earnestly, if somewhat incongruously: "Farming is my vocation."
HOMEOWNERS who have not already done so will soon be taking down storm windows, putting up screens and trying to open windows wide to let in the balmy spring breezes.

HAVANA, April 12 -- The attempt by rebel leader Fidel Castro last Wednesday to bring his "total war" against President Fulgencio Batista from the green jungle of the Sierra Maestra to the streets of this capital city of Havana has been a failure so far.

BUKITTINGGI, Indonesia, April 12 (UP) -- The Indonesian Government has sent 2,000 troops into Northwest Sumatra, the rebel regime reported here today. The drive was said to be directed against rebel forces that have been operating from a "neutral" sanctuary.

Every baseball season is interesting, but the sport faces a particular challenge this year because of the move to California by the Giants and Dodgers. Within the last five years we have attempted to modernize ourselves. How far this program will go depends on what happens in Los Angeles and San Francisco.

Fred Munsch, New York University's freshman star, stole the spotlight in the annual Metropolitan Association Amateur Athletic Union junior swimming championships. The meet was held in New York University's John Quigley Memorial pool.

Five priests and two laymen who were classmates fifty years ago at St. John's College. Brooklyn, will be honored Thursday at the seventy-seventh annual reunion - dinner of the Alumni Association. It will be held at the Hillcrest, Jamaica, campus.

THIS is the checkerboard season in television when all sorts of moves and counter-moves, in relation to programs, are being proposed for the fall season. At headquarters here of the Columbia Broadcasting System a prime question is what decision two sponsors will make about the future of their respective one-hour drama shcws -- "Studio One in Hollywood" and "Climax!"

FOR the tourist in France with three weeks or so to spare, even as little as $200 or so to spend, and the inclination toward quiet, gypsy-like wandering, a voyage through the French canal system can be most rewarding.

MEXICO CITY, April 12 -The Mexican Government appears increasingly concerned over its growing bracero problem.

HAVANA, April 12 (AP) -- The rebel high command in Havana said 5,000 fighters had been ready to stream into the capital's streets Wednesday but Senor Perez never gave the word. The strike fizzled when the Batista regime poured heavily armed policemen into the city's trouble spots.

One of the fastest growing sailboat classes in the country is the Blue Jay, a one-design centerboard sloop, trim and saucy looking, and usually the product of Robert McKean, chairman of the National Sailing Club, whose boat headquarters are at 180 East Prospect Avenue, Mamaroneck, N. Y.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 12 -A carpenter who stood on a street corner and gave away several hundred dollars received a suspended sentence today on an intoxication charge.

In trying to arbitrate one of the thorniest legal disputes between states since the adoption of the Constitution, former Supreme Court Justice Stanley F. Reed has taken on a formidable task indeed.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 12 -Several horsemen in Roosevelt Raceway's paddock were recalling those easy-going, countryfair, straw - between - the - teeth harness racing days that grandpa used to know.
