BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 12 -- Expressing pride in the United States exhibition, Howard S. Cullman said today he was confident that the American pavilion would be ready for visitors when the Brussels World Fair opens Thursday.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 12 -- The Governments of Poland, Czechoslovakia and East Germany renewed their appeal to the Western powers today to forego the arming of West Germany with atomic weapons.

NEXT Friday -- on the 183d anniversary of his Midnight Ride -- the Post Office Department will honor Paul Revere with a new, green, 25-cent stamp. It is safe to predict that no later than next Saturday there will be an outcry on behalf of Revere's neglected fellow-riders, William Dawes and Dr. Samuel Prescott.

ST. JOHN, V. I. -- This unspoiled Caribbean island has a long tourist season. October and November are its only months of bad weather. Three-quarters of the island is national park, largely preserved in a natural state; and its many coves and areas of inland wilderness guarantee visitors as much solitude and primitive atmosphere as they could wish.

DAINTY pinks, which added fragrance and charm to grandmother's garden, are equally effective on the modern landscape. They are ideally adapted to the rock garden, the perennial border and as edging plants.

AN eerie sight for civilian visitors and a sad one for Navy men, the warships shown on this page now lie silently, rank upon rank, at the Naval Supply Depot, Bayonne, N. J. Four battleships (the New Jersey, North Carolina, Washington and Wisconsin), the heroic carrier Franklin (almost burned out under Japanese bombing), smaller carriers, cruisers, destroyers, destroyer escorts -- sit there in inactive and decommissioned status: the so-called "mothball fleet."

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Soviet Union's announcement of a unilateral suspension of nuclear tests has made Washington more conscious than usual of the inadequacies of the United States' propaganda effort.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 12 The richest single truck load of uranium ore on record has been delivered to the Atomic Energy-Commission buying station at Grand Junction, Colo., by Lisbon Uranium Corporation, it was announced here today by A. P. Kibbe, Lisbon's president.

DANBURY, Conn., April 12 -- The Danbury Hospital, a few years ago sicker than the patients within its walls, has just approved a contract for the construction of a six-story wing as part of a $2,500,000 expansion program.
The world premiere of the film "The Vikings," to be held on the evening of June 11 simultaneously at the Astor and Victoria Theatres, will benefit the Crown Princess Martha Friendship Fund.

The South will pay tribute this week to one of the fastestgrowing segments of its economy, the pulp and paper industry.
TRENTON, April 12 -- New Jersey voters will go to the polls Tuesday to nominate major party candidates.
BONN, Germany, April 12 -West German authorities, semipublic bodies and the press sounded the alarm this weekend against symptoms of recrudescent anti-Semitism.

THE First International Congress of Organists, held under the auspices of the American Guild of Organists, Royal College of Organists and Incorporated Association of Organists, took place in London last summer.

Nelson of the Laboratory of the Population Council, the Rockefeller Institute, New York, reported last week at the annual meeting of the American Association of Anatomists at Buffalo on animal experiments with a new type of antifertility compound that has proved itself effective when administered by mouth.
LOS ANGELES, April 12 -Senator William F. Knowland's chances of becoming California's next Governor remain highly problematical.
MADRID, April 12 -- The Spanish Government unleashed today the most bitter criticisms of Moroccan policy in recent months.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney reported widespread support today for a bill designed to "take the mystery out of new car prices."

WASHINGTON, April 12 -The General Electric Company, which has asked the Government to stop buying heavy electrical equipment abroad, has partly achieved this end by underbidding foreign competitors.
PARIS, April 12 -- The French Government agreed tonight to resume direct negotiations with Tunisia. It called the National Assembly back from vacation to meet Tuesday to ratify the decision.

CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -Starting Wednesday motorists traveling between Chicago and the East can rid themselves of one of their biggest headaches for only 25 cents.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- James Harvey Robinson, the historian, used to draw a distinction between the "good reasons" that officials gave for policy decisions, and the "real reasons."

MILWAUKEE, April 12 (UP) -- Al Kaline hit his sixth homer of the spring in the fifteenth inning today to enable the Detroit Tigers to gain a 4-3 exhibition baseball victory as the world champion Milwaukee Braves bowed in their 1958 home debut.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 -- A wage increase of 16 cents an hour will be sought by West Coast longshoremen during negotiations for a new coastwise agreement to replace the contract expiring June 15.

BREWSTER, N. Y., April 12 -- Is the strong, hardy outdoorsman losing his strength and hardihood? Is the nation going soft? The weather today wasn't really too bad, in comparison to other recent years on opening day, but every piece of water checked was entertaining fewer fishermen than usual.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -Spring, rare in this latitude and usually superfluous, is here this year. Its elixir seems to have freed Florida Gulf Coast enterprisers from the cautious mood they might be expected to maintain after the big chill.
HONG KONG, April 12 -- The Peiping radio reported tonight that the Chinese Communists had insisted that the United States designate a new Ambassador for the three-year-old bilateral talks in Geneva.

EAST LANSING, Mich., April 12 (AP) -- Michigan State and Illinois wound up in a tie tonight in the contest for the team title at the sixteenth annual National Collegiate gymnastics championships.

THE author of "Legal Aspects of Photography" (New York: Greenberg, $1.95) divides his book into seven "problems" in place of the usual chapters. The term is appropriate here, as the reader soon learns, for Robert Veit Sherwin, a New York attorney, confronts the reader with an awesome catalogue of legal pitfalls that face the unwary photographer.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- This resort community is winding up its annual, spring vacation season. Each year thousands of college students, whose spring recess comes around the Easter holiday, are in the habit of descending on Fort Lauderdale.

AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France, April 12 (AP) -- Budge Patty eliminated Nick Carter, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, today in an all-American semifinal match in an international tennis tournament today. Patty, who is from Los Angeles, and Carter, from San Francisco, both now live in Paris.

JERSEY CITY, April 12 -Joseph E. McLean is attempting to turn to practical use the political science he taught for eight years at Princeton University.
ALBANY, April 12 (AP) -- Gov. Harriman appealed today to the Judicial Conference, which includes the state's top jurists, to draw up a court reform plan for action in the 1959 Legislature.

HERE is a book with a unique approach to Asia. Written by a Danish journalist, Jorgen Andersen-Rosendal, it is a recollection of the women of the East he has known in old Shanghai, Bombay, Saigon and other cities. Through these pages parade some of the most interesting characters that have come along in many a moon.
Dr. Harold E. Anthony, senior scientist at the American Museum of Natural History and a leading authority on mammals, has retired as chairman of the museum's Department of Mammals.
Police Commissioner. Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday the fourth police shake-up as a result of widespread policy operations in Harlem.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 12-- Al Streelman of Paterson broke twenty-four out of twenty-five targets in a shootoff today to win the singles event in the fourth annual Thomas H. Lawrence Memorial trapshoot at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island range.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field will open its eight-day hearing here on Philadelphia union activities on Tuesday as scheduled.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 13 -- George Van Wyck of Valley Cottage, N. Y., posted a score of 499 today to win the 500-bird marathon handicap in the Thomas H. Lawrence Memorial trapshoot. The event was held at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club.
WHITE PLAINS, April 13 -- Gambling raids by state troopers have goaded Westchester's municipal police into stricter enforcement of gambling laws.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Congress will begin consideration this week of the kind of an organization needed to lead the nation into space.

Professional golfing's annual Tournament of Champions will be televised later this month from Las Vegas, Nev., by the National Broadcasting Company.

EVERY workday morning since last October a comedy girl has pedaled up Madison Avenue from Thirty-third to Fifty-sixth Street on a slender English bicycle. She makes the run in about twelve minutes, hitches the machine to a brass ring set in one of the walls around the International Business Machines Corporation parking lot, vanishes into the I. B. M. Building at Fifty-seventh Street.

TRENTON, N. J., April 13--Although New Jersey has felt keenly the effects of the current recession--five of its major industrial regions have been declared labor surplus areas-nothing concrete has been done in the state to meet the situation.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -- Television comedy is not dead.
LONDON, April 13 -- The threat of a nation-wide railroad strike caused a setback in the stock markets at the end of last week.
The most prolonged strike in network history entered its eighth day today as the Columbia Broadcasting System and a technicians' union sought to break a deadlock on a new contract.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 13 -- A model of the sputnik was installed in the Soviet pavilion today. There, held aloft on a great arrow-like pedestal, it will symbolize one of Moscow's major propaganda aims at the Brussels World's Fair -- to prove equality with any other country in technique and science.

LONDON, April 13 -- Hugh Gaitskell, leader of the Labor party, demanded today that Britain and the United States follow the example of the Soviet Union in suspending nuclear tests.
BOSTON, April 13--Gov. Foster Furcolo, a Democrat seeking re-election this year, is asking for a $50,000,000 bond issue to provide employment in Massachusetts.
A five-story building containing thirty apartments and occupying a plot 75 by 100 feet at 1452 Beach Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Geisinger Germain, realty operator.
Charter rates for tramp ships to carry coal and grain turned slightly higher last week, despite a falling off in volume.

E. E. Cummings, who recently received a Bollingen Award for "his gifts of natural wit and the lyric imagination with which he has delighted so many so long," is represented on lists of three publishers. On May 31, Argophile Press will issue "e. e. cummings: A Miscellany," edited with an introduction by George James Firmage.

The supply of money and savings can be expected to catch up greatly this year with the demand for investment funds, the Bankers Trust Company says in its annual study, "The Investment Outlook," published today.
A threatened "war" in the record industry was headed off yesterday by Columbia Records' announcement that it would release, "in the near future, a so-called non-compatible stereophonic disk."

TUNIS, April 13 -- The French Cabinet decision to accept a compromise in the dispute with Tunisia was hailed here today as an achievement for the Western world, and particularly for the United States.

NEWFOUNDLAND, N.J., April 13 -- Echoes of the Civil War sounded through the hills near here today -- the rattle of Springfield muskets and the throaty roar of muzzle-loading cannon. ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 13--The recession has forced a rise in taxes on three fronts in Maryland.
Mayor Wagner's proposed 1958-59 expense budget of $1,996,952,986 is about to be subjected to a three-day barrage of criticism.

American Airlines said yesterday it had ordered a supply of aluminum air-freight containers for its air cargo service. Each can hold more than a ton of cargo. An all-cargo DC-6A plane will be able to carry ten of the containers.

This is Pan American Day, the only annual day of celebration recognized by all twenty-one Governments of the American Republics. The ceremonies all through the week are going to be special, for this is the tenth anniversary of the founding of the Organization of American States, which is carrying on the work of the Pan American Union.
LANSING, Mich., April 13--Unemployment constitutes a major issue in Michigan with 15.5 per cent of the state's labor forces out of work.
WASHINGTON, April 13--Former President Harry S. Truman is scheduled to testify on the recession before a Congressional committee tomorrow at the unheard-of hour for Congressmen--9:30 A. M.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, April 13 (AP) -- The Hadassah University Hospital described today a new process of treating male infertility by adding fluid from a donor's normal semen to that of infertile husbands.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 -- If a fellow wanted to back away from the American League pennant race in order to reach a more dispassionate appraisal, he couldn't back much farther than this. A couple of more steps and he'd be in the Pacific Ocean. So it behooves a guy to stop at the shoreline.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Congress returns from a ten-day Easter recess tomorrow. It will plunge immediately into controversial issues of the national economy, foreign policy, military reorganization and outer space.

SINGAPORE, April 13 -- The heaviest fighting of the Indonesian rebellion erupted today in Sumatra. Five Government warships arrived off the rebel stronghold of Padang and aircraft bombed and strafed rebel targets' in preparation for an invasion of the rebel heartland.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 13--Three railroad commuter groups have called on Bergen County's seventy towns for help in establishing the proposed bi-state transit district. The duties of the district would be to create a program for a rapid transit system linking New York and Northern New Jersey.

CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- George Harris of the Air Force today successfully defended his heavyweight title in the sixth annual National Amateur Athletic Union judo championships. He defeated John Osako of Chicago, who won the 180-pound crown.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., April 13 -- Henry Cabot Lodge challenged the Soviet Union tonight to take a "step for peace" by permitting the Russian people to see Hollywood movies that did not distort American life.
MOSCOW, Monday, April 14 -- A native of the American Deep South who is the son of an oil company employe and a beneficiary of the Rockefellers: that is who stands as the cynosure of Moscow today.
SYRACUSE, Sicily, April 13 (AP) -- Italy's Luigi Musso drove his big red Ferrari to victory today in the Syracuse Grand Prix auto race.
Cardinal Spellman announced yesterday that "within a few months" he would bless and dedicate two of the costliest undertakings in the history of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -- William Goetz Productions has signed a new three-picture contract with Columbia Pictures under which the studio has transferred to Mr. Goetz for filming on a partnership basis two recently purchased novels and an original story.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Three right-handers, including a converted outfielder, will pitch in the 1958 baseball opener here tomorrow. The reformed outfielder is Dwight D. Eisenhower, who usually favors golf to baseball when not busy being President of the United States.

New Yorkers, who sometimes read of the increasing musical activities of young people across the nation, late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall had a chance to judge some of that progress for themselves. Five ensembles from different regions of the country played there in a gala youth string and orchestra festival sponsored by the Violin, Viola, Violoncello Teachers Guild.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 -- Plans for aircraft that will fly indefinitely without fuel by using the solar energy stored high in the earth's atmosphere were disclosed here today.
The Playwrights Company has a new script in hand from the younger of its two active Andersons.

Jeannine Romer, pianist, made her appearance in recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. A resident of Toronto, Miss Romer was trained at Rollins College and Columbia University and won the Young Artists' Audition of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra.

KANSAS CITY, April 13 (AP) -- A single by Bill Tuttle and and an error by Bill Green scored the winning run in the fourteenth inning as the Kansas City Athletics defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 -- 2, in the wind-up of a three-game exhibition baseball series.

MIAMI, April 13 (UP) -- The directors of the International League today voted to open the baseball season as scheduled in Havana Wednesday, but the Buffalo team immediately sent word that it would not show up because of the armed revolt in Cuba.

The Board of Estimate's three days of public hearings on Mayor Wagner's $1,996,952,986 "austerity" executive budget begin today amid signs of mass protest. By last weekend 394 individuals had asked to be heard, which was 115 more than last year, and more requests for a chance to speak are expected.
Fair weather is the outlook for Wednesday's opening of the city's Salute to Spring.

Decisive action toward solution of problems on the formation of the proposed European Free Trade Area was urged last week by Rene Sergent, secretary-general of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.
Another trade union -- the "Big Six" of the printing industry -- is going into the housing business to help assure continued residence in this city of its middle-income, skilled workers

DECORATION today starts at floor level in even the Spartan-plain modern room. In the present decorating scheme of things, floors are paved with intricately patterned or brightly colored rugs (witness the revival of the once "old-fashioned" Oriental carpet), rich marbles, velvety brown parquet or ornate tile arrangements.

The Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray observed yesterday his thirty-fifth anniversary as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (the Little Church Around the Corner) at 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Representative James T. Patterson, Republican of Connecticut, said tonight the United States would launch a satellite on or about April 24 that will send back five times more information than the first two United States satellites.
MAC MORGAN, baritone, who has sung with the New York City Opera and appeared frequently on radio and television, delighted a Town Hall audience at his debut recital yesterday afternoon.
There is an old belief among people living close to the sea that you can control and dominate it much of the time -- but never permanently.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 -- The Municipal Band played "San Francisco" an enthusiastic crowd of 350 turned out tonight to say hello to the Giants, this city's own entrant in National League baseball.

The moderate recessions of 1949 and 1953-54 were not ended without the aid of substantial tax cuts, resulting from the Revenue Act of 1948 and from certain measures effective in 1954. Without prompt and substantial tax cuts now there is grave danger of cumulative damage from the rapid tapering off in plant and equipment outlays already scheduled, the exhaustion of unemployment insurance rights and the deterioration in the economic position of our trading partners abroad.

The International Automobile Show closed its nine-day stand at the New York Coliseum yesterday with its exhibitors' faces wreathed in smiles. Charles Snitow, president of the show, said he believed the exhibition had established records for automobile shows in sales and attendance.
Orders for four new dry cargo ships recorded during March have added slightly to the ship construction backlog in American yards.
CHICAGO, April 13 -- A national private employment agency, Manpower, Inc., predicted today some upturn in employment by July 1.

PARIS, April 13 -- When NATO's Defense Ministers meet here this week, and again when its Foreign Ministers gather in Copenhagen, they will face a salient issue not listed on any agenda. This, in effect, is how closely does the alliance intend to stick together?
MIAMI, Fla., April 13 (UP) -- The three-man crew of a Cuban airliner stole their own plane today and flew it here with twelve passengers.

More and more the available open spaces of Long Island are being sought for and converted to recreation needs both of the island itself and of other parts of the metropolitan area. Now the Long Island State Park Commission has assured the expansion of Sunken Meadow State Park by purchasing Daybreak, a private estate on Long Island Sound near Fort Salonga.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 13 (AP) -- Rush IV, owned by Victor Sheronas of Philadelphia and sailed by George O'Day, survived a morning mishap and won the first race of the Edward Prince of Wales Cup yacht racing series.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)--Harry S. Truman took a long look at the White House today without the slightest outward sign of regret that he no longer lived there.

One of the features of the American business cycle -- too little recognized -- is the tendency of all of us to take the short-range view in periods of recession. An infectious concentration of attention, with neurotic complications, on the day-to-day figures of employment and production magnifies each dip out of all proportion to its significance in the unfolding panorama of decline and recovery.
The National Interscholastic Swimming Coaches' Association has just disclosed its annual ratings, referred to as the All-American Prep School Swimming Team.

The music lovers of Moscow are an exacting lot. To win their admiration and affection an artist has to be near the top in his field. It is particularly pleasant, therefore, to learn that a young American pianist, Van Cliburn, has taken Moscow by storm.

DELRAY BEACH, Fla., April 13 (AP) -- The defending champion, Dr. Edgar Updegraff of Tucson, Ariz., rallied to take the last three holes and defeat James Jackson of Kirkwood, Mo., 1-up, today in a thirty-six hole first-round match of the Western amateur golf championship.

I have followed with the deepest interest the press accounts of the proceedings concerning proposed changes in Washington Square. When New York University ten or fifteen years ago announced its intention to tear down the red brick houses on the north side of the Square between Fifth Avenue and University Place a committee of citizens was formed to oppose this and N. Y. U. gave it up.

ASBURY PARK. N. J., April 13 (AP) -- Marty Reisman of New York swept through his first two games and then fought back a determined bid by Max Marinko of Toronto to win the men's singles national table championship tonight.
Central Park became a huge playground and promenade area yesterday as its fresh greenery brought together athletes and belated Easter paraders against a sort of carnival background.

NASSAU, Bahamas, April 13 -- Alan Lennox-Boyd, British Colonial Secretary, announced today proposals for labor and electoral reforms meeting nearly all the complaints that led to recent unrest and a general strike in Nassau.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 13 (AP) -- Chancellor Collins J. Seitz said yesterday the management of Williams-McWilliams Industries had dropped its court case against an opposition group of stockholders in a proxy battle for control of the New Orleans dredging company.

Pullman, Inc., increased its consolidated revenues 16 per cent to $105,645,134 in the first quarter from $91,269,433 a year before, Champ Carry, the president reports. Net earnings were $2,897,166 or $1.31 a share, compared with $2,485,454 or $1.12 a share, a year ago.

BENNINGTON, Vt., April 13 -- The Nor'Easter, a three-day Sports Car Club of America national rally, was won today by an American-built automobile. An Oldsmobile 88 sedan, driven by Dick Apolant of Rochester, N. Y., with Ray Hicks as navigator, completed the 700-mile precision test with an aggregate error of only 292 seconds.
Doyle Dane Bernbach, Inc., has been appointed to handle the $900,000-a-year advertising account of Thom McAn shoes.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- The administration of criminal justice in the United States is "failing to meet its twin objectives of protecting society and preserving individual rights," the American Bar Association reported here today.
PARIS, April 13 -- The French Right Wing expressed its hostility today to the Government's decision to reopen direct negotiations with Tunisia.
Seven persons were injured in a three-alarm fire that badly damaged two old-law tenements in Harlem yesterday. Firemen led forty families and two groups of pets to safety.

Cotton futures moved downward in a narrow range last week. At the close of trading on Friday, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 5 to 19 points (25 to 95 cents a bale) lower than the close of the preceding holiday-shortened week.
HAVANA, April 13 -- Faustino Perez, right-hand man in Havana of Fidel Castro, the rebel leader, is still in control of the revolutionary organization here, according to information tonight.
ROME, April 13 -- The fate of migratory birds is straining relations between Italians and northern Europeans.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 (AP) -- Mayor George Christopher, president of the American Municipal Association, urged mayors and officials of more than 13,000 communities today to oppose widespread advertising tax proposals.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Senate Disarmament Subcommittee will investigate this week the possibility of suspending nuclear tests.
Elicum Moishe Levin, a wispy patriarch, danced the hora yesterday, doled candy from his pockets to his great-grandchildren and even tasted a Manhattan. It was his 100th birthday party.

Schild Realty bought the six-story buildings with fifty-three apartments at 357 Avenue P, corner of Dahill Road, Brooklyn, from Jacob A. Schaubin. Hussey Hoeh, in conjunction with J. H. Katz Co., brokers, negotiated the sale for cash over mortgages amounting to $234,900.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Four civilian experts on military affairs disagreed sharply today on whether the defense program was adequate to meet the Soviet threat.
The Ford Foundation has granted $500,000 to the American Council of Learned Societies to encourage international scholarly congresses in the United States.
AMSTERDAM, April 13 -- Total unemployment in the Netherlands in March fell from 124,000 to 116,000, but after seasonal corrections there was a rise from 89,000 to 120,000.
A prominent Harlem clergyman will preach his farewell sermon next Sunday after serving forty-seven years as a Methodist minister.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 13 -- The Brazilian Government is drafting legislation designed to curtail the increased political activities of the Communist party. The legislation is being drafted under army pressure.

Premier Gaillard of France and President Bourguiba of Tunisia, both men of goodwill, are both operating under pressure from extremists. Premier Gaillard's extremists defended the brutal bombing of a Tunisian village by French planes last February and have since insisted on a tough line with Bourguiba.

The Rev. Dr. Albert J. Penner, pastor of the Broadway Congregational Church at Fifty-sixth Street since 1949, announced to his congregation yesterday that he had resigned to become the president and minister of the Massachusetts Congregational Conference.
Ex-Harlem Pastor Tackled as Two Guns Go-Off -- No One Is Injured

VITTORIO GIANNINI'S operatic version of "The Taming of the Shrew" makes a capital show. Presented at the City Center last night, it adorned the season of American opera with the vivacity of its spirits and the boisterousness of its laughter.

Irmgard Seefried, soprano, and her husband, the violinist Wolfgang Schneiderhan, gave a joint recital on Saturday evening in the Hunter College Auditorium. It was the only New York appearance of the season for both, and the event also brought to a close the Hunter College concert series.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -- Leo A. Hoegh, chief of the Federal Civil Defense Administration, announced plans today to train a million high school students to operate instruments that measure radioactive fall-out.
BALTIMORE, April 13 (AP) -- The Redlegs spotted Baltimore two runs in the early innings today, then came back to defeat the Orioles, 3 -- 2, in the rubber game of an exhibition series.

A merger of the Fort Neck National Bank at Seaford, L. I., with the Security National Bank of Huntington, L. I., has been approved by the directors of both banks. A joint announcement was made by George A. Heaney, president of Security National, and Herman H. Maass, president of Fort Neck.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 -- President Eisenhower urged the returning Congress today to act "as swiftly as possible" on his proposal to extend unemployment compensation. The step would benefit workers who had exhausted their drawing rights under state and Federal laws.
Courage and conscientious effort won honorable mention awards for two patrolmen and three detectives among 276 cited yesterday by Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.

SEVERAL first performances were given at yesterday's Music in Our Time program at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. Most of the music on the program was oriented toward the twelve-tone school, and two of the novelties were no exception.
" The Music Man" waltzed off last night with five of the eighteen Tony awards, Broadway counterpart of the Hollywood "Oscars" and the television Emmys.
ACCRA, Ghana, April 13 -- A conference of independent African states scheduled to open here Tuesday has all but completed an unplanned descent from the summit to the foreign ministers level.
ALBANY, April 13--A direct result of the recession has been a substantial liberalization of llexv York State's unemployment insurance program.

MILWAUKEE, April 13 (UP)--Three home runs helped the world champion Milwaukee Braves to a 7-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers today in the wind-up of the spring exhibition baseball season for both teams.

THE television program called "Conquest" devoted its sixty minutes on Channel 2 yesterday to weather and navigation. It was a particularly absorbing hour because, in exploring scientific subjects, it used terms and ideas within the range of understanding of most laymen.

GREENSBORO, N. C., April 13 (AP) -- Bob Goalby, a golf professional only fourteen months, won his first major tournament today. Rounds of 69 and 66 for 275 captured the Greater Greensboro open by two shots.
Carmine G. De Sapio threw the door open yesterday for Mayor Wagner to run for the United States Senate in November.
" Shakespeare in Music," a program for the benefit of the New York Shakespeare Festival, was given last night in Carnegie Hall.
The American Ballet Theatre will present the Ballet Theatre Workshop in a single experimental performance of four new ballets at the Phoenix Theatre next Monday.
At Saturday night's performance of "Trouble in Tahiti" at the City Center, Seymour Lipkin made his debut as a New York City Opera Company conductor.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A new proposal for improving the Federal Government's personal security procedures, brought forward today, focuses attention again on the uncertain legal status of the various security programs.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- House investigators reported today that the Immigration Service had removed a ban on information about the employment of Japanese farm laborers in the United States.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 13 -- Apart from conjecture about prospective developments in the Interhandel case, aroused by the negative outcome of the visit of Dr. Rudolf Pfenninger to Washington, almost no interest in business was evident on the stock exchange last week.

HISTORY does not tell what was cooking in Lyon just 2,000 years ago, when that French city was founded as a Roman colony. But this week, as Lyon celebrates its venerable birthday with an international fair, it is safe to say that the cuisine in even the shabbiest side-street restaurant will be superb.
BOSTON, April 13 (UP) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard scored twice and his brother Henri tallied once for the Montreal Canadiens in a 3-0 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight.
Four new films are slated to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 13 -- James C. Hagerty said President Eisenhower talked by telephone this morning with Secretary of State Dulles about the "implications" of the Soviet reply last Week to the Western Big Three's summit proposals.

ON March 4, 1865, it was raining hard in Washington. The huge crowd assembled before the Capitol steps to hear President Lincoln's second inaugural address was soaked and splashed with yellow mud. Although the long war was nearly four years old, Grant and the Army of the Potomac seemed to be permanently stuck in trenches before Richmond and Petersburg.

PITTSBURGH, April 13 -- Considering the lack of automotive steel orders and the depth of the recession in the steel industry, incoming orders in the last few weeks suggest that a bottom may have been reached.
Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy commended his staff yesterday for shouldering the task of dealing with "a zooming increase" of applications for relief in the recession.

MOSCOW, April 13 -- Trying to document its contention that United States military leaders are ready on the slightest pretext to plunge the world into war, the newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda told today what it said was a true story:
HARTFORD, April 13--Connecticut's General Assembly is discussing anti-recession proposals at a special session.

When President Eisenhower throws out the first ball in Washington this afternoon the 1958 baseball season will be officially open. This is that "opening day" for which all the faithful have been waiting through what seemed like an unconscionably long spring.

OMAHA, April 13 (UP) -- A five-run uprising in the ninth inning carried the Cleveland Indians to an 8-5 victory over the San Francisco Giants today before an overflow crowd of 14,070. San Francisco captured the spring series, however, 13 -- 7.
A piece of New York's musical life has disappeared with the death of 68-year-old Giuseppe Ravita, the sidewalk fiddler of West Fifty-seventh Street.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 13 (AP) -- Harry Bright of the New York Pioneer Club accounted for two individual marks and helped set two relay records today as a touring team of five United States athletes smashed six Ceylon open track and field records.
TRENTON, April 13 -- The campaign for major party nominations for United States Senator from New Jersey will come to a halt tomorrow night.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., April Tom Gately held the lead of 13 -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Gately of Newton, Conn., had a big day as handlers at the eleventh annual Twin Brooks Kennel Club all-breed dog show today.
CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- Nearly all the news affecting corn futures had a distinctly bullish flavor last week and prices on the Board of Trade pushed ahead for the second successive week.
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., April 13 -- The New York National Guard is planning to construct a 3,000-foot airplane landing strip this summer at Camp Smith, its training camp here.
NEW DELHI, India, April 13 -- The Communist party of India, which in the past has demanded outright nationalization of foreign-owned enterprises, has moderated its attitude.

LINDEN, N. J., April 13 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company will formally open its new $100,000,000 electric generating station here Wednesday. The station has an initial capacity of 450,000 kilowatts. It is on the Arthur Kill.
The Appalachian Electric Power Company intends to make the waters of the Roanoke River in Virginia work double time.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 13 -- Czechoslovakia's program of economic reorganization and decentralization, now in full swing, has been made a vehicle for purging "politically alien elements" from even the minor jobs to which they had long ago been relegated.
A spot check of thirteen states disclosed yesterday that most of them were looking to Washington for a strong lead in fighting the recession.
Five East Side families will open their homes and gardens on April 29 as a benefit for the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. The residences have been chosen for their decor and artistic contents.

CLIFTON, N. J., April 14 -- At ten minutes past 11 o'clock this morning, the bell rang at Clifton High School signaling the end of the fifth period. George Telesh, dressed in white bucks, brown slacks and a tweed sport coat, hurried from his English class in room 211 to the first-floor office of Dr. Elinor E. Hanna, the school's principal.

Sales of frozen foods are 10 to 20 per cent above those for last year and nothing but a lack of grocery-store freezer-cabinet space can slow them according to Walter Greenspan, Newark distributor and president of the Eastern Frosted Foods Association.

DELRAY BEACH, Fla., April 14 (AP) -- James (Billy) Key of Columbus, Ga., eliminated the defending titleholder, Dr. Edgar Updegraff of Tucson, Ariz., 4 and 3, in a thirty-six hole quarterfinal of the Western Amateur golf tournament today.
Sugar Ray Robinson, the world middleweight champion, got the better of an old foe, Rocky Graziano, once again last night.

First-quarter sales of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. fell 17 per cent from a year ago, but are showing "a rising trend," Crawford H. Greenewalt, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del. He said volume for the full year might not be more than 5 per cent below the record set in 1957.

CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Corn futures attracted the major interest on the Board of Trade again today as they resumed their price advances, interrupted only twice by minor setbacks during the last two weeks.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 -- New equipment to determine the world-wide distribution of radioactive fall-out was described here today at the annual meeting of the American Chemical Society by the Atomic Energy Commission.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 14 -- A total of $480,000 in erosion repair projects for the storm-battered coastline of Long Island was recommended here today by the State De partment of Public Works. The priority projects were detailed in a preliminary report filed with the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors by Milton E. Goul, district engineer.
FOUR clearly defined personalities emerge in an exhibition of new drawings at the Charles Alan Gallery, 32 East Sixty-fifth Street.

Futures prices closed irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, copper, zinc, lead, burlap and wool rose. Cocoa, sugar, rubber and hides declined. Price movements for potatoes and coffee were mixed.
Encouraging news on the employment situation came from three sources yesterday.

Seldom does the average American receive a letter from the President. Indeed, discounting the summons to all eligible males during a time of national emergency, letters received from the White House are exceedingly rare among the populace and are liable to become collector's items and family heirlooms.

NORFOLK, Va., April 14 -- The Navy announced today plans to deactivate forty-eight ships, including four carriers, during the fiscal year 1959. The action brings to 128 the number of ships to be made idle during the 1958-59 period.

GENEVA April 14 (AP) -- A new article on the arbitration of fishery disputes, adopted today at the eighty-six-nation world conference on the law of sea, led to Latin-American predictions the conference would fail.

Rowing coaches of Eastern colleges gathered at Leone's restaurant yesterday for their first luncheon meeting of the new season, and heard Delos (Dutch) Schoch give high praise to his Princeton heavyweight varsity.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 -- An epoch in baseball begins tomorrow when the former New York Giants and the erstwhile Brooklyn Dodgers meet in the Pacific-Coast's first big league game.

LONDON, April 14 -- Derick Heathcoat Amory, Chancellor of the Exchequer, discussed his 1958-59 budget today with Queen Elizabeth II and with Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and other members of the Cabinet.

When Eddie Arcaro woke up yesterday morning, he had no idea what horse he would be riding in the Wood Memorial this Saturday. Then he got a call from Ivan Parke asking, "Eddie, how'd you like to ride Jewel's Reward in a workout today?"

Stone steps were turned into impromptu benches throughout the city yesterday by office workers using their coffee and noon-hour breaks to bask in the sun. Those who had been grumbling that spring was apparently determined to avoid the city this year eagerly doffed their coats and jackets as the temperature rose to a high for the year -- 67 degrees at 4:35 P. M., more than 5 degrees above Sunday's high of 61.8.
Earnings of the B. F. Goodrich Company declined 38 per cent in the first quarter this year on a sales drop of 11.8 per cent.
DETROIT, April 14 -- Henry Ford 2d, president, announced today a realignment of Ford Motor Company manufacturing activities.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would investigate a planned average increase of 13 per cent in brokerage charges for buying and selling securities on the New York Stock Exchange.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 -- Television viewers and jazz fans across the nation will be hearing variations of the old music form as practitioners of Dixieland, gutbucket, progressive and blues are seen and heard in two new network shows.
The leaders of New York's export-import trucking industry voted last night to boycott the port's piers today.

Dr. Milton Helpern, Chief Medical Examiner, disclosed yesterday that the deaths of two persons in recent months of liver ailments had a "suggestive relationship" to the use of iproniazid, the drug that is sold under the trade name of Marsilid.
An agreement was reached yesterday on terms for a three-year contract covering 11,000 workers in the skirt and sportswear industry.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York announced yesterday the appointment of Ralph F. Leach as vice president and treasurer and of Stuart K. Barnes as vice president and secretary. They were formerly treasurer and secretary, respectively.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -The Supreme Court held unanimously today that payments for rights in future oil profits are taxable as ordinary income, not as capital gains.

TORONTO, April 14 (Canadian Press) -- George Weston, Ltd., parent company in an international food set-up, had a net profit in 1957 of $5,443,579, or $1.76 a Class A and B share, compared with $4,823,103, or $1.56, in 1956.
Present and former fans of the San Francisco Giants and the Los Angeles Dodgers will be able to follow the fortunes of the baseball teams by radio today.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for $670,000 to make filmed copies of the public papers of all of the Presidents of the United States.
ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Harriman named five members to the new Special Legislative Committee on Revision and Simplification of the Constitution today.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 14 (Reuters) -- Cypriote gunmen resumed armed violence against Britons today after a year's pause. They critically wounded an off-duty serviceman in a shooting at the southeast seaport of Famagusta.

JUST back from a month's tour of California vineyards, Tom Marvel, vintner, spoke enthusiastically about improvements in that state's finer wines. He also went out on a limb by naming the particular wines he considered California's best.
RATHER than completely rebuild your wardrobe for spring, it might be wise to remodel last year's sheath into this year's chemise by wearing a cocoon of net over it.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -President Eisenhower snapped a high, hard one at the grouped teams of the Washington Senators and Boston Red Sox today to signal the start of the 1958 baseball opener. A few moments later he was just another of the 26,675 spectators waiting for the umpire's "play-ball" signal.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 14 -- An unidentified two-engine plane attacked the air base at Macassar, biggest city in East Indonesia, yesterday. It was the first air raid on a pro-Government installation since the start of the rebellion in February.

Recently I read in The New York Times excerpts from the address of Andrew Roscoe, president of the Equitable Savings and Loan Association, in which he warned that Brooklyn might become "a slum colony" of New York. I not only heartily approve of what he said, but having read the retort of my long-time friend, Borough President John Cashmore, I find that it is no answer at all to what Mr. Roscoe had previously said.

PARIS, April 14 -- The Western Big Three got renewed approval in principle today from other members of the Atlantic alliance for their decision to begin preliminary diplomatic talks in Moscow, soon on a heads-ofgovernment meeting.
A Chilean diplomat yesterday urged the development of foreign markets to help end the recession in the United States.
BOSTON, April 14 -- Don Larsen, the Yankees' "perfect-game" pitcher of the 1956 world series, stood poised tonight to make another big pitch.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 14 (UP) -- William H. Francis Jr., Assistant Defense Secretary, told an audience of top-ranking National Guard officers, including 100 generals, today that a "regrettable" cut in the guard must be made for national security.
Surpluses of refined copper continued to mount last month despite the copper industry's production curtailment program.
CHICAGO, April 14 -- Sigma Delta Chi, national journalism fraternity, announced today the winners of its twenty-sixth annual awards for distinguished service in journalism.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -Harry S. Truman urged today a $5,000,000,000 tax cut for middle and low income groups. He also proposed a five-year plan for increased Government spending to offset the current recession and keep the economy healthy through 1964.
In the hundred years that Dun Bradstreet, Inc. -- which also calls itself the Mercantile Agency -- has been compiling figures on bankruptcies, it has analyzed more than 1,000,000 business failures.
The New York Central Railroad is seeking to lease its executive office building at 230 Park Avenue.

The threat of a pilots' strike beginning at 11:59 P. M. tomorrow continued to hang over American Airlines yesterday. Spokesmen for the airline and the Air Line Pilots Association reported no change in their contract dispute.

TWO new one-act operas -one very grim, the other frivolous -- were introduced last night by the opera workshop and orchestra of the Mannes College of Music. The grim one was Ned Rorem's "The Robbers," based on his own libretto.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A new strategic plan for Western defense, calling for some reductions in military manpower, will be discussed tomorrow by the Atlantic pact defense ministers in Paris.

Forehanded as usual, R. H. Macy Co. has already been celebrating for several months an anniversary that won't really happen for several months more. But a one hundredth anniversary is extraordinary even in old New York, and worthy of the year-long celebration that Macy's is giving it.
HAVANA, April 14 -- Unrealistic planning, poor coordination and shockingly inadequate communications were mainly responsible for the collapse of the Cuban revolutionary strike.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -The Treasury bill rate rose this week after touching three-year lows in the two previous weeks, the Treasury reported tonight. The average interest rate on $1,700,000,000 of the ninety-oneday discount bills was 1,225 per cent, compared to 1.074 per cent last week.

THERE are those who say that competitive sports fishing is not necessarily a great moral force, but nobody denies now that it is a force of some kind. There are thousands of fishing competitions in the United States, ranging from the International Tuna Cup Match and its ambitious overtones of world good-will down to the little commercial prize - grabbings of remote inland towns.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The 1957-58 recession qualified today as the deepest of the three post-war slumps. As reflected in the index of industrial production, the decline reached 11.7 per cent in March, the Federal Reserve Board reported.

LONDON, April 14 -- The United States, Britain and France have agreed to hold ambassadorial talks with the Soviet Union in Moscow on preparations for a heads-of-government conference, authoritative sources said today.
Residents of Bayside, Queens, will give blood today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at All Saints' Protestant Episcopal Parish Hall, 214th Street and Fortieth Avenue.
A hydrofoil passenger craft of 120 tons that could carry 300 passengers at sixty to seventy miles an hour is now possible, in the opinion of the Maritime Administration.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. John B. Ackerman, who was recalled from the Philippines for poor judgment and extravagant living, has been reprimanded and reduced in grade.

Thousands of Herald Square shoppers witnessed a real cops-and-robber drama yesterday morning. It featured a demonstration of uncommon courage by a sock salesman, and a policeman who shot himself and the bandit with the same bullet.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 -- The Giants triumphed today in their final pre-season appearance.
Dr. Ethel Alpenfels said yesterday that the major task of contemporary Christian education was to develop an understanding of different cultures.
The Vernon Rice Memorial Awards, given annually for "outstanding achievement" in the off-Broadway theatre, were presented yesterday to two performers and a director.
The Railway Express Agency has attacked the Post Office Department for saying that parcel post "pays its own way."

CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- The high choice and prime grades of slaughter steers were as much as $2 lower, and the kinds averaging good or better were 50 cents to $1 lower. The popular good and choice grades brought $24 to $30, high choice and prime $30.50 to $34, the top, and utility and standard kinds $21 to $24.
Steel production edged off last week for the fourth consecutive week and was scheduled to decline further this week, the American Iron and Steel Institue reported yesterday.
The Dow Chemical Company showed the effects of the recession, with lower sales and earnings for the three and nine months ended Feb. 28 than those of the preceding periods.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- A Navy Medal of Honor winner was named today to choose the Unknown soldier of World War II, who will be buried at Arlington National Cemetery on Memorial Day, May 30.

TELEVISION has learned a fashion lesson from the movies. The "trapeze" dress that Zsa Zsa Gabor wore at the Academy Award presentations was such a flop visually that actresses appearing on the Emmy Award show tonight are avoiding the "triangle" shape.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Like the philosopher Plato, the Commerce Department has been holding imaginary conversation with itself.
EVERYONE has made a valiant attempt to be piquant in "Love Me Little," which opened at the Helen Hayes Theatre last evening.
WARSAW, April 14 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka laid down today a new hard line for Poland's workers, and in effect ended the country's eighteen-month experiment with workers' councils.

President Eisenhower has acted wisely and properly in calling upon Congress again to enact into law his proposal for helping the unemployed. Under the President's proposal Federal funds would be used to permit extension of unemployment insurance benefits for a period of time half again as long as that now permitted under the different state systems.
An end to coyness oh the part of those seeking the Republican nomination for Governor was demanded last night by Thomas J. Curran, New York County leader.

HAVANA, April 14 -- Thirty rebels were killed in Oriente Province in encounters with Government troops, according to an army communique tonight. Twenty-six were killed near the small town of Lima and the other four near Jamaica. Three soldiers were wounded in the encounter, the communique said.
ROME, April 13 -- Charges of nepotism involving the Vatican have become an issue in Italy's general election campaign.

Former President Harry S. Truman was revealed yesterday to have declined an invitation to a 1956 Gridiron Club dinner honoring Vice Presidents because of his dislike for Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
Former Justice David W. Peck of the Supreme Court appealed to Governor Harriman and Republicans yesterday to stop making a "political football" out of court reform and cooperate to achieve it.

LONDON, April 11 -- Stocks were buoyant today on the eve of the new budget. Interest centered on equities that benefited from optimism that the Government would announce some incentive for industry in the form of reduced taxes.
Winston Churchill contended in a magazine article distributed yesterday that further opportunities for a summit conference between East and West "must not be neglected."

ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Harriman disapproved today a bill that would have barred the admission in a criminal ease of evidence obtained by illegal wiretapping. Such evidence is already prohibited in civil cases.

MOSCOW, April 14 -- Similar notes from the United States, Britain and France are expected to be delivered to the Soviet Foreign Ministry shortly announcing their readiness to open pre-summit talks in Moscow.

DETROIT, April 14---Charles T. Fisher Jr., president of the National Bank of Detroit and ene of thi city's best-known civic leaders, died today of lUng cancer in Jennings Hospital here. He was 51 years old.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 14 (AP) -- Rush IV, owned by Philadelphian Victor Sheronas and sailed by George O'Day, again finished first today in the second race of the Edward Prince of Wales Cup yacht series.
"Driver failure" should be studied in a major research program aimed at discovering the causes and cures of traffic accidents, a highway official declared yesterday.
Fifteen awards were made last night by the United Negro College Fund to individuals and organizations that had assisted the fund or its member colleges.

WHITE PLAINS, April 14 -John H. Downing, chairman of the Westchester Board of Supervisors, rapped a gavel this morning and sold 1,000 shares of St. Louis Southwestern Railway stock to the Southern Pacific Railroad for $235,000. The drone of "going, going, gone!" ended just seven minutes after the public auction was opened.
HAVANA, April 14 (AP) -- Rebel forces carried their guerrilla warfare to within sight of the United States naval base at Guantanamo in eastern Cuba today.

Manhattan College, which spread its strength all over the program at the Marine Corps Schools Relays last Saturday and came home without a title, will concentrate on the sprint medley and mile events in Saturday's Queens-Iona Relays at Randalls Island.
MOSCOW, April 14 -- The Soviet Union's second satellite has disintegrated, leaving the upper atmosphere to the three American artificial moons.
The first major refunding of corporate bonds since the market for fixed-income investments turned strong last fall was arranged yesterday by the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company.
Two women survivors of fatal loft fires made a dramatic appeal yesterday to the City Council for legislation to prevent such fires.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -The sixty-seventh Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution opened tonight with a keynote speech denouncing Supreme Court decisions of the last year.

District Attorney Edward S. Silver said yesterday that there was no basis for the charge that 1,500 bingo players had been cheated out of prize money at a charity affair Sunday night in the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.
Municipal Court Justice Milton M. Wecht was reported yesterday in line for appointment by Governor Harriman as a City Court Justice in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -Secretary of State Dulles said today that never before had a group of nations "enjoyed so high a measure of fellowship and harmony" as the twenty-one American republics.

Carmine G. De Sapio, the Tammany leader, seems to be laboring continuously under the misconception that Mayor Wagner is available to run again for the United States Senate if the Democratic party needs him. We are sure Mr. Wagner doesn't feel that way about it, because he has said so many times.
FRANKFORT, Ky., April 14 (AP) -- Unemployment in Kentucky, as measured by jobless pay claims, reached a high today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Administration is deeply worried about the future of its foreign trade program -- so much so that the State Department is now seriously considering a revision of two of this Government's pet economic doctrines.

SINGAPORE, April 14 -- Indonesian Government forces reported today they had slashed a major rebel supply route to North Sumatra and pushed to within ten miles of the rebels' last southern lifeline to the outside world.
DETROIT, April 14 -- The automobile industry has poured nearly $5,000,000 into a cooperative research program to eliminate harmful materials from car exhausts.
The National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday consumers carried home last year about $48 billion of food and allied purchases, almost 20 per cent more than in 1954.
TRENTON, April 14 -- A moderate turnout is expected tomorrow when New Jersey voters choose Republican and Democratic nominees for one seat in the United States Senate and fourteen in the House.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -Secretary of State Dulles said today that ambassadorial talks preparing for a top-level meeting might start within "a few days." Administration officials suggested later it was possible the meeting would take place in Moscow as early as Thursday, as proposed by the Soviet Union.
The G. M. C. truck and coach division of the General Motors Corporation has parked its $3,000,000 account alongside Buick's at McCann-Erickson, Inc.
Adlai E. Stevenson, four other individuals and two film corporations were named defendants yesterday in a $750,000 treble damage antitrust suit in Federal court.
DETROIT, April 14 -- The automobile companies have cut their planned output for the second quarter by 99,000 units to reduce the backlog of unsold cars in dealers' hands.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -The Atomic Energy Commission is disclosing the time and place of fifteen past nuclear explosions to help scientists learn more about the structure of the earth.

Mr. Truman's before-breakfast stroll on Sunday took him past the house in Washington where he used to live. He seemed happy enough to be outside looking in instead of inside looking out. He referred, indeed, to the Executive Mansion as "the Big White Jail."

DETROIT, April 14 (AP) -Combined official and unofficial figures indicate that the auto industry sold 1,100,000 new cars in this year's first quarter, compared with 1,448,962 in the like 1957 quarter.

San Francisco received bids yesterday on bond issues totaling $24,225,000 to finance improvements in parking, airport and recreational facilities. The funds also will be used to expand an electric-power system and for other public works.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- Representative John W. McCormack, Democrat of Massachusetts, who is chairman of the House Space Committee, introduced today the Administration's bill to set up a civilian agency that would direct space and aeronautics programs.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 14 -- Al Clark, an old hand at sulky transportation, received one of the biggest thrills of his 38-year racing career in the opening test at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

An investigation into the problem of nuclear test suspension and the necessary conditions for it is being scheduled by the Senate Disarmament subcommittee headed by Senator Humphrey. Certainly an honest and searching effort to ascertain the facts in this critically important area is both timely and necessary.
Youngsters between 10 and 12 years old were characterized yesterday as the "hard-to-reach" group for adults.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- The United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East is looking for an extra $7,000,000. But Henry R. Labouisse, the director, is not threatening to close down if he does not get it.

THE tribal rites and folkways of the Confederacyhaunted South are displayed with skill and understanding in Josephine Pinckney's novels. The mockery is softened with sympathy, the wry comedy of manners is explored by one who was to those manners born. Her last and perhaps her finest book, "Splendid in Ashes,"* is a fond farewell tribute to the proper -- and the improper -- Charlestonians.
SOLOMON HUROK is one of the last survivors of a nearly extinct breed, the fur-collar impresario. When he believes in an attraction he will gamble on it.

LAST night's "Lucille BallDesi Arnaz Show" on Channel 2 may have contained familiar comedy ideas, but they were done in such rousing style that, this one-hour filmed program, the last of the series for the season, was filled with fun.
MOSCOW, April 14 -- Van Cliburn played piano tonight for a chief of state, a chief of government, a queen and a houseful of cheering Muscovites.
Stocks yesterday celebrated the return of the Congressional nose to the grindstone by making the best gain since March 11 in the broadest market since Jan. 16.
The Getty Oil Company is offering to exchange five of its common shares for six of the $5 par value capital shares of the Mission Development Company.
The city should impose new nuisance taxes, if necessary, to finance city salary increases in its 1958-59 "austerity" budget, the Board of Estimate was told yesterday.
The Port of New York Authority turned down another suggestion yesterday that the agency increase the payments it makes in lieu of city taxes on its Brooklyn waterfront development program.

TOKYO, April 14 (Reuters) -- The luxury liner Caronia, carrying many Americans on a round-the-world "millionaires' cruise," was stranded here today after hitting a light marker on a breakwater at the entrance to Yokohama harbor.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 -- The Giants and the Dodgers have been playing ball against each other for almost as long as the cable cars out here have been running up Powell Street to the crest of Nob Hill, Generations of athletic heroes have performed at the Polo Grounds, the old Polo Grounds and the old Polo Grounds.

May I once again crave the hospitality of your columns for an earnest appeal to the Government of the United States and to the people of America? The present is a critical point of time and I implore America to ponder over the situation created by the recent declaration of the U. S. S. R. to abstain from further test explosions.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- The Distillery Workers Union re-elected its president and secretarytreasurer today in a supervised election.
A Federal mediator renewed efforts in Washington yesterday to break a deadlock in contract negotiations between the Columbia Broadcasting System and a striking technician union.
Cotton futures closed unchanged to 8 points down on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. The drop equaled 40 cents a bale.

THE eleventh national print exhibition, opening today at the Brooklyn Museum, could justly take over the words of the standard advance notice of the circus -- "bigger and better than ever." This year's event brings together 136 examples of the printmaker's work in a wide variety of media out of more than 1,200 items submitted from thirty-six states.

The Soviet Union and the United States are taking steps to exchange movies under a cultural agreement signed in Washington in January. The exchange would mark the first time since the end of World War II that such an official transaction had been made.
The police saved a 40-yearold woman from drowning in the Hudson River last night with an improvised lifeline of rope and life preservers.
A $4,500,000 triple-damage entitrust suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court against the Bell Howell Co. involving armed forces contracts for 16-millimeter sound motion picture projectors.
The mortgage money market has staged a complete turnabout since last November. Instead of borrowers having difficulty getting mortgages, lenders are having trouble finding borrowers.
CONCORD, Mass., April 14 -Rebellious prisoners rioted and started a fire after injuring three guards and a civilian instructor at the State Reformatory here today.

Every community needs a girls' club as a "home outside the home, to combat juvenile delinquency," Dorothy Shaver told the Girls Clubs of America yesterday. Miss Shaver, president of Lord Taylor, is also chairman of the board of the club federation. She spoke at the opening of a three-day convention at the Park Sheraton Hotel.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 14 -- A political quarrel that has been largely ignored abroad has brought Lebanon within sight of possible civil war.

In an unusually interesting primary election in both parties the voters of New Jersey today have an opportunity to select two fine candidates to oppose each other in November for the United States Senate seat being vacated by the Republican veteran, H. Alexander Smith.

The Riverdale Children's Association, 12 East Seventy-ninth Street, has chosen the My 21 evening performance of "The Visit," starring Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, for its spring theatre benefit.
A fund-raising dinner scheduled for next Monday by the Committee to Secure Justice for Morton Sobell was canceled "because of public pressure" yesterday by the Tavern on the Green in Central Park.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 14 -Dr. Carroll M. Leevy, director of clinical investigations at the Jersey City Medical Center, said here today that on occasion "unrecognized cirrhosis of the liver is a major contributory cause in cases of mental disturbance."
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Attorneys for Ezra Pound moved today for dismissal of the treason indictment that has been pending against him since 1945.

Two hundred demolition workers on vacant buildings being razed in the Washington Square area were idle until 1 P. M. yesterday until their employers agreed to accept conditions laid down by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -Parents and educators were urged today to stand firm against the advocates of increased emphasis on science and technology in the schools at the expense of a liberal "education for living."
Two morning rush-hour mishaps in Brooklyn delayed thousands of riders on the IND subway's D line for almost an hour yesterday.
Four American peace pilgrims, one of them a Long Island housewife, left for the Soviet Union yesterday to press for a clear, unconditional end to the testing of nuclear weapons in that country.
Death in the electric chair was ruled out yesterday for five of the seven teen-age boys accused of the murder of Michael Farmer.
THE strike of camera men and sound and video engineers at the Columbia Broadcasting System has brought to the fore television's major headache of the future: technological progress vs. job security.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -The Administration's view of the economic recession will be outlined by President Eisenhower in a major address in New York on May 20.

IT WAS a great night at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, and nobody who was there is likely to forget it very soon. The Moiseyev Dance Company from Moscow was making its American debut under the auspices of S. Hurok, the first major dance company from the Soviet Union ever to visit this country.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -Lyndon B. Johnson, Senate Democratic leader, said today he would be willing to grant the Secretary of Defense "discretion to a limited extent" in handling military funds.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -Senator Lyndon B. Johnson indicated today he would not seek a Senate vote to override President Eisenhower's veto of the farm bill.
MINEOLA, L. I. April 14 -The validity of a state law prohibiting wage assignments in installment sales contracts was upheld in the state Supreme Court here today.

CAIRO, April 14 -- Once again President Gamal Abdel Nasser has turned the propaganda campaign against King Hussein of Jordan full blast. It was apparent from the new high pitch of attacks against Hussein that the Egyptian leader was trying once again to stir up a proNasser rebellion among the Palestinian Arabs in Jordan.

Trans World Airlines flew into battle yesterday in the international sandwich war. It filed a formal protest against the kind of sandwiches being served to economy passengers by four European airlines.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, April 14 -- They say in Srinagar that Sheikh Abdullah, the Lion of Kashmir, has learned something from the chiru, an exceptionally wily breed of fish found in Kashmir's icy streams. The Sheikh's enemies have thrown in the baited hook and spread the nets, but the Sheikh remains uncaught.

EXTRAORDINARY survivals through more than a century and a half continually attest to the endurance of antiques. Many endure because they were made to last; many survive through regard for the past and many more through housekeeping inertia.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A Senate subcommittee today said there has been an alarming upsurge in juvenile delinquency since 1948. The report proposed setting up a Federal training center for personnel of juvenile correction institutions.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Harry S. Truman will be distinguished in history for momentous decisions, boldly and promptly made, that helped to assure victory to the United States in the greatest war of the Republic and stayed Europe against the spread of Communist rule.
Edward C. Werle, a former New York Stock Exchange page boy, has been nominated to serve a one-year term as chairman.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 -- Paramount Pictures will make its studio facilities available on a straight rental basis to individual producers of movies.
DARIEN, Conn., April 14 -This town's taxpayers today reversed their stand of last year and approved a $3,000,000 bond issue for a new high school.
The American Bankers Association sounded a new warning yesterday against further relaxation of installment credit terms.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

Now that state and Federal moneys are being sought to forestall further beach erosion in the Northeast, perhaps it is only fair to bring up the question of who owns the beaches and who is to be allowed to use them.

I am exercising my constitutional privilege in objecting to the installation of parking meters on Amsterdam Avenue north of 116th Street. I see no justification to inconvenience and disrupt the lives of private citizenry at the whim of the Department of Traffic.
The National Music League will celebrate the twentieth anniversary of its reorganization under the direction of Mrs. Anna C. Molyneaux with a reception this afternoon at the Lotos Club.

THE bumper baby crop of World War II will be reaching marriageable age this year. Aside from an expected run on honeymoon resorts and apartments, the flatware departments of stores are projecting a bountiful harvest.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- All was well today with that part of the English-speaking, peanut - munching, coke - guzzling world that is aware of the difference between a force-out and a flying missile.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- A Senate Appropriations subcommittee got an appeal from the food processing industry today to give the Food and Drug Administration more money to police the industry's operations.

Sales of the nation's major chain and mail order companies were 4.4 per cent higher in March than in the like 1957 month. This was a marked increase over the 1.5 per cent gain registered in February, though it was less than the 5.9 per cent increase for January.

The New York Yankees will have a warm reception outlined in letters of ice after their home opener on Friday. Eighteen cakes of ice, each weighing more than 300 pounds and totaling nearly three tons, will spell out "Welcome Home Yankees" in front of the Hotel Concourse Plaza near the Yankee Stadium.

A survey of Chinese history and politics is given in a new book by Amaury de Riencourt called "The Soul of China." The author contends that "although the future of China is of primary importance to the world, the West has never understood the essence of the Chinese mind and soul."
The circus' warmest audience of the year turned out yesterday on the warmest day of the year.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 14 -- A three-day African strike timed for South Africa's election week was called off tonight after its failure on the opening day and a strong show of force by the police.

Occasionally, Burgess Meredith likes to turn his hand to directing. The star is thinking of doing, so in behalf of "Ulysses in Nighttown," based on a section of James Joyce's "Ulysses." No date has been set for the arrival of Padraic Colum's version at the Rooftop Theatre, but there are signs that it might take place about May 27.

The Grace Line luxury cruise vessels Santa Paula and Santa Rosa will call at Nassau, the Bahamas, as part of their regular twelve-day cruise itinerary beginning next month. They will be the only American-flag liners in Nassau service.
Sanitation Commissioner Paul R. Screvane announced yesterday a five-week period of grace for the city's chronic litterbugs.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 14 -Algerian and Cameroonian nationalist representatives arrived unexpectedly here today to focus the attention of a conference of independent African states on their struggle against French rule.

Today's new film is "Lily of the Harbor." a Greek-language romantic drama with English titles, at the Cameo Theatre. The Finos Films production was directed by George Tzavellas, from his own story, and stars George Glenos, Elena Haghiargire and Alekos Alexandrakis.

An exhibition consisting of works from the private collections of the Friends of the Whitney Museum of American Art will be held at the museum from April 30 through June 15. More than 170 works by twentieth-century American painters and sculptors will be shown.
At about 10:30 last night, 3,600 persons on all levels of the Metropolitan Opera House exchanged grateful greetings with about 100 Russian dancers on the stage.
Governor Harriman was asked yesterday to veto a bill that would permit cities to sell slum clearance sites to redevelopers without public auction.

Up to the final number of Maya Hoffman's piano recital last night in Town Hall, one would have said that the young artist's greatest talent was for the poetic dreams of Robert Schumann. Most of all she seemed to love the delicate shadings of color, the sensitive rubato phrasing, the singing tone that brought to life the Andantino of Schumann's G minor Sonata, Op. 22.
BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, April 14 (Reuters) -- Fifteen Slovaks went on trial here today accused of murder, rape and theft.
The fact that Communist China has abruptly broken off the negotiation of trade agreements with certain private Japanese groups is not entirely a surprise.
PARIS, April 14 -- Far-reaching proposals for the coordination of arms industries in West Europe will be presented to the defense ministers of the North Atlantic alliance tomorrow by Britain.
Federal and state income tax officials were surprised yesterday when crowds of taxpayers did not appear.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on a challenge to the power of the House Committee on Un-American Activities to compell testimony.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -A Haitian Embassy aide shot and killed his superior officer today in resentment against his recall.
ALBANY, April 14 -- The Republican labor rackets bill, now on Governor Harriman's desk, got support today from an unexpected source, Walter P. Reuther.
SIENA, Italy, April 15 -- The ancient city of Siena, in the heart of prevalently pro-Communist Tuscany, is the Reddest place in all Italy.

Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov of the Soviet Union spread before American businessmen last night a panorama of new markets eager to absorb the output of United States factories now operating on a part-time basis.

MODEL rooms should be "dream" rooms that the consumer knows she cannot afford to duplicate in toto. At the same time, they should contain practical ideas that the consumer can modify at home with her eye on the budget.
A five-story building containing seventy-four apartments at 1192-96 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Robert H. Lindy. He was represented by Richard S. Hull, attorney.

A citation to a Look magazine reporting team for defying an "unconstitutional" ban on travel to Communist China was among the George Polk Memorial Awards presented yesterday by Long Island University.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -- For one fleeting moment it almost seemed like the continuation of the spring training expedition. This was a tour that had hop-scotched through minor league ball parks in San Antonio, Austin, Dallas, Phoenix, Mesa and Las Vegas. And now the caravan had paused again in Seals Stadium, another minor league ball park.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 10 to 20 points (50 cents to $1 a bale) yesterday.

The Four Freedoms Foundation announced yesterday that its annual award for distinguished service to the cause of freedom would be presented Monday night to Brig. Gen. Carlos P. Romulo. The occasion will be a dinner at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.
CHICAGO, April. 15 -- Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, bid farewell today to the city he has served nearly twenty years.
New corporate, utility and railroad securities amounting to more than $136,000,000 are being offered to the investment public today.

TOKYO, April 5 -- Under Secretary of Commerce Walter Williams flew back to the United States tonight after four weeks of advising Japanese business men how to increase their exports to America and reduce their trade deficit with the United States.
All museums carry fire insurance, as well as other coverage, on their works of art, but probably none can carry enough.
A rally of several thousand parents outside City Hall served as a backdrop yesterday for a Board of Estimate public hearing on the 1958-59 budget of the Board of Education.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -- Big league baseball made its debut on the Pacific Coast today to the tune of an 8-0 shut-out of the Los Angeles Dodgers by the San Francisco Giants.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -House Antitrust investigators charged today that the principal Justice Department negotiator of a consent decree with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had promoted the company's interests.
PATERSON, N. J., April 15 -- The New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad appealed today to its cummuters to support a bid for tax relief. The road is urging tax exemption for passenger facilities.
