The Ford Foundation announced yesterday a grant of $500,000 for a program of scholarly and cultural exchange with Poland and other East European countries.
New York University agreed yesterday to let most of its tenants at 71 Washington Square South remain until Dec. 31.

Led by Henry Korn, Archbishop Stepinac of White Plains won two events yesterday in the field section of the fifth annual Catholic High School Athletic Association relay carnival at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
Sales and earnings of Safeway Stores, Inc., for the first twelve weeks of this year exceeded those of a year earlier, the company announced yesterday.
LONDON, April 15 -- Industrial shares again advanced modestly on a wide front today on hopes of tax concessions in the new budget.
NEWARK, April 15 -- In winning the Republican nomination for United States Senator today, Representative Robert W. Kean moved ahead in the political footsteps of his kinsmen.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 15 -- Clark Gable will rejoin the Paramount producing team of William Perlberg and George Seaton this summer to star in "But Not for Me."

CHILDREN of nursery school age have a constant struggle to understand, sort out and put together in some kind of pattern the pieces of the complex puzzle that is the world around them. Listening carefully to their conversations with one another can be as revealing to parents as to educators, according to Dr. Kenneth D. Wann, Professor of Early Childhood Education at Teachers College, Columbia University.

An initial count of tax receipts at the Federal income tax offices at 484 Lexington Avenue on the final day for filing showed that the Government might be getting less money here than it received last year.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -- Interior Secretary Fred A. Seaton urged Congress today to extend the 27 1/2 per cent tax depletion allowance, now given on oil and natural gas, to oil shale, coal and other natural deposits when used to make synthetic liquid fuels.
HAVANA, April 15 -- Intensified action by the Government forces in Oriente Province and the loss of arms is weakening the Cuban insurgents, according to reliable sources.

The new British budget presented to Parliament yesterday is of more than usual interest to us in the United States this year. The reason, of course, is that the policymakers in London who prepared this budget had to take into account the Scylla and Charybdis which bedevil our own Congress now.
Investors were warned yesterday by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to beware of advertisements offering certificates in out-of-state savings-and-loan associations.
Following is the list of those killed and injured in the fire yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art:
ALBANY, April 15 -- Legislation realigning the voting strength of the New York City Board of Estimate was signed into law today by Governor Harriman.
HONG KONG, April 15 -In Communist China these days, colonels are doing duty as company commanders, sometimes even as privates.

MIAMI BEACH, April 15 -The nation's school boards were urged today not to spend so much time worrying about "housekeeping" chores that they neglect to provide educational leadership in their communities.
CINCINNATI, April 15 (UP) -- A possible key to the preventing of miscarriages was presented today at the annual meeting here of the Ohio State Medical Association.
Julie Haydon, widow of George Jean Nathan, said yesterday she hoped to become a nun.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 15 -Personal income of Long Island residents reached a peak in 1957, according to a report today by the Long Island Lighting Company.

A mood of "cautious planning" continues to pervade the operations of advertising agencies. Based on results to date, most executives are reconciled to the fact that profits will be well below those of previous peak years.

Tony Bettenhausen has been a dashing figure on the automobile race tracks of America for twenty years. He has been a national champion in "big car" (Indianapolis type) racing. He has been a terror, too, in midget competition, a man to watch in sprint cars, a man to beat in any contest where the speed is high and the course a challenge.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 15 -- A bipartisan movement to establish the Presidential candidacy of Alberto Lleras Camargo, chief of the Liberal Party, gathered force tonight.

The world chess championship match between Vassily Smyslov and Mikhail Botvinnik, challenger, was resumed in Moscow yesterday. The game, the sixteenth game in the series, was drawn after thirty-six moves.

LONDON, April 15 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Derick Heathcoat Amory gave Parliament today an unexciting budget containing no major changes in policy. He pointed to the United States recession as a reason for caution.

HARTFORD, April 15 -- The special session of the Connecticut General Assembly approved tonight an anti-recession measure extending unemployment compensation payments from twenty-six to thirty-nine weeks.
Blood wil lbe given today to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program at Gimbels department store in Herald Square and the Mutual Life Insurance Company, 1740 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission set out today to encourage more local and regional radio stations.
It is apparent that some readers have interpreted my disagreement with Rear Admiral Rickover's proposals to mean that I oppose special educational provisions for gifted students.

PARIS, April 16 -- The world has had a recent demonstration of the way alliances are understood on both sides of the Iron Curtain. Khrushchev, during his visit to Hungary, announced the principle that Russia reserves the right to intervene in the internal affairs of any of its Warsaw Pact allies.
If the public will not come to the subways, the Transit Authority has decided, the subways must go to the public -- by film.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -- A spokesman for the United States Conference of Mayors said today the nation's airports could become a jet-age "bottleneck" unless Federal aid to airport development was continued and speeded up.
ALBANY, April 15 (AP) -Democrats have taken the lead from Republicans in party enrollments in New York State, the Secretary of State's office reported today.

THE complex job of providing hand-raised muskellunge for the fishermen of New York State this year has begun on Lake Chautauqua. It can throw a little light on a fish to which little attention is paid in this part of the state, although it is a big deal in Western New York.
PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -Isolation of a substance showing promise as a basis for diagnostic tests for cancer was reported here today.
It is a pity that Javier Pereira didn't leave us his prescription for longevity. Javier Pereira will be remembered as the Colombian Indian who died recently at the reported age of 168.
The Composers Group of New York offered a program at Carnegie Recital Hall last night that was enlivened chiefly by the first performance of Alfred Pike's Sanctus, Benedictus and Credo.

Christopher T. Chenery's Surinam was not too highly regarded in the Cross Island Purse at Jamaica yesterday. The main reason was that the Wheatley Stable's entry of Misty Flight and Nasco was in the race, and so was the Greentree Stable's Turpitude.

First-quarter net income of the United States Rubber Company was estimated at $3,800,000, or about 44 cents a common share, H. E. Humphreys Jr., chairman, told stockholders here yesterday. This was less than half the net income of $8,200,000, or $1.20 a share, a year earlier.

The German battle fleet's escape through the English Channel in 1942 is the subject of a new book by Terence Robertson entitled "Channel Dash." In broad daylight on Feb. 12, 1942, Vice Admiral Ciliax led the battle cruisers Scharnhorst, Gneisenau and Prinz Eugen from their base at Brest through the English Channel and the Straits of Dover to the safety of German home waters.
ST. LOUIS, April 15 (AP) -- A major research program to increase world consumption of zinc and lead was announced today at the American Zinc Institute-Lead Industries Association annual meeting here.

Mayor Wagner, faces an opportunity and a responsibility in the reorganization of the New York City Housing Authority which will occur immediately upon the expected signing of a bill now before Governor Harriman. He will then have the power of appointment for three paid commissioners to replace a present five-member board, unpaid save for the chairman.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -Gen. Lauris Norstad, Supreme Commander of North Atlantic forces in Europe, has told Congress that charges that the alliance is about to fall apart are "highly inconsistent with the facts as I know them."

Efforts to settle a strike against the Columbia Broadcasting System continued in Washington yesterday. There was no indication whether any differences had been resolved in the contract dispute between the company and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -Joseph N. Pew Jr., chairman of the Sun Oil Company, reported at the annual meeting today that first-quarter earnings would "be not too much above" the 25-cent quarterly dividend. In the first quarter last year, Sun earned $1.24 a share.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -The Air Force Association today joined critics of President Eisenhower's defense reorganization plan on several key items.
Poetry in paint was consumed yesterday when Claude Monet's huge painting of water lilies perished in the fire at the Museum of Modern Art.
A leader in last December's subway strike charged yesterday from a Brooklyn hospital bed that he had been injured in a deliberate attempt on his life.
PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -Six Navy enlisted men "took off" today on a simulated sevenday round-trip to the moon.
A civil antitrust suit to prevent the merger of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company into the Bethlehem Steel Corporation opened yesterday in Federal Court here.
SPRING planting has begun with a bang at Bonwit Teller.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday instituted contempt proceedings in Manhattan Supreme Court against Selectivision, Inc., a Forest Hills pay television concern, and against the company's principal officers.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 15 -- More than 1,000,000 white South Africans are expected to vote tomorrow in a general election to choose the twelfth Parliament of the Union.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold attended a dinner tonight at which Secretary of State Dulles was present.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -A. symphonic composer joined a cowboy singing star at a Senate hearing today in defending Broadcast Music, Inc.
A 14-year-old pupil in Public School 701, one of the schools established for delinquent students, was arrested yesterday for possessing a zip gun.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message vetoing the water projects bill:
WESTBURY, L. I., April 15 -- Harold Dancer Jr., 22, gained a couple of triumphs last night. Tonight his father, 45, scored his first success of the season at Roosevelt Raceway.

Two teen-age gang members were found guilty last night of second-degree murder in the slaying of Michael Farmer, a 15-year-old polio victim. The General Sessions Court jury convicted two others of seconddegree manslaughter and acquitted three others.

MME. COLETTE HERBERT, whose quiche lorraine, mousse au chocolat and rich chocolate cake have been extolled here in the past has moved to handsome new quarters. The petite Frenchwoman's bakery is now at 1136 Third Avenue, between Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh Streets. The new shop is more spacious and more gaily decorated than the old one, which was about ten blocks south on Third Avenue.

"Wonderful" has an exhilarating effect on Larry Holofcener, a lyricist, whose last Broadway effort was "Mr. Wonderful," starring Sammy Davis Jr. Mr. Holofcener called yesterday to say that he had purchased the rights to the 1946 film, "It's A Wonderful Life," and was making plans to transfer it to the musical stage next season.

MILWAUKEE, April 15 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates, with rookies playing key roles, ruined the 1958 debut of the world champion Milwaukee Braves with a 4-3 decision in fourteen innings today. Pittsburgh achieved victory despite two home runs by Eddie Mathews.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -United States officials today considered the fall of the Gaillard Government little short of tragic. They feared the pains-taking efforts of the British-United States good-offices mission to patch up relations between France and Tunis would be undone.
The Coast Guard will begin an intensified method of collecting information on ship courses on July 1 to improve its far-flung search and rescue operations.
Six discharged Customs inspectors and two importers were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on smuggling charges.

WARSAW, April 15 -- The ruling Communist party got its expected endorsement today for a proposal to subordinate workers' councils to new organizations that will assure stricter party control in Polish factories.
Harrison A. Williams Jr. and Representative Robert W. Kean won the Democratic and Republican nominations for United States Senator in yesterday's New Jersey primary election.

CINCINNATI, April 15 (AP) -- Chuck Essegian and Roman Semproch, both rookies, sparked the Philadelphia Phils to a 5-4 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs today. Manager Birdie Tebbetts of Cincinnati finished the game under protest, then withdrew the protest and finally filed it again.
A 16-year-old youth was critically wounded early yesterday after he and a rival gang member squared off with guns on a Bronx rooftop.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 5 -- The Brussels World Fair of 1958 offered a preview of itself today to 1,500 to 2,000 representatives of the press, radio and television.

Typographical Union Six -- "Big Six" -- founded 106 years ago and pioneer in providing pensions and other social benefits for its members, has joined the growing number of American unions which are going into housing in a big way. The union has formed a cooperative organization to put up eight buildings of varying heights on a 12-acre site fronting on Queens Boulevard from Fifty-ninth to Sixty-first Street.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -Secretary of State Dulles said today the United States was prepared, for the first time, to consult with other nations of the Western Hemisphere about problems raised by declining prices and demand for their export commodities.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 15 -- Patrons for the benefit film Program on Thursday marking the fortieth anniversary of the Alliance Francaise of Greenwich have been announced by Mrs. Walter E. Puschel and Mrs. Walter C: Humstone, co-chairmen of the benefit.

More and more United States oil companies are going in for international activities. The Gulf Oil Corporation issued yesterday a study by Leonard M. Fanning, which reports that about 190 American companies are active in oil exploration and production in ninety-one foreign countries.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The acquisition of original manuscripts and letters of all the makers of the Constitution was announced today by the Daughters of the American Revolution.
LIMA, Peru, April 15 -Strikes and riots last week in the old Inca city of Cuzco have focused attention on the danger of Communist infiltration.
CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 15 -- The question of how strongly members of the Screen Actors Guild feel about the role they are to play in magnetically taped television was answered today. The Guild disclosed that its new contract with producers of television commercials had been ratified by a vote of 5,398 to 80.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -- The board of monitors appointed to watch over affairs of the teamsters union has ordered the union's international officers to report on their outside financial interests.
TUNIS, Wednesday, April 16 -- Tunisian political observers received the news of the French Cabinet crisis early this morning with mixed regret and satisfaction.
DETROIT, April 15 -- L. L. Colbert, president of the Chrysler Corporation, told stockholders today that the first-quarter report would show a loss.

THE Italian Consulate, through Baron Carlo de Ferrariis Salzano, Consul General of Italy in New York, is distributing a handsome booklet on "Giovanni da Verrazano, the Discoverer of New York Bay." The booklet is going to public officials, schools and libraries.
PARIS, April 15 -- Paris' Palais Bourbon, where Premier Felix Gaillard was politically guillotined by the National Assembly tonight, is known as "la maison sans fenetres" (the house without windows).

Botany Mills, Inc., had sales of $21,121,000 in the first quarter this year, compared with $15,344,000 in the corresponding period of 1957, A. M. Sonnabend, chairman and president, reported to stockholders yesterday. He spoke at the annual meeting in the Roosevelt Hotel.
Some truckmen refused to send their vehicles to the piers yesterday in a protest against new, higher charges for loading and unloading instituted by marine terminal operators here.

TOKYO, April 15 -- Full normal diplomatic relations between Japan and Indonesia were restored today when Japanese Foreign Minister Aiichiro Fujiyama and Indonesian Foreign Minister Subandrio exchanged instruments of ratification for the Japan-Indonesia peace treaty and reparations agreement.
ALBANY, April 15 -- A bill that will prohibit employers from discriminating against persons 45 to 65 years old because of their age was approved today by Governor Harriman. It takes effect July 1.

BOSTON, April 15 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins scored once in each period tonight to defeat the Montreal Canadiens, 3 -- 1, and squared their National Hockey League Stanley Cup final series at two games apiece.

"The Comedian," an original television play by Rod Serling, won an Emmy last night as the best single program of 1957. Mr. Serling received a separate award for his script about an egotistical TV performer.
ALBANY, April 15 (AP) -- Bad news for fumble-fingered fathers: The toy bill is dead.
Will Tony Kubek be wearing Army khaki or Yankee flannels this baseball season? That was the $64,000 question yesterday.
MOSCOW, April 15 -- This city just would not let go of Van Cliburn's coattails today.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer said today the world "must go far beyond disarmament" and create a "community of understanding" to achieve peace.
Like the warring clans of Capulet and Montague, the partisans of the departed Brooklyn Dodgers and New York Giants were finally united yesterday, in mourning.

CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- Corn futures prices absorbed moderate but steady profit-taking and pushed ahead today on the Board of Trade, continuing a consistent advance which began more than two weeks ago.

The general elections in South Africa today will be watched around the world with interest but with little hope of a change. All the prophets are foretelling another victory for the Afrikaner Nationalist party, which upholds a rather extreme doctrine of apartheid, or separation of the black and Colored (mixed blood) races from the ruling whites.

ROME, April 15 -- Pope Pius XII wants monks and nuns not only to pray but also to work actively in education and nursing missions or in the pastoral field. The Pontiff has again urged members of the Church's religious orders to "adapt themselves to the needs of our era."

The fire and damage at the Museum of Modern Art are highly unusual occurrences in the art world. The protection of pictures is a primary concern of museums, and except for war and unforeseen events, such as rioting, the safety of works in museums is unquestioned.
ACCRA, Ghana, April 15 -Liberation of colonial Africa was the keynote of the first conference of independent African states, which opened here today.
A proposal was laid before the City Council yesterday that it delegate to a special committee the power to investigate that it has when acting as a whole.
PANAMA, April 15 (AP) -Charging discrimination, Panama asked the United States today to free a Panamanian Negro who had served twelve years of a fifty-year sentence for rape.
First-quarter sales of the Union Carbide Corporation represented only about two-thirds of the company's productive capacity, Morse G. Dial, president, reported yesterday.

President Eisenhower has again shown the courage of his convictions and a high sense of public interest by vetoing for the second time in two years a rivers-and-harbors bill containing more than its quota of succulent tidbits scooped straight out of the pork barrel.
New York University yesterday withdrew its proposal for a pedestrian bridge across West Broadway. The bridge would have connected two of the buildings the university will erect at Washington Square.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 15I -- A method for producing blood plasma without the risk of transmitting the jaundice virus was reported tonight.

While ambassadors of the Big Four powers prepare to meet in Moscow to explore the possibilities of a summit meeting, with special emphasis on disarmament, the defense ministers and service chiefs of fourteen North Atlantic alliance nations meet in Paris to discuss ways and means of strengthening Western defenses.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -Secretary of State Dulles accused the Soviet Union today of endangering peace by prostituting diplomacy for purposes of propaganda.
A balky witness testified before the grand jury in the boxing inquiry yesterday but only after he had been threatened with a contempt citation.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -Party lines were sharply drawn today as the Senate began voting on details of a $1,000,000,000 Democratic program of Federal loans for community public works.
FORT PIERCE, Fla., April 15 (AP) -- Four tornadoes lashed Florida today, flattening homes, felling power lines and injuring more than sixty persons. No deaths were reported.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -Dr. Wernher von Braun disclosed today that the Army proposed to shoot a man 150 miles into space in the nose of a rocket and to return him safely to earth. The trip would take ten minutes.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -Senator John L. McClellan proposed today a law with farreaching controls for labor unions.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -In the age of the common man Dean Gooderham Acheson ornaments contemporary Washington as the extraordinarily uncommon man fighting a rearguard action against the fatuous and the ordinary.

The first Italian to enter New York Bay -- and so far as the historic records show the first European to do it -- found the inhabitants to be "agreeable, friendly and pleasant." That was on April 16 or 17, 1524, and the man was Giovanni da Verrazano, the Florentine explorer in the service of King Francis I of France.
It's spring and proxy fights are busting out all over in the railroad industry.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 15 -- Following are excerpts from the address today by Dean Acheson, former Secretary of State, on "factors underlying negotiations with the Russians."
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 15 -- Michael A. Staats, one of four Democratic candidates in a primary race in nearby Madison Township, was arrested today for electioneering too close to the polls.
Several "road-blocks" will have to be removed before sizable amounts of pension and welfare fund money can be channeled into the mortgage market, a group of bankers heard yesterday.
PARIS, Wednesday, April 16 -- A political crisis erupted in France early today when the National Assembly refused to support the Government's decision to resume direct talks with Tunisia.
The recession has struck the largest electrical manufacturer in the world.
Protestant leaders denounced last night the resale arrangements in Lincoln Square by which Fordham University has acquired two blocks for a new campus.
Ed Sullivan and other television producers are seeking an agreement to present the Moiseyev Dance Company of Moscow on television here.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -Legislation authorizing $1,704,028,300 for development of rivers and harbors and flood control projects was vetoed by President Eisenhower today.

A team of safe-crackers and lock pickers pulled several successful jobs yesterday, but all they got was applause. The applause came from 200 police officers. No arrests were made because the whole thing was in the interest of crime prevention and detection.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -After forty years in international law and diplomacy, Secretary of State Dulles has apparently decided that the "old diplomacy" is better than the "new diplomacy" after all.

GENEVA, April 15 -- The United States abandoned today the principle of a three-mile territorial sea in the face of mounting opposition and an impending deadlock at the United Nations conference on the law of the sea.

The Sperry Rand Corporation has announced the election of Kenneth R. Herman as president of the Remington Rand division, producer of business machines and equipment. He succeeds James H. Rand who has announced his retirement from active duty. Mr. Rand, a founder of Remington Rand, will continue as vice chairman and director of Sperry Rand, formed in 1955 through a merger of the Sperry Corporation and Remington Rand. Inc.
SINGAPORE, April 15 (UP) -Five Indonesian Government warships steamed away from the rebel stronghold at Padang on the west coast of Sumatra today.
A quarter of a century ago a rabbi, a Roman Catholic priest and a Protestant minister teamed up to spread the gospel of brotherly love.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 15 -- Dean Acheson expressed the hope tonight that the United States "would disentangle itself" from an East-West heads-ofgovernment conference.
WILKES-BARRE, Pa., April 15 -- David Dubinsky brought his special brand of perpetual motion unionism into this part of Pennsylvania today, and it may be weeks before the countryside settles down.

LIBSON, Portugal, Apirl 15 (Reuters) -- A group of sixtytwo politicans announced today that they would nominate Gen. Humberto Delgado, Director General of Civil Aviation, as an "independent candidate" in Portugal's Presidential election June 8.

Scientists on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean breathed a deep sigh of relief yesterday. A space-age clock, so delicate that a messenger had to carry it on his lap from London, was delivered safely to Army specialists at Fort Monmouth, N. J.

The private capital market of the United States is providing $15,000,000 to build houses for natives in the Belgian Congo. The money was raised in a bond issue sold here yesterday. It was the first time that an African colony had borrowed money in this market.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- George Meany, American Federation of Labor-Committee of Industrial Organizations president, said today the ranks of the unemployed would grow by many more millions unless Congress quickly passed meaningful anti-recession measures.
In their current enthusiasm for multi-directional sound, makers of stereophonic records are just catching up to Gioseffe Zarlino (1517-90), choirmaster of St. Mark's in Venice.
Oil and water can mix to provide two-way employment for a tanker, it was demonstrated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (UP) -- Former President Truman's disputed statements on unemployment in 1950 started a verbal free-for-all on the House floor today.
It is increasingly difficult to digest such protestations of outraged humanity as the ponderous and illsuited plea in The Times of April 11 of the National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy.

FEW worries can be more disturbing to peace of mind, according to Sloan Wilson in his new novel, "A Summer Place,"* than the worry parents experience when they suspect that their adolescent children are behaving no better than they did at the same age. What an appalling thought! Remembering the troubles they've seen, particularly those caused by adolescent sexuality with or without love, they would like to impart some of their dearly won wisdom.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today a bill that would let former President Harry S. Truman and about 500 other former Government and military officials accept decorations and awards from foreign Governments.
Short-run prospects for industrial expansion are not so good as for construction generally, a building economist declared yesterday.

The Rev. George B. Ford was honored and widely acclaimed as a scholar, a great liberal and humanitarian by persons of prominence on the occasion of his retirement as rector of Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church. These honors were richly deserved.

RABAT, Morocco, April 15 -For the first time in Morocco's two years of independence the opponents of the dominant Istiqlal (Independence) party have formed a coalition whose aim is to bring about radical changes in the governing line-up.
The Museum of Modern Art was damaged by a three-alarm fire yesterday. One workman was killed and three women visitors and twenty-eight firemen were injured.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -The Senate Disarmament Subcommittee released today secret testimony that held 4,000 technicians would be needed to police this country and probably a much larger number to police the Soviet Union if atomic tests and production should be halted by agreement.
CLEVELAND, April 15 (UP) -- Ned Garver of the Kansas City Athletics spoiled Herb Score's comeback today by shutting out the Cleveland Indians, 5 -- 0, on seven hits before 35,307 fans.

Archie Oldham, all 6 feet 7 inches of him, yesterday became Columbia University's head basketball coach. His appointment was disclosed by Ralph Furey, the director of athletics, at a campus news conference.
THE fall line of De Busschere shoes is now on view at Belgian Shoes, Inc., 60 East Fifty-sixth Street.

About twenty-five members of the Walk for Peace Committee picketed the United States, British and Soviet delegations to the United Nations yesterday as part of a campaign to end the testing of nuclear weapons.

Oils and steels took command yesterday afternoon and swept the stock market to its best gains in a month. The day's advances were nearly doubled in the final hour of trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., April 15 -- The Director of Civil Defense here accidentally fired a revolver today in his office and the bullet gravely injured a visitor in the adjacent office.
A four-alarm fire broke out in a loft building at 75-77 Duane Street early this morning. The fire was in the same general area of lower Manhattan where two serious loft fires occurred recently.
LONDON, April 15 -- Britain regards the coming ambassadorial talks in Moscow as a test of whether a summit conference should be held.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -The United States Court of Appeals reversed today the conviction of Frank W. Brewster, former chairman of the Western Conference of Teamsters, for contempt of Congress.
TUNIS, April 15 -- Soccer got into French-Algerian politics today with a trans-Mediterranean kick.

PARIS, April 15 -- The validity of the defense concepts of the Atlantic alliance on the threshold of the missile age was the subject of searching questioning today by the Defense Ministers of the member States.

A 12-year-old French girl has just learned that she has 1,350 foster fathers. She never has seen them, because they are inmates of a United States Federal penitentiary more than 6,000 miles from her home in Le Faou, Finistere.
Harrison Arlington Williams Jr. has risen from political obscurity to a Senatorial nomination in less than five years.

The near-by potato positions fell yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The spot April contract was off the 1/2-cent-a-pound daily limit and the May position opened down 30 points (hundredths of a cent a pound), the daily limit for all months other than the spot contract.
BOSTON, April 15 -- The Red Sox began their home season today under a cloudless sky and before a gathering of 35,223, the largest opening-day crowd in the history of Fenway Park.

MUCH of the remarkable collection of nineteenth-century and twentieth-century School of Paris paintings assembled by Miss Adelaide Milton de Groot will be familiar to visitors to the Metropolitan Museum, where the pictures are often on view.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -- Big league baseball spanned the continent today. The eightytwo-year-old National League finally became a national league in fact.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15 -- Studies suggesting that the addition of calcium to farm lands might reduce the amount of radioactive strontium 90 in foods were reported here today. nuclear explosions, is widely distributed by fall-out.

BALTIMORE, April 15 (UP) -- Billy O'Dell pitched four and a third innings of hitless ball in relief and Gus Triandos belted a two-run homer to help the Baltimore Orioles win their season opener from the Washington Senators, 6 -- 1, today.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to reconsider a recent decision that the Department said might allow the states to collect $1,000,000,000 in retroactive taxes on Federal property.
O. H. Stark was elected president of the Point-ofPurchase Advertising Institute yesterday. He is vice president and sales manager of Snyder Black.
The forty-first season of Lewisohn Stadium concerts will open Monday, June 23, with Leonard Bernstein conducting the Stadium Symphony Orchestra.

In October, 1859, John Brown's attempt to seize a Federal arsenal and start a Negro uprising ended in failure and in his execution. The deed served to inflame and divide the country, "already on the brink of civil war." In "Thunder at Harper's Ferry," Allan Keller gives an hour-by-hour account of this "significant prelude" to the war.
Van Cliburn, 23-year-old Texas pianist who won the International Tchaikovsky Contest in Moscow, will repeat his prize-winning program in New York, Philadelphia and Washington.

CAIRO, April 16 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser was reported today to have made an important compromise offer toward a settlement of the issue of compensation to shareholders of the old Universal Suez Canal Company.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Auto Workers, said today peace would never be secure "as long as half the world is well fed and the other half is hungry."
THE perfect way to startle the world's most blase city is to walk through it wearing a sky-blue wig.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 -- The Giants and the Dodgers, formerly of a certain Eastern metropolis, drew another enthusiastic assemblage tonight for the first big-league night game in this or any other Far Western metropolis.
Sales of Manhattan real estate on the open market continued a downward trend in 1957, according to a compilation released yesterday by the Real Estate Board of New York.

Gov. Robert. B. Meyner's control over the Democratic party in New Jersey is more secure than ever and his prestige is higher as a result of Tuesday's primary election, political observers said yesterday.

The gold medal of the Order Satrei Wathana has been presented to Dr. Helen Brell by the King of Cambodia. The announcement yesterday said the award to the Brooklyn College professor was for her "contribution to Cambodian education and her understanding of the Cambodian people."
MOSCOW, April 16 -- A young pianist from Texas has done more to promote good relations with the Soviet people than any American for a long time.
NEW JERSEY'S first close examination of its own resources was far from a one-man job.
A list of the Fire Department officers who received the ten highest scores in a written examination for departmental chief last May was announced yesterday by the Municipal Civil Service Commission.
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, the nation's largest brokerage house, had record revenues in the year ended Feb. 28. They came to $84,462,000, or 1 per cent above the $83,497,000 of fiscal 1957.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 -- University of California chemists verified last Sunday that they had had the first glimpse of a specimen of the element berkelium. The element does not exist naturally on earth but may occur in stars.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Dissident delegates staged a fair-sized revolt today against the resolutions committee of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 16--This old city has had its face lifted for the 1958 World Fair, which opens tomorrow. The surgery--the widening of streets and the building of roads, tunnels and overpasses--is part of a long-range multi-million-dollar road and communciations improvement program rushed ahead for the opening of the fair.
There will be a seating problem at the New York Athletic Club gymnasium tonight when the Russians meet a United States team in an amateur wrestling match.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Administration feared tonight that it might be impossible to stave off much longer a United Nations debate on the French-Tunisian dispute.

Net earnings of the Crucible Steel Company of America dropped 95 per cent in the first quarter, to $172,395, or 5 cents a common share, from $3,372,606, or 93 cents a share, for the similar 1957 quarter.
Industrial safety programs were credited yesterday with saving 500,000 lives and preventing 50,000,000 injuries in the last quarter century.

WARREN, Ohio, April 16 (AP) -- A state District Court of Appeals unanimously upheld today a ruling that jobless Ohio workers could collect supplemental unemployment benefits without a corresponding reduction in their state unemployment benefits.
HURON, S. D., April 16 (AP) -- Chief Judge Archibald K. Gardner of the United States Court of Appeals said today he would appoint a new judge to hear the integration case at Little Rock, Ark.
The New Lincoln School reported yesterday that it was "delighted" at the way Minnijean Brown, a former student at Little Rock, Ark., Central High School had progressed here.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, April 17 -- The Indonesian Navy announced today that the invasion of Sumatra's West Coast to crush the rebellion against President Sukarno's Government began at dawn.

He likes to get around and see what's happening in the Far East and the Middle East. Although he will never be known as a great storyteller, he has a notable gift for making a coherent narrative out of boilingly complex international affairs.

If the Soviets are honest about wanting a summit meeting to promote peace, serious preparations for it should get under way in Moscow today. The Soviets have acknowledged the need for preparatory work and have agreed to the Western proposal to start this work at a meeting of ambassadors to be followed by a meeting of foreign ministers which would map out the program for the summit meeting.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 16 -- The Algerian National Liberation Front, which is conducting a guerrilla war against French authority, was accorded nonvoting status today at the conference of eight independent African states.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The House Antitrust subcommittee questioned Defense Department officials today on how the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had obtained copies of department memoranda and correspondence.
DARIEN, Conn., April 16 -- John Potter Wheat, an illustrator and art teacher, was shot three times early this morning by his wife Barbara, the police said.
WASHINGTON, April 16--The Senate approved tonight a $1,000,000,000 anti-recession program of Federal loans for construction of local public works.

Participation in the $2,500,000 Fulfillment Program for Colby College in Waterville, Me., got under way last night for the New York City group at a dinner meeting in the New York University Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.

EZIO MARTINELLI is a conservative in the best sense of the word. That is, he has conserved a tradition that sponsors extravagant fantasy and allegory in draftsmanship. It is a tradition that has generous boundaries, having included early Renaissance heraldry, Leonardo, Archimboldo, Blake and countless others, and still finds room for a twentieth-century adherent.

Counsel for Col. Rudolf I. Abel, convicted Soviet spy, argued yesterday in the United States Court of Appeals that his conviction should be reversed because the Government had prosecuted him with unconstitutional evidence after assertedly failing to convince him to defect to the West.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 16 -- Trade Minister John McEwen accused the United States today of "lecturing the whole world on the advantages of free trade, but allotting Australia an import quota of only nine tons of butter yearly."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16 -- A United Nations committee recommended today that the world organization's proposed Special Fund for the Development of Backward Countries should specialize in surveys of large project, susceptible of major capital investment.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Colombia proposed today that the foreign ministers of the Latin American countries and the United States meet to coordinate policies at the United Nations.

Six teen-agers -- four boys and two girls -- were arrested last night for the beating of two persons whom they had reportedly met by chance at York Avenue near Sixty-ninth Street. One of the victims, a doctor, had his jaw broken.
DAVID SUSSKIND took over the executive production reins of the "Kraft Television Theatre" last night and there was a notable turn for the better.

It was "Searching on the inside" in the $22,750 Correction Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. The 6-year-old daughter of War Admiral competing in the silks of Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs took the nineteenth running of the six-furlong burst by a length and a half over Joe W. Brown's Fanciful Miss.
The United States may have to consider whether to give Government support to exporters facing likely Soviet "prestige" price - cutting abroad, Henry Cabot Lodge suggested last night.

Dr. Marie K. Gallagher, a retired associate dean of Hunter College, was killed yesterday when she fell from the seventh floor of the Wickersham Building at 133 East Fifty-eighth Street. She was 64 years old.

Loew's, Inc., yesterday reported a net profit of $1,800,000, equal to 34 cents each on 5,336,019 shares, for its second quarter. The period of sixteen weeks ended March 13. The figures cover the comany's theatre and other subsidiaries.
PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- It might be unwise for people exposed to atom bomb radiation to attempt to walk out of the contaminated region afterward, a scientist said here today.

Two five-story buildings containing twenty-five apartments at 300 Manhattan Avenue and 328 West 113th Street were sold by the Manilla Corporation. The structures, on a plot of 70 by 100 feet, are assessed at $70,000. They were bought by a client of Stanford Lotwin, attorney. Rubin and Abe Solove were the brokers.
A luncheon and fashion show will be given in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza next Tuesday for the benefit of Lots for Little, Inc., a thrift shop that aids seven charities.
HONG KONG, April 16 -- A bitter attack on the United States marked the opening today of the new session of the National Assembly of Communist North Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's statement today after he signed the highway bill:

When a matter of public policy is involved the problems of an industry become a matter of general concern. As yet, for example, the steel industry that has been operating at a steadily decreasing rate for the past several months, and is currently functioning at something less than 50 per cent of capacity, calls forth no alarm.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., April 16 -- Mrs. Audrey Granger, a 30- year-old mother of six children, has been much in demand as a blood donor because of her rare type of blood. But yesterday she became a recipient, too -- and of her own blood.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Charles I. Schottland, United States Commissioner of Social Security, declared here today that 21,000,000 Americans this year would receive more than $22,000,000,000 in benefits from social security, public assistance and related programs.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:
OTTAWA, April 16 (Canadian Press) -- Canada had a net capital inflow of $2,400,000 in February in international trade of securities, the Bureau of Statistics said today.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Thursday, April 17 -- Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom has led his Nationalist party to its third straight victory at the polls, returns from yesterday's general election indicated early today.

RABAT, Morocco, April 16 -- The Government of Premier M'barek Bekkai was dissolved today by King Mohamed V. The action followed the collective resignation of ministers representing the country's leading political force, the Istiqlal (Independence) party.
The Capital Funding Corporation, a Brooklyn real estate concern, was permanently barred by a court order yesterday from dealing in securities in this state.
In signing the bill, Governor Harriman has made millions of parents and teen-age youngsters honest people for the first time in years.
Mayor Wagner's 1958-59 executive budget of $1,996,952,986 was assailed yesterday as a product of a "crazy quilt" fiscal policy based on expediency instead of prudent fiscal planning.

WASHINGTON, April 16--President Eisenhower tartly brushed aside today a Representative's suggestion that he cut down on his golf and visit more small cities to see for himself the need for an anti-recession program of public works.

The tenth annual Presentation Cotillion of Fairleigh Dickinson University will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza tomorrow evening. Twenty-four young women will make their debuts at the event. They will be presented by Ray A. Miller, vice president of the university.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 16 (Reuters) -- Two Boeing Aircraft Company officials urged Argentina today to buy their planes rather than British Comet IV airliners.
LONDON, April 16 -- The Labor party severely criticized the Conservative Government's economic policies today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 -- Whoever acted as stage manager for the newest Western drama did a job that bordered on perfection. There wasn't a flaw in the way the plot unravelled and the denouement left the audience gurgling in delight. Major league baseball finally came to this city of infinite charm, character and graciousness yesterday.
Myles J. Lane, a Democrat, and Jacob J. Grumet, a Republican, were reported yesterday to be in line for appointment to the new State Crime Commission.
WHEN an importer of Scandinavian furniture begins looking to High Point, N. C., for Danish modern designs, New York and Copenhagen can sit up and take notice.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Three months ago illness had so weakened Frank Richardson Kent of Baltimore that he could no longer summon the energy to continue the newspaper articles which in recent years were chiefly editorial vivisections of what he adjudged to be the shams of politicians.

I write you out of a sense of concern as a long-time citizen of New York. Our city is so vast and our community interests so complicated that many decisions are taken without any considerable number of our thoughtful people being adequately aware of propositions that concern all of us.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Despite generally declining earnings, United States corporations paid more in cash dividends in the first quarter of 1958 than in the corresponding 1957 period.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 16 -- The two largest non-Roman Catholic church organizations in the world will merge in 1961.

A recent study made by the Indiana Experiment Station showed that four of every ten persons shopping for food had definite menu plans, one of ten had "vague ideas" for menus and five of ten had no plans at all. Many of those surveyed reported that they decided what to serve just before meal time.

Response to a televised interview last year with Nikita S. Khrushchev indicates that American television does not have the same freedom to gather news as our press does, according to a report issued here yesterday.
MOSCOW, April 16 -- Observers here were doubtful tonight that the diplomatic talks to which the West had agreed would get under way tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- Spokesmen for recession-hit Detroit proposed today that the Government give needy families food stamps that could be exchanged for groceries at retail stores.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A family's emotional, physical and intellectual preparation for a nuclear war may save the lives of its members -- and their sanity -- in the event of such a disaster.
Evander Childs High School gave its annual Pan American Award yesterday to The New York Times for "full, authoritative and fair coverage" of Latin-American affairs.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 16 -- Colombia's political crisis was resolved last night by the confirmation of Alberto Lleras Camargo as bipartisan candidate for the Presidential election May 4.
So far as the Yankee management is concerned, the possibility of military service for Tony Kubek remained undecided yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- Following is the text of the notes to the Soviet Union sent jointly by the United States, Britain and France on preparation for a summit conference:

Election of George Champion, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, as president of the Association of Reserve City Bankers was announced yesterday at Bal Harbour, Fla. The association has been holding its annual convention there. Mr. Champion succeeds Henry T. Bodman, general vice president of the National Bank of Detroit.
Dr. John Hastings, once hailed by students as the "most popular, brilliant and humorous" instructor at City College, will be $4,900 richer as a result of a bill signed by Governor Harriman yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16 -- The Managing Director of the United Nations International Monetary Fund said today that the United States recession could be contained by economic measures.
A special report by the Rockefeller Brothers Fund will recommend a generous, broadly based tax cut.

Announcement was made yesterday by John V. Lindsay, a 36-year-old former president of the New York Young Republican Club, of his candidacy for the Republican Congressional nomination in the Seventeenth District.
The trial of seven youths charged with killing Michael Farmer was declared a farce yesterday by the slain boy's mother.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16 -- Hollywood's star system, its origins, growth and contemporary status, will undergo the scrutiny of the television cameras on "Wide Wide World" on April 27.
CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- All grain futures declined on the Board of Trade today.
The management of the Bullard Company, machine tool maker, yesterday defeated an attempt of an insurgent stockholders' group to gain control.

THERE isn't much doubt that fly fishing, in this region at least, is on a strong uptrend as compared with spinning. Addicted fly fishermen think this is good, since they are like archers: they think everybody ought to use their weapon. Spin fishermen don't seem to care one way or another.
A 90-year-old retired minister and missionary who became a Wall Street runner at 80 won a $21,137 award yesterday for injuries suffered in 1949 when he was struck by an Army jeep.
ST. LOUIS, April 16 (AP) -- The Air Force tonight became the first service to announce full support for President Eisenhower's defense reorganization plan.
MOSCOW, April 16 -- Soviet youth was informed today that many of its members had been poorly reared for the age of communism and that something would be done about it.

The New York Women's Council of the Save the Children Federation, Inc., will hold its eighth annual benefit card party tomorrow in the ballroom of the Pierre. There will be a little bazaar at the event, of which Mrs. C. Herbert Rauch and Mrs. Herbert F. Taylor are co-chairmen.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities said today that it was recommending contempt citations of six witnesses who refused to answer questions at hearings this year in Gary, Ind., and Boston.

TORONTO, April 16 (Canadian Press) -- Peter Crosby, New York stock promoter, freed briefly today after an indictment of fraud, theft and false pretenses against him had been quashed, was rearrested shortly afterward on theft charges.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Senator Ralph W. Yarborough introduced a resolution today calling for the resignation of Ezra Taft eBnson, Secretary of Agriculture.
Prof. Floyd B. Zulli Jr. and his early morning program on WCBS-TV, "Sunrise Semester," were the big winners in the Emmy competition for local programs.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Senate rackets committee closely questioned today a lawyer from Philadelphia for a possible conflict of interests.

DETROIT, April 16 (AP) -- Declaring that "Republicans in Michigan don't want intelligent Negroes in their political organization,'' George A. Isabell resigned today as secretary of the Wayne (Detroit) County Republican Committee. He is a Negro.

In June, 1954, when Alfred E. Perlman became president of the New York Central Railroad following a bitter proxy contest, he canceled a plan of the former management to spend $10,000,000 putting the Central in the business of hauling highway trailers on flat cars.

Leonard Bernstein, musical director of the New York Philharmonic, will lead the orchestra in two major Handel works during the 1958-59 season, as part of a festival commemorating the composer's death.
RUSSIAN and American women have some vexations in common. Their husbands are anti-chemise, their fiances want them to give up a career and their clothing budgets are too small.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 8 points down yesterday, except new October, which rose 13 points.
The Mississippi Power and Light Company borrowed $15,000,000 in the public market yesterday on an issue of first mortgage bonds due in 1988.
Net earnings of the Douglas Aircraft Company dipped in the first quarter ended Feb. 28 to $8,596,000 from $8,773,000 in the similar period last year, despite a $40,831,000 increase in sales.
NEW DELHI, India, April 16 -- V. K. Krishna Menon, the Defense Minister, went before Parliament today to support India's biggest military budget.

When disaster strikes, as it did in the plane crash near Tri-City Airport in Michigan, the large number of victims increases the horror but tends to make the tragedy anonymous. And yet everyone killed in the accident left behind people cruelly bereaved, as well as a task that was waiting to be continued and a life not lived out to its fulfillment.
A spectacular water-and-sand show is available free each day between Beach Ninth and Beach Fifty-second Streets in the Rockaways.
Samuel Cardinal Stritch said yesterday that mission work had helped produce the efforts for equality and betterment among Asians and Africans.
LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- Steps were taken today to put a limit on the tournament appearances and expense allowances of the world's touring amateur tennis players.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16 -- Samuel J. Briskin will rejoin Columbia Pictures Monday as chief of studio operations in Hollywood. He will have a new title -- vice president in charge of West Coast activities.
The memorable correspondence between George Bernard Shaw and Mrs. Patrick Campbell will emerge on Broadway next fall as a two-character comedy called "Dear Liar."

Safety programs that are merely posters, bulletins and prizes were scored yesterday by a shipping official as a "luxury" that ship lines can no longer afford.
St. Francis Prep captured four events yesterday in the eighth annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association relay carnival at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island. There was no team title at stake.
Silky Sullivan, the horse, received two first-place votes, but Sugar Robinson yesterday won the March award in the monthly S. Rae Hickok professional athlete-of-the-year poll.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Benjamin M. McKelway, president of The Associated Press and Editor of The Washington Star, was elected today to lifetime "distinguished service membership" in the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The House of Representatives passed by a voice vote today a bill to stop the Government from withholding information under a vague law enacted in 1789. The bill was sent to the Senate.
FREEPORT, L. I., April 16 -- Long Island's economy will be helped by about $4,000,000 in wages from grade-crossing elimination projects that are now starting.
Eugene Haynes, Juilliard-trained pianist who made his debut here in 1954, returned to Carnegie Hall for his second recital last night.

BOSTON, April 16 -- It developed today that when Casey Stengel remarked during spring training that the Red Sox could give his Yankees a deal of trouble this year, the Ol' Perfessor wasn't merely talking for sound effects.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Governor of Tennessee, who defended country music last month through a telegram to a Senate subcommittee, appeared in person today to hail hillbilly tunes as "the heartbeat of America."

The Washington Square Park Committee said yesterday that Manhattan Borough President Hulan Jack's assurance that there would be no further widening of the roadway in the park was no guarantee that Fifth Avenue would not become a major traffic artery.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 16 -- A bone-peggiing operation to heal troublesome wrist injuries was reported on today by its co-discoverer.

RYE, N. Y., April 16 -- Manhattanville College of the Sacred Heart in Purchase will receive the proceeds of the scholarship benefit cocktail party to be held on Sunday at the home here of Dr. and Mrs. Basil Harris on Dogwood Lane.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- About 100 men of the Western World gathered at a dinner today to celebrate the anniversary of a human institution that works.
Stocks fell steadily yesterday, with the major declines in the first and fourth hours, as business news generally remained unpromising.
The Museum of Modern Art, which had a spectacular fire on Tuesday, was charged yesterday with having illegally created conditions "that could have contributed to a major fire."
The American Hull Insurance Syndicate announced yesterday that it had increased its capacity to insure any single vessel to a maximum of $10,000,000.
Sales of the P. Lorillard Company in the first three months of this year were the highest for any quarter in the 198-year history of the tobacco company, Lewis Gruber, president, disclosed yesterday.
The president of the Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday that he had been advised that wages were the only remaining issue in a contract dispute with a technicians' union.

HOUSTON, April 16 (AP) -- Top-seeded Dick Savitt had to make a strong rally in the third set today to defeat Don Candy, Australia's eight-ranked player, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 9 -- 7, in the second round of the twenty-fourth annual River Oaks tennis tournament.

NEWARK, N. J., April 16 -- Joseph Grillo and Silvio De Vita were convicted here of first-degree murder in Superior Court tonight after their second trial for a slaying in a 1951 hold-up. Both were sentenced to life imprisonment and will be taken tomorrow to the State Prison in Trenton.

HAVANA, April 16 -- The days of Fidel Castro, rebel leader who has been fighting the troops of President Fulgencio Batista in Oriente Province since Dec. 2, 1956, are numbered, according to informed sources.
LONDON, April 16 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer met today for a discussion of the relations between the East and the West.
Mrs. Thomas K. Ware was elected president of the Junior League of Brooklyn, Inc., yesterday. She succeeds Mrs. John B. Mayes.
LONDON, Thursday, April 17 -- The Labor party has scored substantial gains in elections for County Councils in the sixty-two counties of England and Wales.
TORONTO, April 16 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker said tonight he hoped the West would take a stand "in the immediate future" in favor of halting nuclear weapons tests.
The third annual Festival of the Arts opens today at International House, 500 Riverside Drive. It will continue through Sunday.
Massachusetts borrowed $96,877,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance loans to war veterans and a broad program of public works, including highway construction, flood control and sewerage.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 -- A hard-hitting band of Los Angeles Dodgers retaliated with a vengeance tonight against the San Francisco Giants.

Potato futures fell yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, marking the seventh consecutive session of sharp declines for the near-by May position. The May position opened off the 30-point (hundredth of a cent a pound) daily limit and never rose above it.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Administration sent its defense reorganization bill to Congress today, but put off for this year its controversial plan to change military appropriations procedures.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Walter P. Reuther, vice president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, today urged Governor Harriman to veto the pending Republican labor rackets bill.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 16 -- The Standardbred Owners Associaton signed contracts with Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways today that call for increases in purses under certain conditions and a welfare fund for the horsemen and their workers.

The Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd, reported yesterday that its consolidated net income in 1957 declined to $16,864,000 from $17,502,000. Subsidiary companies retained $7,352,000 of the 1957 earnings, so that net income of the parent company was $9,512,000, against $9,094,000 in 1956.

The Flagg-Utica Corporation plans to ask stockholders at the annual meeting May 8 here to approve the sale of its assets, and the investment of proceeds in securities or other businesses. The company produces knit underwear.
Pearl S. Buck confirmed yesterday that she had written five novels between 1945 and 1953 under the pseudonym John Sedges.
ALBANY, April 15 -- Legislation designed to give every accident victim in the state the protection of the new compulsory insurance law was approved today by Governor Harriman.
TUNIS, April 16 -- At least fifteen French prisoners are alive and in good health in the hands of Algerian rebels, a nationalist spokesman said tonight.

LONDON, April 16 (UP) -- Premier Khrushchev said today that international agreement on a complete ban on production, stockpiling and use of nuclear weapons would be possible if the West followed the Soviet lead in banning nuclear tests.
President Eisenhower's recipe for old-fashioned beef stew challenged the cookery yesterday of eight small boys who usually prefer hero sandwiches and pizza.
Governor Harriman joined yesterday with city officials and foreign diplomats in honoring the name of Giovanni da Verrazzano, an Italian navigator who explored the New York Bay area in April, 1524.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Government signed up for the purchase of $6,444,000 worth of mortgages in the first week of operation of the new antirecession housing bill.
GENEVA, April 16 -- Canada moved swiftly today to protect her fishing industry from the possible consequences of a United States proposal at the United Nations conference on the law of the sea.
Twenty persons were rescued by aerial ladder yesterday in a five-alarm fire that damaged two industrial buildings in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section.
CHICAGO, April 16 (UP) -- Frank Bolling slugged a three-run homer with two out in the ninth inning today, powering the Detroit Tigers to a 5-4 triumph over the Chicago White Sox.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's confidence in the future is best measured by the $2,200,000,000 it plans to spend on construction this year, Frederick R. Kappel, president, told some 2,600 stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting at 50 Varick Street.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (AP) -- United States District Judge C. William Kraft Jr. rejected today two items in a petition by Randolph Phillips, New York financier engaged in a proxy fight for a seat on the board of the Pennsylvania Railroad.
LONDON, April 16 -- Industrial shares advanced sharply today in reaction to yesterday's budget message and Wall Street rally.

A SURVEY published recently by a Government source shows that fewer than half of today's homemakers have specific menu plans when they enter grocery stores or supermarkets. The survey implies that the modern food shopper holds haphazard ideas in relation to feeding the family and it indicates that shopping lists are going the way of the whooping crane.
LONDON, April 16 -- Observations made by Dr. Vivian Fuchs on his recent overland in the South Pole have convinced most British scientists that Antarctica is a continent.
The president of a prosperous Western railroad came to the East yesterday, where the traffic picture is grim, and conceded that his line's business wasn't what he would like it to be, either.

PARIS, April 16 -- The defense ministers of the North Atlantic alliance accepted with significant reservations today the high command's proposals for doubling the number of divisions in Europe to thirty and bolstering their firepower with nuclear weapons.
BONN, Germany, April 16 -Franz Etzel, Minister of Finance, submitted to the Bundestag today budget estimates for the 1958-59 fiscal year.

ORIENT, L. I., April 16 -Automation has come to Orient Point Light on the tiny rock outcropping called Oyster Pond Reef in Plum Gut. The gut is one of the tide raceways off the northeastern tip of Long Island, separating Long Island Sound from Shelter Island Sound.
The advertising account of the Air-Wick line of deodorizers has been awarded by the Lever Brothers Company to Foote Cone Belding.
A DISTURBING drama about Soviet despotism, based on the true experiences of an American, was presented last night on "Armstrong Circle Theatre" over Channel 2.
The election of Herbert R. Silverman as president of James Talcott, Inc., 105-year-old commercial financing and factoring concern, was announced yesterday.

France is having a crisis of the emotions, and in the process whatever might be the logical, reasonable and even urgent things to do go by the board. So, now, we have still another political upset, making twenty-five since World War II. Premier Felix Gaillard lasted a little more than five months, which is, close to the average tenure.

MEXICO CITY, April 16 -- A delegation of United States Department of Labor representatives departed from Mexico City today. But the question of how many braceros would be imported this year by North American planters and fruit growers remained unanswered.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 16 (Reuters) -- President Tito's Government conceded today that there was growing "hostile activity" to his Communist regime.
LONDON, April 16 -- A combination of difficulties is threatening to retard Britain's anti-poliomyelitis campaign.

New charges of price squeezes, tie-in sales and freight reciprocity featured yesterday's sessions of the Government's suit to stop a merger of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company into the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Governor Harriman approved today a bill exempting baby sitters 14 years old and more from the state's child labor laws. The sitters thus may continue their activities without first obtaining working papers.
Whatever hope city school teachers may have had of owning homes in the Lincoln Square redevelopment area was dissipated yesterday.
NEWARK, April 16 -- New Jersey was told today that its economic future, otherwise bright, was clouded by outdated tax policies, pinch-penny spending for education and irresponsible waste of water.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16 -- After long negotiations, the United Nations has made arrangements with a Belgian bank to collect the 3 per cent surcharge on ships passing through the Suez Canal.

Joshua Logan, stage and screen director who has left for Europe, plans to screen the film version of "South Pacific" for Russian officials when he arrives in Moscow. Before proceeding to the Soviet Union, Mr. Logan will attend the opening of the film in London.

The nation's crude oil production last week fell 63,250 barrels to an average of 6,186,885 a day, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This was the lowest level since the week ended on Oct. 25, 1954, when output averaged 6,152,750 barrels a day. A year ago production averaged 7,442,065 barrels daily.
BALTIMORE, April 16 (AP) -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad announced today it would discontinue all passenger train service between Baltimore and New York Saturday night, April 26.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Air Force is proposing to catapult a man around the world in the nose of an intercontinental ballistic missile.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Columbia Broadcasting System rejected today a request by Alaska's unofficial "Senators'' for free time to answer an anti-statehood broadcast.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- President Eisenhower did not, and could not, give today all the reasons why he is reluctant to go to an ill-prepared conference with the Soviet, British and French heads of government.

NIAGARA FALLS, April 16 (AP) -- Indian oratory and a threat of violence today stopped two attempts to survey Tuscarora Reservation land the State Power Authority is seeking to take for its Niagara project.
Chief Justice Albert Conway of the Court of Appeals announced yesterday that the Judicial Conference, which he heads, had agreed to propose a court reform program to the next Legislature.
The Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory in Cambridge, Mass., issued an urgent appeal yesterday for information on the incandescent end of Sputnik II.
MOSCOW, April 16 -- The Soviet press turned its cultural attention from Van Cliburn to the Moiseyev Dancers in the United States today.

Governor Harriman has done the right thing in vetoing the foolish bill to prohibit advertising the fact that "the decency or morality" of any publication or movie had been challenged in court or "by any group or agency."

The Committee on Housing of the Community Service Society is pleased that the Legislature passed the measure to make possible the reorganization of the New York City Housing Authority. We are confident that Governor Harriman will sign the bill and that on May 1 a three-man, full-time paid authority will replace the present authority which consists legally, but at present not in fact, of a full-time paid chairman and four unpaid part-time members.
JAKARTA, April 16 -- The Government's forces were said today to have cut the only major supply and communications route linking the hard-pressed Central Sumatran rebels with the rest of the world.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Dr. Edward Teller told the Senate Disarmament subcommittee today that if the United States should suspend nuclear testing now "we may be sacrificing millions of lives in a 'dirty' nuclear war later."
The truckmen's boycott of piers in the Port of New York gathered momentum yesterday.
Chief Justice Albert Conway of the Court of Appeals announced yesterday that the Judicial Conference, which he heads, had agreed to propose a court reform program to the next Legislature.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The United States, Britain and France have begun in Moscow a determined effort to find out whether a second summit conference with the Soviet Union would be worth the risk.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- A House committee said today that State Department refusal to permit a Congressional hearing in the United States Embassy at Madrid amounted to "unwarranted interference with the authority of Congress."

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Legislation authorizing a $1,800,000,000 increase in Federal spending on highway construction this year was approved by President Eisenhower today. However, he voiced "serious misgivings" about some provisions.
New York Catholic Charities reported yesterday that $1,696,303 -- half the money allotted to its Family Service Department -- was spent last year to prevent broken homes.

National unemployment -- as measured in terms of claims for state jobless insurance benefits -- showed no significant statistical change last week. With the second quarter of the year more than a week old, reports from major industrial centers were similar to what they generally had been in the first three months of this recession year.

One hundred and eleven persons were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday in a borough-wide drive on bookmakers and policy racketeers. More than 100 members of the Brooklyn morals squad joined in the round-up.
The 150,000 ships that are handled annually by United States ports are the most tangible link between this nation and the free world, William F. Giesen said last night.

First-quarter earnings of the Aluminum Company of America suffered a sharp decline from a year ago. The net was $11,458,810 compared to $18,594,086, Frank L. Magee, president, informed stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting held in Pittsburgh.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17 (AP) -- Chile proposed today a new international organization to prevent violent fluctuations in copper prices on the world market.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Rayco Manufacturing Company of Paterson, N. J., was accused today by the Federal Trade Commission of using false and deceptive advertising for its auto seat covers and convertible tops.

CINCINNATI, April 17 (UP) -Warren Giles, president of the National League, today turned down a protest by the Cincinnati Redlegs after their 5-4 opening game loss to the Philadelphia Phillies on Tuesday.
Three new films will open today, including a double-bill program.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 17 -- Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said today that he was "not pessimistic" about the world's economic situation.
The Fire Department's chief uniformed officer announced his retirement yesterday. His successor, not yet appointed, will be one of several dark-horse contenders.
BOSTON, April 17 (AP) -- Fire took the lives of approximately 11,300 persons in the United States in 1957. Of these about 6,400 were killed in their homes.
The Soviets, having by tests secured the fundamental data they can put into practice in any short time they desire, now attempt to secure a cessation of nuclear tests by others.
PARIS, April 17 -- The Soviet Army and Air Force in central Europe are more powerful today than a year ago despite widely advertised troop withdrawals from East Germany and Hungary.
