Mayor Wagner was reported yesterday to have offered the chairmanship of a reorganized New York City Housing Authority to William Reid, a former Deputy Mayor. Robert Weaver, the State Rent Administrator, is reported to be the Mayor's choice for the second of the three places on the new authority.
PARIS, April 17 -- President Rene Coty was under strong political pressure tonight to defer designation of a new Premier until after local elections Sunday.

VILLA BENS, Southern Morocco, April 17 -- Spanish troops stood on the alert today in this entrenched town as a Moroccan Army convoy arrived after a four-day safari across disputed wasteland of the Southern Protectorate of Morocco.

MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, April 17 (AP) -- Merger of the Armco Steel Corporation and the National Supply Company, was approved today by Armco stockholders. Armco is the seventh largest United States steel producer. National Supply is a leading manufacturer of oil field equipment.
ST. LOUIS, April 18 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 4 -- 3 tonight on the combined six-hit pitching of Glenn Hobbie, Dave Hillman and Ed Mayer.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Among the criticisms of the Eisenhower Administration is that its tendency, beyond that of preceding regimes, is to withhold information to which the people are entitled. This complaint is being generally affirmed in the discussions of the American Society of Newspaper Editors now in session here.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Democrats drafted a new unemployment relief bill today. It is expected to be approved tomorrow by the House Ways and Means Committee.
Pink and red flowers provided a spring-like background in the ballroom of the Plaza last night for the sixth annual Kips Bay dinner dance.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 521,035 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
HONG KONG, April 17 -- A huge task still lies ahead of the Hanoi Government in establishing a Communist system in North Vietnam.

Democratic enrollment upstate has increased 40 per cent since 1953, Michael H. Prendergast, the Democratic state chairman, reported yesterday. He described the gain as a tribute to Governor Harriman administration.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- For the first time the per capita consumption of margarine has surpassed that of butter.

SAN FRANCISCO April 17] ---Chemical experiments to dem-{ onstrate how major constitu-] ents of life could have risen on earth millions of years ago were reported today at the American Chemical Society meeting.
A BARE-HEADED woman in midtown Manhattan might have felt a bit silly yesterday. For hats in all sizes, shapes and colors dominated the city landscape.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 17 -- The quiet Clint Hodgins is making a lot of noise at Roosevelt Raceway these nights. It's causing a stir among racegoers not accustomed to seeing the Canadian-born reinsman get off to a speedy early-season start.
Teamster pickets marched in front of Manhattan and Brooklyn piers yesterday to tighten a three-day-old boycott called by some trucking companies against waterfront terminals.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission accused the Admiral Corporation of Chicago today of unlawfully discriminating among its electrical appliance customers as to price and advertising allowances.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 17 -- Otto Preminger, director-producer, has obtained motion-picture rights to a new novel by the French writer, Pierre Boulle, author of the Academy Award winner, "The Bridge on the River Kwai."

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd said today that information compiled by the Senate Finance Committee indicated to him that the recession had about reached bottom. He predicted an economic upturn by fall.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Julius Klein, retired, resigned today from the Jewish War Veterans because of what he called "attacks" against him by Drew Pearson, the columnist.

The Federal Communications Commission ordered the three major television networks and several of their affiliated stations yesterday to answer charges that they had presented biased accounts of the controversy over pay-as-you see TV.

The generous cooperation of men and women of all religious faiths enabled New York Catholic Charities, 122 East Twenty-second Street, New York 10, through its 189 affiliated institutions and agencies, to come to the assistance last year of 560,982 needy and deserving persons.

MONTREAL, April 17 (UP) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard broke a tense struggle with a "picture" goal after 5 minutes 45 seconds of sudden death overtime to give Montreal a 3-2 victory over the Boston Bruins tonight.
PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- The York (Pa.) Gazette and Daily won a first leg today on the Ayer Cup for excellence in typography, make-up and printing. It is the first tabloid to win the honor.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- Representative John E. Moss, fresh from a House vote against Government secrecy, told newspaper editors today censorship of Defense Department information "has reached an alarming degree."
PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- The discovery of a clue to the mechanism by which human blood clotting begins was reported here today.
Mayor Wagner has received a report on his inquiry into the dealings between fourteen real estate management companies and the city's Bureau of Real Estate.
A 130-year-old Japanese department store will establish its first American branch on Fifth Avenue in September.

I would like to make a point or two in response to the letter from Wendell P. Brown in your issue of April 11. In his letter Mr. Brown stated that the Committee on Public Employe Security Procedures, set up by Governor Harriman in September, 1956, "warmly approved" the interpretation which the amendment to the Security Risk Law incorporated in State Senate bill 4400.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The United States Court of Appeals sent the case of Miami television Channel 10 back to the Federal Communications Commission today.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Federal Reserve System took twin actions today to assure the continuance of conditions of easy money.

Felice Orsini, one of the "brilliant and tragic figures" of the Italian movement for unity in nineteenth century, is the subject of a biography by Michael St. John Packe. Orsini (1819-1858) spent his childhood studying the arts of war while ostensibly preparing for law and the priesthood.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Atomic Energy Commission has withdrawn one of its major partnerships proposals for construction of an atomic power plant.

A 23-year-old New Jersey youth shot a girl friend at 8:03 yesterday morning as she started down the subway stairs at Eighth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street on her way to work. She died three hours later at St. Clare's Hospital.

The second annual Gadget Show will open tomorrow at the New York Trade Show Building, Eighth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street. Included in the two-day exhibition are the latest ideas in can openers, tooth paste dispensers, concealed garbage pails and noodle makers, among other devices.
Thirty-eight Northern and Southern leaders have agreed that there are two steps of "paramount importance" in solving the race-relations "crisis" in this country.
Sixteen presidents and board chairmen of leading American corporations will take part in a special conference here on May 19 and 20 to discuss methods of combating the business recession.

Bird experts at the Bronx Zoo have decided to increase the egg-laying efficiency of flamingoes there by creating a special island with man-made nests. Accordingly, William G. Conway, the zoo's curator of birds, assisted by his head keeper, Joseph Bell, spent a good part of yesterday morning making nine flamingo nests with buckets, shovels and their own hands.

TUNIS, April 17 -- President Habib Bourguiba declared today he would take the ten-week-old French-Tunisian dispute back to the United Nations Security Council. But he will not do so immediately, "out of regard for France and President Rene Coty," he added. Nevertheless, he said, "if the crisis is prolonged, we cannot wait four or five weeks."

In taking his defense reorganization plan to the nation yesterday President Eisenhower put himself upon strong ground. He deplored the necessity for great military spending and dramatized its wastefulness. The same funds could have been put to vastly more productive use, provided only that we would have been allowed so to use them. Unhappily that condition does not obtain.
Three railroad presidents proposed yesterday that the Port of New York Authority take over operation of Hudson River ferries.
Technicians of the Columbia Broadcasting System who have been on strike for twelve days, last night began voting on whether to accept a C. B. S. contract offer or to continue the strike.
It is three days late, for the first time in more than half a century, but New York finally gets its "live" major league baseball opening today.

Member bank reserves contracted somewhat in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. On average, net free reserves declined $88,000,000 from a revised figure of $542,000,000 a week ago to $454,000,000.

The cancellation of a public dinner that had been scheduled at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel disclosed yesterday the lengths to which the Army had gone to keep its officers from fraternizing with defense contractors.
THE search for the "Betty Crocker All-American Homemaker of Tomorrow" for 1958 has ended.

Your editorial suggestion that Fifth Avenue parades be restricted to Sundays merits some discussion. That being the one day of the week when parking regulations are relaxed, many who reside in the suburbs avail themselves of the opportunity to use their cars as means of transportation to services held at city churches, as well as to visit the various museums and art galleries to be found along this, our greatest thoroughfare.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Senate investigators charged today that a Philadelphia teamster leader had spent his union's funds lavishly.

Loans to business by the larger New York City banks declined $61,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a rise of $115,000,000 in the like week a year ago.

Potato prices moved over a wide range in active trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The May position, which accounted for 3,360 car lots of trading, opened the limit of 30 points (hundreth of a cent a pound) lower, but closed the limit higher.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, said today the Treasury Department should give "careful scrutiny" to the handling of tax delinquencies in the Chicago office of the Internal Revenue Service.
CHICAGO, April 17 (UP) -- The first of two singles by Al Smith today started the Chicago White Sox on their way to a 4-3 triumph over the Detroit Tigers.

A slight spry septuagenarian in a Roman collar tossed an Irish-green paper streamer from the sundeck of the Independence yesterday as the ship backed away from the pier. Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch was off to assume his post in Rome as director of missions for the Roman Catholic Church.

BOSTON, April 17 -- The Yankees acted today in the manner of men preoccupied with more important matters. And that may have been the case because tomorrow they will open their home season at the Stadium, an event that always ranks high in the affairs of the Bombers.
CHZCAGO, April 17 (API --The report I of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A full hearing was ordered yesterday into allegations by a former assistant United States attorney that the Government had used "tainted evidence" to convict three men on income tax evasion charges.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Friday, April 18 -- The margin of Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom's impressive victory in Wednesday's general election grew today.

Real estate sales in the Bronx averaged 118 per cent of assessed valuations in the first quarter, an increase of 5 percentage points from the last quarter of 1957, according to the Taxpayers Service Company.
THE closest fresh - water fishing this week-end will be the best and the chances are that the children will have the best.
A state investigation of corruption in New York City like the famous Lexow and Seabury inquiries was urged yesterday by City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs.

Familiar Economic Story Accounts of what happened only yesterday -- as history is measured -- have a way of sounding strangely familiar. For example: "When the World War ended, every business man realized that the United States had been traveling on the crest of an inflationary wave of enormous proportions -- the natural outcome of 'hurry orders' for munitions of every description.
EL CENTRO, Calif. April 17 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that a jet fighter had zoomed to an altitude record for conventional aircraft -- 76,828 feel.

The Board of Estimate has endured its annual three-day ordeal of hearings on the Mayor's executive budget, sitting all day and into the early morning hours while city officials, employes, educators, civic agencies, taxpayers and plain citizens expressed their diverse views.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Friday, April 18 -- The rebel stronghold of Padang in central Sumatra fell to Government amphibious troops at about 6 P. M. yesterday, the Government announced today.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Department - store sales last week were 16 per cent below sales in the corresponding week last year.

ABOUT three years ago, a teen-age girl had an argument with her father over the alleged existence of anti-Semitism in their small midwestern town. She contended that it did not exist; her father insisted otherwise.

The increasing complexity of news in the Space Age requires that newsmen "must background themselves educationally as never before in history," according to Frank J. Starzel, general manager of The Associated Press.
Production and consumption of newsprint in March continued below the 1957 levels, according to trade association reports issued yesterday.
World airline officials will meet today in London to ponder a problem that looks like a molehill but is really a mountain. It is simply a matter of perspective from the air.

BALTIMORE, April 17 (UP) -- Jack Harshman's brilliant relief pitching and home runs by Gus Tranidos and Brooks Robinson gave Baltimore a 4-0 victory over the Washington Senators tonight, leaving the Orioles as the only undefeated team in the American League.
HE rose to fame on a curtain rod. After thirty years in the business, Ernest Lo Nano finds that his window hangings have taken their place in history.
A phonograph cartridge that can reproduce both stereophonic and conventional recordings has been introduced by the Sonotone Corporation.
Sales and earnings of the Gillette Company in the first quarter fell below those of the corresponding period last year, Boone Gross, president, reported yesterday.
BUFFALO, April 17 -- Governor Harriman gave voters today a preview of the campaign he is expected to wage for re-election.
LOUISVILLE, April 13 (UP) -- Bert Weaver and Bill Collins tied for the lead in the first round of the $20,000 Kentucky Derby open golf tournament today with 65's.

Since John Head, a coach of female basketball players, is a charming, intelligent man who understands the beguiling ways of women, he has been eminently successful in the sport, largely because he dominates women with suave diplomacy, and also knows when to keep his mouth shut.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles warned today that failure by the United States to share nuclear weapons secrets with its allies would make an atomic disarmament agreement impossible.

This is a period of ebb tide among the opponents of President Batista of Cuba and especially among the followers of Fidel Castro. The dust of recent flurries has settled and revealed only too clearly the strength of General Batista's position and the weakness of his opponents.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 -The San Francisco Giants took the West Coast's first major league baseball series with a 7-to-4 victory today over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

"REGINA," the opera Marc Blitzstein made out of Lillian Hellman's taut and mordant play, "The Little Foxes," carries a theatrical wallop. Not many works for the lyric theatre have been blessed with so powerful a book, and Mr. Blitzstein's musical setting has the wit and the skill to keep the drama tense and compelling.

PARIS, April 17 -- The defense ministers of the Atlantic alliance approved a master five-year defense plan for the West in a three-day meeting here. They dispersed tonight to decide separately how much of it each could afford to buy.

PARIS, April 17 -- The United States is increasingly convinced of the need for a non-military settlement of the Algerian rebellion. It does not exclude the possibility of negotiations with the National Liberation Front, the principal rebel organization.
WASHINGTON, April 17. -- The House Judiciary Committee voted today to bring organized baseball under the antitrust laws for the first time.
The economic recession is figuring in the city's plans for its 1959 capital budget.
Many merchants in the metropolitan area have begun campaigns designed to relieve the recession by encouraging consumer buying.

Winners of Altman's third annual competition for tableware design were announced yesterday. More than 3,000 consumers voted in the competition, all of whom had definite likes and dislikes. Comments on the designs ranged from "I loved them all" to "I'd take them back even if given as gifts."

Record sales of $358,380,000 were achieved by the National Dairy Products Corporation in the first quarter this year. This was $8,140,000 higher than in the 1957 period, E. E. Stewart, president and board chairman, reported yesterday at the annual meeting held at the Biltmore Hotel.
NORTH BELLMORE, L. I., April 17 -- Car pools designed to lower the cost of commuter transportation to New York are being organized by residents here.

THEY both were remarkable women. The elder was plain and plump. The younger was beautiful and graceful. The elder was a furious intellectual, "a conversational enchantress" and the author of many books. The younger was a gentle and lovable woman of fashion and an enchantress by charm alone.
Jean P. J. Baltzell, Democratic leader of the Ninth Assembly District, said last night that Anthony J. Akers had been chosen as the Democratic candidate for Congress in the Seventeenth District.

The appeal of Dr. Greenburg, Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, to motorists to help the city's anti-smoke campaign by making sure that their cars burn gasoline and oil as efficiently as possible is a reasonable one. The Commissioner is making available copies of a pamphlet which tells motorists how they can help reduce city air pollution and save themselves money at the same time.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -President Eisenhower's disavowal today of any intent to promote a Prussian type of general staff reminded Pentagon historians of a period in United States history when this form of military command was not a term of opprobrium.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 17 -- The Yugoslav League of Communists, eager to forestall a new war of words with Moscow, published a revised version of its draft program.

WARSAW, April 17 -- For the first time since Poland's political upheaval of 1956, Warsaw streets were festooned today with the red flag of the Soviet Union. Banners proclaimed friendship between the two countries.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 17 -- A Protestant leader challenged the Roman Catholic position on birth control today.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits expressed concern tonight over a "slump in national morale." He said the condition was "deeper in Washington than back home."
The Soldiers, Sailors and Air-men's Club will benefit from a bridge and canasta party to be held Monday at its clubhouse, 283 Lexington Avenue.
Capital spending will decline this year, but spending for research and development will increase, according to the eleventh annual survey of business plans, by the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company.
Maritime labor was urged here yesterday by a high ranking naval officer to make its contribution to ship safety through proper personnel selection.
Republican women were aroused last night by the thought that racketeers have a part in manufacturing women's wear.
CLEVELAND, April 17 (UP) -- Mickey Vernon's pinch double in the ninth inning drove in two runs today and gave the Cleveland Indians a 3-2 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
THE chemise dress is getting the soft sell but, so far, not much hard wear.

The Greater New York Fund took its campaign chairman on a tour of member organizations yesterday. But one stop was a busman's holiday for the chairman, J. Peter Grace, who has eight children. He visited fifty-five youngsters who were awaiting placement in homes at the Divine Providence Foundation, 225 East Forty-fifth Street.
The Port of New York Authority has filed a memorandum with Governor Harriman opposing an amendment to the state tax law.
A campaign begun little more than a month ago by an Oregon brewery has resulted in more than 52,000 fir trees being sent to coupon-clippers.

The Rev. Peter McCormack 73-year-old former Protestant chaplain of Alcatraz Prison, said here yesterday that he believed Morton Sobell was "incapable" of conspiracy to commit wartime espionage. Sobell was sentenced in 1951 to thirty years for the crime.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- President Eisenhower appealed today for public support of his program to modernize the military establishment. He also accused Congressional opponents of his proposals of misrepresentation and "nonsense."
Milk industry employes asserted yesterday that a change in milk-dating to a code system that would be unrecognized by consumers would cause decreases in employment and consumer confidence.
New York City has cut its fatal accident rate by almost one-quarter in the last eight years, Mayor Wagner said last night.
The Government struck yesterday at the heart of the defense case that the merger of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company into the Bethlehem Steel Corporation would increase, not lessen competition.
PRATO, Italy, April 17 -- The electoral campaign in this industrial Tuscan city has become more religious than political.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The House Postoffice and Civil Service Committee approved today a bill to give a 10 per cent pay increase to 1,032,236 Government employes.

DETROIT, April 17 -- A jury in Circuit Court here awarded Carl Renda, a scrap metal dealer, $400,000 in damages today in a suit against the United Automobile Workers, three U. A. W. officials and a private investigator.

The belief that Israel will resolve differences with her neighbors and establish within borders a nation dedicated to God was expressed last night by Dr. Martin Buber, philosopher and Jewish religious leader.
BONN, Germany, April 17 -- The Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany reported today that West German payments could be completed by March 31, 1963, if procedures were accelerated.

MADRID, April 17 -- The Spanish Parliament has restored for the first time in nearly twenty-five years the right of collective bargaining between employers and workers. The measure is expected to affect 3,000,000 workers.

IN the last five years or so local savings banks have borrowed techniques from art galleries, musems, fashion shows, flower shows and nature study. These ideas are based in lobbies and display windows to attract new depositors. The scope is still spreading.
Municipal officials were urged yesterday to push lagging projects for urban renewal into construction as a means of easing the business recession.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 17 -- King Baudouin of Belgium declared open today the Brussels World Fair of 1958, a "universal and international exposition" dedicated to cooperation among nations and the advancement of humanity.

Carrying out the "arm-and-negotiate" decision of the North Atlantic Council's summit meeting last December, the Western powers are now moving to meet the Soviet challenge on two fronts -- the diplomatic and the military. On the diplomatic front American Ambassador Thompson has met with Foreign Minister Gromyko in Moscow in a first contact regarding preparatory negotiations for an East-West summit meeting dealing primarily with disarmament.
MILWAUKEE, April 17 (UP) -Eddie Mathews drove in five runs with two homers today to pace the word champion Milwaukee Braves to a 6-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Governor Harriman and Mayor Wagner urged Congress today to study the economic feasibility of deepening the waterway connecting the Hudson River with the St. Lawrence River.
The seven-story and basement building at 49-51 Broad Street, between Exchange Place and Beaver Street, has been sold by the Manufacturers Trust Company to the Kerr Steamship Company.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -The Daughters of the American Revolution voted today to urge Congress to withdraw the United States from the United Nations from this country's soil.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- Gen. John B. Medaris, chief of the Army's missile projects, called today for a more forward-looking space program.
The Louisiana State University sold yesterday two issues of bonds totaling $8,350,000.
The Museum of Modern Art, making giant strides toward recovery from its fire on Tuesday, will reopen early next week. The date will be announced shortly.

HOUSTON, April 17 (UP) -- Bernard Bartzen of Dallas upset second-seeded Mervyn Rose of Australia, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3, in the quarter-final round of the twenty-fourth annual River Oaks Country Club tennis tournament today.

LONDON, April 17 -- Industrial shares reacted today to Wall Street's opening prices and Laborite success in local council elections. Losses virtually erased yesterday's gains that the new budget tax cuts had engendered.

NEW DELHI, India, April 17 -- India's ruling Congress party has warned that Communists in the country are engaged in a "subtle and cunning" campaign to win power through an appearance of respectability.
HAVANA, April 17 -- President Fulgencio Batista and his Cabinet approved today decrees imposing drastic penalties for criticizing or opposing the regime.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -The Government's right to deny security clearance to defense plant employes on the basis of secret information was upheld today by the United States Court of Appeals.
Russia's seasoned internationalists of the wrestling mat closed out a triumphant tour of the United States last night by registering a decisive victory over an American all-star team.
Charles L. Patterson, chairman of the Transit Authority, announced a campaign last night to eliminate abuses of sick leave on the city transit system.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission inquiry into the merger of two big producers of cleaning products dug into the sales promotion practices of one of the companies today.

THRIFTY food shoppers will find chicken a good buy again this week-end. Quoted at 39 cents a pound by the city's Department of Markets, the broilers and fryers are being offered for as little as 33 cents a pound by one of the major chains.
WALTHAM, Mass., April 17 -Brandeis University has turned down two bequests totaling $225,000 on the ground that they would be contrary to the institution's nonsectarian policy.
ACCRA, Ghana, April 17 -- The Algerian National Liberation Front asked the eight nations at the conference of independent African states today for material aid in its rebellion against French rule.

We regret that it is necessary for a group like ours to oppose the erection of a public housing project -- the Alexander Hamilton Houses slated for 141st-144th Streets between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
Artur Rubinstein was soloist with the New York Philharmonic last night in the Brahms B flat Piano Concerto.
Fifty-six American-made documentary films have been selected for exhibition in the American pavilion at the Brussels World Fair, which opened yesterday.
David Dubinsky yesterday proclaimed the official end of the six-week strike of dress-makers in Pennsylvania.
Sid's Gambol, part of an entry favored at 19-10 in the $7,500 Farmingdale, scored a nose victory over Octagonal at Jamaica yesterday before a sunny-day crowd of 24,590.

Events today: Bucci's "Tale for a Deaf Ear" and Bernstein's "Trouble in Tahiti," double bill, New York City Opera, City Center, 8:15; New York Philharmonic, Artur Rubinstein, pianist, Leonard Bernstein conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Senate hearings on a bill affecting broadcasters were recessed today until next month amid indications that the measure had little if any chance of passage.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., April 17 (AP) -- The Tuscarora Indians, after a brief outbreak of scuffling and shouting, decided today to confine the defense of their land to passive resistance.

LOS ANGELES, April 17 -- If one of the more quotable of the Hollywood Malaprops were asked to describe the Dodger set-up at the Coliseum, he probably would say: "It's colossal in a Lilliputian sort of way."

All tables have been taken for the tenth annual spring frolic and tea dance for the Humane Society of New York, which will be held tonight at the Plaza. A highlight of the event will be a canine fashion show called "Putting on the Dog."

International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation plans to offer to holders of its capital stock a new issue of $28,692,000 of twenty-five-year subordinated debentures convertible into capital stock. The issue was registered yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
MOSCOW, April 17 -- Talks between the United States and the Soviet Union aimed at preparing a heads-of-government conference began today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 5 to 23 points yesterday, with strength most pronounced in the new October contract. The rise equaled 25 cents to $1.15 a bale.

IN one of the newly opened sculpture exhibitions, Dorothea Greenbaum is presenting work of the last four or five years at the Sculpture Center, 167 East Sixty-ninth Street. It is the most varied and ambitious display of her career and decidedly adds to her stature as a craftsman with integrity and personal vision.
A powerful thrust of the railroads led the stock market up yesterday. The modest rise of the industrials showed signs of reluctance.

MIAMI BEACH, April 17 -- The nation's schools, which have come under mounting criticism in recent months, received strong support today at the annual meeting of the National School Boards Association.
A new movable wall system, said to combine low initial cost with design features usually found in more expensive systems, has been developed by the E. F. Hauserman Company of Cleveland.

There was talk yesterday of Cyril Ritchard's affiliation with "The Pleasure of His Company" in a dual capacity.

A six-foot, $1,000, electronic robot that can talk, walk and solve arithmetic problems has been built by a 14-year-old schoolboy in his family's living room. The young inventor, Donald S. Rich, showed his "Robetron" yesterday at the second annual Gadget Show in the New York Trade Show Building.

HALF of the musical Goodman family gave a program last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. She was Lillian Rehberg Goodman, and she played the 'cello. Her husband, Saul Goodman, is the celebrated tympanist of the New York Philharmonic, and he was in a back row chewing his fingernails.

SPRINGFIELD, Vt., April 18 (AP) -- Priscilla "Polly" White-comb, who vanished from the Smith College campus seventeen months ago, came home Past midnight. Twelve hours after the Boston police arrested Richard S. Thatcher, for whom she left school.

FREEPORT, L. I., April 18 -- Vandals broke into the administrative offices of Uniondale High School early this morning and set four blazes in an apparent attempt to destroy truancy and delinquency records.

BUCK HILLS FALLS, Pa., April 18 -- A Protestant expert on foreign affairs proposed today that the United States regard its decision to proceed with nuclear tests as "flexible and alterable."

The annual report of Public Works Commissioner Zurmuhlen is a reminder that even in a recession, when the city has an "austerity" budget, certain types of public improvements must be built. A city of 8,000,000 persons cannot remain physically static.

LONDON, April 18 -- A further cut in the American discount rate provided a better background for the stock market today. Equities threw off yesterday's dullness and joined with Government securities in a modest advance.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- An examiner of the Interstate Commerce Commission threw his support today to an internal reorganization of the Florida East Coast Railway, with control ultimately going to the St. Joe Paper Company.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18 -- The Soviet Union demanded today that the Security Council meet at once to take up Moscow's charges that United States bombers carrying nuclear weapons were making polar flights toward Soviet territory.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 18 -A group of Long Island commuters, who yesterday threatened to take to the highways in revolt against the Long Island Rail Road, today got a word of encouragement from an unexpected source -- the railroad's president, Thomas E. Goodfellow.
MOSCOW, April 18 -- The Communist party dealt vigorously for the second straight day this morning with the long disgraced "anti-party" group.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Justice Department gave its reasons today for opposing Senator John Marshall Butler's bill to counteract recent Supreme Court decisions.

LOS ANGELES, April 18 -- The first major league team ever to press spikes into the turf of the Memorial Coliseum was not the Dodgers but, ironically, the Giants. The transplanted Brooks were too busy being feted in a parade through town to take first licks in batting practice. So the former Polo Grounds tenants were accorded the dubious honor of drawing bead on the target of the neighborly left-field fence.

Net income of the Borg-Warner Corporation for the first quarter this year fell to $5,016,000, or 56 cents a share, from $9,022,000, or $1 a share, in the first three months last year Roy C. Ingersoll, chairman, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting in Chicago.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -- The sixty-seventh Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution ended today with a hymn, a prayer and a last-minute flurry of resolutions.

A chronicle of man's exploration into space is given by Comdr. David C. Holmes, U.S.N., in "What's Going On in Space?" which Funk Wagnalls will publish May 23. Commander Holmes, a graduate of the naval academy, has spent his naval career in missile development.

FOR most people spring means going places. Whether you have Europe on your agenda or plan to be a week-end commuter to the country, the stores have many things to speed you on your way. Here are some useful and pretty new items:
Tom Lehrer, a song satirist, last night attracted to Carnegie Hall an enthusiastic audience that completely filled the auditorium and overflowed onto most of the stage space.
THIS is the story of a man who set a deadline for furnishing his apartment -- and met it with days to spare.

CHICAGO, April 18 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs scored six runs, four of them unearned, in the fourth inning today and went on to rout the St. Louis Cardinals, 11 -- 6, to hold first place in the National League with three victories and no losses.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 18 -Harvard University's Memorial Church, a controversial building when it was dedicated twenty-six years ago, is the subject of a new debate.
United States Attorney Paul W. Williams intervened yesterday in the four-day truckmen's boycott of New York piers.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 18 -- Edward O. Lamb of Toledo. Ohio, an industrialist, won a $25,000 verdict tonight in his $1,000,000 libel suit against a former Tennessee Representative and two Nashville radio-television stations.

Representative Charles O. Porter, Democrat of Oregon, said here last night that he would fly to the nuclear proving grounds at Eniwetok in the Pacific May 1 to dramatize his opposition to further nuclear tests.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., April 18 (AP) --The Carborundum Company said today sales for the first quarter of 1958 were $22,657,346, compared with $27,673,350 in the same period last year. Net profits dropped from $1,468,641 to $452,271.
Construction of a thirty-story building to replace decrepit Bellevue Hospital has been recommended by survey experts. It would cost about $75,000,000.

Designs adopted from frescoes in the Medici-Riccardi Palazzo in Florence will decorate the ballroom of the Plaza on Tuesday night for "A Renaissance Night in Italy Ball." The event is a benefit for the Celestini Orphanage in Prato, Italy.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 17 -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann said today that Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev had conceded publicly for the first time that Jews in the Soviet Union had not disappeared as a national group.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church declared today that artificial birth control was repugnant to the moral sense of men of good will of all nations.
VIENNA, April 18 -- The Czechoslovak Government expelled today Joseph Roche Jacyno, commercial attache of the United States embassy in Prague, for alleged military espionage.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 18 -- An Israeli official said tonight that there were a number of "busybodies" in the United Nations who seemed determined to stir up trouble over an elaborate military parade scheduled here Thursday.

Michael Todd, film producer, divided his estate equally between his wife, Mrs. Elizabeth Taylor Todd, and his son by a previous marriage, Michael Todd Jr. The estate is estimated at $1,000,000 at present. The will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court here yesterday.
Fourteen institutions planning summer workshops in different aspects of educational television have received grants-in-aid from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters.
A thirteen-story office building at 140 West Forty-second Street was sold yesterday to Leonard Winston, realty operator, and resold by him to investing clients.

HARTFORD, April 18 (UPI) -- The Connecticut Supreme Court of Errors expressed its views in important decisions today on both the activities of banks in handling estates, trusts and other fiduciary matters and also on the powers of the Connecticut courts.
Because of the very different nature of the recessions of 1948-9 and 1953-4, I did not then propose a tax cut, as Arthur Krock avers in one of his amusing poems on April 8.
LONDON, April 18 -- Britain and West Germany declared today that disarmament and the reunification of Germany should be emphasized at a meeting of Western and Soviet heads of government.
DETROIT, April 18 (UP) -Herb Score today limited the Detroit Tigers to five hits as he pitched the Cleveland Indians to a 7-5 decision for his first victory since being injured nearly a year ago.
The Commercial Placement Council of New York, an association of employment agencies, assailed yesterday a state bill that would reduce fees charged by private nursing registries.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Secretary of the Treasury said today that Federal spending in the next fiscal year would rise to about $78,000,000,000 -- up $4,000,000,000 from the estimates made in January.

Justice Walter R. Hart of the New York State Supreme Court reserved decision yesterday on a stockholders suit to block the proposed merger of the Glen Alden Corporation and List Industries Corporation.

PARIS, April 18 -- Gen. Maurice Gustave Gamelin, prominent military figure in both World Wars, died here tonight at Val de Grave Hospital. His age was 85. He commanded the Anglo-French forces for nine months in 1939-40.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Rear Admiral Hyman G. Rickover said today the Defense Department was becoming so large it was threatening to take over control of the coun try. Handing down indictments in his typically outspoken manner, the peppery admiral also told Congressmen that they had been too inattentive to the nation's educational needs.

The University of Virginia has just presented its Thomas Jefferson Award to President Colgate W. Darden Jr., who has headed the university since 1947. The award is made annually to the member of the university community who "by personal influence, teaching, writing or scholarship inspires high ideals for which Jefferson founded the university."
Re-education in parenthood is the key to juvenile delinquency, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The House investigation of the Federal Communications Commission will reopen next Wednesday.
Opponents of a roadway through Washington Square met with Mayor Wagner yesterday in City Hall and expressed the view that the square should be closed to all traffic.
A city magistrate, patrolmen, prisoners and spectators in Felony Court stood yesterday with heads bowed while a minister offered a prayer for the man who had assertedly tried to kill him.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- United States strategic bombers have been on a fifteen-minute alert since last November, three months after the Soviet Union announced the successful firing of an intercontinental ballistic missile.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -- Lahourari (Larry) Godih, the French lightweight champion, made a successful United States debut tonight. He jabbed his way to a unanimous ten-round decision over Larry Baker of Mount Vernon, N. Y., in a nationally televised bout.

Archbishop Stepinac High of White Plains and St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn carried off the chief honors yesterday as the fourth annual Queens-Iona Relays opened in perfect weather at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.
CHICAGO, April 18 (AP)Soybean futures scored moderate gains on the Board of Trade today. Grains finished with mostly small fractions both above and below the previous closes.
Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn will dedicate its new building at 333 Jay Street today. The building is on the east edge of the new Brooklyn Civic Center.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The United States said today that its policy in the Algerian-French dispute had not changed, and that press reports to the contrary were without foundation.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Paul Bestor, Professor of History at the University of Illinois, told the American Society of Newspaper Editors today that "professional educationists" had caused "disgracefully low" scholarship standards in American schools.
The 1958 major league baseball season finally has got around to New York.
THE vanguard of future tourist invasions of Europe may well be pram pushers. Those stalwart Americans who have tried it believe in it.
The twelve-day strike of radio and television technicians against the Columbia Broadcasting System ended yesterday.
A chart maker would have an easy time showing the trend in railroad passenger traffic -- almost a straight line slanting sharply down.

The new capital market is slowing. Major new bond issues scheduled for sale next week total less than $200,000,000 for the first time in months. Inventories of bond dealers are beginning to shrink visibly.
The steel industry was pictured yesterday as one in which big companies get bigger and little ones stay little or are gobbled up by bigger ones.
Mayor Wagner made public yesterday a program to cushion the effects of the recession on the city's economy.
The Monsanto Chemical Company reported yesterday that profits in the first quarter of 1958 were 49 per cent below the corresponding period last year.
Stocks made a general advance yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve moves to ease credit. Oils and steels took the lead early in the session and pressed the advance almost to the close.
Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey cautioned Democrats last night against excessive partisanship. He told the Lexington Democratic Club here that "the public is tired of extreme views."

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -- A National Labor Relations Board Examiner recommended today that the board order the Mailers Union Local 6 to stop enforcing closed-shop conditions in mailing rooms of New York newspapers.
NEWARK, April 18 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company moved today to increase its annual gross gas operating revenue by $15,000,000.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -- Clifford E. Carpenter, chief editorial writer of The Rochester (N. Y.) Democrat and Chronicle, said today that "news has become so complex" that newspaper readers could not understand it all without guidance from interpretive editorials.
Fifth Avenue business men spoke out yesterday against parades on business days and specifically against the Loyalty Day parade proposed for next Saturday.
ARDSLEY - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., April 18 -- Thomas K. Finletter said here tonight that the Federal Government should get into education "in a big way" as a matter of national safety.

The Government bond market extended yesterday its bullish response to the Federal Reserve System's new easing of the money market. Nearly all the Treasury's issues of certificates of indebtedness, notes and bonds were bid up to new high prices for the yearm, with the greatest gains registered among the long-term bonds.

RENO, April 18 -- Mrs. Frances Munn Baker was granted a divorce yesterday from George F. Baker Jr., of 1001 Park Avenue, New York, on the ground of extreme mental cruelty. At a private trial the court approved a sealed agreement covering property rights and support of three children.

HELSINKI, Finland, April 18 -- The nonpartisan Cabinet of Premier Raimer von Fieandt, in office less than five months, resigned today. The action followed a vote of no confidence on the Cabinet's recent move to adjust prices of farm produce.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 18 -- You have to be on gait if you want to rate -- with the track's stewards.

A theatre-party office has been set up by the management of the Criterion Theatre for "South Pacific." Special arrangements and accommodations will be given to social clubs, charitable organizations, community-center groups and scholastic associations.

James D. Norris yesterday resigned as president of the New York and Illinois International Boxing Clubs. He was succeeded as head of both companies by Truman K. Gibson Jr., of Chicago, who formerly served as secretary and executive vice president of the organization.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Dr. D. Lawrence Jaffe, president of the Polarad Corporation, manufacturers of electronic equipment, was granted a patent this week on an automatic pancake baker for the home. He has four children, and his experience is that mother can never keep up.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UP) -- Following is the text of the State Department's reply today to the Soviet charges:
WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., April 18 -- The start of a program to develop a resident college of Long Island University at the Suffolk County Air Force Base was announced here today.

JERSEY CITY, April 18 -- Mayor John J. Grogan of Hoboken was urged today by the members of the Hudson County Democratic Council to seek the leadership of the state organization. The council said it would support any effort he might make to replace George E. Brunner, Democratic state chairman.

" When we came into office four years ago * * * our streets were heavily congested with slow-moving cars. * * * Congestion on the streets is a costly inconvenience." -- Mayor Wagner in second inauguration address. Jan. 1, 1958.

NORTHVILLE, L. I., April 18 -- Farmers on Long Island, frustrated by the latest plowing season on record, rolled their mechanized forces into the fields this week for the third time in as many weeks. One farmer here on the North Shore, while industriously joining the move, probably is the least disturbed of them all over the wet, soggy spring.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -This City of Brotherly Love, which became a one-team town in 1955 and almost immediately learned to grin and bear it -New Yorkers please copy -- welcomed home the Phillies tonight.
Tony Kubek, who got into his Yankee uniform for yesterday's home opener, also got into a conversation about his mixed-up military status and more or less cleared it up.

Robert Moses was charged yesterday with "irresponsibly, capriciously and arbitrarily" breaking a contract that would have permitted operation of an outdoor theatre at Central Park's Wollman Skating Rink this summer.
DETROIT, April 18 (AP) -- The auto industry will hold down production next week by laying off about 30,000 workers at assembly plants across the nation.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he had asked Governor Harriman to veto a bill increasing from thirteen to twenty the number of Supreme Court Justices in the Tenth Judicial District. The district consists of Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
LONDON, April 18 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a Moscow news conference statement today by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, as issued in English by Tass, the Soviet news agency:

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 18 -- Jakarta's triumphant troops struck out from captured Padang today in a drive toward the rebel capital of Bukittinggi, sixty miles away, a military spokesman said here tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- An initiative that makes Washington a meeting place for the contemporary composers of the Americas has been long overdue. Since this country regards itself as a cultural leader of the Western Hemisphere, it is high time that it undertook something ambitious to implement its pretensions.
A consolidated suit by 368 concerns seeking $3,763,769 was filed yesterday in the Federal Court, Brooklyn, against the Luckenbach Steamship Company, Inc.

A race that has come to be accepted as one of this locality's most interesting competitions -- the Wood Memorial -- will be contested at Jamaica today. Worth $50,000 added, the mile-and-an-eighth event is for 3-year-olds and it is likely that seven of them will participate in the thirty-fourth running.

PARIS, April 18 -- Before World War II the writer once engaged in argument with the buxom, faintly mustachioed patronne of a small Paris bistro. "Ah," said she by way of summing up, "you Americans were chics in 1917 -- not now."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 18 -- Abundant world supplies of coffee from crops in 1957-58 may be exceeded in the 1958-59 harvest, the Food and Agriculture Organization reports in its March Bulletin of Agricultural Statistics.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -The Pentagon, Congress and the press engaged in new controversy today over defense information policies.
I should like to comment on Prof. Charles Black's animadversions in your issue of March 23 on my piece in your issue of March 16. In brief, I remain unconvinced of error; I still stick to my guns.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -The Atomic Energy Commission said today it planned to resubmit a modified proposal for construction of a large atomic power plant by the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company.
LONDON, April 18 -- The spot rate for the pound sterling in terms of the dollar rose today to $2.81 7/8. This was the highest since July 7, 1954.

The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange on April 15 was somewhat below the level of the preceding month but was still close to a twenty-seven-year high. It was 4,405,118 shares, compared with 14,460,660 on March 14.
Two very gifted singers made debuts last night with the New York City Opera Company in Mark Bucci's one-act opera, "Tale for a Deaf Ear."

May potato futures fell the 30-point (hundredths of a cent a pound) daily limit on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday. The decline was termed a technical reaction following a recent sharp rise.
A small tailor named Anton Joseph was called upon yesterday to make a Russia-bound American basketball team look fashionable, happy, wrinkle-free and prosperous.
Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, has accepted the proposal of the faculty adviser of the student newspaper that the adviser attend editorial board meetings only upon invitation.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. yesterday charged the management of the Lexington Hotel with laxity in sounding a fire alarm and prematurely turning off the sprinkler system.
EZRA POUND'S literary output has poured forth steadily and his literary reputation has flourished despite his confinement in St. Elizabeths Hospital in Washington.

The Soviets have started the ambassadorial talks in preparation for a summit meeting by launching two typical maneuvers that are in keeping with their established Machiavellian strategy and fall into the category described by President Eisenhower as "gimmicks."
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The State Department has cautioned all foreign embassies and legations here to crack down on employes profiteering in tax-free automobiles, liquor and cigarettes.

Recently the intelligence was received here with the utmost sympathy and understanding that in Caracas, Venezuela, it takes weeks for city letters to be delivered and that they often get lost; that a letter from Caracas to some other Latin-American capital may take a month in transit; and that the telephone service is an atrocity.
Events today: Giannini's "The Taming of the Shrew," New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; New York Philharmonic Young People's Concert, Leonard Bernstein conducting, Carnegie Hall, noon.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 18 (AP) -- Rush IV, owned by Victor Sherona of Philadelphia and sailed by George O'Day of Manhasset, L. I., won the K. F. Trimingham Cup for 5 1/2-meter yachts today.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Democrats won approval of a Congressional committee today for a $1,500,000,000 unemployment relief program.
GENEVA, April 18 -- An improvised coalition of Canada, India and Mexico ran aground today on the rocks of the territorial sea issue at the United Nations conference on maritime law.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Treason charges against Ezra Pound were dismissed today, opening the way for the 72-year-old poet's return to Italy.

This morning I asked my two young children to tell me what they knew of the "Minute Men." Neither knew the meaning of the name. So we took a few minutes at breakfast for a short lesson in American history.

A Worcester, Mass., coat manufacturer, who sold inferior-grade cashmere ladies coats, bearing labels of a well-known New York cashmere apparel manufacturer, was ordered in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday to stop the fraudulent labeling of coats as "100 per cent cashmere."
Ralph Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, reported yesterday that shipowners from eighteen countries had agreed to oppose a "genuine shipping link" clause.
A smoldering crate containing radioactive uranium 238 was hosed down by firemen at the Sunnyside, Queens, railroad freight yard last night and then removed to a Queens laboratory.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -Marion B. Folsom stressed today that $25,000,000,000 annually would be required within the next ten years "merely to keep up with enrollment increases" in the nation's schools and colleges.
Republican women gave a spring showing yesterday of fashions and the style of their party's campaign for the November elections.
Building a carport for a gas station can be like child's play. The materials are metal strips strongly resembling the basic sections of a child's construction set -- but man size.

Rufus Lisle has been appointed general manager of the National Housing Center in Washington, D. C. Mr. Lisle was with the Frigidaire Division of General Motors for sixteen years, and since 1956 has been Washington representative of the United States Plywood Corporation.
LONDON, April 18 -- The question of how much meat, hors d'oeuvre, or salad can be piled on a slice of bread and still qualify as a sandwich was argued today in court-like proceedings.
Spring's painting jobs will be done with better brushes this year.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 18 -- Two giants of American industry officially became part of the 1958 Brussels World Fair today.

NEWPORT, R. I., April 18 -- Mrs. Anita O'Keefe Young, widow of Robert R. Young, was allowed to exercise rights to buy 100,000 common shares of Allegheny Corporation at 3.06 1/4 a share under a ruling handed down by Judge Fred B. Perkins in Superior Court here today.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, April 18 -- Sir Grantley H. Adams, former Prime Minister of Barbados, was elected by the party leaders of the House today as the first Prime Minister of the West Indies Federation.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 18 (AP) -- Clarence Cunningham, clerk of the Berkeley Society of Friends, predicted today that there would be some response from the atomic power leaders to whom the Quaker group sent radioactive vegetables Tuesday.

PARIS, April 18 -- Amory Houghton, United States Ambassador, was asked today by the French Government to explain United States press reports from Paris indicating Washington would welcome negotiations between France and the Algerian rebels to end the forty-one-month-old war in Algeria.
MOSCOW, April 18 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States today of flying planes carrying nuclear bombs over the Arctic "in the direction of the borders of the Soviet Union."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 18 -- Henry Jaffe Enterprises has selected "The Magic Fishbone," a fairy tale by Charles Dickens, as the next property to be filmed by Screen Gems for the "Shirley Temple's Storybook" television series.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, April 18 -- United States military authorities in West Germany are cracking down on automobile salesmen who have bilked United States servicemen of many thousands of dollars.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a $3,207,973,039 bill to run the agriculture Department and related agencies in the fiscal year starting July 1.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Administration pressed its campaign for Pentagon reorganization today.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's visit to Camp David has caused a temporary lay-off of 150 workers on a construction project there.
WHITE PLAINS, April 18--Fines collected from traffic violators on the roads of the Westchester County Parkway Authority can be retained by local communities, contrary to previous indications.
A burglar posing as a workman stole $57,500 worth of jewelry from two Douglaston Manor homes in Queens yesterday.

A real estate operator, described as a "possible front man for certain high Building Department officials" was sentenced yesterday to thirty days in jail and fined $250 for criminal contempt of court.

All sections of the transportation industry are not feeling a traffic shortage. Lawrence D. Rahilly, president of the Interstate Motor Freight System of Grand Rapids, Mich., declared yesterday that "there's plenty of freight available. There isn't any depression."

MADRID, April 17 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco has approved a program of official calls and ceremonial visits to be undertaken by Prince Juan Carlos of Spain when he arrives in the United States early in May.
The Committee to Secure Justice for Morton Sobell yesterday lost a court attempt to force the Tavern on the Green to reinstate a dinner reservation the restaurant canceled last Monday.
SPORTSMEN in New York State have done more than ever this year to hold down the starvation of deer in the time of heavy snows but it is already plain that the death count will be high.

MOSCOW, April 18 -- The Soviet Union and the Western Big Three -- the United States, Britain and France -- are in the midst of talks that may determine whether or not an East-West heads - of - government meeting is possible in the near future.
RABAT, Morocco, April 18 -- Morocco would welcome United States intervention to speed a solution of the Algerian problem, Mehdi Ben Barka, president of the National Consultative Assembly said today.
Roman Catholic and Protestant agencies are pushing their appeals for charity and for relief supplies.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Defense Department announced today plans to build two more bases for launching of intercontinental ballistic missiles.

OMAHA, Neb., April 7 -- Imagine that you are the commander of a B-52 jet bomber of the United States Strategic Air Command. You are in flight toward an enemy target. The appointment of former Deputy Mayor William Reid as chairman of a reorganized New York City Housing Authority was announced by Mayor Wagner yesterday.

Net sales of the St. Joseph Lead Company in the first quarter declined to $18,226,561 from $31,572,820 in the corresponding period last year.
The Fire Department closed two more downtown loft buildings yesterday in its campaign against safety violations.
DETROIT, April 18 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that new car sales for the first ten days of April were at a rate of 13,330 units a day.
A slight movement by a human in a space vehicle in orbit would cause it to oscillate up to half an hour, members of the Institute of Environmental Engineers were told yesterday.

The letter published April 11 from Mrs. Eleanor Clark French, acting vice chairman of the Democratic State Committee, on Governor Harriman's record in dealing with crime was remarkable for what she left unstated.

TOKYO, April 18 -- The Kishi Government will dissolve the Diet toward the end of next week, the Liberal Democratic party announced today. The date of the national elections is expected to be set at about May 22.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Average wholesale primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent to 119.4 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

HAVANA, April 18 -- The youthful followers of Fidel Castro have gone into hiding throughout Cuba. They are striving desperately to reorganize their rebellion against President Fulgencio Batista and to escape the army's relentless killings.

LIKE most families today, the Joneses and the Smiths try to keep astronomically high living costs down by economizing on food. One evening recently, Mrs. Jones served her family of four what she considered a thrifty dinner.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Attorney General of Pennsylvania defended before a Senate committee today the fees he had received from a Phildelphia Teamsters' Union now uner investigation.

Mrs. Robert S. Williams Jr. has been named head of the junior committee that is assisting with final plans for the annual dinner dance of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association of the City of New York. The fete will take place Tuesday in the Crystal Ballroom of the Park Lane.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The United States declared today it would be happy to have the United Nations take up Soviet charges that United States nuclear-armed bombers had made "provocative flights" across the Arctic toward the Soviet Union.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 18 (AP) -- The Oklahoma Sooners' sprint medley team bettered the American and intercollegiate record in 3:19.5 and two meet marks were set in the first half of the thirty-third Kansas Relays today.

BRUSSELS, April 18 -- The classic American formula for selling automobiles and toothpaste -- spacious dramatic background and pretty girls -- is helping to sell the American standard of living to visitors to the Brussels World's Fair.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 18 (AP) -- Tim Tam, one of the favorites for the May 3 Kentucky Derby, raced to a half-length victory at Keeneland today and set a track record. The thirty-sixth annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America will be held from May 5 to 9 in Washington in the Shoreham Hotel.
A program of self-help for the city's 800,000 Spanish-speaking citizens was urged yesterday by the Council of Spanish - American Organizations of Greater New York.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The life expectancy of the Vanguard satellite was put at "at least 200 years" today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 19 -- Arthur Knapp Jr., with Agony in the Interclub division, and Runyon Colie, with Doon V among the Penguins, took the leads in the annual spring invitation regatta for frostbite dinghies at Larchmont Yacht Club today.
