ALL sorts of containers are usable as planters and the variety and form are limited only by the imagination and ingenuity of the gardener. The planter may be round, square, oblong, rectangular or bowl shaped.

A born baker, who tried to detour a little and become a banker, only to be tossed back to his native ovens by chance, today heads one of the few companies that expects to make as much money in 1958 as it made in 1957 -- or maybe a little more.
Several New York rabbis delivered sermons yesterday in tribute to the tenth anniversary of the founding of Israel as a nation on May 14, 1948.

America's defense depends largely on human brains that conceive missiles and military aircraft, supplemented by electronic devices that test, guide, control and shield the weapons. The electronic heart of defense is the computer -giant, medium and small. This is the same instrument that is increasing office and factory automation by performing complex arithmetic in minutes instead of hours, days and even months.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -Shutouts long have been Warren Spahn's specialty, so it hardly was surprising that the southpaw stylist of the Milwaukee Braves blanked the Phillies, 5 -- 0, today at Connie Mack Stadium.

AN automatic garage door operator can provide a homeowner with the convenience of being able to open or close his garage door without getting out of the car. Not only will these electronic gadgets eliminate the need for having to wade through snow, rain, or high winds, they can also permit control from inside the house, from inside the garage -- or from almost any other point.
Fifteen thousand persons are expected to march up Fifth Avenue today in the annual Greek Independence Day Parade sponsored by the American-Hellenic Societies of Greater New York.
IN mid-October, 1956, a party leader addressed a large audience of students at a Northeastern university. He held up an "I Like Ike" button and was greeted with loud cheer.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 19 -- Juvenile crime in Nassau County increased by 22 per cent in 1957, according to a report issued this week by John M. Beckmann, Commissioner of Police.

Thousands of parents are looking forward with pride -- and in many cases with relief -- to the graduation of their sons and daughters from college this spring. They have learned, often painfully, that the cost of higher education has more than doubled since 1940.

CAIRO. AN official ban has failed to dim the fascination that rock 'n' roll has among the sons and daughters of Egypt's elite. But it has forced it from the dance floor into the privacy of the better homes.
WARSAW. AFTER a frantic year or two of rocking and rolling Poland is tapering off into a slightly calmer stage of a craze that no political screening could filter out of Eastern Europe.
The average candidate for obsessional, schizoid, etc," personality traits, but they are "compatible with adequate or superior functioning" in that calling, according to a report issued yesterday.

AMERICA is showing a stunning cinematic profile these days inside its Brussels Fair Pavilion via "loops." What are they? Twenty-five diverse, two-and-a-half-minute color vignettes reflecting our scene and way of life, looped to run continuously inside as many projectors, and splashed on screens of varying shapes and sizes throughout the huge rotunda.
Tests of the noise characteristics of the Boeing 707 jet transport will be held tomorrow through Wednesday in Seatle, the Port of New York Authority announced yesterday.
WARSAW, April 19 -- The new ideological dispute between Moscow and Belgrade has spilled over to affect the Polish Communist party.

Jimmy Hoffa, never noted for his humility, has been working hard at being inconspicuous since he took over the presidency of the giant International Brotherhood of Teamsters last January. His retreat from the spotlight is based on a hope that his critics in Government and labor will stop throwing bricks at him if he keeps quiet.
The optimistic outlook of a year ago was absent last week at the twenty-ninth annual meeting of the Shipbuilders Council of America.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- In Florida, where land and water are equally important elements to the flourishing vacation industry, the battle between the automobile and the boat is on in earnest. Bridges are the subject at issue.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- In less than two and a half years, 400 children born with crippled hearts have benefited by new surgical techniques at Federal expense.

THERE is a general belief that foreign aid is the job of the Government alone. But in actual fact no Government can ever replace the individual, his self-reliance, his initiative, his sense of self-responsibility. No dollars-to-person program can ever replace a person-to-person program.

WE received a friendly but forceful letter from a reader the other day taking us to task for what she considers an "error of omission" in our writings. We have made the point repeatedly in general terms that "every child is an individual," and said that parents in their efforts to educate and guide must be sensitive to the unique responses of each of their young.
SHORT HILLS, N. J., April 19 -- Mrs. Garfield Gifford is setting out to prove that two organizations can live together as cheaply as one -- and have more money and services to give away, too.

The business recession continues to ring the bond market with a bright silver lining. As the lag in industrial activity continues, capital is being enticed more and more from the equity gambles of the stock market into the sheltered field of fixed-income investment.

GENEVA, April 19 -- The United Nations conference on the law of the sea rejected today in committee a United States compromise proposal to fix international limits for territorial seas and fishing zones.
Teen-agers from some of the city's toughest neighborhoods said yesterday that adults had some growing up to do.

AFTER the first dismay over the fire at the Museum of Modern Art, second thought must emphasize the good fortune that the damage was so restricted. For this the devotion and efficiency of the museum staff with volunteer aid cannot be too highly praised.
Social problems, no matter how urgent, cannot justify birth control methods that are against "natural law," Roman Catholic lawyers were told yesterday by a Jesuit authority on population studies.
THURMONT, Md., April 19 (AP) -- Blessed with perfect spiting weather, President Eisenhower began enjoying it early today with a round of golf.

THE old-fashioned shrub roses are making a comeback. The flowers that once graced dooryards and formal gardens are appearing in suburban lots, collectors' gardens and shrub borders. Rosebushes may be set out now while they are just beginning growth. They should bloom this year.

French provincial commodes, buffets and other pieces, together with old silver, oriental rugs and other decorations will be auctioned on Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue
Sales of electric power to industry last year accounted for 50.8 per cent of the kilowatt hours, but for only 27.9 per cent of the electric revenues of utility companies.

THE discovery of species tulips led to a fascinating adventure in gardening. Having grown a number of tulip varieties from the early flowering cottage type to tall, later-blooming Darwins, I was advised to try a few species tulips.

AT last! Hills are golden with daffodils, magnolias show pink-white saucers and forsythia is showered with yellow blossoms. Spring is a little late this year, but now that the flower pageant has begun, it's excused.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP) -- The Marine Corps disclosed today that it was arming its troops with nine kinds of missiles.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Poetry won one of its rare victories over politics this week. Yesterday the Federal District Court here dismissed a twelve-year-old treason charge against Ezra Pound. The dismissal will be followed by Pound's release soon from St. Elizabeth's, the Federal mental hospital where he has been confined since 1945.
Soviet and American scientists have agreed to a four month extension of the deadline for publication of data gleaned from earth satellites. It is now to be made public within one year.
BOSTON, April 19 (AP) -- Vince Shomo retained his 139-pound title tonight in the seventieth National Amateur Athletic Union boxing championships at the Garden.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 19 -- Crown Prince Faisal, Premier of Saudi Arabia, announced in a statement published here today that his Government would not join the United Arab Republic or the rival Arab Federation, but would cooperate with both groups.

ATHENS, April 19 -- Though the candidates are conducting whirlwind campaigns in traditional fashion, their platforms for the parliamentary elections three weeks hence appear to differ only in minor respects.

TOKYO, April 10 -- A nationwide survey made recently by the Agriculture and Forestry Ministry on farm land developments in Japan since 1950, when the land reform program was completed, indicates that the Japanese farming population is continuing to decrease gradually every year.

ABILENE, Tex., April 19 (AP) -- Bill Woodhouse of Abilene Christian equaled the world records for the 100 and 220 yard dashes today. He sped the distances in 9.3 and 20 seconds in leading his team to victory in a triangular meet.
ADELANTO, Calif., April 19 (AP) -- Robert Symons, one of the nation's most daring rescue pilots, was killed today in a glider accident near here.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 15 -- The Holy Synod of the Bulgarian Orthodox Church has called upon parish priests to support a Communist drive for 100 per cent collectivization of the land.
LONDON, April 19 (AP) -- Sources close to the family of Sir Winston Churchill said tonight the former Prime Minister had suffered a new attack of illness that had briefly alarmed his household.
MEXICO CITY, April 18 -- President Luis Anastasio Somoza de Bayle's stand against Presidential succession is causing keen interest in diplomatic circles here.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., April 19 -- The year-old "Farm Gang" program at the Suffolk County jail was credited here this week with cutting food budgets at county institutions by $50,000.

FOR the Negro, the Civil War and the end of slavery were but the beginning of liberation. There was a long way to go before the rights of a man and a citizen, which were always his due, were slowly accorded him.

A new kind of dacron for sails, the revival of an old idea in perforated spinnakers and a substitute for kapok in life preservers were among the things that turned up during a visit last week to City Island, commercial heart of New York yachting.
NEW LONDON, Conn., April 19 -- The nation's four armed forces academies completed here today their first move toward closer interservice cooperation.

THE business of awards reached its low point last Tuesday evening with the Emmys of the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. Some gifted and altogether fine people received recognition but the academy's whole approach to the matter of distributing praise and encouragement leaves much to be desired.
MOSCOW, April 19 -- There was a good deal of nit-picking this week on whether the talks of the ambassadors on preparations for a summit meeting had seriously begun.

LINCOLN, R. I., April 19 (AP) -- Staging a fine run through the stretch. Paul Bongarzone's Zolt won the $10,000 Patriots' Day Handicap today at Lincoln Downs, scoring by a nose over the favored Double Bid.
BOSTON, April 19 -- Franjo Mihalic, a pale and wan printer from Yugoslavia, today outran 158 other hoofers (and hitchhikers) in the sixty-second annual Boston Marathon.

THIS eminently competent history of ancient Israel is the work of one of Germany's leading Old Testament scholars. It tells the dramatic story of the Hebrews from their origins to the Second Jewish Revolt against Rome in 132-135 A. D., which ended in catastrophe for the Jews, fighting for freedom under Simeon Bar-Kochba.
A device by which aircraft can be identified on a radar screen is undergoing preliminary testing at the New York air traffic control center.

ONE of the unusual features of the Brussels Fair officially inaugurated on April 17 is that art holds its own next to science and industry in addition to the great international exhibition at the International Palace of Fine Arts many of the exhibiting countries have provided a place and often an important place for art in their pavilions.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 19 -- South Africa voted this week for five more years of apartheid -- a policy of white supremacy and strict segregation of the races.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UP) -- Roy Sievers' game-tying homer and a run-producing pinch single by Ed Fitz Gerald in the ninth inning enabled the Washington Senators to edge the Boston Red Sox, 4 -- 3, today.
Tape readers will find their opportunities for profit curbed a bit after May 1, when the higher commission rates go into effect on the New York Stock Exchange.

WITH the evidence of the Moiseyev Dance Company before us, we might just as well break down and admit that the Russians are the dancingest people -- or group of peoples -in the world. They took over the classic ballet -- tutu, toeshoe and tour en l'air -- generations ago; now they are setting up a similar monopoly in another field, that of the folk dance.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Former President Herbert Hoover supports President Eisenhower's defense reorganization plan, it was made known today.

Warmer weather in many parts of the country stimulated sales of summer apparel to help volume last week, which compared with the Easter week last year. Merchants reported deliveries in medium and better-priced merchandise were about normal.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Secretary of Defense and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff gave emphatic assurance today that there could not be an unauthorized bomber strike against the Soviet Union.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 19 -- One lesson to be drawn from the crowds at the first week-end of the Brussels World Fair of 1958 is that Americans are strong and earnest travelers but that they like to feel at home while they are abroad.

THE growing popularity of frozen foods has prompted hybridizers to create new fruit and vegetable varieties. Home gardeners, who often harvest more than the family can use at one time, would be wise to plan this year's vegetable plot to include a selection of new and old varieties that can be frozen with good results.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 19 -- Indonesian Government troops were reported tonight to have succeeded in splitting the hard-pressed rebel forces on Sumatra.

New York will play host this week to more than 1,200 newspaper executives from the United States, Canada, Alaska, British, Columbia and the Territory of Hawaii. They will gather at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in observance of New York's annual Press Week and take part in a five-day series of meetings, conventions and seminars.
A fighter for democracy in Argentina is back in this country to spread cheerful news.

HONG KONG, April 19 (UP) -- Armed Communist Chinese patrol boats have been stopping Hong Kong fishing junks in the territorial waters of this British crown colony, Chinese reports said today. A Government spokesman said Royal Navy patrol boats had been ordered to investigate and patrol the area.
BOMBAY. THERE is one fairly firm sign that rock 'n' roll has at least a foothold on the Indian-Pakistani subcontinent. In Bombay, Gopal Punjabi is on to it.

POPLAR trees often are not recommended for the average home grounds. Their wood is brittle and the roots are aggressive. (Poplar roots have been known to stop up drains and sewer lines that were sixty feet from the tree.)

THE effect of American movies upon people in foreign lands and the consequent help or injury this may do our reputation abroad is a question that many people have agonized over for years. It is almost as popular a topic as the effect of American movies upon the people of the United States.
PITTSBURGH, April 19 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9 -- 6, today by combining five Pirate errors and an eleven-hit attack into a free scoring game.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Thus far most of the opposition to President Eisenhower's Pentagon reorganization plan has come from Congress. The views of the military have been expressed only indirectly, through private professional associations or service partisans in the Capitol.

THE brilliant victory of the young American pianist Van Cliburn in last week's International Tchaikovsky Competition here and the excellent showing made by three other young Americans, two of whom won substantial prizes, is an achievement in which we can all take great pride.

THIS is the time of year when the income tax people tell the one about the two clergymen and the revenue agent who, departing this world, arrived at the Pearly Gates simultaneously. After hearing out all three, St. Peter waved the tax man through forthwith, but kept the gentlemen of the cloth cooling their heels for an hour.

Born of stern foreign competition and reared under such adverse conditions as a worldwide depression and two world wars, the Finland Steamship Company, Ltd., has emerged as an important Scandinavian maritime unit.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- George W. Healy Jr., 52 years old, editor of The New Orleans Times-Picayune, was installed tonight as the new president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 19 (AP) -- Gail Hodgson, the middle-distance star of the Oklahoma Sooners, and Eddie Southern of Texas led their teams to record performances as seven meet standards were smashed in the thirty-third Kansas Relays today.

CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ind., April 19 (UP) -- About 700 girls attending a state young people's convention were stricken with food poisoning today shortly after eating ham salad sand-wishes at the group's luncheon.

With Hirsch Jacobs, a trainer, as its trunk, the Jacobs horse-racing family tree has now spread three generations of branches over the thorough-bred scene.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 19 -- The Jenner bill and other measures to strip the Supreme Court of some of its power were deplored at a Notre Dame Law School symposium.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Norman Cousins described the Government tonight as a "house divided against itself" on policy matters.

BEETHOVEN: Piano Concerto No. 4; Emil Gilels and Philharmonia Orchestra conducted by Leopold Ludwig (Angel). A good performance but not a very good buy, for Serkin on a Columbia disk plays not only this G major Concerto but also No. 2 in B flat.

THE Greeks had a word for prickly skinned creatures -- Echinodermata. Scientists borrowed the name for some tough, ingenious, ocean-going gangsters who wear nature's own version of a bullet-proof vest -- a tough external skeleton.

ATHENS, April 18 -- Frank Grismer, chief of the United States Operations Mission here, said that the "total contribution from American citizens to this Greek military effort during the last two years is about half as great as that financed by Greek taxpayers."

FREUD and Proust have familiarized the contemporary reader with such relationships as the fascinating one that began in the summer of 1798, when Germaine Necker, Baroness of Stael-Holstein, first met Juliette Recamier. Mme. de Stael, one of the most fertile minds of the transitional period that saw sentimentality burgeoning into romanticism, was 31 at the time, and Juliette, a banker's wife and perhaps the most celebrated beauty of the day, was 21.
DETROIT, April 19 -- The men who attempted to assassinate Walter P. Reuther on April 20, 1948, may be free from possible prosecution after tomorrow.

The eighteenth game of the world chess championship match between Vassily Smyslov and Mikhail Botvinnik, the challenger, begun in Moscow yesterday, was adjourned after forty-one moves in favor of Smyslov.
THERE is, to be sure, nothing like a dame, and Dee Brown proves the point once more in a wise and witty report on those indomitable females who came, saw and conquered the West.

HISTORY is being made at the City Center this spring. After crying in the wilderness for years, American opera has been challenged to fill an entire, ambitious season. A theatre form which was supposed to be alien to our natures is seeking to prove that it has adapted itself to our environment, that it has achieved a distinctive native hue and character and that in this guise it can stand on its own feet.

An outstanding phenomenon in the world of sea commerce in the last ten years has been the growth of tremendous fleets of ships under the flags of small nations that previously had no status as maritime powers.

QUITE a few writers have imagined what would happen if a Being with supernatural powers were to descend on a modern city and try to make that city behave better. Upton Sinclair has now taken a hand at it.

A THREE-DAY exhibition devoted exclusively to ikebana -- the art of Japanese flower arrangement -- will open Thursday at the Nippon Club, 7 East Ninety-sixth Street. Visitors will be welcome from 11 A. M. to 9 P. M.
WARSAW, April 19 -- Fifteen thousand people made a pilgrimage tonight to a deserted spot that once was the center of Warsaw's ghetto.
BERLIN, April 19 -- A statement by Bulgarian and East German leaders published here today advocated a series of compacts banning atomic and rocket weapons in zones of Europe and Asia.

A dance will be held next Sunday in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza to aid the operations in Israel of the Cooperative for American Remittances to Everywhere (CARE). The Motion Picture Chapter of the American Veterans Committee is sponsoring the event, which will commemorate the tenth anniversary of the State of Israel.

In perspective our official interchange in recent weeks with leaders of the U. S. S. R., reaching a high record for canny caution, has little to show for creative humanity. Pre-eminence in suspicion, a necessary factor of public defense, solves no problems of world peace.

At a race track a 235-for-1 pay-off would be considered excellent. Last week Westchester County officials sold at auction 1,000 shares of St. Louis-Southwestern Railroad common stock for $235 a share. As recently as 1944 the bid price was $1 a share.

MANY are the names we Americans celebrate. There are the winners of Hollywood's Oscars; baseball's most valued player of the year; the United States Chamber of Commerce's outstanding young executives; the members of the insurance industry's million-dollar club; the automobile dealer who has sold the most Chevrolets or Fords; the Miss Americas of past and present, and scores of champion skaters, bowlers skeet shooters and fancy divers.
There will be a get-together of society folk this afternoon in the Pierre ballroom to celebrate an anniversary.

AS devotedly chic and air-minded as a pretty stewardess preparing for her first flight, the new International Hotel on the edge of New York's Idlewild airport makes its debut May 8, and the primping and beautifying going on out there these days are wonderful.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 15 -- Mere than thirty planeloads of dairy cattle will move through St. Petersburg-Clearwater International Airport during the next few months. They will be transported to Colombia to pay for all-expense vacations there for midwestern farmers.

THE twenty-fifth annual Gala Night Show of the Metropolitan Motion Picture Club will offer a varied program of eleven amateur films, some of them prize winners, at 8:15 P. M. Friday, May 23, in the Assembly Hall at Hunter College at Sixty-ninth Street and Lexington Avenue.

THE first, and probably the greatest, of the many things biography does for us is to open up the infinite possibilities in people's lives. There is no time when this is more thrilling or more potentially productive than when the reader's own life is just beginning to open up to its possibilities.

OTTAWA. JUST as the cold air from Canada tends to move south into the United States, American manners and mores, ignoring border formalities, sweep northward across the 3,987 miles of undefended frontier to become part of the Canadian way of life.
Israel's tenth anniversary as a nation will be observed in a "Salute to Freedom" ceremony at the Polo Grounds next Sunday afternoon, beginning at 2 o'clock.

Jewel's Reward, 3-10, won the $59,500 Wood Memorial by half a length at Jamaica yesterday. Noureddin was second and Martins Rullah third. A claim of foul against the winner was disallowed. A crowd of 44,078 watched the race.

TWO more cruise ships will be visiting Nassau this spring, the Grace Line's Santa Paula and Santa Rosa. Starting with the May 2 sailing from New York of the former, the ships, sailing on twelve-day cruises to the Caribbean, will stop there instead of at Cartagena, Colombia.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- President Eisenhower is expected to send Congress another defense reorganization message within a week or two. This time it involves nonmilitary defense.

SPYROS SKOURAS, president of Twentieth Century-Fox, believes with all his heart that the "greatest days" for the motion-picture business lie ahead and not behind. Yet he is not a starry-eyed optimist.
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The State Department has relaxed its restrictions on foreign travel by Paul Robeson.

Sir Harold Nicolson in his review of the fourth and final volume of Winston Churchill's history suggests that many American readers will be surprised to discover that the Monroe Doctrine when originally promulgated in 1823 would not have been tolerated by the European powers had it not been supported by the "friendly vigilance" of the British Navy. Sir Harold goes on to quote Sir Winston as saying, "This is a fact seldom openly acknowledged."

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 19 (AP) -- William S. Miller's Better Bee closed out a fine Florida campaign today by winning the $25,000 Southern Cross Handicap, feature race of the final Saturday program at Gulfstream Park.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., April 19 -- Content and method in American education were discussed here today. A physicist stressed the need for solid instruction and an educationist emphasized the practice of values.
BARBADOS, B. W. I. -- The taxi and its conductor are indispensable in the West Indies. In fact, they are among the islands' great natural resources today.

OVER and over again the question last week has been: "Is this Van Cliburn really that good?" It was asked by people who were delighted with his triumph in Moscow and were eager to believe the best. It was asked by a skeptical few who cannot rid themselves of the prejudice that a foreigner is somehow automatically superior as a virtuoso to a tall young man from Texas.

Herman Belz' two-run homer with two out in the top of the ninth enabled the Princeton right-hander to win his own game yesterday at Baker Field. Belz' clout produced a 3-2 victory for the Tigers over Columbia in an Eastern Intercollegiate League test.

No one who has seen the attendance at museums, especially on week-ends, can fail to be impressed by the important cultural role these galleries have come to play in the lives of enormous numbers of people.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 19 -- Science and its application in industry will be demonstrated for three days, starting Thursday, at the Westbury Mid-Island Science Fair.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 19 -- Gov. Frank G. Clement will receive next Tuesday a report on the state's investigation of Criminal Court Judge Raulston Schoolfield of Chattanooga.
A tour of the work studios of seven noted painters and sculptors is being arranged for next Saturday. Proceeds of the event will aid in the work of the Community Service Society.
In its latest move to doctor the ailing economy, the Federal Reserve is trying a new and slightly different prescription.
HARTFORD, April 19 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff denounced today the anti-recession program adopted by the special session of the General Assembly.
Former President Herbert Hoover underwent an operation at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center yesterday for the removal of his gall bladder.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., April 19 (UP) -- An Air Force Thor missile blew up on the launching stand today.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., April 19 -- The team of nineteen amateur frogmen descended into near-by Sackets Harbor in Lake Ontario here today to study what may prove to be a relic of the War of 1812.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 19 (AP) -- Pascual Perez of Argentina retained his world flyweight boxing title tonight by outpointing Venezuela's young Ramon Arias in a fifteen-round bout. The champion weighed 105 1/4 pounds. Arias was 109 1/2.

WARSAW, April 19 -- This may well become known here as the week in which Wladyslaw Gomulka said "enough" about the limbo in which the Polish Communist party has rested since his restoration as First Secretary eighteen months ago.
Truck operators indicated yesterday that their boycott of waterfront terminals here would continue this week in protest against new loading and unloading charges at piers.

Scientists were reminded yesterday of their importance to freedom. Dr. John R. Dunning, dean of the Columbia University School of Engineering. said they "are at this moment bearing a larger measure of responsibility for the survival of freedom than any profession has ever borne at one time in history."
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Congress is back after its Easter recess with its collective opinion about the same on foreign aid and foreign trade.

PETER FREUCHEN, who made something of a stir on television shortly before his death and whose recently published "Book of the Seven Seas" shows that the stir had something behind it. was a remarkable man. He lived for many years in Greenland, and he never lived anywhere without finding out everything he could about the place, its history, its people and its flora and fauna.
PONAPE, Eastern Caroline Islands, April 8 -- Ancient monarchic systems are being gradually transformed into basic constitutional democracy in the Eastern Carolines.

THE plight of the creative writer of the middle years long has been a subject for general lament. Money, encouragement are given younger writers of talent, and presumably the older ones either have become able to fully support themselves by writing or have drifted into other fields.

PARIS, April 19 -- France's nineteenth Government crisis in eleven years since the founding of the Fourth Republic has produced the usual crop of dire warnings that is the survival of republican institutions themselves that is at stake.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Walt Moryn and Dale Long produced five runs with homers in an eighth-inning rally today to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 6-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. It was the fourth triumph in a row for the Cubs.

THE woman who signed herself Varina Jefferson-Davis, her famous husband's death in 1889, holds a unique niche in American history. Against more than thirty First Ladies of the United States, there is only one First Lady of the Confederacy.

MARACAIBO, Venezuela -- Baked in daytime by the tropical sun and caressed at night by the trade winds of the Caribbean Sea, this "City of the Palms," founded by Spanish conquerors and often sacked thereafter by English raiders, thrives today on the modern industry of oil.
Despite another rash of unpleasant economic news last week, the stock market did pretty well.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The continuation of the bipartisan wait-and-see truce on tax-cutting after Congress returned this week from its Easter holiday, and the stepping-up of the Democratic drive for extended and enlarged Federal grants to the unemployed were clear indications of what the legislators heard in their constituencies on the subject of the economic recession.

DURING one of her occasional visits to this country from her home in Mexico, Dolores del Rio will appear in a live television drama this week. IT would be delightful to think that Isabel M. Stewart's account in her letter of the proposal of marriage made by Benjamin Jowett to Florence Nightingale was historically true. The evidence adduced in the letter is not convincing.

MOSCOW, April 19 -- Foreign Minister Gromyko called in the diplomatic representatives of fourteen Communist and neutral nations today to inform them officially of the start of talks with the Western powers concerning preparations of a summit meeting.

The forty-fourth annual meeting of the American Association of University Professors will be held in Denver, Colo., April 25-26. The organization, which has a membership of almost 40,000, will take action on a program for improving the economic status of teachers and will consider censuring some colleges and universities for recent faculty dismissals.

THE future of Sid Caesar's television program may be decided within the next two weeks. Helena Rubinstein, Inc., is committed under its initial contract to continue sponsorship through May 25, but the big question is whether the comedian will resume his show in the fall under the same auspices.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- If you can imagine Nikita S. Khrushchev as the Lorelei, atop a Soviet summit, crooning a song of peace to President Eisenhower as the boatman (accompanied by Prime Minister Macmillan and an unidentified Frenchman, and with Mr. Dulles manning the oars) while the Western statesmen drift ever closer to the rocks, you will have an accurate picture of the extraordinary state of East-West relations.

LOUIS H. WATSON died on St. Valentine's Day in 1936, when contract bridge was in its infancy and Mr. Watson was one of its youngest stars, 29 years old, and already a tournament veteran ranked in or near the top ten players.
Organized labor's own insurance company reported last week that it had its best year in 1957.

THE average home gardener has been subjected to many new fertilizer materials and methods of application in recent years. It is difficult to separate the chaff from the grain. Some helpful suggestions may be noted as a result of widespread tests.

AS an Egyptologist who is especially interested in Late Egyptian sculpture I should like to draw your attention to a picture which accompanied the review of Rex Warner's "The Young Caesar." It was captioned "Julius Caesar."
HONOLULU, April 19 -- Hawaii's sugar strike has surpassed in length and in wage and income losses the first territory-wide strike, that of 1946.

As Casey Stengel hustled himself off the Yankee bench, directly after his Bombers had squeezed through to a 4-3 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles yesterday, he was heard to mutter, "I guess I know now how one of them airplane pilots feels when he runs out of gas."

RINGWOOD, N. J., April 19 -- A colony of nature's best-known engineers faces the loss of its home in Ringwood Manor State Park here. This is no fault of the colony, because even without being eager, it was doing what comes naturally to beavers -- building a dam.

LAUREL, Md., April 19 (AP) -- Boncrist Farm's Backbone was collared by the favorite, Montpelier's Nala, only yards from the finish but surged ahead to win the $24,125 Chesapeake Stakes by half a length today.
An Alton, Ill., woman received a packet containing $7,700 taken from her in a hold-up, with a note from the robber saying: "Sorry."
Final arrangements have been made for the third annual Heart of America Ball which will be held on April 29 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

THE last surviving giant of modern psychology, Carl Gustav Jung, will be 83 years old this July. It is amazing how fervently for or hostilely against Jung modern psychologists and psychoanalysts still show themselves to be when they discuss him and his work.

The Tuscarora Indians won a skirmish with the State Power Authority here yesterday when a Federal Judge handed down an order temporarily banning Authority surveyors from Indian territory in upstate New York.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 5 -- Many thousands of refugees from northern Brazil's drought area present a tragic social problem to add to the country's economic crisis.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Interior Department approved today an order permitting oil and gas leasing and the staking of mining claims on about 20,000,000 acres in Alaska above the Arctic Circle.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Mr. James C. Hagerty, the managing editor of the White House, had a good idea this week. For the amusement of the resident lady journalists and their visiting editors, he undertook to describe the kind of world the next White House press secretary would inherit and to define the qualities necessary for the job.

LONDON, April 19 (Reuters) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers clinched the English League's first division soccer title today as they defeated second-place Preston North End by 2 -- 0 before a home crowd of 48,000.

LONDON, April 19 (Reuters) -- The United States Embassy said today it had instructions to confiscate the passport of Peggy Seeger, American folk singer, who made an unauthorized visit to Communist China last year.

The State Banking Department has begun a drive to enforce a ban on wage assignments in installment sales contracts, according to George A. Mooney, State Superintendent of Banks.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., April 19 -- After thirty years as director of admissions at Mount Holyoke College here, Miss Harriet Newhall will retire next June.
Columbia crews swept the Harlem River yesterday to mark the beginning of a new coaching regime.

The major seaport of the Indonesian rebels on Sumatra, Padang, fell to the forces of President Sukarno with relatively little opposition. Jakarta's troops are now driving on the rebel capital and are apparently ahead of schedule. On the face of it, this first phase of the rebellion is drawing to a close.

Her memorable "February Hill" (1934) was a tender portrait of Jenny, a milltown deliquent, ironically trapped by a life that held out nothing but the hope of "better luck next time."
Air service will be offered to the businessman, sport fisherman and vacationer this year between New York and Montauk, L. I.

The work of the Near East Foundation will be furthered as a result of a card party its board of directors is arranging for the afternoon of May 6. Cleveland E. Dodge, foundation chairman, has announced that it will take place at the organization's headquarters at 54 East Sixty-fourth Street.

PARIS. CINEMASCOPE now has become an accepted part of French film-making and exhibition, though there was no television competition to bring it on. The city's garment center has successfully resisted changes aimed at easing traffic congestion, and the latest study made to effect such changes has been quietly shelved, it was learned yesterday.

ROME. ROCK 'n' roll is already vieux jeu, or old hat, in Italy. Calypso now holds the stage, but it also is heading for the exit. It is a favorite only because nothing newer has come along to displace it.

IN the novel, "Black Grapes," Livia de Stefani takes us behind the barred doors of a strange, haunted Sicilian family. Normally, Sicilian doors are wide open, and the Sicilian lives an external, communal existence that transforms every village piazza into a great, bustling living room.
LONDON, April 19 -- The British Government's hopes for a summit conference have been sharply reduced by recent Soviet actions, Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd said today.

THE hero of this English novel was no good and knew it, but his patient, loving wife, Betty, would not admit it. Her stubborn belief in his artistic talent and dogged industry drove him to drink. When, partly through his fault, she was badly injured in a street accident, he let her rich parents carry her off from the squalid home he had provided.
A national survey of blind students enrolled in colleges and universities has disclosed an urgent need for Braille books, recordings and other special equipment for their normal pursuit of knowledge.
ASILOMAR, Calif., April 19 -- Dr. Willard F. Libby said today that tests at Eniwetok this summer with a "clean" destroyed Hiroshima in World War II.

SHABBY, middle-aged, lonely and unloved, Dugommier seemed one of Nature's nobodies. He was a low-paid audit clerk working in Paris for a British firm of chartered accountants, the only Frenchman in a mixed group of English and Scottish exiles -- "old Dugommier, the chap with the baggy trousers who looked like a professor."
TOKYO. "IT is very rarely in the past that Japan has experienced anything like this," said the respected newspaper Yomiuri recently in what many Japanese must have taken to be a vast understatement.

IN "Nightwood," published in 1936, Djuna Barnes gave us a novel of extraordinary and appalling force, a study of moral degeneration recited in a rhetoric so intensely wrought, so violent and so artificial, that it discouraged all but the hardiest readers and became a kind of symbol of sinister magnificence.

" A single problem is at the root of the cabinet crisis and of French policy: the war in Algeria," the Paris newspaper Le Monde commented last week. Thus it summed up the causes of the latest crisis in France -- the crisis that on Wednesday brought the fall of the Government of Felix Gaillard.

The Story of Robert Smalls. By Dorothy Sterling. (Doubleday. $2.95. Illustrated by Ernest Crichlow. Ages 12 to 16.) -- In 1862 Robert Smalls, a slave-pilot, ran the Confederate steamer Planter out of Charleston and turned it over to the Union fleet.
Men, too, care how they look. They care to the extent that this year they are expected to spend more than $1,000,000,000 on personal grooming products and services, excluding clothing.
BOSTON, April 19 (UP) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney of Oklahoma said today that the Republicans had imposed a "prolonged quarantine on new thinking" about national and international problems.
TO SOME theatregoers, "Blue Denim" is the best American drama of the season.

Balmy weather last week hastened the parade of spring bloom. In New York City it's a week-end to see the single early cherries and magnolias. Grape hyacinths, daffodils, arabis and pansies also add welcome color.
Organized labor's top rackets fighter made a savage attack yesterday on "self-styled friends of labor" in the United States Senate.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 19 -- Marshal Tito started his third term as President of Yugoslavia today as a new squall blew up from the East.

IN warning us about the future death of the off-Broadway theatre in The Times last Sunday, a spokesman for the League of Off-Broadway Theatres refers to "End as a Man" as one of the "marginal productions" that would not survive today.
Last autumn the head of the house began a notable bit of construction. Neither prompted nor goaded by anyone, and indeed ignoring a good deal of sensible advice, he started to build a stone wall.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 19 -- Delvin Glenn Miller, the travellingest man in harness racing, made his season's debut at Roosevelt Raceway a successful one tonight. He drove in two races. He had two winners.
A cultural group here has enlisted the art work of a City College chemistry student from British Guiana to help celebrate the birth of the West Indies Federation.

The Smith College Glee Club joined forces with the Yale Glee Club, Orchestra and members of the Yale Band last night in Carnegie Hall to give the first New York performance of Paul Hindemith's "Canticle to Hope."

Negotiations are in progress for a heavyweight title fight between Floyd Patterson, and Roy Harris at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I., it was reported last night. The fight would be staged in August, after the track's harness racing meeting ends.

Public mental hospitals of the nation reported a decline in patient population for the second straight year. They also had more new patients, readmitted more former patients, discharged more patients and spent more money on each patient, it was reported yesterday.

The steamship charter market was marked last week by a moderate increase in activity and a somewhat firmer tone in freight rates. The net result was spotty rate improvement and a slight rise in the freight rate index.

MEDELLIN, Colombia, April 20 (AP) -- The Liberal party leader, Alberto Lleras Camargo, refused tonight to accept the Presidential candidacy offered him by the Conservatives under Colombia's political truce.

Cardinal Spellman celebrated a solemn pontifical mass at 10 A. M. yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral, marking the opening of the 1958 appeal of New York Catholic Charities in the 400 parishes of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.
DETROIT, April 20 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians blasted four home runs off Jim Bunning and defeated the Detroit Tigers, 4 -- 2, today at Briggs Stadium. All six runs scored on home runs.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- Roy Sievers slammed Murray Wall's first pitch in the tenth inning into the left-field bleachers today to give the Washington Senators a 6-5 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
Americans who have become alarmed in recent months by Russian scientific achievements and alleged American complacency would do well to look to the skies in their own home towns.
MOSCOW, April 20 -- Dmitri Shostakovich suggested today that Van Cliburn had to come to Moscow to get proper recognition for his talents as pianist.
WATERTOWN, N. Y., April 20 -- Amateur frogmen brought up evidence today that a rotting hulk in near-by Sackets Harbor might prove to be a relic of the War of 1812.
Several properties in downtown Manhattan figured in realty transactions reported over the week-end.

LOUISVILLE, April 20 (UP) -- Gary Player of South Africa, shooting precise golf through intermittent thundershowers, today won the $20,000 Kentucky Derby Open. He turned in a three-under-par 69 in the final round for a 72-hole score of 274.

BEAUMONT, Tex., April 20 (AP) -- Louise Suggs of Atlanta rallied in the stretch today to overtake Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge of Delray Beach Fla. and win the $5,000 Babe Zaharias open golf tournament with a 214 total for fifty-four holes.
America's moral standards are steadily "degenerating," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell maintained in a sermon here yesterday.

An appraisal of George Washington by a young British historian, Marcus Cunliffe, will be published Thursday by Little, Brown, entitled "George Washington, Man and Monument." The author observes that, unlike Napoleon, Nelson or Lincoln, Washington "is one of the world's greatest heroes who remains enigmatic and inaccessible" in "spite of the thousands of books, poems and speeches about him.
ALBANY, April 20 (AP) -- New York State embarked today on its first major venture in educational television.

The white-pleated kilts and red-tasseled hats of Evzone guards swung along Fifth Avenue once again yesterday. Twenty thousand Greek Americans marched to recall their heritage and celebrate the 137th anniversary of Hellenic independence from the Ottoman Empire.
VIENNA, April 20 6P----AUs. tria defeated Brazil, 3--2, in an international tennis series 'today, although the Brazilians won two of .the last three matches
New York City is being hurt by planning that is concerned more with automobiles than with people, a forum at the New School for Social Research was told last night.

TWO operas by Gian-Carlo Menotti, "The Old Maid and the Thief" and "The Medium," had first performances of the season last night at the City Center. Evan Whallon made his debut as conductor and Joan Carroll performed for the first time as Monica in the latter work.
RABAT, Morocco, April 20 -- The Government has asked Madrid to withdraw all Spanish troops from Moroccan territory.

AN inscription that made the rounds at the Scott Paper Company in Chester, Pa., now hangs on the wall in the president's office where Thomas Bayard McCabe appreciates its message: "To dodge difficulties is to lose the power of decision."

Our news pages this morning summarize a remarkable document which deserves the close attention and study of all thinking citizens and of government officials at all levels of local, state and Federal administration. "The Challenge to America:
Seven new films are slated to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:

HONG KONG, April 20 -- A Communist court in Chungking has sentenced Yang Chin-hsing to death on a charge that he killed Gen. Yang Hu-cheng and other persons on the eve of the Communist occupation of the city in 1950.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Congress turns this week to one of the biggest battles of the session as the House Armed Services Committee opens hearings on the President's plan to reorganize the Defense Department.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 20 -- Arthur Knapp Jr., the Larchmont fleet winter sailing champion, won the Interclub division of Larchmont Yacht Club's annual spring frostbite regatta with Agony for the fourth consecutive year today.

" Denominationalism came into being through the processes of history and through the processes of history the denominations are coming closer together," the Rev. Dr. Hampton Adams said in a sermon here yesterday.
Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey indicated yesterday that subsidies or public operation would be needed to provide mass transportation between New Jersey and New York.

Arrangements have been completed for a merger of the Federal Glass Company, Columbus, Ohio, and the Federal Paper Board Company, Inc., Bogota, N. J., it was announced over the week-end. Federal Glass produces machine-made glassware and corrugated containers.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- Senator Irving M. Ives said today that the Senate Rackets Committee planned to open an investigation soon into the Mafia's connection with labor and management.

JERSEY CITY, April 20 -- One woman was killed and six other persons were hurt today in an accident involving three cars and an ambulance. A pregnant woman in the ambulance was injured, but not seriously.
Greenwich Village had itself a ball over the week-end.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., April 20 -- The Thomas School of :Horsemanship No. 2 team, made up of Linda Thomas, Fran Fricker and Linnea Krantz, took the challenge trophy for Class A competitors in the sixth annual Junior Olympics horse show at the Thomas School today.
Poland today guarantees "complete equality for all citizens," including Jews, Romuald Spasowski, Polish Ambassador to the United States declared here yesterday.
CAIRO, April 20 -- Negotiations on the question of compensation for nationalization of the Suez Canal Company appeared today to be moving close to a settlement.

THERE has been much ado at the Pillsbury Mills plant in Minneapolis recently. And now shoppers will find on their grocery shelves the results of all that work -- seven new food mixes. One, a cherry angel cake mix, was mentioned here recently.

WASHINGTON April 20 -- The United States prepared today to challenge the Soviet Union to agree to a system of controls against surprise aerial attack across the Arctic.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 20 -- Eight of Africa's independent lands recognized the Algerian rebel National Liberation Front today as the sole legitimate authority in Algeria and called on France to negotiate an end of her "military occupation."

BOSTON, April 20 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens won their third straight Stanley Cup championship tonight as Bernie (Boom Boom) Geoffrion scored twice in a 5-3 victory over the Boston Bruins at the Garden.

LOS ANGELES, April 20 -- The San Francisco Giants routed the Dodgers, 12 -- 2, today to wind up the victors by a two-game margin in their six-game series inaugurating big-league baseball on the Pacific Coast.

ROME, April 20 -- In at least 15,000 campaign rallies throughout the country today, all political parties tried hard to arouse interest for the forthcoming general elections. But what really stirred the Italians was the soccer championship.
Newspaper publishers reported yesterday that much of the country was getting along well despite the recession in major manufacturing areas.
Dr. John R. Dunning, dean of engineering at Columbia University, last night urged a truly experimental approach to the problems of American education.

Nobody knows for sure when the first game of lacrosse was played. But one thing is certain. Indians in Canada were playing it at the time such explorers as Columbus, Hudson and the Cabots were busy in the Western Hemisphere.
A group of about thirty-five Cuban men and women attended the 11:45 A. M. Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday in "memory of all victims massacred in Cuba under the Batista regime."
Central Park became Huckleberry Finn country yesterday. Scores of youngsters found Central Park Lake a fisherman's paradise.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 20 -- Several sticks of dynamite were exploded 100 yards from the residence of Premier Riad Solh this morning. The explosions broke windows in a school and near-by houses. Three passers-by were slightly wounded by flying glass.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended April 19:

Property depreciation will be discussed at a dinner meeting of the Greater New York Chapter of the Society of Residential Appraisers on Thursday at the Brass Rail Restaurant, 100 Park Avenue. Charles T. Upjohn, vice president of Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., will be the chairman. The speakers will be Mr. Upjohn, Freeman L. Meinertz, assistant vice president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, and Harry K. Keller, a broker specializing in realty valuations.

St. Francis Prep's mile relay team won in 3:22.8 to highlight the first All Hallows track and field games yesterday at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. Twenty-nine schools participated in the meet.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- After thirteen substantial revisions or reorganizations in the last nine years, the Pentagon starts on a stormy road this week toward still another change.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 (AP) -- P C. Stevens, sent into the game as a defensive measure, rapped a home run in the ninth inning as the Pittsburgh Pirates ended a three-game losing streak with a 4-3 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs today.
VICTOR HERBERT finished a poor second to the Ampex Corporation in Saturday evening's presentation of "The Red Mill" over Channel 2.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 20 -- Robert Murphy, United States Deputy Under Secretary of State, returned from Paris today with an optimistic, outlook on the French-Tunisian dispute.
MANILA, April 20 -- Congressional investigations of alleged shady deals have forced President Carlos P. Garcia's Administration into a defensive position in recent weeks.
PITTSBURGH, April 20 -- Seasonal influences are keeping steel output from dipping to levels below those prevailing in recent weeks.

Net earnings of W. R. Grace Co. declined in 1957 for the first time in five years. Common share earnings based on the average number of shares outstanding and after preferred dividends, were $3.31, compared with $4.41 in 1956.

Four passengers on a sight-seeing boat were hurt yesterday when a gang of juveniles hurled sticks, stones and large pieces of brick from a bridge as the ship passed below. The bombardment started just as the Circle Line's excursion boat No. 8 steamed into the shadow of High Bridge on the Harlem River.

CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -Grain futures trading lacked any oustanding influences last week and prices drifted along for the most part, accommodating themselves to more or less minor day-to-day influences.
Ecuador's Ambassador to the United States said yesterday that the American republics must have solidarity in the economic field "if we are to have solidarity in the political field."
AN informative one - hour survey of the progress made in man's efforts to conquer space was shown yesterday on "The Twentieth Century" over Channel 2.
The tire of auto makers against President Eisenhower's innocuous remark that they ought to "give us the things we want instead of the things they think we want" is naive and ludicrous.

Mikhail Botvinnik, the challenger in the world chess championship match in Moscow, yesterday defeated Vassily Smyslov in the eighteenth game of the series in seventy-four moves, according to a report from Soviet news sources.
A HANDICAPPED child attending a general summer camp has much to contribute to the experiences of the normal campers.
Red-shirted youngsters with crash helmets, gloves and goggles drove their midget autos around an oval track yesterday to open the fifth season of the Junior Motor Sports Club of Long Island.
Visitors to New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, can now get a control-tower view of the 4,900-acre field and its environs.

TRENTON, April 20 -- A man who confessed running amuck with a shotgun last night at a convent here will be arraigned tomorrow morning in Doylestown, Pa. He wounded three Roman Catholic nuns, a policeman and a passer-by.
WASHINGTON, April 20--The Secretary of Commerce said today that he believed the recession had touched bottom.
Nelson A. Rockefeller said yesterday that the experts who prepared the new Rockefeller economic report had disagreed about when income taxes should be cut as an anti-recession measure.
Californians and New Yorkers apparently like their investing done the easy way.
READING, Pa., April 20 (AP) -- Jiggs Peters of Plainfield, N. J., powered his Offenhauser to first place in the $4,500 Reading Inaugural Sweepstakes at the Fairgrounds today.

Foreign Minister Gromyko's slanders against our Strategic Air Command do not diminish the importance of the Administration's proposal to share nuclear weapons information with our allies. Nothing would satisfy Mr. Gromyko and his friends, apparently, unless we lay down and played dead.
The role of students and colleges in a rapidly changing world was highlighted at religious events here yesterday.

The American Institute of Decorators has announced the winners in its twelfth annual design competition. Twenty-two awards for designers in floor coverings, wall coverings, furniture and fabrics were given.
Youngsters fighting in street gangs are saying in their own way that life is "unbearable," the Rev. Bernard C. Newman said yesterday.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 20 --About 100,000 Trinidadians turned out today to welcome Britain's Princess Margaret on her second visit to their island.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -Abba Eban, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, declared tonight that his nation entered its second decade "in perfect confidence" that it would endure as a state.
Bob Hope's trip to Communist Russia may prove to be a capitalistic prize for the comedian.

The big, high-speed Mariner class of freighter has given the United States an edge it never had before in the Far Eastern trade, according to William B. Rand Jr. He is vice president in charge of freight traffic, United States Lines.

Two interesting commentaries on gold have been published recently. In each case the writer concludes that the price of the metal should be increased by this country, or, in other words the dollar should be devalued. Both writers admittedly enjoy presenting controversial ideas and don't expect all their readers to agree with them on all points.

NOW is the time when those who have been hankering to buy a summer home succumb. Since most of such purchases be budget-conscious ones, most of these houses will be something in the nature of a Victorian relic or shack.

Loomis Grossman, realty operator, contracted to buy the eighty-six family apartment house at 1455 Sheridan Avenue, East 171st Street, the Bronx, from Sheldon Associates. He paid cash over mortgages aggregating $460,000 and resold his contract to an investor. Anne Inselstein was the broker.

" The downward trend of general business had less of an impact on retailing than on other segments of the economy" in the second half of last year, according to Sam Flanel, general manager of the congress of the National Retail Merchants Association.

IN India, as elsewhere, men find what they look for -- whether they are government officials, journalists or tourists. Some find an ancient civilization, a profoundly spiritual religion and an enlightened regime intent on solving a hundred crucial problems. Others find dirt, disease, squalor, frightful poverty, dreadful superstition and omnipresent corruption.
Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, yesterday predicted further trouble in the Middle East unless the United States took steps to prevent it.

PARIS, April 20--The only novel aspect of France's present political crisis is that a new generation of Frenchmen can now be seen to have inherited the insoluble problems of its parents. Felix Gaillard, whose resignation was forced last week, is the first Premier born since World War I.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., April 20 -- Reasons for stripping a 92,160-acre Westchester and Bronx domain from Lord Frederick Philipse 3d after the Revolutionary War are further explained in Philipse family papers just acquired by Sleepy Hollow Restorations.
After a few days of easier prices, cotton in the domestic market turned firmer to close last week in higher ground.

AN enchanting new cantata by Lester Trimble based in four fragments from "The Canterbury Tales" was the highpoint of three premieres presented late yesterday afternoon at the Ninety-second Street Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- This week Census Bureau headquarters will receive reports gathered last week on employment two weeks ago. Next week the data will be fed into a Univac. Univac's answer will be published a week later -- probably after someone has already leaked the news.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -The Supreme Court is about to renew acquaintance with an old problem -- the Georgia County unit system of counting primary election votes.

Maxwell Anderson's new drama, "The Golden Six," which is set in the year 1 A. D., will have its premiere at Boston University's Theatre on April 30 and give additional performances the next three nights.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 20 (Reuters)--Sir Grantley Adams, Prime Minister of the new West Indies Federation, announced formation of his Cabinet today.
DETROIT, April 20 (UP) -- Shutdowns in automobile plants this week will make 25,000 to 30,000 workers idle across the nation, a preliminary check indicated today.
Edward Lindsay, editor of The Decatur (Ill.) Herald and Review, yesterday was re-elected president of the American Council for Journalism.
LONDON, April 20 -- The budget presented to Parliament last week was about what economists and the business community had expected.
Spring blossoms that will last the summer long are being shown by Delman this week.
Herbert Hoover sat up, scanned the newspapers and chatted for about an hour with his two sons yesterday, the day after his gall bladder had been removed.

THE mink stole -- touchstone of more than 1,000,000 American wardrobes -- is under fire. In the opinion of Arnold Scaasi, prominent fashion designer, the mink stole was never very impressive in the first place.
Mayor Wagner, who was 48 years old yesterday, was honored at two surprise parties.

THE Audubon Society, which has been worried about the albino robin that has nested in Central Park each spring since 1955, reported with some delight yesterday that the bird had shown up in the park on Friday, about thirty-four days later than its earlier spring wing-ins.
The New York Academy of Medicine has urged that a nonprofit community organization be established to coordinate the work of the city's blood-handling agencies.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -The newly elected head of the National Jewish Welfare Board called today on the organization's affiliated institutions throughout the country to strengthen programs for coping with the varied problems of teen-agers and elderly people.

ASILOMAR, Calif., April 20 (AP) -- Dr. Stafford Warren, Dean of the School of Medicine at the University of California at Los Angeles, told the World Affairs Council today there was no conclusive evidence that radiation had any genetic effect on humans.
An issue of $4,500,000 of bonds of Independent School District 1 of Tulsa County, Okla., has been posted for sale on May 6.
Armour Co., Chicago meat packer, has sold its local packing and storage plant, 493-511 Eleventh Avenue at Thirtyninth street, to Irving Maidman, New York realty investor and builder.

William Jorden's article in your issue of April 17 correctly points out the significance of Van Cliburn's current pianistic triumph in Moscow and the potential rewards that could accrue to the United States and the Soviet Union from a wider exchange of our most gifted citizens.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 20 -- Hecht-Hill-Lancaster, Inc., has signed Eva Le Gallienne for the forthcoming production of George Bernard Shaw's "The Devil's Disciple."

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The Government reported today that average family income last year was $6,130 -- about 50 per cent higher than a decade ago. The ten-year increase was 20 per cent when taking increased living costs into account.
A halt to all nuclear weapons tests was urged by 140 Protestant clergymen and educators yesterday.

Every year in the month of April organizations all over the world held public meetings to commemorate the Battle of the Warsaw Ghetto and the six million Jews who perished in the ghettoes and in the Germany concentration camps during the second World War.

Stockholders of the Bishop Oil Company of San Francisco were told by the management over the week-end that four Los Angeles stockholders had announced their intention of soliciting proxies in opposition to the management.
LONDON, April 20 (Reuters) -- Everton, a major English soccer club tired of icy and rain-bogged turf, is constructing an underground heating system that will keep its field fit for play at any time.

Impassioned singing by Stephen Henderson, lyric tenor, revived a stodgy performance of iawatha's Wedding Feast," a cantata by Samuel ColeridgeTaylor, at the Middleton Chorale 's Town Hall concert last night.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said today that the United States would test major parts of its Rover atomic-powered rocket engine this fall in Nevada.
The trans-Atlantic airlines have been warned of serious delays in air traffic this summer unless methods of flight planning and routing are changed.

CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) -- Stan Musial's two home runs helped the St. Louis Cardinals crash into the National League victory column today with a 9-4 triumph over the previously undefeated Chicago Cubs.

HOUSTON, April 20 (AP) -- Barry MacKay, 22-year-old Davis Cup star from Dayton, Ohio, settled down after a ninety-minute interruption caused by rain and defeated Luis Ayala of Chile in the final of the twenty-fourth annual River Oaks teams tournament.
The Yankees, who now have New York, all to themselves, soon may have all of the American League locked up as well.
SAN REMO, Italy, April 20 (UP) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami won the mixed doubles final, but lost in the men's doubles final today in the San Remo lawn tennis tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 20 -- The Security Council will take up tomorrow a Soviet charge that flights of United States planes bearing nuclear bombs "toward the frontiers of the Soviet Union" constituted a threat to peace.

WASHINGTON April 20 (AP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower returned to the White House this evening after a week-end at Camp David, the mountain retreat outside Thurmont, Md. They drove through the White House gate at 5:59 P. M.

Two organizations which year after year help to carry on the fight against intolerance, discrimination and the ignorance that is at the root of both these evils are opening their annual drive for funds on Wednesday. These are the American Jewish Committee and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, which unite to carry on the Joint Defense Appeal.
Two brothers learned yesterday that being scoutmasters did not mean that the police would agree with them on what constituted a good deed.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UP) -- David Ben-Gurion, Israeli Premier, said today his Government would favor "complete disarmament" by all the countries of the Middle East.
The United States men's and women's amateur basketball teams left yesterday for a series of games in the Soviet Union. The squads will play six games each under a sports exchange program.

One thousand two hundred visitors to this large city do not cause congestion, but when, as is the case this week, they represent owners and executives of newspapers from all over North America, plus the future State of Hawaii, they may stir up quite a turmoil of ideas and information.
AMSTERDAM, April 20 -- Some sections of the stock market here brightened last week. The technical situation is such that a small demand may cause a considerable rise in prices.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- What's this about the Phillies' Robin Roberts going downhill fast? Anyone who watched the industrious right-hander whip the Milwaukee Braves, 3 -- 2, today would have to reject any allegation that the 31-year-old pitcher is "just about finished."
Five Russian veterans of World War II came here yesterday on their way to Washington for the thirteenth anniversary of the meeting of Soviet and American soldiers at the Elbe River in Germany.
MILAN, Italy, April 20 -- Along queues outside the American pavilion have borne silent testimony to the popularity of the United States exhibit at Milan's thirty-sixth International Sample Fair.
MONTREAL, April 19 -- Ship traffic in the port of Montreal soon will be directed on the principle of aircraft guided to runways by the control tower.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 20 -- Indonesian Government troops are reported to have run into heavy resistance in their drive on Bukittinggi, the rebel capital in central Sumatra.

The chickens hatched by the costly Transit Authority contract settlement with Michael J. Quill's Transport Workers Union last New Year's Eve are now coming home to roost. The frequency with which Charles L. Patterson, authority chairman, mentions the possibility of a fare increase next year is ominous, even though he steadily emphasizes the efforts toward efficiency and economy to avert an increase.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 20 -- Buoyancy dominated the stock exchange business all last week. Nearly all stock prices, both American and Swiss, were appreciably higher at the close than a week earlier. The volume was often very heavy.
BERLIN, April 20 -- Premier Otto Grotewohl denied today that there were any differences between him and Walter Ulbricht, First Secretary of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party.

Hope for the economic security so vital to the future of Israel is being brightened by a rising volume of exports to the United States. As the Mideast nation begins tenth-anniversary celebrations on Thursday, this trend of trade serves to illustrate her basic problem, survival. Recent events, the Sinai campaign and its aftermath, have re-emphasized for Israel that both progress and military security require greater economic strength.
A report of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund called last night for quick, coordinated Government and business action, including a major Federal tax cut, to end the recession.
NEWTON, Mass., April 20 -- Five women, ranging in age from 80 to 96, drowned this afternoon when a driverless car rolled across a rest home lawn and sank in Crystal Lake.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -Here's a springtime story about a President, a leader of the opposition and a boy from Sweet Briar, Va.
KANSAS CITY, April 20 (AP) -- Five-hit pitching by Jack Urban and three-run homers by Bill Tuttle and Billy Hunter led the Kansas City Athletics to an 8-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox today.

OTTAWA, April 20 (AP) -- Prime Minister John Diefenbaker denied in an interview last night he had ever said his Government would divert 15 per cent of Canada's trade from the United States to Britain.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -Mexico's National Symphony Orchestra, making its first visit this far north, took over the symphonic burden last night at the first InterAmerican Music Festival. An ensemble of 100 men and women, it was led by Luis Herrera de la Fuente.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 20 (AP) -- Jordan accused Israel today of violating the 1949 armistice agreement by bringing troops into divided Jerusalem for a parade on Israel's tenth anniversary. The Government ordered troop reinforcements and guns to the Jordanian sector of the city.

TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., April 20 -- Mrs. Malcolm G. Field of Sloatsburg has been named chairman of the Tuxedo Autumn Ball Committee by the Board of Governors of the Tuxedo Club. The ball will be held Oct. 18 at the Club.
Prompt action by the Federal Government in granting funds with which municipalities can fight the recession was urged yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

The advertising accounts of Merkel, Inc., and Vita Food Products, Inc., have been resigned by Blaine-Thompson, Inc. The Merkel business, with billings of about $200,000 a year has been awarded to the L. H. Hartman Company, Inc., and it is reported that Vita will also go there.

Five youths were stabbed and beaten, one of them critically, in a running Brooklyn gang battle that stretched from Coney Island to Flatbush yesterday. Squads of police converged on the bands, broke up the fights and arrested forty-four youths.

LONDON, April 20 --Aneurin Bevan declared tonight that flights of United States aircraft carrying nuclear bombs toward the Soviet frontiers were "exceedingly dangerous" and created a situation "little short of war."

PARIS, Monday, April 21 -- Former Premier Georges Bidault, one of the advocates of a tough policy toward Tunisia who helped upset the Government last week, agreed last night to try to form a new Cabinet.

The New York premiere of the film "Paris Holiday" on the evening of May 9 will benefit the Hospitalized Veterans Service. The theatre will be announced later. There will also be a supper dance at the Plaza, with Bob Hope, a star of the film, as a guest of honor.

At the recent session of the Legislature years of effort by able and dedicated men, as well as some $800,000 in expenses, apparently went down the drain. Nor will anything substantial be accomplished by a request to the courts to consider their organization and to suggest measures for their own reform.

SAN JUAN, P. R., April 21 -- The second Casals Festival will open here tomorrow night. Puerto Ricans already have bought all the seats allotted to them for the twelve concerts. However, tourists from New York have not shown as much eagerness to get to the festival as last year.

DETROIT, April 21 (AP) -- The president of Yale University said here today that graduates of private preparatory schools were, in general, better equipped for college, but that public school products tended to study harder.

The Underwood Corporation has clipped the wings off its trademark and introduced a new symbol -- the first such change in thirty years. The development is part of the adoption of a new "total visual image" for the corporation.

The Government announced yesterday that it expected to rest today in the anti-trust action with which it is attempting to block a merger of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company into the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

The seventh Congress of the Yugoslav Communist party will open today under the cloud of a new flare-up of the Soviet-Yugoslav ideological conflict. JERUSALEM (Israel Sector), April 21 -- The Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission met here today to consider Jordan's protest against a huge military parade Israel has scheduled for Thursday in Jerusalem.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., April 21 -- A joint Smith College and West Point Glee Club concert will take place on Saturday in the Memorial Auditorium at Montclair State Teachers College.

He early discerned that "fantasy, kindled by instinct-born excitements, creates illusory conditions which can rouse or stimulate us more than familiar natural or supernatural ones."
