"WHY THE CIVIL WAR?" by Otto Eisenschiml gives fresh life to old controversies. Although it seems calculated to raise a great debate on whether that war really was an irrepressible conflict, as so many have believed, it comes pretty late in the day to provide an impressive up-roar. Nevertheless, it is one of the most interesting Civil War books of the year.
Sales and earnings of Chas. Pfizer Co. in the first quarter of 1958 were the highest in the company's history.
PERTH, Scotland, April 21 -- Bessie Love, star of movies such as "Broadway Melody" who has lived in London since 1935, appeared here tonight in the premiere of her own play, "The Homecoming."
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 22 -- An Israeli fisherman was reported killed and another missing following an encounter in the Gulf of Aqaba this morning.
Forty-eight American companies last year did a billion dollars or more of business, The United Press reported yesterday in an annual tally.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 -- Sol C. Siegel, who once refused to become president of Loew's, Inc., today became head of studio operations for the company's production arm, Metro-Goldwyn-Meyer.
FOUR Russian women got a chance yesterday to explore an American woman's inner sanctum and they learned some of our beauty secrets.
WASHINGTON, April 22--The battle over the President's Pentagon reorganization bill began on Capitol Hill today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Judge Edward M. Curran, in United States District Cqurt issued a temporary injunction today prohibiting the National Labor Relations Board from holding a representation election among the employes of three Toledo stores.
Resident of Brooklyn Heights will give blood to the Red Cross today at the Bossert Hotel, 98 Montague Street.

HAMILTON, Ont., April 22 (Canadian Press) -- Interest is growing in the development by McMaster University's Medical Research Department of a new technique for detecting coronary disease in its early stages.

Robert Weaver, the State Rent Administrator, withdrew yesterday as a candidate for appointment to the reorganized New York City Housing Authority. He had been reported to be Mayor Wagner's first choice for one of two vacancies at $30,000 a year.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 -- Decision of the Immigration Service to return Mr. Heikkila from Finland will not dissuade his attorneys from proceeding against local officials of the service, they said today.
The city is about to order its second nineteen-foot nine-inch Cadillac since Mayor Wagner several weeks ago suggested shorter automobiles for use by city officials.

ROSCOE, N. Y., April 22 -This part of the Catskills, the location of the renowned Beaverkill, is in surprisingly good shape for trout fishing and an angler can return from an empty day of thrashing about in cold water to hear some pretty brave stories.

Superintendent David G. Salten's point that local initiative and effort to construct schools are whittled away by hope that the Federal Government will soon provide anti-recession school construction funds is more than balanced by another situation he did not mention.
A letter which appeared on April 15 objecting to parking meters on Amsterdam Avenue north of 116th Street presented an incomplete picture of some of the factors involved and an omission of others.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 -- A drama of a group of scientists trapped in a concrete bunker covered with radioactive fall-out will be presented by "Playhouse 90" on May 15.
VALLETTA, Malta, April 22 (Reuters) --- Mounted police tonight charged demonstrators who forced a policeman off his motorcycle here. No casualties were reported.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday formation of Georgia Nuclear Laboratories as a separate operating branch engaged in the design and manufacture of nuclear reactors for the generation of industrial heat.
Two scoutmasters agreed yesterday that from now on they would start foot races for Boy Scouts by blowing a whistle.
Here is the summer weather forecast for the subway system: hot and humid with no air-conditioning.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 22 -- The program of study and action to be carried out for the next two years by the League of Women Voters was debated today at its national convention.

FROM today until May 11 the Museum of Modern Art Guest House, 242 East Fifty-second Street, will show to the public a selection of fifty paintings, sculptures, drawings, prints and illustrated books from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Bareiss.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 22 -- The United States is hoping that it will be able to capture the spotlight of the music, ballet and arts festival at the World's Fair here with a spectacular new entry -- Van Cliburn, 23-year-old pianist.

Hal Foster, creator of "Prince Valiant;" has been chosen "cartoonist of the year" by the National Cartoonists Society. The selection was announced last night at the society's annual awards dinner at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22 -- The Soviet Union expressed eagerness today to join the contemplated United Nations Economic Commission for Africa.
HONG KONG, April 22 -- The Chinese Communist regime's great national monument has been completed.
A practice gimmick he worked up in conjunction with Coach Joe Healey has had much to do with Mike Herman's sensational development as a broad jumper.
Dr. Milton Helpern, Chief Medical Examiner, said yesterday that carbon monoxide rather than mass hysteria was responsible for the collapse of fifteen workers in a basement factory on Monday.

Two new films will open today on a double-feature program at the R. K. O. neighborhood theatres. "Stakeout On Dope Street," a drama of the underworld, features Yale Wexler, Jonathan Haze and Abby Dalton, and was produced by Andrew Fenady.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Hundreds of members of church and temperance organizations jammed a Senate hearing today on a bill to outlaw interstate liquor advertising by radio, television, newspapers and magazines.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Non-military foreign aid grants by the United States last year were at the lowest level since the end of World War II, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Princess Soraya, once wife of the Shah of Iran, said yesterday that the Shah had "no choice" but to divorce her because they were childless. The black-haired Princess, who is 25 years old, arrived on the liner Constitution for an American holiday.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 22 -- A special report on the state's investigation of Judge Raulston Schoolfield of Chattanooga was withheld from publication today by Gov. Frank G. Clement pending a possible call of the Tennessee Legislature to initiate impeachment proceedings.

State Department Press Officer Joseph W. Reap, in commenting upon the Russian charges as to our polar H-bomb flights, has officially stated that the Russians are trying to play upon the nuclear fears of mankind. This assertion, it seems to me, cries out for comment.
The National Maritime Union has accused the recently formed American Banner Lines of hiring unlicensed personnel for its new passenger vessel Atlantic in a "secret and unfair" manner.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The House Judiciary Committee voted today to let 32,000 Hungarian refugees become permanent residents of the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The United States and the Soviet Union are dominating the news with their endless bickering, but the really important news is happening in other countries.
PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 22 -- Princess Margaret formally put the new West Indies Federation and its 3,000,000 people on the road to independent nationhood today.
Following is the text of the talk given yesterday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy at the joint conference of key personnel of the Police Department and the City Youth Board:

INDIANAPOLIS, April 22 -- A new race car, unique in design, is being made ready for practice runs when the Indianapolis Speedway is opened for that purpose on May 1. If its performance is satisfactory to its scheduled driver, one of the consequences may be the introduction of a new driving star in the 500-mile race here on Memorial Day.

The new outdoor Venetian Theatre at Caramoor, Katonah, N. Y., will be opened with a concert Saturday evening, June 21. Marian Anderson, contralto, and Jan Peerce, tenor, will be soloists with Alfred Wallenstein and the Caramoor Festival Orchestra.

For the first time in its history, The New York Times issued an annual report making its financial statements public at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman of the board and publisher, reported a net profit after taxes of $3,010,067 for the year ended Dec. 31, 1957.
LONDON, April 22 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan intervened today in an attempt to settle a dispute that has threatened to cause a country-wide strike on the nationalized railroad system.
With 5,000,000 persons crossing state lines every year, unemployment becomes a Federal problem and not one for the individual states, a welfare official said yesterday.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., April 22 (AP) -- James (Piggy) Lynch, ex-convict and one time handyman for gambler Joe Adonis, died today at Valley Hospital. He was 54 years old. He resided on Spook Ridge Road, Upper Saddle River.

Mayor Wagner made a mistake of judgment last year when he committed himself to support of a change of law to allow the annual Loyalty Day parade to march through the shopping section of Fifth Avenue in midtown. A few days ago he committed himself again, saying he would sign the amendment of the administrative code passed by the City Council.

Nearly 1,200 persons turned out last night for a testimonial dinner to Herman Winner, Bronx Republican leader. It was the first fund-raising dinner the Bronx Republican organization has held in its forty-four years.

The American Express Company which has a network of 399 offices in thirty-five countries, increased its first-quarter earnings from operations 18.3 per cent above the 1957 level, Ralph T. Reed, president, told the annual meeting here yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 22 -- The guest of honor at Moscow's next May Day parade will be Gamal Abdel Nasser. This simple fact is indicative of adroit Soviet diplomacy. For, since the communization of China, Russia's most brilliant international accomplishment has been to associate itself with the cause of Arab nationalism.

LONDON, April 22 (Reuters) -- Following is a translation of excerpts from the address by President Tito today to the Yugoslav Communist party's congress in Ljubljana, as reported by Tanjug, the official Yugoslav news agency:
The Appellate Division in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh has not overstepped his legal powers in his campaign against persistent traffic violators.

Thwarted by a city ruling from putting on musical shows in Central Park, Michael P. Grace said yesterday that he would try to present his summer program at an amphitheatre, in a parking lot or even on a barge. He is now looking for a site.
A New York-New Jersey organization yesterday joined a national movement calling on Congress to reject the bid of the United States Army Corps of Engineers to operate the St. Lawrence Seaway.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Space scientists told Congress today of plans to give a satellite "a kick in the apogee" and to float huge aluminum balloons around the moon.
SINGAPORE, April 22 (UP)--The Indonesian Government Air Force bombed the rebel capital of Sumatra twice today. Ground forces smashed through a key town to less than fifteen miles from the city.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Eisenhower Administration sent Congress today four proposals for long-run solutions of railroad problems, and one for an immediate, temporary program of Federal loan guarantees up to $700,000,000.
More than $60,000,000 was spent for golf equipment in 1957 although no one can guess how much of this went for lost golf balls.

TALK about stereophonic music as the newest of the new? There were composers in the sixteenth century who put the idea into practice with living performers. And did they restrict themselves to two or three channels?

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Senate today confirmed the nomination of Walter Howe of Litchfield, Conn., as Ambassador to Chile. He has been a consultant for the International Cooperation Administration.

LOS ANGELES, April 22 (UP) -- Johnny Podres, the left-handed ace of the Dodger mound staff, pitched five shutout innings tonight as Los Angeles defeated the Cubs, 4 -- 2, in the first night major league baseball game ever played here.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra closed its Carnegie Hall season last night with Eugene Ormandy leading two works -- the first New York performance of Adolf Busch's "Psalm No. 6" for chorus and orchestra and Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.

The April 11 Times carried an Associated Press dispatch from Boston that was headed: "Surgeon Finds Teeth Can Be Transplanted." Apparently an old art has been rediscovered, for back in November, 1784, Mary Morris, the wife of the financier, Robert Morris, wrote to Kitty Livingston, daughter of the Governor of New Jersey:
WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP) -- The House Veterans Committee accused the White House today of withholding almost 5,000 veterans hospital beds from use in an effort to save money.
Isaac J. Collins' Dixie Miss, winner of one division of the Prioress Stakes on April 9, took the $7,500 Grasslands Purse at Jamaica yesterday by half a length.
The use of some city high-school buildings as part-time community college facilities was proposed yesterday by State Controller Arthur Levitt.
The National Institute of Arts and Letters has named Paul Rudolph, chairman of Yale University's Department of Architecture, winner of its $1,000 Brunner Memorial Prize in Architecture.

IN the middle of Act II of "The Enchanted," which was revived last night at the Renata Theatre, the beautiful young heroine is deep in a dreary discussion of the relative merits, as companions, of the dead and the undead.
Many persons prominent in the coffee, tea and allied industries will attend a special benefit luncheon at noon today in the Manhattan Hotel.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 22 (UP) -- Budge Patty gained the quarter-finals in men's singles today in the British hard court tennis championships by crushing Derek Collins of England, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 0.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 22 -- Harvard University modified its policy today concerning the use of Memorial Church in college yard by other than Christians.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 (UP) -- Del Ennis drove in three runs, and Stan Musial collected three hits to lead The St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-5 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight before a crowd of 22,786 in Seals Stadium.

Your lead editorial of April 21 on the Rockefeller report was most informative and interesting. It points up beyond any doubt that a piecemeal approach to the problem of combating any setback in our economy is ill-advised. On the positive side it suggests, and rightly, that any recession must be met by all the forces that contribute to our economy -- to wit, industry, labor and government.
LONDON, April 22 -- The first exchanges in Moscow on a summit meeting were said today to have revealed a Soviet desire to split the Western powers in their approach to such a meeting.

Columbia University's Bancroft Prizes for 1958 were awarded last night to Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. for "The Crisis of the Old Order, 1919-1933" and to Frank Luther Mott for volume four of "A History of American Magazines."
The Southern Railway Company so far this year has managed to carry down to net income a considerably greater percentage of its gross revenues than many other carriers.

It is to be hoped that this week's memorable report of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund -- which proposed a major Federal tax cut as part of a program for reversing the present downward trend of the economy -- will help to get the anti-recession policies of the Administration and Congress off dead center.

The five-story dwelling at 18 East Seventy-sixth Street has been purchased by the Missionary Society of St. Paul the Apostle (the Paulist Fathers). It will be occupied by the Superior General of the order and his council.
PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- Six Navy enlisted men completed a seven-day simulated trip to the Moon at the Philadelphia Naval Base this afternoon.
GENEVA, April 22 -- The United Nations conference on the law of the sea decided today to include in a single convention its articles of law on continental shelves.

An air safety expert yesterday warned that safety research for conventional aviation would suffer as a result of the Government's diversion of equipment, personnel and funds to the problems of space flight.

Smoke pouring from a window on the twentieth floor of the Gotham Hotel at 2 West Fifty-fifth Street yesterday caused a noon-hour crowd of thousands to gather in the street on the Fifth Avenue side of the structure. The fire was confined to a vacant guest room and was brought under control in about ten minutes.

The 1957-58 appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund brought $449,286.11. This total has been divided among the seven cooperating agencies, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the membership corporation.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 22 -- The Elmhurst Stables' pacer, Kirk's Queen, a 5-year-old bay mare, gained the winner's share of the listed $3,000 purse in the featured Pace Setter race at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Kirk's Queen, paying $4.50 for $2, took the race by three lengths over Devastator in 2:06 4/5 for the mile.
The women's division of the National Conference of Christians and Jews will sponsor a tour of New York homes next Tuesday for the benefit of its Brotherhood Scholarship Fund.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Immigration Service today ordered the return of William Heikkila to the United States "forthwith." Mr. Heikkila, a 52-year-old alien who had been in the United States since he was two and one-half months old, was picked up after work Friday, in San Francisco and flown-out of the country. Continued From Page 1 was not allowed to notify his wife, call a lawyer, pack a bag or obtain funds.
PITTSBURGH, April 22 (AP) -- Hank Aaron's three-run homer sparked Milwaukee to a 5-2 victory today over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
PARIS, April 22 -- President Rene Coty decided tonight to call upon former Premier Rene Pleven, a representative of the French political Center, to form a new government.
The Pennsylvania Railroad expects to spend $45,000 to $85,000 in its effort to turn back the bid of Randolph Phillips, an insurgent stockholder, for a place on the company's eighteen man board.

The first conference of independent African states, held at Accra in Ghana, has produced a series of resolutions which emphasize again the decisive changes taking place in the "Dark Continent" that now seeks its place in the sun. Taken together, these resolutions amount to a declaration of ultimate all-African independence and a proclamation of what might be termed an African Monroe Doctrine against foreign rule and foreign industries.

The racial policies of the Government of South Africa were assailed as the "cruelist of human crimes on record" in a report received yesterday by the Bishop's Council of the African Methodist Episcopal Church.

CAIRO, April 22 -- Officials of the Ministry of Finance said today that final agreement had been reached on the Suez Canal compensation issue. The settlement will be announced "within the next twenty-four hours," they added.

The interesting novelty at last night's New Music Concert at Carl Fischer Concert Hall was Ernest Bloch's Suite No. 1 for unaccompanied 'cello. The work was given its first New York performance by Daniel Vandersall.

Thomas P. Whitney, foreign news analyst of The Associated Press, last night was elected president of the Overseas Press Club of America, Inc., at the annual meeting at 35 East Thirty-ninth Street. He defeated Cecil Brown, commentator of the American Broadcasting Company, who sought re-election as president.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Following are President Eisenhower's letter to Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, and the Secretary's letter to Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida and chairman of the Surface Transportation subcommittee, outlining the Administration's proposals to help the railroad industry:
The number of persons receiving public assistance here increased almost as much in the last three months as in all of 1957, Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy reported yesterday.

All wool positions on the New York Cotton Exchange fell yesterday to the lowest levels since 1947. Trading was influenced by unchanged to slightly lower prices at the Australian auctions, new low prices in London and reports that part of the domestic clip had been sold at relatively low prices.
Daniel J. Riesner was re-elected last night to a fifth term as president of the National Republican Club. He defeated George T. Reilly, a vice president, 772 to 99.
Rooting for rain, that's what Casey Stengel was doing right up to game time yesterday at the Stadium.
LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, April 22 -- A source of the latest open quarrel between Belgrade and Moscow is the ten years of Yugoslav "do it yourself" ideology.

Joseph Conrad and his novels are the subjects of two books scheduled for publication a week apart. The first will be "Joseph Conrad and His Characters: A Study of Six Novels," by Richard Curle. To be issued April 29 by Essential Books of Fair Lawn, N. J., the volume contains criticisms of "Lord Jim," "Nostromo," "The Secret Agent," 'Under Western Eyes," 'Chance" and "Victory."

TENAFLY, N. J., April 22 -- The 800 senior high school students here marched from their 35-year-old building at 9:45 o'clock this morning to their new $3,100,000 school half a mile away. Soon after they had vacated the old building, clean-up squads of custodians, students and faculty members from the adjoining Browning Junior High School invaded the building on West Clinton Avenue to prepare it for occupancy as a junior high school tomorrow

MAYBE you haven't noticed it, but this is the season of striking and ambitious first novels. Already in this space I have expressed my admiration for "Home From the Hill," by William Humphrey, and "The Cross of Baron Samedi," by Richard Dohrman. And now still a third is published which is little less than a colossal effort to say all that can be said about war, peace and the crisis of modern man.
ALBANY, April 22 -- A new $300,000 research program in narcotics addiction will be established at Manhattan State Hospital in New York City, Governor Harriman announced today.
PITTSBURGH, April 22 (AP) -- Earnings of the Gulf Oil Corporation for the first quarter of 1958 were down more than 36 per cent from a year ago, officials reported today at the annual meeting.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 18 points up yesterday. The far months were strongest.
The new 37,800-deadweight ton tanker Esso Lexington underwent a strenuous series of builder's tests yesterday, fifty miles off Cape Henry.

Election of J. D. MacKenzie as president of the American Smelting and Refining Company was announced yesterday at the annual meeting. He succeeds R. W. Vaughan, who was named vice chairman of the board. The company held its meeting in Jersey City.
Public health officials warned the National Health Council yesterday that there was a personnel shortage in the medicine and welfare fields.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A way to get albatrosses from around the necks of trans-Pacific airplanes appeared today. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service reported that a land-leveling operation on Midway Islands in the Pacific might be the best method of keeping the albatrosses from soaring over runways and tangling with aircraft.

MAJURO, Marshall Islands, April 9 -- United States administration of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands under the United Nations shows no outward aspects of "colonialism" as colonialism has been known under many flags.

The United Fruit Company has named a marine engineer on its staff for thirty-three years to the top post in its steamships department. The election of the engineer, J. Arthur Marquette, as a vice president was announced yesterday by the board of directors.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, April 22--President Tito called on the leaders of the Soviet Union today to give up their "absurd" ideas about re-educating Yugoslavia and bringing her back into the Eastern bloc.

Vassily Smyslov, the champion, yesterday won the nineteenth game of his return world title chess match in Moscow with Mikhail Botvinnik, according to a report received through Soviet news sources. This reduced the challenger's lead to 3 points.
A Soviet housing delegation started a whirlwind tour of America yesterday. The Empire State Building and the Atlantic Ocean were at the top of its list of sightseeing musts.

The Continental Can Company is in "good shape to weather the recession and will not stop plans of expansion," Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman, told more than 800 stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The United States is consulting with the Soviet Union and other nations on continuing scientific cooperation in Antarctica beyond Dec. 31 when the International Geophysical Year ends.
Kingsbury Smith, vice president and general manager of International News Service, said yesterday that I. N. S. and its various divisions gained 249 new clients during the last twelve months.

THERE is a green world high above the pavement that city groundlings rarely see. Familiar and exotic growths flourish in this sky acreage. The same birds, insects and crawling things that invade open countryside plantings climb to apartment house and skyscraper gardens -- as high as thirty-eight floors at Radio City -- to rob or destroy crops.
CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

THE new West Indies Federation, which inaugurated its first Parliament yesterday, is led by a man who maintains he is a middle-of-the-road Socialist. Observers who have been trying for years to orient him politically come back repeatedly to the conviction that he is no further left than a British Liberal, the party he left to become a Socialist.
LOS ANGELES, April 22 (AP) -- A $750,000 suit was filed against Lana Turner and her former husband today on behalf of John Stompanato's son.
ALBANY, April 22 -- A bill to establish a $150,000 experimental community center for the mentally retarded was signed today by Governor Harriman.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Republican leaders in Congress got President Eisenhower's backing today for a "major fight" against a $1,575,000,000 unemployment relief bill sponsored by Democrats.

William Talbert is one of four new directors elected to the board of the Lawn Tennis Hall of Fame and Tennis Museum. Announcement of the elections was made yesterday by James H. Van Alen of Newport, R. I., and Roslyn, L. I., president of the Hall of Fame and also of the Newport Casino, where it is housed.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz accused a television repair concern yesterday of defrauding its customers of more than $1,000,000 in the last five years.

Bob Hope will star in eight one-hour television shows next season under the sponsorship of Buick. Beginning in October, they will be presented at the rate of one a month over the National Broadcasting Company network.

Fifty years ago this week the New York County Lawyers Association was organized, so this is a good time for congratulations and for public appreciation of the role that the association has played during its first half century. In size alone it is notable. With 9,100 members, it is the largest local bar association in the world.
" You Auto Buy Now" campaigns have been planned in 207 cities in efforts to overcome the recession, newspaper publisher representatives reported here yesterday.

John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, warned last night that Americans would have to embrace "the very thing we hate" if they sought to compete with the Soviet Union "under the rules the challenger lays down."

Governor Harriman has signed into law a pioneering change in the procedure governing withdrawals of savings from savings and loan asso ciations. It is expected that associations chartered by other states and by the Federal Government will move quickly for similar changes.
A sheet of the new Israeli anniversary stamp was presented yesterday to former Senator Herbert H. Lehman, chairman of the American Committee for Israel's Tenth Anniversary Celebration.
Oliver La Farge, anthropologist and president of the Association on American Indian Affairs, was sharply critical yesterday of the Bureau of Indian Affairs in the Department of the Interior.
KANSAS CITY, April 22 (UP) -- Bob Cerv hammered two home runs, one inside the park, and drove in four tallies today as the Kanas City Athletics defeated the Cleveland Indians 9 -- 6.
Public offerings of utility bonds, convertible debentures and industrial shares exceeding $38,000,000 are being made today.
The Crown Zellerbach Corporation has ended a seven-month search for an agency to handle its institutional advertising. It has chosen Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc.

There is a viruslike thing going around, for which fortunately there is no cure. Call it spring fever, and give thanks that it finally has come. For a long time, indeed for a time so long that it seemed a century, there was nothing more prevalent than the common winter cold.
PINEHURST, N. C., April 22 (AP) -- The medalist, Wayne Jackson, and the defending champion, Bill Campbell, passed first-round match-play tests in the North and South amateur golf tournament today.
Profits of the nation's third-largest steel producer, the Republic Steel Corporation, dropped more than 69 per cent in the first quarter this year,

DETROIT, April 22 (UP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers, desperate for a top-notch player to lead them from the National Basketball Association cellar, today hopefully made Seattle's All-America, Elgin Baylor, their first choice in the N. B. A.'s annual draft.

Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy yesterday described New York's youth crime situation as "critical." He predicted that the city would experience "more frequent, greater and bloodier youth gang wars" this spring and summer.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Senate Democratic leadership, for tactical reasons, withdrew temporarily a bill requiring the disclosure of facts about welfare funds.

Stockholders of the American Window Glass Company approved a merger with the Blue Ridge Glass Corporation at the annual meeting yesterday in Pittsburgh. Otto G. Schwenk, president of American Window Glass, is to become president of the new company, which will be known as the American-Saint Gobain Corporation.
An angered Federal grand jury investigating the tax returns of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. has threatened to become a "runaway."
Twenty-one public housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration are planning to offer bond issues totaling $69,870,000 on May 21.

Plans are being completed by a committee headed by Mrs. Hans H. Zinsser for the sixth annual Goddard Gala for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center. The event will take place May 5 in the Jade Room Suite and the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 22 -- Israel's Knesset (Parliament) held a special memorial session today to open three-day independence celebrations.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (UP)--A produce supplier told the Senate Rackets Committee today a Philadelphia teamster official had tried in 1955 to get a $50,000 pay-off from a company that was having labor trouble.
Benjamin M. McKelway, editor of The Washington Star, was re-elected yesterday as president of The Associated Press.

There is a possibility that Sidney Luft, Judy Garland's husband, may join the ranks of Broadway producers. Mr. Luft confirmed the reports yesterday and said he was taking the step with a musical version of "Born in Wedlock," based on Margaret Echard's novel.

Banks here and across the country moved quickly yesterday to cut their lending rates, following a similar step taken Monday by the Guaranty Trust Company of New York and J. P. Morgan Co., Inc. These two banks cut the prime rate, the rate to the biggest customers with the best credit ratings, from 4 to 3 1/2 per cent.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 22 (AP) -- A legislative committee disclosed plans today for an in vestigation of all dealings between the City of Los Angeles and the Dodgers for the Chavez Ravine 'site for a new baseball stadium.

Decision was reserved yesterday on a motion to dismiss the antitrust suit with which the Government seeks to block the acquisition of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 22 -- United Nations truce supervision officers were still trying late tonight to settle the dispute that has arisen over an Independence Day parade Israelis plan to hold here Thursday.
The Associated Hospital Serving of New York has renewed its efforts to obtain the state's approval of an increase in Blue Cross rates.

The building industry the world over is hampered by technological backwardness, according to Ernest Weissmann, assistant director of the United Nations Bureau of Social Affairs. The bureau is in charge of housing, building and planning.
Twenty-two commuter trains of the New Haven and the New York Central railroads were delayed up to fifty minutes last night when a breakdown occurred at the 125th Street Station.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Profits of manufacturing corporations dipped sharply in the final quarter of last year, the Securities and Exchange Commission and Federal Trade Commission reported jointly today.
ACCRA, Ghana, April 22 -- The first Conference of Independent African States ended here today with an appeal to the great powers to stop the production and testing of nuclear weapons.

MOSCOW, April 22 -- The Soviet Communist party urged tonight that the Yugoslavs retract their "wrong statements." The Yugoslavs also were asked to give up what Moscow called their attempt to "weaken" the unity of the Communist camp.

BRUSSELS, April 22 -- With nothing more than patience and the constitution of an ox, one can eat and drink his way around the world at the Brussels World's Fair. He may be wined and dined in more than fifteen languages and may spend from nothing up to astronomy.
HAVANA, April 22 -- Six rebels were killed in two encounters with Government troops in Oriente Province, an army communique said today.
NORWALK, Conn., April 22 -- Shoreline residents today lost a five-and-one-half-year battle to prevent the construction of an electrical generating plant on Manresa Island.
A four-man committee has been appointed by the Board of Estimate to look into reports of a wide disparity between assessed valuations and court condemnation awards for some properties.

SUMMIT, N. J., April 22 -The president of the Lackawanna Railroad called tonight for prompt action at both the Federal and the state level to alleviate the present economic plight of commuter railroad lines.

JERUSALEM, April 22 (Reuters) -- Premier Ben-Gurion said it was a modern "miracle" that has preserved the people of Israel and their culture and language. All other nations of biblical times, he said, have left only broken tablets to recall that they ever existed.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana warned women Democrats today, that highly explosive situations still prevailed in the Middle and Far East.

LOS ANGELES, April 22 -- Two airlines reported today that there were potentially dangerous aerial acrobatics by military jet planes over Las Vegas, Nev., yesterday hours after the collision in that area of an airliner and an Air Force jet fighter.

An all-star crew of eight regulars and two alternates has been signed for the America's Cup defense candidate Vim. Donald Matthews, 24 - year - old son of John N. Matthews of Center Island, L. I., who owns the boat, gave the name and their duties yesterday.
United Press executives were told yesterday that readers appreciate stories that "tell why an event occurred or that explain its meaning."
THE Spuyten Duyvil Infantry has lost a battle, but won a war.

Ideal utility weather combined with reduced expenses to produce yesterday an increased dividend for some 148,000 stockholders of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. Directors declared a dividend of 70 cents a share, payable June 16 to holders of record May 9. The company had previously paid 60 cents a share quarterly.

THE mail was piled up for the returning traveler like a snowdrift against a garage door. One letter that popped out in the first quick shuffle was rather formidable; it covered three typewritten pages, single-spaced. It was from Clark Shaughnessy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22 -- Approximately $1,000,000 worth of development projects that the United Nations Technical Assistance Program was unable to pay for has been carried out by the specialized agencies on a reimbursable basis.

A $150,000,000 program to renew a twenty-block area west of Central Park will be proposed today by the City Planning Commission. It will be submitted to Mayor Wagner, the Board of Estimate and the Federal Urban Renewal Administration.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 22 -- A Soviet spokesman charged today the United States used "muzzling tactics" and "machine voting" to defeat a move to postpone a vote on a Soviet resolution in the United Nations.

Bad news outweighed the good in yesterday's stock market, for the good, mainly concerned with aid for the railroads, appeared to have been discounted. The outcome was a general but conservative decline that affected all groups except the utilities.
The Concourse Plaza Hotel, a Bronx landmark on the Grand Concourse at 161st Street, has been purchased by a group headed by Phillip P. Zipes, realty operator.
DETROIT, April 22 (UP) -Charley Maxwell hit a three-run homer in the first inning today to start the Detroit Tigers on the way to an 8-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox.
A campaign of the Greater New York Fund for $11,000,000 will begin Monday at a luncheon at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, Norman S. Goetz, the fund's president, announced yesterday.
The blockade of piers here by truck owners and teamsters tightened yesterday despite the intervention of Mayor Wagner.
Leonard Bernstein last night received an American Jewish Congress award for his contributions to music.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I. April 22 -- The opening of the Ladies Village Improvement Society's Bargain Box has been announced for Friday.
CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- Grain futures prices on the Board of Trade eased today except in the rye and July wheat contracts.

While televised boxing is occasionally considered an un-lively art, Truman K. Gibson Jr., the new president of the International Boxing Club, said yesterday that pugilism had become part of the television business and that fist-fighters were made to order for sponsors wishing to advertise beer, razors or deodorants.
The operations of the Port of New York were down to 30 per cent of normal yesterday as the boycott of docks by truck owners -- supported by teamster pickets -- entered its second week.

Events night: Down Town Glee Club, George Mead, conductor; Nancy Cirillo, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Peter Bergquist. bassoonist, and Marion Gedney, soprano, Mannes College of Music, 8:30; "Chanticleer" and "In a Garden," Pyramid Theatre, 4 St. Mark's Place, 8:40.
SAN JUAN, P. R., April 22 (UP) -- Pablo Casals received a five-minute standing ovation tonight after his performance opening the 1958 Casals Festival.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration has rejected all proposals by the Burlington County, N. J., planning board to establish an international jet airport in the county.

LONDON, April 22 -- Prices of leading industrials weakened on the stock market today as trading volume declined. The hesitancy of investors was ascribed to the prospect of labor strife in the transport industry.
KINGSTON, N. Y., April 23 -- Bernard Tompkins, former State Senator from Queens, named four staff members today for an investigation of alleged kickbacks in official purchases.
The Administration's proposals for curing the chronic ills of the nation's railroads got a cold shoulder from the industry and from Wall Street yesterday.
GENEVA, April 22 -- Britain and the United States rejected today a Soviet proposal for a meeting of East-West trade ministers this year.

ROME, April 23 -- The Vatican urged Roman Catholics in Italy today to rally in a "single front" for next month's elections. It was made clear that the ruling Christian Democratic party was to be this front.

NEAT and subdued in his business suits, Aleksandar Rankovic would be picked by most persons as a prosperous, middle-aged Middle European business man. At 48, M. Rankovic, who challenged Moscow yesterday at the Yugoslav party congress, is not a man who stands out in a crowd.
MEXICO CITY, April 23 -- Tariff increases ranging from 25 to 400 per cent will go into effect here tomorrow.
LINCOLN, R. I., April 23 (AP) -- Miss Holmdel won the featured seventh race at Lincoln Downs today before 8,703.

THE thriving center for small galleries in the East Tenth Street area has often been compared to Paris' left-bank gallery quarter. Now a comparison is doubly warranted, for the most recent addition to the roster is the Galerie Grimaud, 96 East Tenth Street, a small, professional-looking gallery that could well be situated on the Rue de Seine.
A task force of 100 men from the Police Juvenile Aid Bureau will go into the parks, playgrounds and streets in the next few days in a stepped-up war against youth gangs.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Soviet Union has rejected the West's proposal to set up technical groups to study disarmament controls, the State Department said tonight.

Charges that the Bethlehem Steel Corporation uses tie-in sales to squeeze small independents out of the steel industry were challenged yesterday. Two defense witnesses denied the charges attributed to them in antitrust proceedings by which the Government is trying to block the acquisition of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company by Bethlehem.

A one-story taxpayer building containing five stores at 102-15 to 25 Queens Boulevard, corner of Sixty-eighth Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, has been sold by A. B. and B. B. Block, realty brokers, and Shampan Shampan, architects, who built it ten year ago.
LOS ANGELES, April 23 (AP) -- A new birth control method, said by its sponsor to have the approval of leading Roman Catholic Church officials, was described here today in a medical movie.
HAVANA, April 23 -- The hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church in Cuba may again attempt to end the current civil strife, persons close to the church said today.

SAN JUAN, P. R., April 23 -- Puerto Ricans are an appreciative people, and last night they paid tribute to the two musicians who have done most to help them establish a major music festival -- Pablo Casals and Alexander Schneider.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., April 23 -- A General Electric Company plan to beat the recession and a call for more profits for defense industries were presented today by Ralph J. Cordiner.
A sleek and functional multi-purpose waterfront facility is to be built on the East River at Twenty-third Street, the city announced yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, April 23 -- Being in an expansive mood, Archibald MacLeish has written an epic of mankind. He calls it "J. B." It was acted for the first time at the Yale University Theatre last evening.

OTTAWA, April 23 (UP) -- Canada's trade deficit in the first quarter of the year was $101,000,000, less than half the $241,000,000 deficit recorded in the like period of 1957, the Bureau of Statistics said today.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee neared final action on President Eisenhower's foreign-aid request today after trimming $339,000,000 from the $3,942,000,000 authorization bill for the 1959 fiscal year, beginning July 1.

United States Attorney Paul W. Williams denied yesterday that his office had ever been told by the Department of Justice to drop its grand jury investigation of income tax frauds alleged against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr.
New York City is strongly urging Governor Harriman to veto the bill proposing an interstate transit compact between New York and New Jersey.

Upstate commercial bankers must recognize the need of savings banks there for additional branches, the newly elected president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York asserted yesterday. He is Kilgore Macfarlane Jr., president of the Buffalo Savings Bank.

HONG KONG, April 23 -The Soviet Union and Communist China signed a new trade treaty in Peiping today. At the same time they announced plans for an increase in trade between the two countries, this year, the Hsinhua (New China) news agency reported.

UNDER the catch-all title "From Here to There," three one-act musicals were offered last night at the Sullivan Street Playhouse. Presumably the "Here" applies to the first two entrants, "Otherwise Engaged" and "Slow Dusk," which take place on this planet, and the "There" must be for "A Real Strange One," the setting of which is Mars. So much for deduction.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Two prominent nuclear scientists predicted today that atomic-powered rockets would be able to launch space vehicles weighing ten tons and more.

ATHENS, April 23 -Greek Army officials told today how a Bulgarian family had crossed the border from Yugoslavia in a 1927 model American-made touring car encased in cement and sheet iron and equipped with a home-made periscope.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -The strain and pressure of the job began to show on President Eisenhower today for almost the first time in six years.
Bruno Zirato, managing director of the New York Philharmonic, will retire from that post, after thirty years' association with the orchestra, in May, 1959.
PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- The directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad took no dividend action at today's meeting. The company's second quarter dividend usually is declared at this time.
PARIS, April 23 -- Former Premier Rene Pleven sought today to establish wide agreement on Algerian policy among the divided political parties.

MOSCOW, April 23 (AP) -- American basketball players, preparing for a series of games against the Russians, are having trouble getting used to an Italian basketball and a strange set of international rules.

CLEVELAND, April 23 (AP) -- A few sizable orders in special areas lifted net new orders in the machine-tool industry during March, but the total was only about half that of March, 1957, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported today.

ROSCOE, N. Y., April 23 -- A dignified discussion on the use of the streamer came up here tonight and a man of authority stated that the East Branch of the Delaware could be fished upstream and across, while the Beaverkill had to be fished downstream and across.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Senate and House conferees rejected today the Administration's plan to charge 5 cents for out-of-town letters. This had been approved by the Senate in a close vote last February.
World air lines were told yesterday what every delicatessen man has known for ages -- a sandwich is a sandwich.

Reflecting a 22 per cent sales decline in the first quarter of this year, the net earnings of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company fell $8,157,956 to $5,068,336 from $13,226,292 in the same period a year ago.
LONDON, April 23 -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer said today that Britain would be affected "very seriously indeed" if the United States recession were too deep or too long.

Nickel production by the world's largest producer, the International Nickel Company of Canada, will be curtailed about 10 per cent during the first week of May because of growing surpluses. A similar cutback was made by the company last month.

RUMSON, N. J., April 23 -- Geraniums will mark the roadways and decorate the doorways to unusual and historic Monmouth County homes to be visited May 27 in a "Maytime Tour." The event will aid the New Jersey State Hospital at Marlboro.
NYACK, N. Y., April 23 -Assemblyman Robert Walmsley of Nyack was reported today to be the choice of Republican leaders to replace Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh in the State Senate.

With the best wishes of the British Crown and nation, in which the American people will surely join, The West Indies, the newly born federation of former British colonies in the Caribbean, have now embarked on their separate national existence.

What can be done, in the race against time and blight, to reverse the downhill course of a city neighborhood before the only salvation is to send in the bulldozers and start all over? This was the problem tackled in a two-year study of a twenty-block area west of Central Park made under the supervision of the Department of City Planning, with Federal, state and city cooperation.

Robert L. Joseph, producer-author, has undertaken the assignment of dramatizing for the Broadway stage the French novel "La Face" by Pierre Boulle, author of the Academy Award-winning film "The Bridge on the River Kwai."
A group of next season's debutantes are among the member's of a junior committee formed to work for the success of the annual Spring Festival of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church May 8 and 9.
CHICAGO, April 23 (UP) -- A Probate judge today provided Charles (Chuck) Comiskey with a form of legal insurance against his possible ouster from the Chicago White Sox hierarchy.
The Columbia Broadcasting System television network hopes to liven up the summer by reviving the community sing.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, April 23 -- R. S. Garfield Todd, former Prime Minister of Southern Rhodesia, and six of his supporters broke away today from the governmental United Federal party. Mr. Todd also resigned as Minister of Labor.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 23 (AP) -- The State Conservation Commissioner announced tonight a broad program to improve recreation facilities in the forest preserve. He denounced in detail a proposal to open those woodlands to lumbering operations.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- A "hot cave" and five other new laboratories for basic cancer research were opened today at the Argonne Cancer Research Hospital operated by the University of Chicago for the Atomic Energy Commission.

PINEHURST, N. C., April 23 (AP) -- The defending champion, Bill Campbell, the medalist, Wayne Jackson, and the gallery favorite, Billie Joe Patton, were shunted to the sidelines today as the second and third rounds of the North and South amateur golf tournament produced a wave of upsets.
A former provisional inspector for the Department of Buildings was indicted yesterday on a charge of first-degree perjury.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (UP) -Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference:
ALBANY, April 23 -- A bill designed to reorganize the New York City Housing Authority was signed without comment today by Governor Harriman.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower said today the United States must exchange atomic weapons secrets if it wanted to maintain allies and make them stronger militarily.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Consumer Price Index rose to another record level in March. It posted as large a one-month increase as any since the current upward movement began two years ago.

The leaders of the Yugoslav Communist League have now given clear evidence that they do not intend to retreat any further in the latest flare-up of their decade-long struggle against Moscow's domination. President Tito's rebuff of the Soviet demand for ideological surrender was phrased in firm terms when he opened the Yugoslav Communist Congress on Tuesday.

WARSAW, April 23 -- The political storm between the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia has put Poland's Communist leaders in a dilemma. This was reflected today in an editorial in Trybuna Ludu on the current congress of the Yugoslav party.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) off to 8 points (40 cents a bale) up yesterday. Volume was moderate.

Electric power production last week fell to 11,107,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 11,307,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended April 20, 1957, was 11,485,000,000 kilowatt-hours.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -The Senate headed into an unexpected battle over labor legislation today with the Democratic leadership confident it can turn back Republican attempts to establish new controls over unions.

Harry Stromberg, alias Nig Rosen, a racketeer and underworld leader, was sentenced in Federal Court yesterday to five years in prison and was fined $10,000 for a narcotics conspiracy. He was described as the financial backer of a $20,000,000-a-year international narcotics ring.
Small gains among the industrials and small losses among the rails produced a virtual stand-off in the market yesterday.
HALLANDALE, Fla., April 23 (AP) -- Florida concluded its 178-day horse racing season on an optimistic note today with the final program at Gulfstream Park.
A gorilla showed up yesterday at the American Newspaper Publishers Association convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- House investigators denounced today the Freeport Sulphur Company of New York for hiring a private detective to delve into the personal background of a Government official.
ALBANY, April 23 -- Governor Harriman today overruled a policy of a state administrative agency that was designed to insure equal treatment for all veterans who claim real property exemptions.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 23 -- Israelis will hold a parade of troops and tanks here tomorrow commemorating the tenth anniversary of their nation's independence.

LONDON, April 23 -- For a moment the partisan business of questions in the House of Commons stopped today. The reason was a small, thin figure walking slowly but steadily toward his seat. Sudden cheers burst from the Labor and Conservative benches as the House acclaimed Sir Winston Churchill, its most distinguished member.
