Special Sessions Justice Myles A. Paige, the first Negro to serve in the Magistrates and Special Sessions Courts here, was named yesterday by Mayor Wagner as a Justice of the Court of Domestic Relations.

THE vegetable known as cabbage, now seasonable and inexpensive, does not have to be the pedestrian fare that it is alleged to be. Given a certain amount of derring-do, this stepchild from the greengrocer can take on elegant aspects to make it the equal of its comelier cousins-cauliflower, broccoli and Brussels sprouts.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- Rye and soybean futures were hit fairly hard in a sell-off on the Board of Trade today.

LOS ANGELES, April 23 (UP) -- Chuck Tanner's pinch-hit home run in the top of the ninth followed by Bobby Thomson's two-run double tonight gave a 7-6 victory to the Chicago Cubs over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

On Tuesday, April 22, 1958, the Representative of the Soviet Union to the United Nations, Ambassador Arkady Sobolev, held a press conference at the United Nations in which he made several remarks directed at Henry Cabot Lodge and concerning the meeting of the United Nations Security Council on April 21.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Neil H. McElroy offered his Congressional questioners some concessions today in the Administration's plan for reorganizing the Pentagon. Mr. Mc Elroy, Secretary of Defense, refused, however, to yield ground before sustained attempts by Representatives to depict the plan as a dangerous blueprint for centralizing military power along Prussian lines.

Kaiser Steel Corporation has sold privately 200,000 shares of $100 par value 5 3/4 per cent convertible preference stock to a group of insurance companies, investment trusts, pension funds, universities and other institutional investors. The transaction was negotiated by The First Boston Corporation.

THE Philadelphia Phillies made their bow last night on Channel 9 as a regular television attraction in New York; it may be a while before the Pennsylvania Railroad finds it necessary to add extra trains between the two cities.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 23 -- Delegates to the national convention of the League of Women Voters relaxed this afternoon to watch a parade of hats.

DOTHAN, Ala., April 23 -- Interservice rivalries, spotlighted in Washington by the Congressional hearings on defense reorganization that started yesterday, are conspicuous by their absence in the field.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 (AP) -- Daryl Spencer crashed a two-run homer with two out in the ninth inning today for an 8-7 victory by the San Francisco Giants over the St. Louis Cardinals.
POMPTON LAKES, N. J., April 23 -- The police have arrested a 15-year-old Haskell, N. J., youth on charges of stealing enough explosives from the du Pont plant here to blow up a city block.
LONDON, April 23 -- The stock market was unsettled here today. Government securities advanced, while industrial shares again closed with more losses than gains.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -Senate investigators developed a story today of vandals' splattering acid or paint remover on thirty-nine automobiles while unionists picketed Philadelphia dealers in 1956.
CLEVELAND, April 23 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians today traded an infielder, Fred Hatfield, to the Cincinnati Redlegs for Bob Kelly, a right-handed pitcher.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 23 (UP) -- Two Californians, Bob Perry and Mimi Arnold, advanced to the quarter-finals in singles in the British hard-courts tennis championships today.

TRENTON, April 23 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner appointed John G. Thevos today as Prosecutor of Passaic County and Charles S. Joelson as administrative director of the State Department of Law and Public Safety.
ATLANTA, April 23 (AP) -- A brother of Gov. Marvin Griffin has been indicted with the Mayor of Baxley on charges of cheating and swindling and taking money to influence the Governor.
THERE is something to taste at almost every booth at the Festival of Foods, which opened yesterday at the New York Coliseum.
Mayor Wagner signed a City Council bill yesterday allowing the Veterans of Foreign Wars to hold a parade through the business section of Fifth Avenue on Saturday, Loyalty Day.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (AP) -- Jack Sanford allowed seven hits and contributed a two-run single with the bases loaded tonight as the Phillies defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 8 -- 1. Rip Repulski scored two runs with the Phillies' first home run of the season in the eighth inning.

The implications of the vigorous efforts of the Administration to modify the Atomic Energy Act so as to empower the President to give all necessary ingredients and information on atomic weapons to-anyone he deems fit simply appall me.

FOR the first time in the history of the age-old cottage crafts of Greece, a collection has been gathered for display here. It is the result of a two-year project conducted under the auspices of the International Cooperation Administration.

The annual convention of the National Knitted Outerwear Association was told yesterday by A. W. Zelomek, consulting economist, that the industry should be thinking in terms of a good fall and winter season and preparing for it now. He spoke at a luncheon meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
DUBLIN, April 23 (Reuters) -- The Irish Government bowed to the Iepurechauns tonight.
Fordham University will raise its tuition fees in September.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday first quarter gains of 29 per cent in net income and 11 per cent in operating revenues. Electric operating revenues increased by 5.6 per cent, and gas revenues soared 50 per cent above the 1957 levels.
In your editorial "Humane Slaughter" of April 13, you urge the Senate to pass H.R.8308, recently approved by the House of Representatives.

The New York City police were preparing last night to test a 38-caliber pistol with which John Acropolis, Westchester labor leader, may have been murdered Aug. 26, 1952. Although the Acropolis case has been the subject of several grand jury, state and Federal inquiries, it never has been solved.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 23 -- Dr. Benjamin Fletcher Wright, president of Smith College since 1949, has submitted his resignation, effective in June, 1959.

Sales of Air Reduction Company, Inc., in the first quarter were $43,254,129, a decline of 6.5 per cent from the $46,243,507 in the same period a year ago. Earnings were $3,370,716, or 88 cents a share, against $4,333.945, or $1.16 a share in the 1957 period, it was reported at the annual meeting here yesterday.

From the hills of Galilee to the sands of Aqaba, from the waters of the Dead Sea to the shores of the Mediterranean, a myriad of blue-and-white flags will be flying proudly today in celebration of the tenth anniversary of the independence of the State of Israel.

CAIRO, April 23 -- Official sources said today the United Arab Republic probably would pay the equivalent of about $40,000,000 as compensation for Egypt's nationalization of the Universal Suez Canal Company in 1956.

GLEN COVE, L. I., April 23 -- A small black-and-white mongrel dog has received special permission from city and animal society officials to accompany a 12-year-old blind boy to and from school. Bootsie, the 5-year-old companion of Vincent Basile, ran afoul of the law last Thursday when he wandered from the path between the boy's home at 16 Grove Street and the school, a half block away.

On May 1 the Consolidated Edison Company will raise its monthly minimum charge for electric service from 80 cents to $1 for the first ten kilowatt hours. The increase was approved yesterday by the Public Service Commission.

The Administration has sent to Congress, in the form of a letter from Secretary of Commerce Weeks to the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, four proposals dealing with the long-term problems of the railroads and one dealing with the immediate emergency problem.

CLEVELAND, April 23 (AP) -- Herb Score proved he was back on the beam today by pitching a three-hit shutout and striking out thirteen Chicago batters as the Cleveland Indians defeated the White Sox, 2 -- 0.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

SYRACUSE, April 23 (AP) -- The Cuban heavyweight champion, Nino Valdes, scored a split decision over Mike DeJohn of Syracuse in a ten-round, nationally televised bout tonight. DeJohn weighed 204 pounds, Valdes 206 1/2.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Thursday, April 24 -- The Air Force last night made its first attempt to fire a nose cone the full range of an intercontinental ballistic missile. But indications were that it flew only 600 or 700 miles.

The city can balance its new budget only by borrowing, the relief rolls are rising, the number of unemployed increases, but nothing seems to stay the purchase of Cadillacs for New York City officials. Mayor Wagner has, however, made a distinction. Elected officials may have Cadillacs, regardless of austerity; non-elective officials must travel second-class.
The ominous warning of the city tax collector was sounded yesterday for New York business men.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 23 -- Abe Lev is a Western Union telegrapher assigned to flat and trotting tracks in this area. He has been tapping out dots and dashes for thirty-five years. For an even longer stretch Lev has been a horse-player.
SOMETHING important was lost in the transition that brought the successful novel "Angry Harvest" to the television screen last night.

The State Commission Against Discrimination yesterday announced a series of meetings with Protestant, Jewish and Roman Catholic leaders. The purpose will be to work out "practical, coordinated programs" to combat racial and religious discrimination.
Louis M. Lyons, curator of the Nieman Fellowships at Harvard University, accused the Government last night of attempting to screen and manipulate Washington news.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 23 -- The Association of Motion Picture Producers has turned down a request by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, to resume discussions in an effort to settle the nine-week-old strike of Hollywood musicians.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Representative Kenneth B. Keating urged the Justice Department today to investigate what he called a "propaganda network" of Arab student groups in the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The State of Pennsylvania and the City of Philadelphia asked the Supreme Court today to odred the admission of two Negro boys to Girard College, a school for orphans in Philadelphia.

California borrowed $100,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school construction and loans to war veterans buying homes and farms. The bonds were sold at a cost of 2.9616 per cent on $50,000,000 of veterans' aid bonds, maturing serially from 1959 to 1983, and a cost of 2.9592 per cent on $50,000,000 of school obligations due from 1959 to 1983.
The Sunset International Petroleum Corporation plans to acquire the McRae Oil and Gas Corporation in exchange for more than $8,000,000 (present market value) of Sunset stock.

Cocoa futures closed at or near the highs of the day yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Short covering prior to the first notice date, today, hedge lifting and manufacturer buying for price fixing strengthened the market. Stop-loss buying was reported. Profit-taking and hedging limited the gains. There was switching out of the near-by months.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The most compact statement made thus far of the reasons for the policy of the Administration in proceeding with tests of nuclear weapons was that recently given to the Senate Subcommittee on Disarmament by Rear Admiral Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.
Individuals and business have slowed the rate at which they spend their checkbook dollars. In part, this is offsetting the Federal Reserve's easier money policy.

HOW much should a man dedicated to the arts use his talents in defense of liberty ? The question has been raised time and again throughout modern history. In the last World War -- or the most recent one, at any rate -- it stirred hot talk when writers, musicians and painters were invited to help the propaganda services of the Government.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended Wednesday, April 16:
The Southern Counties Gas Company borrowed $15,000,000 in the public market yesterday on 4 per cent first mortgage bonds due in 1983.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Fourteen medical experts recommended today that the Surgeon General of the Public Health Service call a special conference "to deal with the mounting problem of staphylococcus infections" in hospitals.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Representative Brooks Hays said today that increased drinking in the Soviet Union was worrying Soviet leaders.
Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan warned last night that a worsening of the economic recession might bring "a crisis in group relations."

A vacant plot 230 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Williamsbridge Road and Rhinelander Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the C. A. Realty Corporation. The buyer, a client of Joseph Howard Katz, attorney, plans a one-story building on the plot for occupancy by a supermarket.
Alco Products, Inc., has announced the election of Perry T. Egbert as chairman and William S. Morris as president. Mr. Egbert formerly was president. Mr. Morris had been executive vice president.
Concern over the safety of Algeria's 120,000 Jews because of the deepening crisis in France was expressed here yesterday.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, April 23 -- Ambassadors from all countries of the Soviet bloc except Poland walked out of the Yugoslav Communist League's seventh congress today as President Tito's chief party lieutenant rebuked Moscow in scathing terms.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would operate a dual cotton export program in the marketing year beginning next Aug. 1.
ALBANY, April 23 (AP) -- Police Justice William L. McDermott of Olean was appointed today administrative director of the state Lottery Control Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- It may be that Casey Stengel has been looking at the American League upside down.

BRONXVILLE, April 23 -- The summer camp for blind children operated at Cornwall-on-the-Hudson by The Lighthouse, New York Association for the Blind, will be the beneficiary of the annual dessert bridge Friday afternoon sponsored by the Women's Society of the Reformed Church of Bronxville.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- An attempt to inject the integration issue into a bill designed to aid school construction and operation was rejected decisively today by the House of Representatives.
Hopes for an early settlement in the increasingly effective blockade of New York's piers by truck owners and teamsters were dashed last night.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., April 23 -- The New Jersey State Municipal Contractors Association today denied charges made against it in a presentment handed up by a Bergen County Grand Jury on March 21. The panel was investigating alleged irregularities in municipal garbage collection contracts.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Juvenile arrests increased sharply last year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.

The Warner Stable's Levelation overcame the handicap of the outside No. 9 post position to win the $23,150 Jamaica Handicap by half a length yesterday in 1:10 4/5, the best six-furlong time of the meeting.

Donald C. Slichter was elected yesterday president and chief executive officer of the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company. He will succeed Edmund Fitzgerald, who was named to the new post of chairman.
Twenty-one daily newspapers won prizes yesterday in the annual safe-driving contest sponsored by the American Newspaper Publishers Association and the International Circulation Managers Association.

FESTIVE flowers and regal wedding cakes preside harmoniously over six bridal table settings now on view at Georg Jensen, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. These settings -- they were designed by Mimi Sheraton, a bridal consultant -- offer a myriad of ideas for both formal and informal receptions.

The chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission declared yesterday that nuclear tests should be continued for the purpose of developing relatively clean and accurate weapons for defense against missiles and bombers.

PITTSBURGH, April 23 (AP) -- George M. Humphrey, chairman of National Steel Corporation and former Secretary of the Treasury, said today the recession probably would not become any worse unless the public became unduly alarmed.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- In the United States Court of Customs and Patents Appeals today, the following proceedings were had:
Continued monetary ease calls for lower interest rates on savings deposits, a New York bank stock dealer told a Providence, R. I., audience yesterday.
The Esso Shipping Company, operator of one of the largest tanker fleets under the American flag, got lost in a corporate shuffle yesterday.

" THE GOOD SOLDIER SCHWEIK," like the little man who is its invincibly cheerful hero, accepts the world's foibles and injustices as naturally as the turning of the earth. On the surface there is laughter, but underneath there are bitterness and disillusion.
The Corn Products Refining Company is expanding its operations into dehydrated soup, bouillon cubes and allied products.

ALBANY, April 23 -- A $53,500,000-a-year increase in state financial assistance to local school districts was approved today by Governor Harriman. About $17,100,000 of the money will go to New York City.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- A coal industry spokesman protested today because the Administration did not propose repeal of wartime taxes on railroads. He is Tom Pickett, executive vice president of the National Coal Association.

Recently the "Stop Nuclear Tests" demonstrators were busy picketing on Park Avenue. They distributed leaflets listing as their supporters a formidable array of names. These names were impressive to the politically naive but depressing to those who remember that it was their counterpart in Britain blissfully chanting "Peace! Peace!" who precipitated Munich and diverted attention from the pact Hitler and Stalin were preparing to ignite World War II.

A bill currently pending in the City Council that would prohibit the issuance of permits for burning discarded automobiles or car parts in the open air has the deserved support of the Department of Air Pollution Control. The department notes that there are some 300 auto wreckers in the city and about 200,000 cars are burned here each year, bringing many complaints.

THE boom was lowered on Auburn by the National Collegiate Athletic Association the other day as the nation's top-ranking football team was hit by its second successive three-year probationary penalty. Other campus cut-ups to feel the weight of disciplinary measures -- although to a lesser degree -- were Seattle and Southern Methodist.

The 1954 law authorizing United States participation in construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway said that tolls to be charged against shipping "shall be calculated to cover, as nearly as practicable, all costs of operating and maintaining the works under the administration of the [Seaway Development] Corporation, including depreciation, payment of interest on the obligations of the Corporation, and payments in lieu of taxes.
Election of John A. Coe as chairman and Richard M. Stewart as president of the American Brass Company was announced yesterday.

LONDON, April 23 (Reuters) -- Following, as issued tonight by Tass, Soviet news agency, is an unofficial translation of the text of Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's letter to President Eisenhower:
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower gave no explicit answer today to a question about pending legislation to curb the power of the Supreme Court.

The Moiseyev Dance Company from Moscow, which has no seats left in any part of the Metropolitan Opera House for the remainder of its engagement there, will return to New York at the conclusion of its American tour for four performances at Madison Square Garden under the direction of S. Hurok.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The former patent adviser to the Federal Communications Commission testified today that the commission had adopted a "hands-off policy" that enabled the Radio Corporation of America to monopolize patent licenses for television and radio frequency modulation equipment.
A phenomenon takes place over our heads this time of year. Billions of birds -- 12 to 15 billion, the experts say -- crowd the flyways from the South to northern summering grounds.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- President Eisenhower proclaimed an extraordinary emergency today and suspended the eight-hour work day for all laborers helping to modernize the nation's air navigation system.

Base prices of titanium mill products were reduced an average of 10 per cent yesterday by the Titanium Metals Corporation of America, in the seventh series of reductions since 1954. Some products, such as high-strength alloy plate and billet -- in largest demand by designers of jet engines, air-frames and missiles -- were cut 20 to 30 per cent.

The Texas Company and its subsidiaries had a sharp drop in earnings in the first quarter of this year. Augustus C. Long, chairman, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday that the consolidated net income was $70,003,000, or $1.25 a share.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 23 -- Exhibits in the United States pavilion of the World's Fair are under heavy criticism from many visiting Americans.
GENEVA, April 23 -- The United States requested reconsideration of its formula for territorial sea limits and fishing controls at the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea today.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower referred to the economic recession today as a "minor emergency" that people should not get "hysterical" about.
CLEVELAND, April 23 -- The question of how the business recession will affect philanthropic contributions brought a variety of opinions here today.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower suggested indirectly today that any Republicans who thought the party could not win control of the Senate in the November elections should keep it to themselves.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Arnold Constable Corporation, Fifth Avenue (New York) Department Store, and Feldman Lowe, Inc., fur manufacturer at 305 Seventh Avenue, were charged by the Federal Trade Commission today with violating the Fur Products Labeling Act.
WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

Crude oil production in the week ended last Friday averaged 6,250,535 barrels a day, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. This was 63,650 barrels above the three-and-a-half-year low of 6,186,885 set the week before.
Happy-go-lucky about himself and dead serious about his horses -- that sums up Pat Iovine, a harness driver at Roosevelt Raceway.

Specialists in Soviet affairs are exploring the possibility that an undisclosed leadership crisis in Moscow lies behind the new Soviet-Yugoslav breach. Diplomats in Washington and other close observers of Soviet afafirs have detected signs they believe indicate that Nikita S. Khrushchev and some of his fellow members of the Soviet Communist party Presidium have been quarreling again.

A city policeman, riding a motor scooter on his way to report for duty, was injured by a car on the Triborough Bridge last night. He was sideswiped at 11:10 P. M. and thrown to the roadway. The driver did not stop.

LONDON, April 23 -- Aneurin Bevan's support of Soviet tactics in the diplomacy relating to a summit meeting led today to an insinuation that he was a fellow traveler. This touched off an uproar in the House of Commons.

BONN, Germany, April. 23 -- Franz Etzel, Minister of Finance, told the Bundestag today that the first six years of West Germany's military buildup would cost 52,000,000,000 Deutsche marks (about $12,385,000,000).

The start of a "hard selling" program by newspapers to obtain a larger share of advertisers' expenditures was disclosed yesterday by Charles T. Lipscomb Jr., president of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
The determination of newspapers to print full news about the recession was reaffirmed at the American Newspaper Publishers Association convention yesterday.
Tougher academic programs may be in store for the city's bright high school students, Superintendent of Schools William Jansen indicated yesterday.
Lions Clubs in New York State have collected 150,000 pairs of discarded spectacles for the poor in India.
An unfinished office building at 20 East Forty-sixth Street has been sold by Chain System, Inc., the builder, to Theodore Schementi and Howard Barnaby, construction contractors.

PARIS, April 23 -- The stocks of the Universal Suez Canal Company surged upward on the Paris Bourse today on reports that an agreement was near on the compensation of the company by Egypt for the nationalization of the concern in July, 1956.
After a brief period of uneasy stability, claims for unemployment insurance benefits rose significantly last week in many parts of the country.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- Corn and soybean futures reversed their recent downward trend today on the Board of Trade.
A GIRL who started her little brother off on a fashion career later followed in his footsteps. Now they have joined talents to become a design team.

Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan yesterday entered a plea of not guilty for Mark Zborowski, Russian-born anthropologist accused of perjury. He denied he knew Jack Soble, confessed Soviet spy ring leader.

It should not be startling when newspaper publishers applaud a statement in favor of telling the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth. But the fact is that with the best of intentions newspaper publishers and editors have not always thought it prudent to publish all the news about some subjects.

BONN, Germany, April 24 -Anastas I. Mikoyan, a Soviet First Deputy Premier, is scheduled to arrive tomorrow on a four-day visit to West Germany. It will be the first such visit by a leading member of the Soviet Government since establishment of diplomatic relations in 1955.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The new chairman of the National Citizens for Eisenhower-Nixon 1958 Committee reported to the President today on plans to win Republican control of the Senate and House of Representatives in the fall elections.
Custom smelters of copper, reporting "excellent" sales of refined metal all week, yesterday raised their price 1/4 cent a pound to 23 3/4 cents.
THE news for bargain-hungry food consumers is that prices continue at extremely high levels. This is especially true at meat counters.
MOSCOW, April 24 -- Moscow's diplomatic community felt tonight that the Soviet Union and the West were off on another round of sparring in their attempts to arrange a summit conference.

One widespread and comprehensive racket in New York has had little or no attention from press or government. That is the real estate -- specifically the apartment -- racket here, whose participants include unscrupulous contractors, careless and incompetent workmen, gouging owners and cynical management agencies.

It would be economically feasible for the Bethlehem Steel Corporation to enlarge its Midwest steel-producing capacity by acquiring and expanding the facilities of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, it was testified here yesterday.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 24 -- The Board of Selectmen signed an agreement today with George Alpert, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, for building the proposed new commuter parking lot and station at Fairty Orchards, about half a mile down the tracks toward Stamford.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 24 -Southern Presbyterians were warned here tonight against standing aloof from other Protestant denominations in "spiritual pride and isolation."
Pleasure boating is no longer pre-empted by men. There has been an emancipation of women.
WASHINGTON, April 24--Neil H. McElroy opened the door today to substantial changes in President Eisenhower's Pentagon reorganization bill.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee approved today a $577,038,000 military pay increase designed to attract and retain qualified officers and enlisted men.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted 18 to 5 today for a foreign aid authorization bill cutting $339,000,000 from President Eisenhower's request for $3,942,000,000 for the fiscal year starting July 1.

HONEGGER'S "Joan of Arc at the Stake" is a fine, reverent work. First performed twenty years ago, it has gained steadily in stature, and like a number of other compositions that can be adduced, it is proof that our own time is not so sterile creatively as the mourners would have us believe.
Philip J. Cruise, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, will retire next Wednesday. He has been a member of the agency since July 1, 1947, and its chairman since Jan. 1, 1952.

The Soviets are apparently trying to sidetrack serious diplomatic preparations for a summit meeting, unless they can have one on their own terms for their own purposes. Meanwhile, they try to throw back such "preparations" into the field of propaganda and prolix letter writing.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Maxwell M. Rabb, Secretary to the Cabinet of President Eisenhower, resigned today to become a partner in the New York law firm of Stroock Stroock Levan.
LOS ANGELES, April 24 (AP) -- Duke Snider got in and out of the Dodger doghouse in twenty-four hours.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- The report of today'a livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
JAKARTA, April 24 -- The Indonesian Air Force disclosed tonight two unidentified planes had made three raids in the North Moluccas earlier this week.
LONDON, April 24 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey urged today the development of greater trade among the free nations as a means of combating communism.
The American Ballet Theatre is scheduled to leave at 3 P. M. today on a four-month tour of Europe and North Africa that will include appearances at the Brussels World's Fair.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 24 -- Plion picked today to score his first victory of the year, and, while he was about it, the son of Greek Ship picked a good one. He won the thirty-fourth running of the Blue Grass Stakes in a show of gameness that thrilled the crowd of 8,037 at Keeneland.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The American Association of University Professors announced today a special award for service to academic freedom, to be presented to the president and trustees of the University of New Hampshire.
DELAND, Fla., April 24 (AP) -- Four Lutheran Church groups are working through a joint commission on a proposed union that would create a national church body of nearly 3,000,000 members.

The Military Chaplains Association charged yesterday that there was "calculated and unwarranted discrimination against other denominations" in the appointment of chaplains for the cadets at West Point.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- A Chicago teamster official surrendered twenty-five pounds of union documents to Senate investigators today. But his attorney said that he would be back tomorrow to stand guard over them.

Hardly waiting long enough to give decent burial to business protests, and using the time to rationalize a decision made before the public hearing, Mayor Wagner has signed a law to permit the annual Loyalty Day parade to march through the shopping section of Fifth Avenue on Saturday afternoon.
CHICAGO, April 24 -- The head of United Air Lines blamed the Government today for the collision near Las Vegas Monday that cost forty-nine lives. A United airliner and an Air Force jet were involved.
MIAMI BEACH, April 24 (UP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson said tonight that education must have priority over all other civilian wants if the nation was to survive the East-West struggle.
WARSAW, April 24 -- Yekaterina A. Furtseva of the Soviet Communist party Presidium said tonight that there would never be a repetition of the Soviet-Yugoslav rupture of 1948.

HONOLULU, April 24 -- Federal Judge Jon Wiig today signed a temporary court order restraining the crew of the ketch Golden Rule from leaving Honolulu tomorrow for the nuclear testing grounds at Eniwetok.

A REMARKABLY mature first one - man show of paintings by Walter Feldman is the current attraction at the Kraushaar Gallery, 1055 Madison Avenue. The artist spent two years in Italy on a Fulbright Fellowship, but a visit to Israel has left its imprint on the recent paintings.

A gaily striped marquee amid acres of prize-winning narcissus will be the setting in Rye, N. Y., today for the Spring Garden Party to benefit the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- On the three-shaded green of Independence Square, 5,000 persons joined national, state and city leaders this afternoon in saluting Israel's tenth anniversary as a nation.
LONDON, April 24 -- The continued strength of Government securities was the feature of stock market trading here today.

After receiving some parting guidance from Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, four young Americans were ready to leave for Moscow late last night in the first official exchange of students between the Soviet Union and the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- President Eisenhower sent to Congress today a plan to merge the Federal Civil Defense Administration with the Office of Defense Mobilization. He proposed to call the combined agency the Office of Defense and Civilian Mobilization.
Harry J. Shapolsky, alleged "front man" for realty investments by Building Department officials, won the right to bail yesterday pending his appeal from a thirty-day sentence for contempt of court.

ROME, April 24 -- A widely publicized handshake between Nikita S. Khrushchev and a Hungarian Roman Catholic Archbishop drew the comment from the Vatican today that the latter obviously was not a free man.

Governor Harriman nears the end of his 30-day bill signing period. He is now free to think about the major omission of the regular session of the Legislature, the failure to give first passage to comprehensive court reform. His concern with this failure has been manifested. But the question is whether he has done everything he could to correct it.

ALBANY, April 24 -- The Board of Regents decided today not to increase by one-third the amount of training in professional education required of applicants for permanent certificates as teachers in the state.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24 -- The United States is inviting the representatives of fourteen nations to witness a nuclear test in the Pacific this summer, it became known here today.

Heavy additions to the backlog of new municipal bonds were posted yesterday as the market for tax-exempt securities continued to put on a show of strength. Following quickly on the oversubscription of the State of California's offering of $100,000,000 of school and veterans' aid bonds, eleven state and city governments announced plans for borrowings totaling more than $158,000,000.
The adventures of Peter Freuchen, who was nicknamed "the modern Viking," will be brought to the musical stage.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Legislation to outlaw interstate liquor advertising was denounced by a spokesman for the radio and television industry as discriminatory to a "perfectly legitimate item of commerce."
An airliner with a green shamrock painted on its nose took off from New York International Airport last night to begin the first trans-Atlantic air service of the Irish Republic, would be a success.
Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson said here yesterday that "just lowering prices" is a means of combating the recession as it affects some manufactured goods.
As a climax to the Henry Street Friends Committee camp fund drive, a benefit dance, the Blue Chip Ball, will be held in Oscar's Delmonico here on May 10.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Administration announced today that it would seek a test in the Senate immediately on its 1958 labor-law program.

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- American machine tool builders will move production facilities overseas unless there are changes in the tariff schedule, the president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association said here today. He is Alfred V. Bodine, president of the Bodine Corporation of Bridgeport, Conn.

WITH women looking like children this season, Greta Plattry, long established as a designer of women's sportswear, found it easy to backtrack a bit and design some clothes for girls -- her first such attempt in seventeen years. Her summer collection of sportswear and swimwear for all ages was shown yesterday at Best Co.

SYRACUSE, April 24 (AP) -- Al Mut of New Orleans provided an unusual standings change in the minor events of the American Bowling Congress today when he rolled a 708 series to claim fourth place in the singles standings.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -Opponents of the disputed Democratic unemployment relief bill forced postponement of action today in the House Rules Committee.

Following is the text of the address of Vice President Richard M. Nixon last night at the annual dinner of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel:

HAVANA, April 24 -- President Fulgencio Batista and his Cabinet probably will suspend constitutional guarantees again at midnight tomorrow night, when the present forty-five-day suspension ends, reliable sources said today.
TRENTON, N. J., April 24 -- The State Assembly approved a bill today calling for a referendum this fall on a $45,000,000 bond issue to finance two new reservoirs.
ALBANY, April 24 -- Legislation authorizing New York State to participate in the proposed bi-state Metropolitan Transit District was approved today by Governor Harriman.
Four prominent musicians will make their first appearances with the Stadium Symphony Orchestra during the six-week Stadium Concert season, beginning June 23.

ALBANY, April 24 (AP) -- Insurance companies took Governor Harriman's insurance superintendent into court today in an unusual move to win an increase of $12,000,000 a year in automobile liability premiums.

Commodity futures closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Potatoes, sugar, cottonseed oil, copper, lead and zinc rose. Rubber, hides and coffee declined. Price movements for cocoa and wool were mixed.
LONDON, April 24 -- Britain's Labor party Opposition has rejected a proposal for a bipartisan House of Commons Committee to discuss secret defense information.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 24 (AP) -- Billy Casper shot a seven-under-par 65 today to lead a field of twenty-two golfers in the first round of the $40,000 Tournament of Champions.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The tariff commission today found unanimously that imports of lead and zinc are such as to cause "serious injury" to United States producers. But the commissioners split, three to three, on the vital question of whether quantity restrictions on imports should be imposed.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 24 -- The Indian Government today reasserted its right to treat Kashmir as "an integral part" of India.

The Pennsylvania Railroad recorded a $3,556,200 net loss last month and so far this year has operated at a $14,899,621 deficit. In March of last year the railroad cleared $4,011,863 and in the first quarter of 1957 reported a net profit of $5,373,084.
Van Cliburn, the 23-year-old American pianist who went to Moscow and made a name for himself, will appear on Steve Allen's television program May 25 over the National Broadcasting Company network.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars said today it did not know how "any self-respecting" United States veterans group would want to have any contact with the Soviet veterans of the Elbe River link-up.

In these days when we read about New York as the city of culture, there could not be more disappointing news than the announcement of the disbanding of the famous New York Police Department and Fire Department bands. The respective commissioners have decreed the winding up of these organizations for the sake of economy.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Transamerica Corporation, largest bank holding company in the United States, approved today a plan to turn over its majority interest in 322 banking offices to a new concern, Firstamerica Corporation.

Profits of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest steel producer, dropped nearly 54 per cent in the first quarter of this year, as compared with earnings a year earlier, when the industry was turning out ingots at close to capacity.
CINCINNATI, April 24--(AP) Warren Spahn survived first-inning wildness and, aided by two home runs by Hank Aaron, pitched the Milwaukee Braves to a 6-2 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs tonight.

PONAPE, Caroline Islands, April 12 -- When the scattered tropical islands of Micronesia become a nation in the distant future, the emancipated women of the new state may look back to a jolly Gilbert Islander named Mrs. Rose Makwelung as the liberator of their sex.
A two-day course for physicians on how to restore life after hearts and lungs have stopped began here yesterday at the New York Academy of Sciences, 2 East Sixty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The impression left by the fable is that Diogenes, with or without his lantern, never found the honest man he kept looking for. Since candor is an integral part of honesty, Meade Alcorn, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, is now in a position to demonstrate why Diogenes could not find, at least among politicians, the man he was seeking.
TUNIS, April 24 -- President Habib Bourguiba announced today that he had dropped a plan to renew Tunisian charges against France in the United Nations Security Council.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The nation needs a revised set of values in which society gives high priority to people rather than to things, the American Philosophical Society was told tonight.
MOST well-adjusted, happily married couples who desire children turn emotional somersaults when their first born finally arrives.

CLEVELAND, April 24 -- Housewives, who do most charity collecting in suburban communities, were reported today in revolt against having to repeat visits and phone calls in behalf of various national health organizations.
DETROIT, April 24 -- The president of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway told 1,000 stockholders today that he expected that the company would continue to earn its dividends for the year.
An extensive project to please bird and man is under way in Central Park. It would convert a bleak West Side bird refuge into a picturesque area.

LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, April 24--Vice President Edvard Kardelj, a schoolmaster before he became a Communist revolutionary, read the rulers of the Kremlin a lecture today on the error of seeking to force their doctrine on Yugoslavia or any other country.

Vice President Richard M. Nixon reported "substantial indications" last night that anti-recession moves taken by the Eisenhower Administration "will be all that will be required to give the economy the help it needs."
The maker of a machine that cleans surgical instruments by ultrasonic waves demonstrated it here yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 (UP) -- Daryl Spencer beat out an infield single with the bases loaded in the ninth inning today to give the San Francisco Giants a 6-5 victory over St. Louis before a crowd of 13,674.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UP) -- The nation's two largest auto makers endorsed today a proposed law to require factory price tags on new cars.
One of the largest consignments of heavy duty trucks ever shipped from this country on a single vessel sailed from here yesterday for India aboard the Isbrandtsen Line freighter Flying Foam.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The United States, Britain and France urged the Soviet Union today to take immediate and practical steps toward a serious summit conference.
The International Typographical Union was sharply criticized yesterday by a publishers' committee for "an inordinate increase" in newspaper strikes last year.

Members of the Finch College Alumnae Association will act as models at the annual luncheon and fashion show of the group to be held on Tuesday in the Crystal Room of the Sherry-Netherland. Proceeds will go to the college's development fund.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph M. Swing, Commissioner of Immigration, vowed today to deport William Heikkila "if it takes from now until I get kicked out."

ELEVEN artists are banded together in the Manhattan Group, which exhibits oils, encaustics, enamels and caseins at the Riverside Museum, Riverside Drive and 103d Street. Among oils, Anna Walinska's freely flowing landscape abstractions have the most autographic quality, though Seymour Tubis, George Habergritz, May Heiloms and Robert Baer contribute notable paintings as well.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Friday, April 25 -- The Navy postponed the firing of its first fully instrumented earth satellite early today after turning back four times when the count-down had come within ten minutes of firing time.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The State Department is planning to release Egypt's frozen assets in the United States but to avoid taking political credit for it.

ROSCOE, N. Y., April 24 -- Members of the Beaverkill cult ought to begin this week-end to live, which means catch trout, provided they go to the right places, hit good weather, know how to fish, live right and are lucky.

LOS ANGELES, April 24 -Dr Craig Taylor, noted aeronautical scientist, was killed today when he fell from the roof of the four-story University of California at Los Angeles engineering building. He was 48 years old.

One floor and part of another in the building at 445 Park Avenue, at Fifty-sixth Street, has been leased by the Tishman Realty and Construction Company to the Grey Advertising Agency. The lessee will use the space for five of its departments, media, marketing and research, accounting, publicity and promotion.
The city moved yesterday to cooperate with nine private colleges and universities here in setting up 100 annual scholarships and fellowships to encourage science and mathematics teaching.

A painting of a knight in shining armor in a scenic setting has been put on exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It is on loan from the Castle Rohonez Museum in Lugano, Switzerland, the home of the private collection of Baron Heinrich Thyssen.

The rate of earnings of agencies declined in 1957 for the first time in eight years, Frederick R. Gamble, president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies reported yesterday at the annual meeting at White Sulphur Springs, West Va.

"CLIMAX!" a television show that specializes in plays about assorted forms of violence, tried a change of pace last night. Except for the interference of electronic gremlins, it might have been a success.
TRENTON, April 24 -- The Republican and Democratic parties convened their 1958 state conventions here today.
NARBERTH, Pa., April 24 -- A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Edgar D. Paul Jr. of Narberth on April 15 in Lankenau Hospital, Philadelphia.

The Lloyd Chamber Singers, three men and three women, made their debut last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. They are Lynn Clark, soprano; Jan Ruetz, mezzo-soprano; Nancy Hall, alto; Gordon Richmond, tenor, and Alan Baker and Arthur Burrows, baritones.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- Television rights to Ernest Hemingway's "A Farewell to Arms" have been acquired by the Columbia Broadcasting System for production as a two-hour live show.
GIVAT YESHAYAHU, Israel, April 16 -- Israel started plugging one of the last big gaps along her borders this week when the first families were moved into the Adulum region.
Harrison Salisbury's recent articles on the city's school children, their backgrounds and delinquency problems, well deserved the prominent front-page presentation given them.

A FIFTH-SEVENTH Street furrier is carrying the message to Garcia by way of Moscow. He is Saul Aronowicz, who is arranging the fashion exhibit that will be part of the United States Trade Fair in Moscow's Gorky Park during August.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -President Eisenhower became an art critic for a brief time today. The President cast an amateur painter's eye over a rugged North African landscape by Sir Winston Churchill and proclaimed it "one of his best."

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 24 (AP) -- A waterfront fire destroyed millions of gallons of petroleum products at the Deep-water Terminal of the Esso Standard Oil Company today. An Esso spokesman said damage would run "into several million dollars.

WASHINGTON, April 24--The Interstate Commerce Commission dismissed charges today that the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company violated antitrust laws in acquiring 14.8 per cent of the voting stock of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad Company.

VALLETTA, Malta, April 24 -- The dispute between the governments of Britain and Malta sharpened today. Governor Sir Robert Laycock took control of the day-to-day administration of the island after he had formally accepted the resignation of Prime Minister Dom Mintoff.
THE northwest corner of the Tenth Street-Second Avenue crossroad has been used without break for houses of worship close onto 300 years -- longer than any other church site in the city.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 24 (AP) -- Budge Patty lost to a 22-year-old Briton and two other Americans were beaten today in the quarter-finals of the British hard courts tennis championships.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., April 24 -- The League of Women Voters decided today to concentrate its attention in the next two years on an examination of the nation's foreign policy and its water resources.
PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, April 24 -- The publisher of and two writers for the newspaper Haiti Miroir were jailed yesterday after the publication of an article considered a defamation of the army.
ESSEX FELLS, N. J., April 24 -- The Garden State Women's Golf Association started its season over the Essex Fells Country Club course today.

The Investors Funding Corporation of New York has purchased the nine-story apartment building at 70 East Seventy-seventh Street. The house occupies a plot 99 by 102 feet and contains twenty-eight apartments of seven and eight rooms.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- An old soldier who hunted Pancho Villa in vain gave voice today to a different kind of frustration:

A Queens housewife told the Board of Estimate yesterday that it was extravagant to buy a $6,390 Cadillac for Borough President James J. Crisona of her borough. An embarrassed silence followed her brief but emotional protest. Then the board voted the authorization for the new car.

LENDINARA, Italy, April 24 (UP) -- Gypsy Queen Mimi of the Rossetto tribe died today on the straw-covered floor of her patched tent in the heart of the town square. She left behind a dispute over her successor and a mystery over her treasure.
Gen. Curtis E. LeMay declared yesterday that "the danger of general war is on the increase" because of rising Soviet nuclear and air power.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- First-quarter revenues of United Air Lines, at $66,143,912, were 10 per cent higher than those of the same period last year and made a new record for the first quarter. But the company had a loss of $599,964 from operations.
MONTREAL, April 24 (AP) -- Aluminium, Ltd., big Canadian producer of aluminum, today reported sharply lower earnings in the first quarter of 1958, but added that incoming orders were improving.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., April 24 -- Fourteen-year-old Cheryl Crane, who fatally stabbed an admirer of her actress mother, Lana Turner, was placed tonight in the temporary custody of her grandmother, Mrs. Mildred Turner.
John A. Roosevelt announced yesterday that a "Draft Rockefeller for Governor" headquarters would be opened here next Wednesday.

LOS ANGELES, April 24 (AP) -- Lee Walls, who hit only six home runs last season, smacked three over the Coliseum's screen and drove in eight runs today as the Chicago Cubs routed the Los Angeles Dodgers 15 -- 2.
THINGS are going swimmingly in Bond's Vacation Shop, especially for the woman who wonders whether she can afford a holiday after she has bought her holiday clothes.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The chief of the Air Force ballistic missile program disclosed today that development of a military reconnaissance satellite had been given top national priority.
As long as the top men in government do not know what's wrong with the United States economy, how can we expect the public to know?

THE town in North Staffordshire was a pottery and coal mining center. "Everything was shabby, dirty, dwarfish, peeling and generally lousy." Provincial, drab and uncultivated, it yet throbbed with human energy and with fiercely competitive ambitions. The idea of life as a deadly competition was preached in the town's schools and bred in the bones of its children.

Air travelers throughout the country evidently are taking seriously Kansas City's own slogan "Buy it now and keep business good," according to Warren Lee Pierson, chairman and acting president of Trans World Air lines.
A mining man moved up to the chairmanship of the Anaconda Company for the first time yesterday, and another took his place as president.
SAN JUAN, P. R., April 24 -- Mozart, Beethoven and Brahms are the composers of this year's Casals Festival.

OSLO, Norway, April 24 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Halvard M. Lange told Parliament tonight it was probable that the Soviet Union had platforms in Poland, East Germany and Czechoslovakia for the launching of intermediate-range ballistic missiles.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 24 -- Because exloding tires sound quite a lot like gunshots, two brothers were foiled here early yesterday in an attempt to run -- or drive -- away from home. It began about 5 P. M. The brothers, 11 and 14 years old, decided to strike out into the world together.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Individual inventors are being crowded out of fundamental research by the Radio Corporation of America's control of radio and television patents, a House subcommittee was told today.

Ian Fleming's account of the diamond smuggling racket, which had been scheduled for publication this month, will be issued by Macmillan on May 13. In "The Diamond Smugglers" he tells of the illicit passage of millions of dollars worth of diamonds from Africa to all parts of the world. The account is based on information the author obtained from a secret agent who was chiefly responsible for penetrating the international smuggling network.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 24 -- Harness racing has gone big time to such an extent that trainers and drivers have to be more than horsemen these days. They have to be raconteurs, lobbyists and hail fellows well met.

The number of mental hospital residents in New York State has declined for the third straight year, Governor Harriman reported yesterday. The decrease for 1957-58 was 1,200, compared to an average of 450 in the two previous years.

WHEN the St. John's basketball team upended Toledo in the final of the National Invitation Tournament in 1943, the players of both squads exchanged warm handshakes after the last buzzer. The Toledo scoring wizard, Davage Minor, rushed across the court and bore down on Fuzzy Levane, the man who had guarded him.
PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- A Russian medical expert presented experimental evidence today in conflict with the growing American practice of encouraging early exercise among heart attack patients.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The president of Freeport Sulphur Company defended as fair and reasonable today the royalty that the company receives for supplying ore to the Government's $85,000,000 nickel plant at Nicaro, Cuba.

Consolidated net income of the Shell Oil Company in the first quarter this year declined 36 per cent to $26,469,532, or 87 cents a share, from the $41,449,505, or $1.37 a share cleared in the similar three months last year.
Former President Harry S. Truman told a Democratic fund-raising dinner here last night that the country was headed for another "bust" like the one in 1929 unless "somebody stops these fellows."

COCOA BEACH, Fla., April 24 -- An experimental nose cone, launched from Cape Canavarel last night in the hope that it would fly 6,000 miles or more, appears to have gone at least 1,500 miles before vanishing.
Almost all news, bad as well as good, seemed to be interpreted favorably in the market yesterday, and the aggregate value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange gained about $1,600,000,000.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 24 (AP) -- With Floyd Stahl out as Ohio State University's basketball coach, Paul Walker of Middletown High School applied for the job today.
On recommendation of its chairman, Robert Moses, the State Power Authority went on the warpath yesterday against the Niagara-Mohawk Power Corporation, the largest utility in upstate New York.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 24 -- Marilyn Monroe will be back at work in Hollywood in July.

At his press conference on Wednesday, President Eisenhower spoke of the "agonizing reappraisal" which he and his associates are engaged in constantly in trying to frame economic policy. We can believe that there is a deep personal problem for him, as there would be for any of us in his position, as he faces difficult issues.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- A baseball in spring takes some extraordinary bounces. Back in 1951 Leo Durocher and his Giants lost twelve of their first fourteen games, eleven of them in a row. Yet that year they won the pennant.
GREENWICH, Conn., April 24 -- The National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church today approved a venture into the magazine publishing field.
The ten-day pier blockade by truck owners' and teamsters was broken here in Federal court late yesterday.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 24 -- President Sukarno told a cheering throng of 4,000 today that socialism was on the march throughout the world and would sweep capitalism and imperialism into oblivion.
Under a good ride by Angel Valenzuela, Michael Soto's Lori-El made amends yesterday for two recent defeats by winning the $7,500 Greenwich at Jamaica by two and a half lengths.

First quarter ealmings of the American Bosch Arms Corporation were sharply below a year ago. They amounted to $886,708, or 46 cents a share, against $1,341,615, or 70 cents a share in the 1957 period.
Senator J. William Fulbright took a look at some of his pupils' homework yesterday and liked what he saw.

"MASTERS OF THE BACH FAMILY" was the title of a concert by the Cantata Singers under the direction of Alfred Mann last night in St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church at Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety - ninth Street.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., had record sales of $369,406,393 in the year ended Jan. 31. This was 5.3 per cent or $18,508,473 above the $350,897,920 volume of the preceding year, Bruce A. Gimbel, president, reported yesterday.

Lessening international tension appears to be the general aim of the Western powers as they vibrate toward another summit. Once there, they hope for a climate of cooperation to make possible some progress in solving the great problems of international life.
NEWARK, N. J., April 24 -- Plans were announced today to convert the 171-year-old cemetery of the old First Presbyterian Church here to "parking or appropriate mercantile use."
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Dr. Louis B. Wright, director of the Folger Shakespeare Library, said today that the present period was one of "social chaos -- national and international."
PARIS, April 24 -- Former Premier Rene Pleven reported encouraging results today from political consultations on a basis for a new government.
The first indictment growing out of a Brooklyn ambulance chasing inquiry was returned yesterday before Judge Hyman Barshay in Kings County Court.
A leader of the American Jewish Committee accused major industries and financial institutions yesterday of religious discrimination in selecting executives.

Loans to business by the seventeen larger New York City banks declined $178,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $128,000,000 in the like week a year ago.
BERLIN, April 24 -- Prof. Werner Heisenberg will outline tomorrow a suggested basic equation covering all matter.

Two American feature films have been accepted for the International Film Festival at the Brussels World's Fair and three have been named for the Cannes Film Festival, the respective committees have informed the Motion Picture Export Association of America.

ALBANY, April 24 -- Governor Harriman vetoed today a Republican bill aimed at curbing labor racketeering. He said it contained "serious dangers and flaws" and "could undermine responsible labor unions and harm their members."
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Veterans Administration reported today a big pick-up in early April in the once-moribund G. I. housing program, as measured by appraisal requests from builders.
DETROIT, April 24 -- The international executive board of the United Automobile Workers has approved a 10 per cent wage cut for its top officials.

The Chrysler Corporation yesterday reduced its quarterly dividend to 25 from 75 cents a common share. The action was taken because of the sharp loss incurred in the first quarter on a 53 per cent drop in sales. The dividend is payable June 13.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Following is the text of a statement presented to the Soviet Government today by the British, French and United States Ambassadors in Moscow:

PHILADELPHIA, April 241 (UP) -- Elroy Face put out a Philadelphia ninth-inning rally with one pitch tonight to save a 7-4 victory for the Pittsburgh Pirates and insure Bob Friend's second triumph of the year.
With June approaching, wedding invitations start pouring in, bringing with them the age-old problem of the appropriate gift.

BONN, Germany, April 24 -The Socialist Opposition introduced in Parliament today legislation for a national referendum on nuclear armament for the West German forces and the basing of rockets in West Germany.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), April 24 -- Tiny Israel nearly burst with pride today in a joyous celebration of her tenth anniversary. More than 250,000 Israelis jammed the flag-lined streets in the New City of Jerusalem to cheer picked units of the armed forces in a massive Independence Day parade.
A STEMLESS mushroom produced in manlmoth x-at rather than in sheds was introduced yesterday by tile Yorktown Products Corporation of New York.

Congress and the President are engaged at this moment in an effort to forestall greater unemployment and prevent another economic depression. One of the measures considered is that of stimulating more construction in the field of housing.

Three former Customs inspectors convicted as members of a $20,000,000-a-year international narcotics ring were sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman. Four other men in the ring were sentenced with them.

DETROIT, April 24 -- American Motors Corporation reported today a net profit of $7,329,631 for the six months ended March 31, compared with a net loss of $5,332,471 for the first half of the previous fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- A 24-year-old microphotographer at the Library of Congress said today he had taken 456 classified documents from the Armed Services Technical Information Agency without being detected.
NEWARK, April 25 -- The Newark Housing Authority announced today increases of $300 to $400 on income maximums for admission to Federally aided public housing projects.

A VERSATILE young Israeli artist, Zvi Gali, provides, in his exhibition opening tomorrow at the Jewish Museum, Fifth, Avenue and Ninety-second Street, an index to the extensive activities of younger generation artists in Israel.

The city's fourth "big sweep" clean-up campaign has begun -- a periodic intensification of a continuing effort to rid our streets and open places of the litter that disgraces them. It got off to a good start in October, 1955, with the cooperation of all the city departments concerned, through Mayor Wagner's Interdepartmental Committee for a Clean City, backed by a widely representative citizens' committee of which Keith S. McHugh has been chairman.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 (UP) -- Ramon Monzant pitched the San Francisco Giants into first place in the National League tonight by blanking the Chicago Cubs, 2 -- 0, with a four-hitter.
Battle lines were drawn yesterday between the Government and a potential "runaway" Federal grand jury investigating the tax returns of Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- The National Association of Manufacturers and the National Coal Association today opposed a bill to require companies to give advance notice of mergers and consolidations.
A Bronx jury awarded $100,000 yesterday to a 60-year-old man who seriously injured his back when he fell from a scaffold in 1953.
The Long Island Rail Road in the first quarter of this year operated at a net loss of $1,462,327, more than twice the $704,945 deficit in the first quarter of 1957.
ALBANY, April 25 -- Governor Harriman and the Republican legislative leaders named four former prosecuting attorneys today to $15,000 posts on the new state Crime Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Eisenhower sent congratulations and best wishes today to the National Symphony Orchestra and its conductor, Dr. Howard Mitchell, on the celebration of its 2,500th performance here this evening.
A COUPLE of New England trout seasons open next week and the men whose business it is to make this fact known are making a fine crop of hay, some of which may cure out pretty well.
The American Jewish Committee asserted in a report yesterday that bloc voting composed of "controled units of organized bodies" did not exist in American elections.
TORONTO, April 25 (Canadian Press) -- There is evidence that the recession is moderating and perhaps coming to an end, J. R. White, president of Imperial Oil, Ltd., said today at the annual meeting.
With the tightening of a bolt, work began yesterday on the steel skeleton of The New York Times' West Side plant.
MOSCOW, April 25 -- The Soviet people got their first hint today that nations of the Communist camp were boycotting Yugoslavia's Communist party congress.
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 25 -- Israel's surviving founding fathers held a reunion today in the Tel Aviv museum in which they proclaimed independence ten years ago.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Senate rejected tonight four efforts to broaden a one-point labor bill into general union-control legislation.

ONE of the most popular items in Italian restaurants here is a dish usually listed as "scampi." Requests for a recipe for it are received by this department from time to time, the most recent having come from Miss Betty Osler of Torento.

Cotton futures moved 4 points (20 cents a bale) up to 26 points ($1.30 a bale) off yesterday. The weakness was most pronounced in the far months. Volume of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderate.
CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- Grain futures, weakened by one fairly broad but moderate flurry of selling, closed generally down today on the Board of Trade.
ALBANY, April 25 -- Governor Harriman has vetoed a bill that would have ratified Clarkstown's controversial 1957 tax assessments.
LONDON, April 25--Prime Minister Harold Macmillan declared today that, barring a change in Government or an international treaty, Britain would continue to test her nuclear weapons.

LOS ANGELES, April 25 (UP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers, cashing in on Norm Larker's hitting and Fred Kipp's pitching, tonight scored a 5-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals before 60,635 fans, the largest night crowd in National League history.

Two items close to many women's hearts, jewels and hats, are the subjects of two books to be published next month. One is "Jewels and the Woman," oy Marianne Ostier which Horizon Press will issue May 19. It is a "practical" guide to the wearing of jewels on any occasion and the story of jewels through the ages.
Oils and steels led prices upward yesterday as the market boiled with the largest volume since last Jan. 16 and the greatest number of new highs since April 12, 1957. The eventual gain was moderate.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- After fourteen years of inspecting New York City's rotted window sashes and sills, Gustave J. Soderberg hit on a remedy. This week he received a patent for a combined wood filler and glazing putty that plugs the decayed wood and holds the panes in place.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 25 -- Mrs. Robert J. Phillips of St. Charles, Ill., a suburb of Chicago, assumed the presidency of the League of Women Voters today. She was elected yesterday without opposition by delegates to the league's national convention here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 25 -- There has been some passing conjecture as to the future story content of "Wagon Train," the mobile Western series on the National Broadcasting Company television network.
GANDER, Nfld., April 25 -- The luck of the Irish ran out over the Atlantic early today for a planeload of tourists bound for Dublin.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Administration's widely promised fight for President Eisenhower's Pentagon reorganization bill turned into a quiet, well-ordered retreat today at the Capitol.
The City Housing Authority obtained state approval yesterday for a low-income housing project to relocate tenants in the path of a new roadway to the George Washington Bridge.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 25 -- William Goetz has engaged writers to develop screenplays for two of the three pictures he will produce within the next eighteen months in partnership with Columbia Pictures.
GENEVA, April 25 (Reuters) -- After the voting on the three proposals, the conference approved, 60 to 0, the text of a United States proposal defining the "contiguous zone." It declared: "

An expense budget of $1,991,952,986 for the fiscal year starting July 1 was adopted by the Board of Estimate yesterday. It was $5,000,000 lower than the $1,996,952,986 executive budget submitted to the board by Mayor Wagner on April 1.
The right to represent the 161 operating employes of the Sixty-ninth Street Brooklyn Ferry Corporation has been won again by Local 333, United Marine Division of the National Maritime Union.

Hewitt-Robins, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Austin Goodyear as president. Mr. Goodyear, formerly executive vice president, succeeds Thomas Robins Jr., who had been president and chairman. Mr. Robins will continue as chairman and chief executive officer.

Members of Czarist Russia's nobility and their friends celebrated Russian Easter last night in the ballroom of the Sheraton-East. The fete, a benefit for the Association of Russian Imperial Naval Officers in America, commemorated the ninety-fifth anniversary of the Russian Ball held in the Academy of Music.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration moved today to make illegal the interstate shipment of fruits and vegetables that bear any residue of the pesticide aramite.
LONDON, April 25 (Reuters) -- Middle East oil output rose to some 51,000,000 metric tons in the first quarter, the Petroleum Information Bureau said here today. (One metric ton equals 2,205 pounds.)

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- A Norwegian motorship arrived at the port of Chicago today starting the 1958 overseas shipping season. Longshoremen refused to unload the cargo, however because of a pilots' strike.
GENEVA, April 25 -- The United Nations conference on the law of the sea failed today to agree on an internationally acceptable limit for territorial waters.

The District Attorney's office is considering possible criminal prosecution of a West Harlem automobile insurance broker found to have left thirty-four unsuspecting motorists with uninsured vehicles by pocketing $2,100 in premium payments.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Mexican Ambassador, Manuel Tello, today indicated his country's expected dissatisfaction with the Tariff Commission's recommendation of greater restrictions on United States imports of lead and zinc.

WHITE PLAINS, April 25 -- Federal aid to save the railroads was asked today by the Westchester County Association. As the dominant business and civic group in the county, the association has a membership of 535 that includes banks, manufacturers, builders, unions and merchants.
Capt. Harry F. Guggenheim's Red God, a race horse that has been around, staged a successful return to competition yesterday at Jamaica. He had been sidelined with minor ailments since last June.
Eight Edgars -- busts of Edgar Allan Poe -- and three scrolls were awarded last night by the Mystery Writers of America, Inc., for the mystery writing that its members had voted the best in 1957.
New York's largest labor union prepared yesterday to guard against fires with its own wardens.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.1 per cent to 119.4 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The establishment of a new General Electric Company apparatus and industrial group to be headed by Arthur F. Vinson, vice president, was announced yesterday. Robert Paxton, president, said the new entity would combine the duties and responsibilities of two former components--the apparatus group and the industrial components and materials group.
MOSCOW, April 25 -- The United States gave the Russians another lesson in basketball tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The number of jobless workers among those covered by the unemployment compensation system rose to another record in the week ended April 12, the Labor Department reported today.
BERLIN, April 25 -- To his fellow scientists, the name of Werner Heisenberg conjures up many notable advances in atomic physics. Today, for example, he suggested a basic equation to explain matter.

Vice President Nixon, in his remarks before the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, made at least one much needed contribution to the present controversy over the Government's anti-recession program. He helped to clear up any misunderstanding of the Administration's views that may have arisen as a result of the unfortunate phrasing of the President in his reply to a question on this subject at his Wednesday news conference.
PARIS, April 25 -- A short but precise declaration of French intentions for Algeria would be the cornerstone of the Cabinet that former Premier Rene Pleven seeks to form.
AIR CONDITIONING may cool the air, but its appearance stirs up some heated decorating queries.
THE fall collection of Christian Dior shoes designed by Roger Vivier was previewed yesterday in Bonwit Teller's Shoe Salon.
Two ideas that might give man a firmer understanding of the nature of the physical world about him were reported by scientists yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Long-standing worry and stress can produce effects comparable to physical loss of part of the brain, Dr. Loring F. Chapman, experimental neurologist of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, said here today.

ROME, April 25 -- Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, arrived tonight to assume his new duties as Pro-Prefect of the Vatican's Sacred Congregation for the Propagation of the Faith.
Amid trucks and packing cases, rumbling machinery and the general din of commerce and traffic on a busy midtown street, twenty-four sisters in white pursue their work with tranquillity.

PARIS, April 25 -- Christian A. Herter urged Europeans today to resolve their differences over the future economic organization of the Continent in ways that would encourage trade with the rest of the world.

For some people the advent of a new season is marked by the calendar, the first crocus, robin or balmy day. But such harbingers can be deceptive, as we all know. The steadfast calendar on a pleasant day may say, that spring is here, only on the next day to see a robin shivering in the snow that conceals the crocus from view.

A NATION'S novelists are usually more effective than its statesmen in telling us about that country's people and their ways of living. The reason is plain. The novelist has every advantage. A statesman must deal in policy-riddled national generalities; a novelist can concentrate on individuals, their loves, hates and hazardous fortunes.
LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, April 25 -- High-level efforts to put a limit on public squabbling with the Soviet Union became apparent today at the seventh congress of the Yugoslav League of Communists.

Your opportunity to give to the Fund comes only where you work -- at your place of business. There is no such opportunity at your home, in your neighborhood nor on the street corner.

CLARKSBURG, W. Va., April 25 (AP) -- Meade Alcorn, chairman of the Republican National Committee, accused Democrats in Congress tonight of dragging their feet on Administration labor legislation. Mr. Alcorn also said that the Democrats were practicing "shabby politics at its worst" in pushing unemployment relief legislation going far beyond the President's recommendations.
BALTIMORE, April 25 -- Gene Woodling, a 35-year-old outfielder the Yankees traded away in 1954, has been painfully reminding them of it ever since. He did it again tonight.

BRUSSELS, April 25 -- Comment heard at the Brussels World's Fair has it that the Americans are showing themselves to be not just happy but perhaps slap-happy and that the United States Pavilion is too carefree and lighthearted.
Aircraft generally will not be used for the mass spraying of gypsy moths with DDT in New York State this year.
Commodity future prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was dull in most markets. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.

All the alert capital that is estranged for the moment from the stock market is not being switched into United States Government securities. A sizable amount is flowing overseas for investment in British Government securities.

Investment banking houses made preparations yesterday for another active week in the new capital market. Major bond issues totaling more than $350,000,000 will come up for distribution. There will also be a scattering of transactions involving the issuance of common stock.

Defective brake parts sold to the Army by a Queens company may have been responsible for many deaths and injuries, Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld asserted yesterday in sentencing three officers of the company.
LONDON, April 25 (UP) -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union lashed Out again today at the Malenkov "anti-party" group ousted from the Soviet leadership last June.
