DETROIT, April 25 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that new car sales averaged 14,250 units a day during the April 11 to 20 period, compared with 13,330 a day in the first ten-day period.
CHICAGO, April 25 -- John A. Barr, president and chairman of Montgomery Ward Co., said that first-quarter sales were "perhaps" slightly above sales in the first quarter of 1957.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Foreign scientists will be given access to data on the fission and fusion power of a hydrogen bomb to be tested by the United States this summer, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 25 -- Judging by developments tonight, Alden Gray, the director of racing at Roosevelt Raceway, qualifies as a member of the All-Infallible Weather Prognosticators Association of America.
Having lived for about forty years in the Washington Square neighborhood, I am thankful for the letters printed in The Times. Two observations may be of interest to your readers:

MILWAUKEE, April 25 (AP) -- Bob Rush, a pitching plum plucked by the Braves in a deal with the Chicago Cubs last winter, made his first start for Milwaukee tonight. The big right-hander threw a sparkling three-hitter, good for a 4-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
LONDON, April 25 (AP) -- West Germany, Czechoslovakia and Spain moved into 2-0 leads as European zone first-round Davis Cup tennis matches started today in Munich, Zagreb, Cairo and Budapest.

MOEN, Truk Atoll, Caroline Islands, April 16 -- The man in the white cassock is a familiar and beloved figure in the palm-shaded villages of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands. Because of his influence and wide contacts, thousands of Micronesians are learning English as it is heard in Times Square.
PERENNIAL pearls are giving way to crystals in spring and summer necklaces. The prismied surfaces of these beads pick up the color of any costume and provide an airy, cool look.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 25 -- The "strong transition" affecting advertising and marketing means that agencies will have to operate more scientifically, G. Maxwell Ule, senior vice-president at Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., warned today.
The New York Philharmonic gave a farewell party yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- President Eisenhower today formally designated a seven-man delegation to represent him at the inauguration of Dr. Arturo Frondizi as President of Argentina Thursday.
CARSON CITY, Nev., April 25 (UP) -- Eight Nevada gamblers who hold interests in new Havana casinos were ordered today to pull out of either Cuba or Nevada.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- The American Philosophical Society laid the cornerstone today for a $2,000,000 library building opposite its headquarters on the northeast corner of Independence Square.

With commendable restraint, President Bourguiba of Tunisia announces that he has dropped his plan to demand immediate action by the United Nations Security Council on his charges of "aggression" against France. He has there-by avoided a step which would only have complicated solutions of the French Cabinet crisis, of the French Tunisian dispute and of the whole North African problem, to the detriment of the whole West, to which he has pledged his allegiance.
ALBANY, April 25 -- Two former Presidents of the United States received honorary doctor's degrees from the University of the State of New York tonight.

Two youths -- one 13 years old, the other 14 -- were arrested yesterday and accused of telephoning a bomb threat to their school, P. S. 73. The school is at Fifty-fourth Avenue and Seventy-first Street, Maspeth, Queens.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 25--Hundreds of thousands of Colombians demonstrated here and in other cities last night and today in support of the acceptance by Alberto Lleras Camargo of the joint Liberal-Conservative presidential nomination.
First-quarter net earnings of Eastern Air Lines, Inc. fell 33 per cent to $2,166,741 or 74 cents a share from $3,238,428 or $1.14 a share for the first three months of last year.
A fourth witness testified yesterday in defense of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation against charges that it imposed tie-in sales on customers.
Clergymen of three faiths will participate in a celebration of Israel's tenth anniversary tomorrow at the Polo Grounds.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 25 (UP) -- Billy Knight of England and Giuseppe Merlo of Italy gained the men's singles final today in the British hard court tennis championships by winning hard-fought matches.

WESTPORT, Conn., April 25 -- The Westport police are ready to give up in the case of the mysterious headstones.

The Wabush Iron Company announced yesterday that it had acquired control of the Newfoundland and Labrador Corporation (Nalco). Nalco has mineral and timber concessions from the Newfoundland Government of more than 24,000 square miles in Labrador and on the island of Newfoundland.

Showroom space in the office building nearing completion at 111 West Fortieth Street has been leased by the General Realty Utilities Corporation to the William Lind Company, converter of cotton fabrics. The Lind Company will retain its main office at 83 Worth Street.
EAST WILLISTON, L. I., April 25 -- The Women's Cross County Golf Association opened its season today at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club course.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 25 -- The Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern) is taking up anew here the issue of racial segregation.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 -- Ducks Unlimited plans to spend $525,000 during 1958, the same record appropriation as for 1957, for maintaining and extending waterfowl - breeding grounds in three prairie provinces of Canada.

With its collective face red, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday confessed to a considerable error in the short interest figures reported a week ago. The aggregate short position, instead of falling 1.3 per cent in a month, had risen 6.8 per cent to the largest total since June 4, 1931.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -- Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida, predicted today that a Senate Commerce Subcommittee would come up next week with a "constructive and broad-range" program for easing the railroads' financial troubles.

A Southern publisher and editor said yesterday that pressure groups in small communities were threatening the independence and survival of small weekly newspapers.

Max Planck, who was born 100 years ago and whose memory was honored at a scientific meeting in Berlin yesterday, was one of the world's intellectual giants.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The United States and three of its allies are planning to ask for an early meeting of the United Nations Security Council to consider measures for aerial inspection of an arctic zone.

NAN MATAL, Ponape, Caroline Islands, April 10 -- About thirty miles over a sun-warmed lagoon from the iron-roofed building where a retired contractor from Chicago administers these tropical islands, the great stone capital city of a lost Pacific kingdom is an unsolved archaeological riddle.
The Port of New York began digging out from under mountains of cargo yesterday in the wake of a Federal Court order that broke a ten-day blockade of piers by truck owners and teamsters.
It's never too late for a company to diversify.

WARSAW, April 25 (UP) -- Nikolai S. Patolichev, a Soviet First Deputy Foreign Minister, denied today reports that the Soviet Union had set up rocket-launching bases in Poland, Czechoslovakia and East Germany.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 25 (AP) -- A swift-striding Australian who wasn't supposed to run, Alex Henderson of Arizona State at Tempe, shattered the American collegiate two-mile record at the forty-ninth Drake Relays today.
A scheduled tour of the St Lawrence Seaway and Power PrOject by former President Harry S. Trmnan touched off a tug-of-war yesterday over political credit for the program.
ALBANY, April 25--Nelson A. Rockefeller was elected today as chairman of the new legislative committee that will work to modernize and simplify the state's Constitution.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (UP) -- A Chicago teamster official who had vowed to stand guard over union records subpoenaed by the Senate rackets committee changed his mind today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- Villanova's Ron Delany added an eighth link to an unbroken chain of successes at Franklin Field today as the sixty-fourth annual Penn Relays opened in unwontedly fine weather.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 25 -- After an unusually heavy morning schedule at the White House, President Eisenhower flew here early this afternoon. Half an hour after his arrival he heeded the call of the fairways at Augusta National Golf Club.

New York Telephone Company reported yesterday "some improvement" in first quarter revenues and net income over those for the like 1957 period. Keith S. McHugh, president, traced these improvements "in part" to rate increases last October and to the addition of 287,000 telephones since the year-ago period, service improvements and "an increased number of calls due to adverse weather."
Manhattan College yesterday announced a new admissions policy that would make it possible for students in the junior year of high school to obtain "tentative admission" to the college.

ST. LOUIS, April 25 -- The Supreme Court is being asked to reconsider its order denying a review of the conspiracy conviction of T. Lamar Caudle and Matthew J. Connelly, officials in the Truman Administration. Petitions were forwarded to Washington today.

"DIAL M FOR MURDER" was done on television last night as the season's closing production of the "Hallmark Hall of Fame" over Channel 4. On the home screen it was a swell suspense drama and received a topnotch production.
The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company has made a first-mortgage loan of $2,500,000 at 4 3/4 per cent interest on a new twenty-story apartment building at 110 East Fifty-seventh Street.
Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, defended the Administration's farm program yesterday, attacking its critics in and out of Congress as "propagandists" and "demagogues."

COCOA BEACH, Fla., April 25 -- Electrical and plumbing difficulties were blamed today for repeated delays that finally led to the postponement of the planned launching of a Vanguard earth satellite last night.
NEW HAVEN, April 25 -- Attorney General William P. Rogers urged the legal profession tonight to support action in Congress this year on the question of Presidential disability.

The thirteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 1049 Park Avenue, at Eighty-sixth Street, has been sold by the 1049 Park Avenue Associates to investing clients of Nassoit-Sulzberger Co., broker in the transaction.

LONDON, April 25 -- Wall Street's improvement helped the stock market here to end the week on a relatively firm note.

BERLIN, April 25 -- Prof. Werner Heisenberg proposed today a basic equation for all matter. The equation was formulated from three measurement units used in modern physics and some assumptions based on Plato's philosophy.

HELSINKI, Finland, April 25 -- A new Finnish caretaker Government was formed tonight on what was said to be a nonpartisan basis. It contains members of political parties, trade union leaders and industrialists.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (AP) -- In another report, made to a meeting of the American Academy of Neurology, Dr. Chapman said that the pain chemical that apparently causes migraine headaches had been isolated.

HAVANA, April 25 -- Seven rebels were killed in an encounter with army troops on the Corral Nuevo Plantation near Holguin, Oriente Province, according to a communique issued today by Camp Columbia army headquarters. Seven shotguns, five rifles and nine vehicles were captured, it said.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 25 -- Had there been a world fair similar to the current Brussels international exposition during the fifth century, the Roman pavilion and that of the Ostrogoths would have attracted much attention. New York City's next public sale of bonds will include $36,550,000 of school construction and renovation obligations, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday.

Net income of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation in the first quarter this year dropped to $725,900 from $4,790,665 in the similar three months of 1957. Net sales were $50,454,925 against $81,294,626.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 -- William Heikkila, a former Communist, completed today his round trip by air to his native Finland as a guest of the United States Government.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 25 -- The Swedish Government was defeated in the lower chamber of the Riksdag today, 117 votes to 111, on the question of pension reforms.
TOKYO, April 25 -- Premier Nobusuke Kishi tonight dissolved the Japanese House of Representatives. A national election will be held May 22. It will be the first general election since February, 1955.

They had only to look at first-quarter earnings reports, many of them down sharply, and the level of industrial production, also off. Meanwhile, prices continued to soar to record highs.

MILWAUKEE, April 26 (UP) -- Bob Buhl of the Milwaukee Braves notched his ninth straight victory over the Philadelphia Phillies since 1956 today with a five-hit, 4-2 victory.

A study team from the University of Pennsylvania School of Law has concluded that New York City's bail system often causes unnecessary detention of accused persons and deprives almost 50 per cent of them of the right to freedom on bail.

TO the free world Milovan Djilas is a lonely and heroic figure, a living symbol of disenchantment with communism. Today, at the age of forty-seven, he is in a prison fifty miles from Belgrade, in the same cell he occupied a quarter-century ago when arrested for engaging in a revolutionary movement -- a movement that in time carried him to the vice presidency of Yugoslavia and the Presidency of its Parliament.

MOSCOW, April 26 -- The Soviet Union rejected today a proposal by the United States, Britain and France that their Ambassadors here should meet jointly with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to begin working out plans for a summit meeting.
Kingmaker, holder of the Jamaica track record for a mile and an eighth, yesterday won the mile-and-a-sixteenth Excelsior Handicap by a length and a quarter.

WHITE PLAINS, April 26 -Removal of the yoke from Westchester's spending powers is under consideration by county officials. It would mean that long-term bonds could again be easily issued for capital improvements.

Shouting inmates of the Women's House of Detention threw burning sheets and crockery from the barred windows of their cells last night. The disturbance attracted about 1,000 persons in Greenwich Village.

IF the opening of the major league baseball season is not a strong indication that summer is on its way, then it must be pointed out that the annual big and little league film festival competitions, which are almost as regular as the seasons, start this Friday in Cannes.

THE 116th season of the New York Philharmonic, which ends this afternoon, will be remembered more for its decisions than for its accomplishments. It was the season in which the board of directors took its courage in its hands and voted to entrust the institution's destinies to a young American conductor.
Woodrow Wilson, in the opinion of Herbert Hoover, was the greatest of modern American presidents and the noblest statesman of his era.
The intricacies of map designing will be detailed by Gerard L. Alexander at a free art lecture at 6:15 P. M. Tuesday in the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
A system of campus recruitment and appointment to Civil Service positions, similar to the practices of private industry, may be started by this city.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 26 (AP) -- The nation's independent oil operators in the next three days are to review their campaign strategy seeking stricter controls over oil imports.

BEFORE the development of the rigorous approach to musical history that is known as "musicology," the memoir was a major source of information about musicians and musical life. Disciplined treatment of facts is obviously progress, since memory easily deceives.
Thursday's report by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation underlined sharply the change that has come over the stock market in the first four months of 1958.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- There may be a Government job open for you if you can speak Urdu, and a higher paying job if you also can speak Malay.

HOME garden tomatoes in southeastern New York State, and especially in the Long Island area, have suffered severely from Fusarium wilt in recent seasons. During dry summers the wilt is particularly noticeable.

A FEW months ago Beethoven moved over and made way for bop at the midnight spot on Radio Station WEVD. The Modern Jazz Quartet replaced the one from "Rigoletto" and the only symphony heard now is Symphony Sid, the man who presides over the cool sounds heard from midnight to 3 A. M., Tuesday through Friday.
NEW HAVEN, April 26 -- A warning was voiced here today against the court decision that is a "sudden about-face that reverses judicial and legislative doctrine."
LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, April 26 -- President Tito told Soviet leaders today that they would hurt themselves and the international Communist movement if they took Stalin's road against Yugoslavia.

PROVIDENCE, R. I. -- This state's Heritage Week commences next Saturday and continues through Sunday, May 11. The emphasis will be on Rhode Island's religious history. It was here during the early settlement of the New World that Roger Williams, founder of the Rhode Island colony, established the tradition of religious liberty.
PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -Early surgery for blockage in arteries of the chest or neck might often prevent strokes, a neurologist reported here today.
AS spontaneously as night-blooming cereus bursts into blossom around the Punahou School campus, modern music is flourishing seasonally in this unexpected academic quarter.

WESTBURY, L. I., April 26 -- Recent cases of horses at Roosevelt Raceway drifting out in the stretch and permitting others to slip through to victory along the rail have been called to the attention of the judges.

The present ideological dispute between Yugoslav and Soviet Communists began when the former earlier this year issued a draft program in preparation for the Yugoslav Communist Congress. Last weekend the magazine Kommunist, theoretical organ of the Soviet Communist party, issued a lengthy denunciation of the program.
IF Karl Marx could come alive again and visit Moscow, what would he think of the Soviet Union?
LAUREL, Md., April 26 (UP) -- Brookmeade Stable's Oligarchy, the Widener Handicap winner, held on gamely in the stretch today to score a nose decision over Paper Tiger in the $28,725 Laurel Handicap.

ROME, April 26 -- Samuel Alphonsus Cardinal Stritch, new Pro-Prefect of the Vatican's Sacred Congregation for the Propagation of the Faith, was taken to a clinic today for what was diagnosed as a blood clot in the right arm.

NOT many Presidents of the United States live long enough or have sufficient strength left after vacating the White House to write their memoirs. None, apparently, has ever before undertaken to write a book about a former occupant of the Executive Mansion.

UNLIKE its American counterpart, the British "Who's Who" does not discourage biographers from expressing themselves on the off-beat. Under FRY, Christopher, there are a pair of examples of this. "Life too complicated for tabulation, 1935'39," Mr. Fry says of himself, up near the top. And at the bottom, where under "Recreations," Englishmen of worth customarily go to town, he adds, "Planning holidays which he does not take."

ALTHOUGH no one has yet shouted "millenium," something akin to millenium appears to have come to pass for late season theatre ticket shoppers. Scanning the ads these days they have suddenly discovered that at four current productions it is possible, Mondays through Fridays, to telephone the box offices and make ticket reservations that can be picked up even the same day as late as 7:30 or 8 P. M.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -The National Council of Negro Women will begin a "national mobilization" campaign tomorrow to continue, til June 16.

The night chef at Lindy's Restaurant, 1655 Broadway, was killed early yesterday in a hitand-run accident in front of 250 West Fifty-first Street, between Eighth Avenue and Broadway. The alleged driver was arrested several hours later.

THERE is a saying in musical circles that every city in America has two things -- a five-and-dime and a Boulanger pupil. The Boulanger reference concerns a tiny, gray-haired music teacher in and about Paris, to whom, since the early Nineteen Twenties, American students, starting with Aaron Copland, have flocked with the insistence of crusaders on the way to the Holy Land.

A pseudonym is a writer's privilege and it has been used by all-ranks in the literary order for all kinds of reasons. Some have used it to escape political retribution -- a common reason before the press had any real measure of freedom and when it was risky to write critically of governments and institutions.

WHEN Bobby Bragan became the manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, he entered the National League with only the noblest of motives. He would live down his reputation as a cut-up and umpire baiter. No longer would he ridicule the Men in Blue as he had in the Coast League and the Texas League. Brash Bobby would be a model of decorum.

ONE of those writers -- like Cornell Woolrich or Charlotte Armstrong or M. P. Shiel -- whose novels cannot be justly described is Joel Townsley Rogers. A Rogers story in synopsis might seem unlikely or even absurd.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 -The erstwhile Brooklyn Dodgers are setting attendance records in their Memorial Coliseum home -- along with records for "Chinese," or short-weight, home runs into the stadium's abbreviated left field.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 26 -President Eisenhower served notice on opponents of his defense modernization plan today that "there can be no compromise on -- or retreat from -- the essentials of this legislation."

THE Free Library of Philadelphia announces an important acquisition, the Drinker Library of Choral Music containing more than 20,000 copies of choral works by composers from the seventeenth century to the present.

THE classical music of India, one of the world's great cultural treasures, has so far been little known outside the frontiers of that country. The reasons are mainly three: Indian music, normally not written, is hence not available for study and performance by artists abroad; too few Indian artists tour foreign countries; strangest of all, until recently most of them disliked the very idea of recording.

BONN, Germany, April 26 -Anastas I. Mikoyan, First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union, concluded the official part of his four-day visit to West Germany tonight. He left no doubt in the minds of the West German Government and press of his own Government's firm intention to make its policy on Germany prevail.

A grant of $110,000 has been made by the Rockefeller Foundation to Stanford University, California, for continuation of the university's Japanese studies program which started two years ago. The studies cover the arts, ethical and religious philosophy, political and social ideas.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 -The St. Louis Cardinals, sparked by the first major league homer of Gene Green, a rookie outfielder, punched over six runs in the seventh and eighth innings today to defeat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6 -- 4, before 30,795 fans in Memorial Coliseum.

VINCENT SHEEAN has made no secret of his dalliance with music. In "First and Love" he wrote a full and detailed confession of his life-long infatuation, but this was by no means an effort to win release from the gentle chains that held him fast.
CHICAGO, April 27 -- Federal mediators began today an investigation of the strike that prevented the unloading of the first foreign vessels to arrive here this season.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -The Senate today blocked, for the fifth time, a Republican drive to write general labor legislation.

THE American people have always had a consuming and not very sympathetic curiosity about confidential advisers to their high officers of government. The real or supposed influence of such advisers -- from Amos Kendall and the other members of President Jackson's "kitchen cabinet," to Wilson's Colonel House and to Harry Hopkins and Harry Vaughan and Sherman Adams -- has been an indestructible political issue.

The Senate has shown admirable restraint and wisdom in voting down unwise attempts to load the welfare fund regulation bill with amendments designed to set up controls over unions themselves -- and to further the political fortunes of Senator Knowland, who started the maneuvering.

Influenced by the fact that Easter came two weeks earlier this year than last, retail volume this month will be below the 1957 level. Warm weather and a willingness to promote, however, have been strong factors in minimizing the losses for department and specialty stores. Taken together, March and April sales this year will come close to those for the similar period a year earlier.

ALREADY well known as a cartoonist and an illustrator of children's books, Mr. Saxon launches into the field of story-telling, too, with this tale of Poopsie the pointer and Lucy, his little-girl owner. Poopsie was descended from generations of illustrious hunting-dog ancestors, and it began to look, as he grew bigger and bigger and "clumsy as a baby elephant," that he wasn't a very good pet for a little girl's ruffled bedroom.
PROVIDENCE, April 26 -Dartmouth's varsity crew overpowered Brown by six lengths on the Seekonk River today in the feature of a four-race regatta.

THE heat was on in this general area last week -ar not alone on the movie industry. It was worse on the erstwhile Brooklyn Dodgers, whom Walter O'Malley transplanted to Los Angeles. In their first appearances before their new hometowners, they were definitely on the pan, and the people of the near-by movie colony were bursting with sympathy.

WITHIN the past two years, Italy has become the largest supplier of wines to the United States. Last year, America consumed 1,700,000 gallons of vermouth from Italy, 1,500,000 gallons of Italian table wines, and 66,000 gallons of fortified wines such as Marsala.
LONDON, April 26 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia, West Germany and Spain qualified for the second round of the European Zone Davis Cup competition today.
PARIS, April 26 -- For the nineteenth time since the Fourth Republic began its checkered career in January, 1947, France's Government is reduced to caretaker status.
ALBANY, April 26 (AP) -- Psychology comes of legal age in New York State this year.

A new volatile industry has sprung up to fill the enormous demand for television films. Using Hollywood as a springboard, leaders in the television film business range all over the world to create the entertainment product needed for new programing by hundreds of television stations.

Nobody wants an atomic war. We don't believe Mr. Khrushchev or any of his colleagues or any probable successor wants such a war. We are sure the Russian people, who haven't been asked, don't want it. If it comes it will be due to the most massive blunder in all human history.

THREE phases of the modern movement in sculpture are indicated in newly opened one-man shows. The veteran Sir Jacob Epstein, whose work was once regarded as highly revolutionary, is represented locally for the first time in many years in a retrospective exhibition of portraits at the galleries of James Graham and Sons.

As yet little known publicly, a number of younger American private collectors are amassing treasures on a formidable scale. On one of these collections, remarkable by any standards, that made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter Bareiss, the curtain is raised in an exhibition held at the Museum of Modern Art Guest House, 242 East Fifty-second Street, for the benefit of the museum's Junior Council.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 26 -With the convention of the Democratic-Farmer-Labor party a month away, the contest for the party's endorsement for United States Senator has been narrowed to two participants.

SAN JUAN, P. R., April 26 -- Pablo Casals last night played for the second time at the festival here that bears his name. And now everyone is much happier. Don Pablo, as he is affectionately known, was his old self again.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- For the eighth time in eleven years Congress has been asked to ban interstate advertising of alcoholic beverages. This would involve distillers, brewers, vintners and their agents, and newspapers, periodicals, newsreels, recordings, radio, television and even private mail.

GREAT RIVER, L. I. -- Thirteen Long Island State Park Commission facilities are being groomed for another vigorous season of picknicking, sports and beachfront recreation. Among them, the Bayard Cutting Arboretum is opening very sedately this week-end for its fifth season as a state park.

WARSAW, April 26 -- A serious split has developed in the ranks of Poland's leading Roman Catholics over the amount of tolerance the Church should show to nonbelievers.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., April 26 -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Paxson of Holicong, Pa., joined hundreds of other exhibitors and riders at the annual spring Boulder Brook horse show today and soon became the owners of blue and red ribbons through the efforts of their three hunters.
Cato Danielsen and his lady love celebrated their fortieth anniversary last Friday.

The men's apparel industry feels it is an authority on the recession. Long before other industries began to feel the pinch, the men's wear field was in the doldrums. Production and sales began to fall before last summer.

MOSCOW, April 26 -- Last night's basketball games here, in which American teams opened a series against Russian teams, were handled in the press in varying ways. Izvestia did not report the games. Pravda had one picture and a third-of-acolumn story.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 26 -- The prospect of a work stoppage by movie directors threatened today to cripple motion picture and television film production at major studios.
NEW DELHI, India, April 26 -- The Indian Government will start a new campaign next week to crack down on prostitution, a vice now practiced openly in almost every part of the country.

THE publication of "Great French Painting in the Hermitage," raises an interesting fact about intercultural influences. Throughout the eighteenth century and up to the fall of Napoleon, French culture, art and language dominated all European courts and led, among other things, to the collection of French paintings by the Germanborn Catherine II.

BOSTON, April 26 -- Life on the Charles River today, at least in one respect, resembled life on the Mississippi as once depicted by the marine - minded Mark Twain. The Beantown waterway was a busy river.

SIXTEEN YEAR-OLD Rory Andrews was strong and determined -- the kind of boy you could send to do a man's job. In 1898, he journeyed into the northern wilds looking for his father, a wandering railroad man -- and was swept into the roaring stream of the Alaska-Yukon gold rush.

THERE is hidden significance in Arthur Mizener's discussion of the limitations of recent novels about business in his review of John Brooks' "The Man Who Broke Things." Mr. Mizener complains that everyone from Archibald MacLeish to Sloan Wilson has failed when it comes to creating drama and heroism out of the now-familiar suburbia and executive-suite material.

IT will be recalled that the K-9 (that is, canine) Corps during World War II had police dogs specially trained to be friendly to the American masters and vicious toward strangers. Having been so trained, these dogs had to be retrained to be gentle animals before returning to "civilian" life.

Committee members have been announced for the fifth annual home and garden tour to benefit the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center's Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation. The tour of homes and gardens in Greenwich, Conn., and Purchase, N. Y., will be held May 22.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26 -With Villanova again grabbing the spotlight, the largest crowd ever to see a track meet in the East -- 43,618 spectators -thrilled to a spectacular series of record-breaking performances at the sixty-fourth annual Penn Relays today.

Congratulations to Harry Schwartz for his realistic article. It is time we as Americans looked facts in the face as a means of eliminating fears of Russia. Only if we provide our people with enough knowledge about ideologies and practices of other countries will we be able effectively to combat these fears which hem us in.

WHEN we think of the American of today, our line of stretches from President Eisenhower painting in the White House to a young idealist struggling with his dreams in a Greenwich Village studio. Somewhere between these two poles we fondly imagine that the "typical" American artist may be discovered.

A warning of a "march on, Albany" by the Board of Higher Education to get state financial aid for the four municipally owned colleges was sounded yesterday by Gustave G. Rosenberg, the board's chairman.

THE controversy over whether the shores of Walden Pond should remain immune from bulldozer attacks by the Middlesex County Commissioners in an effort to enlarge beach facilities there -- the case recently came up for hearings in a Cambridge court -- would have grieved Ralph Waldo Emerson of Concord.

POUND RIDGE, N. Y., April 26 -- A New York lawyer was killed and his wife seriously hurt at 1 A. M. today when automobiles they were driving collided head-on. The accident occurred on a straight stretch of highway between here and their home in Stamford, Conn.
ALBANY, April 26 -- Governor Harriman today summoned leaders of business and industry to the Capitol on Thursday to discuss a state-wide program to fight unemployment.
RABAT, Morocco, April 26 -- The Algerian question will dominate discussion at the pan-North African political conference that will begin tomorrow in Tangier.

LONDON, April 26 -- Britain is doing quite well economically. She experienced one of her periodic crises last September, when failing world confidence in the pound sterling led to a run on the currency and a heavy depletion of the gold and dollar reserves of the sterling area.

MONTOUR FALLS, N. Y. -- A forgotten glen, beloved of Seneca Indians and turn-of-the-century picnickers, is being brought back from limbo as a tourist attraction. The new picnic ground is at the base of the 200-foot cliffs at Havana Glen at the outskirts of this village, three miles south of the lower tip of Seneca Lake.
PARIS, April 26 -- France's economy, thus far nervously ignoring the United States recession, was on the upgrade in all domains except the essential one -- exports.
PANAMA, April 26 -- Domestic political rivalries have revived old Panamanian differences with the United States and given rise to new ones.

The city's eleventh annual Loyalty Day parade swung into midtown Fifth Avenue for the first time yesterday. Many store owners in the area said their business was cut heavily as a result. The Fifth Avenue Association had estimated that the parade would cost midtown stores on the avenue $500,000 in business and more than $25,000 in wages and commissions for sales personnel.

Dr. Edward Hodgson, Columbia University zoologist, has reported pioneer studies on the mechanism of taste and smell. The studies, Columbia Research News states, represent "the first successful investigation" of the vital processes of the chemoreceptors, the minute cells of the nervous system that telegraph sensations of taste and smell to the brain of all living creatures having these senses.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. April 26 -- Following is the text of the draft resolution to be submitted by the United States to the Security Council:

THOSE who remember Ken Heyman's first show at Limelight Photo Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South, are in for a pleasant surprise in his second, which will be on view until May 10. Between the two shows, the photographer has made remarkable progress both in perfecting his ability to organize material significantly and in his more purposeful use of technique. The gallery is open from 6 P. M. to 1 A. M. daily.

The problems of city government will be considered at a two-week seminar beginning tomorrow at the American Press Institute, Columbia University. Twenty reporters, five editorial writers and two news executives who specialize in municipal problems will attend the meeting.

IT was reported recently in The New York Times that the Columbia Broadcasting System has arranged to broadcast the Saturday evening concerts of the New York Philharmonic next year, instead of those given at the traditional Sunday afternoon time.

I'm happy that "End As a Man" showed such a neat profit in 1953, even as "The Threepenny Opera" is prospering today. These shows are needles in haystacks. [Jack Garfein in a letter in this section last week said "End As a Man" made a substantial profit during its offBroadway run.]

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 26 -- Plans to double the enrollment of Rutgers University by 1965 will fall short of New Jersey's immediate needs, according to Dr. Louis Webster Jones, president of the state university.

THE Intercollegian, published by the National Student YMCA-YWCA, announces a contest for college student photographers. The theme of the contest is student life and education in America. Prizes are in cash and equipment, with a first award of $150 cash and a choice of equipment.

ALL those little motor scooters zipping around New York these days are not just a way of getting from one place to another: they're a way of life. Look at the scooters going by and you may see a man with a Tyrolean brush in his hat, or a young lady balancing her Trapeze Line over the rear seat while pedestrians whistle and cheer.

ANY small boy who carries a snake in his pocket will understand immediately why Mme. Bodot's son sent that elderly French lady a boa constrictor for her birthday. And Mme. Bodot, remarkably adaptable, appreciated his thoughtfulness -- after her initial shock.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -Throughout the opening stages of the House Armed Services Commitee hearings on defense reorganization this week, the Secretary of Defense testified he was willing to conciliate and compromise.

Charles Munch will open the 1958 Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood, Lenox, Mass., on Friday evening, July 4. He will conduct a chamber orchestra composed of members of the Boston Symphony in the four Orchestral Suites of Bach.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, April 26 -- As a result of the split in the United Federal party this week, former Prime Minister Garfield Todd and six members of Parliament have quit the party. UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 26 -- The United States called on the United Nations Security Council today to consider international control of bomber flights over the Arctic.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UP) -- Department of Labor experts predicted today that because of the recession the average June high-school and college graduate will have fewer job opportunities.

Thus ended sixty-eight years of continuous through service, operated in a gentlemanly fashion, between those points.

THE Alexander Hamilton Bicentennial of last year has produced the usual flood of printed matter about this great American: biographies, special studies, tracts for our own times and short collections of his writings.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -Democratic policy makers in the House of Representatives are about ready to rule out a general tax cut this session.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The East-West wrangle on the holding of a summit meeting has now reached a point of complexity, obscurity and futility that can be compared only with medieval debates on how many angels could stand on the head of a pin.

THE French people are divided, confused, frustrated and worried about the future because they are not sure where they are going. They are at once apathetic and intense, active and passive about their political destinies. They are coldly reasoning out their economic future while sentiment and emotion often do service for political logic.
Governor Harriman said last night that he was accepting a Republican challenge to make his veto of a bill aimed at labor racketeering a "king-sized issue" in this election year.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 26 -The "African personality" asserted itself this week at the first conference of independent African states as a voice rather than a tangible being. But it promises in the months and years immediately ahead to put on the flesh and blood of a political bloc of great potential strength.

ISRAEL is 10 years old -- a 10-year-old among the nations, the likes of which the world has rarely seen; at least not for 2,000 years or so. Israel at ten is a product of a complex past. Her fathers were harried through the ghettos of Warsaw and Kiev, Casablanca and Baghdad.
Eight Americans who have reached positions of prominence from humble beginnings will receive Horatio Alger Awards for 1958.

Law groups in New York City will join with others over the country Thursday in the observance of Law Day -- U.S.A. In proclaiming Law Day, President Eisenhower called on the nation to rededicate itself to the rule of law.

WITH an Angel disk of the Brahms Symphony No. 4, Otto Klemperer and the Philharmonia Orchestra bring to a conclusion their recording of the four Brahms symphonies. It is, with one reservation about the E minor Symphony, a triumphant undertaking.

THESE few words, of unknown origin, are familiar to thousands of saltwater men. They do not constitute a prayer to be spoken in fear, or even a supplication. They come nearer to being a resolute statement of the terms of a fair contest. The sea is great and the ship may be small, but a sailor knows the odds are not impossibly against him; otherwise he would never go to sea.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- Richard H. G. Bonnycastle of Winnipeg was re-elected president of Ducks Unlimited (Canada) at the twenty-first annual meeting of the Canadian affiliate of Ducks Unlimited today.

LONDON, April 25 (Reuters) -- A British-Pakistani Himalayan expedition got under way today with the departure of its members for a three-month survey of the effects of high altitudes on men.

DALLAS, April 26 (UP) -Heavy rain and hail fell on Texas today, sending the Trinity River surging out of its banks. Flash floods raced through Dallas.

WHAT is a "directorial touch?" This long has been one of the more contentious mysteries associated with moviemaking. When critics, in commenting on some visually intriguing expositions of dramatizing, describe them as directorial touches, writers are quick to respond with a loud Bronx cheer.

A "Moonlight on the Hudson" cruise the evening of June 12 will benefit the Graham School, Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y. Founded in 1806, the school was originally known as the Orphan Asylum Society in the City of New York.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 26 -- The Brussels World's Fair of 1958 is still in its infancy, having run only ten of its 185 days of treaty-fixed life. But although it will continue to grow -- it is still not entirely finished -- its character and personality seem already well formed.
HONG KONG, April 26 -Evidence accumulating here indicates 1958 has become a year of absolute maximum production effort in Communist China.
Sales of more than $40,000,000 in a little more than a year -- that is the story of the National Cash Register Company's electronic bank posting machine.
LOUISVILLE, April 26 -- Belleau Chief won the Stepping Stone as Churchill Downs opened today, but Silky Sullivan stole the show with a late rush that thrilled the crowd of 20,000 fans.

Sceptre, the yacht with which the British will try to win the America's Cup late next September, has a deck plan that is different from any Twelve Meter within memory. There are two cockpits instead of the usual one.

CAIRO, April 26 -- Top-ranking officials in Cairo expressed confidence today that an imminent settlement of the Suez Canal compensation question would pave the way for early resumption of financial and trade relations with Britain and France.

The $1.8 billion increase in Federal highway construction assistance having now been approved, and anticipating some form of Federal loan program for local public works also as an anti-recession measure, it seems wise to extend a word of caution to the mayors, city councils, budget directors and county commissioners of the United States.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 26 -King Paul and Queen Frederika of Greece arrived here on the cruiser Helli today for a four-day state visit. They were accompanied by Princess Sophia and several Greek Government and military officials.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 26 -- "Continuing retrenchment in business investment" was cited by an economist today as the core of the recession.

AN amiable young Londoner temporarily disillusioned with the practice of the law, Chris Brandon was searching for a rural retreat, and when he came upon the old Round House at Compton Only he knew it for his future home.

CLEVELAND, April 26 -- The demand for cargo vessels on the Great Lakes will be much lighter than customary this season, but freight rates for the transportation of iron ore and coal will be the same as those in effect at the close of the 1957 season.
World tanker owners have deferred for at least a year plans to form an international shipping pool designed to enable operators to ride out a slump in freight rates.
Adlai Stevenson's article is a penetrating analysis of our education problems.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., April 26 -- Malcolm Cowley, author and critic, defended American literature against its detractors in an address here today.

TO use a phrase that George Jean Nathan once applied to a friend, the Great Bookkeeper has closed the account. George died on April 8 at the age of 76, after fifty years as a critic and two years of failing health.

Ground will be broken tomorrow for a five-story classroom and library building for Barnard College -- the first new building on the campus since 1925. It will be named Adele Lehman Hall and the Wollman Library.

FORWARD on Page 1 this morning is a review of "Land Without Justice," second of the Milovan Djilas books. In the trade it is spoken of as "the literary one." as opposed to "the political one," or "The New Class." Like the predecessor, its arrival has been bathed in rumors of cloak-and-dagger.
JERSEY CITY, April 26 -- Long litigation is expected from the dismissal this week of the Pennsylvania Railroad's claim of discrimination on Jersey City tax assessments.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -The Civil Rights Commission agreed today to appoint local advisory committees in all forty-eight states.

WITH Khrushchev's recent power-grab arises new speculation, not very optimistic, upon the outlook for Soviet policy in the arts. Of late there had been a growing confidence among the Russian intelligentsia, illustrated by the appearance in literature of such things as Dudintsev's "Not by Bread Alone" and Pasternak's "Doctor Zhivago."

THERE'S a story, some say, in every family. All it needs is someone to recognize it and set it down. That isn't always true, because a good part of any story is in the writer, the viewpoint, the understanding, the sense of drama.

An alarming drop-out rate among college students was disclosed in a recent report issued by the United States Office of Education. It showed that more than one of four students quit college before the beginning of the second year and a slightly higher percentage drop out over the following three years.

As a veteran of the recent odyssey of "Porgy and Bess" through twenty-nine countries on five continents, I especially appreciated Mr. Taubman pointing out that American productions overseas, even when under the aegis of the State Department, have to earn their own way at the box office.

DICKENS was the first major novelist to aim at a mass market. Most of his books came out in monthly parts, at a shilling a number. The method had the advantage of closer relations with the readers. If newsstand sales slumped, it meant that the story needed pepping up, and this -- since the author was seldom more than one number ahead of the printer -- was fairly simple, especially in the earlier books.
Repeal of wartime transportation taxes has been urged by the executive committee of the National Defense Transportation Association.

THIS new novel by Anand Lall of life in India is altogether charming and fascinating. For an American reader whose first-hand experience of that land is slight, it rings exceptionally true because of the subtle mixture of Indian and Western values and activities.

MANY, strange and diverse have been the criticisms leveled at modern art. These criticisms have come from outraged conservatives on traditional esthetic grounds and from totalitarian regimes because modern art does not suit their propaganda purposes.

THOUGH concrete is usually unaffected by the elements, a rigorous winter such as the one just passed may disclose cracked or crumbled sections which need patching or replacing. A checkup is required on concrete walks, driveways, basement foundations and walls.

BONN, Germany, April 26 -The United States recession has had no visible repercussions on West Germany's economy, which continued to expand at an annual rate of 7 per cent in the first quarter of this year.

Five bystanders were hospitalized as a result of a shabbily dressed man's flight from the police last night. He was captured in Grand Central Terminal at 6:30 P. M. after knocking one of the victims down a flight of stairs.
The Maritime Association of the Port of New York reports it is entering its eighty-sixth year in "sound" financial condition.
The piano playing of Joseph Wolman yesterday afternoon in the Carnegie Recital Hall was a solid pleasure of a kind that is all too rare.

ALTHOUGH Brock Chisholm, a physician long active in the field of public health, marshals more than merely impressive evidence to the contrary, he is convinced that people can "learn to learn," that they can come to know and appreciate each other.
OTTAWA, April 26 -- Broadening of foreign trade was at the forefront of Canadian attention this week.
LONDON, April 26 (Reuters) -- Clyde slammed home a firsthalf goal today to beat Hibernian. 1 -- 0, at Glasgow and win its second Scottish Football Association Cup in four years.

NATURAL opposites who had somehow become sworn enemies in the struggle for success, Robert Lamb and Ned Roper bestrode the narrow, smoky world of Britain's pottery towns like warring colossi. At least, that was how they seemed to the easy-going, impressionable narrator, Joe, who had watched them maneuvering for position from their school days, when "the rat-race of adolescence quickens its pace, and boys begin to see life in competitive terms."

COCOA BEACH, Fla., April 26 -- The nose cone of Sputnik II, the dog-bearing Soviet satellite, has been reported to have been made of a ceramic containing cobalt, suggesting that it may have been intended for recovery.

A NEW airline begins a new Bermuda-New York service this Thursday. The carrier is Eagle Airways of Bermuda, Ltd., and it will offer daily flights in each direction beginning on Saturday. On Thursday there will be an initial flight from Bermuda, then a New York to Bermuda flight on Friday, with daily service both ways thereafter.
The menu has been decided upon, the seating arrangements made, the entertainers rehearsed and the prefatory parties planned for the Spring Dance of the Boys Club of New York.

Events since the budget came up for decision appear to favor the Chancellor's judgment of necessity. His "half-a-loaf" concession on the cinema tax brought some groans of disappointment from those who had argued long and loud that only total abolition of the u30,000,000 [$84,000,000] annual impost could save the film industry.
BARI, Italy, April 25 -- The people of this city say that if Paris had the sea it would be a small Bari.

THINKING of pogonotrophy, which many Americans do during their vacations, daring men about to grow beards can draw courage from the reply sent to a bright young advertising dreamer by George Bernard Shaw. The former had enclosed his company's latest electric razor for the latter's famous beard.

KANSAS CITY, April 26 -(UP) -- Elevator shoes used by a Russian to top the world record in the high jump and tried by at least one United States collegian, were banned today by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

DETROIT, April 26 -- The automobile industry has revolutionized the nation's economy. It has thrust city boundaries outward and eliminated rural isolation. It has given independence of movement and added pleasure to 80,00,000 licensed drivers and their families.
MADISON, Wis., April 24 -The Democratic party of Wisconsin is riding on a wave of optimism from which it sees dazzling prospects in the November elections.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- As the capital debates the course of the recession, and specifically the question of a tax cut, questions are being raised as to the machinery by which the Administration reaches economic decisions, and the coordination among its various elements.
The busiest three-month peacetime period in the annals of shipbuilding has brought new ship construction at world shipyards over the 10,000,000-gross ton mark for the first time.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 26 -- The Government today warned public employes on strike that they must go back to work by Monday or it would take "other measures" to maintain the public services.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 26 -- The Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern) took a major step here today toward the liberalization of its traditional stand on the remarriage of divorced persons.

RIVERDALE, N. D. -- Motorists crossing the arid flatlands of the upper Plains States this summer should take along bathing suits and fishing tackle. The northern route to the Badlands, Yellowstone or the Pacific Northwest is no longer an ordeal of unrelieved dusty desertland.

THE New York apartment shown here may point the way to a new decorating trend -- styles from the turn of the century. These include garden rooms with wicker and ceramic furniture (below left), patterns of the Middle East and bear skin rugs (below), and the Eighteen Nineties' Art Nouveau (right).

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The broad powers which the framers of the Constitution gave the Federal Government to conduct foreign policy, wage war and maintain internal security are once more being weighed by the Supreme Court against the competing constitutional guarantees of individual liberty.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., April 26 -- Fordham University's varsity eight coasted to a six-length victory over George Washington University today, with St. John's University another six lengths back, over a mile course off Travers Island.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 26 -- The Government is considered likely to abolish within the next few years all three Parliamentary seats for representatives of Africans.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- The Twentieth Century Limited completed today its last New York-to-Chicago run of the winter season. It arrived 4 hours 23 minutes late, having been derailed in Syracuse, N. Y.

The sun and the stars produce their light by slow thermonuclear reactions similar to those that take place at a violent rate in the explosion of the hydrogen bomb. In these reactions the nuclei of lighter elements are fused into heavier ones under the influence of tremendous temperatures and pressures, the fusion resulting in the conversion of part of the mass of the lighter elements into energy.
Nelson A. Rockefeller painted a bright picture here last night of the nation's economic, social and human rights prospects in the next decade.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 26 -- In the eyes of South Americans, Mr. Nixon's trip will be a highlight of what is hopefully seen here as the beginning of a new United States policy of greater interest in their lands.

THE United Nations Statistical Yearbook, a 675page compendium covering everything from soybean production to illiteracy rates, offers a comprehensive picture of world tourism to anyone who is not totally allergic to columns of figures.

NEW York State's first major venture in educational television at long last is ready to begin. Governor Harriman last week signed the bill authorizing an expenditure of $600,000 for daytime telecasts over Channel 9, effective Sept. 1.
PALMA, Majorca -- With the arrival of spring, the great tourist air-lift began bridging the skies once again, converging from all over Europe onto this sunny vacation island.
An ex-president of Chicago's Pabst Brewing Company, whose name figured prominently in the recent proxy fight there, is back in New York selling cleanser instead of suds.
Thursday's performance of "The Firstborn" will benefit the Rehearsal Club. The play, starring Katharine Cornell, opens on Tuesday at the Coronet.

Crime figures for New York State for March showed a seasonal increase of 13.2 per cent in arrests over the February total. But the March figures of 4.096 arrests for major crimes was 4 per cent less than in March, 1957.

HERBERT HOOVER is 83 years old, an indomitable old man convalescing from a major operation. An elder statesman whose retirement has been many times as busy as most men's years of full employment, he has been an ex-President for twenty-five years and an author of books for forty-eight.
LONDON, April 27 -- The stock markets finished last week in a good mood.
RAMONA FINE, a parrot living on the first floor of a ramshackle brownstone at 149 West Twenty-first Street, would drop her tail feathers if she knew what was going on upstairs.

Young Mr. Nixon, who seems almost as tireless as elderly Mr. Dulles, has taken wing again, this time to attend the inauguration of Dr. Arturo Frondizi, Argentina's first democratically elected President since 1938. The Vice President took some expert advisers on LatinAmerican problems along with him and will drop in at seven capitals besides Buenos Aires.
LONDON, April 27 -- Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd said today Britain could not draw a distinction between nuclear and conventional war from the point of view of survival.

PARIS, April 27 -- Former Premier Rene Pleven sought today to enlist the support of French political leaders for a new declaration of intentions on which his Algerian policy would be based if he formed a Cabinet. He said he was encouraged by the reactions he had elicited.
Sterner resistance to low rates by vessel owners last week forced a rise in the steamship charter market index. However, little activity was reported at the slightly improved rates.
NEWARK, April 27 -- A 10year-old girl was paralyzed and in critical condition today after being struck in the spine by a bullet fired accidentally by a neighbor, an off-duty policeman.
The Christian attitude toward human misery is a sense of sharing and not one "simply of relieving," the Rev. Francis X. Duffy said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- The Strategic Air Command's "fail safe" system to prevent accidental triggering of nuclear warfare apparently requires United States bombers to turn back about two hours' flying time this side of Soviet territory.

DUBLIN, April 27 (AP) -Mayor Robert Wagner of New York attended mass in Dublin's procathedral today and later made a trip around the city visiting friends. Mr. and Mrs. Wagner arrived at Limerick yesterday on the inaugural trans-Atlantic flight of the Irish Airlines.
An investigation of a disturbance Saturday night at the Women's House of Detention was started yesterday.
Blue and gold flags of the Greater New York Fund are making their appearance today in midtown and on principal buildings. They have come to be known as harbingers of real spring.

BALTIMORE, April 27 -- As rain wiped out today's scheduled double-header between the Yankees and the Orioles, Casey Stengel, who only a few days ago thought he had only smooth sailing ahead, suddenly found his immediate plans well scrambled.
CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- Every grain and soybean future on the Board of Trade finished last week on the minus side.

The Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission made a new effort yesterday to convince New Jerseyans that they would not be saddled with a "package deal" under the proposed commuter rail compact with New York.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Secretary of State Dulles is back in the Capital masterminding the negotiations with the Soviet Union, and the interesting thing about it is that he is taking a more sympathetic attitude toward seeking a reliable accommodation with Moscow than many of his associates.
THREE new singers were in the cast when Vittorio Giannini's "The Taming of the Shrew" had its third performance at the City Center yesterday afternoon.
AMSTERDAM, April 27-- The Dutch trade gap narrowed considerably during March.
An international conference of Soviet specialists that met last week-end found a significant source of tension in Soviet society in a new type of "class struggle."

NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 27 (Reuters) -- About 5,000 Turkish Cypriotes decided at a meeting today to form separate Turkish municipalities in the island's main towns and to pay no more taxes to Greek Cypriote councils.
PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -The quick action of a resident surgeon today prolonged the life of a wounded policeman thought at first to be dead.

THE Saturday Consort, a delightful group of specialists in renaissance and baroque music, who gave their first public program here two years ago, made its last appearance on the stage of Town Hall yesterday afternoon.
Houston, Tex., is planning the sale of bond issues totaling $15,600,000 on May 21.
CHARLES TREGER, violinist, played a sonata program late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall.
The Grand Union Company realized a 15 per cent increase in earnings during the fifty-two weeks .ended March 1 on a sales gain of 14.4 per cent over the previous fiscal year.

Irving Maidman, realty investor and builder specializing in investments on the West Side, has leased the two-story building on plot 50 by 100 feet at 416-18 West Forty-second Street for twenty-one years.
GENEVA, April 27 -- The United Nations conference on maritime law adopted today an article that in effect upholds Israeli shipping rights in the Strait of Tiran and the Gulf of Aqaba.

A broad $5,500,000 land reclamation project is being planned by the city in the Idlewild section of Queens to provide 264 acres of new parks.

LOS ANGELES, April 27 (UP) -- Johnny Podres scored his third victory of the season today. He scattered ten hits to give the Dodgers a 10-3 decision over the St. Louis Cardinals and their first series triumph of the year.

BUENOS AIRES, April 27 -- The Argentine auto industry, like its American counterpart, is suffering from economic chills. The industry here consists entirely of a jeep and jeep station wagon plant that Henry J. Kaiser, United States industrialist, conceived three years ago when Juan D. Peron was in power.

WARSAW, April 27 -- Poland's Communists appear to have buried their differences with the Soviet Union in the face of what is viewed as the danger to both countries from a West Germany armed with nuclear weapons.
The American Smelting and Refining Company (Asarco) said today it probably would be forced to close two domestic lead smelters and one lead refinery if quotas on lead and zinc imports were imposed.

After fluctuating within a narrow range early last week, cotton prices weakened to close in lower ground. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses at the close Friday of 5 to 38 points (25 cents to $1.90 a bale).

SAN JUAN, P. R., April 27 -- Only once before have Puerto Ricans had as large a symphony orchestra on the island as the one that is assembled here for the second Casals Festival. That was when the New Orleans Philharmonic stopped here for a single night two years ago.

MILWAUKEE, April 27 (UP) -- Jack Sanford's five-hit pitching and a twelve-hit attack by the Philadelphia Phillies, including Richie Ashburn's first home run in two years, combined today to defeat the Milwaukee Braves, 6 -- 2.

"Second-Rate Brains," a critique of the present status of American education as a foundation for United States world leadership, will be published as a paper-bound Doubleday News Book on Thursday. The book has been edited by Kermit Lansner, a general editor of Newsweek, who also wrote a running commentary to its fifteen articles.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., April 27 -- Tony Ziluca, 28-year-old fleet captain of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, became the dinghy champion of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound today.

OOSTERBEEK, Holland, April 27 -- A fault of United States policy in the Arab world is that we have tended to deal with men outdated by events. Too many of our compacts are with leaders who represent the past more than the future. Our prestige suffers when those whom we back decline in power.
The Fire Department will put into service tomorrow a fast, equipment-packed fireboat tender, the Smoke II.

New York City's famous redcarpet treatment has seldom been given to a more worthy person than Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold. As Mayor Wagner and others repeatedly stated, he is the world's most eminent civil servant --unique in that he serves more than eighty countries and is generally recognized as the "foremost diplomat of the world."
College students who in debates earlier in the week were taking both sides of the question of "right-to-work" laws had a chance yesterday to express their own opinions of them.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 -- Dr. Billy Graham, the evengelist, opened his long-heralded San Francisco area crusade today before an overflow gathering in the Cow Palace.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -The chairman of a panel studying research problems for the Air Force sharply criticized today one of the main objectives of President Eisenhower's defense reorganization and space development plans.
DUBLIN, April 27 -- The de Valera Government is mounting a double-pronged offensive on its economic problems. The campaign involves Shannon Airport and the country's important aviation industry.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, said today that the nation's military leaders had "pulled bombs out of the stockpile and inserted something that makes them dirtier."

The Friends of the Greek Village will benefit from the eighth annual benefit ball to be held May 8 at the St. Regis Roof. The Village is a charity of the King's Fund of His Majesty King Paul of Greece.

PITTSBURGH, April 27 -- When the steel order statistics are in later this week, they should show April sales about equal to those for March. The latest view holds that May order volume should be slightly higher than the total for this month.

LONDON, April 27 (UP) -- Premier Khrushchev has accused the Western Ambassadors in Moscow of trying to dictate to the Soviet Union in pre-summit negotiations, the Soviet news agency Tass reported today. He made the charge in a speech in Kiev yesterday.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27 -- Bette Davis will appear for the first time since 1951 in a movie made outside the United States, when she assumes the role of Catherine the Great in "John Paul Jones."

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The National Academy of Sciences announced today that seven scientists will receive medals tomorrow night in restanding achievements in research.
All persons in New York State will be ordered to seek shelter for ten minutes Tuesday morning, May 6, as part of the national civil defense training exercise Operation Alert 1958.
GENEVA, Monday, April 28 (AP) -- The sea-law conference ended early today. Five treaties were adopted during the nine--week meeting.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 27 (AP)--Canada's Stan Leonard cashed in for his richest golf victory today when he won the $10,000 Tournament of Champions and the $10,000 first prize.
The American Bankers Association has decided against undertaking a national advertising program. The decision followed a poll among the group's 13,884 member banks.
The president of a branch of the Egyptian Crowns gang was charged last night with the shotgun murder of Michael Ramos, a member of three rival youth gangs.
